title: They Knew What They Wanted
description: A writing table anchors a home built on a grandfathers tragic legacy.

title: Industrial Sleek
description: Building a modern loft in Portland, Ore., suffused with local character and treasured flaws.

title: The Imperfectionists
description: For Joan Childs, southeast Portland, Ore., is the model New Urbanist neighborhood: mixed-income and mixed-use, with small-scale streets. I almost cried realizing I was home,  she said, recalling her first tour of the area after moving there.

title: A Simple Gift
description: This story begins with a wooden table. My grandfather Sidney Howard, a playwright and screenwriter, needed a new desk and hired a local carpenter to make one for him. The dimensions, four feet wide and seven feet long, were odd but practical: The large surface was perfect for laying out pages and scenes after he finished typing them.

title: Standouts in Tech: Drones, Virtual Reality, Instant Translation and A.I.
description: LOTS of cool new technology products come out every year, but usually only a few stand out. These few, though, are often mind-bending  they alter your perspective of whats possible in the future. There were four such technologies for me in 2014:

title: Barbecue Chains Original Link, in Unlikely Spot, Is No More
description: It was an exercise in contrast, a tableau of multimillion-dollar apartments, sticky barbecue sauce and lemon-scented towelettes.

title: Edward Herrmann, Actor With a Noble Air, Dies at 71
description: Edward Herrmann, a stalwart American actor of patrician bearing and earnest elocutionary style who became familiar across a spectrum of popular entertainment, from movies and television shows to plays, audiobooks and advertisements, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 71.

title: Canada Holds Off U.S. in Preliminary Junior Championship Game
description: MONTREAL  Led by a line of Sam Reinhart, Max Domi and Anthony Duclair, Canada outlasted the United States, 5-3, on Wednesday in their final game of group play at the World Junior Championship at Bell Centre.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the editor:

title: Exit Alarms in the Subways Are Silenced by the M.T.A.
description: The aural offenses of the New York City subway are legion. Trains screech. Announcements drone on. Panhandlers performances lurch off key.

title: The First Pop Quiz of 2015
description: Ready to take the challenge to see how much you remember from 2014? No cheating and Googling for answers!

title: Cuomo, Using Pardon Power, Gives Pair a Second Chance
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Wednesday that he had pardoned two men, saying that each deserved a second chance without fear of being separated from their families through deportation.

title: Doug Marrone Quits Bills and Is Said to Draw Jets Interest
description: Doug Marrone opted out of his contract as coach of the Buffalo Bills on Wednesday, and he has drawn interest from the Jets, a person familiar with the teams thinking said. The Jets are likely to schedule an interview with Marrone, a Bronx native who served as the teams offensive line coach for four seasons under Herman Edwards.

title: Social Programs That Work
description: WASHINGTON  HARDLY anyone knows it, but since its earliest days the Obama administration has been pursuing the most important initiative in the history of federal attempts to use evidence to improve social programs.

title: Hens, Unbound
description: The most significant animal welfare law in recent history  Californias Prop 2  takes effect today. The measure, which passed by a landslide vote in 2008, requires egg and some meat producers to confine their animals in far more humane conditions than they did before. No longer will baby calves (veal) or gestational pigs be kept in crates so small they cannot turn around and, perhaps more significantly, egg-laying hens may not be held in battery cages that prevent them from spreading their wings.

title: Much of David Dukes 91 Campaign Is Now in Louisiana Mainstream
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  David Duke seems a figure from the past, the former Klansman and white supremacist who two decades ago was almost elected Louisiana governor.

title: With Schoolgirls Taken by Boko Haram Still Missing, U.S.-Nigeria Ties Falter
description: STUTTGART, Germany  Soon after the Islamist group Boko Haram kidnapped nearly 300 teenage girls in Nigeria in April, the United States sent surveillance drones and about 30 intelligence and security experts to help the Nigerian military try to rescue them. Gen. David M. Rodriguez, the top general for American missions in Africa, rushed from his headquarters here to help the commanders in the crisis.

title: Arrest Statistics Decline Sharply; Police Unions Deny an Organized Slowdown
description: Word from police officials came quickly: The targeted killings of two New York City police officers meant that officers on foot patrols must walk only in pairs, and uniformed sentries would now guard each precinct station house.

title: When Airplanes Go Missing
description: For the second time this year, a passenger plane has vanished midflight. In March, Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 disappeared and the most expensive search mission in recent aviation history followed. It is still missing.

title: Sugar Bowl 2015: Alabama vs. Ohio State Preview
description: SUGAR BOWL

title: Florida State vs. Oregon: Rose Bowl Preview
description: ROSE BOWL

title: A Guide to Minimum Wage Increases at the State Level
description: By Jan. 1, 29 states and the District of Columbia will have minimum wages above the federal minimum wage of $7.25.

title: States Minimum Wages Rise, Helping Millions of Workers
description: For some low-wage workers, everyday tasks like spending money for bus fare to get to and from work also involve deciding which bill to pay or delay, or what to give up.

title: In Foiling Gmail, China Foils Itself
description: Back at the turn of the century, when China began trying to crack down on the Internet, Bill Clinton said, Good luck. Thats sort of like trying to nail Jell-O to the wall.

title: Before Ball Drops, the Knicks Continue Their Own Descent
description: LOS ANGELES  As 2015 begins, a handful of Knicks, including Shane Larkin, Cleanthony Early and Quincy Acy, have vowed to lead cleaner, healthier lives. They have resolved to no longer eat pork.

title: The Palestinians Desperation Move
description: In some ways, the decision by President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority to force a losing vote on Palestinian statehood at the United Nations Security Council on Tuesday and then sign papers to join the International Criminal Court on Wednesday was not surprising.

title: Euro and Immigration Promise Challenges for Merkel in 2015
description: BERLIN  Although she is still popular at home and respected abroad, Chancellor Angela Merkel is entering 2015 facing fresh challenges in both arenas.

title: New C.D.C. Job Overseeing Laboratory Safety
description: A new job title  chief of laboratory safety  will be created at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the agency said Wednesday. The move follows a series of lab accidents, the most recent of which may have exposed a scientist to the Ebola virus. Applicants are being recruited, and a spokeswoman said that whoever filled the post would report directly to the C.D.C.'s director, currently Dr. Thomas R. Frieden. Each of the agencys divisions had handled lab safety separately. In the past year, different high-security C.D.C. labs shipped out samples of anthrax, H5N1 bird flu and Ebola that had not been properly killed. Thus far, there have been no injuries and no spread of the pathogens, but the agencys procedures have been heavily criticized as sloppy.

title: Massachusetts: New Effort to Move Bombings Trial
description: Lawyers for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the defendant in the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, made a last-ditch effort late Wednesday to move the trial out of Boston. In a 32-page filing, they asked a federal appeals court to grant a change of venue, or at a minimum to order the trial judge, George A. OToole Jr., to hold a hearing on moving the trial. They also asked Judge OToole to delay the start of jury selection, which is scheduled for Monday, while the appeals court considers its request. Judge OToole has twice denied the request, most recently earlier Wednesday, saying the jury selection process could find impartial jurors. But Mr. Tsarnaevs lawyers insisted that would be impossible, arguing that virtually everyone in the Boston region has a connection to the marathon and is, in effect, an actual victim. Government prosecutors have until 5 p.m. Thursday to respond.

title: Ben Ammi Ben-Israel Dies at 75: Led Black Americans in Migration to Israel
description: Ben Ammi Ben-Israel, a former Chicago metal worker who led a migration of hundreds of fellow black Americans to what they consider their ancestral homeland, Israel, died on Saturday in a hospital in Beersheba, Israel. He was 75.

title: Mission Ends in Afghanistan, but Sacrifices Are Not Over for U.S. Soldiers
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  Sgt. First Class Ramon Morris, a muscular dynamo and a father on his fifth deployment, was killed Dec. 12 in a roadside bombing in Afghanistan.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 31, 2014
Central Park, After Hours
description: Its not yet 4 a.m. and Im out walking at a healthy clip. The moon is bright. In the distance, a subway train toots its horn, breaking the silence. A pair of ducks waddle through the mist across my path. Rounding the bend, I detect movement among the trees and notice a shadow lurching. I quicken my step, but then stop to see two large raccoons locked in a mating embrace. They give me a startled stare but then get back to business.

title: Depiction of Lyndon B. Johnson in Selma Raises Hackles
description: Was Lyndon B. Johnson a civil rights mastermind, or a reluctant follower pulled along by activists led by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.?

title: Anti-Putin Protest Fizzles as Police Sweep Square
description: MOSCOW  In the end, Russias white ribbon opposition, which roared to life in December 2011 hoping to oust Vladimir V. Putin from power, came down to this: not quite two dozen stalwarts huddled all night inside an oversize Christmas tree ornament just outside the Kremlin walls, awaiting inevitable arrest. By morning, it came.

title: Stanford Women and Silicon Valley
description: To the Editor:

title: Dozens Are Killed in Stampede in Shanghai
description: HONG KONG  At least 36 people were killed and 47 injured in a stampede during New Years Eve celebrations in Shanghai, the citys government reported.

title: On Brooklyn Campus, Annual Antique Display Goes Out With a Terrifying Wail
description: Among the New Yorkers preparing for New Years Eve festivities on Wednesday afternoon  like a young woman applying eye shadow on the G train, or the thousands of revelers who had already turned Times Square into a no-walk zone  were a few whose arrangements could be heard a Brooklyn neighborhood away.

title: Average
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  Happy New Year! I hope everyone is enjoying welcoming in Baby New Year in the most pleasant way possible. Mine is relatively quiet: It will involve lots of food and binge-watching the BBC America Doctor Who marathon with my nearest and dearest, which is just right after all the noise of 2014. Many thanks to the unbelievably dapper Tom Gaffney for holding the fort while I was away.

title: Cuba Arrests Dissidents 2 Weeks After U.S. Accord
description: MEXICO CITY  A performance artist who was arrested Tuesday, along with several dissidents and journalists, after she sought to test change in Cuba and promote free speech by setting up an open mike in Havanas Revolution Square was briefly detained again on Wednesday and told she could not leave the country for several weeks.

title: The New Year Around the World
description: Celebrations, with light shows, fireworks and even a camel ride, ushered in 2015.

title: Whereabouts of U.S. Spy Released in Cuba Deal Are Unknown
description: MIAMI  Two weeks after the release of an imprisoned spy whom President Obama called one of the most important intelligence agents the United States has ever had in Cuba, the mans family is still asking: Where is he?

title: After Several False Starts, Finding a Career Path
description: All Julio Olmedo needed was five years. That would be enough time to find a job in the United States, build his savings and then return to Mexico with enough money to start his own produce business.

title: Look Back to Move Forward
description: The second of the two police officers ambushed and gunned down in Brooklyn by Ismaaiyl Brinsley will be laid to rest Sunday.

title: College Football Playoff May Be a Boon, or Just a Pandoras Box
description: PASADENA, Calif.  This is what we wanted.

title: North Korean Leader Says Hes Open to Summit With South
description: TOKYO  In a nationally televised New Years speech, the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, said Thursday that he was open to holding a summit meeting with the South Korean president, proclaiming his willingness to make a big shift in the tensions on the Korean Peninsula.

title: The New Year Around the World
description: Celebrations, with light shows, fireworks and even a camel ride, ushered in 2015.

title: Queens Man Is Charged With Murdering 4-Month-Old Son
description: A Queens man who was accused of beating his 4-month-old son was rearrested and charged with murder on Wednesday, one week after the infant died from his injuries, the authorities said.

title: Five Surprising Economic Trends in 2014, and What They Mean for 2015
description: It was a confounding year in global financial markets. Not because it was a disaster for most investors; American stocks and bonds both rose in value. It was confounding because of some major moves that defied expert consensus this time a year ago  not only what was predicted, but what was even thought plausible.

title: Whats on TV Thursday
description: 11 A.M. (HGTV) ROSE PARADE 2015 The new year is once again coming up roses for HGTV, which heralds 2015 from its traditional perch at this 126th annual parade. Louis Zamperini, the Olympic runner turned World War II bombardier of Unbroken fame, who died in July, will be honored as the grand marshal as nearly 40 floats inch their way down Colorado Boulevard in Pasadena, Calif. The floats, adorned with more botanical elements than the average florist might go through in year, are based on inspirational stories. The Property Brothers  Drew and Jonathan Scott  and Nancy ODell will provide play-by-play. (The parade will also be broadcast on ABC, NBC and the Hallmark Channel. The University of Oregon will take on Florida State in the Rose Bowl game at 5 p.m. on ESPN.) The HGTV programming moves into prime time at 8 with a tour of the latest Dream Home giveaway: a 3,200-square-foot, three-bedroom Cape Cod-style vacation house on Marthas Vineyard. The property includes soaring ceilings, patios off each sleeping area, a bike rack and a doggy dream home. The winner also gets furnishings from Ethan Allen, a GMC Acadia Denali and $250,000.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: They had forgotten. We had to call to remind them. The whole country has forgotten. People dont realize we still have troops risking their lives out there.

title: Corrections: January 1, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: The New Year Around the World
description: Celebrations, with light shows, fireworks and even a camel ride, ushered in 2015.

title: China-Japan Dispute Over Islands Spreads to Cyberspace
description: In a new effort to bolster its claim to disputed islands in the East China Sea, the Chinese government has endowed the isles with a website under their Chinese name, www.diaoyudao.org.cn, for the Diaoyu Islands. Japan, which also claims sovereignty, calls them the Senkaku.

title: Rough Seas Halt Search forAirAsia Jet; Data Recorders Are Still Missing
description: SURABAYA, Indonesia  The search for remnants of the AirAsia jet that crashed in the Java Sea turned up little on Thursday, and an Indonesian official said finding the plane could take another week, but more bodies were reported to have been found on Friday.

title: Three Al Jazeera Journalists Remain in Jail After Egyptian Court Orders a Retrial
description: CAIRO  Egypts highest appeals court on Thursday ordered a retrial for three imprisoned journalists from Al Jazeeras English-language service, implicitly acknowledging critical procedural flaws in a case that rights advocates have described, from the mens arrests to their convictions, as a sham.

title: Carmakers Take a Hint From Tablets
description: Reaching an apogee of confusion, car dashboards have become a bewildering array of screens, buttons and knobs to control functions like the radio, ventilation, advanced safety systems and Internet services.

title: Finding the Bus With the Backpack
description: Dear Diary:

title: Writers Are Mixed Over Amazon Unlimited
description: Amazon is disruptive, which means it is divisive. So inevitably the retailers new all-you-can-read venture, Kindle Unlimited, is the subject of heated debate, pro and con, among self-published writers.

title: In Moments, New Years Revelry Became Fatal Crush in Shanghai
description: SHANGHAI  With a dazzling light show set to begin at midnight, a huge crowd of revelers had gathered for an outdoor New Years Eve in this citys historic riverfront district. They began to grow unruly.

title: Inside the Motorbass studio
description: The music producer Philippe Zdar and his Paris-based studio Motorbass are benefiting from a renewed interest in the French Touch sound.

title: Turning the Garden Into a House Party
description: Minutes before midnight on New Years Eve at Madison Square Garden, the dance party paused for a video montage. As a look back on the year that was, it was a bit random, mixing hints of hellishness with small victories: Robin Williamss death, Ebola and Ferguson, Mo., but also Derek Jeters farewell to Yankee Stadium, a goal by Clint Dempsey in the World Cup and footage from Burning Man of the nights headlining D.J.s, Diplo and Skrillex.

title: Soy
description: A Japanese comfort food spot on the Lower East Side.

title: Make Yourself at Home
description: The first time I stepped into Soy, I almost turned around and stepped out.

title: Your Next Lesson: St.-Joseph
description: I tend not to think of wines seasonally. The convention of reds in cold weather, and whites and ross in warm, doesnt make much sense to me, as food dictates the choice of a wine more than the temperature. Yet certain exceptions present themselves: namely, the red wines of the northern Rhne Valley of France, which I seem to crave especially in the fall and winter.

title: Days of Remembrance
description: TIMES INSIDER  Happy New Year! Baby, its cold outside, and a person could develop cabin fever during a month like January. The holidays are over and the decorations have hopefully been put away. Or if they havent, no worries; we dont judge. But we need something to keep us occupied until the spring thaw.

title: 1940: Paris Celebrates New Year
description: Paris forgot the war and its black-out and the other entire minor inconveniences of a nation in arms Sunday night to enjoy the best New Years Eve in twenty years, as one old timer described the evenings festivities.

title: Unashamedly Maturing Into Her Role
description: LOS ANGELES  When Patricia Arquette was 19, spirited, rebellious, and juggling auditions between waitressing and a job at Planned Parenthood, she learned that she was pregnant by her punk rock boyfriend, whom she was living with here.

title: Ten Tips for Happiness, on a Postcard From the Past
description: When Michelle Grewe was going through some boxes in her grandfathers house, she found a cache of writing by her grandmother, Eleanor Virginia Webster. Among other things, shed written out her Ten Tips to Happiness on a series of 20 postcards, sometime during the war in Vietnam. No one in her family had seen the postcards, or realized that Eleanor, who died in 1998, was a closet writer. Michelle and I both thought all of you young people would appreciate her grandmothers words.  KJ DellAntonia

title: The Most Popular Upshot Articles of 2014
description: We thought you might like to see the most popular articles and graphics among The Upshots readers in 2014. These are the most popular articles as ranked by the number of times they were viewed.

title: Shelling Strikes Afghan Wedding Party, Killing at Least 25 Civilians
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  At least 25 civilians were believed to have died in southern Afghanistan after shelling amid fierce fighting struck a wedding party, Afghan officials said Thursday.

title: Where Big Stars and Space Heaters Mix
description: This obviously isnt for money or glory, so come and do it if you want.

title: Upshot Highlights, 2014
description: You may have read the list of the articles that the readers of The Upshot liked the most. This is the list of Upshot features that the writers, photo editors and graphics editors most liked doing for you:

title: New York Citys Pedestrian Fatalities Lowest on Record in 2014
description: Pedestrian deaths in New York City fell to a historic low last year after a push by the city to make streets less dangerous.

title: Abandoning Doubt in Sedona, Arizona
description: While the idea of renewing your vows on a tropical beach at sunset like a pair of histrionic telenovela stars may sound romantic to some, my husband, Sacha, and I found the idea of celebrating our anniversary that way, well, boring.

title: A Midtown Apartment Offers a Change of Pace
description: After their wedding and honeymoon in September, Brian and Stephanie Cashin turned their attention to an apartment hunt.

title: 8 Ways to Save on Travel in 2015
description: Interested in 37 newfangled apps that will save you 0.01 percent on travel for the coming year? I didnt think so. At some point, you have to stop trying to find every new tool for and shortcut to bargains as they appear and just wait to see which ones stick. By now, you surely know some basics: You probably use meta-search sites to compare airfare and hotel prices; youve either tried or consciously avoided sharing economy services like Uber; you know that most domestic car rental reservations can be canceled with no penalty should you find a better rate even on the day of the trip.

title: Bob Hall, Harlem Globetrotter Who Relished the Showman Role, Dies at 87
description: Bob Hall, a key showman for the Harlem Globetrotters, basketballs barnstorming comedy troupe, from the late 1940s until the mid-1970s, died on Dec. 24 near his home in Detroit. He was 87.

title: 1907-8 | The Times Drops the Ball
description: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

title: A Kanye West-Paul McCartney Single Drops Just Before the Ball
description: It turns out 2014 wasnt a Kanye-less year after all. Before midnight on Wednesday, Mr. West released a new single titled Only One, featuring Paul McCartney, on his website and iTunes.

title: Andrew Cuomo Puts Bigger Challenges on His 2nd-Term Agenda
description: Beginning his second term only hours before the death of his father, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Thursday promised to confront some of the most deep-rooted challenges facing New York and the nation: unfairness in the criminal justice system, an eroded economic mobility and the distortion of the public education system from a great equalizer during his fathers youth into a great discriminator for children born into poverty today.

title: 1914: Christmas at the Front
description: LONDON  Eye-Witness, in his latest descriptive account sent from General Headquarters, tells, as follows, how the soldiers passed Christmas at the front: Christmas has come and gone, but it has brought no modification of the situation. On Christmas Eve a hard frost set in, and Dec. 25 was very cold, though it was not bright, for a mist hung over the countryside.

title: Real Estate Chief Fears Troubled Sibling Has New Weapon: TV
description: Douglas Durst recalled the last time he saw and spoke with his troubled older brother, Robert.

title: Recent History in One Chart
description: A number of people have been putting up candidates for chart of the year. For me, the big chart of 2014 wasnt actually from 2014  it was from earlier work (pdf) by Branko Milanovic, which I somehow didnt see until a few months ago. It shows income growth since 1988 by percentiles of the world income distribution (as opposed to national distributions):

title: Proulx Says She Regrets Brokeback Mountain
description: Regrets, Annie Proulx has had a few, starting with Brokeback Mountain. That 1997 story about two gay cowboys may have won wide acclaim and been turned into an Oscar-winning movie, but in a 2009 interview with The Paris Review, which drew renewed attention this week, Ms. Proulx said she wished she could take it back.

title: 3 Die in Queens Fire; City Records First Killing of 2015
description: Just minutes before the New Years Eve ball dropped in Times Square, three members of a family in Queens died in a fire that started in the kitchen of their ninth-floor apartment in the LeFrak City housing complex, officials said on Thursday.

title: Government Spending, Edging Up, Is a Stimulus
description: NAPLES, Fla.  For a long stretch, government spending cutbacks at all levels were a substantial drag on economic growth. Now, finally, relief is in sight.

title: Digital Tax Increase to Take Effect in Europe
description: LONDON  Europes tax showdown could be headed straight to peoples wallets.

title: Syria Deaths Hit New High in 2014, Observer Group Says
description: More than 76,000 people died in Syrias civil war in 2014, including more than 3,500 children, a monitoring group reported on Thursday. The figures would make last year the deadliest in Syria since the conflict began in March 2011.

title: A Shared Legacy: Folk Art in America
description: A look at the new show at the American Folk Art Museum.

title: Pride in Success of Saban Resounds Across Alabama
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  On Oct. 6, Phyllis Chapple-Perkins called in to Paul Finebaums daily radio show, the pre-eminent Southeastern Conference talkfest, and let loose.

title: Simple, but Oh, What Depths
description: In a letter he wrote in 1825, the American painter John Vanderlyn said that paintings by the itinerant portraitist Ammi Phillips were ... cheap and slight, for the mass of folks cant judge of the merits of a well-finished picture. Vanderlyn had gone to France for academic training. His masterpiece, Ariadne Asleep on the Island of Naxos (1809-14), a suavely erotic, neo-Classical vision of a nude woman dozing in a pastoral landscape, is one of the gems of the collection of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts. But a discerning viewer today might well prefer Phillips. His Girl in Red Dress With Cat and Dog (1830-35) is one of the loveliest paintings by any American artist.

title: Turkish Police Thwart Attack on Prime Ministers Office in Istanbul
description: ISTANBUL  The Turkish police arrested an armed man on Thursday after he tried to attack a palace complex near the prime ministers office in Istanbul.

title: Dark Times Ahead for Two Major Paris Theaters
description: PARIS  The Thtre de la Ville and the Thtre du Chtelet, two of the most important theaters in Paris, will close for extensive renovations at the end of the 2016 season, darkening the houses for one and a half to two years.

title: Piketty Turns Down the Legion of Honor
description: The economist Thomas Piketty, the author of the surprise best-seller Capital in the Twenty-First Century, has turned down the Legion of Honor, the highest decoration offered by the French government.

title: Painting as Process, Painting as Life
description: A look at the Guggenheim Museums new retrospective of the 20th-century Indian modernist V.S. Gaitonde.

title: An Indian Modernist With a Global Gaze
description: Many Western abstract painters in the early 20th century  Albers, Kandinsky, Mondrian  were deeply influenced by Asian art and philosophy, though no one dismissed them as Orientalists. Their cosmopolitanism was a point in their favor, and proof of Modernisms wide embrace. By contrast, if Asian artists showed signs of absorbing Western models, their work was disdained as derivative, inauthentic and evidence that Western Modernism was the only true one, the source that supplied the world.

title: Selma to Be Screened Free in Selma
description: Selma, Ava DuVernays film about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.s 1965 civil rights marches in that small Alabama town, is making the rounds among Oscar voters, who began casting ballots this week.

title: Frank Lampard Lifts Manchester City as Fans in New York Fume
description: Frank Lampard came off the bench to score the winning goal in Manchester Citys 3-2 victory over Sunderland on Thursday. The goal highlighted Lampards value to City, which moved into a tie for the Premier League lead when Chelsea lost to Tottenham later in the day, but it also exposed a deep wedge between Lampard and American soccer fans who had expected to see him play in New York this spring.

title: Talking (and Talking) About Love
description: Opening a new production of Franz Lehars enduring operetta The Merry Widow as a New Years Eve gala at the Metropolitan Opera seemed a promising idea. Here is a light comedy with a rich, tuneful score and plenty of opportunities for dancing. And, in its way, the story, which centers on an attractive widow from a Balkan land, now living in Paris, whose husband left her a fortune, touches on wistful emotions that often well up with the coming of a new year: the byways of romantic attachment, the passing of time, the difficulty of amending lost opportunities.

title: A Creative Vision, So Down to Earth
description: One of the smallest but most salient works in Jean Dubuffet: Soul of the Underground, at the Museum of Modern Art, is a sketchbook page covered with tiny contour drawings of footprints. Made during one of Dubuffets late-1940s sojourns in El Gola, a Saharan oasis, it hints at the inspiration he would find under his soles over the next couple of decades.

title: Communing With Mr. Turner
description: The Tate Britain in London houses the worlds largest collection of paintings by J. M. W. Turner, but Americans dont need a passport to see his works in person. Below is a list of institutions in Manhattan or within a days journey from the city that own pieces prominently featured in Mike Leighs film Mr. Turner, followed by several museums with Turners work in their collections.

title: Plotlines? Brush Strokes Are Enough
description: I tend to be a sucker for movies about art and artists. It almost doesnt matter whether these films are good, bad or middling. Watching them is like watching sports or maybe a game show. You keep score. How much is right, how much seems off, how much is so inaccurate it makes you squirm. And, yes, theres also a certain know-it-all satisfaction in catching mistakes.

title: The Best Sports Films Often Take a Dark Turn
description: The sports film is imbued with the impulse to inspire, or at least to make the moviegoer feel good. Think of the familiar blueprint: an underdog high school basketball team in Hoosiers or the aging ballplayer Roy Hobbs in The Natural battles the odds to emerge with a victory.

title: Richard Sandomirs Top 10 Sports Films
description: 1. Raging Bull: A brilliantly directed epic about misanthropy that is propelled by a great story, more-than-credible action and fascinating, doomed relationships. And Robert De Niro won an Oscar as best actor.

title: New Years Day Bowl Games
description: Images from Thursdays college football bowl games, including the College Football Playoffs two semifinal games: the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif.; and the Sugar Bowl in New Orleans.

title: John I. Goodlad, Progressive Educator, Dies at 94
description: John I. Goodlad, an influential educator whose study of more than 27,000 students, teachers and administrators in the late 1970s and early 80s documented the problems plaguing American public schools, died on Nov. 29 in Seattle. He was 94.

title: How the Civil War Created College Football
description: At a ceremony in Cambridge, Mass., on June 10, 1890, the philanthropist Henry Lee Higginson declared, I ask to make [Soldiers Field] a memorial to some dear friends who gave their lives  to their country and to their fellow men in the hour of great need  the War of the Rebellion. The 31 acres of marshlands and pasture that Higginson donated to Harvard College, his alma mater, would serve as the site of the countrys oldest concrete football arena, Harvard Stadium, built over a decade later in 1903. As he memorialized the Civil War dead, the Union veteran addressed a group of 400 male students and alumni, most of whom were too young to have experienced and learned from the horrors of battle during the nations bloodiest war. Like Higginson, however, many late-19th-century Americans saw a deep connection between the battlefield and the athletic field, believing that collegiate athletics, including football, could teach the next generation their own duties as men and citizens of the Republic and train them to manage the burden of carrying on this country in the best way.

title: After a Remake for American Viewers, Back to Understatement
description: The police drama The Bridge, in both its original (Scandinavian) and American versions, took its title from its evocative opening gimmick: A body is found on a bridge that crosses an international border, lying half in one country and half in the other. The result is an unlikely partnership between detectives from two countries, Sweden and Denmark in the original, the United States and Mexico in the remake.

title: Recalling Blind Tom, an Autistic Pianist Born to Slavery
description: The pianist Blind Tom began drawing crowds to his performances as a child in the 1850s. His black family and various white guardians fought for rights to earn money from his career until his death in 1908. Blind Tom himself, who was born into slavery and given a series of last names over the years, was autistic and unable to fathom the legal battles.

title: Societys Flaws and Foibles, Etched for Posterity
description: THE registrar at the National Arts Club in Manhattan decided last summer to impose some order on a donated collection of books that once belonged to the Ashcan artist Robert Henri.

title: Movie Listings for Jan. 2-8
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Rolling and Flexing to Massage Away Pain and Stress
description: THE MELT method  a kind of body work that has been the subject of gym classes and a best-selling book  claims to address a host of middle-age complaints: chronic pain, aching joints, weight gain, stress, wrinkles, digestive problems, low energy and insomnia.

title: Comedy Listings for Jan. 2-8
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Pop, Rock & Cabaret Listings for Jan. 2-8
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Where Have All the Cod Gone?
description: PORTSMOUTH, N.H.  IN November, regulators from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration shut down recreational and commercial cod fishing in the Gulf of Maine, that enchanting arm of the coastal sea stretching east-northeast from Cape Cod. They did not have much choice: Federal law requires action to rebuild fish stocks when they are depleted, and recent surveys revealed cod populations to be at record lows, despite decades of regulations intended to restore them.

title: Weekend Entertainments From the Archives of The New York Times
description: 79 YEARS AGO

title: Teach Congress a Lesson
description: WASHINGTON  OVER the last decade, Congresss approval ratings have gone from bad to worse to outright terrible, dropping from about 40 percent at the end of 2004 to a meager 15 percent today, according to Gallup. The American people are frustrated with the gridlock and hyperpartisan atmosphere in Washington, but a large part of the problem is the perception that lawmakers believe the rules dont apply to them.

title: As Bubbly as a Midnight Glass of Champagne
description: The New York Philharmonics New Years Eve concert at Avery Fisher Hall offered cleverness and good spirits aplenty. That much was all but guaranteed in a program celebrating the Gershwin brothers: the composer George and the lyricist Ira.

title: Mortality and its Discontents
description: ESTES PARK, Colo.  On the first day of the new year, as on the last day of the old year, I slip outside at dusk and try to run away from my problems. There is no better way to make sense of the daily clutter of inchoate thoughts than bouncing along a trail, immortality in every stride.

title: Jazz Listings for Jan. 2-8
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: In the Sweet Shop, Happily Sampling New Concoctions
description: George Balanchines The Nutcracker is a marvelous holiday entertainment, but it is also an education for the young. The children in the production try out adult dances and formal courtesies. The child heroine, Marie, and the hero, Drosselmeiers nephew (who becomes the Nutcracker Prince), battle mice and imagine the independence of maturity. The children in the audience learn how to watch ballet.

title: Opera & Classical Music Listings for Jan. 2-8
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Dance Listings for Jan. 2-8
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: 20 Shows to Watch
description: When did winter become the season of televisions most distinguished content? The fall season, with its organized and heavily publicized broadcast-network premieres, still gets the attention, but a greater number of interesting shows now arrive on cable, broadcast and online in the first quarter of the year.

title: Alas, the Indignity: Murder Victims Entombed in Cows
description: The French filmmaker Bruno Dumont has described his mesmerizing 197-minute murder mystery, Lil Quinquin, as a comedy. The term fits that definition only if you understand that he means the human comedy in all its grotesque and happy-sad variations. As in most of his films, Mr. Dumont assumes the aesthetic and moral stance of a semidetached, some would say pitiless, observer of the human condition. Lil Quinquin is a quasi-epic farce that mostly wears a poker face as it elaborates his continuing obsession with the collision of humankinds bestial and spiritual impulses.

title: Cops and Crime Versus Crumpets: Two Shows Reveal Two Britains
description: There is an antidote to Downton Abbey.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Jan. 2-8
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Spare Times for Children for Jan. 2-8
description: First Saturdays for Families: Group Choreography

title: Stopping Goals, and Opening Up
description: If you want to know what one of his spectacular crashes feels like, Evel Knievel once told a reporter, strap on a helmet and sit on the hood of a car. Have someone get that car up to 90 miles per hour. Then you hold your nose and fall off, he said.

title: Jeb Bush Resigns From Board Seats, Possibly Edging Closer to Presidential Run
description: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida has resigned from each of his corporate and nonprofit board positions, an aide confirmed Thursday, the latest indication that he is moving toward starting a presidential campaign.

title: Spare Times for Jan. 2-8
description: Museums and Sites

title: An Actor Uses a Pen This Time
description: Every actor wants to play a robot, said Mike Iveson, speaking by telephone from his Upper West Side apartment. Thats the truth.

title: Doing Close-Ups With No Camera
description: Video projections, once the sole province of technologically precocious companies like the Wooster Group, have become standard fare for theater artists. A GoPro camera and a relatively flat surface can now transform the humblest of stages instantly.

title: Theres Hope for Nebraskas Liberals
description: To the Editor:

title: Dancers Homage to a Kindred Soul
description: The story of how the dancer, actor and choreographer Fred Herko died is mythic in avant-garde circles: He took a bath, danced around his friends Cornelia Street loft to Mozarts Coronation Mass and leapt out of a window in a grand jet. It was Oct. 27, 1964.

title: Keeping Up With the Visuals
description: Circus performers are used to a bit of competition for the audiences attention, whether from cream-pie-wielding clowns, befezzed elephants or popcorn-selling vendors.

title: Not Paying for Hostages
description: To the Editor:

title: Unclean Nuclear Energy
description: To the Editor:

title: By Editing Plant Genes, Companies Avoid Regulation
description: Its first attempt to develop genetically engineered grass ended disastrously for the Scotts Miracle-Gro Company. The grass escaped into the wild from test plots in Oregon in 2003, dooming the chances that the government would approve the product for commercial use.

title: A Cold Month Is No Longer Dark
description: MOST of us abandon our New Years resolutions. But if you vowed to see more live art in 2015, you can start keeping that one right away. A decade ago, January was a performance doldrums. No more.

title: Rights Crisis in Venezuela
description: To the Editor:

title: Relying on Propane Gas
description: To the Editor:

title: Add Coffee to Subway Evils
description: To the Editor:

title: An All-Gyllenhaal Weekend, Anyone?
description: Its not often that the stars align this way. But the cosmic event here concerns the sibling actors Gyllenhaal, Maggie and Jake. She stars in a play on Broadway that will close on Sunday (Tom Stoppards The Real Thing, second from right). He stars in a play on Broadway now in previews that will open in a little more than a week (Nick Paynes Constellations, far right). And they are both getting awards-season attention for their current screen work. She has been nominated for a Golden Globe for her performance in the summer TV mini-series The Honorable Woman (far left), which you can view now on Sundance.tv. And he is suddenly being mentioned everywhere for his creepy role in the film Nightcrawler (second from left), still in theaters. Binge away.

title: A Ghost With a Grudge (Watch Out, Kids!)
description: THE WOMAN IN BLACK 2

title: To Rescue Economy, Japan Turns to Supermom
description: TOKYO  When she was pregnant with the first of her three sons, Chiaki Kitajima, an advertising executive here, said her bosses were shocked that rather than accept reduced hours and a demotion after maternity leave, she made a presentation on why the company should subsidize child care.

title: Boston Marathon Bombing: What We Know
description: At 2:49 p.m. on April 15, 2013, two explosions occurred near the finish line at the Boston Marathon, killing three people and wounding more than 260. The trial for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, now 21, who is accused in the bombing, started on Monday in Boston.

title: Finding Meaning in a Dish
description: Opens on Friday

title: Despite Thaw, American Base at Guantnamo Still Stings for Cubans
description: GUANTNAMO, Cuba  At a military checkpoint on the road that approaches the American naval base here, one of three along the way, four Cuban soldiers in pea-green fatigues, without guns, stood on duty last Sunday laughing over a joke in the shade of an almond tree, beside a neatly cultivated flower bed. A large sign declared the site the first anti-imperialist trench.

title: Theater Listings for Jan. 2-8
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: A Year of Columns, a Memorable Trove of Characters
description: HANGING OVER HIS FUTURE For Zachary Warren, the 30-year-old magna cum laude graduate of Georgetown Law School caught up in the 2012 collapse of the big law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf, probably the best thing that can be said about 2014 is that its over.

title: Ditch the Persona, Then Move a Piano
description: Singer, songwriter, punk-rocker, actress, fashionista, tabloid bonanza and ... piano mover? Thats part of Courtney Loves latest and thoroughly unexpected gig. The performer who made her name in the 1990s with her primal rasp and confrontational, straight-from-the-id songs will play the lead in Kansas City Choir Boy, a music-theater piece shes performing with its songwriter, Todd Almond, in the 84-seat South Village performance space Here from Jan. 8-17.

title: Top 2 Thruway Authority Executives Quit Without Warning
description: The top two executives of the New York State Thruway Authority abruptly quit this week, the latest sign of turmoil at the agency as it faces a deep budget shortfall and difficulty financing the construction of a new Tappan Zee Bridge.

title: Web Freedom Is Seen as a Growing Global Issue
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Government censorship of the Internet is a cat-and-mouse game. And despite more aggressive tactics in recent months, the cats have been largely frustrated while the mice wriggle away.

title: Deal Makers Notched Nearly $3.5 Trillion Worth in 14, Best in 7 Years
description: By almost every measure, 2014 was a time for deal makers to pop the corks of their Champagne bottles.

title: Is the Modern American Dream Attainable?
Mario Cuomo, Ex-New York Governor and Liberal Beacon, Dies at 82
description: Mario M. Cuomo, the three-term governor of New York who commanded the attention of the country with a compelling public presence, a forceful defense of liberalism and his exhaustive ruminations about whether to run for president, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.

title: Hope for the Homeless
description: Though homeless encampments elsewhere in the country have been dismantled by the authorities, officials in Las Cruces, N.M. have funneled money and services to Camp Hope.

title: In New Mexico Tent City, a Glimmer of Hope
description: LAS CRUCES, N.M.  On a dusty lot in a rough stretch of this city, homeless people have pitched dozens of tents, some nearly empty and others so packed with possessions that their residents are practically entombed inside. There is no electricity, and the unrelenting winds batter the tents so badly that duct tape, used for repairs, is coveted like gold.

title: A Voice for American Liberalism
description: Mario M. Cuomo, a three-term governor of New York, was a liberal beacon in a conservative age and several times flirted with a presidential run.

title: Mario Cuomo Is Dead at 82
description: Mario M. Cuomo, a three-term governor of New York, was a major voice for American liberalism in a conservative age and several times flirted with a presidential run.

title: Georgia Police Chief on Leave After Shooting of His Wife
description: The police chief of an Atlanta suburb shot his wife early on New Years Day, telling 911 operators that it was an accident, officials said. The victim, Margaret McCollom, 58, was in critical condition, and the chief, William E. McCollom, was placed on administrative leave.

title: Joining International Criminal Court Wouldnt Guarantee Palestinians a War Crimes Case
description: JERUSALEM  The political fallout from the Palestinian move Wednesday to join the International Criminal Court is likely to be swift and profound.

title: A Vital Nuclear Agreement, at Risk
description: Theres much more to the deeply troubled Russian-American relationship than Ukraine. Under the radar, tensions have also been brewing over compliance with a number of arms control treaties that for decades have been vital to keeping the peace between the two nuclear powers and setting an example for other countries.

title: An Enemy of Reform in New York Jails
description: The Justice Departments decision in December to join a class-action suit against New York Citys Correction Department has prepared the way for reforms proposed by Mayor Bill de Blasio to root out corruption and brutality at the notorious Rikers Island jail complex. Success depends heavily on the cooperation of Norman Seabrook, the president of the politically powerful correction officers union and a longtime supporter of the disastrous status quo.

title: Whats Happening to New Yorks Skyline?
description: Its not a tourist attraction yet, but when hard-hatted construction workers journey down from the summit of 432 Park Avenue at 57th Street they proudly rattle off-sky-high statistics  1,396 feet and 96 stories tall  that now make the luxury condominium tower in Midtown the tallest habitable building in the city.

title: Ducks Reach Title Game, in a Blur
description: PASADENA, Calif.  As Jameis Winston moved forward, looking for another improbable outcome, then circled counterclockwise in desperation, Florida States comeback magic came unraveled in spectacular fashion.

title: Cuomo at the 1984 Democratic Convention
description: At the 1984 Democratic National Convention, then Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York delivered his famous tale of two cities keynote address.

title: The Age of Bibi
description: METULA, Israel  If I were a political novelist, Id try to write a novel about Benjamin Netanyahu, the prime minister of Israel.

title: Cuba Again Arrests Artist Seeking Dissidents Release
description: MEXICO CITY  A performance artist advocating free speech in Cuba was arrested for the third time in two days on Thursday, her supporters said, along with several dissidents after they went to a jail demanding the release of government opponents rounded up in a crackdown this week.

title: Events on Long Island for Jan. 4-10, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut for Jan. 4-10, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Events in New Jersey for Jan. 4-10, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Westchester for Jan. 4-10, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Twin Peaks Planet
description: In 2014, soaring inequality in advanced nations finally received the attention it deserved, as Thomas Pikettys Capital in the Twenty-First Century became a surprise (and deserving) best seller. The usual suspects are still in well-paid denial, but, to everyone else, it is now obvious that income and wealth are more concentrated at the very top than they have been since the Gilded Age  and the trend shows no sign of letting up.

title: Man Threatened to Kill Officers, Authorities Say
description: Emergency dispatchers were jarred by a string of predawn calls on Tuesday: A mans voice, the police said, asked that officers be sent to his location so he could shoot them when they arrived.

title: Boston Is Eager to Begin Marathon Bombing Trial, and to End It
description: BOSTON  The blood has long since been scrubbed from the finish line. The memorials have vanished, and the fund that raised money for victims has closed.

title: Lottery Numbers
Battling Suns Glare at Ballpark, the Capitals Deliver a Final Bit of Brilliance
description: WASHINGTON  Under a national spotlight, there was no avoiding the glare.

title: Vanguard of Syrias Uprising, Now on the Run From ISIS, Weighs a Bleak Future
description: ANTAKYA, Turkey  The cigarette smoke in the hotel room grew as thick as the cottony fog outside in this Turkish border town, as Syrian men, night after night, told their war stories. Their memories veered from exhilaration to black humor to terror, but mostly they told of what they had lost: Friends. A fiance. An arm. A country. None were out of their mid-20s.

title: Ebola Doctors Are Divided on IV Therapy in Africa
description: Medical experts seeking to stem the Ebola epidemic are sharply divided over whether most patients in West Africa should, or can, be given intravenous hydration, a therapy that is standard in developed countries. Some argue that more aggressive treatment with IV fluids is medically possible and a moral obligation. But others counsel caution, saying that pushing too hard would put overworked doctors and nurses in danger and that the treatment, if given carelessly, could even kill patients.

title: Burning Sensation
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Its always weird when you have New Years Eve in the middle of the week. We started off our solving year with a terrific themed puzzle by Jill Denny and Jeff Chen, and next, bam! Right into the crunchy, themeless part of our week we go. If you were hoping to start out the New Year with a nice, easy Monday, youre out of luck.

title: Mothers Courage Helps Daughter Change Course Amid Illness
description: There was little doubt that she would win her battle with breast cancer, Nora Zenteno said, because she was filled with faith that God would heal her.

title: Ferret Fanciers, Ruffled by Ban, Are Eager for New York City to Lift It
description: Since a bizarre incident in which Rudolph W. Giuliani verbally abused a ferret enthusiast on the radio a decade and a half ago, New York Citys ferret owners have been dealing with two major problems.

title: Soothing the Aged With Verse, a Lawyer Takes a Road Less Traveled
description: On the public stage, Marvin Wexler is a hard-boiled commercial litigator, skilled at defending the unpopular: the actress Vanessa Redgrave, for instance, when she was cut from a role for supporting the Palestine Liberation Organization in the 1980s; more recently a New York City hospital, against accusations that it pressed Huguette Clark, the copper heiress and a longtime patient, to donate lavishly from her fortune.

title: A Contentious Source of Income Is Set to Dry Up
description: Soccers hot stove league  the winter transfer window  fired up again Thursday, beginning a monthlong frenzy in which some of Europes best-known teams will buy and sell the rights to some of the worlds best players.

title: The Family of New York: Cuomos Inaugural Address
description: Following is a transcript of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos inaugural address on Thursday, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Oh, the Places Weve Been
description: In 2014, Metro stories took photographers to places most New Yorkers rarely see, from rooftop water tanks to abandoned islands.

title: A Different Sort of Santa Suit
Doug Marrone Is Among Jets Candidates
description: Make Doug Marrone the Jets seventh confirmed coaching candidate. The team plans to speak next week with Marrone, who opted out as coach of the Buffalo Bills on Wednesday, but no interview has been scheduled yet, said a person with knowledge of the teams thinking.

title: Yankees Trade Former Top Prospect to Braves
description: After years of waiting for the left-hander Manny Banuelos to fulfill his potential, the Yankees gave up on him, trading him to the Atlanta Braves for the right-handed pitcher David Carpenter and the left-hander Chasen Shreve. Banuelos joined the Yankees organization in 2008 but never reached the major leagues despite his promising ability.

title: Where Theres a Drink, Theres a Whey
description: Whey, the cloudy liquid runoff of ricotta, mozzarella and yogurt usually destined for the sink drain, is finding new uses among creative chefs who are salvaging the tart, calcium-rich fluid for sodas and beverages. Though its essentially a byproduct of cheese production, whey can be a delicious ingredient in its own right.

title: A Bright Classic With a Radiant Finish
description: The Capitals edged the Blackhawks with 12.9 seconds remaining to win the Winter Classic at Nationals Park.

title: Whats On TV Friday
description: 9 P.M. (13) BILLY JOEL: THE LIBRARY OF CONGRESS GERSHWIN PRIZE Mr. Joel adds this lifetime achievement prize  which honors living songwriters whose work, according to the library, exemplifies the standard of excellence associated with George and Ira Gershwin  to his 33 Top 40 hits and 23 Grammy nominations. Justice Sonia Sotomayor of the Supreme Court and Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, were among those who bestowed the award on Mr. Joel on Nov. 19 at Constitution Hall in Washington. That celebration, presented here, features Tony Bennett performing New York State of Mind, LeAnn Rimes singing Lullabye (Goodnight, My Angel), Josh Groban rendering Always a Woman and John Mellencamp covering Allentown. Then its Mr. Joels turn with renditions of Movin Out, Vienna, You May Be Right and, with Kevin Spacey, Piano Man.

title: A No. 3 Quarterback Topples No. 1 Alabama
description: NEW ORLEANS  Nick Saban walked slowly down the sideline Thursday night, barely picking up his head as Ohio State running back Ezekiel Elliott sprinted toward the end zone with a trail of Alabama defenders helplessly chasing him.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Theres no doubt in my mind that if he had the opportunity to kill me, he would.

title: No Corrections: January 2, 2015
description: No corrections appeared in print.

title: Traffickers Set Freighter on a Course for Italy and Flee, Leaving Migrants Aboard
description: VERBANIA, Italy  For the second time in three days, the Italian authorities found themselves racing on Friday to rescue hundreds of migrants from an aging freighter that traffickers had pointed toward Italy and then abandoned, leaving the ship to plow through wintry seas at top speed with no one at the helm, heading straight for the coastline.

title: Hairstyles That Ascend, and Aspire, in Nigeria
description: In Nigeria, its not just hair.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: European Central Bank Hints of Stimulus as Euro Falls Against Dollar
description: FRANKFURT  A strong indication on Friday that the European Central Bank is on the verge of aggressive action to stimulate the economy, just as the Federal Reserve is dialing back its stimulus, helped push the euro to its lowest level against the dollar since 2010.

title: New York Today: Words About Pictures
description: Good morning on this chilly Friday.

title: Teenagers in the Times | December 2014
description: We ring in the New Year with the December edition of Teenagers in the Times, a feature that presents almost everything published in The Times about young people during the prior month.

title: Bono Fears He May Never Play the Guitar Again
description: Bono, the lead singer of U2, has announced on the bands website that he may never play the guitar again because of injuries sustained in a cycling accident in New York.

title: Morning Agenda: Looking Back on a Year of Deals
description: LOOKING BACK ON A YEAR OF DEALS | The holidays are over, but a final toast is still in order.

title: A Historical Drama Shows Too Much Cleavage for Chinas Censors
description: In The Empress of China, Fan Bingbing portrays Wu Zetian, the only woman in Chinese history to rule in her own right. When the highly anticipated television show The Empress of China was abruptly pulled from Chinese airwaves just days after its premiere on Dec. 21, many speculated that the reason might have had less to do with technical problems, as the shows producers claimed on its official microblog account, than with one aspect of the show that was, well, impossible to miss: the plunging necklines and tightly squeezed bosoms.

title: A Day With Apple Pay
description: For years, payments industry insiders have been skeptical of the rise of the mobile wallet, a vision of the future where customers eschew wallets for credit cards stored on their smartphones.

title: Jeb Bush, and Two Myths About Shifting to the Right
description: Even before Jeb Bush announced he was exploring a run for the presidency in 2016, the question emerged: Could Mr. Bush win the nomination without pandering to the Republican partys conservative base in the primaries? The answer from many strategists was an uncomfortable no.

title: Time to Assess Your Financial Fitness
description: When the Dow Jones industrial average closed above 18,000 for the first time late last month, you could practically hear the champagne corks popping. Traders wore hats celebrating the occasion, and email news alerts were followed by dutiful articles.

title: Kenyan Court Suspends Part of New Antiterrorism Law
description: A Kenyan court on Friday suspended some of the most contentious provisions of a new security law that detractors have said would undermine democracy.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: Dying in the E.R., and on TVWithout His Familys Consent
description: Anita Chanko could not sleep. At 4 a.m., on an August night in 2012, she settled onto the couch in her Yorkville living room with her dog, Daisy, and her parrot, Elliott, and flipped on the DVR. On came the prior nights episode of NY Med, the popular real-life medical series set at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, starring Dr. Mehmet Oz. Mrs. Chanko, 75, was a fan of the show and others like it.

title: A Ringtone Gets an Encore
description: Dear Diary:

title: Four Big Pieces of AirAsia Jet Are Found; Search Crews Have Recovered 46 Bodies
description: SURABAYA, Indonesia  An Indonesian official said four major pieces of the Airbus A320-200 jetliner that plunged into the Java Sea last Sunday had been found. The wreckage was located by sonar equipment, but divers had not yet been able to examine it because of high waves and perilous currents, according to the National Search and Rescue Agency.

title: Panda Bear on the Books, Films and Music That Inspire Him
description: A name is just a name, even the not-so-vaguely menacing title Panda Bear Meets the Grim Reaper.In fact, the fifth album from Panda Bear  the singer-songwriter also known as Noah Lennox  shows the Animal Collective members purported encounter with the afterlife to have been quite productive. As was the case with Lennoxs 2011 release Tomboy, the new album transforms experimental techniques into moody yet uplifting pop music that somehow evokes both a dank basement rave and the sunny sounds of the Beach Boys.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Stuff We Liked: Clever Data Visualization and a Year in Outrage
description: Here is a sampling of the things we liked elsewhere on the web:

title: The Films of Hayao Miyazaki
description: Images of the directors work.

title: A Master of Childhood Dreams
description: The nominations wont be announced until Jan. 15, but its safe to say that the greatest filmmaker associated with the 2015 Academy Awards has already received his Oscar, delivered a modest but revealing acceptance speech and flown home to Japan and, perhaps, retirement.

title: Mike Nichols Told Him Not to Do It
description: Audiences could get vertigo following the meta-narrative of Birdman, Alejandro G. Irritus film about a washed-up action star, Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton), trying to regain a little prestige by doing a Broadway play  contending with showboating actors playing showboating actors  and losing track of reality in the process.

title: Its Her Freak Show Right Now
description: In a silky, beguiling whisper, Elsa Mars, the Marlene Dietrich manque played by Jessica Lange on American Horror Story: Freak Show, tells a new employee why she wont allow matinees. Audiences, she says, want to watch these kinds of acts only at night, when darkness moves in and speaks of mystery and the unknown, when logic loosens its vise grip and the imagination comes out to play.

title: Tim Burton Narrates a Scene From Big Eyes
description: In this video, the director Tim Burton discusses a sequence from his film Big Eyes, based on the life of the artist Margaret Keane (Amy Adams) and her husband, Walter (Christoph Waltz), who takes credit for her artwork. Some of the look of the scene, Mr. Burton said, was inspired by the films of the Italian director Mario Bava. He also discusses the quiet, internal performance given by Ms. Adams.

title: Daily Report: Web Freedom Is Seen as a Growing Global Issue
description: Government censorship of the Internet is a cat-and-mouse game. And despite more aggressive tactics in recent months, the cats have been largely frustrated while the mice wriggle away, Vindu Goel and Andrew E. Kramer report.

title: Letter From the Editor: About Writing What We Wished to Read
description: Some of the most satisfying work Ive done has stemmed from a bit of dissatisfaction Ive had as a reader: Why havent I been able to read that before?

title: Indian Officials Seek 2 Police Officers Accused of Raping Girl, 14
description: NEW DELHI  The Indian police said on Friday that they were searching for two officers in the Budaun district of Uttar Pradesh after a 14-year-old girl from a local village accused them of raping her.

title: Private Letters Untangle Mysterious Death of Oscar Wildes Wife
description: LONDON  Multiple sclerosis may have contributed to the mysterious early death of Constance Wilde, the wife of the Irish playwright Oscar Wilde, according to a paper published on Friday in the medical journal The Lancet.

title: (Yet Another) Brand-New Me
description: The fate of unfulfilled New Years resolutions.

title: The Split-Screen Marriage
description: The other day, just off the train, I pulled out my phone and texted my wife: just off the train. A few minutes later, standing in line at the grocery store, I decided that this moment, too, was not without import, and so out came my phone again: in line at store. My wife, throughout the day, contributed reporting of her own: heading into gym; forgot my umbrella; wait, have umbrella. When we reunited that evening, we were  like so many couples who spend their days smiling faintly at their phones  as well informed of each others doings as if we had each hired a private investigator to trail the other.

title: Brain Freeze
description: I was wheeled into a room full of doctors ready to pry and poke, clipboards in hand. I counted more than seven and fewer than 15  I couldnt tell, because it was hard to turn my neck. All I could think about was how bad I smelled. God, how I must have smelled. I hadnt washed myself in juvenile protest of my symptoms, which arrived with no notice and, I convinced myself, would surely depart as quickly. Help me, I thought while trying not to slump in my wheelchair, but please forgive me for reeking.

title: The Complicated Origins of Having It All
description: A woman sits on the edge of a desk, a spray of pink daisies to her left and floral paper on the walls. The desk bears the gentle clutter of somebody busy but not overwhelmed: a leaning stack of papers, a cup filled with too many pencils, a tangle of paper clips. The woman wears a plum-brown dress, cinched at the waist and unbuttoned at the collar, large button-pearl earrings and still more pearls looped around her neck, along with a gold pendant chain. With her hands clasped loosely in her lap, she smiles, her mouth curved into a languid grin.

title: Reply All: The 12.21.14 Issue
description: WHEN MARISSA MAYER TRIED TO BE STEVE JOBS

title: D-List Doppelgnger
description: I share a highly uncommon name with a very minor celebrity who hasnt worked much in decades. A fan, mistaking me for the celebrity, sent me a note offering praise for his fine work several decades ago and asked for an autograph on an enclosed publicity photo. Ive had a few such misunderstandings over the years and have come to learn that the celebrity is impossible to locate. The fans note was quite endearing, and I am tempted to simply sign the photo and thank the fan for the support. Id be claiming to be someone Im not, which is deceitful, but the fan would probably be happier with that than with the truth. Does the charity of such an act outweigh the deception? NAME WITHHELD

title: Whats On This Week Around the World
description: Santiago, Chile

title: 1940: Whereabouts of Unity Mitford
description: London  Mystery more obscure than London in a black-out surrounded the whereabouts of Miss Unity Freeman-Mitford, 25-year-old daughter of Lord Redesdale and a friend of Hitler, who is reported to be seriously ill with a revolver wound in her head, en route to her home in England either in a special hospital train or an airplane. Since the first report this morning that Hitler had supplied the hospital train from Munich, where Miss Mitford was reported to be hovering between life and death, the mystery has been complete.

title: Exclusive | 775 Park Avenue
description: An elegant Park Avenue penthouse is poised to enter the market for the first time in 26 years.

title: Harry Reid Is Hospitalized After Exercise Accident
description: Senator Harry Reid had a painful New Years Day, breaking ribs and bones in his face after falling while exercising at his home in Nevada.

title: An Outsiders Borough Shaped a Politician Who Helped Shape It
description: When a parochial fight over a school field projected Mario M. Cuomo beyond the obscurity of Queens into a national figure nearly 50 years ago, his home borough was already reverberating with the shocks of tectonic demographic change.

title: A Decline in Problem Mortgages
description: While the lingering effects of the housing-market collapse continued to recede last year, millions of homeowners will still struggle in 2015 and beyond.

title: Inside the List
description: Grishamstyle: Thrillers thrive on villains and heroes, and usually these characters are not overly complicated; writers dont want to confuse or slow the plot. That was Steven Brill  whose book about the health care system, Americas Bitter Pill, is reviewed in next weeks Book Review  writing in 2008, in these pages, about John Grishams novel The Appeal. Brill is best known as a media mogul and entrepreneur: He founded The American Lawyer magazine in 1979, followed a decade later by Court TV and then by the short-lived magazine Brills Content. (I believe in journalism, he told the National Press Club in 1998. I believe deeply in journalism. Apparently he still does; his latest venture is a partnership with The Timess former executive editor Jill Abramson to promote articles too long for a magazine and too short for a book.) But Brill also has personal experience with the best-seller list: In 1978 he hit the nonfiction list with his first book, The Teamsters  the whole squalid story meticulously researched, according to the Book Review back then  while in 2011 he spent a few weeks on the extended list with Class Warfare, a look at education in America. Reviewing Grishams novel, Brill had some kind words for its political observations, although he didnt think much of what he called Grishamstyle: At times, he wrote, his weakness with words is painful to watch, . . . as if someone new to English decided to mimic The Bonfire of the Vanities.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: A Sobering Perspective on a Looming Retirement Crisis
description: Feeling pleased that I had survived another year and the annual predictions of the apocalypse, I made the mistake of picking up  Falling Short: The Coming Retirement Crisis and What to Do About It  (Oxford University Press).

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Charles DAmbrosios Loitering
description: This week, Phillip Lopate discusses Charles DAmbrosios Loitering; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Sven Beckert talks about Empire of Cotton; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Parul Sehgal is the host, filling in for Pamela Paul.

title: How Dick Cheney and Marvin Gaye Inspired A Most Violent Year
description: While the title A Most Violent Year suggests, as Vanity Fairs Richard Lawson put it, a picturesque orgy of gangster violence, the film instead tells a quieter story about a heating oil (!) salesman with bourgeois aspirations and industry enemies.

title: Year of the Condo in New York City
description: At least twice as many new condominium units are scheduled to hit the Manhattan market this year as in 2014, the most since 2007. That means more choice for buyers and some welcome competition among developers.

title: In Miami, a New Outpost for Fashion-Forward Fine Jewelry
description: Rattling off a list of top avant-garde jewelry brands, Roma Cohen  the owner, with his wife, Erika, of Miamis Alchemist boutiques  says, Though weve always been able to represent these people, a lot of times, we havent had the space to give them a proper presentation. Now, the roll call that includes such fine-jewelry designers as Lydia Courteille, Abraxas Rex, Stephen Webster, Garrard and many others will have room to shine in Alchemists spacious new third outpost, opening in the Palm Court complex in the citys Design District.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Charles DAmbrosios Loitering
description: This week, Phillip Lopate and Sven Beckert.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks houses include a five-bedroom in Mount Laurel, N.J., and a three-bedroom on an island in Yorktown, N.Y..

title: Advice for the 114th Congress
description: Four departing members of Congress, including Senator Saxby Chambliss, Republican of Georgia, give advice to freshman lawmakers.

title: Loitering, Essays by Charles DAmbrosio
description: The great promise of essays is the freedom they offer to explore, digress, acknowledge uncertainty; to evade dogmatism and embrace ambivalence and contradiction; to engage in intimate conversation with ones readers and literary forebears; and to uncover some unexpected truth, preferably via a sparkling literary style. In the preface to Loitering, his new and collected essays, Charles DAmbrosio presents himself as a true believer in the form. Having digested all of Joan Didion and George Orwell, all of Susan Sontag and Samuel Johnson, all of Edward Abbey and Hunter Thompson and James Baldwin, he saw essays as fast friends: I must have needed that sort of close attachment, that guidance, the voice holding steady in the face of doubt, the flawed man revealing his flaws, the outspoken woman simply saying, the brother and the sister  for essays were never a father to me, nor a mother.

title: Maotanchang: Study City
description: Chinese students hope this no-nonsense town will transform them into test-taking machines.

title: Departing Lawmakers Bemoan the Decline of Compromise
description: WASHINGTON  With more than 120 years in the House and Senate among them, four lawmakers offered a bit of parting wisdom to Capitol Hill newcomers: Partisanship is easy, governing is hard.

title: Bodies Recovered From AirAsia Crash
description: Bambang Soelistyo, Indonesias National Search and Rescue Agency chief, said on Tuesday that 30 bodies have been recovered from the wreck of Flight 8501.

title: Corky Pollan: Supershopper, and Now, Cookbook Author
description: For a generation of New Yorkers, Corky Pollan was the citys premier shopping maven. Beginning in 1981 and continuing for about two decades, Ms. Pollan wrote and produced New York magazines weekly Best Bets column, whose tagline was the best of all possible things to buy, see and do in the best of all possible cities.

title: Style-Minded Oregon Shows Its Substance
description: PASADENA, Calif.  On a big day for college football, the national semifinal game between Oregon and Florida State was as much a morality play as a matchup of two of the countrys best teams.

title: The Year in Pop Feuds, Charted
Us, by David Nicholls
description: David Nichollss Us, which had yet to be published when it was selected for the longlist of the Man Booker prize last summer, was widely regarded as the judges nod to popular taste, a kind of token cute blonde candidate for an award often criticized as quirky and elitist. Nichollss previous novel was the best-selling One Day, which served as the basis for a movie starring Anne Hathaway and Jim Sturgess. Like its predecessor, this new offering charts the path of an unlikely love affair over the course of decades.

title: Mermaids in Paradise, by Lydia Millet
description: Its a bold move to make mermaids the center of a grown-up story, even in a novel as hilariously funny as this one. But Lydia Millets novels raise the bar for boldness. Through the window of the unlikeliest events or plot twists, she poses the questions many contemporary writers shy away from, or simply skirt: Whats going to happen to the earth? How do we know what to believe? What are the costs of irony?

title: Fiction in Translation
description: OUTLAWS

title: Eve of Destruction
description: Picking up one of Charles Todds post-World War I historical mysteries is like starting off on an uncertain journey. In each book, Inspector Ian Rutledge of Scotland Yard, a shellshocked veteran of the Great War, makes his solitary way to some provincial English town, ostensibly to assist the local constabulary with a baffling crime but also to bear witness to the incalculable devastation brought about by the fighting. In 16 previous novels, the authors (a mother and son who write under a pen name) have sent their haunted hero all over the country, taking stock of the terrible desolation he sees everywhere and knowing that true justice is beyond his powers.

title: The Bully of Order, by Brian Hart
description: From the opening pages of his second novel, The Bully of Order, Brian Hart warns the reader of the harshness to come. This is war but bloodier, one voice tells another. Nah, the other replies, I seen war and this is darling compared.
