Those brave enough to forge ahead are soon faced with a fond recollection of a sexual act with a steers heart and a story that culminates in a dogs hanging itself, among other atrocities. On Harts late-19th-century Pacific Coast, nothing stays clean for long, literally or spiritually: White here is brave and temporary, steam in the windows, ice in the pan. Violence is a way to pass the time, and time is just counting down to death. Hopes, when a character dares to have any, are shattered into pieces, those pieces burned and the ashes tossed into the ocean.

title: Paperback Row
description: DYING EVERY DAY: Seneca at the Court of Nero,  by James Romm. (Vintage, $17.95.) Romm adeptly unravels the enigma of the great Stoic philosopher Seneca, who watched his student Nero spiral into madness as Roman emperor  a descent that saw family murders, the apocalyptic fire of A.D. 64 and a savage purging of the supreme minds of the Imperial Senates golden age.

title: New Books for the New Year
description: For those who cant face living in the present, the end of all the retrospective 2014 lists doesnt have to spell doom. Its time for year-ahead lists. So what does 2015 promise for readers?

title: Letters: Who but a Psychopath?
description: Who but a Psychopath?

title: To Make Men Free, by Heather Cox Richardson
description: America does not have a broken political system. It has a broken political party: the Republicans.

title: The Happiest People in the World, by Brock Clarke
description: At the center of this new novel from the author of An Arsonists Guide to Writers Homes in New England and Exley is a high school guidance counselor named Henry. Well, not really. His name isnt Henry, its Jens, and he isnt a high school guidance counselor, hes a Danish cartoonist on the run from terrorists. But hes not one of the Danish cartoonists youre thinking of, the ones who satirized the Muslim world with their representations of Muhammad. Rather, hes a different Danish cartoonist, one who drew a cartoon about the other cartoonists, and whose cartoonist cartoon proves to be just as controversial as the original cartoonists cartoons. Anyway, for the purposes of this paragraph, lets just say hes a high school guidance counselor in Broomeville, N.Y., a cold and isolated upstate town. Although, really, hes one of two guidance counselors there. The first one has been fired for being a drunk, but actually shes been fired so that the principal of the school, Matty, who is sort of the protagonist  well, wait, hes not really the protagonist, per se, hes one of several people who function, at various times, as protagonists  but as I was saying, Matty has fired the original guidance counselor in order to do a favor for his ex-lover, the wildlife researcher, which is to hire Henry, who is actually Jens. Because the ex-lover, whose name is Locs but really its Lorraine, isnt a wildlife researcher anymore, shes a C.I.A. agent. And she is trying to protect the cartoonist-of-cartoonists-cum-guidance-counselor by hiding him in Broomeville from the terrorists, who are actually, it turns out, just this one guy, who, it also turns out, is not really a terrorist. But, it further turns out, shes just trying to find a way to get Matty (whom she calls Matthew) back, though she never really had him in the first place.

title: A Tale of Two Plantations, by Richard S. Dunn
description: For enslaved peoples in the New World, it was always the worst of times. Whether captured in Africa or born into bondage in the Americas, slaves suffered unimaginable torments and indignities. Yet the specific form their miseries took, as the historian Richard S. Dunn shows in his painstakingly researched A Tale of Two Plantations: Slave Life and Labor in Jamaica and Virginia, depended on whether one was a slave in the British Caribbean or in the United States. The contrasts between the two slave societies were many, covering family life, religious beliefs and labor practices. But one difference overrode all others. In the Caribbean, white masters treated the slaves like disposable cogs in a machine, working them to death on sugar plantations and then replacing them with fresh stock from Africa. In the United States, white masters treated their slaves like the machine itself  a breeding machine.

title: The Ploughmen, by Kim Zupan
description: Some protagonists crave a perch in history. Others hope merely to survive with dignity. The lead characters of Kim Zupans first novel, The Ploughmen, occupy opposite ends of this spectrum, but share two critical traits: They cannot sleep, and the source of their insomnia is their terrible familiarity with death.

title: Editors Choice
description: SUSPENDED SENTENCES: Three Novellas,  by Patrick Modiano. Translated by Mark Polizzotti. (Yale University, paper, $16.) These novellas offer as good a place as any to enter the long, slow-moving river of the French Nobelists fiction.

title: Citizen Coke, by Bartow J. Elmore
description: Halfway into Citizen Coke, Bartow J. Elmore describes taking a treacherous journey through an Indian jungle in 2010. He was searching for a Coke bottling plant that had been shut down six years earlier after villagers claimed it had parched their wells and polluted their streams, causing skin and stomach diseases. Thirsty and tired, he stumbled upon a restaurant in a secluded village where the only safe thing to drink was . . . Coca-Cola. It seemed I had become trapped in the history I had come to investigate, he writes.

title: Jane Gardams Hollow Land
description: Just as devotees of certain television shows dream of finding lost episodes and Beatles fans imagine opening a box and fishing out recordings of forgotten studio sessions, so readers long for ways to extend the pleasure they receive from beloved writers. In this regard Jane Gardam has been more than accommodating. After American readers began to embrace the British writers novel Old Filth, released here in 2006, they learned that Gardam had been publishing fine fiction regularly since the 1970s. Her backlist is extraordinary and deep, populated by titles published only in Britain as well as ones that also appeared in America but had essentially been hiding in plain sight, the way books sometimes do when they dont find their audience.

title: Noontide Toll, by Romesh Gunesekera
description: This collection of linked stories, set in post-civil-war, post-tsunami Sri Lanka, is narrated by a retired clerk who has sunk his savings into a minibus and now hires himself out as a driver. Each story traces a different journey, with passengers that include three Russians on their way to a new luxury spa; a Roman Catholic priest and his acolyte pursuing a kind of detective mission; a Czech couple who share a walk on a beach with a night watchman whose entire family perished, along with more than 30,000 other Sri Lankans, in the 2004 tsunami; a delegation of Chinese businessmen appraising vast junk fields of military scrap; and a Sri Lankan general (also a renowned ballroom dancer) en route to a meeting with a woman whose family he has all but destroyed. The 14 stories in Noontide Toll function like the stages of a tour through a place thats trying to emerge from the ruins, yet is still trapped by the past despite the prospects ahead.

title: Oil Price Slump May Spur European Oil and Gas Deal-Making
description: There was $383 billion in mergers and acquisitions in the oil and gas sector last year, as of Dec. 11. Yet Europe has largely missed out: About three-quarters of the targets have been in North America, according to Thomson Reuters data. Shale has played a big role. In 2015, oil and gas bankers in Europe will get a bigger slice of the action.

title: Fight on Guns Is Being Taken to State Ballots
description: WASHINGTON  The gun control movement, blocked in Congress and facing mounting losses in federal elections, is tweaking its name, refining its goals and using the same-sex marriage movement as a model to take the fight to voters on the state level.

title: The Year in Jazz 2014
description: [Listen in iTunes | Download the MP3]

title: Facts & Figures: Government Leadership Worries Americans Most
description: A poll released on Friday found that Americans were more worried about the countrys political leadership and political conflict than any other issue.

title: Clothes and Character: Annie
description: The central character has been popular with children and adults alike since the 1920s, and the score is based on the catchy tunes of a 1980s musical. But for the new adaptation of Annie, about a precocious orphan in search of her family, the director Will Glucks goal was to be sure the film felt modern.

title: A Stress Test for Mario Draghi and the European Central Bank
description: Mario Draghi indulged the photographers and their rapid-fire shutters for a few moments, making his first appearance for the news media in the European Central Banks ostentatious new high-rise headquarters in Frankfurt.

title: Sharing Flickr Photos Privately
On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties include a Greenwich Village one-bedroom; a Hells Kitchen two-bedroom; and a Brooklyn house with two units.

title: Humble Leeks Can Add Brightness to Winter
description: In my experience, leeks are usually terribly overcooked or strangely undercooked. Either way, its a sad situation: Its so easy to get them right, and results can be sublime.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York York City:

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York York region:

title: Book Review Podcast: Charles DAmbrosios Loitering
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Phillip Lopate reviews Charles DAmbrosios Loitering: New and Collected Essays. Mr. Lopate writes:

title: A Royal Ride in Portugal
description: Tom Harper River Journeys new 12-day tour explores Portugal on a luxury vessel built for the queen of England to lead the diamond jubilee pageant on the Thames in 2012 in London.

title: Chocolate Factory in Brooklyn Asks: What, Us? Gentrifiers?
description: If the wind is right, the scent of chocolate will waft up 35th Street in Brooklyn from the waterfront toward the commercial strip of Sunset Park, winding past pornography shops, liquor wholesalers and building-supply warehouses. Once you pass under the Gowanus Expressway, there is no mistaking it, even amid the exhaust of the 18-wheelers jockeying for position on the cobblestone streets in front of the loading docks of Industry City.

title: Easing Into Leisure, One Step at a Time
description: At 54, Jack M. Guttentag decided to downsize. His children had grown, and he and his wife thought they should prepare for the future and move from their townhouse in Philadelphia to something countrified, a few dozen miles west in Valley Forge, Pa.

title: For Bond Investors, Ignoring Expert Advice Has Been Profitable
description: OVER the last three or four Januarys, the advice for investing in bonds has been remarkably consistent. Its gone something like this: Beware of them, because inflation is going to rise, interest rates are going to spike and bond holders are going to lose enormous amounts of money. When it came to losses, comparisons were made to what happened to equities in 2008.

title: Jared Letos Oscar Selfie Update
description: Among this weeks most retweeted Oscar-related messages was one from Jared Leto, the actor-musician who was on the edge of the original Oscar selfie  but got a do-over courtesy of The Simpsons:

title: Saudi King, 90, Hospitalized; Pneumonia Is Diagnosed
description: Uncertainty about the longevity of Saudi Arabias king intensified on Friday with the announcement that he was battling pneumonia and needed temporary help from a breathing tube.

title: American Cinema Editors Release Their Nominees
description: The American Cinema Editors have announced their Eddie Award nominations. A tie resulted in six nominees for best edited drama. The complete list, including television nominees, is here.

title: PJ Harvey Turns Her Album Into an Art Installation
description: Bringing a touch of Marina Abramovic to the music industry, the musician PJ Harvey is turning her next album into a public art installation. This month, Ms. Harvey, the Mercury-award winning British songwriter and vocalist, will record her ninth album behind a one-way mirror at Somerset House, a cultural center in London.

title: How Times Reporters Unraveled the Ebola Epidemic
description: Celia W. Dugger, deputy science editor for health, has helped to coordinate the Timess coverage of Ebola. She edited a feature published Tuesday on the origin of this years Ebola outbreak, and shares how the story came together after months of reporting.

title: A Closer Look at the Colorado Senate Race
description: Colorado was the state that got away from Republicans in 2010 when Michael Bennet, the Democrat, won a come-from-behind victory. Yet if any Republican Senate win in 2014 was symbolic of the completeness of that partys victory on Nov. 4, it was Cory Gardners in Colorado.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking
description: The champagne has been popped and the Times Square confetti (mercifully) cleared away. Yet as we say goodbye to 2014, it seems too early to tell if the past 12 months set the stage for strong economic growth in 2015 or were merely a momentary burst of activity before a global slowdown. This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar take a look at some of the major events and storylines of the past year and make predictions for tomorrows financial headlines. Plus, a dive into the rumored tech bubble.

title: Jim Harrison: A Prairie Prologue in Nebraska
description: In 1954, as an impetuous, irascible 16-year-old, I got my first view quite by accident of Nebraskas Sand Hills. In my sophomore year of high school it had occurred to me that the lakes and forests of Michigan were too small for my burgeoning personality. I was an athlete of sorts, a student leader, but also an addict of Faulkner and James Joyce. Throw in Rimbaud and Dostoyevsky and I was an absurdly premature powder keg and felt I should look in a far field.

title: More Sanctions on North Korea After Sony Case
description: The Obama administration doubled down on Friday on its allegation that North Koreas leadership was behind the hacking of Sony Pictures, announcing new, if largely symbolic, economic sanctions against 10 senior North Korean officials and the intelligence agency it said was the source of many of North Koreas major cyberoperations.

title: Funeral for Mario Cuomo Is Set for Tuesday
description: The funeral for Mario M. Cuomo, the former governor, will be held at 11 a.m. on Tuesday at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola on the Upper East Side.

title: Britains Success Story
description: Simon Wren-Lewis asks how good British economic recovery  which is being touted as a wonderful success story  really has been. Not very, he says. Indeed. Heres a comparison of the UK with two other major economies since 2007:

title: Departing Members Urge Congress to Govern
description: Partisanship is easy; governing is the hard part.

title: Lines to Speak and to Savor
description: Birdman

title: A First at the Garden Earns an Encore
description: The game is a distant but shining beacon, its significance magnified across four decades of growth. But the first womens college basketball game at Madison Square Garden was initially just a showdown between fierce rivals, producing a winner, a loser and acute memories of how the result came about.

title: Park Avenue Penthouse in a Rosario Candela Building
description: An elegant three-level penthouse with two terraces at 775 Park Avenue that has been lovingly restored in homage to the buildings original architect, Rosario Candela, is poised to enter the market at $40 million.

title: Palestinians Submit Papers to U.N. to Join International Criminal Court
description: UNITED NATIONS  The Palestinian ambassador to the United Nations, Riyad H. Mansour, formally submitted papers for the Palestinians to join the treaty creating the International Criminal Court, paving the way for the tribunal to potentially investigate serious crimes on Palestinian lands committed by either side in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

title: Big Bang to Be Investigated From Balloon in Antarctica
description: Cosmologists celebrated the new year by launching a new experiment on a balloon in Antarctica to investigate the Big Bang.

title: Brahms From Different Batons
description: Over the last few years, Riccardo Chailly and Christian Thielemann have been engaged in a quiet, almost implicit battle for the soul of the orchestral repertoire. Both pursue a markedly different style of conducting. Both relate to tradition in conflicting ways, even as they work with some of the oldest orchestras. And both, as if to confound the stories told about the industry today, have their recordings lavishly presented by major record labels.

title: The Olden Days, With Nymphs and Trolls
description: For more than half a century, Americans have felt a kind of fascination for Danish dancers. The attraction dates at least to the 1950s, when a small group from the Royal Danish Ballet traveled to the Jacobs Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass., for the first time. At those performances, audiences and critics were charmed by the companys buoyant dancing, amiable stage manner and seemingly natural acting abilities. The most celebrated ballets were by August Bournonville, a 19th-century choreographer in the Romantic vein who has come to define the Danish style. An ensemble of 13 dancers from the company, led by the principal dancer Ulrik Birkkjaer, will perform a program of Bournonville excerpts at the Joyce Theater in Manhattan from Jan. 13 to 18.

title: Children at Weddings Dont Forever Hold Their Peace
description: The scene: A little flower girl at a wedding is given the cue to begin walking up the aisle and drop the rose petals in her basket, one by one, along the way. The wrinkle: She forgets about the rose petals until she reaches the top of the aisle, at which point she takes the basket, upends it and dumps all the petals in a heap on the floor.

title: Wait, You Need to Suffer Some More
description: Which master managed, as Beethoven did in his late music, to weld together present, past and future, the sublime and the profane? Alfred Brendel wrote in his recent book for piano aficionados, A Pianists A-Z  aptly describing music whose depth prompts even the most expressive virtuosos to delay performing it, saying, Im not ready.

title: A Crash Course in Airbnb
description: When the 1962 Ford Galaxie convertible cruised up the hill, my car-crazy son Caleb, 15, was behind the wheel, a giddy smile on his face.

title: Playing Jams
description: Ricardo Steak House is an unapologetic party spot, attracting people of all walks, races and ages.

title: At Ricardo Steak House, Theyre Gonna Party Like Its Your Birthday
description: Just north of 110th Street, on a stretch of Second Avenue with a pawnshop, a laundromat and a couple of bodegas, a single velvet rope at No. 2145 signals something out of the ordinary. On a recent cold night, a bouncer kept a watchful eye while two hostesses, wearing short dresses despite the temperature, swiped their tablets touch screens, trying to free up space inside.

title: A Full Floor at One57 for $52.9 Million
description: A full-floor apartment on the 84th floor of the glass-sheathed One57 tower, with panoramic water, park and city vistas, sold for $52,952,500 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: A Primer in House Sitting
description: I am living the life of the rich and famous, although I am neither.

title: Gay Marriage Prompts Call for Clergy to Shun Civil Ceremonies
description: If you read wedding announcements, you may have noticed that members of the clergy do not matter as much as they used to. More and more people are married by judges, or justices of the peace, or friends who get officiating privileges from the state. Others use what we might call clergy lite, ordained by online services like the Universal Life Church, which has but two tenets  To promote freedom of religion and To do that which is right  and requires only your name and email address and a promise that you are over the age of 13.

title: Rocking a Speedo and a Spatula
description: The actor Ebon Moss-Bachrach has been kicking around Brooklyn for 15 years, since just after college at Columbia University. So a few years ago, when he heard about an HBO pilot called Girls, chronicling post-collegiate life in the borough, it seemed like the perfect fit. I was begging my agents to get me an audition, and they couldnt, he recalled.

title: Home Exchange 101
description: The offers pop into my inbox: Come stay in my villa in Tuscany. Bordeaux is beautiful in the spring, and our country house has a pool. Wouldnt you like to come to Rio and use my place at the beach? Each one ignites its own little fantasy: drinking coffee in the garden of a French chateau from a big, chipped cup, so chic it doesnt have to be perfect. Waving to George and Amal in their speedboat on Lake Como. Coming home at night to cocktails on the terrace of my cutting-edge London apartment.

title: Theres No Place Like Homes
description: Have you heard of Airbnb? Of course you have. Have you used it to book your vacation lodging? Probably not.

title: Roaring Down an Unlikely Path to Romance
description: Margie Goldsmith is known for her firecracker energy and a keen sense of adventure. One friend recalled that the lithe Ms. Goldsmith entered a triathlon in Cuba so that she could explore the country on an athletes visa. Another remembered that after she learned the rudiments of playing blues harp, she would perform exuberantly on her harmonica at every opportunity  with Pygmies in Uganda, at a pub in Ireland, at a bar in New York.

title: All Aboard
description: A group want to bring rides to the Bronx and New York City as a way to repurpose stretches of little-used or abandoned railroad tracks for recreational use.

title: In the Bronx, Test-Driving a Plan to Open Railroad Tracks to the Public
description: The three-minute ride was just long enough to give a taste of what could be.

title: A Kingdom of Jousting, Kidnapping and Some Saucy Singing, Too
description: Television sure is eager to appropriate the stage musical form lately, and ABC makes a saucy, silly attempt on Sunday with Galavant, an eight-episode comic series featuring men in armor and devious damsels. Despite some amusing bits and clever songs, its only occasionally as much fun as it ought to be.

title: Unruly Factions Hurt Talibans Bid to Capture Afghan Hearts, and Territory
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A series of kidnappings and robberies struck northern Helmand Province this summer, paralyzing residents and embarrassing the Taliban leaders who controlled the area.

title: On, or Just Near, the Ice at Brookfield Place
description: Brookfield Place, the riverfront development formerly known as the World Financial Center, offers views to the east of Santiago Calatravas massively over-budget PATH station; to the west, the sun setting over the Hudson River; and to the middle, Hudson Eats, a food court that has the rare good taste not to blast bad music.

title: Argentina Agrees to Extradite American Who Sought Asylum
description: INTENDENTE ALVEAR, Argentina  An American who sought refuge in Argentina after he was accused of killing his wife in 2002 should be sent back to the United States, Argentinas Supreme Court announced this week.

title: Sharon Isbin: Seeking Out Serenity
description: Sharon Isbins living room is decorated with two Grammy Awards and a keepsake from her time performing in the Amazon: a handcrafted poison-dart gun. (It does not work.) She lives on the Upper West Side with a view of the Hudson River and of a statue of her heroine, Eleanor Roosevelt. Ms. Isbin, a 58-year-old classical guitarist, has been a trailblazer both for female musicians and for the guitars place in the classical music world. She is the director of guitar programs at the Juilliard School and at the Aspen Music Festival, and will tour again this spring. A documentary on public television, Sharon Isbin: Troubadour, explores her musical beginnings in Italy, her teenage years in Minnesota and her lifelong collaborations with composers.

title: Steven Gerrard Will Leave Liverpool, Perhaps for M.L.S.
description: Steven Gerrard, the longtime Liverpool captain, announced Friday that he would leave the club that he has supported and played for since he was a boy when his contract expires at the end of the season.

title: India Says Men on Pakistani Boat Set Off Explosion in Arabian Sea
description: NEW DELHI  India said on Friday that its coast guard had intercepted a suspicious Pakistan-based fishing boat at sea late on New Years Eve, but that when Indian officers approached the vessel to investigate, four men aboard the boat set off an explosion and major fire that completely destroyed the vessel.

title: At the Racetrack
description: Theo Zierock photographed bettors at Aqueduct Racetrack in Queens, where they gamble for gamblings sake, he said.

title: Photographs at Aqueduct Racetrack: Where Horses Race, but No One Wins
description: Thoroughbred horse racing provides one of the great American spectacles: the magnificently chiseled athletes, the elemental contest of speed and power, the libidinal rush of personal fortunes won or lost by the margins of a split second.

title: The Paradox of the Free-Market Liberal
description: IN American politics, personality is, supposedly, destiny: Having a conservative personality makes us conservative on economic and social policy, and vice versa for liberals. Think of the stereotypes: the free-spending, libertine liberal; the rock-ribbed, free-market conservative.

title: Pictures of the Day: Sweden and Elsewhere
description: Sweden and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Pictures of the Day  Jan. 2, 2015
description: Photos from Sweden, Indonesia, Italy and the Philippines.

title: Five-Alarm Obsession: A Fire Truck Buff Custom-Builds Models
description: Tom Eve, 63, still remembers the day in 1958 that the firehouse on his South Bronx block got its new pumper: a gleaming new Mack whose cab could fit five firefighters.

title: Who Will Replace Michael Grimm?
description: Congressman Michael Grimm, who pleaded guilty on Dec. 23 to cheating on his taxes when he ran a health food restaurant, has finally realized that he can no longer represent his New York City district 100 per cent. The Republican from Staten Island announcedearlier this week that he would resign from Congress onJan. 5because it is time for him to start the next chapter of my life.

title: For Writer, Talent Finally Succeeds Where Chance Failed
description: BROOKLINE, Mass.  On a recent drizzly afternoon, the short-story writer Edith Pearlman sat reminiscing in the living room of her apartment here with her best friend, Sandy Siler, a retired psychoanalyst.

title: Next Men Up? Cardinals
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  Two hours before the Cardinals played perhaps their biggest regular-season home game in their 27 years in Arizona, Michael Bidwill raced around University of Phoenix Stadium trying to pump up the crowd.

title: Bill Cunningham | Global Debutantes
description: The debutantes resembled orchids in their dresses, which echoed the influence of a recent Charles James exhibition.

title: What Were Reading: Great Reads From the Editors of NYT Now
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Bill Cunningham | Global Debutantes
description: On Dec. 29, the 60th annual International Debutante Ball, which benefited the Soldiers, Sailors, Marines, Coast Guard and Airmens Club, invited young women from Europe, the United States and Asia to the Waldorf-Astoria in New York. The debutantes resembled orchids in their dresses, which echoed the influence of a recent Charles James exhibition. Actual orchids, designed by Anthony and Joseph Silva, set the atmosphere.

title: Evening Hours | Midnight Song
description: An opening at the opera on New Years Eve.

title: In Georgia, a Weekend of TV Highlights
description: The Cloister at Sea Island is celebrating 30 years of TV (rooms there didnt have television sets until 1985) with a trip to the broadcast past.

title: Of Witches, the Forest and Field Hockey
description: Fun is not enough, said the playwright and director Tina Satter, one of downtown theaters most meticulous yet reliably entertaining artists.

title: Ferran Adri Feeds the Hungry Mind
description: One day in November, Ferran Adri, the Spanish chef who turned foods into foams and pioneered a new era in gastronomic innovation while running one of the worlds most popular restaurants, bounced through a loft space in Barcelona. He peered at pencil-sketched mind maps tacked to plastic foam bulletin boards and examined books jammed on narrow shelves  until he reached the end of a display table featuring a variety of Asian soup spoons. Then he stopped.

title: A Craigslist Missed Connection Lure (Updated With Podcast)
description: UPDATED: You can now listen to our Modern Love podcast, featuring Broadway actress Lauren Molina reading this column and a conversation with the writer. Look for the play button below.

title: Paying for Peace
description: Our daughter and son-in-law, a certified 1 percenter, moved to suburbia with their children. They need a second car because he wont take the train to work. Our son lent them his pristine vintage Mercedes, and our daughter got into an accident with it, causing $6,000 of damage. So far, our son-in-law has balked at all estimates for repair and told my son to submit an insurance claim. But our son doesnt want to because his premiums may increase. Harsh words were spoken. Who is right?

title: Literature of India, Enshrined in a Series
description: When the Loeb Classical Library was founded in 1911, it was hailed as a much-needed effort to make the glories of the Greek and Roman classics available to general readers.

title: Selfies Get a Little Help
description: Visitors to Times Square and Rockefeller Center made use of a popular tool for taking self-portraits.

title: Fusillades Piercing a Fog of Dementia
description: LONDON  For Edie and Arthur, an English couple who have lived together on a farm for some 40 years, lifes final horizon seems to have reared up with an alarming suddenness. The days and years have passed by uneventfully for this contented and very settled pair, for whom even holidays were rare events. But now Edies mind has begun to falter. She cant move very well, but more distressingly, words dont come as easily as they once did, and when they do, they may not be the ones intended.

title: A Deal From the SportAccord World Mind Games
description: At the fourth SportAccord World Mind Games last month in Beijing, two pair events followed the team competitions.

title: The Selfie Stick Takes Manhattan
description: If the throngs of tourists who congregate each December in Times Square and Rockefeller Plaza were not conspicuous enough, the selfie stick took matters to new heights this holiday season. On the last day of the year, you could barely walk through New Yorks most touristy areas without getting poked or prodded by the latest craze in digital accessories.

title: Bitcoin Foundation Parts Ways With Its Global Policy Counsel
description: Jim Harper, whose appointment as the Bitcoin Foundations global policy counsel last March was viewed as a sign that the advocacy group was taking digital currency regulation seriously, has been dismissed from the foundation.

title: Virgin Conceives; Network Profits
description: It is the tale of a 23-year-old named Jane, a virgin, who becomes pregnant after she is artificially inseminated  accidentally.

title: Oscars 2015: Stephen Holdens Picks
description: For the major categories of the Oscars, the New York Times film critics composed a list of films they would like to see nominated. Stephen Holdens choices are below. Manohla Dargiss choices are here and A. O. Scotts choices are here.

title: Oscars 2015: A. O. Scotts Picks
description: For the major categories of the Oscars, the New York Times film critics composed a list of films they would like to see nominated. A. O. Scotts choices are below. Manohla Dargiss choices are here and Stephen Holdens choices are here.

title: Oscars 2015: Manohla Dargiss Picks
description: For the major categories of the Oscars, the New York Times film critics composed a list of films they would like to see nominated. Manohla Dargiss choices are below. A. O. Scotts choices are here and Stephen Holdens choices are here.

title: The Team Behind the N.F.L.s No More Campaign
description: This National Football League season got off to a disastrous off-the-field start. In early September, TMZ published a video of Baltimore Ravens running back Ray Rice punching his fiance (and now wife), Janay Palmer, in an elevator. Days later, Minnesota Vikings running back Adrian Peterson was charged with child abuse for striking his son with a tree branch. The Associated Press named the N.F.L.s domestic violence problem the top sports story of 2014, ahead of Donald Sterlings racist comments and LeBron Jamess return to Cleveland.

title: The Unending Anxiety of an ICYMI World
description: In case you missed it, the initials ICYMI stand for the first five words of this sentence. In the event you have, indeed, missed it (ITEYH, I, MI has not taken off yet for some reason), its most likely because youre not on the Internet much, particularly Twitter, where individuals and outlets deploy it every few seconds to bring links to the attention of others who may not have seen them. The New York Times now even has a section at the bottom of its app called In Case You Missed It with articles from previous days.

title: What Isnt There an App For?
description: I am afraid of the Machine. Expose me to banner ads or anticipatory marketing and I am instantly reminded of the inexorable rise of the android; hand me a pair of Google Glass and I am convinced that RoboCop was a documentary.

title: Katherine Waterstons Red Carpet Looks
description: The actress has drawn the fashion worlds attention with her style.

title: Katherine Waterston of Inherent Vice Shyly Captivates the Fashion World
description: Opacity is Katherine Waterstons stock in trade. On screen, her disarmingly childlike features are as hard to read as the fine print on a lease, a quality that has set her apart in a string of film roles, most recently that of Shasta Fay Hepworth, the oddly inscrutable temptress of Paul Thomas Andersons Inherent Vice.

title: How My Mom Got Hacked
description: MY mother received the ransomnote on the Tuesday before Thanksgiving. It popped up on her computer screen soon after shed discovered that all of her files had been locked. Your files are encrypted, it announced. To get the key to decrypt files you have to pay 500 USD. If my mother failed to pay within a week, the price would go up to $1,000. After that, her decryption key would be destroyed and any chance of accessing the 5,726 files on her PC  all of her data  would be lost forever.

title: Suicides Spread Through a Brazilian Tribe
description: FRIENDS and family gathered around the limp body of a 15-year-old boy laid out on a bed in a thatched hut near the Brazilian town of Iguatemi, close to the border with Paraguay. A shaman shook a small wooden rattle while chanting and dancing  final rites for yet another victim of a suicide epidemic that has plagued the Guaran Indians of the western Brazilian state of Mato Grosso do Sul.

title: Thai Cuisine, by Way of Laos
description: Among the colorful textiles and Buddhist temple rubbings that decorate the walls of Green Papaya Thai Restaurant, in Canton, hangs a Hmong story cloth that depicts the flight of refugees from Laos into Thailand. This blue fabric, stitched with images of helicopter gunships and people swimming across the Mekong River, is a subtle clue that Green Papaya is not your run-of-the-mill Thai place.

title: Hairstyles That Ascend, and Aspire, in Nigeria
description: J.D. Okhai Ojeikere captured fleeting hairstyles that he came to see as embodying beauty, knowledge and art.

title: Gasoline-Tax Increase Finds Little Support
description: When gasoline topped $4 a gallon, opponents of an increase in the gas tax argued that prices were already too high.

title: A Time for Traitors
description: TEL AVIV  Here is Amos Oz on writing a novel: It is like reconstructing the whole of Paris from Lego bricks. Its about three-quarters-of-a-million small decisions. Its not about who will live and who will die and who will go to bed with whom. Those are the easy ones. Its about choosing adjectives and adverbs and punctuation. These are molecular decisions that you have to take and nobody will appreciate, for the same reason that nobody ever pays attention to a single note in a symphony in a concert hall, except when the note is false. So you have to work very hard in order for your readers not to note a single false note. That is the business of three-quarters-of-a-million decisions.

title: New Zealand Glaciers Ebb and Tour Guides Play Catch-Up
description: FOX GLACIER, New Zealand  This town of about 300 residents trades on its namesake: a giant slab of ice and snow a short drive from the main street. Guided glacier hiking began here in 1928 and is a main reason for the areas popularity as a destination for international travelers.

title: Friday Night Music: The Boys of Sumer
description: The girls too. And yes, I mean Sumer. As I understand it, this is a (seriously) informed guess at what ancient Sumerian and Babylonian music sounded like. And its quite haunting:

title: Combining Funk and Sophistication
description: Does fried avocado sound like a good idea to you? It didnt to me either. But at the Hudson Room, a happening new space in the heart of Peekskill, it somehow worked. Part of a shrimp and avocado fry that included expertly fried Gulf shrimp and chunks of avocado with a side of spicy mustard rmoulade, vegetables and brown rice, the bowl captured the feel of the restaurant: Funky meets sophisticated.

title: Rikers Inmate Found Dead Despite Suicide-Watch Alert
description: The warning was sent at 4:45 p.m. on New Years Eve: A Rikers Island inmate, distraught over an imminent prison sentence, was threatening to harm himself and was possibly suicidal.

title: Where the Pho Cures All
description: Never have I had a holiday-induced ailment that a steaming bowl of pho at Viet Ai in Florham Park could not cure. Every element of this soup is purifying, from the star-anise-scented broth made from beef bones (paleos should love this) to the sprigs of fresh basil served on the side so that you, the diner, may add them, thus minimizing wilt time. Delicate rice noodles swim in the fragrant broth. They amaze me every time I eat them because in this one rendition, they actually taste like rice.

title: Euro Falls Lower as Central Bank Hints at Increase in Stimulus Plan
description: Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, may be pushing hard for a weaker euro to spur growth in Europe, but his central bank peers seem to be several steps ahead of him.

title: The Dcor and Menu: Elegant but Casual
description: Since its opening about three years ago, the Paramount Theater in Huntington has added sparkle to the community. Some of that stardust has drifted to neighboring enterprises like Swallow.

title: Cuba: Performance Artist Is Freed
description: The Cuban performance artist Tania Bruguera was released from custody on Friday after her third arrest this week related to her efforts to push for freedom of expression. Her #YoTambienExijo (I also demand) support group said she returned to her mothers house after being released from a police station, though the authorities had not returned her passport. They told Ms. Bruguera, who divides her time between Cuba, New York and France, that she could not leave the country while resistance and public disorder charges were pending. Several activists among about 50 government opponents detained Tuesday were also released. The crackdown, condemned by the State Department and 1,000 artists who signed a letter on Friday to President Ral Castro, was the largest since the diplomatic thaw between the United States and Cuba was announced Dec. 17.

title: A Glamorous Spa Day for Little Girls
description: The Seriously Spoiled spa in Dix Hills, N.Y., is one of an increasing number of spas that cater to children. A birthday party celebration includes hairstyling, manicures and pizza.

title: After a Spa Day, Looking Years Younger (O.K., Theyre Only 7)
description: AURORA, Colo.  It was a day out at the spa for Paige Ehresman and her closest friends. Manicures. Hairdos. Makeup. And some gossip  about second grade.

title: John W. Hinckley Jr. Wont Face Charges in James Bradys Death
description: John W. Hinckley Jr., who shot and wounded President Ronald Reagan and three others in 1981, will not face charges in the death last summer of James S. Brady, the former White House press secretary, federal prosecutors said Friday.

title: A Doctor Who Denies Hes a Kingpin
description: Good afternoon. Doctor speaking.

title: A Republican Ruse to Make Tax Cuts Look Good
description: LOS ANGELES  AS Republicans take control of Congress this month, at the top of their to-do list is changing how the government measures the impact of tax cuts on federal revenue: namely, to switch from so-called static scoring to dynamic scoring. While seemingly arcane, the change could have significant, negative consequences for enacting sustainable, long-term fiscal policies.

title: When Celebrity Fortunetellers Talk, the Lebanese Listen
description: ADMA, Lebanon  As the clock ticked toward midnight on New Years Eve, Leila Abdel Latif, a Lebanese fortuneteller, sat under the glaring lights of a television studio here and unveiled to viewers across the Arab world what 2015 held in store.

title: Betting on Default
description: Imagine a lender demanding that you miss a payment. That is the situation described in a recent article in The Wall Street Journal. In 2013, GSO Capital Partners, the debt-investing arm of the private equity firm the Blackstone Group, refused to renew a $122.3 million loan to the Spanish gambling company Codere unless it delayed paying interest on other existing debt. Why? It turns out that GSO had placed a bet that Coderes existing debt would not be paid on time. When, lo and behold, the payment was late, GSO collected on its bet.

title: Win for ESPN, but Title Game Is the Real Test
description: For the $7.3 billion it is pouring into the new College Football Playoff over 12 years, ESPN surely wants a spectacular payoff. The return on investment was to begin with big viewership for the semifinal games on New Years Day, followed by even more viewers for the title game on Jan. 12.

title: From the Bands Music, the Weight Builds a Future
description: Gamely traversing his native Woodstock on a rainy weekday recently, the guitarist Jim Weider pointed out its onetime cultural hot spots, ending at Levon Helm Studios, which stands as a wooden shrine to its creator, the co-founder of the Band and a latter-day link to Woodstocks post-festival heyday.

title: A Calligrapher Brings an Elegant Touch to an Officers Funeral
description: The man placed a hand on the paper as gently as a doctor feeling for a pulse. With his other hand he dipped a bamboo brush into a bowl of ink, turning the thirsty bristles black, then brought its tip to the papers surface.

title: Seat of Bostons Catholic Power Gives Way to Other Pursuits
description: BOSTON  The house on the rise has long been a symbol of Catholicism in Boston. When it was built, its grandeur demonstrated the wherewithal of the citys newly powerful Roman Catholic community. When it was sold, the transaction reflected the straits of a once-powerful archdiocese brought low by scandal.

title: In Sweden, the Land of the Open Door, Anti-Muslim Sentiment Finds a Foothold
description: ESKILSTUNA, Sweden  As Khalif Samantar knelt for afternoon prayers at theEskilstuna Islamic Dawa Centeron Christmas Day, he sensed a growing heat and a low, rushing sound coming from a nearby hallway. He focused his mind on the ritual, only to realize seconds later that someone was shouting, The mosque is on fire!

title: Donna Douglas, the Fairest Beverly Hillbilly, Dies at 82
description: Donna Douglas, who played the shapely, blue-eyed daughter of the suddenly wealthy mountaineer Jed Clampett on The Beverly Hillbillies, the wildly popular television sitcom of a half-century ago, died on Thursday in Baton Rouge, La.

title: As Refugee Tide Swells, Lebanon Plans a Visa Requirement for Syrians
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  For the first time since colonial powers carved Syria and Lebanon into separate countries, Syrians will soon need visas to enter Lebanon, the latest and most significant in a series of new measures by Syrias neighbors to try to control an overwhelming flow of refugees that appears unlikely to end any time soon.

title: Mario Cuomos Life in Public Service
description: Mario Cuomo, the former governor of New York, came on the political scene with a surpassing idealism about the potential of government and a passion for defending its power to address the plights and hopes of ordinary citizens. Well before his three terms ended, he had become an eloquent champion of those values for the entire country.

title: Hong Kong Slaughters Chickens After an Outbreak of Bird Flu
description: HONG KONG  Hong Kong health officials have slaughtered thousands of chickens from mainland China, closed one wholesale market and banned imports of live poultry after tests found some birds were infected with a strain of bird flu.

title: One Last Confluence for Mario and Andrew Cuomo, Proud Rivals
description: New Years Day was to be a day of triumph and celebration for Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo. He was being sworn in for a second term not once but twice, in Manhattan and in Buffalo, with a stirring speech that heralded the accomplishments of his first term and laid out an aggressive agenda for the next four years.

title: Science Fuels the Writing, and Faith, of a Nicaraguan Poet
description: MEXICO CITY  ERNESTO CARDENAL is a poet and a priest, a revolutionary and a mystic. His poetry speaks of Marilyn Monroe and Charles Darwin, of Spanish conquistadors and pre-Columbian gods. Science saturates his writing.

title: N.F.L. Playoffs, as Seen From Below .500
description: Many roads can lead to the N.F.L. playoffs. Some teams get there with offense, others with defense or special teams. Some have depth, while others ride a superstar through the regular season.

title: New Jersey Schoolgirl Samplers, Like a Stitch Out of Time
description: By todays academic standards, the schoolwork stitched onto the 151 samplers that comprise the Hail Specimen of Female Art! New Jersey Schoolgirl Needlework, 1726-1860 exhibition at Morven Museum and Garden here might not be A-plus-worthy.

title: Jimmy Dickens, an Outsize Country Singer, Dies at 94
description: NASHVILLE  Little Jimmy Dickens, the diminutive but big-voiced country singer best known for his novelty recordings and his self-deprecating sense of humor, died on Friday at a hospital here. He was 94.

title: Albany Lawmakers and Their Secret Incomes
description: It has taken far too long, but federal authorities are finally asking the right questions about how New Yorks part-time lawmakers make money apart from their legislative salaries. The Times reported Tuesday that investigators are examining substantial secret payments from a small law firm to one of New Yorks most powerful politicians, Speaker Sheldon Silver of the Assembly. So far, there has been no real explanation from Mr. Silver.

title: Dazing SEC Titans, Big Ten Lives Up to Its Adjective
description: NEW ORLEANS  With less than two minutes left in the Sugar Bowl on Thursday night, Ohio State, ahead by 7 points and having just recovered an onside kick by Alabama, tried a deep pass along the left sideline  Ohio States sideline.

title: Many Identities of New York Officers Killer in a Life of Wrong Turns
description: His entire life, Ismaaiyl Brinsley tried on identities as if they were new clothes. He was a bad boy with a gun, a fashionable man in Gucci and Cartier, a T-shirt maker, a film director, a screenwriter, a devout Muslim, a rap producer.

title: Domestic Discombobulation in an Odd Kitchen
description: One sunny morning, John ODonnell was making coffee when, from the corner of his eye, he was diverted by a ray of light glinting off a pan in his dish drainer. I was shocked, he said. I spent more time than I ever had looking at my dish rack.

title: A Ring Sparks Speculation That North Korean Leaders Sister Has Married
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The younger sister of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, was shown in the North Korean media wearing a ring on her left ring finger on Friday, prompting speculation that she may have recently married.

title: Helping Holocaust Artifacts Tell Their Stories
description: A shoe. A light bulb. A beer stein. An accordion. A concentration camp uniform.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 2, 2015
Eschewing a Higher Calling
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Have you ever traveled to a new town with no real plan for exploring and just meandered along the streets, taking in the sights as you go? I love doing that, because its the best way to stumble upon the hidden jewels that a town has to offer. Thats precisely how solving Sam Ezerskys fine puzzle felt to me. I wandered around his grid, laughing and learning as I went, and that is the best possible outcome one can hope for on a Saturday.

title: Hillary Versus History
description: When Hillary Clinton thinks about running for president, do you think she contemplates the fact that no Democrat has been elected to succeed another Democrat since James Buchanan in 1856?

title: The Legion of Honor? Thomas Piketty Refuses
description: Sometimes an award means more to the giver than the recipient. That is probably the case with the French governments decision to give the Legion of Honor to Thomas Piketty, the economist and author of the critically acclaimed book about inequality, Capital in the Twenty-First Century, who says he doesnt want the award.

title: New York City Requiring Flu Shots for Preschoolers
description: New York City preschoolers will be heading back to class next week with memories of new holiday toys, vacation adventures, and, health officials hope, a flu shot.

title: A.F.C. Wild-Card Matchup: Baltimore Ravens vs. Pittsburgh Steelers
description: Ravens (10-6) at Steelers (11-5)

title: N.F.C. Wild-Card Matchup: Arizona Cardinals vs. Carolina Panthers
description: Cardinals (11-5) at Panthers (7-8-1)

title: The Abortion Stereotype
description: DAVIS, Calif.  ITS been widely observed that in recent elections men have leaned Republican and women Democratic. A key element of that gender gap is often assumed to be a difference in attitudes to womens reproductive rights.

title: No Turned Backs at Officer Lius Funeral, Bratton Asks
description: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton urged New York City police officers on Friday not to turn their backs when Mayor Bill de Blasio appears on Sunday at the funeral of an officer who was killed on duty in Brooklyn last month.

title: Miller Williams, Plain-Spoken Arkansas Poet, Dies at 84
description: Miller Williams, a poet who championed the power of everyday language and who delivered a poem at the Capitol for President Bill Clintons second inauguration, died on Thursday in Fayetteville, Ark. He was 84.

title: Mario Cuomo: The Liberal Idealist
description: To the Editor:

title: After an Attack, a Mans Options Slowly Fade
description: Along Main Street in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., the occasional landmark was a backdrop to commuting cyclists, bundled against an early December chill. A few men leaned against mull posts outside storefronts with boarded-up windows. Where the glass remained unbroken, hand-lettered signs hung outside family-owned businesses: Tenemos pan! one read.

title: Serge Hochar, Producer of Lebanese Wines, Dies at 75
description: Serge Hochar, who navigated Chateau Musar, his familys winery in Lebanon, through 15 years of civil war as Musar became one of the most admired wine producers in the world, died on Wednesday in Acapulco, Mexico. He was 75.

title: The Trouble With Common Core Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: The Souths Newcomers
description: To the Editor:

title: Rajon Rondo Stars in Boston, Wearing Blue This Time
description: BOSTON  Reunions represent the high point of the Celtics schedule these days. The team does not win much  it is 11-19  but it has learned during the past few seasons how to pay tribute to its former players and coaches.

title: A Toddler and a Gun
description: To the Editor:

title: Denied Entry to Egypt
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks, Desperate for Points and Bodies, Fall Again
description: Before the Knicks heard resounding boos in the second quarter, missed their first 11 shots in the third and fell behind by 30 points in the fourth, before all of this on Friday, Coach Derek Fishers pregame question-and-answer session veered into the absurd.

title: Girl, 7, Survives Kentucky Plane Crash That Killed 4, Police Say
description: A 7-year-old girl walked away from a small-plane crash on Friday that killed four people, including two children, in southwest Kentucky, according to the authorities.

title: Chinas Crime-Free Crime Films
description: HONG KONG  A FEW years back I got a call from a film director based in China who had read one of my detective novels. Can you help me write a screenplay for a crime story? he asked. The tricky thing is that its set in Beijing, so no crime can be involved.

title: Whats on TV Saturday
description: 3:40 P.M. (HBO Signature) THE TRUTH ABOUT CHARLIE (2002) In Jonathan Demmes remake of the 1963 comic thriller Charade, Thandie Newton steps into the Audrey Hepburn role as a new wife who returns to her Paris apartment to break it off with her art-dealing husband, Charlie, only to find the place ransacked. She soon discovers that nothing is as it seems. Mark Wahlberg, in the role originated by Cary Grant, portrays the charming stranger eager to help; Tim Robbins is the man she turns to at the United States Embassy. The sensual, butter-voiced Ms. Newton is so good that when shes on screen, the movie works  or at least you think it does, Elvis Mitchell wrote in The New York Times. Its a spot-specific case of alchemy.

title: Corrections: January 3, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day
description: They do deserve something special. I dont want them to feel that my saying no means that I dont love them.

title: Qaeda Suspect Facing Trial in New York Over Africa Embassy Bombings Dies
description: A Libyan suspected of being an operative for Al Qaeda who was captured by United States commandos in Libya in 2013 and brought to New York to face trial died in government custody on Friday night after complications from longstanding medical problems, prosecutors said.

title: Five Arrested in India Rape Case
description: NEW DELHI  Five men have been arrested in connection with the alleged abduction and rape of a Japanese woman who said she was held captive for 12 days, the Indian police said Saturday.

title: Penn Station: A Place That Once Made Travelers Feel Important
description: If you dont enjoy arriving in or departing from New York City through the squalid cavern known as Pennsylvania Station, you can blame  at least for a start  the desperate executives, short on public spirit, who tried to prop up the money-losing Pennsylvania Railroad in the 1950s.

title: If You Want to Meet That Deadline, Play a Trick on Your Mind
description: Its just a few days into the new year. How are you doing on your resolutions? Wait: Have you even started on them yet?

title: Learning a Foreign Language Called Public Relations
description: It was an odd phone call, a request out of the blue to ghostwrite a book for a man whod read a magazine column of mine.

title: Racial Bias, Even When We Have Good Intentions
description: The deaths of African-Americans at the hands of the police in Ferguson, Mo., in Cleveland and on Staten Island have reignited a debate about race. Some argue that these events are isolated and that racism is a thing of the past. Others contend that they are merely the tip of the iceberg, highlighting that skin color still has a huge effect on how people are treated.

title: Maynard Webb, Yahoos Chairman: Even the Best Teams Can Be Better
description: This interview with  Maynard Webb, a veteran technology executive whose current roles include serving as chairman of Yahoo, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Whole Foods High Hurdle for Investors
description: Shareholders own the companies they invest in, but they have long been largely shut out of any role in naming the people who are supposed to represent them: corporate directors.

title: Maintaining Rent-Stabilized Status
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Variety: Takeaway
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  The Variety puzzles are a lovely breath of fresh air from our daily crosswords, unless they make your brain hurt. It took me a few tries to get into Matt Ginsbergs Takeaway puzzle, but get into it I did. Once my brain stopped hurting.

title: Resolving to Create a New You
description: THE annual ritual of the New Years resolution  Ill lose 10 pounds, get my finances in order, be more patient with my family, feel more grateful  misses the point. We try to steel our wills to do what we already know we should be doing. Kick-in-the-pants reminders, however stern, are missed opportunities for genuine self-renewal. (Not to mention that the shelf life of any motivational juice we generate in January tends to expire in February.)

title: Obama Plans 3-Day Tour to Preview State of the Union
description: HONOLULU  President Obama plans to spend the weeks leading up to his State of the Union speech traveling across the country to promote different themes from it, a new approach by the commander in chief to the annual address to Congress.

title: The Liberation of Growing Old
description: LONDON  WHY do we have such punitive attitudes toward old people? Granted, the ancients did hideous things to elders who were unable to work but still needed food and care, but in more recent times, that had changed: In 18th-century New England, it was common for people to make themselves seem older by adding years to their real age, rather than subtracting them.

title: Healthy and Hungry Again
description: LOS ANGELES  It was almost 2015, and Victoria Azarenka was parked in her sleek sport utility vehicle on a Beverly Hills street with the rain drumming on the windshield as she spoke about how it felt to no longer be above the rest, to be ranked No. 31 instead of No. 1.

title: Heavyweight Response to Local Fracking Bans
description: LONGMONT, Colo.  This northern Colorado city vaulted onto the front lines of the battle over oil and gas drilling two years ago, when residents voted to ban hydraulic fracturing from their grassy open spaces and a snow-fed reservoir where anglers catch smallmouth bass.

title: Confessions of a Columnist
description: IN the new year, it goes without saying that we should all eat more vegetables, exercise more often, tweet or text a little less and pray a little more. But for the professional pundit, theres really only one resolution that matters: Be less wrong.

title: Islanders Enjoy a Raucous Advantage in Their Soon-to-Be Former Home
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  As the Islanders final home game of 2014 began, Tom LoFaso stood poised in the next-to-last row of Section 329 surrounded by dozens of his orange-and-blue-clad brethren.

title: Radical Islam, Nihilist Rage
description: LONDON  FACED with a horror like the slaughter of 148 schoolchildren and school staff members by the Taliban in Pakistan, it is tempting to describe the act as inhuman or medieval. What made the massacre particularly chilling, though, is that it was neither. The killings were all too human and of our time.

title: After Killing of Gaza Teenager, Calls for Egyptian Inquiry
description: GAZA  Palestinian officials are demanding that the Egyptian government investigate the fatal shooting of a 16-year-old boy from Gaza who they say was killed by Egyptian soldiers, condemning what the officials called excessive force against a teenager who had been crossing the frontier to find work.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: Indian and Pakistani Guards Trade Fire on Disputed Border
description: NEW DELHI  Indian and Pakistani border guards exchanged fire along the disputed northern border in the state of Jammu and Kashmir, leaving at least two people dead and at least one other wounded, officials said Saturday.

title: Anthony Doerr
description: Anthony Doerr is a fiction writer living in Boise, Idaho, whose most recent novel is All the Light We Cannot See.

title: Obama Is the Nations Private Golfer in Chief
description: HONOLULU  President Obamas drives were consistently short. It often took him one shot too many to get his ball on the green. And when he finally took out his putter, he struggled with his touch.

title: Filling Garden With Misery and, at Least for Now, Fans
description: Milton and Anthony Tembelis, cousins from Queens, were eating pastrami and turkey sandwiches at a table for two Friday night in a concourse at Madison Square Garden.

title: Playing Dumb on Climate Change
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  SCIENTISTS have often been accused of exaggerating the threat of climate change, but its becoming increasingly clear that they ought to be more emphatic about the risk. The year just concluded is about to be declared the hottest one on record, and across the globe climate change is happening faster than scientists predicted.

title: Two Stars Dont Start, and the Nets Thrive
description: In the last few seasons, the Nets have developed a habit of making midseason turnarounds after making major personnel changes. Two seasons ago, they went 35-19 after Avery Johnson was fired as coach. Last season, they closed the season with a 34-17 record after adjusting to the loss of Brook Lopez. Having defeated the Magic in Orlando on Friday night, the Nets have won six of their last seven games.

title: Faces of Worship
description: Readers discuss an essay about religious practices that dont center on a belief in God.

title: Turkeys President Traces a New Internal Threat: The Way Hes Drawn
description: ISTANBUL  In the cartoon, an image of Recep Tayyip Erdogan stands watch while two thieves empty a safe full of cash. No need to rush, one of the thieves says with a grin. We have a holographic watchman, he adds.

title: The Afghan Presidents Overreach
description: President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan is known for occasionally being hot-tempered. But it was nonetheless baffling to Western diplomats when, in recent days, he abruptly demanded that the United Nations Development Program, the agency that manages hundreds of millions of dollars provided by Western donors to run the police force, relinquish responsibility for the fund within six months.

title: A Weary Greece Considers Its Options
description: The human toll of the economic crisis in Greece has been significant: Rates of hunger, suicide and unemployment have increased sharply, thanks to years of misguided austerity policies. So it is hardly shocking that polls are showing that voters are likely to give control of Parliament to the leftist political party Syriza in an election later this month.

title: Brazen Attempts by Hotels to Block Wi-Fi
description: Some large hotel chains want to  block guests from using their own wireless Internet devices. Its a blatant attempt to limit customer choice, and the Federal Communications Commission should say no.

title: F.B.I. Employees With Ties Abroad See Security Bias
description: WASHINGTON  The F.B.I. is subjecting hundreds of its employees who were born overseas or have relatives or friends there to an aggressive internal surveillance program that started after Sept. 11, 2001, to prevent foreign spies from coercing newly hired linguists but that has been greatly expanded since then.

title: Are Two Dynasties Our Destiny?
description: JEB and Hillary. Hillary and Jeb. Its getting to the point where a mention of one yields a reference to the other, where theyre semantically inseparable, presidentially conjoined. Should we just go the extra step, save ourselves some syllables and keystrokes? The 2016 matchup as envisioned by many: Jebary. Or, more economically still, Heb.

title: Stanislaw Baranczak, 68, Polish Underground Poet, Dies
description: Stanislaw Baranczak, a Polish poet and essayist who defied state censors to write about living under Communist oppression and who later emigrated to the United States, where he taught at Harvard, wrote in English about living in exile and translated Polish masters into English and English masters into Polish, died on Dec. 26 at his home in Newton, Mass. He was 68.

title: Making the Case for Don Mattingly on His Last Chance for Cooperstown
description: Don Mattingly is the author of one of baseballs most preposterous statistical anomalies. In 1987, he set the major league record (it has since been tied) for most grand slams in a season  six  and those were the only ones he ever hit.

title: Healthy Body, Unhealthy Mind
description: MANY of my friends were shocked some years ago when I cut down on my junk-food intake. Even my wise old physician was a little put out. He had more or less given me the green light to the golden arches a few years before when, one afternoon, following my annual checkup, hed asked me what I consumed every day. A Big Mac, medium fries and Coke for lunch, I answered, and frozen pizza from the convenience store for dinner.

title: As Dallas Cowboys Hit Stride, Tony Romo Pursues His Legacy
description: IRVING, Tex.  At 34, Tony Romo stands at a crossroads of his career and his legacy. There is only one criterion by which to judge what he has accomplished as quarterback of the Dallas Cowboys: Super Bowl appearances.

title: Emotions Flip From Note to Note
description: Almost from the outset of his tenure as music director of the New York Philharmonic, Alan Gilbert has championed the music of the Danish composer Carl Nielsen. This week he conducts performances of Nielsens Clarinet Concerto with the orchestras new principal clarinetist, Anthony McGill, taking on the solo part that flips through emotions ranging from sardonic humor to deep melancholy. The program also includes Ravels Valses nobles et sentimentales and selections from Tchaikovskys Swan Lake. (Thursday, Friday and Saturday, Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, nyphil.org.)

title: New to New York, but Not to Music
description: How could it be possible that Neneh Cherry has never performed in New York before? The song she is most famous for  Buffalo Stance, from the album Raw Like Sushi  was full of self-conscious hip-hop style and smart, joyous, Madonna-like pop, an almost perfect 1989 New York radio record, even if made by a Swedish-British bohemian with meaningful roots outside of the mainstream. (Her stepfather was the jazz trumpeter Don Cherry, and she had already been a member of the important English post-punk bands Rip, Rig + Panic, and the Slits.)

title: Theres More Than Movement
description: Although only one of the two groups sharing the Joyce this week has etc. in its name, both Bodytraffic and Doug Elkins Choreography, Etc. could be called et cetera companies. In their productions, a range of dance and musical forms are added to one another in theatrically rich mixtures.

title: Life Itself, a Documentary
description: A simple biography of the film critic Roger Ebert would have made for a full documentary, but the director Steve James set the bar much higher with Life Itself. The film, receiving its television premiere Sunday night on CNN, covers the life and career of Mr. Ebert, who died in 2013, but it also chronicles the final months of his battle with cancer, his philosophy of criticism, the influence he had on filmmakers and more.

title: The Pains of War, Long After Battle
description: John Huston made his 1946 documentary, Let There Be Light, about soldiers with neuropsychiatric disorders  what we now call post-traumatic stress disorder  for the Army. But the Army banned the film for 35 years. What did it fear? Presumably the power of the soldiers pain and of Hustons movie, which follows a group of soldiers from admission to a hospital through treatment (talk therapy, hypnosis) and rehabilitation to release.

title: Where Housing Is Cheapest
description: Data shows that the least affordable areas lean blue politically.

title: Black History, Told by Works
description: The first work by a black American artist to be acquired by an American museum was Henry Ossawa Tanners luminous The Annunciation (1898), in which the angel Gabriel in the form of a burst of pure light appears to Mary in her humble, typically Middle Eastern bedroom  it entered the collection of the Philadelphia Museum of Art in 1899. The museum has since collected much more art by black Americans. On Jan. 10, it will open Represent: 200 Years of African American Art, an exhibition of about 75 works by more than 50 artists from the museums holdings. The show will include works made by free and enslaved pre-Civil War artists and artisans; early Modernists like William Henry Johnson and Jacob Lawrence; and self-taught artists like William Edmondson, Horace Pippin and Bill Traylor. Glenn Ligon, Martin Puryear, Carrie Mae Weems and other contemporary artists will bring up to date what promises to be an enlightening, kaleidoscopic reflection of black American history and experience. (Through April 5, philamuseum.org.)

title: Is Life Better in Americas Red States?
description: THE new Congress that starts work this week is the latest reminder of Americas stark political divisions: The parties in Washington are more polarized than they have been in decades, the partisanship gap between rural Republicans and urban Democrats has grown, and the battle for suburban voters keeps intensifying. Much less is said, however, about the equally significant economic division between conservative red states and liberal blue states.

title: Indianapolis Colts Offensive Line Remains Fluid
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Anthony Castonzo has been a rock on an ever-shifting beach.

title: When Prisoners Are Patients
description: Its an odd thing, to take care of someone who is chained to a bed, guarded 24/7 by bored corrections officers idling away time with TV and card games, who cannot receive visitors or even phone calls. But it happens when prison inmates are sick enough that they need care that only a hospital can provide.

title: Tensions Mount as Israel Freezes Revenue Meant for Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM  Israel is withholding $127 million in tax revenue it collects for the Palestinian Authority in response to its move last week to join the International Criminal Court, further escalating tensions with a step that could have serious repercussions for both sides.

title: The Next Battle for Ukraine
description: CAN a group of young reformers fix a broken country?

title: Me, Me, Me and My Therapist
description: Just because I go someplace doesnt mean you lost me, Jeffery, my therapist, said. Crouched on the floor, my back to him, I tried not to listen. Its true I do other things, but that doesnt mean I forget you.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Rethinking Business Of College Football

title: With Knicks Crumbling, Maybe Carmelo Anthony Can Heal
description: Carmelo Anthony did not miss a shot against the Detroit Pistons on Friday night. He did not commit a turnover. He was neither outrebounded for putbacks nor caught flat-footed on backdoor cuts. Instead, he occupied a seat behind the bench and watched his teammates do everything wrong without him.

title: Mourners Pay Respects to Wenjian Liu, Officer Slain in Brooklyn
description: A cold rain pelted the long, blue line of police officers that stretched for blocks outside the Aievoli Funeral Home in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn on Saturday.

title: The Economics (and Nostalgia) of Dead Malls
description: OWINGS MILLS, Md.  Inside the gleaming mall here on the Sunday before Christmas, just one thing was missing: shoppers.

title: Edward W. Brooke III, 95, Senate Pioneer, Is Dead
description: Edward W. Brooke III, who in 1966 became the first African-American elected to the United States Senate by popular vote, winning as a Republican in overwhelmingly Democratic Massachusetts, died on Saturday at his home in Coral Gables, Fla. He was 95.

title: N.F.L. Coaches Now Reach for Next Level: College
description: In the early days of his first season in the N.F.L. as the Tennessee Titans offensive coordinator, Norm Chow was in a meeting in which, he recalled, coaches and players were bantering with a rookie, chiding him to pay closer attention. When Chow joined in, the rookie, a recent high draft pick, responded that he had a direct line to the owner.

title: N.F.C. Wild-Card Matchup: Detroit Lions at Dallas Cowboys
description: Lions (11-5) at Cowboys (12-4)

title: Change of Venue Denied for Boston Marathon Bombing Suspect
description: BOSTON  Denying a defense plea for a delay and a change of venue, a divided federal appeals court ruled 2-1 on Saturday that it would not intervene in the scheduled trial of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who is accused in the 2013 bombing of the Boston Marathon. The trial will go ahead as planned here on Monday morning.

title: A.F.C. Wild-Card Matchup: Cincinnati Bengals at Indianapolis Colts
description: Bengals (10-5-1) at Colts (11-5)

title: Infant Found Unconscious in Harlem Dies, Police Say
description: A 23-day-old boy died on Friday after the police found him wounded and unconscious in his familys apartment in East Harlem, the authorities said.

title: Condition of British Ebola Patient Worsens
description: LONDON  A British health worker who is being treated for Ebola in a London hospital is now in critical condition, her doctors said on Saturday.

title: The Descent of Man
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  It was not a surprise to me that Finn Vigeland, who recently graduated from college and is now out in the real world seeking his fortune (or at least a paycheck; I understand that he works in the academic sector), included the word BILDUNGSROMAN in his puzzle.

title: Adviser Guides Obama Into the Google Age
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas top technology adviser cringes when she hears highly educated adults say how bad they are at science and math, particularly when they do so in front of children.

title: Poppies Bloom Again in Myanmar
description: Growing opium poppies is illegal, but farmers see it is a low-risk cash crop and the country has returned as a big player in the heroin trade.

title: G.O.P. Turns to the Courts to Aid Agenda
description: WASHINGTON  As Republicans prepare to take full control of Congress on Tuesday, the partys leaders are counting on judges, not their newly elected majority on Capitol Hill, to roll back President Obamas aggressive second-term agenda and block his executive actions on health care, climate change and immigration.

title: In Myanmar, Harvesting for Heroin
description: A toxic mix of civil war and poverty has driven some Burmese farmers back to the poppy, satisfying a growing global hunger for heroin.

title: Myanmar Returns to What Sells: Heroin
description: BANG LAEM, Myanmar  A decade ago, Myanmar seemed on course to wipe out the opium fields and heroin jungle labs along its eastern border, the notorious Golden Triangle.

title: Ukraine Leader Was Defeated Even Before He Was Ousted
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Ashen-faced after a sleepless night of marathon negotiations, Viktor F. Yanukovych hesitated, shaking his pen above the text placed before him in the chandeliered hall. Then, under the unsmiling gaze of European diplomats and his political enemies, the beleaguered Ukrainian president scrawled his signature, sealing a deal that he believed would keep him in power, at least for a few more months.

title: Doug Marrone Is Said to Interview With Jets
description: As their list of general manager candidates expanded Saturday, the Jets also continued searching for their next coach. Three days after opting out of his contract as coach of the Buffalo Bills, Doug Marrone interviewed with the Jets, a person familiar with the teams thinking said.

title: Putting Life on Pause to Care for Her Parents
description: The person on the other end of the line that day last summer could hear how desperate Susan Bowers sounded.

title: In New York City, a Toll Is Newly Felt as Asians Rise in the Police Ranks
description: Officer Peter Liang is the rookie who fatally shot an unarmed man, in what police officials said was an accident, in the stairwell of an East New York, Brooklyn, housing project.

title: Prince Andrew and Alan Dershowitz Are Mentioned in Suit Alleging Sex With Minor
description: A court filing in a civil case in Florida last week included new allegations against Jeffrey E. Epstein, a businessman who pleaded guilty to soliciting prostitution, and two other high-profile men: a member of the British Royal family and an American lawyer.

title: Despite Loss, Iowa States Transfers Are Flourishing
description: When Fred Hoiberg was in sixth grade, on winter nights he often walked the five blocks from his house in Ames, Iowa, to Hilton Coliseum to work as a ball boy for the Iowa State Cyclones.

title: For Panthers, Only Record That Matters Now Is 1-0
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Much was made of the Carolina Panthers winning the N.F.C. South title. How could a team with a losing record make the playoffs while a 10-win team like the Philadelphia Eagles did not? Shouldnt the N.F.L. overhaul its playoff format?

title: Huckabee Leaves Fox News Show to Consider 2016 Run
description: Mike Huckabee, the former governor of Arkansas, announced Saturday night that he was ending his cable talk show and would make a decision about a presidential bid this spring.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 3, 2015
Poppies Bloom Again in Myanmar
description: Growing opium poppies is illegal, but farmers see it is a low-risk cash crop and the country has returned as a big player in the heroin trade.

title: A Community Responds
description: The fatal shooting of Police Officer Wenjian Liu has prompted many in New Yorks Asian-American community to reflect on the impact of his death among those who share his heritage.
