title: Ravens Top Steelers in Rough Rivalry Game That Upends Playoff Field
description: PITTSBURGH  They tussled after whistles and slapped one another in the head and traded helmet-to-helmet hits, the nastiness ratcheted as skyscraper-high as it had been for every previous installment of this vicious rivalry, the border feud between the Baltimore Ravens and the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: Lauren Gentry and Alidad Damooei
description: Lauren Beauchamp Gentry and Alidad Adam Damooei were married Friday by the Rev. Jarlath Dolan, a Roman Catholic priest, at St. Maximilian Kolbe Church in Westlake Village, Calif.

title: Maureen Mahle and Steven Klocke
description: Maureen McGeary Mahle and Steven Mark Klocke were married Thursday at the Lockwood-Mathews Mansion Museum in Norwalk, Conn. Ray Cooke, a Connecticut justice of the peace, officiated.

title: Jenna McCauley, John Heffernan
description: Jenna Catherine McCauley, the daughter of Catherine G. McCauley and Daniel D. McCauley of Walla Walla, Wash., was married Friday to John Casey Heffernan, a son of Barbara J. Heffernan and John B. Heffernan of Newport Beach, Calif. The Rev. Justin Brady, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Snows Catholic Church in Sun Valley, Idaho.

title: Wayne Cornelius Jr. and Jer Rahn
description: Wayne Armstrong Cornelius Jr. and Doil Jaralin Rahn were married Friday in the Del Mar, Calif., home of Judge Carol Isackson of the San Diego County Superior Court, who officiated.

title: Grier Tumas and Jonathan Dienstag
description: Grier Whitmer Tumas, the daughter of Alison W. Tumas and Michael B. Tumas of Wilmington, Del., was married Saturday to Jonathan Gordon Dienstag, a son of Judy I. Dienstag and Dr. Jules L. Dienstag of Boston. The brides mother, a retired judge of the Family Court of the State of Delaware, officiated at the Hotel du Pont in Wilmington, with William Chapman Jr. and Aida Waserstein, current judges of the court, assisting.

title: Sara Tabor, Cameron Simonds
description: Sara Leigh Tabor, a daughter of Susanne Siben Tabor and David P. Tabor of Marietta, Ga., was married Wednesday to Cameron Ross Simonds, the son of Sandra Saggus Simonds and Gil C. Simonds of Atlanta. The Rev. Craig Goodrich, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Vinoy Renaissance Hotel in St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: Kate Lee, Zachary Seward
description: Kate Laurie Lee and Zachary Moses Seward were married Wednesday by Rabbi Sarah Reines at the Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn.

title: Lindsay Potanka, Matthew Fitzgerald
description: Lindsay Marie Potanka and Matthew Ryan Fitzgerald were married Wednesday at St. Marys Church in New Haven. The Rev. Lawrence Bock, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Jennifer Egan, Paul Isom
description: Dr. Jennifer Anne Egan and Paul Christopher Isom were married Thursday by the Rev. Chris Tuttle at the Westminster Presbyterian Church in Durham, N.C.

title: Judith Ellis Glickman and Leonard Lauder
description: Judith Ellis Glickman and Leonard A. Lauder were married Thursday at the Ritz-Carlton beach club in Sarasota, Fla. Rabbi Brenner J. Glickman, a son of the bride, officiated with his brother Rabbi Jeffrey Glickman, and Rabbi Elaine Rose Glickman, who is married to Rabbi Brenner Glickman.

title: Rebecca Hyman and Bradley Leader
description: Rebecca Danielle Hyman and Bradley Jacques Leader were married Saturday evening in New York at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park. Rabbi Melvin N. Sirner officiated.

title: Corrections: January 4, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: U.S. Health Worker Exposed to Ebola in Sierra Leone Arrives in Nebraska
description: An American health care worker who experienced a high risk of exposure to the Ebola virus while in Sierra Leone was flown to a hospital in Nebraska on Sunday for observation and possible treatment, according to a hospital official.

title: Fire and Ice: Mount Kenyas Lost Glaciers
description: In October, Simon Norfolk went to Mount Kenya to document the gradually disappearing glaciers. Even though the shrinkage of the glacier that he focused on has been well surveyed since 1934, it is difficult to photograph what has already disappeared.

title: North Korea Denounces U.S. Over Its Latest Sanctions
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea denounced the United States on Sunday for imposing new sanctions on it after a cyberattack on Sony Pictures, calling them byproducts of American hostility toward the North.

title: U.S. Drone Strike in Pakistan Is Said to Have Killed 6 Militants
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  At least six foreign militants were believed to have been killed in an American drone strike in the North Waziristan tribal region on Sunday morning, a Pakistani security official said.

title: For the Indie Writers of Amazon, Its Publish or Perish
description: One big argument for all you can eat music, video and book services is that they encourage people to sample new artists and ultimately develop a deeper relationship with a few of them. You listen to songs you have never heard before because there is no additional cost, and then maybe you go to the concert and, perhaps, buy a T-shirt. Artists are rewarded at the end of the process, not in the beginning the way they used to be.

title: In Fervent Support of the Gap Year
description: I wasnt enthusiastic when my daughter first floated her plan to take a gap year before college. As someone who couldnt wait to matriculate, I didnt see the point of delaying that great intellectual awakening. I felt vaguely disappointed that she wasnt more eager to embrace all those books and ideas and late-night conversations about the cosmos. And what if her gap year turned into a permanent crevasse and she never earned a degree?

title: 1940: British Shipping to Be Operated by Government
description: LONDON  The government will take over full control of British and colonial shipping beginning February 1 to obtain more tonnage for national use, the Ministry of Shipping announced tonight [Jan. 4]. All ships of United Kingdom and colonial registry, with the exception of vessels of Indian and Burman registry, will be taken over when they discharge their first cargo in Great Britain after that date. The scheme, identical to the one employed successfully during the World War, will make it possible to operate ships more efficiently and economically because of the community of interests of the British Dominions, it was explained. Such a control system, it was stated, will result in a regular execution of the shipping program for the efficient conduct of the war. The companies will continue to manage and operate their ships as though carrying on their own business but will receive instructions as to the cargoes to be carried and the routes to be followed. They will maintain their organizations in Britain and abroad but will keep an account of costs for the Ministry. Operating profits and losses are to be treated as on government account.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 5, 1940

title: Another Silent Protest of Mayor de Blasio as Officer Liu Is Laid to Rest
description: For the second time in just over a week, a river of pressed blue uniforms filled the streets of a New York City neighborhood on Sunday as law enforcement officers from across the country paid respects to a slain colleague. And for the second time, hundreds of those officers made a silent show of protest against Mayor Bill de Blasio.

title: Updates From the Funeral of Police Officer Wenjian Liu
description: Officer Wenjian Liu, who was shot dead with his partner on Dec. 20 in their patrol car, was laid to rest today, with services that began at a funeral home in southern Brooklyn and were attended by thousands of police officers and members of the Chinese-American community.

title: Stuart Scott, ESPNs Voice of Exuberance, Dies at 49
description: Stuart Scott, a prominent ESPN sportscaster who was known for infusing his reports with a blend of pop culture references, slang and exuberant phrases that made him something of a pop culture figure in his own right, died on Sunday in a Hartford-area hospital. He was 49.

title: The Funeral of Officer Wenjian Liu
description: Images from the funeral of Officer Liu, who was shot dead with his patrol partner as they sat in their car.

title: Pope Names 15 New Cardinals Reflective of Diversity of the Faithful
description: VERBANIA, Italy  Pope Francis named 15 new cardinals from 14 countries on Sunday, continuing his efforts to diversify the church hierarchy and extend the global reach of the church.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 9 P.M. (13, 49) DOWNTON ABBEY The times are a-changin at Downton as Season 5 of this soapy Masterpiece drama picks up in 1924. Upstairs, Lord Grantham stews about the first Labour Government under Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald and what he perceives as its anti-aristocracy stance. Downstairs, the servants think that someone in charge might finally understand the concept of hard work. Lady Edith, meanwhile, turns to the tenant farmer Mr. Drewe and his unsuspecting wife to secret away Marigold, her illegitimate daughter with her married lover, Michael Gregson, still missing in Germany. Lady Mary finds herself inundated by dashing suitors. And when the committee in charge of creating a World War I memorial comes knocking, it isnt Lord Grantham they want, but rather Mr. Carson, the butler. In The Manners of Downton Abbey, at 10:15, Alastair Bruce, an expert on royal ceremony and custom who serves as the shows historical adviser, discusses the code of conduct that governed Britain in the early 20th century and how he goes about tutoring the actors in speaking, sitting, dressing and keeping an appropriately stiff upper lip. Hugh Bonneville, Elizabeth McGovern, Michelle Dockery (above, with Allen Leech), Laura Carmichael, Brendan Coyle, Joanne Froggatt and Lily James chime in.

title: 1965: T. S. Eliot, 76, Dies
description: LONDON  T. S. Eliot, 76, American-born poet, critic and dramatist, died at his London home tonight [Jan. 4]. Thomas Stearns Eliots best known poems include The Waste Land, The Love Song of J. Arthur Prufrock, and Four Quartets, and his plays: The Cocktail Party and Murder in the Cathedral. Born in St. Louis. Mo., of a Colonial Boston family, he was a naturalized British subject and held the highest civilian honors of both Britain and the United States. He was given the U.S. Presidential Medal of Freedom last September, and received the Order of Merit in Britain; as well as the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1948. France also made him an Officer of the Legion of Honor. Mr. Eliot was acknowledged as one of the most important creators of poetic style in the 20th century. He found in the cultural tradition of Europe a source of renewal for English poetry.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 5, 1965

title: The Hobbit: The Battle of Five Armies Reigns at the Box Office
description: As expected, The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (Warner Bros.) continued to lead the North American box office, taking in an estimated $21.9 million, for a three-week total of $220.8 million. But the two films hot on its tail  Rob Marshalls Into the Woods and Angelina Jolies Unbroken  were the reason Hollywood started the year smiling: Each release is a prime example of a type of film that supposedly can no longer succeed in theaters.

title: National Society of Film Critics Chooses Goodbye to Language as Best Film
description: Jean-Luc Godards 3-D film Goodbye to Language took top honors from the National Society of Film Critics on Saturday, edging out Richard Linklaters Boyhood by just one vote for best picture.

title: Pricey Arenas, With a Patriotic Furor
description: Olympic stadiums can engender more passion than almost any other buildings.

title: National Pride at a Steep Price
description: TOKYO  The Olympic stadium designed by the Pritzker-winning architect Zaha Hadid, to be built here for the 2020 Summer Games, looks to some like a pleasingly sleek, contoured spaceship. But many others deplore it, with one prominent Japanese architect saying it reminded him of a turtle. Another likened the $1.37 billion building, already projected to be the most expensive Olympic stadium in recent history, to another kind of animal.

title: Signs of Economic Promise Are Offering Some Hope for the New Year
description: The news came in a text: All employees at Zara clothing stores would receive raises in the first month of the new year. Valery Jourdan, a sales associate at Zara, directed a dubious eye at her cellphone. Really? Really?

title: Madonna Causes a Commotion (Again) With #RebelHeart
description: A hiatus from media headlines apparently was not one of Madonnas resolutions for 2015.

title: Cuomo Ponders Who Is God?
description: Mario M. Cuomo, raised as a Catholic, speaks about God at a panel discussion at the 92nd Street Y in 1991.

title: Battling Up a Sheer Yosemite Face, Seizing a Dream, Not a Rope
description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif.  The tip of El Capitan, 3,000 feet above its base, glowed in late-day sunlight while a full moon rose at the other end of the Yosemite Valley on Saturday. In the shadows halfway up the sheer granite face were a pair of dots, the latest to attempt one of rock climbings greatest challenges.

title: Iran Leader Suggests Direct Votes on Issues
description: TEHRAN  Irans president said Sunday that he might invoke a powerful but neglected tool in his fight with hard-liners, suggesting the possibility of organizing direct referendums that would bypass the institutions the conservatives control and give more of a voice to Iranian voters.

title: At the International CES, the Internet of Things Hits Home
description: By just about any measure, the International Consumer Electronics Show is big. The event, held in Las Vegas, attracts more than 150,000 visitors. It occupies two million square feet, the equivalent of about 35 football fields, of exhibition space. More than 3,500 companies come to show their wares.

title: Q. and A.: Jeremy Wallace on Chinas Rush to Urbanize
description: Jeremy Wallace, 35, is a political scientist at Ohio State University. His new book, Cities and Stability: Urbanization, Redistribution, and Regime Survival in China (Oxford University Press), is a look at how China has avoided the instability that urbanization has brought to many other countries around the world.

title: As Maestro Directs, the Colts Advance
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Time after time, the Cincinnati Bengals futilely tried to pressure Indianapolis Colts quarterback Andrew Luck.

title: Ulrich Beck, Sociologist Who Warned of Technology, Dies at 70
description: BERLIN  Ulrich Beck, a sociologist who became one of Germanys most prominent public intellectuals by exploring the ways technology had created a new, riskier society, died on Thursday. He was 70.

title: December Auto Sales, and Job Data for U.S. and Europe
Still Studying, Inventing and Respecting After All These Years
description: In 1994, the guitarist Peter Bernstein made the record Signs of Life for the Dutch label Criss Cross Jazz, with the pianist Brad Mehldau, the bassist Christian McBride and the drummer Greg Hutchinson. Almost exactly 20 years later, starting on Friday, Mr. Bernstein assembled the same band  all of them among the most respected players in jazz  for a three-night run at Dizzys Club Coca-Cola.

title: Virtuosity Isolated, but Running Free
description: Its telling that Haydns name does not feature in the title Music for a Prince: The Esterhazy Orchestra, an all-Haydn concert presented by the period-instrument ensemble Artek at Immanuel Lutheran Church on the Upper East Side on Saturday. The fruitful relationship between Haydn and the aristocratic Esterhazy family, in whose employ Haydn created the bulk of his vast output, is well known. But Arteks delightful performance served as a reminder that within the much-cited isolation of the Esterhazy country estate  where Haydn said he was forced to become original  the most direct influence on his music was the small band of highly talented court musicians.

title: Happy New Year in Russia
description: The year has barely begun and the economy is drying up fast.

title: Disgraced Sets Broadway Closing Date
description: The Broadway production of Ayad Akhtars Disgraced will close on March 1, producers announced on Sunday. That Pulitzer Prize-winning play first came to New York in 2012 and was warmly received by critics after opening at the Lyceum Theater in October. The play, directed by Kimberly Senior, stars Hari Dhillon and Gretchen Mol as a couple whose dinner party becomes a verbal joust over religion and politics. It will have had 149 performances and 27 previews when it closes.

title: An Algerian Author Fights Back Against a Fatwa
description: PARIS  There are elements of the absurd about the plight of Kamel Daoud, an Algerian writer whose debut novel reaped glowing international reviews, literary honors and then, suddenly, demands for his public execution.

title: Another Girl Gone in a Tale of Betrayal
description: The Girl on the Train has more fun with unreliable narration than any chiller since Gone Girl, the book still entrenched on best-seller lists two and a half years after publication because nothing better has come along. The Girl on the Train has Gone Girl-type fun with unreliable spouses, too. Its author, Paula Hawkins, isnt as clever or swift as Gillian Flynn, the author of Gone Girl, but shes no slouch when it comes to trickery or malice. So The Girl on the Train is liable to draw a large, bedazzled readership too.

title: An Unhinged Kings Downfall, in a Chapel Setting
description: As all those best-of-2014 lists start to fade into memory, a strong contender for the 2015 classical music honors has already appeared.

title: An Exuberant Array of Sweets Closes the Holiday Rush
description: Between the day after Thanksgiving and the first weekend of the new year, New York City Ballet gave nearly 50 performances of George Balanchines The Nutcracker. Thats a lot, but if the dancers were suffering from Nutcracker fatigue (a common seasonal condition) on Friday afternoon at the David H. Koch Theater, it didnt show. If anything, many seemed to summon extra verve and abandon to carry them through the homestretch of the run.

title: A Battle of Bandits and Wits in Civil War Era China
description: The Taking of Tiger Mountain, a protracted, oddly proportioned Chinese war picture from the director Tsui Hark, celebrated for his action movies, begins in New York, as Jimmy (Han Geng), about to leave for a Silicon Valley job, attends a farewell party.

title: Spoleto Festival Announces Lineup
description: Organizers of Spoleto Festival USA have announced the lineup for the 39th annual event, including more than 150 performances of opera, dance, theater and music. Highlights of the 17-day festival include the world premiere of Paradise Interrupted, a contemporary opera composed by Huang Ruo and designed and directed by Jennifer Wen Ma, whose visual installations were used in the opening and closing ceremonies of the 2008 Beijing Olympics. Also making world debuts will be What Moves You, by the dancer Lil Buck and the cellist Ashley Bathgate, as well as the Spoleto-commissioned performance of Francesco Cavallis opera Veremonda lamazzone di Aragona. Other festival highlights will include a new production of Romeo and Juliet by Shakespeares Globe theater company, the Carlo Colla and Sons Marionette Company performing Sleeping Beauty, and the Casus Circus of Australia. Featured dance performances will include Trisha Brown Dance Company, Shen Wei Dance Arts, and Scottish Ballets adaptation of the Tennessee Williams play A Streetcar Named Desire. In the musical category, highlights include performances by the Westminster Choir, Emmylou Harris and Rodney Crowell. Spoleto Festival USA runs May 22 through June 7 in Charleston, S.C. Schedules and more information are at spoletousa.org.

title: Winning Solo at the SportAccord World Mind Games
description: The fourth SportAccord World Mind Games in Beijing last month ended with two individual events. These are always enjoyed by top players. Although it can be frustrating not to have a finely tuned bidding system, it is fun partnering so many experts from around the globe.

Mr. Abbas has now announced that he will turn to the International Criminal Court  a move that will produce Palestinian charges and Israeli countercharges but not alter the reality on the ground.

title: Shifting Politics on the Death Penalty

Mr. Clintons decision not to grant clemency to Mr. Rector, who had been sentenced to death for killing a police officer, was widely seen as an attempt to fend off the familiar charge that Democrats were soft on crime.

title: In Madrid, a New Restaurant Features a Rotating Cast of Regional Chefs
description: In Madrid, an ingenious new pop-up restaurant is putting Spains culinary talent on display by showcasing a different chef from the countrys provinces each month. The Table By, which is located in the Hotel Urso and debuted with a soft opening in late 2014, changes completely with the arrival of each new chef, down to the wine list. The visiting chef also gets free rein to redecorate the dining room in the style of his or her restaurant. The project is fantastic because in a homogenizing world, it champions the riches of Spanish regional cooking and produce, says Marcos Cerqueiro, whose Abastos 2.0, a restaurant in Santiago de Compostela in Galicia, served as The Table Bys debut offering.

description: Experts recommend that young people who have suffered a concussion get one or two days of rest at home, until symptoms start resolving, before gradually returning to school and physical activity.

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 10:30 A.M. (Showtime) THE DIVING BELL AND THE BUTTERFLY (2007) Jean-Dominique Bauby, a 43-year-old French magazine editor and something of a playboy, had a stroke in 1995 that left him with a condition in which he retained vision, hearing and a functioning mind but was almost completely paralyzed. He told his story in a book that he dictated to an assistant by blinking. In this film from the artist Julian Schnabel, Mr. Bauby is played by Mathieu Amalric, above at right with Max von Sydow; Emmanuelle Seigner is Cline, the longtime partner he has recently left and the mother of his three children; and Marie-Jose Croze is a speech therapist who teaches him to use his left eyelid to communicate. The phrase triumph of the human spirit hovers over The Diving Bell and the Butterfly, along with a swarm of other empty, uplifting clichs, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. But Mr. Schnabel and the screenwriter, Ronald Harwood, have other themes in mind  among them, limitation, constraint and incarceration  Mr. Scott said. (Both men were nominated for Oscars.) Their common subject, however, is freedom, the self-willed liberation of a difficult, defiant individual, he added, noting that Mr. Schnabel demonstrated this with imaginative freedom in every frame and sequence, dispensing with narrative and expository conventions in favor of a wild, intuitive honesty.

title: Taiwans Ex-Leader Released From Prison on Medical Parole
description: Chen Shui-bian, the imprisoned former president of Taiwan, was released on medical parole on Monday, after Justice Ministry officials accepted the recommendation of a panel of medical experts that his failing health could be better treated at home.

Some 1,205 issuers raised nearly $249 billion globally, according to data from Thomson Reuters, making 2014 one of the busiest since 2010 for companies seeking to list on the stock markets. Such enthusiasm has prompted comparisons to the dot-com boom and bust of 1999-2000.

title: China Issues Complaint After North Korean Defector Is Said to Kill 4

Additionally, Emma Stone will continue her role as Sally Bowles through Feb. 15, extending her run by two weeks.

title: Meet Jessica Pratt, 2015s Folk Singer-Songwriter to Watch
description: The Californian singer-songwriter Jessica Pratt tends to be classified under the term freak-folk. Yet on Strange Melody, the third track from her forthcoming second album, On Your Own Love Again (out Jan. 27 from Drag City), she accidentally evokes a familiar 80s New Wave tune. I noticed there was a similar vocal melody to Duran Durans Hungry Like the Wolf right when I was recording it, Pratt says by phone from San Francisco in the midst of a biblical downpour. I like those strange references that happen sometimes in music, so I just left it in there. A similar spirit of serendipity also informs the rest of the album, a collection of eloquent, lingering acoustic songs that brings to mind everyone from the chanteuse Judy Collins to Joanna Newsom.The first single, Back, Baby, appears below.

description: DUBLIN  Irish beef will be the first from Europe to be sold in the United States in almost 16 years, after the lifting of a ban that had stemmed from an outbreak of mad cow disease in the late 1990s.

title: Former Governor Spoke Willingly of His Religion and Politics
description: Its always been safer not to talk about religious beliefs because religious beliefs are so personal that they tend to antagonize, Mario M. Cuomo once cautioned. Never one to dodge a debate, though, he predictably, and dramatically, rejected his own advice and tackled the issue.

title: Club Med Shares Fall as Battle for Resort Operator Ends
description: PARIS  Shares of Club Mditerrane fell on Monday, after an Italian businessman who had been battling for control of the vacation resort operator conceded to his rival, the Chinese conglomerate Fosun International.

title: 1940: Paris Welcomes Hitlers Coffee
description: Following an announcement that 4,000 tons of coffee seized on a German freighter are to be distributed shortly in France, Parisians are hoping that some of this amount, which is enough to supply national consumption for ten days, will come to their particular groceries. As French newspapers announced it yesterday morning, Our coffee for the next ten days will be on Adolf Hitler. For some time Frenchmen, who remember that during the last war there was always an adequate supply of coffee, have been asking themselves why is there a shortage. Coffee is to the French what tea is to the English.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 6, 1940

title: Heroins Growing Scourge in Myanmar
description: The New York Times video journalist Jonah M. Kessel discusses the revival of heroin production and use in the Golden Triangle.

title: How Can Democrats Take Back the States?
description: Of all the depressingresultsfor Democrats in the midterm elections, the ones at the state level might be the most grim  as in, not since the Jazz Age grim.

title: Talk Turns to Inequality at Annual Meeting of Economists
description: The big annual gabfest for academic economists, currently underway in Boston, provides a useful signal of how the field is evolving. Consider this a dispatch from the pleated khaki-clad trenches. The clearest theme so far is a renewed interest in inequality.

title: AirAsia Jet Was Cleared to Take Off Without All Permits in Order, Officials Say
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  AirAsia Flight 8501, which crashed in the Java Sea on Dec. 28, was allowed to take off from Surabaya, Indonesia, even though it did not have all the required clearances from regulators to fly that day, the Indonesian Transportation Ministry said on Monday.

title: Decks Tilting, Crew Grounded Ship Off Southern England to Save It
description: LONDON  Seen from some angles, tilting at a crazy angle in shallow water, it might almost resemble a huge plaything discarded by capricious giants.

title: Art Directors Pick Their Nominees for Best Production Design
description: The Art Directors Guild has announced its nominees for production design, divided into period, fantasy and contemporary categories.

title: Inside Myanmars Opium Fields
description: Jonah M. Kessels video Relapse in the Golden Triangle explored the resurgence of poppy and opium production in Myanmar, where he reported the story with Thomas Fuller. Here, Mr. Kessels behind the scenes video shows what went in to putting the story together. Mr. Fuller also tells of what surprised him about reporting in the region, where so many are dependent on harvesting the drug.

title: Like Advice From a Friend
description: Cookbooks today fall largely into two camps. There is glossy art-house food erotica assembled by chefs eager to set down markers of regional pride, of particular aesthetic technique, of gastronomic genius. Cooking from those books is like making a paint-by-numbers Ingres or Hockney. You get the shape and the color and the line. But the dish is never really art.

title: A Grand Hotel, a Miniature Design
description: With its candy-colored dollhouse sets, miniaturized funicular and post-Weimar-era grandeur, The Grand Budapest Hotel offered moviegoers one of the most visually sumptuous confections of 2014.

title: 19 Years Later, Article by Kagan Echoes at the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON  What is the best way for a scholar to influence the Supreme Court through a law review article? Join the court.

title: Harvard Ideas on Health Care Hit Home, Hard
description: WASHINGTON  For years, Harvards experts on health economics and policy have advised presidents and Congress on how to provide health benefits to the nation at a reasonable cost. But those remedies will now be applied to the Harvard faculty, and the professors are in an uproar.

title: Border Clash With Iraqis Kills Seven, Saudis Say
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Four heavily armed men from Iraq attacked a Saudi border patrol early Monday, firing automatic weapons and detonating suicide belts in a confrontation that left three guards and all the assailants dead, Saudi officials said.

title: Keshia Knight Pulliam Ousted From Celebrity Apprentice Over Refusal to Contact Bill Cosby
description: The season premiere of NBCs Celebrity Apprentice resulted in an awkward juxtaposition of reality television and actual reality when one of its contestants, the Cosby Show star Keshia Knight Pulliam, was ejected from the program by host Donald Trump for not seeking assistance from Bill Cosby, the comedian and actor who has been accused of sexually assaulting several women.

title: Protests Turn Violent in Bangladesh
description: Fighting broke out in Dhaka between supporters of the ruling party, the Awami League, and the Bangladesh Nationalist Party. Protests were timed with the first anniversary of controversial elections.

title: Penelope Casas Final Lessons
description: To Learn: All You Need to Know About Spanish Cooking

title: CES: Sensors Rule From the Start
description: With virtually no preamble, the 2015 International Consumer Electronics Show, which opens to the public on Tuesday, jumped directly into a flurry of press events and even a little news on Sunday night.

title: Keeping Older Pedestrians Safe
description: Too many older adults put their lives at the mercy of two- and four-wheeled vehicles when performing an activity that they are repeatedly advised to do: walking.

title: The Latest to Defect From Boehner: Cantors Replacement
description: Speaker John A. Boehner and former Representative Eric Cantor occasionally had their differences, but Mr. Cantors replacement in the House, Dave Brat, has taken his opposition to a new level.

title: No Comment Necessary: The Obama Economy
description: The C.E.O. of Westgate Resorts, a Florida-based timeshare company, told his employees in 2012 that if President Obama were re-elected, that would mean fewer jobs, less benefits and certainly less opportunity for everyone. Two years in to the presidents second term, that same C.E.O. is giving raises.

title: Morgan Stanley Breach Put Client Data Up for Sale on Pastebin, an Online Site
description: In mid-December, a posting appeared on the Internet site Pastebin offering six million account records, including passwords and login data for clients of Morgan Stanley.

title: The Chess Master
description: We start off the new year with a puzzle suggestion by Marco Moriconi, a regular Numberplay contributor and professor of physics at the Universidade Federal Fluminense, in Niteroi, Rio de Janeiro. (Dr. Moriconi also writes a monthly math column for the Brazilian national science magazine, Cincia Hoje (Science Today), called Qual o Problema, or Whats the Problem?).

title: Boehner Challengers Website Goes Up, Then Comes Down
description: Representative Louie Gohmert, the Tea Party favorite from Texas, said on Sunday that he was launching a challenge to take the House speakership from John A. Boehner, put up a campaign website to lay out his platform as a true conservative, and made a case that it was time for the current leadership to move on.

title: Ferrying the Dead of Both Sides in a Cruel Afghan War
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  On the brindled plains of southern Afghanistan, Malik Abdul Hakim is deaths ferryman.

title: Bess Myerson, New Yorker of Beauty, Wit, Service and Scandal, Dies at 90
description: Bess Myerson, a New York favorite daughter who basked in the public eye for decades  as Miss America in 1945, as a television personality, as a force in public affairs and finally as a player in a shattering municipal scandal  died on Dec. 14 at her home in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 90.

title: Apps Everywhere, but No Unifying Link
description: Navigating the Internet used to mean painstakingly typing the exact address you wanted into your computer. The web browser and the search engine simplified that, giving us the Internet we take for granted today.

title: Anti-Immigration Rallies in Germany Defy Calls to Desist
description: DRESDEN, Germany  Defying appeals from an array of German institutions to stay away from anti-immigration rallies, some 18,000 people took part in a protest here on Monday, parading against what they call the Islamization of Europe and putting pressure on the authorities to defuse social tensions.

title: 1915: Plot to Smuggle Opium Foiled
description: LONDON  The American Embassy here, with the assistance of the Home Office, has succeeded in nipping in the bud a plot to smuggle huge supplies of opium into England from America. The first installment of the drug, contained in three large trunks in charge of Sophie Ghee, wife of a Chinese, was confiscated upon the arrival of the Baltic here on Friday, and the woman was sent back to New York on board the Philadelphia on Saturday. Mr. Horace Lee Washington, the American Consul at Liverpool, by getting in touch with the Baltics officers by wireless, enabled them to have everything ready for the womans detention when the liner reached port.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 6, 1915

title: Capturing Manhattans Waterfront
description: A collection of Barbara Menschs photography from her South Street series and Brooklyn Bridge work.

title: Finding Glamour, Not Grit, at South Street Seaport
description: Looking as tough as gangsters, which some of their bosses were, the fishmongers are lined up against a wall at the South Street Seaport in Manhattan, menacing any stranger who passes by. Vinny smiles through his cigarette, handsome as Brando. Jake the Snake, after decades on the docks, looks as swollen as an octopus. Big John has drawn his tiny pistol, a joke and a threat.

title: Pick Me! Four American Cities Put Best Olympic Foot Forward
Patient, Heal Thyself
description: Dr. Eric Topol and I appear to practice medicine on two different planets. This fact makes it difficult for me to comment sensibly on his books, let alone critique them. Instead, I read along with mouth slightly agape, marveling at this missive from a far-off place whose atmosphere, physical laws and inhabitants bear no resemblance to the ones I know.

title: Discovery, Guided by Morality
description: MENLO PARK, CALIF.  Ann Lam delicately places a laboratory slide holding a slice of brain from a living human onto a small platform in a room the size of a walk-in refrigerator. She closes a heavy door and turns to a row of computers to monitor her experiments.

title: War and Gorillas and Other Hazards of Documentary Filmmaking
description: Virunga, one of 15 candidates shortlisted for the best documentary Oscar, is a nature film with an edge.

title: Who Is a Whistle-Blower? The Courts Weigh In
description: The 19th-century German leader Otto von Bismarck once remarked that laws are like sausages, it is better not to see them being made. Figuring what a law means can be no less problematic.

title: TPG Investors Pay Twice for Work on Chobani Deal
description: The senior partners of Wall Streets private equity firms typically draw their salaries from management fees paid by clients, including the nations biggest pension funds, whose capital they invest.

title: Son Is Charged With Murder in Death of Manhattan Hedge Fund Manager
description: The son of a wealthy Manhattan hedge fund manager was arrested on a murder charge on Monday after shooting his father at his parents home, the police said.

title: Right Price for Oil? Not the Current One
description: The price of oil is still too high, often too low and much too volatile. In other words, this is a market that doesnt work well for anyone.

title: Aleksei Navalny, Defying Kremlin Again, Declares End to House Arrest
description: MOSCOW  Taunting the Kremlin yet again, the Russian political opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny on Monday snipped the electronic bracelet used by the authorities to monitor his whereabouts and personally declared an end to his more than 10 months of house arrest.

title: Witnesses on Capsized Ship Near Scotland
description: Passengers of a nearby ferry described the search-and-rescue operation for a Cyprus-registered cement carrier, the Cemfjord, which overturned off the coast of Scotland.

title: Signs of a McConnell Senate on the Cafeteria Menu
description: Senator Mitch McConnell officially takes over as Senate majority leader tomorrow, but traces of the senators Kentucky influences are already popping up on Capitol Hill.

title: For Second Week, Arrests Plunge in New York City
description: For two straight weeks, New York City police officers have sharply cut back on making arrests and issuing summonses throughout the five boroughs, magnifying the growing divide between the citys police force and its mayor, Bill de Blasio.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: A Challenge to America
French Leader Urges End to Sanctions Against Russia Over Ukraine
description: MOSCOW  Western nations should stop threatening Russia with new sanctions and instead offer to ease off on existing restrictions in exchange for progress in the peace process in Ukraine, President Franois Hollande of France said in an interview on Monday.

title: Producers Surprise With Nominations for Nightcrawler, Whiplash
description: The Producers Guild of America has unveiled its feature nominees. They are:

title: Dish Network Unveils Sling TV, a Streaming Service to Rival Cable (and It Has ESPN)
description: Dish Network, the satellite provider, is trying to lure younger viewers back to paying for television with the start of a web-based offering that includes ESPN and a number of other popular networks for $20 a month, about a fifth the cost of the average household bill for cable and satellite service.

title: Working Extra Hours for No Extra Pay
description: It has been nearly 10 months since President Obama ordered the Labor Department to revamp the outdated federal rules on overtime pay, but the department has yet to propose new rules.

title: Congress More Devout Than Most of America
description: When it comes to religion, Congress appears to be much more devout than the rest of the country.

title: Europes Trap
description: There are many risks in the world economy right now  a possible Chinese hard landing (local governments depend heavily on land sales for revenue? Oh, boy), a financial crisis in Russia and other oil exporters, etc.. But one thing is not a risk, because it has already happened: the euro area has entered a Japan-style deflationary trap.

title: Defiant on Witness Stand, Times Reporter Says Little
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.  After losing a seven-year legal battle, James Risen, a reporter for The New York Times, reluctantly took the witness stand in federal court here on Monday, but refused to answer any questions that could help the Justice Department identify his confidential sources.

title: Oils Fall Continues Into 2015, and Stock Markets Shudder
description: HOUSTON  Oil prices tumbled below $50 a barrel on Monday, spooking global financial markets and signaling that the remarkable 50 percent price drop since June was continuing this year and even quickening.

title: White House Says Elevating Scalise Reflects G.O.P. Values
description: President Obama was far away in Hawaii last week while the firestorm surrounding Representative Steve Scalise was gathering pace, but the White House was clearly watching.

title: Judge Sets Date to Consider Release of Eric Garner Grand Jury Records
description: A Staten Island judge ruled on Monday that he would hear arguments this month over whether to release grand jury transcripts in the case of Eric Garner, the man who died after being placed in a chokehold by a police officer.

title: Not Invented Here Macroeconomics
description: Martin Wolf writes sympathetically about Richard Koos latest; let me be a bit less sympathetic.

title: Yeovils Big Moment
description: Images from Yeovil, England, where in the third round of the F.A. Cup on Sunday, Yeovil Town, which plays two divisions below the Premier League, drew mighty Manchester United to its tiny stadium.

title: 2014 Auto Sales Jump in U.S., Even With Recalls
description: When the history of the contemporary auto industry is written, 2014 will go down as a year of contrasts. Deluged by safety recalls, auto manufacturers faced the ire of regulators and consumers. Yet, buyers did not stay away and instead gave the American auto industry its best sales year in nearly a decade.

title: Leon Wieseltier Joins The Atlantic
description: Leon Wieseltier, the former literary editor of The New Republic, will be joining The Atlantic as a contributing editor and critic, writing for both the print magazine and the website on his customary wide range of subjects, according to a news release.

title: Two Ways Infrared Cameras Have Boosted the Case for E.P.A. Rules Cutting Methane Leaks
description: I first realized the enormous value of infrared imagery in pollution detection in 2009, when I co-wrote Curbing Emissions by Sealing Gas Leaks with Clifford Krauss. In the related Dot Earth post, I included some remarkable video shot for the Environmental Protection Agency showing the difference between looking at an oil or gas facility with a standard camera and one tuned to the infrared wavelengths absorbed by gases like methane  the main constituent of natural gas:

title: Grand Juror in Ferguson Sues to End Silence Rule
description: A member of the grand jury that did not indict a white police officer in the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager in Ferguson, Mo., sued the county prosecutor on Monday, seeking to speak out because the publics impression of the grand jurys work was not entirely accurate.

title: The Bloom Is On for Maple Syrup
description: Pancake lovers, take heart. In the coming weeks, maple farmers throughout Quebec, Vermont and elsewhere in the syrup belt will dust off their metal spiles for another harvest season, and some scientists are predicting that the sugary sap will flow even more freely than usual.

title: Allie Sherman Dies at 91; Led Giants to Title Games
description: Allie Sherman, who possessed a dubious football pedigree as a left-handed quarterback at Brooklyn College but went on to take the New York Giants to National Football League title games in his first three seasons as their coach, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91.

title: When Leaves Fail to Fall
description: Q. Why are the leaves still clinging to my Japanese maple this winter, shriveled and brown, rather than falling to form a vermilion carpet as usual?

title: Illusions Fool Even the Blind
description: That bats use echolocation to navigate and to find food is well known. But some blind people use the technique, too, clicking their tongues and snapping fingers to help identify objects.

title: Ask Well: Blockages in the Heart and Brain
description: Question:

title: Fit for the Job, Even in an Ill-Fitting Suit
description: IT seems that Ive been in an airplane most of my life. When I was younger I raced professionally in motocross. I did the national circuit and we traveled all over the country. My family started planting grapes in 1978. I remember getting into a little trouble at school once and my dad said if I didnt shape up he was going to make me work the vineyards. I thought working on the land was the coolest thing ever, which probably wasnt the reaction he wanted. But there is a great joy to be found when youre working a vineyard and seeing grapes develop and grow. I dont know how I did it, but somehow I managed to get my college degree in fruit science from California Polytechnic State University, San Luis Obispo. Now Im president and winemaker for our business, Hope Family Wines, including Treana, and Im still traveling all the time.

title: Euro Countries Take Tough Line Toward Greece
description: PARIS  As a caustic election campaign in Greece revives fears that the country could leave the euro, European officials are taking an increasingly hard line toward Athens, saying they want to keep Greece in the single currency, though not at any cost.

title: Where Security Fails: Airport Worker Access
description: AS business travel resumes robustly this week, frequent fliers could reasonably be asking questions about security. Do we in fact have a serious problem with guns in our airports and, if so, is there anything to be done about it?

title: For One New Member of Congress, Twitter Silence
description: A new Congress means a new freshman class  71 members are scheduled to be sworn in for the first time on Tuesday. For political obsessives like us at First Draft, though, it also means updating our Twitter feeds to keep track of the newcomers.

title: Grace Helbig Gets E! Talk Show
description: With female faces becoming an increasing rarity on TV talk shows that are shown after sundown  currently none of the major late-night shows are hosted by women  the E! network is continuing to do its part to reverse that trend.

title: Philharmonic Names a New Fundraiser
description: It is a daunting task: raising hundreds of millions of dollars to renovate Avery Fisher Hall while simultaneously doubling the New York Philharmonics endowment fund. Now that task will be assigned to Lisa Mantone, who has been appointed to the new position of the orchestras senior vice president of institutional advancement, the Philharmonic announced on Monday.

title: Chadwick Boseman and His James Brown Exorcism
description: Chadwick Boseman was heaped with plaudit upon plaudit for his portrayal of James Brown in last summers Get On Up. From the dancing to the smoothness to the PCP-fueled meltdowns, Mr. Boseman, who rose to fame with hisportrait of Jackie Robinson in 42, was heralded for singularly channeling the Godfather of Soul.

title: Fueled by Rotten Eggs, an Annual Mock Coup Mirrors Spains Mood
description: IBI, Spain  Wearing a top hat and surrounded by supporters mostly dressed in outlandish military uniforms, Vicente Candela stormed the town hall here briefly last month and proclaimed himself mayor of Ibis 24,000 residents.

title: Rare Frogs Give Birth to Live Tadpoles
description: A tiny frog discovered in the rain forests of Indonesias Sulawesi Island is the only frog known to give birth to live tadpoles.

title: How It Happens | Volcanic Eruptions
description: The eruption of a volcano can be one of the planets most destructive events  spewing huge amounts of rock, gas and ash that can kill people. Henry Fountain explains how a volcano can blow its top.

title: Pressure, and Mystery, on the Rise
description: SKAFTAFELL, Iceland  Just north of here, on the far side of the impenetrable Vatnajokull ice sheet, lava is spewing from a crack in the earth on the flanks of Bardarbunga, one of Icelands largest volcanoes.

title: Sneak Peek at the G.O.P. 2016 Field
description: With the next presidential election a mere 22 months away, its high time for speculation  informed, ill-informed and just plain wild  about who will be running for the nominations of the two major parties.

title: Sanford Rubenstein Will Not Face Rape Charges
description: After spending more than three months investigating rape allegations against the prominent lawyer Sanford A. Rubenstein, the Manhattan district attorneys office announced on Monday that it would not bring charges against him.

title: Next Year in Havana
description: The Cuba you can look forward to.

title: Money From Merce Cunningham Trust Goes to Two Arts Groups
description: The Merce Cunningham Trust, established in 2000 to further the choreographers legacy, has announced an award of $250,000 to the Baryshnikov Arts Center and of $375,000 to the Foundation for Contemporary Arts. Both organizations, said Allan Sperling, a trustee, were crucial to Cunningham, who died in 2009.

title: Documentaries in Focus at Miami Jewish Film Festival
description: Nancy Spielberg said she knew that her older brother, Steven, and others had toyed with the idea of making a film about the foreign volunteers, or the Machal, who played a crucial role in Israels War of Independence in 1948, but she feared the story would never fully be told.

title: Perceptions of Race at a Glance
description: Jennifer L. Eberhardt, 49, an associate professor of psychology at Stanford University, studies the effect of unconscious ideas about race on the workings of the criminal justice system. She was one of 21 winners of 2014 MacArthur genius grants.

title: 6-Year-Olds at the Spa: Understandable, Not Laudable
description: There is something about the image of toddler girls and their not-too-much older counterparts engulfed in pink fake fur and trying on tiaras at a day spa that makes me want to begin muttering dire things about bread and circuses and tossing around end-of-days imagery. Im like a windup baseball batter: Throw the Seriously Spoiled Salon and Spa at me, and Ill swing.

title: African Nations Can Help More on AIDS, Study Says
description: The 12 African countries that receive most of the American taxpayer dollars spent fighting AIDS could do much more to pay their own way, according to a new study.

title: Drinking In a New Year (and Lifestyle)
description: In his new book The New Health Rules (out Jan. 6 from Artisan, $20), Dr. Frank Lipman, the founder and director of the Eleven Eleven Wellness Center in New York City and a regular contributor to Gwyneth Paltrows lifestyle website Goop, offers his secrets to feeling our best. He prescribes a new lifestyle, not a diet, which he breaks down into five categories: eating (eat till youre only 80 percent full), moving (stop if it hurts), boosting (spend lots of time with people you love), healing (wander barefoot) and living (lose the mainstream deodorant). Its a handy little collection of healthy habits, endorsed with book-jacket blurbs by prominent multitaskers including Paltrow, Arianna Huffington and the makeup artist Bobbi Brown.

title: Jury Selection Begins in Patz Murder Case
description: Jury selection began on Monday in the trial of a man accused of murdering 6-year-old Etan Patz, and the judge warned potential jurors the proceedings could take more than two months.

title: Scrutiny for Laxatives as a Childhood Remedy
description: The Food and Drug Administration has raised new questions about the safety of an adult laxative routinely given to constipated children, sometimes daily for years.

title: The Inherent Vice Bus Tour (Cough, Cough)
description: Everybody must get stoned, Bob Dylan sang, and the director Paul Thomas Anderson is apparently taking that maxim to heart.

title: Biotech Company Moderna Raises $450 Million
description: Moderna Therapeutics, a four-year-old company with a promising but unproven technology for developing drugs, said on Monday that it had raised $450 million in its latest round of financing, a figure that could be the largest ever in a single round for a private biotechnology company.

title: Enter Huckabee
description: In Sundays column, my first of the new year, I looked back on some of my mistakes and oversights in the old one, starting with my underestimation of Jeb Bushs belly-fire: I didnt think hed actually run for president, and my analysis of the 2016 G.O.P. field last year mostly reflected that assumption, but in the last month hes looked much more like an actual, all-in candidate than I expected.

title: Turkey Will Help Train Moderate Syrian Rebels, Diplomat Says
description: MUGLA, Turkey  Turkey is ready to conclude an agreement this month to train and equip moderate Syrian rebels as part of the American-led effort to combat Islamic State fighters, a senior Turkish diplomat said Monday.

title: Cancers Random Assault
description: It may sound flippant to say that many cases of cancer are caused by bad luck, but that is what two scientists suggested in an article published last week in the journal Science. The bad luck comes in the form of random genetic mistakes, or mutations, that happen when healthy cells divide.

title: At the Bottom of the Ballot, One Last Shutout
description: As debates rage about the Hall of Fame worthiness of players like Mike Mussina, Curt Schilling and John Smoltz ahead of Tuesdays announcement of the class of 2015, no one is bothering to argue the case for Aaron Boone.

title: CES: New Options for Networked Speakers
description: Since streaming music has become more popular, it should come as no surprise that home stereo systems are starting to get a connected makeover. This could be the year that Sonos, the longtime leader in this field, gets some competition.

title: Scott Walker, Starting Second Term as Wisconsin Governor, Resists New Union Battle
description: MADISON, Wis.  Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, who rose to national prominence in the Republican Party by cutting the collective bargaining rights of most public sector unions, strongly indicated in the final days of his re-election campaign that he had no plans to expand the battle with labor unions that defined his first term.

title: Profit at Point72, Cohens New Firm, Outshines Many a Hedge Funds
description: If Steven A. Cohens investment firm were operating as a hedge fund, it would have been one of the industrys most profitable in 2014.

title: Gohmert Doesnt Talk Like a Speaker, or Donate Money Like One
description: Louie Gohmert, the Texas Republican challenging John Boehner for Speaker of the House, doesnt talk like the G.O.P. leadership.

title: Falling Euro Fans Fears of a Regional Slowdown
description: FRANKFURT  The value of the euro fell to its lowest level in years on Monday, prompting sharp declines in European stocks and creating uneasiness about whether the region is on the verge of a new economic and financial crisis.

title: N.F.L.s Underdogs Have Reasons for Optimism
description: In 1990, the N.F.L. switched to its current playoff format, featuring six teams from each conference, with the top two seeds earning first-round byes.

title: Thinking About International Bond Yields
description: One of the occupational hazards of being a professional economist writing for a broader audience is that sometimes you lose track of what is and isnt obvious to smart people who havent spent their lives immersed in your field. (Actually, the same problem arises in teaching undergraduates.) So I welcome it when people ask questions in an open-minded spirit, and reveal that there is some bit of stuff that Ive been taking for granted as obvious, but isnt.

title: Gov. Jerry Brown Begins Last Term With a Bold Energy Plan
description: LOS ANGELES  Gov. Jerry Brown began his fourth and final term on Monday proposing a broad reduction in Californias energy consumption over the next 15 years  including a call to slash gas consumption by cars and trucks by as much as 50 percent  as part of what he said would be a sweeping campaign to heighten the states role in the fight against global warming.

title: From the Upshot: Gohmerts Leadership PAC
description: Gohmert Doesnt Talk Like a Speaker, or Donate Money Like One

title: Famous Faces in Oscar de la Renta
description: Since the designers death in October, his brand has been among the best represented at high-profile events.

title: Kaleidoscopic Naturalist Collages, a European Collectives American Debut and More From the Art Calendar
description: Ts list of happenings worth visiting in the week ahead.

title: Mugler
description: The prefall collection included a tailored suit with grommets details and lots of leather.

title: A Banner Week for Broadway
description: Coming off a hugely profitable run of performances during Christmas week, Broadway musicals and plays did even better last week over the New Year holiday, grossing the highest amount ever  $42.8 million  for a weeks worth of performances, according to box-office data released on Monday by the Broadway League.

title: An Unlikely and Tumultuous Pair, Making History in Avant-Garde Theater
description: Rehearsals for Kurt Weill and Bertolt Brechts The Threepenny Opera ended near dawn on Aug. 31, 1928, the day of its premiere. They had not gone well.

title: Creating a New Mission Statement
description: Forget the New Years resolution. This year, try creating a personal mission statement instead.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Afghanistan and Elsewhere  Pictures of the Day

title: Pictures of the Day  Jan. 5, 2015
description: Photos from Afghanistan, Indonesia, Japan and France.

title: Stark Pictures of Authority at Sundance and Other Science Events
description: January events at the intersection of culture and science.

title: Our Planet, Our Holiday
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Missed Opportunities
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Hanging Out 1,200 Feet Up (Yes, Downtime)
description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif.  The two men attempting to free climb the daunting 3,000-foot Dawn Wall route of El Capitan spent much of Monday morning in their tents, hanging 1,200 feet above the valley floor.

title: Debt Dispute Between Hedge Funds and Argentina at Impasse
description: BUENOS AIRES  The hopes of easing a debt dispute between Argentina and a group of New York hedge funds seemed to be dashed on Monday after the countrys economy minister made an offer that appeared to fall well short of what the investors were seeking.

title: Still Music to the Ears, but From Odd Sources
description: You never know what might inspire a composer to write a piece. On Sunday afternoon, for a Winter Festival program in the Here and Now contemporary-music series at Bargemusic in Brooklyn, several of the extremely diverse works derived from unusual sources.

title: Shots Beat Pills for Knee Arthritis Relief
description: The most effective treatment for the pain of knee osteoarthritis may be an injection of hyaluronic acid or corticosteroids, and the least effective may be Tylenol or Celebrex pills, a review of studies concludes.

title: In Performance | Courtney Love
description: Ms. Love performs the song All I Ever Wanted from Kansas City Choir Boy, with the shows composer, Todd Almond, on piano, and Eric Allen on cello. The show is at Here Arts Center from Jan. 8-17.

title: For a Trailblazer, Odd Was the Norm
description: The odd has become commonplace these days. Do you have anatomical malformations or enjoy looking at them? Pinterest has a board for you. Does your collection of mustard bottles number in the thousands? A reality TV show will be calling shortly.

title: Jeb Bush Strikes Conciliatory Note on Same-Sex Marriage
description: As gay couples began to wed in Florida after a court ruling, Jeb Bush, the states former governor and long an opponent of same-sex marriages, struck a conciliatory note on Monday, telling The New York Times that regardless of our disagreements, we have to respect the rule of law.

title: A Furor in France Over the Final Resting Place for a Roma Child
description: PARIS  A 2-month-old Roma infant was buried on Monday in a town south of Paris amid accusations that the mayor of the nearby town where the baby died had refused burial space in the local cemetery. The episode has prompted antidiscrimination investigations by local prosecutors and Frances human rights ombudsman.

title: Life After Captain America
description: The title Marvels Agent Carter may create a misleading impression for a show set in 1946 New York and featuring automats and fedoras. This latest product of the Marvel comics-adventure factory, an eight-episode series starting on Tuesday, has less in common with its sister ABC show, Marvels Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D., than it does with some of the more active British mysteries on PBS. Viewers with long memories may even be reminded of Remember WENN, the serving of World War II-era schmaltz that was AMCs first scripted show.

title: Official Says Crucial Call Was Missed by Referees
description: The Dallas Cowboys are set to head to Green Bay to play the Packers on Sunday in the divisional round of the N.F.L. playoffs, but the Cowboys victory over the Detroit Lions on Sunday is still being picked over.

title: Two in U.S. Face Charges After Coup Attempt Fails in Gambia
description: A botched coup attempt in the tiny West African nation of Gambia last week reached into the American heartland on Monday with criminal charges against two United States citizens, accused in federal court of helping to finance, lead and arm the plotters.

title: Albums From Art Hirahara and Death Grips
description: ART HIRAHARA

title: Ally of Deposed Leader Is Nominated to Be Premier of Tunisia
description: LONDON  A former government official of the dictatorship in Tunisia, Habib Essid, was nominated Monday to be prime minister and charged with forming a new government.

title: Discounted Tickets: A Test for the Metropolitan Opera
description: One of the first measures Peter Gelb instituted when he arrived as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera in 2006 was to introduce a rush ticket program, which offers up to 100 or so $25 tickets in prime seating locations for each performance. Surprisingly, people are still grumbling.

title: Racially Ignited, a Magical World Is Uncanny
description: LOS ANGELES  The Wizard of Watts, a coming animated television musical, was conceived two years ago as a big, fat gob of raucous entertainment wrapped around a nugget of racial commentary.

title: Grilling and Being Grilled
description: When a child chef is eliminated on MasterChef Junior, two things happen. First, the unbearable: The child cries. This is almost always the case: Competitors range in age from 8 to 13, and by and large dont have the backbone to endure being told they didnt succeed. Its agonizing, of course, or maybe heartening, if youre the sort of person who appreciates emotional transparency.

title: What Would MacGyver Do?
description: What idiot forgets to buy charcoal for a barbecue but has a large sack of potato chips, another of nacho chips and, for some reason, another of marshmallows?

title: For Flight Attendants, High Fashion Goes the Way of Free Peanuts
description: If it is indeed true that you are what you wear, then consider the statement American Airlines recently made when, as part of its postmerger rebranding, it unveiled prototype uniforms for its flight attendants and other employees.

description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Judge Lifts Ban, and Gay Weddings Begin in Florida
description: MIAMI  Ending a drawn-out battle over same-sex marriage in Florida, Miami-Dade on Monday became the first county in the state to allow gay couples to wed after a state judge lifted a temporary ban on the nuptials.

description: Since 1993, Robert Hellers advanced photography students at the University of Tennessee have documented life in LaFollette, which has seen better days.

description: Boston, Los Angeles, Washington and San Francisco are competing to host the 2024 Summer Games.

title: An Africans Message for America
description: This short documentary profiles a Kenyan activist who asks American student volunteers: Why do you want to help us? Help your own country.

title: An Africans Message for America
description: A volunteer trip abroad has become almost a rite of passage for a certain set of Americans, particularly students. This Op-Doc video profiles a Kenyan activist who has one simple question for them: Why?

title: Illinois Introduces Automatic Retirement Savings Program, a First for the Nation
description: Illinois is taking a novel approach to getting its residents to save for retirement. Starting in 2017, most state residents with jobs who dont already have a retirement plan at work will be automatically enrolled in individual retirement accounts, funded through a 3 percent deduction from their paychecks.

title: Bess Myerson Dies at 90
description: Ms. Myerson was a favorite daughter of New York who basked in the public eye for decades.

title: Walkabout: Olympic Stadiums  Some Iconic, Others in Ruins
description: Faster, Higher, Stronger Olympic stadiums have become potent symbols of architectural prowess and national pride. A look back at arenas and forward to the one designed for the 2020 Summer Games in Tokyo. (The New York Times)

description: It just might be time to book that vacation in Paris youve been thinking about.

title: Man Killed by San Francisco Police Had Air Gun and Suicide Motive, They Say
description: The San Francisco police shot and killed a man outside a police station on Sunday night after a brief confrontation in which he brandished a weapon that turned out to be an air gun.

title: Stop Subsidizing Big Pharma
description: WASHINGTON  ROBERT J. BEALL, the president and chief executive of the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, called his recent decision to sell the royalty rights to his organizations research a game changer. Indeed: Deals like this, in which an investment company paid the foundation $3.3 billion for its future royalties from several cystic fibrosis drugs it helped finance, could revolutionize the way medical research is funded. Rather than the staid model of government-funded institutions handing out grants to academic research facilities, a new breed of venture philanthropies like the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation could corral private investment into developing lifesaving drugs quickly and cheaply.

title: The Path to Closing Guantnamo
description: WASHINGTON  WHEN I began as the State Departments envoy for closing the detention facility at Guantnamo Bay, many people advised me that progress was impossible. They were wrong.

title: Boehner Facing Dissent and Defections in Vote to Remain Speaker of House
description: WASHINGTON  Speaker John A. Boehner is all but assured of re-election to the top House leadership post when his colleagues vote on Tuesday, but the new term also could serve up the embarrassment of a potentially record number of his own Republican conference voting against him as speaker.

title: A Spa for Young Girls? Parents: Just Say No
