Valentino, for instance showed embroidered cargo pants and a camouflage dress, while Michael Kors incorporated such covetable items as a knee-length green trench coat that doubles as a utility cape. Since the big designers always seem to revisit the theme, its safe to say that this small army of styles  available in stores now  will always be on-trend.

title: Health Premiums Rise More Slowly, but Workers Shoulder More of Cost
description: When Charlotte Alger, 25, was working at a Home Depot just outside Boston last year, she said she earned $10.75 an hour working on the sales floor in the woodworking department. She chose one of the more comprehensive health insurance plans offered, but it came with a whopping $3,000 deductible.

title: Study Finds Reading to Children of All Ages Grooms Them to Read More on Their Own
description: Cue the hand-wringing about digital distraction: Fewer children are reading books frequently for fun, according to a new report released Thursday by Scholastic, the childrens book publisher.

title: Word of the Day | sacrilegious
description: sacrilegious \sa-kr-lij-s\ adjective

title: Two Brothers Suspected in Killings Were Known to French Intelligence Services
description: PARIS  When Chrif Kouachi first came to the attention of the French authorities as a possible terrorist a decade ago, he was in his early 20s and, according to testimony during a 2008 Paris trial, had dreamed of attacking Jewish targets in France. Under the influence of a radical Paris preacher, however, he decided that fighting American troops in Iraq presented a better outlet for his commitment to jihad.

title: China: North Korean Soldier Dies
description: A North Korean soldier who fled into China and killed four Chinese citizens in late December has died after being injured during an arrest attempt by Chinese security forces, according to reports by Chinese state news organizations. An article published Wednesday by Xinhua, the state news agency, cited a foreign ministry spokesman discussing the soldiers death. Chinese police immediately arrested him after the incident, the spokesman, Hong Lei, said, according to Xinhua. The runaway was injured during the process and died after treatment failed. Mr. Hong said the murders by the soldier, which took place in northeast China near the North Korean border, were an individual criminal case. Earlier this week, Chinese officials said they had lodged a formal diplomatic complaint with the North Korean government.

title: The Men Behind the Cartoons at Charlie Hebdo
description: The four cartoonists killed in the offices of Charlie Hebdo, the satirical French newspaper, represented a radical, crude and vital strain of that nations culture, according to those who knew them and followed their work.

title: Study Finds More Reasons to Get and Stay Married
description: A new economics paper has some old-fashioned advice for people navigating the stresses of life: Find a spouse who is also your best friend.

title: A Rhode Island Rule on Health Enrollment Offers a Consumer Experiment
description: Millions of people signed up for Obamacare health plans in 2014. But states and the federal government faced a quandary when it came to keeping them enrolled for 2015.

title: Taking On Politicians on the Cover of Charlie Hebdo
description: French political leaders were among those skewered by cartoonists in recent editions of the Paris newspaper.

title: Places to Go, Revisited
description: Our annual Places to Go list features a mix of destinations from around the world that you should explore in 2016. Take a trip down memory lane, and around the world, with our previous top picks.

title: Corrections: January 8, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day
description: This was a maximum-impact attack. They did this to shock the public, and in that sense they succeeded.

title: Police Hunt for Suspects in Paris Attack as Nation Mourns
description: PARIS  As France mourned, thousands of law enforcement agents mobilized on Thursday in an extensive manhunt for two brothers suspected of killing 12 people, including two police officers, at the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo in Paris.

title: U.S. Charter Airline Cited for Neglecting Cargo of Macaques From China
description: An American charter airline has been accused by the United States Department of Agriculture of violating an animal protection law while shipping monkeys to laboratories in the United States from China.

title: Standard Chartered to Close Equity Sales and Research Business
description: HONG KONG  Standard Chartered said Thursday it would close its unprofitable equity sales and research business, eliminating about 200 jobs in an effort to cut about $100 million in annual costs by 2016.

title: Test Yourself | New York City Ferrets
description: Below are seven paragraphs from a Jan. 1 article, Ferret Fanciers, Ruffled by Ban, Are Eager for New York City to Lift It.

title: Panoramic Photos Show the Decisive Minute
description: Panoramas make sense to Chuy Benitez, even if they dont to some editors. He grew up in El Paso, where sprawling murals cover city walls. Hes also devoted to Diego Rivera, whose works set in specific communities layer every available inch to create full scenes. So its no mystery why the wide format struck him while he was exploring uncharted aesthetics in art school.

title: Chinese Official Is Removed From Post and, Again, Salacious Details Flow
description: The announcement on Thursday that the Communist Party chief of the city of Nanjing had been removed from his post gave little explanation, save for a line about serious discipline and law violations, a phrase that generally refers to corruption.

title: What Public Behavior Annoys You Most?
description: The New York Times recently asked subway riders what behavior irritated them most  and hundreds of answers poured in.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Terror Attack on Charlie Hebdo Newspaper in Paris Kills 12
description: In One Suspect Surrenders in Attack on French Newspaper; Two Others at Large, Dan Bilefsky and Maia de la Baume write about Wednesdays strike on a satirical newspaper.

title: Sri Lankan President Concedes Defeat After Startling Upset
description: NEW DELHI  After a startling upset in Sri Lankas presidential election, President Mahinda Rajapaksa conceded defeat on Friday morning, bringing an abrupt end to a larger-than-life, increasingly controlling presidency that he had hoped to extend into a third six-year term.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: New York Today: Its That Cold
description: Good morning on this frigid Thursday.

title: Merkel Sticks to Tough Line on Russia Sanctions
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said on Thursday that the crisis in Ukraine could be eased only if Russia made tangible progress on all 12 points of a four-month-old agreement and that sanctions imposed on Moscow for its actions in eastern Ukraine could be lifted only if that overall progress was made.

title: Democrats Step Up Efforts to Block Obamas Trade Agenda
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is facing opposition from fellow Democrats to one of his top priorities: winning the power to negotiate international trade agreements and speed them through Congress.

title: Nestl Sells Spanish Frozen Foods Brand to Findus Group
description: LONDON  The food giant Nestl said on Thursday that it had agreed to sell its La Cocinera frozen meals business to the Spanish arm of Findus Group, the British frozen food and seafood supplier.

title: Jazz & Colors Will Head Indoors, to the Met
description: Jazz & Colors, which has twice presented a bounty of jazz ensembles at picturesque locations all over Central Park, will return this year. But the festival is moving indoors  to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, according to an announcement scheduled to be made today. Jazz & Colors: The Masterworks Edition, as its being called, will be held on Friday, Jan. 30, with sets at 6 and 7:30 p.m. It will be free with museum admission.

title: Today in Politics
description: Attack in France Elicits Support and Poses a Dilemma in Congress

title: Daily Report: F.B.I. Offers More Evidence Linking North Korea to Attack on Sony
description: The F.B.I.s director, James B. Comey, said on Wednesday that the United States had concluded that North Korea was behind the destructive attacks on Sony Pictures partly because the hackers failed to mask their location when they broke into the companys servers, Michael S. Schmidt, Nicole Perlroth and Matthew Goldstein report.

title: Morning Agenda: Fed Shows Signs of Optimism
description: Federal Reserve officials were encouraged by the strength of the economy at the December meeting of the Feds policy-making committee, according to an official account published on Wednesday. But the signs of optimism were tempered by concern that the weakness of the global economy, and the weak response of foreign governments, could weigh on domestic growth, Binyamin Appelbaum reports in The New York Times. As a result, the account of the meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee made clear that Fed officials were determined not to act too quickly on raising interest rates.

title: Mourning in Paris, and a Manhunt for Suspects
description: Masked gunmen opened fire Wednesday at the Paris offices of Charlie Hebdo, a satirical weekly newspaper.

title: Animal Rights Groups Video of Hens Raises Questions, but Not Just for Farms
description: An animal rights group released on Thursday a disturbing video of laying hens at a farm in Northern California that supplies eggs to Whole Foods and Organic Valley, among other retailers and distributors.

title: How to Design an Indian Classic
description: How do you design a book for the ages?

title: Whats on TV Thursday
description: 8 P.M. (Showtime) FINDING VIVIAN MAIER (2014) In 2007, John Maloof bought a box of negatives  nearly 40,000, taken from the 1950s to the 70s  at a Chicago auction for about $400. He was told they were by Vivian Maier, but a Google search revealed no information about her. Eventually he mounted some of the works on Flickr, which led to a story in the British newspaper The Independent and an exhibition at the Chicago Cultural Center about Ms. Maier, a nanny and amateur street photographer who died in 2009. This film, which Mr. Maloof directed with Charlie Siskel, documents his search for the woman behind the images while serving as a sort of feature-length advertisement for the work he owns, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Its no surprise that Maier is now the subject of a documentary, given the quality of her work, the nominal exoticism of her life and the secrets that still drift around her, Ms. Dargis said. Shes a terrific story  part Mary Poppins, part Weegee  who was at once emancipated and in service. Still, she added, time and professional pronouncements will decide if she was an outsider artist or just an unorthodox one who, as a single 20th-century woman, found freedom, her voice and her own private bohemia while under cover of other peoples bourgeois domesticity. The documentary has been shortlisted as an Oscar contender.

title: Shes About a Lot More Than That Bass
description: Meghan Trainor doesnt really dance.

title: A Literary Triumvirate of Love and Lust
description: A frail, handsome artistic genius and the women who fuss and fight over him: That not-so-novel concept powers the German director Dominik Grafs sumptuous, soaked-in-suds costume drama, Beloved Sisters. The movie, Germanys candidate for the best foreign-language Oscar, imagines a fraught mnage  trois of the German poet and dramatist Friedrich Schiller (Florian Stetter) and two sisters.

title: To Treat Depression, Drugs or Therapy?
description: Youre feeling down, and your doctor or therapist has confirmed it: You have depression. Now what?

title: Intel Takes Wearables Beyond the Wrist and Dares Fashion to Have a New Idea
description: I admit it, among the shows I have been most excited about recently is one that is not a fashion show at all, but the Consumer Electronics Show, and if my fashion travel schedule werent so horrendous, Id be in Las Vegas right now. As it is, Ive had to survive on live streams and a constant check-in with the Twitterati. And at this stage, the news that has most piqued my interest, because I think it has the greatest potential to affect the fashion wearables market, is the introduction of Intels button-sized computer.

title: Recounting a Bustling Office at Charlie Hebdo, Then a Vision of Horror
description: PARIS  Stphane Charbonnier was perched, as was his habit every Wednesday morning, at a U-shaped wooden table on the second floor of the light-filled Parisian offices of Charlie Hebdo, the French satirical newspaper he headed. An array of papers was spread before him.

title: Updates on the 2nd Day of Search for Suspects in Charlie Hebdo Shooting
description: A manhunt continued on Thursday over a wide area of northern France for the two chief suspects in the Paris newspaper attack, as the country mourned the 12 victims.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: A Brazen Umbrella Thief
description: Dear Diary:

title: Dicks Sporting Goods Is an Attractive Candidate for Private Equity Firms
description: Dicks Sporting Goods may become the next private equity plaything. The vendor, whose stock is valued at more than $6 billion, is contemplating a leveraged buyout, according to a Reuters report on Wednesday. A relatively clean balance sheet means there is an opportunity to make money. It would, however, require healthy growth assumptions for the company at a time when stiff online competition is challenging many retailers.

title: A Softer Side of Loathing
description: No comic moves from premise to punch line as unpredictably as Louis CK.

title: Sebastian Seungs Quest to Map the Human Brain
description: In 2005, Sebastian Seung suffered the academic equivalent of an existential crisis. More than a decade earlier, with a Ph.D. in theoretical physics from Harvard, Seung made a dramatic career switch into neuroscience, a gamble that seemed to be paying off. He had earned tenure from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology a year faster than the norm and was immediately named a full professor, an unusual move that reflected the sense that Seung was something of a superstar. His lab was underwritten with generous funding by the elite Howard Hughes Medical Institute. He was a popular teacher who traveled the world  Zurich; Seoul, South Korea; Palo Alto, Calif.  delivering lectures on his mathematical theories of how neurons might be wired together to form the engines of thought.

title: Yankees Are Banking on Stephen Drew to Regain His Form at the Plate
description: During the final week of the 2014 regular season, when almost every microphone and camera lens at Yankees games was pointed in Derek Jeters direction, Stephen Drew was quietly finishing his worst year in the major leagues.

title: An Artistic Video from the Hot Chip Spinoff New Build
description: We had no real desire to release a video for this song unless we found something we really liked, says the British synthesizer artist and programmer Felix Martin of Pour It On, the new single from his band New Build. It was serendipity, then, when the band received an entrancing, unreleased video by the filmmaker Richard Heslop, known for his work with the Smiths and the Cure, which fit perfectly with the atmospheric track. I had seen a show reel of his work, and I really liked his approach to editing, as well as the way he worked with sound footage and different kinds of textures, Martin says. The band approached Heslop, who offered up the footage that would eventually become the video for Pour It On. It stars the British performance artist Rachel Gomme, who walks the beach while continuously filling her dress up with stones as a personal test of endurance.

title: Singing Oscars Tune
description: For even the most established musician, composing for film can be terrifying. As Patti Smith, the godmother of punk who wrote the lullaby Mercy Is for Noah, told the Bagger: Theres nothing worse than when youre watching a movie and one of the characters takes you out and you no longer believe the atmosphere. The same thing can happen with the wrong piece of music, so I felt a responsibility.

title: French Streaming Service Acquires Toehold in the U.S.
description: In the race to sign up subscribers for digital music, the French streaming service Deezer has had success around the world but is little known in the United States, where it faces more established competitors like Spotify, Rhapsody and Google Play.

title: First Draft Focus: Up in the Clouds
The New Obamacare Bill Would Hurt Workers and Increase the Deficit
description: Addressing lawmakers on Tuesday after his reelection as House Speaker, John Boehner chalked up partisan and intra-party divisions of the past six years to the battle of ideas that never ends, and frankly never should.

title: Santander Plans $8.9 Billion Capital Increase to Strengthen Balance Sheet
description: MADRID  Emilio Botn reshaped Banco Santander into one of the largest financial institutions in Europe through a series of major acquisitions.

title: Ralph Lauren
description: The prefall collection was an ode to camel, fringe and cashmere including jogging pants and chunky knitwear.

title: A Postcard From Paris
description: I arrived in Paris yesterday, scheduled to give a series of lectures in philosophy. The lectures are in political philosophy, on how power distorts liberal democracy. Ive been nervous about giving these lectures in Paris, the city in which a liberal democratic revolution toppled a system of power, monarchy, which seemed to those subject to it both permanent and inevitable.

title: Throwback Thursday | Ruffians Living By Pillage, Underwater Nightclubs and Other Predictions for 2015
description: In 1906, The Times reviewed a new book, The Doomsman, that was all about what the year 2015 would be like after a terror had extinguished some 99 percent of the human race and all the desperate characters from the whole country had flocked to New York City.

title: Parenting on the Dark Side
description: SPOKANE, WASH.  My therapist calls me a loyal skeptic, a person who struggles to gain security and certainty in a world that she believes is inherently dangerous.

title: Neneh Cherry Will Get an Overdue New York Debut
description: THE itinerant avant-pop singer Neneh Cherry has a routine when she visits New York, where she lived as a child and has intermittently since. Most of the stops are food-related: a diner breakfast, pastrami from Katzs, Veselka on her old corner in the East Village, and, of course, a slice of pizza.

title: Carlyle Hires Information Chief From T. Rowe Price
description: The Carlyle Group has hired a former T. Rowe Price executive, Georgette Kiser, to run its information technology operations.

title: Video Review: The Lincoln MKC Is the Right Vehicle at the Right Time
description: A few years back, the future looked hazy for Lincoln. Fords luxury division had killed its best-known model, the Town Car. The MKZ looked like a gussied-up Fusion, the MKX was based on the Edge.

title: Driven | Lincoln MKC
description: Built on the bones of Fords Escape, Lincolns compact MKC crossover is speedy and athletic.

title: Parisians Join in Moment of Silence
description: People stood in the rain to join in a minute of silence honoring the victims of the shooting attack on the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo.

title: Next Year in Havana
description: Cuba is the idiosyncratic sister of the Caribbean, and a large part of its idiosyncrasy stems from having watched as the last half-century passed it by. What was once a cultural hotbed moldered under Communism. Still, there is an embattled dignity in Havanas dilapidated architecture, whether colonial style or Art Deco or even the midcentury classics; nowhere else does the traveler find this peculiar marriage between the contemporary and the antiquated, with its incongruous traces of the space age, of Spanish flair and Soviet flotsam. There is, too, a unique resilience among Cubans themselves, whose talent for improvisation, for making do with whats at hand, is legendary. The feeling of living in frozen time is one of Cubas most frustrating realities and its most powerful allure. To imagine Cuba without it evokes an almost existential question.

title: San Franciscos Tenderloin Casts Light on Artists It May Lose as Wealth Moves In
description: In a small stand against gentrification, the nonprofit Wildflowers Institute has helped the gritty neighborhood define its cultural assets.

title: 1915: Wedding Party Travels in Punts
description: LONDON  As a result of the floods there was a romantic military wedding at Bray yesterday.The bride, bridegroom and the guests had to travel part of the way to the church in punts. The bridegroom was Captain Forbes Adams, of the Indian army, who only arrived here last night straight from the trenches on a weeks leave. The bride was Miss Pitman, the second daughter of Mr. F. Pitman, the well-known Cambridge Blue. Every arrangement had been made by Mr. Pitman to enable the wedding party to get to and from the church, for his house, Bray Mead, is completely surrounded by water.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 8, 1915

title: Peoples Choice Awards
description: The ceremony, held at the Nokia Theater in Los Angeles on Wednesday, is an anything-goes precursor to the Golden Globes.

title: Activist Hedge Fund Again Warns Yahoo Against Making a Big Acquisition
description: With speculation picking up among investors about Yahoo going on a shopping spree, an activist hedge fund that has taken a position in the company has again publicly declared its opposition to such a move.

title: Mapping Out a Holiday With the Family
description: If you want to see true collaboration between a playwright and a director, check out the floor of the performing space at City Center Stage II. Its a mass of painted lines that suggests what youd get if a football-play diagram and an astrological chart had a baby. And it was the key that allowed a young director to take an intriguing but formless play by a new writer and make a startlingly entertaining theatrical experience out of it.

title: An Upper East Side Apartment Convenient to Work
description: Two years ago, Alexis Wold arrived in New York from her hometown, Albuquerque, and rented a studio in a dog-friendly Yorkville walk-up. It had two of the things she wanted most  a laundry room and an easy walk to the hospital where she works.

title: Clothes and Character: Colleen Atwood on Into the Woods and Big Eyes
description: Having two projects released on the same day was a surprise for Colleen Atwood, the costume designer for both Big Eyes, Tim Burtons biopic about the artist Margaret Keane, and Into the Woods, Rob Marshalls adaptation of the Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical. Both films hit theaters on Dec. 25, one of the most competitive box office dates of the year.

title: Poetry Pairing | Khaleesi Says
description: This Poetry Pairing features Leah Umanskys poem Khaleesi Says and the Op-Ed column Bring Me My Dragons! by Maureen Dowd.

title: Louis CK at the Garden
description: The comedian performed a stand-up set on Wednesday night.

title: Cartoonists Respond to Charlie Hebdo Massacre
description: LONDON  Yesterday and today cartoonists around the world created drawings responding to the attacks in Paris that killed 12 staffers at the satirical French weekly Charlie Hebdo. Many of the responses quickly gained traction on social media, gathering likes, shares and retweets.

title: A Relais & Chateaux Hotel in Hawaii
description: Hawaii has no shortage of upscale hotels, but Relais & Chateaux, the group of more than 500 luxury properties and restaurants worldwide, had never had a presence in the state until this month.

title: Politics Helpline: Ask Us About the 114th Congress
description: Do you have a question about the new Congress? How the new Republican majority in the Senate will work with President Obama? Which bills will reach the floor first, or which have the best chance at becoming law?

title: As Wealth Changes the Tenderloin, a Move to Preserve Artistic Gems
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Ira Watkins paints his pictures in a faded Dodge van with velveteen seats parked beside a center for seniors in the Tenderloin, a seamy part of town frequently associated with displaced loners, drug addicts in squalid alleyways and other manifestations of human misery.

title: Detroit Institute of Arts Director to Step Down
description: Graham W. J. Beal, one of the most battle-scarred directors in recent American museum history, announced plans to retire in June after leading the Detroit Institute of Arts through an unprecedented threat to its world-class collection during Detroits federal bankruptcy.

title: In Web Video, Senator Boxer Announces Plans to Retire
description: Senator Barbara Boxer of California made an unconventional retirement announcement on Thursday when she told her grandson in a video interview that she would not seek re-election in 2016.

title: BLVD Bistro
description: Southern comfort on the menu in Harlem.

title: Weaving the Threads of Soul Food
description: It would take more than my fingers and toes to count the classic Harlem joints that have closed in recent years, taking their Southern specialties with them to the grave. M & G Diners corn muffins, gone. Pan Pans chicken and waffles, gone. Louises Family Restaurants fish and grits, gone.

title: John Luther Adams Wins a Lifetime Achievement Award
description: The composer John Luther Adams continues to ride the wave. Mr. Adams, who won a Pulitzer Prize last year for his mesmerizing,environmentally aware orchestral work Become Ocean, will be awarded the $50,000 William Schuman Award this fall, Columbia Universitys School of the Arts announced on Thursday.

title: A Games Grand Young Man
description: Several weeks had passed since the greatest moment in Sam Sevians chess life, enough time to allow for some quiet reflection. On a recent Sunday afternoon inside a Midtown Manhattan high-rise, where the teenage Sevian had been invited for a training session with the chess champion Garry Kasparov, he recalled a recent game with enormous stakes.

title: The Art Worlds Holy Fool
description: A look at the work of the artist Ray Johnson.

title: Boxer Says She Wont Seek Re-election to Senate in California in 2016
description: LOS ANGELES  Senator Barbara Boxer announced Thursday that she would not seek re-election as senator from California, ending a 30-year career in Congress and breaking a generational logjam in a state where the three top political officeholders are older than 70.

title: Always on His Own Terms
description: Twenty years ago next week, the artist Ray Johnson jumped off a low bridge in Sag Harbor, N.Y., and backstroked placidly out to sea. Two teenage girls saw him plunge into the frigid water and tried to alert the police, but when they found the station closed they went to see a movie instead, a detail many of Mr. Johnsons friends said would have delighted him.

title: 1956 | The Voice of a Free Press
description: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

title: How Keystone XL Got (So) Political
description: As Washington debates Keystone XL, heres how the 1,179-mile pipeline became so political.

title: Experts Say That Battle on Keystone Pipeline Is Over Politics, Not Facts
description: WASHINGTON  In 2009, the Obama administration approved a 986-mile pipeline to bring 400,000 barrels of oil sands petroleum a day from western Canada to the United States. Almost no one paid attention. Construction on the pipeline, called the Alberta Clipper, was quietly completed last year.

title: Spineless? A Squish? The Words Do Sting, Boehner Says
description: Two days after surviving a minor coup attempt, Speaker John A. Boehner on Thursday took a stab at answering the question that has been nagging him for his entire speakership: Why do Tea Party conservatives hate him so much?

title: Honda Fined for Violations of Safety Law
description: In a sharp escalation of penalties against automakers that skirt safety laws, the nations top auto safety agency has fined Honda Motor a record $70 million for grossly underreporting fatal accidents and injuries to the government, regulators said on Thursday.

title: 1965: Actress Still a U.S. Citizen
description: WASHINGTON  Elizabeth Taylor tried to renounce her U.S. citizenship but failed because she could not bring herself to disavow all allegiance and fidelity to the United States, the State Department said today. The London-born film star reportedly said the United States had been good to her and that she did not want to imply that she bore it ill will by using such language. Miss Taylors New York spokesman said she decided to renounce her citizenship because she wanted to have the same citizenship as her husband, British actor Richard Burton.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 8, 1965

title: A Foreign Film Coincidence, Two Years in a Row
description: In last years competition for the Oscar for best foreign-language film, something seemingly odd, the apparent product of coincidence, happened: the Israeli and Palestinian submissions dealt with the same story. Both Yuval Adlers Bethlehem and Hany Abu-Assads Omar, which eventually received a nomination, focused on the relationship between a young Palestinian informer and his control agent in Israeli intelligence, and the two movies even ended the same way, with the mole turning on his handler.

title: In Vermont, Election Is Held on Nov. 4, and Governor Is Chosen on Jan. 8
description: MONTPELIER, Vt.  November came and went, and even until Thursday, Vermonters did not know who would be inaugurated as governor. They seemed to take this uncertainty in stride, much as they ignored the record-breaking low temperature of minus 20 degrees that encased the gray granite statehouse here in a brittle air.

title: Washington Power Lunch
Uber Tests a Cargo Delivery Service in Hong Kong
description: Uber has made millions offering quick, convenient rides to customers. Its ambitions are much larger.

title: First Draft Focus: And I Had On These Bright Blue Slippers!
Peaks and Valleys of Nero dAvola
description: For a decade now, Sicily has been among the most exciting wine regions in the world. Ive fallen in love with reds and whites, wines full of freshness and vitality, complexity and a sense of place, from both Mount Etna in the east and the region centering on Vittoria in the southeast.

title: A Georgian Competing on Estonias Behalf
description: It is 1992, shortly after the breakup of the Soviet Union, and the newly independent republic of Georgia is embroiled in a war with a Russian proxy army supporting the breakaway province of Abkhazia. From the Caucasus Mountains to the Black Sea, villagers have fled, but in one remote settlement a pair of old men, Ivo and Margus, have stubbornly remained behind, hoping to harvest a crop of tangerines.

title: Paris Terror Suspect Shown in 2005 Film
description: Chrif Kouachi, one of the suspects in the Charlie Hebdo shootings in Paris, appeared in a 2005 investigative documentary about jihadism that aired on French television.

title: General Motors Chief Pledges to Move Beyond Recalls
description: DETROIT  In her first year as chief executive of General Motors, Mary T. Barra was engulfed by the gravest safety crisis in the companys history.

title: Caesars Gets More Support for Restructuring Plan, With Sale by BlackRock
description: Some of Wall Streets largest investors are playing a game of high-stakes poker in preparation for a big casino company bankruptcy.

title: The Stumbling, Tumbling Euro
description: European leaders and central bankers have been saying for years that their economic policies would soon revive the economies of the eurozone. It seems that investors have finally stopped believing those fairy tales.

title: First Build an Island, Then Make a Film
description: The Georgian filmmaker George Ovashvili, director and co-writer of Corn Island, says he is living a dream these days. He was 13 when he decided he wanted to direct movies, but his first feature, The Other Bank, was released only when he was 45, after years of political turmoil in his homeland and decades of personal struggle and sacrifice.

title: When Dynasties Roamed
description: Once upon a time, it was common for teams to advance to the Super Bowl two years in a row.

title: Alongside Je Suis Charlie, Slain Officer Inspires His Own Social Media Refrain
description: PARIS  In an amateur video that was widely circulated online after the shooting Wednesday at the Charlie Hebdo newspaper offices in Paris, two gunmen could be seen killing a police officer as he lay wounded on the ground.

title: Tenderloin Artists Unite
description: As a tech boom reshapes San Francisco, a nonprofit group is searching for and cataloging the artists of the Tenderloin, arguably the central citys last working-class neighborhood.

title: A Different Lion to Stalk the Stage
description: LONDON  A length of rubber tubing becomes a bucket of squirming eels. Aluminum ladders are transformed into the cage-like walls of a sinister pharmaceutical company. Boxes and ropes evoke the crowded, bustling streets of London or a ship peopled by an itinerant circus troupe.

title: A Close Call on Publication of Charlie Hebdo Cartoons
description: Was The Times cowardly and lacking in journalistic solidarity when it decided not to publish the images from the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo that precipitated the execution of French journalists?

title: In Ray Rice Case, N.F.L. Chose Not to Ask Many Questions
description: An investigation into how the N.F.L. handled a domestic abuse case involving the former Baltimore Ravens running back Ray Rice determined that the league was aware of the nature of the altercation but chose not to aggressively pursue additional information.

title: Top Bankers in Europe Making Big Bonuses, According to Latest Data
description: LONDON  The public is getting its annual peek at the top earners in Europe at major banks.

title: Teaching The Kite Runner With The New York Times
description: In the original Times review of The Kite Runner, published in 2003, Edward Hower describes the novel as telling a story of fierce cruelty and fierce yet redeeming love. He goes on to write, Both transform the life of Amir, Khaled Hosseinis privileged young narrator, who comes of age during the last peaceful days of the monarchy, just before his countrys revolution and its invasion by Russian forces.

title: Police Department Slowdown? A Parkers Paradise and a Reporters Challenge
description: This week, the Metro reporter Vivian Yee wrote  about the visible effects of an apparent slowdown in arrests and ticketing by the New York Police Department. Here, Ms. Yee describes the reportorial oddity of covering events that are NOT occurring.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | A Most Violent Year
description: The writer and director J.C. Chandor narrates a sequence from his film.

title: Santander Finally Gets the Message on Capital
description: Ana Patricia Botn is grabbing the bull by the horns. The new executive chairwoman of Banco Santander is seeking 7.5 billion euros of fresh equity in a speedy share sale and slashing the dividend. The Spanish bank has long resisted raising capital or touching its outsize payout. The moves may be overdue and including pre-emption rights would have been fairer on shareholders. But Santander is getting capital now without the challenge of a drawn-out rights issue during a critical Greek election.

title: Obama, in Bid to Ease Home Buying, Cuts Mortgage Insurance Rate
description: PHOENIX  President Obama announced on Thursday new measures to try to assist a still-sluggish housing market, even as he hailed an economic recovery that he said was finally roaring ahead.

title: Documentary on Russell Brand to Open South by Southwest Film Festival
description: Russell Brand, the comedian, actor, author and activist, will take the spotlight at the South by Southwest Film Festival: hes the subject of the opening-night film, Brand: A Second Coming, organizers announced Thursday. The documentary, directed by Ondi Timoner (We Live in Public), offers an intimate look at the British entertainer, whose film credits include Get Him to the Greek, Forgetting Sarah Marshall and, in the title role, the remake of the 1981 comedy Arthur.

title: Congress Passes Measure to Cover Terrorism Risk
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday gave overwhelming final congressional approval to a revamped federal backstop to terrorism insurance, just eight days after lawmakers allowed it to lapse. Businesses had pleaded for the bill, saying it was necessary to avoid losing some important investments.

title: Robert S. Mueller III's Report on Ray Rice Domestic Violence Case
description: The report by Robert S. Mueller III, the former F.B.I. director chosen by the N.F.L. to determine how the league handled its investigation of a domestic abuse case involving the former Baltimore Ravens running back Ray Rice.

title: Talking to Your Teenager About Online Pornography
description: If Parenting in the Age of Online Pornography has you worried, take heart. Encountering pornography on the Internet, intentionally or inadvertently, may be a near-guarantee for the modern teenager, but the parents of those teenagers dont need to feel helpless in the anticipation of the event, or in its discovery.

title: The Recruiter From Another Planet
description: Not long ago I received an email from someone using a Gmail address, claiming to be a headhunter representing Fortune 500-level companies. The person asked about my interest in a position at an unnamed firm, and requested a rsum. I responded positively, but became suspicious when a follow-up asked for my salary information and the reason Id left the last company I worked for.

title: Whose Baby Is Boyhood?
description: LOS ANGELES  In early September 2001, Barack Obama was a state senator. The World Trade Center still stood. And the director Richard Linklater was sitting in a restaurant in Venice, pondering a very personal film idea.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: marriage, youth and exercise and alcohol poisoning. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Obama Announces Housing Plan in Arizona
description: The president visited Arizona to herald gains in the recovering housing market and announced a housing initiative to lower annual mortgage insurance premiums.

title: Chita Rivera and Roger Rees to Star in The Visit on Broadway
description: The Tony Award winners Chita Rivera and Roger Rees will star on Broadway this spring in The Visit, a darkly romantic musical that has been evolving over the last 15 years; its creators are the acclaimed theatrical songwriters John Kander and Fred Ebb (Chicago, Cabaret) and their frequent collaborator, Terrence McNally. The producers announced on Thursday that The Visit, directed by the Tony winner John Doyle (the 2005 Broadway revival of Sweeney Todd), will begin performances March 26 at the Lyceum Theater and open on April 23  the eligibility deadline for 2015 Tony nominations.

title: Inside Helmut Langs New Art Show
description: Ten years ago, Helmut Lang sold his stake in his eponymous label and shifted focus to making art at his studio in East Hampton. Tonight, he opens his first New York City solo gallery show at Sperone Westwater in SoHo, presenting a body of sculptural works from 2010 to 2014. Some include repurposed materials from his past vocation, while other, more recent, works comment on the passage of time in a less narrative and more metaphysical way.

title: The Risk of Material Parenting
description: As a parent and scholar who has studied materialism for much of her professional life, Marsha Richins had long pondered the following question: Does dangling goods in front of children as a reward for good behavior or yanking them away as a form of punishment contribute to materialism when those kids grow up?

title: Man Convicted of Environmental Terrorism Is Freed
description: A man serving a 19-year prison sentence for environmental terrorism won an early release from prison on Thursday, with a California judge approving a settlement between defense lawyers and prosecutors that acknowledged that the authorities had withheld documents during his criminal trial.

title: Honda Motors Fined a Record Amount, but Its Still Just a Rounding Error
description: After a year filled with news about the negligence of automakers, federal regulators are getting tougher on car companies. But the penalties still seem modest.

title: New Clues on Googles Plans for Insurance
description: The insurance industry takes it for granted that Google will soon introduce its Google Compare auto insurance shopping site  available in Britain for two years  in the United States.

title: Unraveling the Key to a Cold Viruss Effectiveness
description: If there is a champion among contagions, it may well be the lowly rhinovirus, responsible for many of the coughs and sniffles that trouble us this time of year. Rhinoviruses are spectacularly effective at infecting humans. Americans suffer one billion colds a year, and rhinoviruses are the leading cause of these infections.

title: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar to Publish a Novel About Sherlock Holmess Brother Mycroft
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbars first novel, Mycroft Holmes, which stars Sherlock Holmes brainy older brother, will be published this fall by Titan Books.

title: Trove of Still Lifes on the Auction Block
description: Until recently, Henry and June Weldons Park Avenue apartment reflected a kind of passionate, obsessive collecting of a bygone era. Wood-paneled rooms featured cabinets stuffed with rare English pottery and 17th-century Dutch and Flemish paintings hung cheek by jowl on every available wall. Asian sculptures were also scattered around the place.

title: What I Love | Angus McIndoe
description: The restaurateur parks his sneakers far from the Broadway crowd.

title: Barbara Boxer and the Rise of Democratic Partisan Discipline
description: It might seem unremarkable that Senator Barbara Boxer of California, who announced on Thursday that she would not seek re-election, voted with a majority of her Democratic colleagues 98 percent of the time during the past two years.

title: Shamans on Call for Rites Near Machu Picchu
description: In the highlands surrounding Machu Picchu in Peru, luxury hotels are calling on Andean shamans to spiritually cleanse their guests, renew wedding vows and lead ceremonies to offer gratitude to Mother Earth.

title: The One-Word Resolution
description: I love this idea. For New Years, instead of a resolution (and its not too late for resolutions, the month is still fresh), why not boil all your bubbling good intentions down into a single word? It came first from a Facebook post from Lisa Belkin, in which she credits the author Laura Lippman for the inspiration:

title: Former Georgia Tech Engineering Professor Indicted on Racketeering Charges
description: A former high-profile electrical engineering professor has been indicted on racketeering charges, nearly five years after his career at the Georgia Institute of Technology collapsed over a wireless chip start-up he founded.

title: Tracing a World Awash in Lies
description: Sun Xun was in residence at Sean Kelly in December, working in an ad hoc studio on the lower level of the gallery with his assistants and adding paintings and drawings to the exhibition upstairs as he went along. The news release for the show says, Questions and dialogue with the artist will be encouraged, so I obliged.

title: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
description: France and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Raising the Profile of Columbias Art
description: Columbia University owns thousands of antiquities, antiques and paintings, but it has no major display spaces and no comprehensive database. So the works largely go unnoticed even by some staff members. Roberto C. Ferrari, an art historian and librarian who became Columbias curator of art properties in 2013, has set out to raise the profile of the 10,000 objects on campus.

title: Times Readers on the Charlie Hebdo Massacre
description: Readers responding to a Times editorial on the Charlie Hebdo killings seemed most keen to discuss what wasnt in the editorial: Reproductions of Charlie Hebdo cartoons. A Times spokesperson has explained that the paper does not normally publish images or other material deliberately intended to offend religious sensibilities. But many readers said that was a cop out.

title: J. C. Chandor Narrates a Scene From A Most Violent Year
description: In this video, the writer and director J. C. Chandor narrates a sequence from his film, featuring Oscar Isaac as the intimidating owner of a heating oil company.

title: More on the Complex Tax-Minded Deal That Starboard Doesnt Want Yahoo to Do
description: The activist hedge fund Starboard Value fretted on Thursday that Yahoo might employ a type of complicated transaction to dispose its minority stakes in the Chinese Internet giant Alibaba Group and in the publicly traded Yahoo Japan.

title: From Czarist Rubble, a Russian Autocrat Rises
description: Readers plunging into Stephen Kotkins Stalin: Paradoxes of Power expecting a detailed dissection of the cobblers son and seminarian from Georgia who evolved into the monster called Stalin may be disconcerted to find that, as a boy called Iosif Dzhugashvili (Jughashvili in this book), he plays a relatively minor role in early chapters.

title: Rudy Burckhardt: Subterranean Monuments: A Centenary Celebration
description: Rarer than the artists artist is the poets artist, and Rudy Burckhardt was one. Born in Switzerland in 1914 into a family of scholars and businessmen, he picked up photography early and, after meeting the American poet and critic Edwin Denby, came to New York in 1935. Creating art and living in an aesthetic milieu seemed, initially at least, to have about equal weight for him. Mr. Burckhardt tended to speak of himself as a committed amateur in the sense of being someone who does what he does for love, not glory or pay. In his case, that love embraced several mediums, all represented in a small museum-ready survey called Rudy Burckhardt: Subterranean Monuments: A Centenary Celebration at Tibor de Nagy.

title: Those Who Nailed 2014 See Volatility This Year
description: Volatility will be the new normal in 2015.

title: Takashi Murakami: In the Land of the Dead, Stepping on the Tail of a Rainbow
description: In his exhibition at Gagosian, Takashi Murakami appears unintimidated by big historical and religious subjects but strangely cowed by his fellow artists. Working in response to the devastating earthquake and tsunami of 2011 in the Tohoku region of Japan, he has come up with a quasi-spiritual installation of paintings and sculptures surrounding a copy of the gates of a Buddhist temple. It invites us to meditate and heal from the trauma of natural disasters and to savor expensively fabricated art objects while worshiping Koons, Hirst and Warhol (as if we needed another place to do that).

title: Entang Wiharso
description: One of Indonesias most prominent contemporary artists, Entang Wiharso represented his country in the Venice Biennale of 2013. He has been included in other biennials and museum exhibitions from Tokyo to Rome. This gaudy, overstuffed exhibition reveals an artist of extraordinary industry and canny versatility. In near mural-scale paintings and in sculptures cast in aluminum, brass and resin, he mixes traditional Indonesian styles with Pop and Surrealism, creating allegories of psychic stress in a global economy.

title: Modern Photographs
description: Photos from the new show at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Cy Twombly: Treatise on the Veil
description: Cy Twombly: Treatise on the Veil ostentatiously combines two museum trends: exhibitions built around one important painting, and the growing urge of museums of all kinds to feature modern and contemporary art. Here the yen for newness is lavishly advertised by a show centering on the billboard-size painting Treatise on the Veil (Second Version), a panoramic canvas measuring nearly 33 feet across that Cy Twombly (1928-2011) made in Rome in 1970.

title: House Passes Bill to Alter Health Laws Workweek Provision
description: The 114th Congress took up its first bill to impose changes to the Affordable Care Act on Thursday, with the House of Representatives passing legislation to expand the laws definition of a workweek to 40 hours, from 30.

title: Tamir Rice Shooting Aftermath
description: The Cleveland Police Department released surveillance footage showing the aftermath of the shooting of 12-year-old Tamir Rice, in which his sister can be seen running toward him.

title: Police Gave Boy No Aid After Shooting in Cleveland
description: The two Cleveland police officers involved in the fatal shooting of Tamir Rice, a 12-year-old boy who was carrying a pellet gun, stood by without rendering medical aid as the boy lay wounded next to their patrol car, a newly released extended surveillance video shows.

title: For a Love of His People
description: A new show at the National Museum of the American Indian features the work of the photographer Horace Poolaw.

title: Black and White and Accessible All Over
description: Overflowing with prints by Berenice Abbott, Andre Kertesz, Edward Weston and other luminaries from the first half of the 20th century, Modern Photographs: The Thomas Walther Collection, 1909-1949, at the Museum of Modern Art, would seem to be a straightforward look at photographys past. But the show, packaged with a book, a symposium and an engrossing interactive website, is really a bold attempt to visualize the future of photography inside the museum as it reckons with the unwieldy, image-saturated culture outside the galleries.

title: Going Mainstream on Their Own Terms
description: A 2001 exhibition called Spirit Capture: Native Americans and the Photographic Image, at the National Museum of the American Indian in Lower Manhattan, remains one of the most moving photography shows Ive seen in New York in two decades. Culled from the museums permanent collection, it wasnt about formal perfection or a singular sensibility. It was an archival look at a group of people as they were historically portrayed through a visual medium they didnt invent and, until recently, rarely used. Indeed, it was a show about how that medium invented and used them, or rather stereotyped images of them  the recalcitrant savage, the timeless primitive, the vanishing race  to create an official American saga from a victors point of view.

title: A Kaleidoscope of Meaning on a Single Surface
description: Devin Powerss kaleidoscopic new paintings muster an elaborate physicality while corralling a profusion of references to different cultures, mediums and artifacts within their irregular borders. They might more logically be called painted reliefs, but they confuse matters by being so clearly derived from a single surface on which a mongrel process of drawing, painting and chiseling has run a bit rampant. And nothing is quite as rampant as the unhinged geometric patterns, defined first by automatist drawing and then by divots painted with contrasting colors, which give the best works a writhing, billowing energy.

title: G.O.P. Faces Push From Right to Be Bolder
description: WASHINGTON  The Heritage Foundation, long known as a font of conservative ideas, is planning a two-day policy conference next week aimed at nudging Republicans toward a more aggressive agenda, just days before House and Senate Republicans are set to hold a joint retreat.

title: As San Francisco Booms, So Does its Gallery Scene
description: San Francisco, as has been well documented, is undergoing seismic cultural shifts. The second technology boom has brought an influx of wealth, investors and start-up prospectors to the city, drawing parallels with the gold rush of 1849. Now, as members of the newly well-heeled tech elite look to invest their money, the citys small but thriving gallery scene is finding itself the recipient of their attention.

title: Before Paris Shooting, Authors Tapped Into Mood of a France Homesick at Home
description: PARIS  The cover of this weeks Charlie Hebdo, the French satirical newspaper that was the target of a massacre on Wednesday by masked gunmen, featured a cartoon depicting Michel Houellebecq, whose polemical  some say prophetic  new novel, Submission, imagines a Muslim becoming president of France in 2022.

title: Passengers Accounts of Rescue From Burning Ferry Differ Sharply
description: VERBANIA, Italy  Leonidha Ndreu was one of the first of nearly 450 passengers to leave the Norman Atlantic, the ill-fated ferryboat that caught fire en route from Greece to Italy early last week, killing at least 11 passengers. Zoran Koron was one of the last.

title: The Thing and the Thing-in-Itself
description: This spare, thought-provoking exhibitions title derives from a distinction posited by Immanuel Kant. That is, a thing can be known by a human being only from his or her unique perspective. What the thing is, in and of itself, independent of any perceivers view of it, isnt fully knowable. Organized by the art historian Robert Hobbs, the exhibition presents seven things, which he introduces as works that pit peoples sight and insight against the limits of what they are able to comprehend.

title: Music Emanating From a Box
description: Temporary Distortions durational installation My Voice Has an Echo in It, part of the Coil festival, has the feeling of a happening in which not much actually happens. The company drew notice with a trilogy of plays  Welcome to Nowhere, Americana Kamikaze and Newyorkland  that juxtaposed skillful video sequences with less compelling live ones. The video sprawled and soared and dazzled. The stage actors hunched in viselike shadow boxes.

title: North Korea Seems to Be Closer to Missile-Launching Submarine
description: North Korea has displayed its cyberattack capabilities and advances toward making nuclear warheads, the countrys adversaries say. Now, the North appears to have shown progress in fitting submarines with missile launchers.

title: After Six Years of Homelessness, Taking Comfort in an Apartment of Her Own
description: After six years without a home, Elisa Byard had no choice but to enter New York Citys shelter system in 2012.

title: Al Qaeda Trained Suspect in Paris Terror Attack, Official Says
description: WASHINGTON  One of the two brothers suspected of killing 12 people at a satirical newspaper in Paris traveled to Yemen in 2011 and received terrorist training from Al Qaedas affiliate there before returning to France, a senior American official said Thursday.

title: Comedy Listings for Jan. 9-15
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Pictures of the Day  Jan. 8, 2015
description: Photos from France, Lebanon, India and the United States.

title: After the Terrorist Attack in Paris
description: To the Editor:

title: Movie Listings for Jan. 9-15
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: A Trans-Atlantic View of Modernism
description: At the Metropolitan Museum of Art, lots of works of early European and American modernism are now sharing the same galleries. This shouldnt be radical. It is. At least for New York.

title: Boehner vs. the Far Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Theater Listings for Jan. 9-15
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: When Traveling Through Time, Pack a Change of Identities
description: Jumping across time and space is tough, thankless business in Predestination, a slab of science-fiction speculation draped in old-fashioned detective story crepe. The story centers on a temporal agent, a futuristic enforcer (he tries to right wrongs before they happen) nicely played by Ethan Hawke with a hungry, hangdog look that suggests that his character has spent long nights howling in the wasteland, often without either a scrap or a prayer. Whether slinking through 1985 or another vintage year (usually while chasing down a bomber), the temporal agent looks like a classic lone wolf.

title: Helping the Transgendered
description: To the Editor:

title: A Latter-Day Chaplin, Pining for Romance
description: In recent years the choreographer Doug Elkins has been consumed by stories and the music behind them. His entertaining Frulein Maria, created in 2006, is a Bessie Award-winning sendup of The Sound of Music. Six years later Mr. Elkins returned to an early distillation of Othello, using a Motown-inspired score and B-boy moves, in his wildly popular Mo(or)town/Redux.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Weekend Entertainments from the Archives of The New York Times
description: 41 YEARS AGO

title: Visual Beauty and History in Hartford
description: Hartford bears the scars, and reaps the benefits, of the urban renewal and social upheaval of mid-20th century America. Yet for a small city, it boasts extraordinary ethnic diversity and fluidity.

title: Jazz Listings for Jan. 9-15
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: The Supreme Court, Online
description: To the Editor:

title: Harvard and Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Moving Toward Internet Fairness
description: The Federal Communications Commission is moving closer to issuing strong rules that would stop cable and phone companies from establishing fast lanes and slow lanes on the Internet. Such arrangements would discriminate against smaller companies that have a tough enough time as it is competing against big content providers like Amazon and Netflix.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Jan. 9-15
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Stigma of Ebola Customer Is Too Much for Bridal Shop
description: CHICAGO  Unable to shake its reputation as the Ebola store, an Ohio bridal shop visited by a woman who later tested positive for the virus will close this year, the stores manager said Thursday.

title: Gene-Modified Grass
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeking Solace Elsewhere, Before Encountering It at Home
description: Dal Lake, the setting of Musa Syeeds small glowing film Valley of Saints, is a picturesque body of water in the Kashmir region where tourists flock to have boatmen take them to sites with names like Floating Garden and Lotus Lake. The water is dotted with small man-made islands.

title: Opera & Classical Music Listings for Jan. 9-15
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Dance Listings for Jan. 9-15
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Pop, Rock & Cabaret Listings for Jan. 9-15
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: The Birth of Civil War Reenacting
description: On the morning of Feb. 22, 1864 in Hillsborough, Ohio, a crowd gathered for a celebration of Washingtons Birthday. The usual monotony of our peaceful and quiet town was agreeably broken, wrote the local newspaper, the Highland Weekly News, when three cavalry companies forming the 24th Battalion of the Ohio Volunteer Cavalry, armed and equipped with sabres and carbines, paraded in front of the public square. No one but the officers knew what would happen. In short time, the 4-pounder known as Old Red was brought out, and a gun-squad formed of a number of veteran volunteers. Then the cavalry galloped off to the outskirts of town, the artillery took position and the infantry began building breastworks.

title: Challenging Corruption in the Niger Delta
description: There are no half-measures in the Nigerian brand of moviemaking called Nollywood: Black November, a blood-for-oil drama directed by Jeta Amata, with a mix of Nigerian and American actors, opens with a hostage crisis in a Los Angeles tunnel. It unfolds in flashbacks to corruption and protests in the oil-rich Niger Delta, where Mr. Amata stages as many face-offs and tirades as he can, bringing a full-on pulp style and speechifying to a fraught subject.

title: High-Ranking Editor to Leave Bloomberg News
description: Laurie Hays, a senior executive editor at Bloomberg News, is leaving the company, people with knowledge of the matter said on Thursday.

title: U.S.O.C. Chooses Boston as Candidate for 2024 Summer Olympics
description: Boston, which stages a celebrated marathon and has a rich history of professional championships in basketball, football, baseball and hockey, will now swing for the fences in international sport as it seeks to host the 2024 Summer Olympics.

title: Captive, and Not Just to the Internet
description: There is something profoundly draining and suffocatingly incestuous about watching a film thats dedicated to watching a computer screen. Its as if directors hoped to lure audiences away from their hand-held and desktop devices by focusing on characters who are glued to their own. All theyre likely to end up with, however, are movies that hardly ever move.

title: Skip Your Annual Physical
description: WE all make resolutions and promises to live healthier and better lives, to make the world a better place. Not having my annual physical is one small way I can help reduce health care costs  and save myself time, worry and a worthless exam.

title: Reading The Times With Meghan Daum
description: Meghan Daum is an op-ed columnist for The Los Angeles Times and the author, most recently, of The Unspeakable: And Other Subjects of Discussion.

title: In Intimate Quarrels, Deciphering Whats Unsaid
description: Corneliu Porumboiu makes films in which talk leads to obfuscation. 12:08 East of Bucharest hinges on a debate over whether revolutionary action took place in a small Romanian city in 1989. Police, Adjective climaxes with an argument over how literally the law should apply to an insignificant hashish bust.

title: Spare Times for Children for Jan. 9-15
description: Winter Blast

title: DuPont Finds Itself a Target of Activist Nelson Peltz
description: DuPont is about to face one of the biggest challenges in its two centuries as an industrial powerhouse: a fight with one of Wall Streets most prominent activist investors over its board.

title: Spare Times for Jan. 9-15
description: Around Town

title: Apples Cut From App Sales Reached $4.5 Billion in 2014
description: Apple continues to make billions of dollars from mobile apps sold in its App Store. The company said on Thursday that in 2014, billings from app sales rose 50 percent from the previous year, which results in roughly $15 billion in revenue for app developers and a $4.5 billion cut for Apple.

title: A Family Fractured by the Holocaust
description: Interweaving multiple perspectives and three generations of family memories, Yael Reuvenys Farewell Herr Schwarz traces a Holocaust mystery with stumbling curiosity and endearing sincerity.

title: In Cat-Kicking Case, Judge Dismisses Most Serious Charge
description: A Brooklyn man whose cat-kicking case infuriated animal activists had his most serious charge dismissed on Thursday, after a State Supreme Court judge ruled that the prosecution had not shown that the cat had been injured.

title: On the Dawn Wall, Climbing and Tweeting
description: MADISON, N.H.  A LITTLE before noon on Nov. 18, 1970, a blood-flecked hand pawed the top of the southeast face of El Capitan, the massive, 3,000-foot vertical wall in Yosemite National Park known to climbers as the Dawn Wall. A bearded, wild-eyed man eventually pulled himself up and stumbled back into the realm of horizontal existence after 26 nights lashed to the cliff. Approximately 70 reporters and well-wishers rushed forward to greet him. A dozen TV cameras whirred.

title: Death Watch on a Dutch Farm
description: In Its All So Quiet, the Dutch filmmaker Nanouk Leopold brings us close to a middle-aged farmer whos looking after his bedridden father, and looking ahead to the changes that are likely to occur when the old man dies.

title: Searching for Family Along a River of Tears
description: Little more than an archipelago of historical set pieces linked by a syrupy causeway of sentiment, JK Youns Ode to My Father may have slain them in South Korea, but its packaged pain and bullet-point structure are likely to leave Western audiences cold.

title: N.F.L. Dynasties, on the Decline
description: With the Broncos and the Seahawks  last years Super Bowl contestants  hosting playoffs games this weekend, the N.F.L. may seem like a closed club, with the same few teams winning every year. Actually, that has never been less true than now.

title: Where Deer Arent the Only Trophies
description: A young money manager, his bored wife and his brother, a war veteran, head into the woods to hunt deer in Preservation, and as the venerable movie trailer clich has it, the hunters become the hunted. Thats assured from the opening sequence, which patiently tails their truck at a respectful stalker-cam distance down winding country roads.

title: Finding Her Way Back in Small, Slow Steps
description: The carmine nail polish that Peggy (Ashley Shelton), a young real estate agent in Knoxville, Tenn., applies so carefully at the beginning of Something, Anything isnt the films only facade. Before the opening credits have faded, Peggy has married a handsome go-getter (Bryce Johnson), become pregnant and settled in an enviable starter home. But theres something adrift in her expression, and when a personal tragedy slaps her into awareness, she suspects that the life she has passively accepted may not be the one she wants.

title: Coca-Cola to Cut Up to 1,800 Jobs
description: Coca-Cola said on Thursday that it was cutting 1,600 to 1,800 jobs globally as part of $3 billion in costs it hopes to pare over the next several years.

title: Egypt Moves to Eradicate Town Near Gaza Strip
description: CAIRO  Egypt began evacuating hundreds of families from a town bordering the Gaza Strip on Thursday after a senior official acknowledged that the military was eradicating the town in order to complete a security zone abutting the Palestinian territory.

title: Tripping Over the Hazy Line Between Fiction and Reality
description: In 1971, the actor-director Dennis Hopper, flush with success from his directorial debut, Easy Rider, made The Last Movie, ostensibly a final, definitive statement about the medium but a notorious box office bomb. About a stuntman (Mr. Hopper) who leaves a film production in Peru to live among the locals, the movie, in its ragged, druggy way, aimed to be both a comment on Hollywood cultural imperialism and an apocalyptic examination of fiction versus reality.

title: Obama Plan Would Help Many Go to Community College Free
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Thursday that he would propose a government program to make community college tuition-free for millions of students, an ambitious plan that would expand educational opportunities across the United States.

title: Codes and Vendettas, Frozen in Time
description: A Civil War legacy cascades through the backwoods of North Carolina in the 1970s in The World Made Straight, an overcooked adaptation of a novel by Ron Rash.

title: In Weather Fit for Hibernation, Central Park Grizzly Bears Debut
description: As the city shivered around her, a 20-something blonde, new to this part of town, stood in the middle of Central Park, the wind ruffling her fur coat, and took in her surroundings.

title: This Weeks Movies | Jan. 9, 2015
description: The New York Times film critics review Unbroken, A Most Violent Year and Into the Woods.

title: De Blasio and Police Both Blamed for a Feud That Few Like
description: It is understandable that New Yorkers might think they are witnessing something scripted for a grade school playground. In the stubborn showdown between the police and Mayor Bill de Blasio  turned backs, forgiven infractions  many citizens can only watch with sentiments that flow from bemusement to revulsion, if not a mixture of both.

title: Voodoo Time Machine
description: Many of us in the econ biz were wondering how the new leaders of Congress would respond to the sharp increase in American economic growth that, we now know, began last spring. After years of insisting that President Obama is responsible for a weak economy, they couldnt say the truth  that short-run economic performance has very little to do with who holds the White House. So what would they say?

title: The News We Need to Hear
description: Happy 2015, our fifth year of Fixes.

title: Drug Switch May Delay Executions in Ohio
description: The state of Ohio said Thursday that it might delay several executions as it changes its lethal-drug protocol after a convicted man choked, gasped and clenched his fists for more than 20 minutes during his execution last year.

title: U.S. Consolidates Forces in Europe to Save Money
description: WASHINGTON  The Defense Department is consolidating American forces in Europe to save what Pentagon officials say will be about $500 million a year while not reducing the number of American military personnel  some 67,000  who are currently there.

title: I Am Not Charlie Hebdo
description: The journalists at Charlie Hebdo are now rightly being celebrated as martyrs on behalf of freedom of expression, but lets face it: If they had tried to publish their satirical newspaper on any American university campus over the last two decades it wouldnt have lasted 30 seconds. Student and faculty groups would have accused them of hate speech. The administration would have cut financing and shut them down.

title: Federal Grand Jury to Look at Brownback Loans
description: Federal grand jurors are scheduled to hear testimony next week about loans made to the re-election campaign of Gov. Sam Brownback of Kansas, a subpoena of a state ethics official shows.

title: Bombardiers CSeries Gamble Is Facing Longer Odds
description: MONTREAL  If all had gone according to plan, Bombardiers direct challenge to the Boeing 737, the worlds best-selling commercial plane, would be approaching its second year in service. Instead, Bombardiers grand plan for a new plane, the CSeries airliner, has faced myriad delays.

title: Arch Moore, Trailblazing West Virginia Governor, Dies at 91
description: Arch A. Moore Jr., the only West Virginia governor to serve three four-year terms, beginning in 1969, and the first sitting governor of the state to be formally charged with a crime, for which he later served time in federal prison, died on Wednesday in Charleston, W.Va. He was 91.

title: Voices Join Greek Lefts Call for a New Deal on Debt
description: Many investors are worried that an election later this month may produce a new radical government in Greece.

title: A Welcome Ban on Forever Foam
description: Score another victory for the sustainable city. New York is broadly banning expanded polystyrene, the all but unavoidable, near-everlasting plastic foam used in drink cups, food trays, packing peanuts and many, many other things.

title: Gun-Running in the Jet Age
description: Anyone who has spent time waiting shoeless on an airport check-in line  in fact, anyone who flies  should pay serious attention to the recent revelation that an airline baggage handler was allegedly able to smuggle 153 firearms in an accomplices carry-on bag on 17 Delta flights from Atlanta to New York during a seven-month period. The reason, shocking in its simplicity, is that most back-room airport workers are not required to pass through metal detectors on the way to the job.

title: Debt Buyer Faces Fine and Loss of Thousands of Court Judgments
description: In courtrooms across New York State, lawsuits poured in by the hundreds as if manufactured on an assembly line. Some included generic testimony, others relied on bogus affidavits, churned out so rapidly that they were seldom viewed for accuracy.

title: From Sergeant-at-Arms to Canadian Ambassador, After Ottawa Attack
description: Kevin Vickers, the sergeant-at-arms of Canadas House of Commons who became a national hero in October after an armed attack on Parliament, was appointed the ambassador to Ireland on Thursday.

title: Auto Leasing Gains Popularity Among American Consumers
description: JIMMY ZAID says he is always looking for a deal. As he stood in the lobby of a Houston-area Infiniti dealership on the last day of December, he took satisfaction at the one he had just secured on his new sport sedan.

title: Jethro Pugh, Unsung Pillar for Cowboys on the Doomsday Defense, Is Dead at 70
description: Jethro Pugh, a durable lineman for the Dallas Cowboys who played in four Super Bowls as part of a famed unit nicknamed the Doomsday Defense, died on Wednesday. He was 70.

title: Scorch Marks and Questions Linger After N.A.A.C.P. Bombing in Colorado
description: COLORADO SPRINGS  A shadow of char is the only remnant of an improvised bomb that exploded Tuesday outside the local offices of the N.A.A.C.P. here at the feet of the snow-covered Rocky Mountains, jolting the volunteers more accustomed to running membership drives and planning prayer breakfasts.

title: Is It Child Abuse to Make a Trans Child 'Change'?
Struck by Bench in School Gym, New Jersey Boy, 7, Dies
description: NEW MILFORD, N.J.  The soccer practice in the Berkley Street Elementary School gym was about to begin on Wednesday evening, and when a ball was kicked toward a wall in the building, Brendan Jordan, 7, a second grader from nearby Bertram F. Gibbs Elementary School, chased after it, officials said. But as he tried to retrieve the ball, they said, a heavy fold-up bench inexplicably fell from a wall where it was thought to have been secured, striking him in the head and killing him.

title: Ticket Falloff, 2 Officers Deaths and Overdue Contracts
description: Hoisting boxes of chicken parts from a truck at 1 p.m. on Thursday afternoon, Victor Arroyo did not, at first, notice the four police officers strolling up Ninth Avenue in Midtown Manhattan. He stepped off the tailgate and stacked the boxes on a dolly for his partner to roll inside a butcher store.

title: Jets Focus on Texans Executive in G.M. Hunt
description: A favorite has been established in the Jets general manager search: Mike Maccagnan, the Houston Texans director of college scouting. Maccagnan, the only candidate the Jets have asked back for a second interview, was scheduled to speak with the team again on Friday.

title: House Fires Shot at Health Care Law, Seeking to Alter Critical Coverage Rule
description: WASHINGTON  The House on Thursday easily passed legislation that would redefine a full-time worker under the Affordable Care Act, brushing aside qualms from conservatives and liberals who fear the bill would prompt employers to cut worker hours to avoid being forced to offer them health insurance.

title: A Pipeline and a Pie in the Sky
description: LOS ANGELES  The Koch brothers Congress, purchased with the help of about $100 million from the political network of the billionaire energy producers, got down to its first order of business this week: trying to hold off the future.

title: The Roots of Obamas Ambitious College Plan
description: The roots of President Obamas ambitious proposal for free community college can be found in a 2008 book by the economists Claudia Goldin and Lawrence Katz called The Race Between Education and Technology.

title: Modest Rise in Inflation Gives China Room to Act
description: HONG KONG  China is increasingly likely to take new action to bolster growth, economists said, after figures released on Friday showed that inflation in the country remains near its lowest levels in five years.

title: G.O.P. Aims to Fund Homeland Security While Blocking Obamas Immigration Plan
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans moved Thursday to create a bill that would fund most of the Department of Homeland Security while preventing President Obama from carrying out his recent executive action on immigration, in an effort to appease their more conservative members.

title: New York to Settle Suit on Policing in Public Housing
description: New York City reached a preliminary settlement in a federal class-action lawsuit over the Police Departments trespassing-enforcement tactics in public housing developments, according to court papers filed this week.

title: A Moment of Optimism on Sudan Peace Fades as New Talks Approach
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia  Up and down the stairs of the five-star Radisson Blue Hotel, they moved from one meeting to another. Some wore suits, some came in traditional white clothing with turbans, some dressed casually. One rebel leader wore a baseball cap.

title: Ty Hensley, a Top Yankees Prospect, Is Left With Broken Jaw After Altercation
description: Ty Hensley, the Yankees top draft pick in 2012, was severely beaten and was hospitalized on Dec. 28 after a former college football player assaulted him in the town of The Village, Okla., according to a report by the Oklahoma County district attorney.

title: Peru: Jailed Ex-President Is Convicted of Corruption
description: Former President Alberto Fujimori on Thursday was convicted of using public money to influence newspaper coverage during his 2000 re-election campaign. Mr. Fujimori is already serving a 25-year sentence, handed down in 2009, for ordering the killings of 25 people during a war with leftist guerrillas. On Thursday, he was sentenced to eight years to be served concurrently with his earlier sentence so it will not add to his time in jail. Mr. Fujimori, who was president from 1990 to 2000, was also ordered to pay restitution of about $1 million. Local news media reported that evidence showed that a representative of Mr. Fujimori paid newspapers up to $3,000 for articles smearing his opponents.
