The verdict could affect the political prospects of his daughter, Keiko Fujimori, a probable candidate for president next year.

title: South Carolina: Former Police Chiefs Defense Begins
description: Prosecutors on Thursday rested their case in the murder trial of a former police chief accused of killing Bernard Bailey, an unarmed black man, in 2011. Lawyers for Richard J. Combs, the former Eutawville, S.C., police chief, immediately began their defense before the jury in Orangeburg County. Prosecutors say Mr. Combs was reckless when he tried to serve an arrest warrant on Mr. Bailey, but Mr. Combss lawyers say the chief fired his weapon because his life was in jeopardy when the two men fought. Jurors on Thursday heard from six witnesses, including Brittany Dantzler, a former Eutawville official who saw the shooting and said she thought Mr. Combs was at risk of being run over by Mr. Baileys truck. Mr. Combs is expected to testify as soon as Friday. The United States Department of Justice investigated the shooting but did not file any charges. Last year, the town agreed to a $400,000 settlement in a lawsuit related to the shooting.

title: Cuba Is Reported to Release 26 Dissidents
description: MEXICO CITY  After a flurry of arrests in recent weeks raised questions about its human rights record, Cuba on Thursday released more than two dozen dissidents, some of them believed to be among 53 it had agreed to free last month as the United States and Cuba decided to normalize diplomatic relations.

title: Cowboys Aim to Pry the Ball From a Team That Isnt in a Giving Mood
description: IRVING, Tex.  A football attached to a spring-loaded, flexible rod awaits the Dallas Cowboys defensive players as they enter their meeting rooms. They are expected to punch, slap, rake, strip, claw, grab  anything that might hone their technique and cause a turnover.

title: A Martyr for the Cause, if Only He Could Pick One
description: Who can get enough of Soviet-era stage comedies? Thats a joke, of course. Who knew there were any?

title: Robots May Get an Emotional Upgrade, but Humans Are Also Up for Retooling
description: Though it is a tale told by an automaton, there is nothing remotely inhuman about Sorry Robot, which opened at the New Ohio Theater on Thursday night as part of the 2015 Coil festival of experimental theater. On the contrary, this gleeful, ramshackle tale of a not-too-distant future in which machines are our very best friends and our mortal enemies (or has that day already arrived?) is only and all too human.

title: Made a Speedy Return
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Hooray for us! A Patrick Berry puzzle to take us into our weekend.

title: Calendar for London, Milan and Paris Mens Fashion Weeks and Pitti Uomo
description: Friday, Jan. 9

title: Dont Chew on My Blue Suede Shoes: A Contest of Elvis Presley and Dogs
description: Elvis fans around the world celebrated what would have been the Kings 80th birthday on Thursday in many different ways, from appearances by impersonators to memorabilia sales and shows.

title: What Grade Do You Give Mayor Bill de Blasio?
description: Hows he doing? A year in, The Times asked readers to grade Mr. de Blasios performance. Submissions are now closed.

title: Grading Bill de Blasios First Year as New York Citys Mayor
description: Nobody said freshman year would be easy.

title: Outside the Spotlight,Bill de Blasio Wages a War on Inequality
description: A year ago, just days into his tenure as New York Citys 109th mayor, Bill de Blasio fell under criticism for his approach to eating pizza, one that depended on cutlery. That this minor peculiarity became a matter of mass media interest  Jon Stewart, Time magazine, The Guardian all weighed in obsessively  only confirmed Mr. de Blasios status as a national celebrity. He had been elected by a wide margin, promising to rectify the imbalances of an ever more economically divided city. On the right were predictions that Mr. de Blasios progressive commitments would return the city to the anarchy of the 1970s; elsewhere was the concern that we were now to be led by someone dull and dismissible. And yet we havent ended up in an era of another Abe Beame.

title: Picture the Mayor
description: When he was sworn in as New York Citys mayor, Bill de Blasio was also inaugurated into a newfound celebrity, someone whose every move is scrutinized, evaluated and also photographed.

title: Photographs ofMayor Bill de Blasio, Year One
description: No one wants a picture with a state senator. City Council members rarely elicit cheers or hisses from passing vehicles. A sitting comptroller could wear a sash and parade down the Canyon of Heroes after a budget triumph and remain anonymous to all but a few devotees of municipal arcana.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Jan. 9
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include scenes from the start of the New Year and the funerals of former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Officer Wenjian Liu.

title: A New Jersey Town Faces Scrutiny on Police Hiring
description: When Wayne R. Kubs, a former Navy corpsman who spent years deployed in the Middle East, applied to the police force in his hometown in New Jersey, he thought his chances were good. He had grown up in Rutherford, a working-class borough of 18,000 people and about eight miles from Manhattan. He was a volunteer firefighter and a tactical paramedic for the largest hospital in the state, sometimes part of a SWAT team.

title: Indonesia: Teams Detect Pings at AirAsia Flight 8501 Site
description: Indonesian officials said Friday that search and rescue teams had detected pinging from the black box recorders of AirAsia Flight 8501, which crashed into the Java Sea on Dec. 28 with 162 people aboard. Tatang Zainuddin, deputy chief of operations for the National Search and Rescue Agency, said a research ship from Indonesias Agency for Assessment and Application of Technology had picked up pinging from the planes flight data and cockpit voice recorders on Thursday afternoon. He said that the Sampson, an American Navy destroyer, had also detected the pinging. He said the authorities had not yet determined the exact coordinates of the black boxes. The bodies of 45 victims had been reovered as of Thursday.

title: Walter Khr, Performer, Bandleader and Accordion Evangelist, Dies at 59
description: A gentleman, a widely repeated anonymous quotation has it, is a man who can play the accordion but doesnt.

title: Little Excitement at Garden, on the Court or Off
description: Madison Square Garden has become, at least, a warm and quiet place to spend a cold evening.

title: Even ESPN Is Trying to Hide From the Knicks
description: If youre the Knicks, and playing more like the Washington Generals than the Washington Wizards, youre likely to be penalized. But relegation is out, and fans are still stuffing Madison Square Garden even as they have watched their heroes play to a 3-16 home record this season.

title: Raising Questions Within Islam After France Shooting
description: CAIRO  Islamist extremists behead Western journalists in Syria, massacre thousands of Iraqis, murder 132 Pakistani schoolchildren, kill a Canadian soldier and take hostage cafe patrons in Australia. Now, two gunmen have massacred a dozen people in the office of a Paris newspaper.

title: Lottery Numbers
Events in New Jersey for Jan. 11-17, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut for Jan. 11-17, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: 52 Places to Go in 2015
description: Untrammeled oases beckon, once-avoided destinations become must-sees, and familiar cities offer new reasons to visit.

title: Word of the Day | prologue
description: prologue \pro-log, -lg\ noun

title: Huddled Masses, Yearning to Be Warm
J. P. Parise, Goal Scorer in Milestone Win by Islanders, Dies at 73
description: J. P. Parise, an All-Star left wing for the Minnesota North Stars who was traded midseason to the Islanders in 1975 and went on to help them win their first playoff series, defeating the Rangers, died on Wednesday at his home in Prior Lake, Minn. He was 73.

title: Photos: The Games Warriors Play
description: For generations of young Maasai, the tradition of lion hunting served as a rite of passage into adulthood. But as Africas lion population diminished, village leaders recognized a need for change.

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 9 P.M. (Showtime) PHILOMENA (2013) With the help of a former political journalist (Steve Coogan), an Irish Roman Catholic woman (Judi Dench, in an Oscar-nominated performance) seeks the son who was taken from her 50 years earlier, when she became pregnant as a teenager and was forced to live in a convent, in this drama directed by Stephen Frears. Their sleuthing takes them to Washington after they discover that the boy  sold for 1,000 pounds  was adopted by an American couple and worked for the Reagan administration as an adult. Ms. Denchs Philomena Lee glows with the radiance of someone serene in her faith despite inhumane treatment by the church, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. That she makes you believe her character has the capacity to forgive provides the movie with a solid moral center. Her dignified performance and the screenplay  adapted by Mr. Coogan and Jeff Pope from Martin Sixsmiths 2009 nonfiction book, The Lost Child of Philomena Lee  stabilize a volatile blend of ingredients, he added. In less confident hands, the film could have been a mawkish, rambling tear-jerker.

title: Jackie Chans Son Given 6-Month Sentence on Drug Charge
description: The 32-year-old son of the film star Jackie Chan pleaded guilty to a drug charge in a Beijing courtroom on Friday and was sentenced to six months in prison.

title: Freeze Frame
Corrections: January 9, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Some people who feel crushed or ignored will go toward extremism, and they use religion because that is what they have at hand.

title: Inside Charlie Hebdo After the Attack
description: Julien Beaup was in a nearby office when masked gunmen attacked the satirical newspaper. Moments later, he entered the newsroom to help emergency medical workers and survivors.

title: Signals Are Detected From AirAsia Jets Black Boxes
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Search and rescue teams have detected pinging from the so-called black boxes of the AirAsia plane that crashed into the Java Sea, Indonesian officials said on Friday as divers resumed attempts to reach the doomed aircrafts tail section in hopes of finding the devices inside or nearby.

title: French Police Storm Hostage Sites, Killing Gunmen
description: PARIS  The French police killed three terrorists on Friday in raids, ending three days of bloodshed that shook a nation struggling with Islamic extremists.

title: Test Yourself | The Princess Treatment
description: Below are eight paragraphs from a Jan. 2 article, After a Spa Day, Looking Years Younger (O.K., Theyre Only 7).

title: Honda in Japan Distances Itself From Fine on U.S. Subsidiary
description: TOKYO  A record $70 million fine imposed on Honda Motor by safety regulators in the United States was being treated in Japan like a mildly intriguing piece of foreign news: an American problem for what has become, in many ways, a highly American company.

title: 6 Qs About the News | A Grandmaster Before 14, With Kasparov on His Side
description: In A Grandmaster Before 14, With Kasparov on His Side, Joe DePaolo writes about how a special program provides support for the chess prodigy Sam Sevian.

title: Do You Have Childhood Memories of Being Read Aloud To?
description: The Cat in the Hat, Winnie the Pooh and Where the Wild Things Are. Did your parents or teachers ever read these or other classic childrens books to you? Did you have bedtime stories or class read-alouds when you were younger?

title: Visual Beauty and History in Hartford
description: Even before I had moved to the area, I had heard all the warnings. Hartford, once the insurance capital of the world and one of the countrys most prosperous cities in the 19th century, had degenerated into one of its poorest. There was little of interest beyond the historical landmarks of its Yankee past. Major highways ran through the city  making for an easy escape to the cultural meccas of New York and Boston. Even real-estate agents eager to sell me a house told me as much: The good thing about Hartford is how easy it is to leave.

title: Job Growth Fails to Help Paychecks of Workers
description: The nations economy is entering 2015 in its best shape since the recession, but the improving job market has so far failed to help most Americans earn significantly more at work.

title: Paris Attack Updates, Day 3: Two Hostage Situations
description: French security forces launched simultaneous raids on two locations where suspected killers were holding hostages on Friday evening. These two major police operations underway around Paris appeared to be the culmination of the search for the suspects in Wednesdays attack at the offices of the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo in Paris.

title: Hong Kong Tycoon Li Ka-shing to Overhaul Corporate Empire
description: HONG KONG  Li Ka-shing, Asias richest man, is shaking up his corporate empire in an extensive reorganization.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: After Charlie Hebdo
description: What being an editorial cartoonist looks like now.

title: New York Today: 2015 in Review
description: Updated 10:06 a.m. Good morning on this snowy Friday. Alternate-side parking has been suspended.

title: Today in Politics
description: Good News for the Economy, but Maybe Not So Much for the G.O.P.

title: Irelands XL Group Agrees to Buy the Bermuda Insurer Catlin for $4.2 Billion
description: LONDON  The Ireland-based insurer XL Group said on Friday that it had agreed to acquire the Catlin Group in a deal that values the Bermuda insurer at about 2.79 billion pounds, or about $4.2 billion.

title: Morning Agenda: Proxy Fight at DuPont
description: PELTZ IGNITES PROXY FIGHT AT DUPONT | Trian Fund Management, the investment firm run by Nelson Peltz, announced on Thursday that it had nominated four director candidates to the board of DuPont, escalating its campaign to break up the $67.5 billion chemical maker, DealBooks Michael J. de la Merced and Andrew Ross Sorkin report. The proxy fight, the first major challenge by an activist investor in 2015, would be one of the biggest tests in DuPonts two centuries as an industrial powerhouse. DuPont is one of the biggest companies ever to face a proxy battle.

title: Turning a New Years Resolution Into Action With the Facts
description: DESPITE the best intentions for the new year, the reality is that by next month, gym memberships will lapse, chocolate will replace carrots and Candy Crush will edge out Moby Dick.

title: Theater Games: Our Contribution to Kids Night on Broadway
description: Kids Night on Broadway this year Jan. 9-15  is a program of The Broadway League, the national trade association for the Broadway theater industry. Created in 1996 by the League and Theatre Development Fund, its goal is to introduce young people to the magic of live theater and make Broadway accessible to a new generation of theatergoers in New York and across the U.S.

title: Box, a Data Storage Provider, Seeks Up to $162.5 Million in I.P.O.
description: After months of delay, Box is finally close to making its stock market debut.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: In Britain, Spy Chief Calls for More Power for Agency
description: LONDON  Britains domestic intelligence chief has demanded greater authority for spies to help fight the threat of Islamist extremism, a sign that the attack on a satirical newspaper in Paris is likely to sharpen the security-versus-privacy debate in Western countries.

title: Politics Helpline: The 114th Congress, Part 1
description: Were taking questions and answering them as fast as we can as part of our continuous political helpline. On Friday, our congressional team answers select questions about the 114th Congress. Here is their first batch of answers. We will post more as the day goes on.

title: For China, a New Leader in Sri Lanka May Herald a Change in Ties
description: Last January, Sri Lankas health minister, Maithripala Sirisena, joined his colleagues in toasting the Chinese New Year at a red-lantern-festooned gala featuring performances of the songs Love My China and Mother Sri Lanka and hosted by the Chinese Embassy in Colombo, the capital.

title: Celebrities to Watch at the Golden Globes: Handicapping the Fashion Winners
description: Given that every movie critic I know is busy handicapping the winners of the Golden Globes on Sunday, I thought I might as well chime in, fashionwise. After all, the pool of well-dressed actresses at this event is, perhaps, the greatest of any awards show, given the best-actress-trifecta of stars in dramatic films, comedy/musical films and TV shows. Arguably, its a bigger fashion event than the Oscars, at least when it comes to frocks and frippery.

title: How We Chose Our List
description: Each January, the editors of the Travel section publish our Places to Go issue. And each year after we do, readers wonder why their favorite destination was overlooked or why their least favorite made the top 10. To add some clarity to the process, weve decided to answer some frequently asked questions about how we chose our 52 Places to Go in 2015.

title: Show Me the Money
description: Another good employment report  and another triumph for future Republican policies (hahahahaha)  and there will be many voices calling on the Fed to accelerate its tightening.

title: Time Warp, 56th and Broadway
description: Dear Diary:

title: Theories of Everything
description: Ive worked on a lot of interesting things over the course of my career, but I surely had the most intellectual fun working on economic geography. The models were nifty, the stories seemed to shed a lot of light on history. And maybe too much light  the temptation to claim universal explanatory power was strong. I can certainly see why Noah Smith likes to suggest that the New Economic Geography may be a theory of everything. But heres what Tony Venables and I wrote in the paper (pdf) that comes closest to what Noah is saying:

title: When Autocorrect Goes Wrong (And So, So Right)
description: There were a few things that were sweetly grandmotherly about Patricia Duncan Morans Facebook post to her great-granddaughter Devyn on her birthday. For starters, Ms. Moran had posted it to her own wall instead of Devyns. She named but did not tag her great-granddaughter. But most striking was the signer.

title: Ask Well: Making Exercise a Habit
description: Question:

title: On His Best Behavior and Hoping to Fit In
description: LONDON  He is an illegal immigrant, small, brown and different-looking, lonely and unwelcome in a metropolis in which people try hard not to notice other peoples problems. Carrying a battered suitcase that contains very little, he encounters hostility, rudeness and indifference, and must battle prejudice and enmity.

title: Whats On This Week Around the World
description: Kochi, India

title: Big-Budget Effects Without the Budget
description: Special effects are usually considered the province of Spider-Men and guardians of galaxies. But for a while now, visual effects have quietly become part of small films in ways you might not expect. Hidden away in art-house movies, including a recent crop of dramas, are digital tricks that reduce the cost of potentially expensive shots or, more subtly, help filmmakers heighten the visual impact of seemingly naturalistic tales.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Romantic Fancy in French Flavors
description: Mood Indigo, the retro-futurist folly fashioned by Michel Gondry from L'cume des Jours (The Foam of the Days), written in the heady aftermath of World War II by the French novelist, jazz critic, musician and Saint-Germain-des-Prs scene-maker Boris Vian (1920-1959), is an evident labor of love. It is often labored but sometimes lovely, particularly in the longer version included on Drafthouses DVD and Blu-ray edition.

title: Carlyle Reports Declines in Energy Investments
description: With the collapse in oil prices weighing on the energy sector, the Carlyle Group suffered declines in its energy investments in the fourth quarter of 2014.

title: Job Growth Looks Great; Wage Growth, Less So
description: The last few weeks have been a time of, dare we say it, buoyant optimism about the United States economy. The long winter slumber may be over, or so it has seemed after news of a 5 percent G.D.P. third-quarter growth rate and a November jobs report showing the strongest gains in years.

title: Daily Report: Box Seeks to Raise up to $162.5 Million in I.P.O.
description: After months of delay, Box is finally close to making its stock market debut, Michael J. de la Merced reports.

title: Masters of Crime
description: FOUR NOVELS OF THE 1970S

title: Back to the Studio, With Hits in Hand
description: I remember this couch, Mark Ronson said, eyeing a brown suede number in the basement of Electric Lady, the storied recording studio in the West Village. It was here that Mr. Ronson, the club D.J. turned in-demand producer, made his first proper album, for the singer Nikka Costa.

title: Placing Bets on How Many Takes Fincher Will Need
description: The character of Margo Dunne  better known as Go, sister to Ben Afflecks Nick in the smash hit adaptation Gone Girl  was a critical one in the film. In the vicious tale of a presumed-dead wife and a husband under suspicion, Margo provided a much-needed voice of reason for the audience, illuminating the unsavoriness of the wife, Amy, and allowing the husband, Nick, to seem less like a monster when all evidence points to him.

title: Americans Use More Online Social Networks
description: Teenagers may be spending more time on messaging services like Snapchat, but American adults are still increasing their use of social networks, according to a new survey released Friday by the Pew Research Center.

title: For Republicans, Jobs Report Offers Little Help
description: The hot debate among Republicans over how to respond to economic improvement got little clarity on Friday from a December jobs report that gave ammunition to those Republicans who want to claim credit for the recovery and those who want to keep bashing it.

title: McDonalds Runs Out of Fries in Venezuela
description: In most countries, McDonalds running out of fries would be seen as an inconvenience. (Or a blessing, if your New Years resolution is to eat healthier)

title: Blocked In
description: I live in a town that is notoriously difficult for parking. After years of circling blocks for spaces, I found an apartment with a garage. Then a business moved in, and one of its employees started parking in front of my garage every day. I only use my car occasionally, but when I do, I have to ask her to move hers. She does it right away, but its still annoying. The other day I told her it had to stop. She was furious and called me selfish (because I use the car infrequently). Was I wrong?

title: Sleeps Marketing Problem: You Have To Go to Bed.
description: Its 7 p.m. My children should be winding down for sleep, but my 6-year-old cannot fathom leaving his Lego X-Wing Fighter incomplete. My 3-year-old wont brush her teeth. When she finally does, she decides she must change her pajamas again.

title: Obama Facing Rising Pressure onKeystone Oil Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama came under new pressure on Friday to make a decision on the Keystone XL oil pipeline as the Nebraska Supreme Court cleared the way for its construction through the state and the House passed a bill to approve the project.

title: Retrograde Beliefs
description: The planet Mercury is small, not much larger than our moon, but dense, mostly a molten iron core with hardly any crust or atmosphere. It flies fast, orbiting the sun once every 87.97 earth days, and spins slowly, rotating only 1.5 times every trip around. During those long nights and days, temperatures drop to minus 280 degrees Fahrenheit and rise to 800 degrees. The poles, surprisingly, contain deposits of ice, but the rest of Mercurys surface is rough ground, a record of the early years of the solar system, when the planet was pummeled by asteroids and meteors.

title: Need for (Reduced) Speed
description: I didnt go to Colorado to ski. I went because my father, to help me conquer my longstanding fear of driving, talked me into attending a two-day class at the Bridgestone Winter Driving School in Steamboat Springs.

title: The Cannabis Queen of Beverly Hills
description: Cheryl Shuman, founder of the Beverly Hills Cannabis Club, arrived at the Perennial Holistic Wellness Center, an upmarket medical-marijuana dispensary in Los Angeles, in a red 2010 Ferrari California, a gift, she said, from a friend. She had come to get supplies for a mansion party that she was hosting the following evening, one of the semiregular events she organizes with her daughter, Aimee, to promote their marijuana enterprises. Shuman, a tall 54-year-old blonde with the unflagging cheer of someone accustomed to being noticed, handed the keys to Perennials valets with a Mae West-inflected Careful, boys. She headed inside to present her state-issued Medical Marijuana Identification Card.

title: The Case for Throwback Baseball Uniforms
description: Some Major League Baseball teams wear retro uniforms as alternates, allowing for increased opportunities to market jerseys to fans. Ive seen some teams wearing Negro league jerseys as retro alternates. Ostensibly, theyre celebrating the tradition of Negro league baseball  but its an odd premise, given that Major League Baseball is the same organization that didnt allow black players until after World War II. Is it ethical for M.L.B. teams to wear Negro league uniforms and potentially reap profits by selling them? PETE TOSIELLO, NEW YORK

title: Reply All: The 12.28.14 Issue
description: When I glanced at the cover of the Lives They Lived issue, I knew immediately that it was a tribute to Massimo Vignelli. I worked with Vignelli as the first design director for Unimark in Chicago. Vignellis passion for design was constant. He was a very soft-spoken and wonderful guy with a desire to make communication minimalist and beautiful. I first thought that he was nuts when he said you only need five great typefaces, but I soon came to understand what he meant. Massimo touched many designers in his life, and all of us are better because of it. Thank you so much for this issue, which was beautifully written and designed. JIM LIENHART, Tucson

title: Death by Robot
description: Imagine its a Sunday in the not-too-distant future. An elderly woman named Sylvia is confined to bed and in pain after breaking two ribs in a fall. She is being tended by a helper robot; lets call it Fabulon. Sylvia calls out to Fabulon asking for a dose of painkiller. What should Fabulon do?

title: When Judging Financial Advisers, Look Beyond the Annual Return
description: ANY day now, financial advisers will start sending clients their annual reviews and outlooks along with year-end account statements. Both will probably look pretty good.

title: Well Into Adulthood, but Still Trying to Figure It Out
description: Togetherness, a beguiling new comedy beginning Sunday on HBO, is an intimate, bittersweet look at the travails of a clique of disaffected middle-class friends. So, of course, is Girls, which returns the same night for a fourth season, and so is Looking, which begins its second season.

title: Charlie Hebdo Attack Chills Satirists and Prompts a Debate
description: The killing of a dozen people in Wednesdays attack on the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo has prompted an outpouring of tributes from cartoonists around the world, who have flooded the Internet with images ranging from the elegiac to the scabrously rude.

title: 1915: Anger Over Garibaldis Death
description: ROME  Feeling against the Austrians, and against the Germans who are supporting them, is growing daily more intense, and it now seems that the nation has been fired to a hatred ripe for action, the death of Lieutenant Bruno Garibaldi having supplied the necessary spark. The death of Costante Garibaldi added fuel to the fire. All Rome mourns Garibaldis grandson tu  lennemi, as the simple but eloquent inscription on Brunos coffin read. As I telegraphed to you yesterday [Jan. 8], no funeral ever drew so vast a crowd, and General Ricciotti Garibaldis heartfelt words over his sons grave, foreshadowing Italys speedy avenging of the lieutenants death, stirred the blood of the whole nation. There was, at the beginning of the European war, a great outburst on the part of the Italian people. War against Austria appeared inevitable, as a consequence of the aggressive action against Servia, which action, in case it proved successful, would have profoundly affected the Balkanic equilibrium.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 10, 1915

title: Lentil Salad With Roasted Vegetables
description: Melissa Clark makes a bright lentil salad with roasted root vegetables and sherry vinaigrette.

title: The Root of the Matter
description: A lentil salad can be tasty. It can be healthy. But its rarely pretty.

title: The Webster and Le Bon March Join Forces for an All-White Series of Designer Collaborations
description: Last September, the Miami retail-scene mainstay the Webster and the Parisian department store Le Bon Marche Rive Gauche approached more than 50brands with a carte blanche of sorts: the opportunity to design an item for a limited-edition collection to launch in 2015. The (appropriate) caveat? Each contribution had to be rendered in white, as part of le mois du blanc (the month of white), a Bon March traditionsinceJanuary 1873, when the stores founder Aristide Boucicaut stocked a selection of snow-hued garments to fill his shelves following the holiday shopping season.

title: Topman Design: Fall 2015 Menswear
description: London

title: Verbatim: Out of Excuses
description: Speaker John A. Boehner, following a Nebraska Supreme Court ruling that cleared the way for the Keystone XL pipeline to be built through the state.

title: Looking for the Most Recent Facebook Posts
description: Q. When I use Facebook on my computer, I want to see the most current posts in my news feed, and not the Top Stories, which always seem to be older. When I change the view to Most Recent, it always reverts back to Top Stories after a while. Why wont it stay on Most Recent?

title: Charlie Hebdo, Before the Massacre
description: In this short documentary filmed at Charlie Hebdo in 2006, cartoonists and editors design a satirical front page image of Muhammad.

title: Why the Doorman Is Lonely
description: The marble lobby at CitySpire, a skyscraping 72-story tower in Midtown, bustles with rushing people bundled against the cold. Nattily dressed doormen hail taxis and see to a constant stream of deliveries.

title: Teaching Islams Forgotten Side as Germany Changes
description: MNSTER, Germany  AT a time of fear and loathing for Muslims and non-Muslims in Europe, Mouhanad Khorchide, professor of Islamic pedagogy at the venerable university in this town near the Dutch border, preaches and teaches a course of tolerance and understanding.

title: Head of Clinton Foundation Steps Down
description: The Clinton Foundation announced the departure of its chief executive, Eric Braverman, on Friday after just 18 months on the job. A veteran aide to Hillary Rodham Clinton is taking his place temporarily.

title: Why Reams of Intelligence Did Not Thwart the Paris Attacks
description: PARIS  The bloody denouement on Friday of two hostage crises at different ends of a traumatized Paris means attention will now shift to the gaping question facing the French government: How did several jihadists  and possibly a larger cell of co-conspirators  manage to evade surveillance and execute a bold attack despite being well known to the countrys police and intelligence services?

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: In Riverside, Conn, a renovated five-bedroom and in Westbury, N.Y., a rebuilt four-bedroom colonial.

title: Frank Lampard, in Statement, Says Hell Join New York City F.C. in Summer
description: In late December, when Manchester City caught Chelsea at the top of the English Premier League standings, Citys fans showered their teams new hero in song. Hes top of the league, hes top of the league. Oh, Frank Lampard, hes top of the league.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A co-op on the Upper West Side; another in the Flatiron District; and a house in Ditmas Park.

title: At Home With Angus McIndoe, Tavern Owner to the Stars
description: As the owner of the popular theater hangout Angus on West 44th Street, Angus McIndoe has a steady diet of crowds and clamor, of customers intent on making a matinee, of customers intent on making an entrance  or a scene.

title: Insider Tips: Culture in 2015
description: A New Years gift for Times Insiders: a series of inside tips from Times editors and reporters. In the first of these, Dan Wakin, deputy culture editor, shares his top picks for the years cultural events.

title: Retweet of the Week
A Rare Peek Into How Wachtell Bills for Deal Work
description: For most law firms, work on mergers and acquisitions is paid by the usual model of billable hours. And then there is Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz.

title: A Stand-Up Antipasto of Crunchy Bites
description: Every culture does fried food, but Italian cooks do it especially well. In Italy, whether its artichokes, lamb chops or shrimp, the result is bound to be crisp and golden. Eaten with a just a sprinkle of salt and a squeeze of lemon, a well-fried morsel is supremely satisfying.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York York region:

title: Politics Helpline: The 114th Congress, Part II
description: Were taking questions and answering them as fast as we can as part of our continuous political helpline. In this latest installment, our congressional team is answering select questions about the 114th Congress. This is the second batch of answers. The first group of answers can be found here.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York York City:

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Americas Bitter Pill
description: This week, Steven Brill discusses Americas Bitter Pill; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Heidi Julavits talks about Rachel Cusks Outline; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Sebastiaan Pieters Latest Collection
description: The mens wear designer debuts his 2015 fall/winter collection in a video.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Americas Bitter Pill
description: This week, Steven Brill and Heidi Julavits.

title: London Mens Wear Designers on Where to Savor a Sunday Roast
description: With another round of Londons mens collectionskicking off today, weary showgoers shuttling around town will need sustenance. Though the U.K.s gastronomic tradition cant match those of the other mens wear capitals, Italy and France, one particular meal is inarguably owned by the Brits. The Sunday roast, a weekend meal with friends and family, can be enjoyed at home or at one of the countless pubs dotted around the capital. Choose between lamb, chicken or beef (or the veggie options) and youll be served generously with roasted potatoes, cooked vegetables, gravy and an oversized Yorkshire pudding.

title: Port Agencys Reorganization to Start With Exit of Executive Christie Picked
description: A year after her predecessor resigned over his role in the shutting of traffic lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge, Gov. Chris Christies top executive appointee at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is stepping down.

title: The Art Forger Who Wasnt in It for Money
description: Even in the shadowy world of art forgery, Mark Landis seemed an aberration. From the 1980s on, he copied all kinds of paintings and drawings, from Picassos and Monets to panels from Peanuts and illustrations from The Cat in the Hat. But instead of selling his counterfeits, he assumed the role of a philanthropist, sometimes disguising himself as a priest, and donated his fake masterpieces to unsuspecting museums.

title: F.H.A. Loans More Affordable
description: An announcement by the Obama administration that the Federal Housing Administration would lower its annual insurance premiums by 0.5 percentage point could make it possible for a quarter-million more borrowers to buy their first homes, according to the agencys estimates.

title: Despite Pipeline Ruling, White House Renews Veto Threat
description: Nebraskas highest court gave its blessing today to construction of the Keystone XL pipeline, but its ruling hasnt swayed President Obama.

title: Trader With a Taste for Bubbly Convicted in $7.5 Million Investment Scam in Britain
description: LONDON  A trader who reportedly once spent more than $188,000 on a single bottle of Champagne was convicted of fraud on Friday in an investment scam that authorities say took in 5 million pounds, or about $7.54 million, from investors.

title: Charlie Hebdo, Before the Massacre
description: In February 2006 the editors of the French magazine Charlie Hebdo met to discuss a matter of what turned out to be deadly consequence: Would they publish a satirical image of Muhammad on their cover? We were making a documentary about Jean Cabut, known as Cabu, one of the most famous cartoonists in France. So we were there, filming his conversation with his colleagues as they chose the cover. The issue that came out of this meeting  with a Cabu cartoon on the cover and the images they discussed here  turned out to be one of the most popular in the magazines history. Almost nine years later, gunmen stormed this very meeting and killed 10 editors and cartoonists, including three of the people in this film: Cabu, Bernard Verlhac (known as Tignous) and Georges Wolinski.

title: My Heart Is a Drunken Compass, by Domingo Martinez
description: The memoirist Domingo Martinez is irreverent, judgmental and unapologetic. At its best, his writing calls to mind the bravado of Junot Daz, another foul-mouthed son of contemporary literature. Like The Boy Kings of Texas  Martinezs first memoir, which was a 2012 finalist for the National Book Award and was recently optioned for an HBO series  his latest, My Heart Is a Drunken Compass, is a tragic comedy filled with wit and cultural insight.

title: Editors Choice
description: HONEYDEW: Stories,  by Edith Pearlman. (Little, Brown, $25.) With simultaneous intimacy and distance, the tales in Pearlmans majestic collection excel at capturing the complex and surprising turns in seemingly ordinary lives.

title: Vanessa and Her Sister, by Priya Parmar
description: Rarely do you encounter a woman who commands as much admiration as does the painter Vanessa Bell in Priya Parmars multilayered, subtly shaded novel, Vanessa and Her Sister. The sister of the title is, of course, Virginia Woolf, who understood how hard it is for a novelist to capture a character. Few catch the phantom, Woolf said in a lecture at Cambridge in 1924, the year before the publication of Mrs. Dalloway. Most have to be content with a scrap of her dress or a wisp of her hair. Parmars portrait brings Vanessa out of the shadows, into fully realized, shining visibility. The world remembers Virginia better than her enigmatic older sister: Parmar restores the symmetry of their relationship in the familial landscape, showing how essential Vanessas steadying force was to Virginias precarious balance.

title: Please Look After This Bear
description: When Paddington Bear landed in London in 1958, it was still quite a provincial place. Safe, settled, a little gray  no sign of the Beatles or the swinging 60s yet  it upheld the ceremonial proprieties immortalized in Brief Encounter and 84, Charing Cross Road. Men wore ties to dinner, women skirts; the post-nuclear nightmares and beatnik explosions of America were barely visible on occasional television screens. Yes, the likes of the Trinidad-born novelist Samuel Selvon were beginning to give voice to other realities in works like The Lonely Londoners, but if a British familys name was Brown, you could be fairly sure its skin was not.

title: China 1945, by Richard Bernstein
description: To err is human. To blame someone else is politics. Hubert H. Humphreys aphorism came to mind as I was reading China 1945, Richard Bernsteins excellent history of United States policy toward China at the end of World War II. The comment is particularly apt when intractable problems provide myriad paths to failure but no clear right answer  and the civil war in China after Japans surrender was just such a problem. (Today, think of Syria.) The debates over China policy were acrimonious and personal, and this was several years before Joseph McCarthy lent his name to sneering political assassination.

title: It Will End With Us, by Sam Savage
description: I wasnt going to begin again, having stopped, apparently, and started up again, foolishly, too many times already. So protests Eve Taggart, the narrator of Sam Savages fifth novel, It Will End With Us. Like the first-person narrators of Savages earlier work, Eve begins with the intention, or at least the possibility, of ending in mind. This awareness that the narrative may be abandoned gives the book the feel of being cobweb-slight. It seems arbitrary, almost incidental; yet the texts fragility reads as purity of a kind.

title: American Queen, by John Oller
description: In the prelude to her great novel Middlemarch, George Eliot meditates on the fate of heroic women who found for themselves no epic life equal to their passion and intellect, but instead only a life of mistakes, the offspring of a certain spiritual grandeur ill-matched with the meanness of opportunity. One wonders what Eliot would have made of Kate Chase Sprague  daughter of a Civil War-era American cabinet minister, wife of a governor, mistress of a senator  whose career as a behind-the-scenes kingmaker is chronicled in John Ollers American Queen. Beautiful, wealthy and clever, she could dazzle a Washington salon or (said one historian) scheme like a cigar-chewing convention rigger. But her horizons were limited by the same constraints that tied Eliots heroine Dorothea Brooke, and the results for her bordered on the tragic.

title: My Life as a Foreign Country, by Brian Turner
description: Theres a persistent idea in our culture that what we experience is true, while what we imagine is untrue. But without exploring the possibility of imagination in nonfiction, we leave out a fundamental part of the human experience  digressive wanderings, the chaotic interior self and, most important, our empathy. Empathy, after all, starts as an act of fiction. We must think ourselves into the lives of others.

title: Cowardice: A Brief History, by Chris Walsh
description: Cowardice is not quite one of those words, like honor, whose meaning was once understood by everyone but is now understood by almost no one. Yet its meaning has lately become more elusive. Are suicide bombers cowardly, as we are so often assured they are, or insanely courageous? Is it more cowardly to refuse to fight or to fight for fear of being called a coward for not fighting? Some people claim to have the answers to such questions about this once familiar and unproblematic subject, but they tend to disagree. There is no consensus as to who is a coward and who is not  or even about whether the question is one of any importance. Cowardice, whatever it means, must seem a matter of individual choice, like everything else, and the implied judgment made by the term probably requires that we decline to use it at all.

title: All Eyes Are Upon Us, by Jason Sokol
description: If, as many believe, Americas experiment in postracialism is over, then All Eyes Are Upon Us is a prescient book that offers a great deal to explain a national self-deception of stunning brevity. According to Jason Sokol, whose anecdotally rich first book, There Goes My Everything, tracked white Southerners variously coping in the civil rights era, historians have paid insufficient attention to the Janus-faced responses of white Northerners to the struggles of black Americans. To be sure, monographs by James Goodman and Thomas Sugrue have explored the dark side of Northern race relations. They found that although the dominant racial philosophies of whites in the North and South were antithetical, opportunity for a majority of black men and women in the North was not very different from what it was in the South.

title: Tell, by Frances Itani
description: Here be dragons. There are the stories we tell our friends, the versions we tell our partners and, most important, the stories we tell ourselves in order to keep on living.

title: Health Care as High Drama
description: With Americas Bitter Pill, Steven Brills new book, on this weeks cover, we asked reporters at The Times with experience covering health care to name a favorite book on the subject.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE BROKEN ROAD: From the Iron Gates to Mount Athos, by Patrick Leigh Fermor. Edited By Colin Thubron and Artemis Cooper. (New York Review Books, $17.95.) In 1933, an 18-year-old Leigh Fermor set out on a walk across Europe, from Holland to Istanbul. Decades later, he recounted that life-changing journey in A Time of Gifts (1977) and Between the Woods and the Water (1986). The Broken Road, posthumously published last year, covers the final leg of his travels, through Bulgaria, Romania and Greece. In her absorbing biography Patrick Leigh Fermor: An Adventure (New York Review Books, $18.95), Artemis Cooper adds further details and intrigue to the British wayfarers life, including his heroic efforts in occupied Crete during World War II.

title: Inside the List
description: Home to Roost: Fans of the doctor-turned-romance-novelist-turned-thriller-writer Tess Gerritsen (whose latest Rizzoli and Isles mystery, Die Again, enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 5) may not know that last winter she briefly assumed yet another role: organic farmer. When Gerritsens son wanted a vacation from the farm he and his partner own in Maine, his parents agreed to take over for two weeks. Theres a comforting rhythm to farming, Gerritsen wrote on her blog. Every morning, the cows stand eagerly at the fence, excited to see us bringing hay, and the sheep come stampeding like hungry children. . . . Ive found out that I love hanging out with chickens. Ive learned which hen leaves the flock every morning to hide out with the sheep, and which hen sneaks away to spend time with the outcast rooster. Ive learned the secret places where those two lay their eggs. Ive learned that the alpha rooster can be brutal with hens (and Im going to talk to my son about turning him into coq au vin). The wry sadism of that last sentence wont surprise Gerritsens readers  in the opening pages of Die Again, a murdered taxidermist is discovered hung and dressed like game in his garage, with organs discarded in a nearby trash can. The inspiration for the organs, at least, may have come from the farm. Thanks to my son, Gerritsen wrote when her stint was done, Ive also been blessed with a bountiful supply of free-range eggs and chicken livers. Will all this turn up in a book some day? Trust me, Im thinking about it.

title: Lives in Ruins, by Marilyn Johnson
description: The past has a way of suddenly speaking to us. When images appear, for example, of human hands that archaeologists say were stenciled 40,000 years ago, a haunted feeling of connection and perspective quickly emerges. But many archaeologists themselves seem to experience this sense of connection more or less continuously. As Marilyn Johnson suggests in Lives in Ruins, her lively survey of archaeology and the people who practice it, it fuels their dedication to the job, which they desperately need because the actual work and the challenges involved are pretty continuous as well.

title: Letters: Found in Translation
description: Found in Translation

title: Sailing the Forest: Selected Poems, by Robin Robertson
description: Its impossible to talk about the poetry of Robin Robertson without talking about sex, but to do so is to slip into perilous waters. And by waters I mean a hot tub. Because you cant bring up sexy poetry without thinking of Roger and Virginia Klarvin, the randy and dithyrambic professors (played by Will Ferrell and Rachel Dratch) who always seemed to be in the middle of a steamy soak on Saturday Night Live. If even the most masterly fiction writers botch the job of describing the erotic act, its more challenging still for poets. One false move and they run the risk of sounding like Mr. Klarvin, the grandiloquent scholar and love-ah who proclaimed, in one episode, that beneath the surface of these very waters a virtual ant farm of activity is taking place.

title: Robert Bauschs Far as the Eye Can See
description: Bobby Hale, the hero of Robert Bauschs new novel, is a frontier hustler with a heart of gold. A Civil War veteran with a sketchy past, Hale heads west in 1869 simply because it seems like a good idea: Everybody said it was the place to be  with free land and open skies. What everybody doesnt say is that its also a land of treachery, deception, double-dealing, torture, warfare and death.

title: The Bishop, the Cyclist and a Death on the Road
description: BALTIMORE  Two days after Christmas, Thomas Palermo took advantage of a rare moment of free time to do what he loved most: ride his bike up a busy road popular with cyclists for its challenging hill and wide bike lanes, the afternoon sun warming his face. About the same time, the police say, an Episcopal bishop got into her car, her blood-alcohol level far above the legal limit, and drove toward him.

title: Rod Taylor, Star of The Birds and The Time Machine, Dies at 84
description: Rod Taylor, the ruggedly handsome Australian-born actor who fended off attacks from above in Alfred Hitchcocks revered horror film The Birds and helped an 8,000th-century people escape a monster race in the film version of the science-fiction classic The Time Machine, died on Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 84.

title: MAN: Fall 2015 Menswear
description: London

title: Explosions After Kouachi Brothers Siege
description: Explosions and gunfire were heard at a printing plant outside Paris where the two brothers suspected in the Charlie Hebdo attacks were killed.

title: What a Great Place to Work Ought to Look Like
description: Imagine a workplace that you truly look forward to arriving at every day  one that meets your most important needs so that you feel freed and inspired to bring your best to work.

title: 1940: Chamberlain Speaks on War
description: LONDON  In a fifty-five-minute address to an enthusiastic gathering of notables in the Mansion House, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain reviewed the course of the war, affirming once again Britains determination, with the aid of our dauntless French Allies to bring it to a successful conclusion, but warning his listeners that the road ahead might be a long one and most certainly hard.

title: State of the Art Museums in New Report
description: A new report from the Association of Art Museum Directors compiled from a survey of its 236 members offers a sometimes surprising snapshot of the state of the museum ecosystem.

title: Letter From the Editor: Marriage, and When Liberals Are Wrong
description: One of todays more intriguing social-science debates is whether changes in family structure have helped cause the rise in economic inequality  or are merely an effect of that rising inequality.

title: Stuff We Liked: Happiness in America
description: If this is not proof of American exceptionalism, I am not sure what is. When Pew Research Centers Global Attitudes survey asked people around the world how their day was going, it found that people in poor countries were often more likely than those in rich ones to report having a good day. But in America, where the pursuit of happiness ranks with life and liberty, the data shows we are pretty happy.

title: Warming Up for Winter Jazzfest
description: When the Winter Jazzfest celebrated its 10th anniversary last year, it stretched out to five days of programming, from the customary two. This years edition isnt quite so big, but its still plenty big enough, officially kicking off Thursday night with Blue Note Now! a lineup of bands from the current Blue Note Records roster  and Jazz Legends for Disability Pride, an all-star concert that raised funds for the first annual Disability Pride NYC Parade.

title: On Snowy Day, Late Reprieve on Alternate-Side Rules Doesnt Ease Drivers Ire
description: No words are sweeter to the ears of New York Citys car owners than these: Alternate-side parking regulations are suspended.

title: The Punk Ballerina Karole Armitage Brings Together Lacroix, Gaultier, Koons and More
description: A new exhibition at Mana Contemporary, curated by Jeffrey Deitch, highlights the choreographers many collaborations with key art and fashion figures.

title: Sebastiaan Pieter Debuts His Fall/Winter 2015 Mens Collection in an Eerie New Video
description: I wanted to make a video to place the clothes, the Pieter guy, more in a reality context, says Sebastiaan Pieter, the 26-year-old Dutch designer who will present the fall/winter 2015 collection of his nascent line, Pieter, on Saturday in London. Collaborating with Max Pearmain, the stylist and editor of fashion magazine Arena Homme Plus, as well as the art director Jonathan Baron, Pieter created a voyeuristic look at the new collection, which features a cool merging of activewear with unconventional tailoring and knitwear: athletic tights layered under knit tops with slashed openings (inspired by Lucio Fontana paintings) and unstructured outerwear made from fabrics typically used for uniforms of the Royal Guard. Filmed in a bleak office environment with expansive views of Londons Financial District and composed of grainy time-stamped clips mimicking security footage, the video, which will run on loop during the presentation, grounds the clothes, says the young designer (albeit rather eerily). For this new season, as with his previous two collections, Pieter, who worked both in publishing (Fantastic Man) and design (for Jil Sander under Raf Simons) before launching his own line in early 2014, explores the loosening and blurring of mens sartorial norms through more feminine cuts and roomier silhouettes. Theres a dark twisted way of sexuality, Pieter says, that Im always thinking about.

title: Life Sentence for British Cleric Who Helped Plan 1998 Kidnappings in Yemen
description: A fiery British cleric who was convicted last year of 11 terrorism-related charges, including helping to orchestrate the violent 1998 kidnappings of 16 American, British and other tourists in Yemen, was sentenced in Manhattan on Friday to life in prison.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Black Box Pings Detected in AirAsia Hunt
description: Supriyadi, operational officer at Indonesias National Search and Rescue Agency, said his team detected pings in their efforts to find the black box flight recorders from AirAsia Flight 8501.

title: Obamas College Proposal Is Also a Bid to Rev the Economy
description: Economic history provides the broader context for understanding President Obamas proposal to make community college available free.

title: All About Meghan Trainor
description: Ben Ratliff and Joe Coscarelli discuss Ms. Trainor as surprise, as a formula, as contrivance and as a product of Nantucket, hip-hop and Nashville.

title: Exclusive | Sands Point, N.Y.
description: An eco-friendly mansion on nearly four waterfront acres is poised to enter the market at $38 million.

title: Readers Respond: On Islam and the Charlie Hebdo Shootings
description: Muslim voices from the United States and around the world joined with thousands of others to provide a kaleidoscope of straightforward, anguished and angry replies to the question posed in Nicholas Kristofs column Is Islam to Blame for the Shooting at Charlie Hebdo in Paris?

title: Kerry to Meet Iranian Counterpart Next Week Before Nuclear Talks Resume
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State John Kerry plans to meet with his Iranian counterpart next week in Geneva to try to advance the negotiations over Irans nuclear program, the State Department said on Friday.

title: Views From Every Room
description: A nearly new, postmodern, eco-friendly mansion on almost four waterfront acres in Sands Point, N.Y., an affluent village on the North Shore of Long Island, is poised to enter the market at $38 million.

title: House Passes Pipeline Bill, Adding to Pressure on Obama
description: Legislation to authorize the Keystone XL pipeline project is moving on to the Senate.

title: Worker Fatally Struck by Elevator in Upper West Side Building
description: A 30-year-old worker was killed on Friday morning while working on the elevators at a building on the Upper West Side, the authorities said.

title: Hostages Flee Kosher Store in Paris
description: Video shows people fleeing a kosher supermarket in Paris after the police stormed the building where an armed man held several hostages on Friday.

title: London Mens Fashion Week: Topman Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

title: Cosby Makes a Joke About Drinking Around Him
description: As the number of women accusing Bill Cosby of spiking their drinks before sexually assaulting them continues to grow, the comedian has not commented on the allegations, except obliquely. But on Thursday night during a performance in London, Ontario, Mr. Cosby did make a joke about them.

title: Joan Didions Cline Ad, Caras Side-Shave and So Much Bieber
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: At Cuomos Request, Panel May Again Weigh Casino Bids for Southern Tier of New York
description: What a difference a governors letter makes.

title: Expansive House G.O.P. Immigration Bill Undercuts the President
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans introduced legislation Friday that would roll back President Obamas executive actions on immigration, undoing a provision that would allow five million undocumented immigrants to remain in the country and one that protects young people brought to the United States illegally by a parent.

title: Popcast: All About Meghan Trainor
description: Meghan Trainors first single, All About That Bass, the cheeky 50s-style self-empowerment anthem, spent eight weeks in all at No. 1 on Billboards Hot 100 chart last year. (Thats more weeks than Michael Jacksons Billie Jean spent at number one  an astonishing statistic  but fewer weeks than Lordes Royals or Pharrells Happy.) And much about the story is odd: Ms. Trainor, now 21, is a young songwriter from Nantucket with no pop star training, but an apprenticeship in Nashville writing songs for Rascal Flatts, Sabrina Carpenter, and others.

title: Why You Should Be More Optimistic About Wage Growth
description: Commentary on this months employment report has focused on whats happening to wage growth. Throughout the recovery, wage growth has been disappointing, barely keeping pace with inflation.

title: European Official Criticizes Russian Law Banning Transgender Drivers
description: MOSCOW  One of Europes most senior human rights officials, the Council of Europes human rights commissioner, Nils Muiznieks, has criticized as ridiculous a new Russian law on road safety that prohibits transgender people from obtaining a drivers license.

title: Video Reviews of Unbroken, A Most Violent Year and Into the Woods
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Unbroken, A Most Violent Year and Into the Woods.

title: Start Paying Attention: Whats Happening Now in G.O.P. Matters for 2016
description: If you want to be a savvy political reader, its time to start paying attention to the flurry of articles about the so-called invisible primary: the behind-the-scenes competition for the support of elected officials, donors, party leaders and political operatives.

title: The Story Behind Joaquin Phoenixs Inherent Vice Style
description: Watching Inherent Vice, the new Paul Thomas Anderson film based on Thomas Pynchons novel about a surfer/stoner private eye, is like being taken on a joyride through the very best of late 1960s and 1970s SoCal fashion. Theres the orange crochet minidress worn by one character, the Rudi Gernreich-style bikini on another, the wacky purple suit of a square dentist trying to be hip. The movie, out today with an all-star cast (Joaquin Phoenix, Josh Brolin, Benicio Del Toro, Owen Wilson, Reese Witherspoon and the promising newcomer Katherine Waterston), follows the sandal-wearing gumshoe Larry Doc Sportello (Phoenix) around Los Angeles as clues pile up in a shaggy-dog mystery. But Phoenixs character is more hippie fashion plate than noir tough guy in his green army coat, navy turtleneck, jean jacket and slew of vintage flannel shirts. And its all thanks to Mark Bridges, the films costume designer, who has worked with Anderson since before Boogie Nights.

title: Bronx Man Surrenders and Is Charged in a Fatal Hit and Run
description: A Bronx man was arrested and charged in a hit-and-run accident on New Years Eve in Manhattan that killed a 44-year-old woman, the authorities said on Thursday.

title: A Bad Flu Season Hits the Halfway Mark, C.D.C. Says
description: The nation is halfway through a bad flu season, dominated by a viral strain that is not very vulnerable to this years vaccine, federal health officials said on Friday.

title: When Outside Factors Dictate Retirement Age
description: FOR many, deciding to retire can be as straightforward as reaching Social Security eligibility age or amassing a solid nest egg. But for others mulling over when to stop work, there are other powerful, if less measurable, considerations like life expectancy, changing technological demands of the workplace and fear that age bias will limit continued employment.

title: From The Upshot: Community College and the Economy
description: Obamas College Proposal Is Also a Bid to Rev the Economy

title: The Dress Is Temporary, the Memories Forever
description: Stephanie Grimes Cornman coveted the designer wedding dress she had ogled in fashion spreads. But the price kept it out of reach  that is, until she embraced the idea that a dress, unlike a spouse, is not to have and to hold forever.

title: DuPonts Main Defense Against Nelson Peltz: Performance
description: Nelson Peltz has kicked off only his second proxy fight by seeking four board seats at DuPont. But the chemical maker is an unusual target for a shareholder activism campaign  in part because the company appears to already be performing well.

title: CES: Everything Old Is New Again
description: Friday is the last official day of International CES, the giant technology trade show in Las Vegas. It is also, as it happens, the eighth anniversary of the introduction of the original iPhone.

title: In Africa, a Decline in New Ebola Cases Complicates Vaccine Development
description: As authorities and drug companies hurriedly prepare to begin testing Ebola vaccines in West Africa, they are starting to contemplate a new challenge: whether an ebbing of the outbreak could make it more difficult to determine if the experimental vaccines are effective.

title: Pursuing Games, Boston Jumps In With One Foot
description: Christmas has come and gone, but a holiday spirit lingers in Boston. Not the holly-jolly kind, but the quizzical kind where you unwrap a glitzy present and immediately wonder if it ought to be returned.

title: A Proxy Fight as Much About Nelson Peltzs Firm as About DuPont
description: Nelson Peltzs latest proxy fight will resonate beyond its immediate target, DuPont. The billionaire activists Trian Partners is seeking four director seats at the venerable chemicals group, its first public battle since squeezing onto Heinzs board nine years ago. Flexing muscle sends a message to other stubborn targets, like PepsiCo. It also gives Mr. Peltzs potential successors experience in the trenches.

title: London Mens Fashion Week: Topman Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

title: Behold the Republican Immigration Strategy: Mass Deportation
description: Its a new year, with a new Congress, but the same old Republican Party hard line on immigration. Harder, actually.

title: Sizing Up Seismic Activity of Football Fans
description: SEATTLE  What if the Big One happens during the Big Game?

title: 2 Entrepreneurs Know the Value in Serendipity
description: Amanda Moskowitz had no interest in peering into a crystal ball. She was the type who knew where she was going, the girl who took first prize in statewide oratory contests, snagged the lead in school plays, and was admitted to Brown University. Fortunes were to be made, she believed, not told.

title: Of a Feather, but a Flock Apart
description: Yekaterina Kondaurova, the elegant, flame-haired principal of the Mariinsky Ballet, appeared in Swan Lake during her first year with the St. Petersburg company in 2001. I was in the last row of the corps of swans, she recalled in an email interview. At the time I thought it was the most frightening thing there could be in life. My arms and legs were shaking so much. It was even hard to stand on my two feet.

title: So Nice, They Do It Twice
description: They are demanded, they delight and then theyre over, rarely to be remembered like the big concerto, sonata or symphony to which they form brief codas.

title: Storm Adds to Misery of Gazas Most Vulnerable
description: GAZA  As a winter storm continued to pound the Middle East, thousands of Gaza residents whose homes were destroyed or damaged in last summers war with Israel struggled with the harsh weather for a third day, and a 4-month-old baby from the southern part of the territory died on Friday from complications caused by the bitter cold, Palestinian health officials and relatives said.

title: A Reporter Treads Carefully When Writing About Religion and Violence
description: In the aftermath of the attack at the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo in Paris, The Times Cairo bureau chief, David D. Kirkpatrick, wrote a front-page article about debates over the connection between violence and Islam. Here he describes the care involved in writing about an inherently fraught subject and why it seemed important to address the questions.

title: A New Direction
description: As some readers have already discovered, The Times is discontinuing publication of The New Old Age blog. I join many of you in disappointment  but, to paraphrase Mark Twain, reports of its death have been exaggerated.

title: A Propulsive Leap Forward and a Nod to Late Blooms
description: Out with the old? Not quite yet. Before the year fully gears up, this Playlist lingers over some albums from 2014 that earned some belated notice  and welcomes some 2015 albums that defy the January doldrums.

title: Live Coverage: Golden Globes 2015
description: The Times covered the 72nd Golden Globe Awards live, with interviews and photos from the red carpet, reports from backstage, commentary during the telecast from Dave Itzkoff and Jon Caramanica, and more.

title: From Vertigo to Tinnitus, Ear Ailments Are New Focus for Drugs
description: Driving to a meeting in 2008, Jay Lichter, a venture capitalist, suddenly became so dizzy he had to pull over and call a friend to take him to the emergency room.

title: Obama, in Tennessee, Begins Selling His Community College Tuition Plan
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.  In California, community college tuition and fees average less than $1,500 a year, the lowest in the nation, and with government grants, most students pay nothing. In Florida and Michigan, the cost is over $3,000, yet poorer students still attend free. But in Vermont and New Hampshire, prices are around $7,000, well over what government grants cover.

title: London Mens Fashion Week: MAN Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

title: Christopher Shannon: Fall 2015 Menswear
description: London

title: Easily Channeling a Vulnerable Vicar
description: With his model looks, plummy British elocution and bad-boy twinkle, James Norton gives the impression of having the acting world on a string. But his first film role  a few seconds in Lone Scherfigs An Education, stealthily undertaken in defiance of institutional rules while a student at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art  didnt exactly portend a star in the making.

title: Cameras and the Tricks They Play
description: Though its not for want of trying, we can never fit real life into a frame. Thats the premise, both sobering and invigorating, that animates two affectingly inventive works from South America at the Under the Radar festival of experimental theater this weekend, ruefully sentimental plays about the deceptions of sentimental journeys.

title: Israelis Link Attacks to Their Own Struggles
description: JERUSALEM  Like leaders around the world, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was quick to condemn the attack that killed 12 people in Paris on Wednesday at the offices of a satirical newspaper, Charlie Hebdo. The next day, Mr. Netanyahu sent a letter of condolence and outrage to the French president and declared after a meeting with Norways foreign minister, Israel is being attacked by the very same forces that attack Europe.

title: Stormy Waters Decide a Familys Fate
description: The tools that contemporary composers, conductors and directors are using to expand the spectacle of music can sometimes seem like unnecessary embellishments, whether video projections, acrobatics or reflecting pools of water. So the great achievement of The Scarlet Ibis  an outstanding new chamber opera by the composer Stefan Weisman and the librettist David Cote that opened the Prototype festival at Here on Thursday night  is not only that its a moving, intense and dignified creation, but also that it adds puppetry to operas basic elements in a completely organic way.

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
description: A snowy landing and more in the Week in Politics slideshow.

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
The Punk Ballerina Karole Armitage Brings Together Lacroix, Gaultier, Koons and More
description: Nearly four decades ago, in 1978, a twentysomething dancer and choreographer named Karole Armitage tapped Christian Marclay, then a budding artist studying at Cooper Union, to create the set and costumes for her production Ne. It was kind of like Ne was destroying all that there was before, that jubilation, that you can remake the world in your own way, Armitage remembers. The piece was originally supposed to debut in an East Village squat. There was no heat, which is why we decided to have bright, fluorescent, fake-fur pants  because we just wanted to keep the dancers warm, Armitage explains. The squatters changed their minds, so Ne eventually premiered at a gymnasium in Chelsea.

title: A Memorial for a Jazz Great
description: The bassist Charlie Haden, who died last year at 76, was a generous collaborator throughout his expansive jazz career, sowing seeds of deep melody and pliable rapport among several generations of fellow musicians. A few dozen of them will gather to pay respects, in words and music, at his memorial celebration on Tuesday at Town Hall. Organized by his widow, Ruth Cameron, the service will include two of his flagship ensembles: the Liberation Music Orchestra, featuring the composer Carla Bley and, for this occasion, the bassist Steve Swallow; and Quartet West, with Scott Colley on bass. Members of Mr. Hadens musical family  his son, the singer-songwriter Josh Haden, and his daughters, known as the Haden Triplets will appear.

title: Piano and Strings, or Mahler
description: This week night offers a couple of strong concert choices. On Sunday, you can head to Spectrum, a very cozy space on the Lower East Side, for Morton Feldmans late, visionary Piano and String Quartet, featuring the pianist Joseph Branciforte and string players drawn from several ensembles: Christopher Otto, Pauline Kim Harris, John Pickford Richards and Mariel Roberts. (9 p.m., 121 Ludlow Street, second floor, spectrumnyc.com.)

title: When Spite Trumps the Nielsen Ratings
description: When last we saw Beverly and Sean Lincoln, the fictional creators of a British TV hit made unrecognizable by a Hollywood studio, theyd been swept out of fantasyland and back to reality with the cancellation  finally  of Pucks!

title: The Uphill Push to Save a Bike-Share Pioneer
description: The typical origin story for a tech company includes a paper napkin and a garage. But the company that powers the bike-sharing programs in New York, London, Chicago and a dozen other cities started much differently: It began with a municipal parking authority, wound through bankruptcy court and got another shot at corporate viability off the Madagascar coast during the annual hatching of the green sea turtles.

title: Scenes of France, Sketched in Oil
description: Oil sketches are the Twitter of 18th-century painting, dashed off sometimes in mere minutes to capture a fleeting idea or a quality of light that would be gone forever with the next cloud bank. Their power is not only in their immediacy but also in how they prefigure outdoor painters who elevated landscape as a genre. Starting Tuesday, the Morgan Library & Museum will focus on the history of the practice in Exploring France: Oil Sketches From the Thaw Collection. The collector Eugene V. Thaw and his wife, Clare, benefactors of the Morgan and the Metropolitan Museum of Art, have donated 135 oil sketches to the two institutions, in addition to giving hundreds of old master and 19th-century drawings to the Morgan. Mr. Thaw has described the sketches as the most wonderful, fresh, free pieces on paper  work that mattered to him because it mattered to the artists, who considered them much more than disposable studies: They traded them amongst each other, and they preserved them. (Through Oct. 4, 225 Madison Avenue, at 36th Street, 212-685-0008, themorgan.org.)

title: Uncovering Secrets
description: In the film version of Match, Stephen Belbers play about choices, regrets and long-hidden secrets, Patrick Stewart takes on the role brought to Broadway by Frank Langella in 2004. The movie, adapted and directed by Mr. Belber, opens on Wednesday at the IFC Center (323 Avenue of the Americas, at Third Street, Greenwich Village). Mr. Stewart plays Tobias Powell, a dance teacher and former performer whose long career is supposedly the reason Lisa (Carla Gugino) and her husband, Mike (Matthew Lillard), have come to interview him. But that is just a pretense; they are really interested in a piece of his past he has long buried. Its a three-hander thats also a showcase for the actor playing Tobias. What does Mr. Stewart have to live up to?

title: West Village Townhouse for $21 Million
description: A meticulously renovated townhouse in the West Village, with ample outdoor space that includes a two-tiered patio and a paved roof deck offering a wide range of cityscape and river views, sold for $21,000,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Gesture, Genetics and Other Fare
description: Are we on our way to becoming a single-sex species? In Preparation for the Obsolescence of the Y Chromosome, the choreographer Michelle Ellsworth considers the possibility, building on her body of jubilantly absurd yet pragmatically minded work. (Her past projects include an online inventory of pseudospiritual paraphernalia and a video archive of motivational talks.) Preparation, which draws inspiration from the folklorist Alan Lomax and recent genetic research, digests cultural lore through gestural choreography, a male gaze simulator and other witty devices.

title: Obamas Community-College Plan: A Reading List
description: President Obama is in Tennessee on Friday, along with the states Republican governor and two Republican senators, to lay out his plan for free community college. The plan  which would require congressional approval  would apply to students attending a two-year college, including part time, so long as the college offered credits that could transfer to a four-year college or provided training that led to jobs.

title: Christie to Pay His Way to Watch Cowboys Play
description: Showing that his loyalty to the Dallas Cowboys has no limits, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is shrugging off controversy over his football loyalties  and his acceptance of flights and tickets from the teams owner, Jerry Jones  opting to pay his own way to attend this weekends playoff game in Wisconsin.

title: George Washington Fought  and Lost  Here
description: The history of the Revolutionary Wars bloody Battle of Brooklyn is on display at the Old Stone House in Park Slope.

title: Where George Washington Lost a Battle in Brooklyn, a Museum Dedicated to Its History Sits
description: A tumult of children play soccer and skateboard around a Dutch Colonial farmhouse in Park Slope, oblivious to the sites brutal, blood-drenched past. The Battle of Brooklyn, the Revolutionary Wars biggest conflict, was waged around the OLD STONE HOUSE, a museum dedicated to the chaos that unfolded on Aug. 27, 1776, less than two months after the Declaration of Independence.

title: After Taking His Bows, a Super Bowl Star Takes a Seat
description: RENTON, Wash.  The morning after his life changed forever, Malcolm Smith boarded a private jet bound for Florida. A waiter catered to his and his girlfriends every need, recharging Smith for the parade that awaited him when he landed.
