title: Bitcoin Exchange Bitstamp Resumes Services
description: Bitstamp, the prominent Bitcoin exchange that suspended its services this week after a security breach, has resumed operations, capping a period of uncertainty in the virtual currency industry.

title: Blast Kills at Least 7 People at Mosque in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  At least seven people were killed and 18 were wounded Friday when a suicide bomber detonated his explosives outside a Shiite mosque in Rawalpindi, police officials said.

title: London Mens Fashion Week: MAN Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

title: How Places to Go Gets Done
description: Everyone wants to visit Rome. But have you considered Cleveland? The Travel sections 10th annual 52 Places to Go feature is live, and there are destinations that some may find surprising.

title: After Workout Accident, Reid Says Regaining Full Vision Is No Slam Dunk
description: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada said Friday that he might not regain the vision in his right eye after suffering a nasty fall in which he broke four ribs and some bones around his eye.

title: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
description: France and Elsewhere  Pictures of the Day

title: Pictures of the Day  Jan. 9, 2015
description: Photos from France, Manila, India and the United States.

title: Target-Date Funds Can Pose Complexities
description: Deborah L. Lemmerman, vice president for human resources at Hebrew SeniorLife in Boston, believes in the benefits of target-date retirement funds. Over the last 15 years, in her current post and in previous ones, she has seen employees embrace these investments.

title: For U.S. Stocks, at Least, a Solid Finish
description: Stocks ended the fourth quarter of 2014 near record highs, but they traveled a circuitous route to get there  falling, then soaring, then falling again before making a strong late run. Bonds went in either direction, depending on the quality of the vehicle used for the trip. And in the quarters biggest surprise, oil headed due south.

title: Trying to Capitalize on Lower Oil Prices, Through E.T.F.s
description: ONE of the biggest events in an eventful fourth quarter of 2014 may have been something that didnt happen.

title: The Rise of Trading in the Dark
description: JUDGING solely by the name, stock trading in so-called dark pools may conjure up images of mysterious deals cut beyond public view. Also called simply dark trading, it happens when computers serve as matchmakers and bid-and-ask quotations arent displayed to all participants. Whats surprising is just how big the dark-trading market has become.

title: Gauging Funds Emergency Preparedness
description: WHENEVER markets are hot, mutual fund companies tend to go far off the beaten track in their hunt for better returns.

title: For Bond Investors, That Other Shoe Still Didnt Drop
description: BONDS confounded conventional wisdom in 2014 with a much-better-than-expected return.

title: A Day of Calm for Kathryn Garcia
description: Kathryn Garcia remembers having just four snow days when she was a student in Park Slope in the 1970s. Growing up, she would listen to the radio for the announcements. Theyd go through a laundry list of suburban schools, Ms. Garcia said. " Mount Vernon, Montclair schools are closed, New York public schools are ...open.  Sigh. Now, as the New York City sanitation commissioner, Ms. Garcia, 44, is the one who advises the Education Department as to whether to call a snow day, consulting with the citys meteorologists and with three weather services. With the city not seeing its first accumulation until Tuesday, Ms. Garcia has been savoring her non-snowy Sundays. She does not venture far from the Park Slope home she shares with her husband, Jerry Garcia, 45 (he does not play guitar), and their daughter, Anna, 16. Their son, Alex, 18, is a freshman at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Suddenly, BRIC Markets Are on a Shakier Foundation
description: Investing in rapidly developing economies is an inherently risky proposition. That is why more than a decade ago, investors embraced what seemed a prudent approach: focusing on the BRIC countries  Brazil, Russia, India and China  which have the largest and most liquid stock markets in the emerging-market world.

title: An Instrumental Force in the Face of Darkness
description: For the New York Philharmonics first subscription series program of 2015, Alan Gilbert, the music director, had chosen some joyous music for the New Year, he told the audience at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night. But while the orchestra was preparing this concert, he said, the horrific massacre took place at the offices of the newspaper Charlie Hebdo, in Paris.

title: Two Schools of Thought, Adding Up to Success
description: GROWTH and value styles of investing are often described as opposites, but managers of three of the better-performing funds of the fourth quarter of 2014 dont see it that way.

title: Feeding the Beast With Ever-Cheaper Oil
description: GOOD news! Oil prices have dropped through the floor.

title: Investment Strategies for Resolution Breakers
description: THE problem with most New Years resolutions is that they arent any fun. Sure, many of us should eat less  and healthier. And of course, more exercise would be a good thing. But actually doing these things can be hard.

title: If/Then to Close on Broadway
description: The Broadway musical If/Then, a star vehicle for the Tony Award winner Idina Menzel that portrays the implications of career and romantic choices on a modern-day New Yorker, will close on March 22 at the conclusion of Ms. Menzels run in the show, the producers announced on Friday.

title: The Freewheeling Event Thats Part Performance Art, Part Dance Party
description: High rents and branded, well, everything may loom over the arts in New York City  but some grassroots culture organizations still manage to tough out the mean streets of the metropolis without compromising their homespun ethics. On Jan. 10, the whirlwind, ball-of-wax performance showcase Catch stages its 66th iteration  a feat for a sui generis arts project. The secret to its fancy-free success for over a decade? Beer, deadpans Caleb Hammons, one-third of Catchs advisory team. As it says on the flyer, $20 gets you in and gets you drinking. As Hammons explains, It signals that its okay to enjoy yourself.

title: An Escape Artist, Unlocking Door After Door
description: The objects for sale on Miranda Julys website seem entirely ordinary and even deliberately random. A pink hairbrush. An envelope. A painted vase. A bag of popcorn.

title: Keeping the Laughs on Track
description: STUDIO CITY, CALIF.  When the writers of the ABC sitcom Last Man Standing broke for lunch one recent Friday, five of them took their food to Ed Yeagers office on the lot here.

title: Before Dying, French Suspects Speak
description: Shortly before being killed in police shootouts, Chrif Kouachi and a man believed to have killed a police officer spoke on the phone with a French television station.

title: London Mens Fashion Week: Christopher Shannon Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

title: Saudis Begin Public Caning to Punish a Blogger
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The authorities in Saudi Arabia on Friday began the public flogging of a blogger who was sentenced to 1,000 blows, 10 years in prison and a large fine for starting a website that featured content critical of the countrys religious establishment, the rights group Amnesty International reported.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: The Duet as a Physical Sculpture, Unburdened by Noise or Clothing
description: Rude World, the title of a new duet choreographed and performed by Molly Lieber and Eleanor Smith, might refer to all that the dance appears at first to exclude. The walls of the tiny Chocolate Factory theater, where the work was performed on Thursday as part of PS 122s Coil festival, have been draped in black, the floor covered in black vinyl. The two women, entirely silent and naked most of the time, could be alone, dancing only for each other. Dancing with each other, they intertwine, skin to skin. Their world seems self-contained.

title: Stop Checking Email So Often
description: IS email overload bad for you?

title: Hooting, Hissing and Ululating to Protest Mans Inhumanity
description: Much of Toxic Psalms, a striking new work by the rabidly talented Slovenian female vocal ensemble Carmina Slovenica, is dark. Literally: Enveloped in shadow, the vast stage of St. Anns Warehouse in Brooklyn, where the piece runs through Sunday, has rarely looked as forlorn as it did on opening night on Thursday.

title: Jeb and Hillary Have Some Work to Do, a Pollster Finds
description: The political classes may be embracing the inevitability of a Bush-Clinton clash in 2016, but some voters are not sold.

title: Help Unravel a Gordon Parks Southern Mystery
description: A Gordon Parks photo from 1956 raises tantalizing questions about race and class in the Jim Crow South. Now, Lens is asking readers to help uncover the identities of the people in the picture.

title: London Mens Fashion Week: Christopher Shannon Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

title: Cocktails, Karaoke and Occasional Cringing
description: Schadenfreude is perhaps a natural reaction to The Blind Date Project, an improvisational theater piece presented as part of this years Coil festival that allows you to be a voyeur at the first meeting between two strangers. Admit that theres something sneakily appealing in the prospect of watching other people navigate the jittery horrors of that initial encounter, a grueling rite of passage pretty much everyone has endured, and often regretted.

title: In New York, a Hotel by Baccarat
description: The venerable French crystal company Baccarat is venturing into hotel business for the first time with the Baccarat Hotel & Residences New York in a glass tower in Midtown Manhattan across the street from the Museum of Modern Art. While the 60 residences have been open since December, the hotel will make its debut in March.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Informative Auction at World Mind Games in Beijing
description: At the fourth SportAccord World Mind Games in Beijing last month, Vincent Demuy of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., found a great opening lead in the open pair event. Admittedly, he was helped by the very informative auction of his opponents, Fulvio Fantoni (North) and Claudio Nunes (South) from Monaco.

title: Book Review Podcast: Americas Bitter Pill
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Zephyr Teachout reviews Steven Brills Americas Bitter Pill: Money, Politics, Backroom Deals, and the Fight to Fix Our Broken Healthcare System. Ms. Teachout writes:

title: Koons, Murakami and Other Artists Donate Works for Childhood Education
description: London  Jeff Koons, Damien Hirst, Cai Guo Qiang, Jenny Holzer, Takashi Murakami, Richard Serra and Luc Tuymans are among the 17 major artists who have donated works for auction to benefit 1 in 11, a new campaign to improve education for children.

title: Another Avenging Rampage
description: After Non-Stop, Unknown and three installments of the Taken thrillers, Im not sure that Liam Neesons signature avengers are actually good people to know. On the plus side, theyll use any means necessary to rescue you from kidnappers and killers. But if youve been kidnapped or are facing death, its probably directly related to knowing Mr. Neesons character in the first place, or just being nearby.

title: Staten Island Prosecutor to Run for Grimms House Seat
description: The race to succeed former Representative Michael G. Grimm has officially begun.

title: Boston Bombing Trial, Week by Week
description: A synopsis of the trial of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who is accused of killing three people and injuring more than 260 in the bombing at the Boston Marathon in 2013. Mr. Tsarnaev is facing 30 federal charges, 17 of which carry the death penalty. He has pleaded not guilty.

title: Vessel, Directed by Diana Whitten
description: The debates over access to abortion often invoke personal rights. Vessel concerns the intersection of those rights with national sovereignty. The movie follows the work of Dr. Rebecca Gomperts, a physician from the Netherlands who founded Women on Waves, an organization whose goal was to provide medical abortions in international waters to women from countries where the procedure was illegal. She later started Women on Web, a telemedicine support service. (Emily Bazelon covered Dr. Gompertss efforts at length in The New York Times Magazine last year.)

title: F.B.I. and Justice Dept. Said to Seek Charges for Petraeus
description: WASHINGTON  The F.B.I. and Justice Department prosecutors have recommended bringing felony charges against David H. Petraeus, contending that he provided classified information to a lover while he was director of the C.I.A., officials said, and leaving Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. to decide whether to seek an indictment that could send the pre-eminent military officer of his generation to prison.

title: Wrongly Convicted Man Was His Own Best Advocate
description: They would meet every week in the law library, researching legal databases, discussing United States Supreme Court decisions and reviewing copies of Justice Denied, a magazine for the wrongfully convicted.

title: If at First You Dont Succeed, Try Scaling Back Your Dream
description: It was just last season that the bio-musical Soul Doctor opened and quickly closed on Broadway, a box-office failure with a price tag of at least $5 million.

title: The Battle to Belong
description: NEVER before have so many people been on the move. New opportunity, like a bright star, draws immigrants across the world. In every one of the past four generations my family has moved, hopping from Lithuania to what is now South Africa and on to Britain, Israel and the United States. Sometimes they have found success and happiness. But the other side of displacement, its black sun, is loss.

title: Who Will Be Americas Next Top Mentor?
description: The January issues of fashion magazines usually contain extra lashings of diet and exercise advice (and the fewest ads of the year), but this months Elle, with Nicole Kidman on the cover, offers something new. To celebrate its third decade, the magazine announced, it is convening a board of 43 female powerhouses who are joining forces to improve the lives of women  thats you!  for the next 30 years.

title: Users Say TurboTax Deluxe Is Less Deluxe Than It Used to Be
description: TAXPAYERS buying commercial software to prepare and electronically file their 2014 income tax returns should double-check that the version they are purchasing fits their needs.

title: Where Fabric and Trinkets Are Found
description: Broadway Silk Store has been an anchor in Astoria, Queens, since the Depression.

title: Where Elmos People Shop: Broadway Silk Store in Astoria
description: Is it a coincidence that Broadway Silk Store, a Queens purveyor of fabric and costume jewelry, sits across the street from the Greater Astoria Historical Society? The store has been an anchor in the neighborhood since the Depression. It is two blocks from Kaufman Astoria Studios and has furnished costuming for an array of productions over its 80-year history, including Sesame Street, Men in Black 3 and The Good Wife. And as with other multigenerational, family-owned institutions, it has an oral history so rich that it can be hard to distinguish fact from fiction.

title: The Fury Over Chirlane McCrays Trousers
description: The firestorm of social media accusation and response that blew up around the question of what New York Citys first lady, Chirlane McCray, did, or did not, wear to the slain police officer Wenjian Lius funeral last Sunday may seem a silly distraction in the greater, more urgent story of fraying relations between City Hall and the police force, but it is also a powerful reminder of the power clothes have, for both good and ill.

title: To Fall in Love With Anyone, Do This
description: More than 20 years ago, the psychologist Arthur Aron succeeded in making two strangers fall in love in his laboratory. Last summer, I applied his technique in my own life, which is how I found myself standing on a bridge at midnight, staring into a mans eyes for exactly four minutes.

title: The 36 Questions That Lead to Love
Mitt Romney Says Hes Considering a 2016 Presidential Run
description: WASHINGTON  Mitt Romney, the 2012 Republican presidential nominee, told a group of donors in New York on Friday that he was considering running for president again next year, sending a signal to the partys financiers that they should not yet commit to Jeb Bush.

title: Piano Tuner Is Known as a Pro, and a Scold
description: Between you and me, a job like this is a pain in the neck, the piano tuner said, surveying the aging Baldwin spinet before him.

title: Amid Urban Debris, the Snowy Owl Is a Wintertime Ghost
description: The first snowy owl I ever saw turned out to be a Clorox bleach bottle, perched on the crest of a dune in the Rockaways. Three friends and I spent a half-hour stalking its glowering, yellow cap, which, at least at a distance, made for a passable yellow eye in what seemed like an accurate white silhouette. Lesson 1: Not all bumps on a dune in New York City are snowy owls.

title: Uber Cuts Fares in 48 Cities, Raising Some Concern Among Drivers
description: Uber, the popular ride-hailing start-up, has enticed millions of new customers with a simple promise: The experience will be better and cheaper than taking a taxi.

title: Police Efforts to Free the Hostages
description: The police moved on two sites in France where suspects were said to be holding hostages.

title: At A.F.I. Lunch, an Award for Everyone
description: The formation of hierarchies seems an indubitable part of human nature, which is perhaps why the American Film Institute awards luncheon on Friday came off, to your Baggers new-to-all-of-this eyes, as a little flat.

title: Remembering Bess Myersons Turbulent Public Life
description: For the first 70 years of her life, Bess Myerson barely breathed without making headlines.

title: Books About Sodom by the Sea and the Bronx
description: Its the nature of Coney Island to confuse, Kevin Baker writes in his foreword to A Coney Island Reader: Through Dizzy Gates of Illusion (Columbia University Press), by Louis J. Parascandola and John Parascandola, an overdue anthology that vividly paints Brooklyns seaside playground in psychedelic prose and poetry.

title: New Mexico: Deal Would Restore Doctors License
description: An obstetrician/gynecologist in Hobbs whose medical license was suspended over accusations that he had sex with patients, drank on the job and was unavailable as his patients went into labor has been ordered to undergo evaluation for sex addiction as a condition of returning to work. The doctor, Christopher S. Driskill, one of the few obstetrician-gynecologists in Hobbs and president-elect of the New Mexico Medical Society, had his license suspended in November by state medical officials. In December, he reached a settlement with state Medical Board prosecutors to restore his license. The settlement was approved Thursday by the board, which required that he submit to a comprehensive inpatient evaluation within the next three months by the Sexual Recovery Institute in Los Angeles.

title: Friday Night Music: Nickel Creek
description: How is it that I missed this band? Some simple joy after a week of terrible headlines:

title: At Princeton, a Student of Sports Leadership Successfully Applies Her Research
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  As a womens basketball assistant at Dartmouth in 2007, Courtney Banghart juggled her coaching duties with requirements for a masters degree in writing and leadership development. For her final project, she conducted in-person interviews with accomplished coaches, including the North Carolina womens soccer coach, Anson Dorrance, and the Connecticut womens basketball coach, Geno Auriemma.

title: Dozens Said to Die in Boko Haram Attack
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Refugees in northeast Nigeria fleeing an attack by the Islamist group Boko Haram have spoken of dozens of civilian deaths and scores of houses destroyed in an already hard-hit fishing village near Lake Chad.

title: Julio Scherer Garca, Investigative Journalist in Mexico, Dies at 88
description: MEXICO CITY  Julio Scherer Garca, a newspaper and magazine editor who created a school of critical journalism that unmasked Mexicos political corruption and helped lay the groundwork for the countrys democratic transition, died here on Jan. 7. He was 88.

title: A License to Say Anything?
description: SPECIALTY license plates  which bear the logo of a college or a sports team, or a slogan like Save Our Seas or Stop Child Abuse  bring in lots of money for state governments, as well as the schools, nonprofit groups, professional organizations and other entities that sponsor them. But these vehicular tags have also become a new frontier in debates over freedom of speech.

title: Windfall for Taxpayers Coming to an End
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserves bond-buying campaign continues to produce one clear benefit: a windfall for taxpayers.

title: A Pop-Punk Singer and the Blurred Line Between Digital Fan Mail and Trouble
description: As technology has eroded the traditional barriers between musicians and their admirers, the old-fashioned methods of connection  sending fan letters into the record label ether, sneaking backstage at a concert for a photo  have given way to new forms of interaction: Twitter, Instagram, Facebook. Online, artists are closer to their public than ever.

title: Ex-Police Chief Tells South Carolina Jury Why He Shot Unarmed Black Man
description: ORANGEBURG, S.C.  For much of the week, Richard J. Combs, a former police chief in the small town of Eutawville, sat in silence at his murder trial while jurors heard how he killed an unarmed black man.

title: Chicago Man Is Indicted on Charge of Trying to Aid ISIS
description: A 19-year-old man from the Chicago suburbs has been indicted by a federal grand jury on charges that he tried to provide support to a terrorist group in his effort to travel to Syria with his younger sister and brother.

title: At Ramen Shops in Westchester, Broth and Noodles Harmonize
description: So many places to eat ramen, so little time. Ramen seems to be the food of the moment. And why not? These noodle soups are clean, hearty, filling and cheap, just the bracing, nourishing meal needed to get on with your day.

title: Easing the Rules on Home Schooling
description: To the Editor:

title: Turkey: Leftists Retract Their Claim About an Attack
description: A Marxist extremist group that took responsibility for a suicide bombing in Istanbul this week retracted its claim on Friday, saying that it had made a mistake. On Tuesday, a woman detonated explosives in a police station in Istanbuls tourist district, Sultanahmet, and blew herself up. One police officer died in the attack and another was wounded. The outlawed Revolutionary Peoples Liberation Party claimed responsibility and identified the suicide bomber as Elif Sultan Kalsen. But Ms. Kalsens family said that the body that was shown to them was not their daughter. On Friday, the group retracted its claim that it carried out the bombing. It said it had made a mistake because the bombing corresponded with an attack it had planned in the same area. It did not offer details about its planned attack. The Turkish news media has reported that the bomber was a Russian citizen of Chechen descent. An investigation is underway, the Interior Ministry said.

title: Police vs. de Blasio: Examining the Reasons
description: To the Editor:

title: Economy Up, G.O.P. Wants a Little Credit
description: WASHINGTON  After years of finding the dark lining in every silver economic cloud, Republicans are facing a political quandary that is dividing their leadership even as it buoys the nation: The economy appears to be achieving liftoff.

title: Israel and Gaza
description: To the Editor:

title: Rumor Fatigue Sets In at False Alarms of Castros Death
description: MIAMI  The bulletin now falls squarely in the pantheon of unconfirmed phenomena, along with U.F.O.s, sightings of the Loch Ness monster and the breakup of Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie:

title: Truth and Myths About the Keystone Oil Pipeline
description: To the Editor:

title: Broadway Ticket Prices
description: To the Editor:

title: Reaching Outside C.I.A., Obama Picks Treasury Official to Become Agencys No. 2
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has chosen the Treasury Department official who has directed the effort to cut off funding of the Islamic State and impose economic sanctions on Syria, Russia and Iran to become the C.I.A.s deputy director, the agency announced on Friday.

title: Four Oklahoma Inmates Seek Delay in Executions
description: Lawyers for four Oklahoma inmates who are scheduled for lethal injection this winter filed an emergency request for a delay with a federal appeals court on Friday, claiming that a sedative the state plans to use cannot reliably induce the deep coma needed for a humane execution and that its use constitutes human experimentation.

title: Court Could Move Quickly on Israeli-Palestinian Case
description: UNITED NATIONS  The chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court could start looking into allegations of war crimes and crimes against humanity on Palestinian lands even before Israelis go to the polls in March, according to the court.

title: Evening Hours | Past Elegance
description: Throwback style and fashions new generation.

title: How to Stop Currency Manipulation
description: WASHINGTON  IF the new Congress can agree on anything this year, it may well be the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a trade deal between the United States and 11 other countries throughout the Asia-Pacific region. Passions run high when it comes to trade deals these days, and the Obama administration is working hard to sell it to labor unions, which roundly oppose it.

title: Students in Maryland Test Civic Participation and Win Right to Vote
description: HYATTSVILLE, Md.  Sarah Leonard, 15, joined a group of local teenagers here recently as they lobbied the City Council to grant them more power. Wearing a black I am Hyattsville T-shirt, she stood in front of a standing-room-only crowd, sounding confident as she addressed the lawmakers.

title: To Keep Rams in St. Louis, City Unveils Stadium Plan
description: In a bid to keep the Rams from moving to Southern California, civic leaders in St. Louis on Friday unveiled plans to build a 64,000-seat outdoor stadium along the Mississippi River.

title: Growing Up on Easy Street Has Its Own Dangers
description: When Thomas Gilbert Jr. was arrested on Monday and charged with killing his wealthy father with a gunshot to the head, the rubbernecking and tut-tutting began almost immediately.

title: An Attitude Forecast: Bitter and Nasty
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Thirty years ago, when restricted free agency kept N.F.L. rosters unchanged and parity was not the goal of the game schedule, it was customary for powerhouse teams to meet in the postseason year after year.

title: Bill Cunningham | Fashions Deep Freeze
description: While no one was turning blue from the cold, several fashionable women wore blue coats, and one young man appeared in a silk, quilted coat.

title: Bill Cunningham | Fashions Deep Freeze
description: All the drama of winter cold arrived just as the last holiday tourist throngs left the city on Monday. In Bryant Park, on the Sixth Avenue side, the fountain was covered in icicles. By Friday, the fountain was no longer visible. Members of the usually politically correct fashion crowd pulled out their fur coats. Cellphones disappeared, and hands clutched hot cups of coffee instead. The few visitors to the city who were left after the cold set in still had breakfast at Tiffany & Co., even as their teeth chattered. A surprise was the sight of many capes and ponchos, which are not very practical in the cold. More practical were the belted coats. And while no one was turning blue from the cold, several fashionable women wore blue coats, and one young man appeared in a silk, quilted coat.

title: Extremists Harming Islam, Leader of Hezbollah Says
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The leader of Hezbollah declared on Friday that extremists claiming to act in the name of Islam did more harm to the religion than any cartoon.

title: Bratton Tells New York Police Officers Its Time to Get Back to Work
description: Seeking to end more than two weeks of a precipitous drop in police activity, Police Commissioner William J. Bratton said on Friday that he had instructed top commanders to do what they could to reverse the trend.

title: Boston, in Old College Try, Uses Campuses in 2024 Olympic Bid
description: BOSTON  The odds were against James B. Connolly. He was born in South Boston in 1868, one of 12 children of poor Irish immigrants. But he schooled himself and managed to get into Harvard.

title: The Labor Picture in December
description: Employers added 252,000 jobs in December as the labor market closed out a breakout year on a strong note, the Labor Department said Friday. The unemployment rate fell from 5.8% to 5.6%, lowest since June 2008. The rate plunged just over a full percentage point between 2013 and 2014, the largest decline since 1984.

title: Days of Sirens, Fear and Blood: France Is Turned Upside Down
description: PARIS  It was a day of sirens, helicopters in the air, frantic news bulletins; of police cordons and anxious crowds; of young children led away from schools to safety. It was a day, like the previous two, of blood and horror in and around Paris, one that ended with France unsure whether this drama is now truly over or a predictor of more cultural, religious and political violence to come.

title: Connecticut Teenager With Cancer Loses Court Fight to Refuse Chemotherapy
description: The police were banging on the doors and the windows of her home while she cowered in the closet, a 17-year-old girl recounted. She remembered clutching her phone, crying, calling her mother.

title: They Dont Rebuild. They Replace.
description: ST. JOSEPH, Mo.  The Lady Hornets of Emporia State, 130 miles from home, had gone scoreless in their first two possessions against Missouri Western on Thursday night when the freshman point guard Addie Lackey cradled the basketball near midcourt and turned to her coach, Jory Collins, for instruction.

title: New President in Sri Lanka Puts Chinas Plans in Check
description: NEW DELHI  On a Sunday four months ago, a vessel pulled unannounced into Sri Lankas Colombo harbor: the Chinese Navy submarine Great Wall No. 329, which is designed to carry torpedoes, a cruise missile and a 360-pound warhead.

title: Gov. Christies Cowboy Connection
description: The video of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey clumsily trying to high-five Dallas Cowboys executives went viral days ago. But apart from causing a good deal of merriment, the awkward embrace between Mr. Christie and the Cowboys owner, Jerry Jones, after the teams comeback win Sunday over the Detroit Lions, has drawn attention to a potentially more troubling connection between two powerful friends.

title: On Duty for the Chris Christie Hug Watch
description: As we move into a big football weekend, one exciting question uniting fans and nonfans alike is: What will Chris Christie do if Dallas wins?

title: Measuring Football Fans Seismic Effects
description: Scientists from the Pacific Northwest Seismic Network set up earthquake trackers ahead of a playoff game in Seattle on Saturday to capture the ground-shaking effects of about 67,000 people.

title: A Groundbreaking Game Remembered
description: Fifty years ago, Father Ryan Highs integrated basketball team played Pearl Highs team, which because of segregation was entirely black, in Nashville.

title: Tense Scene on Basketball Court 50 Years Ago Recalls Catholic Role in Civil Rights
description: NASHVILLE  In the locker room beneath the packed bleachers of the Municipal Auditorium here, Bill Derrick gathered the basketball players he coached at Father Ryan High School. They recited The Lords Prayer and said a Hail Mary, as they always did before tipoff. Then, with unusual emphasis, Mr. Derrick intoned two or three times, Lady of victory, pray for us.

title: After Brutal Traverse, Climber Looks Upward
description: About 200 miles away from Yosemite Valley and El Capitan, Jacqui Becker got a text message and a photo from her boyfriend, the climber Kevin Jorgeson. The photo was of him smiling in front of a wall of granite. The text announced that he was not stopping now.

title: Is Pakistan Worth Americas Investment?
description: It doesnt take much to stir controversy over Americas relationship with Pakistan. The latest dust-up involves $532 million in economic assistance that the United States expects to provide later this year. Last week, Pakistani officials jumped the gun by suggesting the money is closer to being disbursed than it is; the news annoyed India, which doesnt think the aid is merited.

title: For Author of Younger Novel, Its Showtime
description: The author Pamela Redmond Satran recently read the comedian Amy Poehlers memoir, Yes, Please, and found a few things within that resonated.

title: Racial Isolation in Public Schools
description: New Yorks schools are the most segregated in the nation, and the state needs remedies right away. That was the message delivered to the governor and the Legislature last week by the chancellor of the State Board of Regents. Minority children are disproportionately trapped in schools that lack the teaching talent, course offerings and resources needed to prepare them for college and success in the new economy.

title: Riddle of the Pyramids: What Is Herbalife?
description: Were doing Gods work, said William Ackman, the hedge fund manager, on CNBC this week. He was referring to his $1 billion bet against Herbalife, the company that he accuses of being an illegal pyramid scheme.

title: M.T.A. Officers Bid Farewell to Comrade Who Was Struck on the Verrazano in 2013
description: The mayor and the governor did not attend. The sea of pressed blue shirts often seen outside police funerals appeared more like a stream. The buzz of uniformed officers radios told not of crime and distress but of eastbound traffic on the lower level of a bridge.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 9, 2015
Four at the Fore
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Well, Ive gotta tell you, its been a heck of a week for New York Times crossword puzzles. There was a strong reaction to the puzzles over the past few days (Patrick Berrys puzzle may be the exception), and rightfully so. The consensus, both here and on social media, is that the level of arcane knowledge needed to solve some of the puzzles, especially Wednesdays, was excessive.

title: For the College Playoff, Super-Size Ads
description: When commercials for advertisers such as Allstate and AT&T made their debuts during the Rose and Sugar Bowls on New Years Day, it was reasonable to assume that some marketers saw the College Football Playoff as an event with Super Bowl-like power to reach a massive audience.

title: A Statue of Muhammad on a New York Courthouse, Taken Down Years Ago
description: It would have given great offense, had anyone known it was there.

title: Down an Unlikely Path, a Culinary Hideaway
description: The first impressions of Farm Country Kitchen in Riverhead are not promising. To get there, you drive down an industrial road full of car dealerships and auto body shops. Then you will invariably drive past the place, since there is no sign except for a chalkboard easel sitting inconspicuously outside, the restaurant itself hidden behind a tall line of bushes.

title: Conquering Her Fears While Learning Job Skills and Moving Toward Independence
description: All her life, Alba Ramos has been haunted by a single question, one she posed to Ydalia Gomez constantly.

title: 11 Are Injured, Two Critically, in Bronx Fire
description: A two-alarm fire in a Bronx apartment building on Friday injured 11 people, two of them critically, and left dozens of families seeking shelter, the authorities said.

title: Samuel Goldwyn Jr., 88, Dies; Hollywood Scion and Film Influence
description: LOS ANGELES  Samuel Goldwyn Jr., an urbane, soft-spoken scion of a Hollywood dynasty who became an influential movie executive in his own right, supporting promising young directors and advancing the independent film movement, died here on Friday. He was 88.

title: Staying Close to Home
description: Greenwich Avenue, the long, long main shopping street in affluent Greenwich, is not the sort of area where you can expect to dine on the cheap. Thats why finding the two-year-old Harvest was such a pleasant surprise.

title: He Zhenliang Dies at 85; Chinas Olympic Crusader
description: He Zhenliang, a key figure in returning China to the Olympics in the 1980s after an absence of almost three decades and in securing the 2008 Summer Games for Beijing, died on Jan. 4 in Beijing. He was 85.

title: David H. Marlowe Dies at 83; Helped Army Nurture Bands of Brothers
description: David H. Marlowe, an anthropologist whose immersive studies among soldiers drove home the importance of group cohesion in combat and helped prompt enduring changes in how the military disciplines, organizes and cares for its troops, died on Dec. 27 at a retirement community in Silver Spring, Md. He was 83.

title: A Resurgent Harvard Will Confront Yale at the Garden
description: For the past two seasons, the Harvard mens hockey team had to look up at its archrival Yale.

title: The Links Among the Paris Terror Suspects and Their Connections to Jihad
description: Where their lives intersected and what may have influenced them.

title: Andra Crouch, 72, Who Infused Gospel With Soul, Dies
description: Andra Crouch, a singer and songwriter whose plaintive, passionate gospel songs knitted religious music to rhythm and blues, soul and contemporary balladeering and found their way into mainstream pop music, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 72.

title: Faces of a Small Southern Town: Becoming Disfarmer, at the Neuberger Museum of Art
description: A visitor could spend hours studying the faces on display in Becoming Disfarmer, an exhibition of photographic portraits at the Neuberger Museum of Art. Couples, families, men dressed in military uniforms, pretty young women in lipstick and barrettes: They peer out from the walls and up from the glass cases. Some of the faces are freckled, others weathered and lined. A few smile, but most are grave. All stare intently into the cameras lens.

title: Baltimore Ravens at New England Patriots: Saturdays A.F.C. Divisional-Round Matchup
description: Ravens at Patriots

title: Carolina Panthers at Seattle Seahawks: Saturdays N.F.C. Divisional-Round Matchup
description: Panthers at Seahawks

title: Old Belts and Fishing Tackle Transformed
description: Sometimes wildly different exhibitions connect through kindred approaches to the artistic process. That synergy has Alan Shields: In Motion conversing with Steven and William Ladd: Mary Queen of the Universe at the Parrish Art Museum. Visit, and you will see two generations of artists born in the Midwest who have transformed ordinary stuff  from fishing tackle to Miss Piggy sheets  into high art. A meandering line through Kansas, Missouri and New York reveals a moral compass pointing to a shared American heartland ethic: Waste not. Improvise. Do what you love.

title: The Dawn Wall: El Capitans Most Unwelcoming Route
description: A graphic tracks an attempt by Tommy Caldwell and Kevin Jorgeson to free-climb the 3,000-foot Dawn Wall, a vertical sheet of mostly smooth granite that many believe is the hardest climb in the world.

title: Big City Book Club
description: The Big City Book Club returns for 2015, and were getting things rolling with Bernard Malamuds classic New York novel The Assistant. Set in Brooklyn in the 1950s, the novel has it all: the clash of immigrant cultures, the threats of modernization to old shopkeeping ways, crime and illicit love. Join us for the online discussion of the novel on Thursday, Feb. 12, at 6:30 p.m. on The New York Timess City Room blog.

title: Maher Hathout, a Powerful Voice for American Muslims, Dies at 79
description: Dr. Maher Hathout, an Egyptian-born cardiologist who became an influential American Muslim leader, preaching interfaith comity and helping to sustain the Muslim faithful in the United States against the backlash after the Sept. 11 attacks, died on Jan. 3 in Duarte, Calif. He was 79.

title: With Fans in Tow, Islanders Edge Devils to Land in First
description: NEWARK  At the midway point of their farewell season at Nassau Coliseum, the Islanders have surprisingly entrenched themselves as a contender for the Metropolitan Division title.

title: Dallas Cowboys at Green Bay Packers: Sundays N.F.C. Divisional-Round Matchup
description: Cowboys at Packers

title: Indianapolis Colts at Denver Broncos: Sundays A.F.C. Divisional-Round Matchup
description: Colts at Broncos

title: Whats on TV Saturday
description: 9 P.M. (CUNY) ONE DAY YOULL UNDERSTAND (2008) As the 1987 trial of the Nazi war criminal Klaus Barbie unfolds on television, a Frenchman, Victor Bastien (Hippolyte Girardot), pores over old family documents and finds an Aryan declaration written by his deceased father  a discovery that upends his concept of his history. His mother, Rivka (Jeanne Moreau), a Jewish woman living an elegant life, evades Victors questions. Rivkas embrace of that life can look like a form of denial, but as Ms. Moreaus performance unfolds, the characters courage and resilience emerge more pointedly into view, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this meditation on memory, identity and reconciliation from the Israeli director Amos Gitai based on a book by Jrme Clment. She gives a master class in how to be regal without vanity and how to use the hard-won charisma of a movie star to illuminate the dignity of an ordinary person. The film contains no great revelations or surprises, but rather is suffused with a quiet glow of sympathy and enlightenment, he added.

title: Dawn Wall: El Capitans Most Unwelcoming Route
description: Tommy Caldwell and Kevin Jorgeson are trying to free-climb the 3,000-foot Dawn Wall, a vertical sheet of mostly smooth granite that many believe is the most difficult climb in the world.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: The G.O.P. said Obamanomics would kill the economy. It didnt. Now what?

title: Corrections: January 10, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: Haiti: Judge Throws Out Cholera Suit Against U.N.
description: A federal judge in Manhattan dealt a set back on Friday to victims of Haitis cholera epidemic who have been seeking to hold the United Nations responsible. Judge J. Paul Oetken dismissed a class-action lawsuit by Haitians against the United Nations, deeming the organization immune because of treaties. Lawyers for the plaintiffs vowed to appeal. The courts decision implies that the U.N. can operate with impunity, said Beatrice Lindstrom, a lawyer with the Institute for Justice and Democracy in Haiti, which helped file the lawsuit in October 2013. Two other lawsuits filed by Haitian cholera victims are still pending in American courts. The cholera epidemic, which has killed 8,700 people in Haiti since 2010, has been traced to infected United Nations peacekeepers who were then assigned to the country.

title: French Premier Declares War on Radical Islam as Paris Girds for Rally
description: PARIS  Prime Minister Manuel Valls declared Saturday that France was at war with radical Islam after the harrowing sieges that led to the deaths of three gunmen and four hostages the day before. New details emerged about the bloody final confrontations, and security forces remained on high alert.

title: AirAsia Jets Tail Retrieved; Data Recorders Still Missing
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  An Indonesian search team on Saturday pulled the tail section of the AirAsia plane that crashed last month from the Java Sea, but the aircrafts data recorders were not inside, officials said.

title: Private Rocket Fails to Stick the Landing
description: An unmanned rocket carrying equipment and supplies for the International Space Station reached orbit on Saturday morning, but an audacious attempt to land the rockets first stage on a floating platform in the Atlantic Ocean was unsuccessful.

title: Lou Dalton: Fall 2015 Menswear
description: London

title: Police Search for Escaped Suspect as Victims of Attack Are Mourned
description: On Saturday, people left bouquets of flowers at the supermarket in eastern Paris where four hostages were killed by a gunman the day before.

title: South Korea Deports American Over Warm Words for Trips to North
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A South Korean-born American citizen who has spoken warmly about her trips to North Korea in public appearances and articles was deported from South Korea on Saturday, after an outcry from conservatives who accused her of sympathizing with the North Korean government.

title: Deflation As Betrayal
description: Ambrose Evans-Pritchard writes that Europes slide toward deflation amounts to a betrayal of Southern Europe. This sounds over the top, but it is the simple truth. So let me elaborate with a picture I find illuminating.

title: Astrid Andersen: Fall 2015 Menswear
description: London

title: How to Make Yourself Go to the Gym
description: If youre like a lot of Americans, one of your New Years resolutions is to work out more. If youre like a lot of Americans, youll join a gym this January as part of that plan. And if youre like a lot of Americans, you wont go very much.

title: Marla Malcolm Becks Three Keys to Hiring: Skill, Will and Fit
description: This interview with  Marla Malcolm Beck, chief executive of Bluemercury, a beauty products and spa services retailer, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: The Depressions Unheeded Lessons
description: The global economy stood on the precipice, making the possibility of a descent into the horrors of the Great Depression  the despair our grandparents told us about  all too real. Then some brave leaders with a knowledge of history and names like Bernanke, Geithner and Paulson (or if you have an international bent, Trichet, King and Darling) stepped in, applied the lessons of that brutal period and pulled us back from the abyss.

title: When the Parking Space Becomes a Park
description: The three parking spots on the street directly in front of Tonys Pizza Napoletana, in the North Beach neighborhood of San Francisco, have been the site of a rap-music video, poetry readings, a fashion photo shoot and jazz mini-concerts.

title: Watching Their Every Step
description: Stacy Steffen, 31, is a biomechanist at the Brooks Running Company in Seattle.

title: Staying Up to Speed
description: Michelle Kumbier is senior vice president for motorcycle operations at the Harley-Davidson Motor Company, Milwaukee.

title: Orthodoxy, Heterodoxy, and Ideology
description: Many economists responded badly to the economic crisis. And theres a lot wrong with mainstream economic analysis. But how closely are these two assertions related? Not as much as you might think. So Im very much in accord with Simon Wren-Lewis on the remarkable unhelpfulness of recent heterodox assaults on the field. Not that theres anything wrong with being heterodox in general; but a lot of what weve been seeing misidentifies the problem, and if anything gives aid and comfort to the wrong people.

title: Kicking Dodd-Frank in the Teeth
description: The 114th Congress has been at work for less than a week, but a goal for many of its members is already evident: a further rollback of regulations put in place to keep markets and Main Street safe from reckless Wall Street practices.

title: 1890: Canonization of Jeanne dArc
description: The cause for the canonization of Jeanne dArc will, as soon as the documents relating to her life are ready, be discussed by the Cardinals belonging to the Sacred Congregation of Rites. Every minute particular relating to her life is being looked into with the greatest care by Mgr. Caprara, a learned advocate, who is employed by the Vatican always in matters concerning beatifications and canonizations.

title: Dialect Society Names Its Word of the Year: #blacklivesmatter
description: The American Dialect Society has overwhelmingly voted to name #blacklivesmatter its word of the year for 2014, marking the first time that the group has chosen a Twitter hashtag in its annual vote.

title: Writing Off the Warhol Next Door
description: The Brant Foundation Art Study Center  a picturesque gallery space inside a converted 1902 stone barn  is just down the road from the Greenwich, Conn., estate of its creator, Peter M. Brant, the newsprint magnate and avid art collector. There are no identifying signs for the center, whether at the turnoff on North Street, at the security gate or on the building itself, though the location is known to the art-world cognoscenti and celebrities who attend the twice-a-year gala openings, held at the private polo club next door that Mr. Brant also founded. Visits to the center itself are by appointment only.

title: Agi & Sam: Fall 2015 Menswear
description: London

title: Dealing With Hyperactive Upstairs Neighbors
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Should Schools Teach Personality?
description: Self-control, curiosity, grit  these qualities may seem more personal than academic, but at some schools, theyre now part of the regular curriculum. Some researchers say personality could be even more important than intelligence when it comes to students success in school. But critics worry that the increasing focus on qualities like grit will distract policy makers fromproblems with schools.

title: After Terrorist Attacks, Many French Muslims Wonder: What Now?
description: PARIS  Last weeks terrorist attacks without doubt set all of France on edge, but the sense of wariness, even siege, has grown increasingly profound among Frances Muslim population  the largest in Europe  which seems braced for a potential backlash, both political and personal.

title: When Satire Cuts Both Ways
Race, the Police and the Propaganda
description: WELCOME visitors to New York City! This has been the best time ever to urinate on a street, sneak onto the subway or run a red light, for the police force has been on a virtual strike.

title: Variety: A Childish Acrostic
description: VARIETY  I need to brush up on my vocabulary. Did this acrostic make you feel that way?

title: Moshe Safdie
description: Moshe Safdie is an Israeli-born architect and protg of Louis Kahns whose modernist designs emphasize locale, geography and culture.

title: Your God and My Dignity
description: IVE been called many unpleasant things in my life, and Ive deserved no small number of them. But I chafe at this latest label:

title: The Backlash Against African Women
description: JOHANNESBURG  A FEW weeks ago, as I was leaving my office, I stopped at a traffic light and watched a young woman cross the street in front of me. She wore a pair of jean shorts cut fashionably high, and I could see the crease of her left buttock extend each time she took a step. She wouldnt have been out of place in London or New York or Tokyo. Except that this was Johannesburg, the biggest city in a country known for its high levels of violence against women. As I pulled away, I worried that she might be assaulted.

title: Obama to Announce Cybersecurity Plans in State of the Union Preview
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will announce new initiatives next week designed to bolster online security and improve access to cyberspace, White House officials said Saturday.

title: Is the War Crimes Court Still Relevant?
description: UNITED NATIONS  Fatou Bensouda, chief prosecutor for the International Criminal Court, is about to face her toughest trial yet: to demonstrate that the court has enough muscle to tackle the gravest human rights cases, even if it means confronting the worlds most powerful countries.

title: Old Nazis Never Die
description: AS the decades roll by, there are fewer and fewer Nazi war criminals left alive to track down. Which made the recent reports suggesting that Alois Brunner, the top lieutenant to Adolf Eichmann, may have died as recently as a few years ago in his late 90s all the more surprising.

title: In New Era of Terrorism, Voice From Yemen Echoes
description: For more than five years now, as Western terrorism investigators have searched for critical influences behind the latest jihadist plot, one name has surfaced again and again.

title: When Will the North Face Its Racism?
description: ATLANTA  THE groundswell of protests over police brutality in the closing days of 2014, when people dropped to the marble floor of Grand Central Terminal and shut down the Brooklyn Bridge, blocked Lake Shore Drive in Chicago and chanted I Cant Breathe from Boston to Oakland, summoned ghosts not only of the marches of the civil rights era but of the larger forces that led to the arrival of so many African-Americans in the big cities of the North and West in the first place.

title: North Korea Offers U.S. Deal to Halt Nuclear Test
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said Saturday that it had told the United States that it would impose a temporary moratorium on nuclear tests if Washington canceled its joint annual military exercises with South Korea to help promote dialogue on the divided Korean Peninsula.

title: Getting Grief Right
description: By the time Mary came to see me, six months after losing her daughter to sudden infant death syndrome, she had hired and fired two other therapists. She was trying to get her grief right.

title: Saving the Nuclear Deal With Iran
description: Twice recently, Irans president, Hassan Rouhani, has acted boldly in support of his biggest political gamble, pursuit of a nuclear agreement with the major powers. In a speech last Sunday on Irans troubled economy, he argued that Iran will never enjoy sustained growth if it is isolated from the rest of the world. Three weeks earlier, he made clear that he would confront Irans hard-liners in his efforts to clinch a deal in which Iran would agree never to produce a nuclear weapon in return for the lifting of crippling international sanctions.

title: Raise the Gas Tax to Fix Americas Roads
description: Gasoline prices have fallen more than 40 percent since the end of June thanks to the collapse of global oil prices. That makes this the perfect time for Congress to overcome its longstanding terror of offending the nations motorists and raise the tax on gasoline and diesel fuel. The results could only be beneficial: for the nations roads, bridges and transit systems, which badly need repair; for the budget; and, to the extent that higher taxes encourage greater fuel efficiency, for the climate.

title: Gun Rights, From Holsters to Bras
description: For all the clichs about pistol-packing Texas, the state is one of the few that has not yet succumbed to the gun lobbys big push to let citizens carry handguns at the hip wherever they go. That may be about to change as the State Legislature convenes next week with open carry a top priority of the Republican majority and with Governor-elect Greg Abbott pledging to sign it into law. The result could produce a far from reassuring civic tableau if even a modest number of the 800,000 Texans who have concealed-carry licenses choose to strap their weapons on in public.

title: Team Has Golden Moments but Lacks a Halo in Bronze
description: Tim Mead was 12 years old when his family moved from Virginia to California. The family drove, arriving at its new home in Highland ahead of its furniture. Mead, who had brought a transistor radio, sat on the floor of his familys new kitchen, turned the dial and found an Angels game. He was hooked on a team not much younger than he was.

title: In Illinois, New Governors Campaign Promises Are About to Meet Budget Realities
description: CHICAGO  As Bruce Rauner swept out the Democratic governor of this Democratic-leaning state, he made one absolute pledge: He would shake up Illinois. Mr. Rauner, a multimillionaire who has never held elective office, said the state needed, at long last, to put its finances in order. He has said the state ought to lower income taxes, reduce regulations on businesses and devote more money to education.

title: The Deano Chronicles, Continued
description: KISSING the sun. Swilling merlot. Plotting revenge.

title: France, the Crucible of Europe
description: THE France that endured a vicious terrorist attack last week is a France that has suffered, for decades and centuries, from anxieties about its own decline. And for good reason: Since the 18th century, when it bestrode Europe and seemed poised to dominate the globe, France has seen its relative power diminish, suffering defeats and humiliations at the hands of rival forces, from Britains navies to Germanys jackboots to the invading might of American popular culture.

title: In the Era of N.F.L. Blackouts, Giants Nation Put Its Lead Foot Down
description: One day in late October 1962, when the Giants were playing the Washington Redskins at Yankee Stadium, 500 fans were watching the game at a motel in Stratford, Conn.

title: Seizing Assets in Crimea, From Shipyard to Film Studio
description: YALTA, Crimea  In the scramble for Crimeas spoils, armed forces have raided myriad enterprises across the peninsula, expelling the owners and claiming the property for the Crimean government.

title: College Football Is Powerful: The Proof Is in the Alcohol
description: Spectators at the mens basketball Final Four last April at AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Tex., could buy burgers, sodas and even Texas-shaped waffles. But they could not buy alcohol. The N.C.A.A. does not permit alcohol sales  or even its advertising  at the 89 championships it administers.

title: This Time, Forecast in Green Bay Is a Balmy 20 Degrees
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  The N.F.L. loves to trumpet that its players can overcome anything, including subzero temperatures and howling winds. So it is no surprise that the divisional playoff game between the Packers and Cowboys here has been called Ice Bowl II, a reference to the last time these teams met at Lambeau Field in the postseason in 1967.

title: An Uneasy Mix of News and Opinion
description: RACHEL SWARNS feels free to use the word I in her weekly column, The Working Life. But as a longtime news reporter, who made the transition to columnist about a year ago, she prefers to tell other peoples stories, not her own.

title: Hearing Is Believing
description: THE thriller writer Jeffery Deaver has released an original work called The Starling Project as an audiobook  only its not what we think of as an audiobook: a printed book read aloud that you can listen to on your laptop or phone. Featuring 29 actors in more than 80 speaking roles combined with state-of-the-art sound and music design, Mr. Deavers book was conceived as an audio drama for Audible. There are no plans to turn it into a traditional text-based book, either on paper or digitally.

title: America, Falling Short
description: Readers discuss whether America should adopt European-style policies for caring for the populace.

title: In Nigeria, New Boko Haram Suicide Bomber Tactic: Its a Little Girl
description: DAKAR, Senegal  A girl perhaps no more than 10 years old detonated powerful explosives concealed under her veil at a crowded northern Nigeria market on Saturday, killing as many as 20 people and wounding many more.

title: Health-Law Suit Hints at G.O.P. Divide
description: WASHINGTON  After President Obamas Affordable Care Act was enacted in 2010, Republicans at both the state and federal levels seemed to speak with one voice in flatly rejecting it.

title: For Jeb Bush, Evolving Views Over 2 Decades
description: Jeb Bush once called for building prisons and emphasizing punishment over therapy for juvenile offenders. Today, he supports reforming the criminal justice system, arguing that incarceration can harden low-level lawbreakers into career criminals.

title: Christopher Raeburn: Fall 2015 Menswear
description: London

title: What Were Watching: Sunday Shows
description: Terror gripped France after gunmen attacked a satirical newspaper office and held hostages at a kosher supermarket, leaving at least 20 dead, including the three terrorists.

title: Where Are The Friedmans Of Yesteryear?
description: I never got around to commenting on the infamous Economist list of influential economists; theyve been given plenty of deserved grief, to which I neednt add. But I think I might have something useful to say about a fact that is really unmistakable when you look at a list corrected by removing central bankers, or make a more subjective judgment: these days, the economist as public intellectual is overwhelmingly likely to be a liberal.

title: In Baltimore, Fighting an Incinerator
description: Students from Benjamin Franklin high school in Baltimore, Md., are fighting the construction of a proposed waste-to-energy incinerator plant in their already highly toxic neighborhood, Curtis Bay.

title: George Zimmerman Is Charged With Assault in Florida
description: George Zimmerman, who was acquitted less than two years ago in the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager, was arrested in Florida on Friday night and charged with aggravated assault, officials said.

title: Gophers Lose a Leader but Find a New Resolve
description: MINNEAPOLIS  The Minnesota players watched Rachel Banham, their leader, collapse in pain during a Dec. 10 game at North Dakota. But Coach Marlene Stollings missed it. Stollings had turned to say something to one of her reserves while Banham, a senior guard and the preseason pick as Big Ten player of the year, drove to the basket.

title: Garbage Incinerators Make Comeback, Kindling Both Garbage and Debate
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  Rising from a denuded landscape not far from this areas famed beaches, the nations first new commercial garbage incinerator in 20 years is about to be fired up, ready to blast up to 3,000 tons of trash a day into electricity for thousands of houses.

title: Ohio State Receiver Capitalizes on Skills Transferable Across Two Sports
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  On a Sunday night in late November, Ohio State wide receiver Devin Smith, like millions of other Americans, was watching Sunday Night Football when the Giants Odell Beckham Jr. made a leaping, one-handed catch for a touchdown against the Dallas Cowboys.

title: New Courts Offer Pakistans Generals the Power They Used to Seize
description: LONDON  After Taliban gunmen massacred dozens of schoolchildren in Peshawar last month, Pakistans two most powerful men convened an emergency meeting at army headquarters. Their body language, captured in a government-released photo, was revealing: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif looked glum and ill at ease, while the man beside him, Gen. Raheel Sharif, the army chief, lectured confidently.

title: Sibling: Fall 2015 Menswear
description: London

title: When Art Is Dangerous (or Not)
description: THE only time art ever seems to make news here in the West anymore is when a Pollock or Warhol sells for a sum commensurate with the budget of a Transformers film. It seems bizarre, then, to find ourselves grappling with international crises in which art is the issue: the imbroglio involving the Sony movie The Interview, the massacre at Charlie Hebdo in Paris. The incomprehension, whether bemused or horrified, that we feel toward people who take up arms against the creators of cartoons or comedies is a chastening reminder that there are still cultures in which art is not a harmless diversion or commodity, but something real and volatile, a potential threat to be violently suppressed. These attacks are, in a way, a savage, atavistic show of respect.

title: Phil Jackson Takes Blame Before Yet Another Knicks Loss
description: This is a mea culpa, Phil Jackson said, his tall frame leaning slightly against a lectern Saturday. In 30 minutes, his hapless Knicks were due to tip off against the Charlotte Hornets. Jackson had lost sleep, he said, and it was evident. He wore a black suit and a black-and-gray tie, but none of the 13 N.B.A. championship rings he had won over the years.

title: Buckeyes Are Beloved in Oregon (Not That One)
description: Michael J. Seferian is the mayor of Oregon, Ohio.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Tough Climb Has Its Comforts

title: Broncos Have a Void Thats Difficult to Fill
description: ENGLEWOOD, Colo.  The Denver Broncos are like the perky family whose holiday card is the picture of beatitude. Outwardly, it looks as if all is well. What others fail to see, but what is glaring to the Broncos, is the shadow darkening this seasons group portrait.

title: Jeff Golub, a Guitarist at Home in Several Genres, Dies at 59
description: Jeff Golub, a guitarist who worked with rock stars like Rod Stewart and Billy Squier and for the last two decades had a successful genre-crossing solo career, died on Jan. 1 at his home in Manhattan. He was 59.

title: Two Ducks Are Out After Positive Drug Tests
description: DALLAS  Oregon Coach Mark Helfrich said Saturday that wide receiver Darren Carrington and running back Ayele Forde would not play in Monday nights College Football Playoff championship game against Ohio State after positive drug tests, a violation of N.C.A.A. rules.

title: Carl N. Degler, Scholarly Champion of the Oppressed in America, Dies at 93
description: For four decades, as a Stanford University scholar, a Pulitzer Prize-winning author and a commentator who envisioned a future that did not repeat the mistakes of the past, Carl N. Degler endeavored to remedy American myopia.

title: Cleveland Reaches for the Unteachable
description: Red Auerbach won nine N.B.A. titles as coach of the Boston Celtics and seven more as an executive. He was known for, among other things, lighting victory cigars and having an aversion to cheerleaders. One of his most enduring quotations referred to virtually any player who stands 7 feet or taller: You cant teach height.

title: Personal Statements
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  You might have noticed that there is a style rule here at The New York Times that says that even a name that ends with the letter S must have an apostrophe-S if it is possessive, as opposed to just the apostrophe. Its not something I did naturally when I was hired but, like most things in life, I adjusted and now I apostrophe-S my S-ending names like a boss. That will come in handy with todays puzzle by Peter A. Collins.

title: Elevating the Humble Bird
description: Rotisserie chicken has become something of a food-world darling over the last few years, with renowned chefs like Marcus Samuelsson taking an interest in the once-humble weeknight dinner staple. Some trendy restaurants are even stuffing their birds with foie gras.

title: Triangle Offense Baffles a Second Group of Lowly and Anemic Knicks
description: WHITE PLAINS  Although the Knicks trailed by 18 late in the second quarter, with nine turnovers by the time they hit their first nine field goals, nobody at Westchester County Center on Friday seemed ready to boo, or storm out, or don a paper bag mask in mock protest, a common gesture these days at Madison Square Garden.

title: Muslim Employee of Kosher Market in Paris Praised for Hiding Customers From Gunman
description: As the authorities in France worked on Saturday to piece together the sequence of events at a kosher supermarket in Paris where a gunman and four hostages were killed on Friday, there was an outpouring of praise online for a young employee credited with saving the lives of some customers by hiding them in a cold-storage room.

title: In Jerry Jones, Dallas Cowboys Have a Lightning Rod Made of Mettle
description: IRVING, Tex.  It was 72 hours after the Dallas Cowboys had won a thrilling playoff game against the Detroit Lions, and Jerry Jones, the teams owner, president, general manager and chief cheerleader, was beaming. Tired, but beaming.

title: No Moon Suits, Just Trunks and the Healing Surf
description: BUREH BEACH, Sierra Leone  There is at least one place in this country, along a quiet, palm-fringed cove, where nobody is talking about viral loads or death rates, treatment centers or protective suits.

title: Jihadists and Supporters Take to Social Media to Praise Attack on Charlie Hebdo
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Within hours of the deadly attack on the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo, Islamic extremists and their supporters were praising the killings and lauding the attackers on social media under hashtags like #we_avenged_the_prophet and #lone_wolves.

title: Patients Seek Right to Try New Drugs
description: LYONS, Colo.  Since May, a string of states have passed laws that give critically ill patients the right to try medications that have not been approved by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Ex-Leaders Trial Details Union Coercion
description: PHILADELPHIA  A former union boss is fighting accusations that he led a campaign of violence, extortion and vandalism at local construction sites in an effort to force nonunion contractors to hire his members.

title: Warning: That Tan Could Be Hazardous
description: TEQUESTA, Fla.  On their way home from an SAT tutoring session, the Van Dresser twins, Alexandra and Samantha, 17, popped into Tan Fever & Spa, a small family-owned salon tucked into a strip mall between a bar and a supermarket.

title: French Police Say Suspect in Attack Evolved From Petty Criminal to Terrorist
description: PARIS  When French police raided the home of Amedy Coulibaly, a suspected Islamic extremist, in May 2010, they found his computer crammed with religious texts, holiday pictures of himself with a veiled female companion and photographs of a pedo-pornographic character, according to an official record of the search. They also found 240 gun cartridges for a Kalashnikov automatic rifle.

title: Receivers Pass Does Trick for Patriots
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Pro football plays in the modern era usually have lengthy, byzantine names designed to make them almost incomprehensible to anyone outside the team. But the play that turned around the A.F.C. divisional playoff game between the Baltimore Ravens and the New England Patriots on Saturday was just the opposite.

title: Turning His Life Around to Gain Custody of His Child
description: The seventh birthday of Jada Rodriguez  queen of their block in the West Bronx, her father, David, said  was always going to be a princess party.

title: The JetsChris Johnson Is Arrested
description: Jets running back Chris Johnson was arrested Friday in Orlando, Fla., on misdemeanor weapons charges, the police said. Johnson was charged with open carrying of weapons/firearms, a second-degree misdemeanor in Florida.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: When youre inside the water, you shouldnt be thinking about anything, not Ebola, not nothing, just the waves.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 10, 2015
Robert Stone, Novelist of the Vietnam Era and Beyond, Dies at 77
description: Robert Stone, who wrote ambitious, award-winning novels about errant Americans in dangerous circumstances or on existential quests  or both  as commentary on an unruly, wayward nation in the Vietnam era and beyond, died on Saturday at his home in Key West, Fla. He was 77.

title: A Sigh of Relief as the Ravens Fade From View
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Here on the dark side of the A.F.C. postseason draw, the New England Patriots gave Roger Goodell, the N.F.L. commissioner, what he most needed and presumably wanted as he shivered in the stands Saturday evening at a frigid Gillette Stadium among the rabid riffraff.

title: Kerry Lays Groundwork for Obamas Visit to India
description: AHMEDABAD, India  Secretary of State John Kerry met with Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Sunday to promote economic ties with India and set the stage for President Obamas visit later this month.

title: Jacqueline Korenthal, Brian Swanson
description: Jacqueline Paige Korenthal and Brian Ober Swanson were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Roger Ross at the Pierre in New York.

title: Susan Tranbaugh and Jason Spinell
description: Susan Ridge Tranbaugh, a daughter of Margaret Husted Tranbaugh and Dr. Robert F. Tranbaugh of New York, was married Saturday to Jason Carlson Spinell, a son of Janet Carlson Spinell and Alfred B. Spinell Jr. of Avon, Conn. The Rev. Michael L. Lindvall, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the home of the brides parents.

title: Kelly West and Christopher Valentine
description: Kelly Ann West and Christopher Eric Valentine were married Thursday at Hoboken City Hall in New Jersey. James Farina, the Hoboken City Clerk, officiated.

title: Tanya Paz and Aaron Goldstein
description: Tanya Alejandra Paz and Aaron Nathan Goldstein were married on Saturday evening by Rabbi Susan Goldberg at the Wilshire Boulevard Temple in Los Angeles.

title: Rachel Jolly and Brian Janiak
description: Rachel Anne Jolly, a daughter of Susan J. Dissinger of Lake Mary, Fla., and Tom Jolly of North Bergen, N.J., was married Friday to Brian Michael Janiak, a son of Jane Gumley Janiak and Peter L. Janiak of Hilton Head Island, S.C. C. Vernon Malone, a marriage officer in Hope Town, the Bahamas, officiated at the Hummingbird Cottage Art Center there.

title: A Crush on the Homecoming Queen
description: Sara Alexandra Squire and Jason Brock Saunders were married Saturday evening at Dover Hall Estate in Richmond, Va. The Rev. Dr. Charles E. Brown, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Margaret Kurtzman and David Kantor
description: Margaret Beren Kurtzman and David Aaron Kantor were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Craig T. Scheff at the University Club in New York.

title: Jade Frampton and Samuel Homburger
description: Jade Petra Frampton, the daughter of Barbara A. Frampton of Bal Harbour, Fla., and the guitarist Peter Frampton of Nashville, was married Saturday evening to Samuel David Homburger, the son of Louise C. Homburger and Jeffrey E. Homburger of New York. Rabbi David Gelfand officiated at the Harold Pratt House, an event space in New York.

title: Candice Hebden, William Osnato
description: Candice Brooke Hebden and William Peter Osnato were married Saturday at the Sofitel Philadelphia hotel. The couple were joined under Pennsylvanias self-uniting marriage statute.

title: Risa Staszewski, Marc Zegen
description: Risa Levine Staszewski and Marc Joseph Zegen were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Alan B. Lucas at the Old Westbury Hebrew Congregation in Old Westbury, N.Y. Cantor Ofer Barnoy assisted.

title: Winning in a Runaway, Seattle Takes a Step Toward Another Title
description: SEATTLE  The chants of Seahawks, Seahawks cascaded from the stands at CenturyLink Field, where the playoffs returned on Saturday evening, and not a day too soon.

title: Yale Topples Harvard (Again) in Matchup at Garden
description: Yale picked up where it left off against Harvard, scoring twice in the first period on the way to a 4-1 victory at Madison Square Garden on Saturday.

title: London Mens Fashion Week: Lou Dalton Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

title: Whats on TV Sunday
description: 8 P.M. (NBC) THE 72ND ANNUAL GOLDEN GLOBE AWARDS Tina Fey and Amy Poehler host these awards  often considered predictors of the Oscars  sponsored by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association and broadcast live from the Beverly Hilton in Beverly Hills, Calif. In the motion picture drama division, the nominees for best picture are Boyhood, Foxcatcher, The Imitation Game, Selma and The Theory of Everything; for best actress, Jennifer Aniston, Felicity Jones, Julianne Moore, Rosamund Pike and Reese Witherspoon; and for best actor, Steve Carell, Benedict Cumberbatch, Jake Gyllenhaal, David Oyelowo and Eddie Redmayne. In the comedy or musical division, the nominees for best picture are Birdman, The Grand Budapest Hotel, Into the Woods, Pride and St. Vincent; for best actress, Amy Adams, Emily Blunt, Helen Mirren, Julianne Moore and Quvenzhan Wallis; and for best actor, Ralph Fiennes, Michael Keaton, Bill Murray, Joaquin Phoenix and Christoph Waltz. Awards will also be handed out for television work. Red carpet coverage begins at 7.

title: A Chronicler of an America Without a Path
description: Robert Stone was one of the few writers to capture the apocalyptic madness of America in the 1960s and 70s, as the country lurched deeper into the jungles of Vietnam and the counterculture party at home turned increasingly nihilistic, as Woodstock gave way to Altamont and as violence  propagated by the likes of both Charles Manson and the Weather Underground  rocked the home front.

title: Corrections: January 11, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Huge Show of Solidarity in Paris Against Terrorism
description: PARIS  More than a million people joined over 40 presidents and prime ministers on the streets of Paris on Sunday in the most striking show of solidarity in the West against the threat of Islamic extremism since the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: An Eternal Dilemma in the Golden Triangle
description: For more than 40 years, opium poppies have been cultivated and processed into heroin in the Golden Triangle, a mountainous area that straddles the borders of Myanmar, Laos and Thailand. Along with Afghanistan, it has supplied most of the worlds heroin.

title: J.W. Anderson: Fall 2015 Menswear
description: London

title: Coach and Public School Add a U.S. Flair to London Collections: Men
description: LONDON  New Years Eve is barely a faded memory by the time the January mens wear runway circuit grinds into gear. Christmas is still within spitting distance. For those whose job it is to make or follow mens clothing, who gather with back-to-school regularity, the post-holiday precipice is steep. When the troops gathered in London last week for the newly expanded London Collections: Men shows, many still sported tans.

title: Scores Killed After Bus Collides With Oil Tanker in Pakistan
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  At least 62 people were killed on Sunday when a passenger bus crashed into an oil tanker on the outskirts of Karachi.

title: Language Translation Tech Starts to Deliver on Its Promise
description: The tech industry is doing its best to topple the Tower of Babel.

title: Anita Ekberg, International Screen Beauty, Dies at 83
