description: Anita Ekberg, who became an international symbol of lush beauty and unbridled sensuality in the 1960 Federico Fellini film La Dolce Vita, died on Sunday in Rocca di Papa, southeast of Rome. She was 83.

title: Margaret Howell: Fall 2015 Menswear
description: London

title: Spying on College Life, via Yik Yak
description: Im a recovering helicopter parent with an only child who is now in college. The transition for her has been wonderful, almost seamless. For me, not so much.

title: James Long: Fall 2015 Menswear
description: London

title: London Mens Fashion Week: Lou Dalton Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

title: Antiterror Rally in Paris
description: Hundreds of thousands of people poured into the streets of Paris to join top French officials and world leaders for a rally and march.

title: Paris March Draws More Than 1 Million Into the Streets
description: More than one million people joined world leaders on the streets of Paris on Sunday for a rally and march under extraordinary security after a series of terrorist attacks in the city. Elsewhere in France, and around the world, hundreds of thousands of people showed their support for freedom of expression and to honor the 17 people killed last week in Paris.

title: 1915: Russian Columns Advancing Into Transylvania
description: PETROGRAD  Only skirmishing actions are reported in the latest official communiqus from the Polish and Caucasian fronts. Grand Duke Nicholas remains intentionally vague about the movements in Galicia and Bukowina. To-days [Jan. 11] statement from the Great General Staff says that on the left bank of the Vistula the Germans attempted yesterday and during the night to attack the Russian front at several points, but were repulsed by artillery fire. In an attack near the village of Sarnice, east of Skierniewice, the Germans reached the barbed wire protecting the Russian trenches and shouted: Dont fire on your own men! The Russians, however, failed to be taken in by this worn-out ruse and replied with a murderous fire and inflicted heavy losses on the enemy. The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 12, 1915

title: London Mens Fashion Week: Fashion East Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

title: Unity March in Paris
description: Hundreds of thousands of people poured into the streets of Paris to join top French officials and world leaders in a government-sponsored show of unity.

title: Rex Ryan Is Close to a Deal to Coach the Bills, the Jets A.F.C. East Rival
description: Rex Ryan, the outspoken coach who was fired by the Jets after a six-year tenure of extreme highs and lows, was close to a deal Sunday night to take over as coach of the A.F.C. East rival Buffalo Bills.

title: London Mens Fashion Week: Matthew Miller Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

title: London Mens Fashion Week: Matthew Miller Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

title: Video Shows a Paris Gunman Declaring His Loyalty to the Islamic State
description: PARIS  Amedy Coulibaly, one of three gunmen killed by the police on Friday after carrying out Frances worst terrorist attacks in more than half a century, spoke from the grave on Sunday in a slickly produced video, declaring allegiance to the Islamic State militant group, describing his role in what he called a coordinated offensive to defend Islam, and urging young French Muslims to take up the fight.

title: Deaths of East Harlems Cultural Leaders Put a Legacy in Flux
description: The strains of Ave Maria resounded through the pristine East Harlem community room where Fernando Salicrup lay in state on Tuesday night. A huge Puerto Rican flag hung behind his open coffin, a reminder that Mr. Salicrup  an artist and activist  had helped to carve out a cultural space that defined Puerto Ricans in New York City.

title: Moschino: Fall 2015 Menswear
description: London

title: Scenes From Paris Rally Against Violence
description: More than a million people marched in Paris to honor victims of the deadly attacks on the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo and on a kosher supermarket.

title: Taken 3 Tops Box Office
description: The weekend box office provided a primer on why Hollywood spends more time pumping out sequels than it does attempting to make meaty, well-reviewed original movies. Taken 3, starring Liam Neeson and receiving a paltry 12 percent positive score on the review-aggregation site RottenTomatoes, was a huge No. 1 at North American multiplexes, taking in an estimated $40.4 million  one of the best opening results on record for January.

title: Pringle of Scotland: Fall 2015 Menswear
description: London

title: Victims of the Terror Attacks in Paris
description: Among the 12 people who were killed in the attack Wednesday on the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo were cartoonists, a proofreader, a maintenance worker and two police officers. A police officer was killed the next day in a Paris suburb, and four hostages were killed at a kosher supermarket in eastern Paris on Friday.

title: Five People Shot Outside Chris Brown Concert in California
description: Five people were shot early Sunday morning near a California nightclub where the singer Chris Brown was performing, The San Jose Mercury News reported.

description: London

title: Shire to Buy NPS Pharmaceuticals for $5.2 Billion
description: The Irish drug maker Shire has agreed to acquire NPS Pharmaceuticals for $5.2 billion, a deal that will allow it to move on from its botched sale to AbbVie last year.

title: KTZ: Fall 2015 Menswear
description: London

title: 1965: New U.S. Effort to Cut Cigarette Smoking Urged
description: WASHINGTON  Surgeon General Luther L. Terry called today [Jan. 11] for a new national effort to convince people of the danger of cigarette smoking. Dr. Terry made the appeal on the first anniversary of his advisory committees report that cigarette smoking could cause lung cancer and other diseases.

description: London

title: Hereeeees Ikechukwu! (Complete With Sidekick and Fake Cityscape)
description: Maybe some things that happen in Brooklyn should stay in Brooklyn. And before you assail me for my highfalutin Manhattan attitude, admit that we now have a reverse-snobbery situation, where Brooklyn dwellers sniff in umbrage at the interlopers who clog the L train in a frantic clamor to visit the latest white-hot restaurant in Williamsburg.

title: A Bruising Love Throbs Anew
description: A glamorously tarnished rock goddess, Courtney Love, plays an elusive muse named after the deity Athena in Kansas City Choir Boy, a music-theater piece by Todd Almond being presented as part of the Prototype festival of new opera and musical theater. Ms. Love, looking trim and intense, her long blond hair caught in a tangled ponytail, portrays the onetime love of a dream-bound musician in Mr. Almonds dramatically blurry but musically inviting work, which is being presented in a small underground space at HERE Arts Center.

title: Crouched Behind a Barricade, Until a Crude Stranger Barges In
description: The first novel by the filmmaker and artist Miranda July is like one of those strange mythological creatures that are part one thing, part another  a griffin or a chimera, perhaps, or a sphinx. The novel starts off tentatively, veers into derivative and willfully sensational theater-of-the-absurd drama  part Pinter, part Genet  and then mutates, miraculously, into an immensely moving portrait of motherhood and what it means to take care of a child.

title: European Central Bank Policy Makers Remain Divided on Bond Purchases
description: FRANKFURT  Top officials of the European Central Bank offered dueling views over the weekend on how to deal with the risk of a downward price spiral in the eurozone, a sign that internal debate continues ahead of a crucial meeting next week.

title: Casely-Hayford: Fall 2015 Menswear
description: London

title: Winter Jazzfest 2015
description: Scenes from the annual music festival.

title: A Canvas for Mystery and Unabashed Lewdness
description: For those who think American Realness 2015, a festival of dance and performance, is about promoting one kind of art, two recent shows, seen Friday at Abrons Arts Center, presented two sides of contemporary choreography. One was by a brash young duo from Europe; the other, an experienced New York formalist.

title: Dryly Shattering Taboos
description: The American Realness festival can be a cliquish affair in which the performers seem to be interested mainly in one another. But with the participation of the Bulgarian-born provocateur Ivo Dimchev, this genre-crossing series has at least acquired a saving sense of humor about itself.

title: For Cowboys, Its Overturned and Out
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  By all accounts, Cowboys quarterback Tony Romo threw a perfect, arcing pass on a fourth down with the game on the line. Dallass star receiver, Dez Bryant, leapt high in the air and made a fabulous grab, landing a yard short of the goal line.

title: Kravitz to Join  Super Bowl Show
description: The Grammy award-winning artist Lenny Kravitz will join Katy Perry (both above) at the Super Bowl halftime show. Ms. Perry made the announcement on Saturday during NBCs broadcast of the playoff game between the New England Patriots and Baltimore Ravens. My first special guest is going to be an incredible rock n roll icon, a guitar god, Ms. Perry said, adding that other artists would be added. Hes going to make me so much cooler that day, she said. The Super Bowl takes place on Feb. 1 in Glendale, Ariz. Ms. Perry, 30, is currently on a world tour in support of her 2013 album, Prism. Mr. Kravitz, 50, will begin the second leg of his international Strut tour in March.

title: $5 Million to Benefit New York Dance
description: The Harkness Foundation for Dance announced on Sunday that it would distribute $5 million in grants over the next decade to five organizations that support dance. The recipients are the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the Joyce Theater, City Center, the 92nd Street Y and the NYU Langone Medical Centers Hospital for Joint Diseases, which houses the Harkness Center for Dance Injuries. Each organization will receive $1 million, making this the foundations largest grant to date. Plans for the funding include support for dance presentation at the academy; a new performance series at the Joyce; renovations at City Center; a new residency program at the 92Y; a new boardroom at the Hospital for Joint Diseases; and the development of online courses about dance injuries and treatment.

title: A Standout at the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional
description: The Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional took place in New York City from Dec. 26 through 30.

title: Sanctions on North Korea
description: Things are heating up.

title: Golden Globes: From the Red Carpet
description: Cara Buckley reports from the red carpet of the Golden Globes.

title: When Ordinary Words Sprout Wings and Fly
description: Words seem to be plucked from the air, with great care and wonder, in Reread Another, a charming palate-teaser of an opener for the Target Margin Theaters season devoted to the writings of Gertrude Stein at the Bushwick Starr in Brooklyn. They are simple words, said with savor and, occasionally, apprehension.

title: Egyptian Authorities Release a Morsi Adviser
description: CAIRO  Egyptian authorities on Sunday released, for the first time, one of the advisers to ousted President Mohamed Morsi who were detained with him at the time of the military takeover on July 3, 2013.

title: French Gunman Speaks
description: The French police confirmed that this is Amedy Coulibaly, one of three men suspected in the deadly terrorist attacks in Paris.

title: Highly Confident in His Own Catalog
description: At around 3 in the morning on Saturday, near the end of Robin Schulzs 90-minute set at Webster Hall, he looked, more or less, like the archetypical superstar D.J. aspirant. He had stepped out from behind his turntable setup to assess the crowd. There was a video camera attached to an elaborate contraption that dangled it in front of his face. He was holding a bottle of champagne. A cluster of red balloons dropped from the ceiling, and he perfunctorily sprayed the champagne out over the crowd.

title: Reaction to Dez Bryant Call Includes Plenty of Head Shaking
description: A controversial call in an N.F.L. game can certainly get Twitter buzzing. Sundays replay reversal on a seemingly key catch in the Dallas-Green Bay game by the Cowboys Dez Bryant was no exception, as people inside and outside the game were left questioning the rules governing pass receptions.

title: A Sense of Frenetic Energy in a Hardscrabble World
description: Maybe the code-orange, brain-overload feeling produced by the Winter Jazzfest, this year in particular, can be explained by a formula.

title: Striding Back Into the Limelight With Heady, Hip-Swiveling Glee
description: Neneh Cherry had international hits in the late 1980s and early 1990s, when she was a sassy young woman in her 20s, immersed in Londons overlapping post-punk, hip-hop and club cultures. She fused them in songs like Buffalo Stance, in 1988, rapping and singing about pimping, poverty, dancing and love. Now 50, she was just as bold in her New York City solo debut on Friday night at the Highline Ballroom. Its kind of a deep thing that this is actually at last happening, she said. Its about the now, right here, right now.

title: Reweaving a Tapestry From Charpentiers Threads
description: The French Baroque composer Marc-Antoine Charpentier never wrote an elaborate choral work in the manner of Monteverdis 90-minute Vespro della Beata Vergine. But that has not stopped Scott Metcalfe, the early-music violinist and music director of the Green Mountain Project, from piecing together a Vespers score on Charpentiers behalf.

title: Who Is Solving This Puzzle
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  Ah, thats better. Theres nothing like a nice, easy, smooth Monday to restore ones sense of puzzle-solving self-worth.

title: Catch Is Ruled a Bobble as Dallass Good Fortune Turns to Agony
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  More than three decades ago, the Dallas Cowboys lost an N.F.C. championship game to the San Francisco 49ers because of a 6-yard touchdown pass from Joe Montana to Dwight Clark that has become known as the Catch.

title: Justice Department Declassifies 2012 Inspector General Report on FBI Activities Under the FISA Amendments Act of 2008
description: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit by The New York Times, the Justice Department has partially declassified this report about the F.B.I.s involvement in administering the warrantless surveillance program authorized by the FISA Amendments Act. When the report was completed in September 2012, it was entirely classified.

title: F.B.I. Is Broadening Surveillance Role, Report Shows
description: WASHINGTON  Although the governments warrantless surveillance program is associated with the National Security Agency, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has gradually become a significant player in administering it, a newly declassified report shows.

title: Deal Makers Invade CES, the Land of Geeks

title: A Swarm in Dead City
description: I was 14 and desolate, living in a place so unlike the vibrant home Id left behind that I named it Dead City. Determined to return to civilization, I planned to hitchhike to OHare Airport and buy a ticket back to New York. There was just one hurdle. Outside my grandmothers suburban front door was a plague of cicadas.

title: Silicon Valley Turns Its Eye to Education
description: The education technology business is chock-full of fledgling companies whose innovative ideas have not yet proved effective  or profitable. But that is not slowing investors, who are pouring money into ventures as diverse as free classroom-management apps for teachers and foreign language lessons for adult learners.

title: Shooting in Brooklyn Kills Boy, 15, and Wounds Man
description: A 15-year-old boy was killed and a 20-year-old man was wounded in a shooting Sunday afternoon in the Flatlands area of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Tony Award for Teachers
description: A new Tony Award will be given annually to a theater teacher who has made a monumental impact on the lives of students, executives who oversee the Tonys and officials at Carnegie Mellon University announced on Sunday. The honor is intended to reflect the appreciation that many Tony winners  actors, writers, directors  have expressed for drama teachers who guided or inspired them. The award is the first new Tony since 2009. Through March 31, anyone can nominate a teacher for the new Excellence in Theater Education Award. Nominees must be current teachers at an accredited elementary, middle or high school or community theater organization in the United States. (College professors and retired teachers are not eligible.) A panel of judges comprising members of the American Theater Wing and the Broadway League, which oversee the Tonys, and Carnegie Mellon officials and theater industry executives will choose the winner, who will receive the award onstage at the annual Tonys ceremony in June.

title: For Jimmy Lai, Hong Kongs Rebellious Tycoon, Next Battle May Be in Court
description: HONG KONG  Jimmy Lai, Hong Kongs most fiercely anti-Communist tycoon, calls himself a rebel who likes to make trouble  and he has found no shortage of it.

description: DURHAM, N.C.  WITH Washington bitterly divided between a Democratic White House and a Republican Congress, it seems unlikely that America will see substantive progress on the grand challenges of the day, ranging from immigration to energy policy and entitlement programs.

title: In Cold Political Terms, Far Right and French President Both Gain
description: PARIS  Amid the horrors of the last week, Franois Hollande is widely judged to have kept his calm, acted decisively and spoken the words of condemnation, defiance and unity expected of a French president, who by tradition is called on to embody the nation.

description: For generations, the label has been at once exclusive and widely misapplied, available to millions in earnest, but vulnerable to line-blurring by suburban peers who claimed New York City residency without an address to match.

title: For the Love of Carbon
description: It should come as no surprise that the very first move of the new Republican Senate is an attempt to push President Obama into approving the Keystone XL pipeline, which would carry oil from Canadian tar sands. After all, debts must be paid, and the oil and gas industry  which gave 87 percent of its 2014 campaign contributions to the G.O.P.  expects to be rewarded for its support.

title: On National Stage, Coach Mark Helfrich Lets Oregon Roots Show
description: COOS BAY, Ore.  Mike Helfrich knew the curves of the bay and the nature of the ocean here so well that he could position his boat just so, not far from the others, fish for a few hours in a few spots and end the day with a boatload of crabs and fish.

title: New Golden Gate Bridge Barrier Draws Sighs of Relief
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Dillon Hartwigs commute from south of San Francisco to a Sausalito restaurant took three times longer than usual this weekend because his usual route  over the Golden Gate Bridge  was closed.

title: Aiming to Break Out in a Crowded TV Landscape
description: The demand for original scripted television series is white hot.

title: Croatians Elect Kolinda Grabar-Kitarovic as Their First Female President
description: WARSAW  In an unexpectedly tight runoff, Kolinda Grabar-Kitarovic, a conservative challenger, won Croatias election on Sunday and is set to become the countrys first female president.

title: Groundswell Chooses Democracy in Sri Lanka
description: NEW DELHI  Across the great Eurasian plate these days, from Belarus to Beijing, one can find leaders dispensing with truly competitive politics. But traverse the Himalayas to South Asia and the climate is different: Democracy is on a winning streak.

title: United in Outrage
description: The solidarity march of more than one million people in Paris on Sunday was rich in placards and symbols but appropriately devoid of speeches. Like many in the vast throng that filled the broad boulevards between Place de la Rpublique and Place de la Nation, the world leaders who marched a portion of the route with President Franois Hollande locked arms and embraced. But there was no podium, no pulpit, only ubiquitous signs reading Je suis Charlie. For the moment, that said it all.

title: In Peyton Mannings Woes and Andrew Lucks Grit, a Torch Seemingly Passed
description: Every new beginning comes from some other beginnings end  isnt that how life is scripted?

title: The Two Faces of Azerbaijans Mr. Aliyev
description: President Ilham Aliyev of Azerbaijan does a masterful political Jekyll and Hyde. A cable from the American ambassador to Baku released on WikiLeaks described him as a Michael Corleone-Sonny Corleone figure  referring, respectively, to the coolly calculating and the impetuously violent brothers of the Godfather mafia family. Mr. Aliyev is pro-Western in many of the ways the West admires: He is suave, well dressed and well spoken in English; he is ready to send his countrys ample supplies of oil and gas to Europe and to Israel; his Islam is moderate and modern; and he hosts lavish international events like the Eurovision Song Contest in 2012 and the European Games to be held next June.

title: Santorum Criticizes Potential G.O.P. Rivals as Bomb Throwers
description: WASHINGTON  Rick Santorum sharply criticized a group of potential rivals for the Republican presidential nomination in an interview that indicated he intends to reclaim conservative primary voters ahead of another White House bid in 2016.

description: The Times examined the moments both big and small, as well as perceived slights and missed opportunities, that have fed a sense of distrust of the mayor.

title: Jihadism Born in a Paris Park and Fueled in the Prison Yard
description: PARIS  They jogged together or did calisthenics along the hilly lawns and tulip-dotted gardens of Buttes-Chaumont, the public park in northeastern Paris built more than a century ago under Emperor Napoleon III. Or they met in nearby apartments with a janitor turned self-proclaimed imam, a man deemed too radical by one local mosque because of his call for waging jihad in Iraq.

description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Monday called for federal legislation intended to force American companies to be more forthcoming when credit card data and other consumer information are lost in an online breach like the kind that hit Sony, Target and Home Depot last year.

title: Taylor Negron, of Fast Times at Ridgemont High, Dies at 57
description: Taylor Negron, a comedian and actor who described his style as California Gothic and who brought a funereal, straight-faced sensibility to a careers worth of character roles in cult comedies like Fast Times at Ridgemont High and One Crazy Summer, died on Saturday. He was 57.

title: Rebuilding 3 Lives After Family Loses a Husband and a Provider to Cancer
description: Leukemia took Jean Carlos Ocasio in November, but the apartment he shared with his wife, Yaresly Cosme-Alicea, and their children still vibrates with his presence. It is in the walls he painted in warm earth tones, the steel kitchen shelves he custom made, the dividing wall he built in the apartments one bedroom, which is only half-finished, beams and Spackle still visible.

title: Justice Department Declassifies Additional Portions of Inspector General Reports on Using Patriot Act Section 215 for Business Records Collection
description: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit by The New York Times, the Justice Department has declassified additional portions of these two inspector general reports about the governments use of Section 215 of the Patriot Act, which is the legal basis for the once-secret National Security Agency program that systematically collects records in bulk about Americans domestic and international phone calls.

description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  At the Woody Hayes Athletic Center here, there is a wall listing all the Ohio State captains with the title A Legacy of Leadership.

Jeff Pentland will be the principal hitting instructor, according to a person familiar with the matter, and Alan Cockrell will be the assistant. Both have extensive major league experience.

description: The first investigation by New York Citys police inspector general includes the finding that in several cases where officers were found to have used a chokehold, the banned maneuver was the officers initial physical response to verbal resistance.

title: Harry V. Jaffa, Conservative Scholar and Goldwater Muse, Dies at 96
description: Harry V. Jaffa, who explored Americas founding in many books, but shifted modern politics with two speech lines that cast Senator Barry M. Goldwater as an extremist, abetting his landslide defeat in the 1964 presidential race and the birth of a zealous new conservatism, died on Saturday in Pomona, Calif. He was 96.

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 9:15 A.M. (IFC) IGBY GOES DOWN (2002) Kieran Culkin portrays Igby, a 17-year-old military school runaway who camps out in a New York loft as he rebels against his preppy older brother (Ryan Phillippe) and high-strung mother (Susan Sarandon), in this sarcastic comedy written and directed by Burt Steers. Amanda Peet, above with Mr. Culkin, is the heroin-addicted choreographer and trophy girlfriend of Igbys wealthy godfather and benefactor (Jeff Goldblum) with whom Igby finds solace; Bill Pullman is Igbys father, in a mental hospital after a schizophrenic breakdown. Even though the movie drifts uneasily between satire and realism, and its visions of military school and bohemia feel secondhand, it maintains a ruthless emotional honesty, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. Ultimately, it gets at something that no other recent American movie has captured quite so acutely: a resentful, lurking disappointment in the good life.

title: Roche to Buy Majority Stake in Foundation Medicine, Leader in Tumor Testing

title: Q. and A.: Jimmy Lai on the Democracy Movement in Hong Kong
description: Jimmy Lai, profiled in Mondays New York Times, is the founder and owner and was until recently the chairman of Next Media, which publishes the Apple Daily newspaper and Next Magazine in Hong Kong and Taiwan. He was a central figure in the pro-democracy Occupy Central protests, in which demonstrators closed major streets in three sections of Hong Kong between late September and mid-December. Now, officials in Hong Kong are weighing bringing formal charges against scores of people they have identified as key members of the protests. On Friday, Mr. Lai, 66, was instructed to report to police headquarters on Jan. 21.

description: LONDON  GrandVision, the Dutch operator of Vision Express in Britain and Gnrale dOptique in France, said on Monday that it planned to list its shares in an initial public offering on Euronext in Amsterdam.

title: Aer Lingus Shares Fall 5% After Second Rejection of British Airways Parent
description: LONDON  Shares of Aer Lingus fell more than 5 percent in afternoon trading on Monday after the parent of British Airways and the Spanish carrier Iberia confirmed on Friday that the Irish airlines board had rejected a revised takeover bid.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Golden Globes: Which Brand Won the Night?
description: The brand/celebrity equation has had its ups and downs  once upon a time, a single brand could dominate awards nights, outfitting multiple stars and making a major splash (Armani, anyone?), a situation that gave way to the one-brand, one-woman approach. But interestingly, if the Golden Globes on Sunday night are anything to go by, fashion seems to be leaning back toward the dress-as-many-as-possible technique.

title: The Best-Positioned Rival to Jeb Bush May Not Be the Best Known
description: Jeb Bush had a good month. He struck first in the invisible primary  the behind-the-scenes competition for the support of donors, officials and operatives. And for all of the talk about the depth of the Republican field, the opposition to Mr. Bush remains unclear and underwhelming.

title: New York Today: Sloppy Commute
description: Good morning on this not-very-nice Monday.

title: E. Tautz: Fall 2015 Menswear
description: London

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | Jan. 12, 2015
description: Updated: Jan. 13, 2015

title: Today in Politics
description: Obama Misses French Unity March, and His Absence Is Noted

title: Daily Report: Education Technology Attracts Silicon Valleys Attention
description: The education technology business is chock-full of fledgling companies whose innovative ideas have not yet proved effective  or profitable. But that is not slowing investors, who are pouring money into ventures as diverse as free classroom-management apps for teachers and foreign language lessons for adult learners, Natasha Singer reports.

title: Reaganomics Undefended
description: OK, Im accustomed to getting attacked  if what I write doesnt induce some hysterical backlash, Ive wasted the space. And its kind of flattering when people devote whole print columns to attacking yours truly; its kind of a compliment, a tribute to their sense of my malign influence.

title: Kerry Vows Aid for Displaced Pakistanis
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The United States plans to provide $250 million in emergency aid to help resettle and sustain civilians displaced by the Pakistani militarys campaign against militant groups, senior American officials said Monday night after the first day of a visit by Secretary of State John Kerry.

title: Morning Agenda: Shires Deal for NPS
description: The Irish drug maker Shire has agreed to acquire NPS Pharmaceuticals for $5.2 billion, the first big corporate acquisition of the year, DealBooks David Gelles reports. Shire, based in Dublin, said on Sunday that it would pay $46 a share for NPS, which is based in New Jersey and specializes in drugs for gastrointestinal disorders. That represents a 51 percent increase over NPSs share price on Dec. 16, before rumors of the deal first surfaced. Shire will pay for NPS using all cash.

title: Burberrys Fall 2015 Collection at London Mens Fashion Week
description: [Watch the live stream.]

title: Family Dollar Urges Shareholders to Back Dollar Tree Deal
description: Almost a month after Family Dollar postponed a shareholder vote on its planned $8.5 billion merger with Dollar Tree, the company is making a direct pitch to investors to try to win support for the deal.

title: Ireland Hires Goldman to Advise on Allied Irish Banks Stake
description: LONDON  The Irish government said on Monday that it had hired Goldman Sachs to advise it on potential capital restructuring at Allied Irish Banks, the first step ahead of any sale of a portion of its stake in the lender, which was nationalized in 2010.

title: Doing More for Patients Often Does No Good
description: Given the remarkable advances that have been made in the last 50 or so years in pharmaceuticals, medical devices and surgical procedures, its not a surprise that people want more, and more invasive, care than they have had in the past. Just as its hard to do nothing when youre ill, its sometimes hard to do less than the maximum when there are different treatments to choose from.

title: Craig Green: Fall 2015 Menswear
description: London

title: 6 Men, Said to Have Attacked the Police, Are Killed in Chinas Far West
description: BEIJING  In the latest outburst of violence in Chinas troubled Xinjiang region, security forces shot and killed six men on Monday after they attacked police officers not far from the Silk Road city of Kashgar, a government website reported.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: AmerisourceBergen to Buy MWI Veterinary Supply
description: The AmerisourceBergen Corporation, a drug distributor, agreed on Monday to buy MWI Veterinary Supply for about $2.5 billion in cash, expanding into the animal health business.

title: History and Policy Failure
description: Ive been having a hard time reading Barry Eichengreens Hall of Mirrors, about how the lessons of the Great Depression were ignored after 2008. Its not that its a bad book; so far, it seems to be a very good book, with a lot about the 1930s that I didnt know. But the recent history is painful, because I was watching in real time, warning desperately that what did happen, would happen.

title: What the Globes Say About the Oscars (and Grand Budapest)
description: LOS ANGELES  With the Golden Globes behind us, Hollywood and awards aficionados find themselves in a 72-hour limbo until the Oscar nominations are announced at the crack of dawn (Pacific Standard Time, that is) Thursday.

title: Nominee for Attorney General Less an Activist Than Holder
description: WASHINGTON  While interviewing aspiring prosecutors for jobs in the United States attorneys office in Brooklyn, Loretta E. Lynch, an African-American Democrat who grew up in the segregated South, often poses a favorite question.

title: On Econoheroes
description: I gather that some readers didnt get what I was driving at in declaring that Joe Stiglitz and yours truly are the lefts econoheroes, but the likes of Stephen Moore and Art Laffer play that role on the right.

title: EMC to Add 2 Directors in Temporary Truce With Elliott Management
description: The data storage giant EMC has reached a truce with a prominent activist hedge fund  for now, anyway  by agreeing to add two directors to its board.

title: White House Still Backs Annual Testing in Schools
description: With debates about the appropriate role for the federal government in public education increasingly polarized, the secretary of education, Arne Duncan, insisted on Monday that the administration would not back away from annual testing for students and performance evaluations of teachers based in part on the results of the tests.

title: Jets Favor Candidate With Eye for Talent
description: As the Jets enter what their owner Woody Johnson called a critical juncture for the organization, they are set to entrust the football operations department to Mike Maccagnan, who is on the verge of being hired as general manager.

title: Speaking While Female
description: YEARS ago, while producing the hit TV series The Shield, Glen Mazzara noticed that two young female writers were quiet during story meetings. He pulled them aside and encouraged them to speak up more.

title: Cuba Frees 53 Prisoners, U.S. Says
description: MEXICO CITY  The Cuban government has released 53 dissidents it had promised to free under the accord with Washington to restore diplomatic relations and step up economic exchanges, United States officials said Monday.

title: Canary Wharf Owner Urges Investors to Reject Takeover Bid
description: LONDON  The board of the owner of the Canary Wharf office-and-retail development said on Monday that shareholders should reject a hostile bid for the company made by Qatars sovereign wealth fund and Brookfield Property Partners.

title: Kerry Reasserts U.S. Support for France
description: Secretary of State John Kerry, reacting to criticism that the U.S. was not represented at Sundays rally in Paris, said the relationship with France is not about one day or one particular moment.

title: London Mens Fashion Week: Casely Hayford Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

title: Peanut Butter With Sticking Power
description: FREDONIA, N.Y.  Throughout a life of erudite jousting and patrician bonhomie, William F. Buckley Jr. was known as a conservative, a writer, a publisher, a talk-show host, a novelist and an avid sailor. But friends and family would say this biographical summary is incomplete without three more words: peanut butter freak.

title: London Mens Fashion Week: Casely-Hayford Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

title: Strains Show as Afghan Leaders Announce Long-Awaited Cabinet Nominees
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A three-month deadlock that paralyzed Afghanistans new government appeared to dissipate on Monday, as a palace official announced 25 nominees to lead cabinet ministries.

title: Big Movies Plunged Into Our Still-Wrenching History. Did the Golden Globes Award Them?
description: Frank Bruni:You and I come into these conversations hoping to focus on new movies with special cultural and social relevance, and for much of the year were hard pressed. But December gave us plenty: Selma, American Sniper and more.

title: A Reporters Beat, and a Poets Muse
description: Times readers often send reporters and editors notes with feedback or questions. Recently, Rachel Abrams, a business reporter, received a few reader messages that gave her pause. As journalists are wont to do, she investigated. Heres her story.

title: The Slackers Secret to Success
description: Before Abbi Jacobson and Ilana Glazer descended into the Union Square subway station one chilly Wednesday morning, they made it clear they were not hoping for any outrageous interactions that could be spun into material for Broad City, their Comedy Central series.

title: After 26 Years in Prison, Settling a Wrongful Conviction
description: WHITE PLAINS  Dewey Bozella was once the light-heavyweight boxing champion of Sing Sing, a distinction he won while serving 26 years in prison for a murder for which he was eventually exonerated.

title: Paris Attacks Prompt Tougher Stance on Security in Britain
description: LONDON  The British capital has effectively been on high alert since a deadly series of suicide attacks on its transport system killed 52 people in 2005, but last weeks shootings in Paris have compelled the government to add new scenarios to an ever-growing list of threats.

title: France to Mobilize 10,000 Troops
description: Jean-Yves Le Drian, the defense minister of France, announced that the country will increase security with its military to combat threats.

description: From Amal Clooneys opera gloves to Felicity Joness demure Dior, the stars turned it out at last nights event.

title: When Diabetes Treatment Goes Too Far
description: NEW HAVEN  ONE of my elderly patients has Type 2 diabetes and heart disease. He takes a number of medications, including insulin to control his blood sugar levels. A few years ago, he was driving when his blood sugar suddenly dropped. He felt lightheaded for a moment, and then ran into a tree.

title: Minnesota Orchestra Set to Complete Sibelius Symphony Recordings
description: Let the cycle be unbroken: The Minnesota Orchestra and Osmo Vanska, whose efforts to record a complete cycle of the seven Sibelius symphonies for BIS Records were interrupted in 2013 by their 16-month labor lockout, plan to finish the job later this year.

title: London Mens Fashion Week: Craig Green Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

title: Access and How to Get It: Congressional Reporters Notebook
description: Congress is back in session, and though it remains to be seen how the new Republican majority will affect legislation, some things almost never change. Jeremy W. Peters, a congressional reporter for The Times, describes the reporters abiding concern with access and the question of how to get past handlers and other hurdles.

title: The 10 Best Dressed on the Golden Globe Awards Red Carpet
description: From old-Hollywood glamour to red-carpet rebels, the stars turned it out at last nights Golden Globe Awards. Several trends emerged on the red carpet, such as silver-embellished gowns that shined like disco balls, worn by Julianne Moore and Dakota Johnson, and suiting and separates, as seen on Emma Stone and Lorde. Only a brave few took risks, but they did so successfully: Last years award winner Lupita Nyongo stood out in one of the nights only prints; the most anticipated guest of the evening, Amal Clooney, sported white opera gloves; and the nominee Felicity Jones wore demure, high-necked Dior, proving amidst all the cleavage and cutouts that being covered up can make just as much of an impression. Last but not least, there were the ladies who wore true fashion and wore it well: Claire Danes in Valentino, a pregnant Keira Knightley in Chanel and Sienna Miller in Miu Miu. All in all, it was an exciting kick-off to 2015s awards season.

title: The Sony Hack and the Gender Pay Gap
description: Its rare to see such clear evidence of women making less pay for equal work. Among other unflattering details revealed by the Sony Pictures Entertainment hack (presumably sponsored by North Korea in retaliation for the film The Interview) was that Chris Hemsworth had secured higher compensation than his co-star Charlize Theron for the upcoming movie The Huntsman.

title: Suit Alleges Widespread Deficiencies in South Carolina Foster Care
description: In a new challenge to South Carolinas embattled foster care program, child-welfare activists filed a lawsuit in federal court on Monday claiming that widespread deficiencies in the system have endangered thousands of children.

title: 1915: A Battle Royal in the Sky
description: LONDON  A thrilling sequel to the German aerial raid on Dunkirk, a battle royal 9,000 feet above the ground between two Belgian aeroplanes and seven enemy machines, has become known here. As shrapnel and rifle bullets from the anti-aircraft guns were pattering down on houses, two plucky Belgian aviators took to the air and engaged seven foes. Rapidly outmaneuvering the hostile pilots, the Belgians ascended, and half hidden by the thin gray clouds, they poured a hail of bullets from their machine-guns. As fast as the remaining German planes rose, the Belgians climbed more swiftly, until the final phase of the duel was decided at an altitude of 9,000ft.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 13, 1915

title: Shire Gambles AbbVie Breakup Fee on a Risky Deal
description: Shire is gambling its AbbVie breakup fee on risky M.&A.

title: London Mens Fashion Week: E. Tautz Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

title: A Yearlong Celebration of The Nations 150th Anniversary
description: The Nation, Americas oldest weekly magazine, will celebrate its 150th anniversary with a yearlong schedule of events including public discussions, a book release, new online projects and a documentary by the Academy Award-winning filmmaker Barbara Kopple, the magazine announced Monday.

title: Daniel Finkel and the Balance Problem
description: Our puzzle this week was proposed by regular contributor Daniel Finkel, part of the Seattle-based Math for Love duo committed to revitalizing grade- and high-school math education. I think Ive just concocted a novel coin-balance problem, he wrote in a recent email. To the best of my knowledge, it is totally original.

title: A Killing Spree Ignored for Decades
description: Nobody knows how many women may have been killed during a spree in Los Angeles that began in the 1980s and ended with the arrest in 2010 of Lonnie Franklin Jr. He has been charged in 10 cases, but in Tales of the Grim Sleeper, one of 15 films shortlisted for the Oscar for best documentary feature, the British director Nick Broomfield argues that a more realistic count would have to be in the hundreds.

title: Volvo to Export Sedan Made in China to U.S.
description: After years of promises by the industry followed by manufacturing delays, a major automaker is finally on the verge of starting sustained exports from China to the United States.

title: UVA Fraternity Reinstated After Rolling Stone Article on Rape
description: The University of Virginia, after receiving guidance from the local police, on Monday reinstated the fraternity at the center of a Rolling Stone magazine article that detailed gang rape allegations that later came into question.

title: ScienceTake | How to Swim in Sand
description: X-ray videos show that a slender, flexible body and smooth skin allow the shovel-nose snake to move efficiently through sand.

title: The Skinny on Moving Under Sand
description: Some subsurface animals burrow and dig tunnels. Others, in sandy environments like the deserts of Arizona or the Sahara, wiggle along under the surface in a way that looks like swimming.

title: Celebrating King in Atlanta, Memphis and Boston
description: In Atlanta, where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was born and raised, his holiday, coming up on Jan. 19, feels both somber and celebratory, said Kim Severson, a domestic correspondent for The New York Times based there. You definitely feel like its a special day when youre in Atlanta, probably more so than in other cities.

title: Monochrome Mens Looks at the Golden Globes
description: There was a time when wearing a navy tuxedo during awards season seemed a revolutionary choice for men. But after last nights Golden Globes, its safe to say what was once a risky move has nowadays become commonplace. Plenty of navy tuxedos walked down the red carpet yesterday evening; however, the above men took it a step further. The actors William H. Macy and Adrien Brody and the musician Common  who wonthe award for Best Original Song for the film Selma  opted against the traditional crisp white shirt that actors are wont to wear with their evening suits and instead buttoned up dark layers beneath, creating dapper monochromatic looks that were just a bit more exciting than the basic navy tux.

title: Takedown Tactics
description: Phil Messina, a retired sergeant from the New York Police Department, demonstrates ways officers can disable a suspect before handcuffing.

title: Lorrie Moore Among Finalists for Story Prize
description: Lorrie Moores Bark, the authors first collection of short stories since 1998, is one of three finalists for this years Story Prize, which comes with an award of $20,000.

title: Congress Gets More Diverse, but Still Lags Country as a Whole
description: Congress has become less politically diverse since last years midterm elections, but when it comes to race and ethnicity, the 114th Congress is the most diverse in history.

title: Best Selling Science Books
description: 1 WHAT IF? by Randall Munroe. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt. Scientific (but often humorous) answers to hypothetical questions, based in part on the authors website, xkcd.com. (Last months ranking: 2)

title: Newsom Says He Wont Run for Boxers Senate Seat
description: Lt. Gov. Gavin Newsom of California just crossed himself off the list of potential candidates to replace Senator Barbara Boxer, who announced last week that she would not run for re-election in 2016.

title: Colbert Gets a Sept. 8 Start Date for CBS Show
description: Stephen Colbert can pick up his keys to the Ed Sullivan Theater any time before Labor Day: he will begin hosting Late Show, CBSs flagship late-night program, on Sept. 8, the network announced on Monday.

title: McCaskill Says She Wont Leave Senate to Run for Governor
description: Senator Claire McCaskill on Monday issued a firm no on whether she would give up her Senate seat to run for governor of Missouri.

title: Harsh Critics in Public Spaces, Judging Only What They See
description: The last time it happened was in the grocery store. A scowling woman closed in on me and my son, Nico, in the produce section. Glaring, she waved at my sons face and said, His nose! And then she mimed wiping with furious gestures. I sighed and pulled a tissue from my pocket. She harrumphed slightly and walked away. I offered Nico the tissue.

title: Despite Scrutiny, Police Chokeholds Persist in New York City
description: Before pepper spray, Tasers, expandable batons and portable radios, New York police officers facing resistance from a criminal suspect had another option: the chokehold. By 1993, though, the New York Police Department had joined departments in other large cities by banning the chokehold with an order that amounted to, in the words of former Chief of Department John F. Timoney: Stay the hell away from the neck.

title: Emerging Markets After The Tantrum
description: And now for something completely different. Im heading off to Asia in a few days, and trying to think about emerging-market issues. And I have something of a puzzle on my mind.

title: Portugal Telecom Shareholders Agree to Put Off Vote on Asset Sale
description: LONDON  Shareholders of Portugal Telecom agreed on Monday to postpone a vote on whether to sell assets valued at $8.7 billion to Altice, the European cable and mobile service provider.

title: British Prime Minister Suggests Banning Some Online Messaging Apps
description: LONDON  Popular messaging services like Snapchat and WhatsApp are in the cross hairs in Britain.

title: Fox News Beats a Retreat After Gaffes About Islam
description: LONDON  First, the owner of the Fox News Channel incited an outpouring of ridicule for suggesting that all followers of Islam must take responsibility for the Paris attacks. Then the Fox pundit who is a self-described terrorism expert caused a second wave of stunned disbelief, asserting that some parts of Europe  including Britains city of Birmingham  have become so Islamic they are off limits to non-Muslims.

title: London Mens Fashion Week: Craig Green Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

title: Charlie Hebdos New Issue Features Muhammad on Cover
description: PARIS  Around 9:10 on Monday evening, laughter and a round of applause broke out among the surviving staff members of Charlie Hebdo, followed shortly by cries  joyous if ironic  of Allahu akbar!

title: After Enterovirus 68 Outbreak, a Paralysis Mystery
description: A nationwide outbreak of a respiratory virus last fall sent droves of children to emergency departments. The infections have now subsided, as researchers knew they would, but they have left behind a frightening mystery.

title: ISIS Is Cited in Hacking of Central Commands Twitter and YouTube Accounts
description: WASHINGTON  Hackers claiming to be working on behalf of the Sunni militant group known as the Islamic State took over the Twitter and YouTube accounts of the United States Central Command on Monday, sending out a series of posts far different from the American militarys standard fare.

title: Verbatim: White House Expresses Paris Regrets
description: the White House spokesman, Josh Earnest, expressing regret that the United States did not send someone more prominent to a unity march in Paris.

title: White House Acknowledges Error in Not Sending a Top Official to March in Paris
description: WASHINGTON  The White House, facing a storm of criticism for President Obamas absence from Sundays peace march in Paris, said Monday that his team erred in failing to dispatch a high-ranking American official to join the show of solidarity against terrorism. But French officials quickly rejected the idea that Mr. Obama had snubbed the event.

title: When Picking a Fight Can Also Be a Way to Start to Talk
description: WASHINGTON  In the halls of the White House and the corridors of the Capitol, there was a stark dissonance last week between President Obamas rhetoric of consensus and compromise and his confrontational actions, offering the first glimmers of the presidents strategy for engaging with a Republican Congress that holds the fate of his agenda in its hands.

title: Stick With Me Sweets Opens in NoLIta
description: To Indulge: Playing for Keeps

title: A Touch Screen to Ease Airport Stress
description: For the beleaguered and bored waiting out delays in the nations airports, there isnt much to turn to beyond the TV on the wall or an uninspired restaurant. But some airports are trying to change that, as they install iPads by the thousands so that travelers can browse and, officials hope, eventually buy.

title: Falling Oil Prices Help Overhaul of a Hong Kong Empire
description: Cheap oil could be vital to Li Ka-shing keeping control of his empire.

title: Phil Steeles Preview of Ohio State vs. Oregon
description: Phil Steele, the founder and author of a highly regarded college football preview magazine now in its 20th year, will have all 12 televisions in his office tuned to one game Monday night: the national title showdown between Oregon and Ohio State. He gave us some quick thoughts on the matchup. (This interview has been edited and condensed.)

title: Spotify Says Its List of Subscribers Has Grown to 15 Million
description: Spotify, the streaming music service, has signed up 15 million subscribers, a sign of rapid growth for the company and an implicit rebuttal in a roiling industry debate over whether people are willing to pay for music online.

title: Common and John Legend Perform Glory
description: In an exclusive performance, the artists showcased the song Glory from the movie Selma at the Metropolitan Club in New York City. The composition won a Golden Globe for best original song.

title: Retrospectives of Balthus and Brian Weil, Graham Littles Renaissance Redux and More From the Art Calendar
description: Ts list of happenings worth visiting in the week ahead.

title: Getting Over Cold Feet: The Case for Impulse Buying
description: I live in a part of the country where we take skiing pretty seriously. Its common for people to ski a few times a week since there are three great resorts right in our town. Our family is no exception. We ski a lot, but as my wife and I have gotten older, we discovered a painful reality: Our feet get colder faster.

title: British Nurse With Ebola Is Improving, Hospital Says
description: LONDON  A British nurse who contracted an Ebola infection in Sierra Leone last month is no longer in critical condition, the hospital treating her in London said on Monday.

title: Common and John Legend in Performance
description: Common and John Legend won the Golden Globe on Sunday night for their contribution to Selma: the song Glory. As the Bagger recently recounted, the song came about when the director Ava DuVernay asked Common, the rapper and actor who played the civil rights activist James Bevel in the film, to contribute a song as well. He immediately thought of Mr. Legend, who sent him the composition three days later.

title: Inside the Golden Globe Parties
description: After the ceremony, celebrities flocked to parties hosted by InStyle/Warner Bros. and the Weinstein Company/Netflix.

title: No Smoke, but Haze Around E-Joint
description: At a recent Seahawks football game in Seattle, Shy Sadis, 41, took a drag on a slim vapor pen that looked like a jet black Marlboro. The tip glowed red as he inhaled.

title: How Medicaid for Children Partly Pays for Itself
description: When advocates talk about the advantages of government health care, they often talk about a moral obligation to ensure equal access. Or they describe the immediate health and economic rewards of giving people a way to pay for their care.

title: 1965: Burch to Quit as GOP Leader
description: WASHINGTON  The Dean Burch battle has ended, and with it the brief reign of Barry Goldwater over the Republican party. Today [Jan. 12], less than six months after his triumphant nomination for the presidency, the Arizona conservative announced that Mr. Burch, his choice for national chairman, would step down from the top party post April 1 in favor of Ohio state chairman Ray C. Bliss. It was hailed by most leaders of the GOP as a harbinger of a new era of harmony within the faction-ridden party.  The New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 13, 1965

title: Plunging Teenage Angst Deeper Into the Woods
description: A lively squadron of archetypes, long familiar to fans of popular myths, wanders into a mysterious forest. Uncanny and unsettling things happen there, including encounters with a witch. Songs are sung, lessons are learned, and by the end all these explorers have grown just a bit in their knowledge of lifes uncertainties.

title: Inside the Golden Globe Parties
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  The hottest accessory after Sunday nights Golden Globes was neither beaded, bejeweled nor bespoke. It was the paper ticket, wristband or, trendiest yet, invisible wrist stamp for the after-parties.

title: Naps May Be Good for a Babys Learning
description: A napping infant is busy learning and memorizing, a new study suggests.

title: Varied Routes to Safer Streets
description: Are the streets in your neighborhood safe for walking? Not just for able-bodied, cognitively sound, safety-conscious adults, but also for those with physical or cognitive impairments, pedestrians in a hurry, and especially children and teens who are often distracted?

title: BATS to Pay $14 Million Penalty Stemming From Direct Edge Merger
description: The stock exchange operator BATS Global Markets has agreed to pay $14 million to settle accusations by the Securities and Exchange Commission concerning two exchanges it acquired through its merger with Direct Edge last year.

title: Pope Will Turn Spotlight on Asia With Trip to Sri Lanka and the Philippines
description: VATICAN CITY  Pope Francis left Monday for his second trip to Asia, where he will deliver a message of peace and reconciliation in Sri Lanka, a country shaken by a decades-long civil war, and then visit the Philippines, the Vatican said on the eve of his visit.

title: Stock Market
description: 9 ways to make more flavorful soups.

title: Maison Martin Margiela Couture Collection
description: John Galliano debuted his couture collection for Maison Martin Margiela in London.

title: Russian and Ukrainian Officials Meet in Germany
description: BERLIN  The foreign ministers of Russia and Ukraine met here on Monday with their German and French counterparts in the latest attempt to ease the crisis in eastern Ukraine, where some 4,700 people have been killed since the conflict erupted last spring.

title: Grief and Defiance in Pakistan as Survivors of Taliban Massacre Return to School
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  The survivors of a massacre at a Pakistani school last month returned to their school on Monday, offering a grief-tinged show of defiance and apprehension.

title: Bitter Cold Claims More Lives in Gaza
description: GAZA  Three infants and a young fisherman have died from exposure during a fierce storm that plagued the Gaza Strip with bitter cold, rain and wind over the past week, Palestinian health officials say.

title: Elusive Middle Ground in Punishment of White-Collar Criminals
description: The punishment meted out to criminals convicted of white-collar crimes like fraud and tax evasion can seem confusing to the public. A low-level accountant once received nearly 25 years for inflating with the companys revenue while a wealthy entrepreneur received probation for hiding millions of dollars in a secret Swiss bank account.

title: Oil Prices: Whats Behind the Drop? Simple Economics
description: Updated: Wednesday, Feb. 4.

title: A Taylor Swift-Harvey Weinstein Moment and Other Post-Globes Memories
description: Start with the comic Martin Mulls oft-repeated truism, which was quoted to the Bagger last night: Hollywood is high school with money.

title: Meet Martine Rose, Londons Rising Mens Wear Provocateur (and Rihannas Go-To Label)
description: Since her debut collection in 2007, the London-based mens wear designer Martine Rose has searched for and celebrated what she calls an awkwardness that is beautiful in its entirety. The punk, skinhead, 90s raver and 70s S-and-M scenes, to name a few, provide references for her odd proportions (outrageously oversize trousers paired with super-cropped or tight tops) and unexpected fabric combinations. The fashion world has taken notice; so, too, has Rihanna, who has worn Roses designs on multiple occasions.

title: Gallianos Back, on Tiptoes
description: LONDON  The klieg lights went up on Act III of John Gallianos career on a rainy Monday here, on the fourth floor of a brand-new eco-sensitive glass and steel office tower just around the corner from New Scotland Yard and behind Buckingham Palace. In case you missed it: new building, new businesslike beginning.

title: Manhattan Clinic That Treated Joan Rivers Will Lose Federal Funding
description: The Manhattan clinic where Joan Rivers went into cardiac arrest while being treated for a voice problem has failed to correct deficiencies implicated in her death and will be prohibited from having its services paid for by Medicare and Medicaid funds, according to a letter released on Monday from the federal agency that oversees those two programs.

title: Lane Departs and Sales Sag for Its Only a Play on Broadway
description: Call it the Nathan Lane effect. A two-time Tony Award winner and one of theaters biggest box-office draws, Mr. Lane recently departed the Broadway hit comedy Its Only a Play  and ticket sales promptly slid without him last week, just as they did when he left earlier Broadway shows like The Addams Family and The Producers.

title: A Computer That Knows When to Hold Em
description: It has been eight years since a computer program solved checkers, calculating a strategy so optimal that it guaranteed at least a draw. Now, an algorithm has done the same for poker, producing a winning strategy that researchers say no human can beat in a single lifetime.

title: Rivalrys Edict: Drub Thy Neighbor
description: HOLLAND, Mich.  As much as he emphasizes the twin concepts of consistency and continuity, Kevin Vande Streek dabbled in the unconventional when his players gathered for practice Friday.

title: Egyptian Court Acquits 26 Men Accused of Debauchery
description: CAIRO  A Cairo court on Monday acquitted 26 men accused of debauchery in a case that was seen as evidence of an intensifying crackdown on gay men by the government of President Abdel-Fattah el-Sisi.

title: Regulators Again Reject Doral Financials Capital Plan
description: Doral Financial, the troubled Puerto Rico bank with offices that were raided by the F.B.I. last month, has run afoul with banking regulators over its plans to restore its depleted capital levels.

title: Deviating From the Modern, to Fresh Effect
description: Not every career has a watershed moment. But the violinist Johnny Gandelsman, who gave a mesmerizing performance of Bachs sonatas and partitas for unaccompanied violin at Bargemusic on Saturday, recalled the pivotal experience that forever changed his approach to this music.

title: White House Admits Misstep
description: Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, said that the United States should have sent a higher ranking official than the ambassador to France to attend Sundays peace march in Paris.

title: Women Run 30 Percent of All Businesses, but Only 5 Percent of the Biggest, Study Shows
description: Women own or manage more than 30 percent of all businesses but 5 percent or less of the biggest enterprises, the United Nations said in a report published Monday.

title: Arrests and Summonses Rise in New York City, but Fall Short of Pre-Slowdown Levels
description: The shift could be seen across New York City. Orange parking tickets again fluttered on windshields; turnstile jumpers again faced a summons or arrest; and drivers encountered more traffic checkpoints.

title: Your Letters: Cancers Luck, Earth-Like Planets and Protecting Pedestrians
description: Cosmology

title: Celebrating 2 Broadway Powerhouses, Bit by Bit
description: When David Loud auditioned for the ill-fated original Broadway production of the 1981 Stephen Sondheim-George Furth musical, Merrily We Roll Along, he was just a college student. After many callbacks, he joined the cast of a production that closed after only 16 performances, thus ending the string of remarkable collaborations between Mr. Sondheim and the director and producer Harold Prince; they reunited in 2003 for Bounce.

title: Thermal Imaging Allows for Picturing the Invisible
description: The thermal imaging systems used by the French police to find the two brothers suspected in the Charlie Hebdo massacre last week are based on a rapidly evolving technology now turning up in hospitals, airports, and even smartphones.

title: Murdoch and Fox News Mocked on Twitter for Claims About Muslims
description: This cannot have been an enjoyable weekend for anyone at 21st Century Fox responsible for cultivating the image of either Rupert Murdoch or his Fox News Channel.

title: An Ambassador for Physics Is Shifting His Mission
description: Rolf-Dieter Heuer, a crinkly-eyed German with a snowy goatee, showed up at the Four Seasons, the perennial Manhattan power lunch spot, dressed like the physicist he is  in a sweater and baggy jeans for the red-eye to Geneva  rather than the diplomat he had just been playing.

title: London Mens Fashion Week: Burberry Prorsum Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Roberta Ridolfi.

title: Justices Seem Unsettled by Ordinance Restricting Arizona Towns Signs
description: WASHINGTON  An Arizona town ordinance that places strict limits on some religious signs appeared to be in trouble on Monday at the Supreme Court.

title: First Draft Focus: Obama Adds to His Jersey Collection
Clown Shoes and Other Surprising Travel Necessities
description: I RUN a global outsourcing company, Integreon, that provides legal, document, research and business support to law firms, financial institutions and multinationals. My job as chief executive means Im kind of like a casting director, making sure we have the right people at the right place at the right time. That involves an incredible amount of travel helping clients.

title: Child With Symptoms? App Lets You Text Doctors, With No Guarantees
description: Its happened to nearly every parent: the child with the borderline temperature and the amorphous symptoms, prompting the classic should-we-or-shouldnt-we dilemma. Does this call for a visit to the pediatrician, or not?

title: At the Golden Globes, Beauty Looks Got Matchy-Matchy
description: At last nights 2015 Golden Globe Awards, the stars seemed to be feeling riskier than ever when it came to hair and makeup. And a few celebrities even embraced what might be considered a faux pas  coordinating the colors of their hair, makeup and nails to their fashion choices. The Homeland actress Claire Danes reproduced the palette of her Valentino gown with an off-pink nude lip and a soft royal-blue eyeshadow (which also matched her earrings). Jessica Chastain chose the exact metallic bronze color of her Versace dress for her nails, while Zosia Mamet wore a gray dress and silver jewelry to echo her dyed gray hair.

title: A Gallery of Tenacious Survivors
description: Some people are accused of living in the past. The photographer Rachel Sussman is captivated by the past living in the present.

title: Age and the Shingles Vaccine
description: Q. Why do many health insurers pay for the shingles vaccine only for people who are 60 or older?

title: Sparrows Dont Just Sing Same Old Song
description: A sparrows song may sound simple, consisting of little more than whistles and trills. But to the sparrows, those few noises can take on vastly different meanings depending on small variations in context and repetition, researchers have found.

title: Former Oregon Quarterback Laments What He Lost
description: MILLBRAE, Calif.  The last time Oregon played Ohio State was at the Rose Bowl five years ago. Jeremiah Masoli and Terrelle Pryor were the quarterbacks. Ohio State won, 26-17, and Masoli lingered on the field afterward, watching as the Buckeyes celebrated. He vowed to work harder the next season.

title: PC Market Exited 2014 With a Whimper
description: SEATTLE  Many people and businesses havent found compelling reasons to buy new personal computers in recent years, and PC companies didnt discover any new gimmicks to change their minds over the holidays.

title: At Museum, New Front in Guinea Worm Fight
description: There were only 126 cases of Guinea worm reported in the world last year, a 15 percent drop from the year before, according to former President Jimmy Carter, who has fought for decades to eradicate the debilitating disease, which once affected millions.

title: London Mens Fashion Week: Burberry Prorsum Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Roberta Ridolfi.

title: 2015 Detroit Auto Show
description: The auto industry, after reporting a strong 2014 a week ago, gathered in Detroit to show off its new models.

title: Paul Ryan Announces He Will Not Run for President
description: As potential presidential candidates continue to jockey for position before official announcements are made, one prominent Republican is withdrawing his name before the rumors even begin.

title: In Performance | Slotnick and Wilson
description: Joey Slotnick and C.J. Wilson in a scene from Moira Buffinis dark comedy Dying for It, an adaptation of Nikolai Erdmans 1928 play The Suicide. The show is at the Atlantic Theater through Jan.18.

title: Parents Challenge President to Dig Deeper on Ed Tech
description: Education technology companies that have pledged not to exploit student data they collect for marketing purposes welcomed President Obamas endorsement on Monday of the industrys effort to limit its use of classroom data.

title: Albuquerque Officers Are Charged With Murder in Death of Homeless Man
description: ALBUQUERQUE  Prosecutors here said Monday that they would pursue murder charges against two police officers who were involved in the fatal shooting last year of a homeless man with a history of mental illness, a case that led to protests and a federal criminal investigation and that is likely to be among the first to rely on evidence obtained by a camera worn by an officer.

title: Walkabout: New Scrutiny for U.S. Visa-Waiver Program
description: High Alert Sen. Dianne Feinstein criticized the nascent visa-waiver program, which helps travelers from 38 countries to enter the United States visa-free for fewer than 90 days. The program may come under new scrutiny, following increasing terrorist threats and the latest attacks in Paris. (Skift)

title: Mawmaw, The Dwarf Mammoth and M&Ms
description: If Thomas Pierces first book, Hall of Small Mammals, makes him sought after on the interview circuit, he will be asked the same thing over and over: Where do your ideas come from? Usually, thats a silly question, but its unavoidable for a writer whose short-story collection opens with Shirley Temple Three, about a mans bringing a waist-high, supposedly extinct Bread Island Dwarf Mammoth home to his mother.

title: Amid Seeming Progress, a Vicious Backlash
description: Klansville U.S.A. is a documentary about the Ku Klux Klan, but its short on images of terrorists on horseback and bodies hanging from trees. It more often resembles home movies of a Sunday outing: picnics, dancing, cooking a pig. And much of it looks like the civil rights rallies and marches that were taking place at the same time, except for the white robes and the occasional 60-foot burning cross.

title: If Mitt Romney Challenges Jeb Bush, Rand Paul Stands to Gain
description: It is still not a sure thing that Mitt Romney will run for president. No losing nominee has done so in decades. But it now seems more likely. The Washington Post reported on Monday that he was reassembling his campaign apparatus, and even told one Republican he almost certainly will run.

title: New Releases From Justin Townes Earle, Liam Hayes and Justin Kauflin
description: JUSTIN TOWNES EARLE

title: Now Onstage: Steady and Evolving
description: There was a telling moment in her recital on Sunday afternoon at the Morgan Library & Museum when the soprano Angela Meades voice did something surprising: It didnt do what she wanted it to. She was finishing the recitative that leads into Non mi dir, one of Donna Annas arias from Mozarts Don Giovanni, and she sent up a floating high note, like a gymnast launching herself into the air.

title: Stillness and Motion and Voluptuous Curves, in a Temple Setting
description: In India, ancient temples teem with sculptures of dancing figures, testifying to the spiritual origins and importance of dance. To see a performance of a classical Indian dance in such a setting must be revelatory, an experience impossible for an Indian dance troupe to reproduce for North American audiences. But New York got the next-best thing on Saturday, as the Nrityagram Dance Ensemble performed in the Temple of Dendur at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Climber Yearns for the Summit, and a Shower
description: SANTA ROSA, Calif.  Inside Kevin Jorgesons living room, his smiling, bearded face popped up on the screen. His hair, two weeks since a shampoo, stuck straight up.

title: Where Terrorism is Normal (Nigeria) and News (France)
description: Its heartening to see a growing discussion of the lack of attention thats been paid in recent days to the latest atrocities committed in Nigeria by what The Times recently described and mapped asBoko Haram, the other Islamic State.

title: Oil Prices Fall to Lowest Since 2009
description: HOUSTON  Oil prices took another sharp turn downward on Monday to levels not seen since the depths of the 2009 recession. Several international banks predicted even lower prices later this year because of an oversupplied global crude market.

title: No Time for Bats to Rest Easy
description: LEWISBURG, PA.  The 10 hibernating little brown bats hang from a corner of their tailor-made refrigeration chamber at Bucknell University like a clump of old potato skins, only less animated. In torpor, bats become one with their wintry surroundings, their body temperatures falling to just above freezing, their heart rates slowing to one or two beats a minute, their breathing virtually undetectable.

title: Equipped to Body Slam, or Embalm, if Necessary
description: WGN America got off to a strong start last year in its effort to build a national profile, introducing two decent scripted dramas, Salem and Manhattan. How does its latest series, Wrestling With Death, fit into the channels emergent strategy? Perfectly, if that strategy is Lets squander our tidbit of hard-won credibility by serving up a spectacularly idiotic reality show.

title: Brooklyn District Attorney Affirms Conviction in 2003 Killing of Student
description: After an examination by his Conviction Review Unit, the Brooklyn district attorney said on Monday that he would stand by a conviction in the 2003 murder of a popular Fairfield University student athlete.

title: Worlds and Rhythms Meet, in Euphoric Result
description: To a traditionalist, the Nile Project might look like an ungainly mlange: a gathering of musicians from the 11 countries of the Nile basin, playing instruments that werent made to share a stage or a song. They included an Egyptian wooden flute, an oud, African harps, a thumb piano, a saxophone. But at Globalfest, the annual world-music showcase on Sunday night at Webster Hall, the Nile Project was a committed, euphoric international coalition.

title: Performing at Globalfest
description: Images of some of the performers at the world-music showcase Globalfest.

title: Fidelity Introduces Location-Based Stock-Picking App, for Some Reason
description: Its Grindr, but for stocks.

title: With Win, Amazon Shakes Up Yet Another Industry
description: LOS ANGELES  Among the usual names invoked during the acceptance speeches at Sundays Golden Globes  Harvey Weinstein, Scott Rudin, Les Moonves  was an unusual one: the tech billionaire Jeff Bezos, founder and chief executive of Amazon.

title: Facing Opposition, Nominee for Treasury Under Secretary Withdraws
description: Antonio Weiss, a senior investment banker at Lazard, withdrew his name from consideration to be a senior Treasury Department official in the face of liberal opposition Monday, and will instead serve as a counselor to the secretary of the Treasury, Jacob J. Lew.

title: No-Shows in Paris
description: To the Editor:

title: Ways to Fund Research on Rare Diseases
description: To the Editor:

title: Evenhanded on Spending
description: To the Editor:

title: Making It Rain: Members of Congress Are Mostly Millionaires
description: Members of Congress hold a lot of the power in America and, a new report shows, plenty of wealth. In fact, more than half of them are millionaires.

title: Pencil Tower on 57th St.
description: To the Editor:

title: From the Upshot: Romney, Bush and Paul
description: If Mitt Romney Challenges Jeb Bush, Rand Paul Stands to Gain

title: Ratings Suggest Drop for Globes
description: LOS ANGELES  Meaningful ratings data for the 72nd Golden Globes was hard to come by on Monday, as Nielsen worked through technical difficulties. But early information suggested a decline.

title: An Unsettled Chapter in Martin Luther Kings Legacy
description: ATLANTA  The legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. seems to be everywhere these days with the success of the film Selma, which begins with his being awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.

title: Getting From Here to There, but Not in a Straight Line
description: The title of Alexandra Bachzetsiss A to B via C suggests a series of scrambled steps, a beginning and an end linked by a roundabout middle. On Sunday at the Swiss Institute, in its United States premiere, this coolly disarming work revealed many such convoluted structures, favoring switchbacks, detours and double exposures over any linear route.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
description: France and Elsewhere  Pictures of the Day

title: Coachella Organizers in Deal With Hangout Music Festival
description: Since it started in the Southern California desert in 1999, Coachella has become the premier name in pop festivals. Now it is extending its reach to the Alabama coast through a deal with a smaller festival.

title: Silky and Shivery Tones, With Flickers of Heat
description: The concert by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday featured no timpani jolts or cymbal crashes. These were works for strings, after all: trios by Beethoven and Kodaly and the American Quintet by Dvorak. But give these works to fiercely temperamental players, and theyll still find ways to make you jump out of your skin.

title: Quandary: When Cousins Arent Friends
description: In our parenting Quandaries, we pull from the comments, the weekly open thread or email a question that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than one parent. You  the readers  provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family?

title: A Threat to Unionize, and Then Benefits Trickle In for Players
description: BOULDER, Colo.  College football has gone on a roll that would bring a giggle to the lips of King Midas.

title: Pictures of the Day  Jan. 12, 2015
description: Photos from France, Syria, Haiti and the Philippines.

title: Highlights and Analysis: Ohio State Wins National Championship
