description: Couldnt get to a television? Want to discuss the result with other fans? See how the inaugural College Football Playoff championship game between Oregon and Ohio State happened in real time.

title: Choke First, Ask Questions Later
description: The policy couldnt be clearer: Members of the New York City Police Department will NOT use chokeholds, says section 203-11 of the departments Patrol Guide. But as last Julys fatal police assault on Eric Garner showed, reality is messier than the rule book  and more dangerous for civilians.

title: Docker, a Software Start-Up, Sees a Future in Containers of Code
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A tech start-up called DotCloud was on its last legs in 2012. Now called Docker, its software has been downloaded 70 million times.

title: Senate to Debate Keystone XL, Setting Stage for More Energy Battles
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate voted Monday to take up a bill that would force approval of the Keystone XL pipeline, opening a debate on energy and climate change that will preview other clashes to come between President Obama and the new Republican Congress. It will also set the stage for the energy and climate battles of the presidential election next year.

title: A Mine Erodes an Andean City
description: High in the Andes, a smoldering mine eats away at residents whose rich traditions sustained them for generations.

title: Times Reporter Will Not Be Called to Testify in Leak Case
description: WASHINGTON  James Risen, a New York Times reporter, will not be called to testify at a leak trial scheduled to begin this week, lawyers said Monday, ending a seven-year legal fight over whether he could be forced to identify his confidential sources.

title: Netanyahu Visits Paris Supermarket
description: Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, lit a candle outside the kosher supermarket where four Jewish hostages were killed in a terrorist attack on Friday.

title: A Musicians Lament? Carrying On the Instrument
description: BASEBALL cap turned backward, Zachary De Pue stands on the tarmac by the boarding steps of a US Airways Express regional jet in Charlotte, N.C., furiously fiddling the prelude to the Partita No. 3 in E by J.S. Bach on his 250-year-old violin.

title: For French Muslims, a Moment of Truth
description: PARIS  On Friday, after prayers at the Grand Mosque here, the faithful emerged holding banners saying, against the background of the French flag, Touche pas  mon pays, or Hands off my country  echoing the slogan of the French anti-discrimination association SOS Racisme: Touche pas  mon pote, or Hands off my buddy. Other signs proclaimed that the terrorists who killed the journalists at Charlie Hebdo and the customers of a kosher supermarket last week were not true Muslims  as the family of Ahmed Merabet, the Muslim police officer who was killed trying to protect Charlie Hebdo, has poignantly noted.

title: The Meanings of I Am Charlie Hebdo
A Tradition of Ambition
description: For centuries, China has used colossal public works projects like the Great Wall and Three Gorges Dam to showcase its engineering prowess and project its economic might.

title: Conspiracy Theories Mix With Official Condolences
description: MOSCOW  In Russia, reaction to the violence that rocked Paris last week fell quickly into two camps.

title: West Virginia Revisits Science Standards
description: West Virginia joined 25 other states several years ago to help develop a set of standards for teaching science across the United States. Among other topics, the standards acknowledge the overwhelming scientific consensus that climate change is real and has been profoundly affected by human activity.

title: Letter From the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services Ending Federal Benefits to Yorkville Endoscopy
description: Yorkville Endoscopy, the Manhattan clinic where Joan Rivers went into cardiac arrest while being treated for a voice problem, will lose those benefits effective on Jan. 31, the letter said.

title: After Stabilizing, Overdose Deaths Rose in 2013
description: Deaths from drug overdoses rose by 6 percent in 2013 from 2012, the federal government said Monday, reversing progress made in 2012, when the national rate, which had long been increasing, appeared to have stabilized. The 2013 increase was driven in part by a 39 percent jump in heroin deaths, the third consecutive year of increases for that drug. Deaths from opioid pain relievers  the biggest cause of drug overdose deaths  were up by about 1 percent in 2013. In 2012, such deaths declined by 5 percent, the first drop since the late 1990s. That decline helped level out drug overdose deaths overall, for an increase of less than 1 percent from 2011 to 2012.

title: Ethical Questions of Investing in Pot
description: Last week, the venture capital firm run by Peter Thiel  a co-founder of PayPal and an early investor in Facebook, SpaceX and Spotify  invested millions of dollars in a marijuana company.

title: S.&P. Nears Settlement With Justice Dept. Over Inflated Ratings
description: On television and in the courtroom, Standard & Poors has waged war against a Justice Department lawsuit. But behind the scenes, the giant bond-rating agency wants nothing more than to buy peace.

title: Interpol Calls for Arrest of Yanukovych and Other Former Ukrainian Officials
description: MOSCOW  Interpol issued a worldwide directive on Monday seeking the arrest of Viktor F. Yanukovych, the former president of Ukraine, and other former senior officials including Mykola Azarov, who was prime minister, on charges of embezzlement and misappropriation of public funds.

title: Oklahoma: Request to Delay Four Executions Is Denied
description: A federal appeals court on Monday denied the request by four prisoners in Oklahoma to delay their executions, now scheduled for this winter, rejecting their claim that the drugs to be used are unreliable and could result in unconstitutional pain and suffering. The decision in the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit, in Denver, appeared to clear the way for the execution on Thursday of Charles F. Warren, which would be the states first since the botched lethal injection of Clayton D. Lockett in April. Defense lawyers argued that the sedative used in Mr. Locketts case and planned for Mr. Warner, midazolam, has unpredictable effects. But the state said it would multiply the dosage, and has refined procedures to ensure that the drug is properly administered. While defense lawyers said they would appeal to the Supreme Court, legal experts said there was little chance of success.

title: In China, Projects to Make Great Wall Feel Small
description: DALIAN, China  The plan here seems far-fetched  a $36 billion tunnel that would run twice the length of the one under the English Channel, and bore deep into one of Asias active earthquake zones. When completed, it would be the worlds longest underwater tunnel, creating a rail link between two northern port cities.

title: Paris Attacks Expected to Influence Boston Trial
description: BOSTON  A pair of brothers viewed as homegrown Islamic terrorists. Horrible acts of violence. Manhunts that forced the lockdown of entire neighborhoods.

title: Libyan Militants Aligned With Islamic State Claim Kidnapping of 21 Egyptian Christians
description: CAIRO  Libyan militants calling themselves part of the Islamic State said on Monday that they were holding captive 21 Egyptian Christians, raising new fears about the extremist groups spreading influence beyond the battlegrounds of Syria and Iraq.

title: Whats Wrong With All Lives Matter?
description: This is the fifth in a series of interviews with philosophers on racethat I am conducting for The Stone. This weeks conversation is with Judith Butler, Maxine Elliot Professor in the department of comparative literature and the program of critical theory at the University of California, Berkeley. She is the author of numerous influential books, including Dispossession: The Performative in the Political, which she co-authored with Athena Athanasiou. She will publish a book on public assemblies with Harvard University Press this year.  George Yancy

title: As Truck Sales Surge in U.S., Toyota and Nissan Unveil Upgrades
description: DETROIT  Rock music shook the room as the gleaming blue pickup drove up behind Toyotas top American executive, William D. Fay.

title: Brooklyn District Attorney Stands by 21 Convictions, So Far
description: The Brooklyn district attorney, Kenneth P. Thompson, said on Monday that his office would stand by the convictions in 21 murder cases examined by his conviction review unit, including 18 that involved the retired police detective Louis Scarcella.

title: Stellar Passers, Sure, but That May Not Be Enough
description: At Stanford, Andrew Luck was immensely hyped as the next great quarterback prospect. The Indianapolis Colts selected him with the first overall pick in 2012, and remarkably, Luck has managed to meet even the highest of expectations. After helping turn a 2-14 team in 2011 into a playoff team in 2012, Luck won his first playoff game during the 2013 season and has now guided the Indianapolis Colts to the A.F.C. championship game.

title: G.M. Reboots Chevrolet Volt as Automakers Push Electric Cars
description: DETROIT  While sales of new cars and trucks are soaring, demand for electric vehicles is still sputtering along in the slow lane.

title: Francesco Rosi, Italian Filmmaker With Political Bent, Dies at 92
description: Francesco Rosi, a filmmaker who was fascinated with power, poverty and politics, and whose commitment to social issues made him a direct heir to the traditions of Italian neorealist cinema of the postwar years, died on Saturday in Rome. He was 92.

title: Too Soon Gone: Alberto Behar, Who Used Robots and Rubber Ducks to Probe Icy Secrets
description: Alberto Behar, a polar researcher who combined a scientists deep curiosity with an engineers audacious inventiveness, died on Friday when the plane he was flying crashed shortly after he took off from a small airport near his longtime workplace, NASAs Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif.

title: The Child in the Basement
description: Maybe youre familiar with Ursula Le Guins short story, The Ones Who Walk Away from Omelas. Its about a sweet and peaceful city with lovely parks and delightful music.

title: Safety Chief Pressures Carmakers on Recalls
description: DETROIT  The nations new top auto safety official delivered a frank message to carmakers at the Detroit auto show on Monday, demanding that recalls be aggressive, pre-emptive and aim to fix every vehicle they affect.

title: Playing College Moneyball
description: Writing this column on Monday afternoon, I can only guess at the final score of the big game between Ohio State and Oregon. But I certainly know who the winners are in this first ever true national championship college football game.

title: When Jihadists Come Home
Rangers and Knicks Have Same Address, but Theyre on Different Planets
description: Except for the fact that they share an arena and an owner, the Knicks and the Rangers have been going their separate ways for some time now.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 12, 2015
New York Citys ID Card Program Draws a Large Response
description: The applicants clustered on Kissena Boulevard, clutching documents from around the world, trading familiar stories with strangers in a driving rain outside the Queens Library in Flushing. There were the police encounters, the school visits, the fraught hospital trips  all negotiated without the bureaucratic lubricant of local identification.

title: With Rise of Talk Radio, a College Sport Fades as a Staple of the Airwaves
description: Dave Popkin, the play-by-play announcer for Seton Hall mens basketball games, knew things would be different when the team switched radio homes three years ago. After almost two decades on the air with WABC-AM, Seton Halls games moved to WMTR-AM  a 7,000-watt station based in Morristown, N.J. But fans were finding only static.

title: Instacart, a Grocery Delivery Start-Up, Raises $220 Million
description: In the world according to venture capitalists, our daily lives will soon become a lot more convenient.

title: Run Out of Rhythm
description: Administrivial Deb Amlen Sighting Alert! Once again, the Ace Hotel and I will be gently waking up New York City with the January 25th Sunday crossword, and we hope you can join us for trivia, coffee and crossword-solving fun. We invade, sorry, start at 11:00 a.m. in the beautifully appointed Ace lobby, located at 20 West 29th Street. Click here for more information. See you there!

title: New York City Council Discusses Cap on Prices Charged by Car-Service Apps During Peak Times
description: Hypothetically, if there were no traffic on a journey from Times Square to La Guardia Airport, the price of a ride from a car-service app like Uber would be around $41.88. If the journey were to occur around 6 p.m. on a rainy Monday in January, the trip could cost more than twice as much, because Uber increases rates to give drivers incentives to work during peak times.

title: De Blasios Proposed Tax Code Changes Would Affect Businesses Large and Small
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio proposed on Monday to modernize New York Citys corporate tax code to allow the smallest companies to pay less and make it harder for large companies to evade city taxes.

title: Knicks Heading to London as a Ragged Ambassador
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Since the Phoenix Suns and the Utah Jazz opened the 1990-91 N.B.A. season in Tokyo, the league has used parts of its schedule to promote its product overseas.

title: Fear on Rise, Jews in France Weigh an Exit
description: PARIS  French Jews, already feeling under siege by anti-Semitism, say the trauma of the terrorist attacks last week has left them scared, angry, unsure of their future in France and increasingly willing to consider conflict-torn Israel as a safer refuge.

title: Woman Dies After Smoke Fills Washington Metro Tunnel
description: WASHINGTON  One woman aboard a subway train died and 83 other people were taken to hospitals here Monday after a downtown Metrorail tunnel filled with smoke during the late afternoon rush, National Transportation Safety Board officials said. Two of the injured were reported to be in critical condition.

title: Echoes of 83-84: New York Rivalry Stirs Again
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  A game against the first-place Islanders is not familiar territory for the Rangers, or any team for that matter. That makes Tuesday nights clash at Madison Square Garden that much more meaningful.

title: Obama Assures Netanyahu That U.S. Opposes Palestinians Bid to Join Court
description: President Obama told Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Monday that the United States opposed the Palestinian Authoritys bid to join the International Criminal Court, the White House said. Mr. Obama, in a telephone call with Mr. Netanyahu, reiterated the United States position that the Palestinian Authority does not yet constitute a state, and is therefore not eligible to join the court, the administration said in a statement. President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority moved to join the court last month as part of a strategic shift by the Palestinians to pursue statehood on their own after decades of failed negotiations with Israel brokered by the United States. Mr. Obama also told Mr. Netanyahu that Washington wanted a comprehensive deal that would prevent Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon, the White House said.

title: New York City PromotesDiversity in Bid for2016 Democratic National Convention
description: New Yorks diversity, beginning with more than 2.4 million Hispanic residents, puts the city ahead of its rivals for the 2016 Democratic National Convention, supporters of the bid said.

title: The Aftermath of Hurricane Ike
description: Texas officials continued the largest rescue operation in state history, taking thousands of people out of flood-ravaged towns.

title: Germany Anti-Immigrant Protest Grows
description: In Dresden, an estimated 25,000 protestors took to the streets to protest Germanys immigration policies.

title: Big Anti-Immigration Rally in Germany Prompts Counterdemonstrations
description: BERLIN  A public clash about immigration and integration in Germany heated up on Monday as opposing marches took shape  one denouncing the perceived threat posed by Islam, the other a public vigil for an open and tolerant society.

title: At Bess Myersons Former Home, Shades of a Bronx Utopia
description: Everywhere Bess Myerson went growing up, people would stare. At 5 feet 10 inches tall she was already hard to miss, with a figure that was the definition of statuesque, capped by full cheeks and fuller eyebrows. Those looks would help her become Miss America in 1945.

title: Joan Peters, Journalist Who Wrote on Israeli-Palestinian Conflict, Dies at 78
description: Joan Peters, a journalist whose 1984 book, From Time Immemorial: The Origins of the Arab-Jewish Conflict Over Palestine, drew accolades and outrage by arguing that claims of a historical Palestinian homeland in Israel were invented, died on Jan. 5 at her home in Chicago. She was 78.

title: A Tradition of Ambition
description: For centuries, China has used colossal public works projects like the Great Wall and Three Gorges Dam to showcase its engineering prowess and project its economic might.

title: A Scottish Distillery Celebrates 200 Years by Changing Absolutely Nothing
description: Though whisky experts are divided on whether the spirit has a terroir like wine (flavors reminiscent of the place it was made), one sip of any whisky produced on the Scottish island of Islay is enough to suggest that, yes, indeed it does. The salty sea air and characteristic peat infuse aging casks there with a signature brininess and smokiness  and fierce sense of origin. Large-scale distilleries have inhabited the small Hebridean island since 1779, when Bowmore settled in; a new one called Gartbreck is set to open there this spring. And this year Laphroaig, arguably the smokiest of the distilleries on Islay, celebrates its 200th anniversary.

title: Word of the Day | delta
description: delta \del-t\ noun

title: Going Back to College, and Teaching Her Daughters the Value of Education
description: A white Christmas tree and a pair of childrens pink-and-white bicycles lined the entryway of Latisha Hopewells apartment in Lower Manhattan, where her two daughters, Shaun, 11, and Shani, 6, were losing their battle against post-holiday malaise minute by minute.

title: From Big Ten to Big One
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Ezekiel Elliott tucked the ball and barreled through the Oregon defense and into the end zone for another touchdown, and his offensive linemen helped him up and hugged him. Elliott looked exhausted, having carried Ohio State to the brink of the inaugural College Football Playoff championship, and it was the least they could do.

title: Yankees Hire Two Hitting Instructors and Reshuffle Some Coaches
description: When Brian Cashman was interviewing candidates for the Yankees hitting coach opening, they told him that the job was now a two-person assignment.

title: Ohio State Takes Championship
description: Ohio State defeated Oregon to win the inaugural College Football Playoff national championship game, 42-20.

title: Trial Over a Mans Role in a Black Market Begins
description: The trial of Ross W. Ulbricht, safe to say, will be like few that have ever taken place in Federal District Court.

title: West Struggles to Halt Flow of Citizens to War Zones
description: WASHINGTON  For more than a decade, Western governments have struggled to stem the flow of their citizens traveling to fight in war zones in Muslim countries, increasing surveillance of those who have expressed an interest in joining extremists, creating computer programs to track suspicious travel patterns and taking other measures.

title: Whats on TV Tuesday
description: 10 P.M. (TLC) MY BIG FAT FABULOUS LIFE After Whitney Thore received a diagnosis of polycystic ovarian syndrome, this once slender dancer quickly gained more than 200 pounds. Struggling with self-doubt but still eager to dance for all to see, she posted a performance piece on YouTube last January  and it became a viral hit. Eventually she founded the No Body Shame Campaign, a movement created to promote body acceptance, centered on the motto Love yourself. Live fully. No excuses. No shame. This new series follows Ms. Thore as she tries to find happiness through teaching and performing, confronting online bullies, dating and even wearing a bikini on the beach for the first time in a decade.

title: Corrections: January 13, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Leaving would be caving into terrorism. If we leave, the terrorists win.

title: First Playoff, Familiar Champion
description: Ohio State rumbled over Oregon to win the national title in the inaugural College Football Playoff championship game.

title: Mistrial Declared for Ex-Police Chief Who Killed Unarmed South Carolina Man
description: ATLANTA  Faced with a jury that was deadlocked, a South Carolina judge declared a mistrial early Tuesday in the proceedings against a former police chief charged with murder in the 2011 killing of an unarmed black man.

title: Keeping a Promise to Afghans
description: The legacy of Americas war in Afghanistan, which nominally ended on New Years Eve, will come into sharper focus in the coming decade. Historians will spend years figuring out what went right or wrong and which of Washingtons programs will prove to be of lasting value.

title: God, Gays and the Atlanta Fire Department
description: Until last week, Kelvin Cochran was the chief of the Atlanta fire department, where he oversaw a work force of more than 1,000 firefighters and staff.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Games Played by the Laws of Physics (Though Bent a Little in Some Cases)
description: In Games Played by the Laws of Physics (Though Bent a Little in Some Cases), Kit Eaton writes about how some popular games can actually teach about the laws of physics.

title: Pope Says Sri Lanka Must Confront Truth About Its War to Heal
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka  Pope Francis arrived in this capital city on Tuesday and said Sri Lanka must address the wounds from the civil war that convulsed it for more than 25 years.

title: Indonesian Divers Recover AirAsia Voice Recorder
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Indonesian search teams on Tuesday retrieved the second of the so-called black boxes from the AirAsia crash in the Java Sea and also located the aircrafts fuselage, officials said, as they began a new phase of the operation aimed at determining what happened to the plane and recovering the bodies of more victims.

title: Test Yourself | Keeping Those New Years Resolutions
description: Below are several paragraphs from a Jan. 9 article, Turning a New Years Resolution Into Action With the Facts.

title: Falling Oil Prices, a Boon to Airlines, Pose a Challenge for Airbus and Boeing
description: PARIS  Sharply falling oil prices are a boon to airlines, saving billions of dollars in monthly fuel bills for a highly competitive industry that last year eked out an average profit of just $6 a passenger.

title: Anger at Officials Expensive Meal Before Deadly Shanghai Stampede
description: A cover story in the latest issue of Caixin New Century Weekly, a Chinese business magazine, includes important details about the deadly stampede in Shanghai on Dec. 31: howfew police officers were on duty, what preceded the sudden crush that killed 36 people and howemergency vehicles were slowed by the huge crowds that had gathered along the citys famous riverfront to celebrate.

title: The Point of Order
description: The question of whom the police serve, and whose order they impose, is once again up for debate. But it is as old as policing itself. A political cartoon by Charles Jameson Grant, sold for a penny or two on the streets of London around 1834, depicts the British secretary of state addressing members of Londons recently formed Metropolitan Police Force. My lads, he says, you are always justified in breaking the heads of the public when you consider it absolutely necessary for the maintenance of the public peace. The assembled constables, a rough-looking crew, appear perfectly capable of such a task. By Jasus I wish your honor would give us a few throats to cut, one says, for we have had enough of breaking heads.

title: Could Following These Directions Make You Fall in Love With a Stranger?
description: Is there only one, or a small handful, of special someones out there for each of us? Does fate, or perhaps chemistry, make us fall in love?

title: A Mine Erodes an Andean City
description: In the heart of Cerro de Pasco, a Peruvian city perched 14,000 feet in the Andes, a mile-wide mine pit smolders. For residents, the growls of heavy machinery are background noise. Just as ever-present is the hazardous cocktail of smoke and lead that seeps into their air and water. As the mine grows in diameter, it eats away at the city and its residents little by little, said the photographer Paccarik Orue.

title: Egyptian Judge Voids Mubaraks Last Standing Conviction and Orders Retrial
description: CAIRO  Former President Hosni Mubarak embezzled $17.5 million for personal expenses during his last eight years in power, according to billing statements cited as evidence in his only criminal conviction still standing: $5,455 for four La-Z-Boy recliners, $6,336 on a marble mosaic for a sons bathroom, $2,018 for a chess set, and hundreds of other items.

title: Emotion Mixes With Politics as 4 Killed at Paris Market Are Buried in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM  They were buried Tuesday not in the land where they had made their homes but in what was described as their homeland. The funeral for the four Jews killed Friday in a terrorist attack on a kosher market in Paris was at once emotional and political, underscoring the tension roiling in recent days between a call for mass immigration to Israel and a demand to protect diaspora communities.

title: Burberry, McQueen and Others Puncture the Fashion Bubble
description: LONDON  The most telling cameo at the four-day mens wear shows here, the kickoff of the fall 2015 multicity mens fashion circuit, was not from the three-piece-suited David Gandy, the male model better recognized in his Dolce & Gabbana-ad skivvies; the visiting designers of the American labels Public School and Coach in town to show their wares; or any of the unplaceable Brit rockers at Burberry. It was by the most unlikely guest star of all: the plastic bag, making arguably its most prominent cultural appearance since American Beauty.

title: Inflation in Britain Falls to Lowest Rate in 15 Years
description: LONDON  Driven by drastically falling oil prices and lower food prices, British inflation fell to 0.5 percent in December, a steeper drop than was expected and the lowest rate recorded in the past 15 years.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: New York Today: Flash Your ID
description: Greetings on this raw Tuesday morning.

title: Daily Report: Software Start-Up Builds Future on Containers of Code
description: A tech start-up called DotCloud was on its last legs in 2012. Now called Docker, its software has been downloaded 70 million times, Quentin Hardy reports.

title: Maison Martin Margiela Changed Its Name, and No One Noticed
description: Yes, I include myself in the above statement, at least initially (might as well get that out of the way early on). Of all the changes that took place on Monday in London as John Galliano unveiled his new look for the house of Margiela (which was mostly an oldish runway look) and a new look for himself (which involved his take on the Margiela uniform: no makeup  or, most likely, no-makeup makeup  hair pulled back in a low ponytail, dark suit under white lab coat), the new look of the brands name passed almost unnoticed.

title: France Mourns Attack Victims and Takes Steps Against Further Terrorism
description: PARIS  On a day of mourning and defiance, brave words and choking sadness, funerals were held Tuesday in Israel and France for some of those who died in the attacks in Paris last week, and French leaders sought to prevent further attacks while reaffirming the values that their country regards as its defining strengths.

title: 1940: Newsie in Paris Jumps to Death
description: Ike Meltzer, 41 years old, who brought a Broadway accent and the American style of selling papers to the worlds most famous corner  Place de lOpra on the Caf de la Paix angle  jumped out of the fifth-floor window of a building in the Rue Caumartin Friday noon. He died three hours later in a hospital from injuries sustained in crashing through the skylight on the rear courtyard. The war cut off his supply of American dailies but, even more important, it kept thousands of tourists, who had been his customers, out of the combat zone. Moreover the news-vendors wife was seriously ill in London.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 14, 1940

title: The News From France
description: The far-right National Front has made gains following the attack on the offices of Charlie Hebdo.

title: Today in Politics
description: Cant We All Get Along? Obama and Republicans Give It Another Try

title: Oil Output Seen Rising, Despite Fall in Its Price
description: HOUSTON  Even with oil prices continuing to plummet and oil companies decommissioning drilling rigs every day, the Energy Department on Tuesday projected that domestic crude production would continue to rise in 2015, although growth would slow.

title: Morning Agenda: S.&P. Seeks Peace
description: Standard & Poors has publicly fought a Justice Department lawsuit, but behind the scenes, the bond-ratings agency now wants peace, Ben Protess reports in DealBook. After S.&P. mounted a two-year campaign to defeat civil fraud charges  portraying them as retaliation for cutting the credit rating of the United States  the ratings agency is now negotiating with the Justice Department to settle the case, according to people briefed on the matter, he writes.

title: MetLife Sues Over Being Named  Too Big to Fail
description: MetLife sued a panel of regulators led by the Treasury secretary on Tuesday to fight its designation as systemically important, making it the first financial company to go to court over the issue since the government started singling out so-called too-big-to-fail institutions in an effort to stem any future financial crises.

title: Weekly News Quiz | Jan. 6-12, 2015
description: Have you been following the news?

title: Facebook Will Push Amber Alerts to Users News Feeds
description: Amber Alerts, which already buzz your cellphone, light up highway billboards and appear on television and radio broadcasts, will now start showing up in your Facebook feed, too.

title: When Spell-Check Cant Help
description: Heres the latest batch of sound-alike mix-ups, featuring old standbys and new twists.

title: Christie Speech Points to a Presidential Path
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey will hint at the framework for a potential presidential run in his State of the State speech on Tuesday afternoon by highlighting just how bad things were when he won office five years ago and arguing that he brought New Jersey back from the brink of financial and political crisis, aides said.

title: In Performance: Joey Slotnick and C.J. Wilson of Dying for It
description: This weeks video features the actors Joey Slotnick and C.J. Wilson in a scene from the dark comedy Dying for It, an adaptation by the playwright Moira Buffini of Nikolai Erdmans 1928 play The Suicide. Set in Moscow in 1929 over a decade after the Russian revolution, the play tells the story of Semyon Semyonovich (played by Mr. Slotnik), who cannot find a job or any meaning in his life and decides to end it all. In this scene, Semyon discovers that his friend Alexander (Mr. Wilson) is exploiting his proposed suicide for money. The show, directed by Neil Pepe for the Atlantic Theater Company, is at the Linda Gross Theater through Jan. 18.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: Years After Aurora Theater Rampage, Colorado Braces for the Trial
description: DENVER  To choose a jury in the trial of the man charged with killing 12 people in a packed Colorado movie theater, court officials mailed notices to 9,000 people in suburban Arapahoe County, casting such a wide net that residents ran about a one-in-50 chance of being tapped as potential jurors. An uncle, a father, husbands and friends of people who work in the prosecutors office received jury summonses. So did 12 people who are slated to be prosecution witnesses.

title: Bootleg Liquor Kills at Least 23 in India
description: NEW DELHI  At least 23 people died and 200 others were seriously sickened after drinking contaminated moonshine in the northern Indian state of Uttar Pradesh, the authorities said on Tuesday.

title: Ascap Names Elizabeth Matthews as Its Chief
description: Ascap, the giant music licensing agency, has appointed Elizabeth Matthews as its new chief executive, a generational shift as the century-old organization adapts to the digital age.

title: All Raving, No Working
description: Dear Diary:

title: Honoring Victims of the Attacks
description: Hundreds gathered in Jerusalem to bury the four men who were killed last week at a kosher market in Paris, and three slain police officers were honored in France.

title: Meal Deliveries Endorsed by Lena Dunham and the Like
description: Marissa Lippert, a registered dietician and owner-chef at Nourish Kitchen + Table in New York, offers a little perspective to those hoping to reset in 2015: The new year gives us the opportunity to set intentions, rather than unattainable resolutions. Diving into a restrictive detox isnt sustainable, and its certainly not any fun. These four NYC-based meal services, including Lipperts own, are designed for a less punishing post-holiday recovery than juicing alone. And for those strictly shopping for a little motivation (or not within delivery range), each company below has its own blog full of inspiring meal plans and recipes.

title: Angelina Jolie on How Japan May View Unbroken
description: Well know early Thursday whether Angelina Jolies Unbroken, which, after months of anticipatory hoopla, was toasted by the American Film Institute but received no Golden Globes love, will land one of the Academys best picture nominations. Another place where Unbrokens reception remains unknown is Japan, where the book on which the film is based has not been translated and the countrys wartime past is the subject of debate. Though the film has yet to open there, there have been reports of outrage.

title: Selective Voodoo
description: House Republicans have passed a measure demanding that the Congressional Budget Office use dynamic scoring in its revenue projections  taking into account the supposed positive growth effects of tax cuts. It remains to be seen how much damage this rule will actually cause. The reality is that there is no evidence for the large effects that are central to right-wing ideology, so the question is whether CBO will be forced to accept supply-side fantasies.

title: Obama Calls for New Laws to Bolster Cybersecurity
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Tuesday called on Congress to pass broad legislation to bolster cybersecurity across the United States government and private industry, working to capitalize on concern about recent high-profile computer breaches to counter an escalating threat.

title: Ryanair Expects Revised I.A.G. Bid for Irish Airline Aer Lingus
description: LONDON  Ryanair, the largest shareholder of the Irish airline Aer Lingus, said on Tuesday that it expected the parent of British Airways to make another takeover bid for Aer Lingus as soon as this week.

title: No Comment Necessary: Hitler and Obama
description: Randy Weber is a U.S. Representative from Texas. His tweet below contains a very important parenthetical.

title: Museum of Fine Arts, Houston Unveils Expansion Design
description: The Museum of Fine Arts, Houston on Tuesday is to reveal designs by Steven Holl Architects for a redevelopment of its 14-acre campus, including a master plan; a 164,000-square-foot-building for 20th- and 21st-century art; and a new, 80,000-square-foot home for the Glassell School of Art.

title: Amazon Signs Woody Allen to Write and Direct TV Series
description: After more than four decades of making films, Woody Allen is coming to television  streaming television.

title: Why Are We Obsessed With the Great American Novel?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Cheryl Strayed and Adam Kirsch try to get to the bottom of our long-running obsession with the Great American Novel.

title: Pakistan Executes Terrorism Convicts During a Visit by Kerry
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistan executed seven prisoners on Tuesday, including one who had been convicted of taking part in an attack on an American Consulate, as part of a broader crackdown on militancy after last months school massacre in Peshawar.

title: Want to Be Happy? Join a Union
description: Fewer and fewer Americans belong to a union. Membership is down to a historic low of 11.2 percent of the work force, and only 6.7 percent of workers in the private sector.

title: For G.O.P., Precedent to Cooperate and Shed Its Party of No Label
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Shelley Moore Capitos optimism about winning a seat in the Senate is tempered by another reality.

title: Share Your Experiences After the Paris Attacks
description: The New York Times would like to hear from Europeans, particularly Muslims, about their experiences.

title: 1965: Good Skiing Near Madrid
description: MADRID  Skiing in Spain exclaim some with more than a hint of disbelief. Yes, indeed. After only an hours drive from Madrid its possible to be on the snow-covered slopes of the Guadarrama mountains schussing and slaloming. Skiing is not new to Spain or Spaniards. Navacerrada, the ski center near this capital, has been in existence since before the Spanish Civil War. But it is since the war that it has really developed. If there is any doubt that Spaniards like to ski, figures show that on an average Sunday as many as 12,000 of them appear at Navacerrada.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 14, 1965

title: Suburban Poverty, Hidden on Tree-Lined Streets
description: Sticking my hands between the cushions, I blindly dig through the maze of lint and mashed-up cracker pieces. Coming up empty handed, I start to pick at the thin layer of dust that has collected beneath my fingernails. Nervously, I start on my cuticles as well, as I often do when I am stressed.

title: Rikers to Ban Isolation for Inmates 21 and Younger
description: New York City officials agreed on Tuesday to a plan that would eliminate the use of solitary confinement for all inmates 21 and younger, a move that would place the long-troubled Rikers Island complex at the forefront of national jail reform efforts.

title: Eric Church, Ariana Grande and Madonna Among Grammy Performers
description: The performances at the 57th annual Grammy Awards next month will cover the pop landscape from self-proclaimed country outsider Eric Church, who has four nominations, to the next-generation diva Ariana Grande, who has two, the Recording Academy said on Tuesday.

title: At 78, McCain Savors a New Dream Job in the Senate
description: WASHINGTON  One by one, Senator John McCains fellow prisoners from the Vietnam War have been dying, and at 78, he said, he is aware more than ever that his time will come, too. Every single day, he mused in an interview, is a day less that I am going to be able to serve in the Senate.

title: Verbatim: Boehner on 2016
description: Speaker John A. Boehner, when asked if Mitt Romney deserves a third chance at running for president.

title: New Bronx Senior Center Aims to Provide a More Welcoming Atmosphere
description: Tom Esola has become a regular at a senior center in Midtown Manhattan, where he drops by two to three times a week to see friends, sit down to shepherds pie dinners, volunteer in the computer room and even try a tango lesson.

title: Quarterback Is a Work in Progress, but Oh, What Progress
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Cardale Jones was not the most valuable player of college footballs national championship game Monday night. That honor went to the sensational sophomore running back Ezekiel Elliott, his Ohio State teammate, who alternated between safety net and battering ram in the Buckeyes 42-20 pulverizing of Oregon.

title: Spring for Music Festival to Be Reborn in Washington
description: It turns out that spring will come again after all, or at least something like it.

title: Honoring Victims of the Attacks
description: Hundreds gathered in Jerusalem to bury the four men who were killed last week at a kosher supermarket in Paris, and three slain police officers were honored in France.

title: Paris Pays Respects to Slain Officers
description: President Franois Hollande spoke at a burial ceremony in France for the three police officers, including one Muslim, who were killed in last weeks violence.

title: Kamala Harris Announces Senate Bid in California
description: LOS ANGELES  No exploratory committees here. Kamala D. Harris, the California attorney general, announced on Tuesday that she was running for the Senate seat that is opening up with Barbara Boxers impending retirement.

title: A Lost City Haunted by Crooks and Nazis
description: There are many adjectives you can use to describe the fiction of the French novelist Patrick Modiano, winner of the 2014 Nobel Prize in Literature. Elusive is often among them. Timely rarely is.

title: Jazz Festivals in New Orleans and Newport Name Lineups
description: Two of the countrys most significant summer jazz festivals have announced their lineups: the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival and the Newport Jazz Festival.

title: Many Who Take a Daily Aspirin Dont Need It
description: Many healthy people take a daily aspirin to reduce the risk of heart disease and stroke, but a new study has found that more than 11 percent of them should not be doing so.

title: Charlie Hebdos Defiant Muhammad Cover Fuels Debate on Free Speech
description: PARIS  Immediately upon unveiling its new cover  a depiction of Muhammad  the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo on Tuesday reignited the debate pitting free speech against religious sensitivities that has embroiled Europe since 12 people were killed during an attack on its Paris offices by Muslim extremists a week ago.

title: New Report Urges Less Intervention in Births
description: A few weeks ago, Britains national health service advised healthy women that it was safer to have their babies at home, or in a birth center, than in a hospital. For low-risk mothers-to-be, giving birth in a traditional maternity ward increased the chances of surgical intervention.

title: Pope Francis Remarks in Sri Lanka
description: Pope Francis addressed an interfaith audience in Sri Lanka, calling for healing and unity after the countrys civil war.

title: Alibaba Will Help Curb Export of Recalled Items
description: Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce company, has a new partner in rooting out products deemed unsafe for American consumers, but the cooperation could also bring it more headaches.

title: One Democrat Announces While Others Ponder a Race for the Senate in California
description: LOS ANGELES  No exploratory committees here: Kamala D. Harris, the California attorney general, announced on Tuesday that she was running for the Senate seat that is opening up with Barbara Boxers retirement.

title: For Li Na, Retirement Has Been a Busy Time
description: Uncertainty abounds heading into the Australian Open, the first Grand Slam event of the season, which begins next week in Melbourne. But one thing is for sure: There will be a different champion on the womens side. Li Na, who won the Australian Open last year after being runner-up in 2011 and 2013, retired in September because of persistent knee problems. Li, who became the first Grand Slam singles champion from Asia when she won the French Open in 2011, reached a career high of No. 2 last year.

title: Verbatim: United by Football
description: President Obama to Speaker John A. Boehner during a meeting with congressional leaders on Tuesday. Mr. Boehner is from Ohio and is a fan of Ohio State, which won last nights championship game against Oregon, 42-20.

title: Seeing Beauty in Talking Heads
description: At the core of The Kill Team, one of 15 films shortlisted for the best documentary Oscar, is a moral dilemma with life-and-death consequences.

title: New Analysis Challenges Arguments for Repealing Tax on Medical Devices
description: WASHINGTON  A tax on medical devices, imposed by the Affordable Care Act, has become a prime target for Republicans, some Democrats and a small army of lobbyists for the industry. But a new report from the Congressional Research Service challenges economic arguments that are being made to justify repealing the tax.

title: Upland
description: Classic California cuisine on Park Avenue South

title: Restaurant Review: Upland on Park Avenue South
description: Go to Upland is my current answer to anybody who asks for a good new place to eat in Manhattan. It will probably remain my answer for some time. The recommendation is the same for fetishists who unwind by reconstructing recipes from the court of Catherine de Medici as for parishioners in the Church of St. Rachael. It holds for drinkers who are on the lookout for unexplored grapes and for those who call all white wine chardonnay. The only diners I would not send to Upland are the ones who categorically refuse to take any meals along Park Avenue South. Their loss.

title: Mix Diskerud Signs With New York City F.C.
description: New York City F.C. completed the signing of midfielder Mix Diskerud on Tuesday, bolstering a midfield  and a club  trying to regain its footing since the recent announcement that another of its high-profile signings would not arrive in time for the start of the teams inaugural season.

title: Honoring Victims of the Attacks
description: Hundreds gathered in Jerusalem to bury the four men who were killed last week at a kosher market in Paris, and three slain police officers were honored in France.

title: Who Needs a Waiter to Sing When You Have John Boehner?
description: Those in Washington are familiar with the Boehner birthday song, the original song that Speaker John A. Boehner and his family sing to anyone in earshot who is celebrating a birthday.

title: Rage and Reaganolatry
description: A bit more on the curious back and forth between myself and Robert Samuelson. It started when I made the commonplace point that normally the Fed, not the White House, is responsible for managing booms and busts, and that the great disinflation of the 1980s was basically a story of a Fed-imposed recession, and had little if anything to do with Reagans supply-side tax cuts.

title: Putin Wont Attend Commemoration of Auschwitz Liberation
description: WARSAW  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia will not be attending the 70th anniversary commemoration of the liberation of the Auschwitz concentration camps, his spokesman told a Moscow radio station on Tuesday. The spokesman said that the presidents schedule was too packed and that he was not invited.

title: NASAs Dawn Spacecraft Maps the Surface of Ceres
description: Dawn is mapping the dwarf planet Ceres, a Texas-size ball of ice and rock.

title: Prime Rib
description: Roast beef makes a comeback, though at some restaurants it never really left.

title: Polanski Says Hell Cooperate With Poland as It Weighs Extradition Request
description: WARSAW  Roman Polanski has promised to cooperate with the Polish authorities after theyreceived an extradition requestfrom the United States, which the filmmaker fled before final sentencing on a statutory rape charge in 1978.

title: Not Just Any Piece of Meat
description: As Cherche Midi sailed toward its opening date on the Bowery last year, the restaurants owner, Keith McNally, summoned his two chefs so he could sample and critique the dishes they had dreamed up for the French-inspired menu.

title: A Trip Down Euromemory Lane
description: Jean-Claude Trichet, June 2010:

title: In Colorado, a New Ski Program at a Restored Resort
description: Dunton Hot Springs resort, a restored 19th-century mining town in the San Juan Mountains in the Colorado Rockies, has started a Nordic ski program in partnership with the former two-time Olympian Wendy Wagner.

title: The Future of France
description: Here are three points, or maybe three elaborations, that didnt make it into my Sunday column on why the fate of Europe may be heavily shaped by the future trajectory of France, and then one point I did make that deserves a caveat.

title: Directors Guild Unveils Nominees: Shoo-Ins, Long Shots and a Snub (for Selma)
description: The Directors Guild of America has released its slate of feature-film nominees (the winner will be announced on Feb. 7) and they are:

title: Christies National Aspirations Underlie State Speech
description: TRENTON  As Gov. Chris Christie delivered his State of the State address on Tuesday, it sounded less like the valedictory of a presidential hopeful on his way to bigger and better things than a defensive move by a politician anticipating the shots that could be leveled against him.

title: Images of Pluto From NASAs New Horizons Spacecraft
description: The New Horizons probe flew past Pluto and its moons early Tuesday morning.

title: Senior Rebel From Uganda to Be Moved to the Hague
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  A recently captured Ugandan rebel commander who is accused of helping plan massacres and kidnap countless children will be handed over to the International Criminal Court, Ugandan and Western officials said on Tuesday.

title: MetLifes Decision to Challenge Regulators May Backfire
description: Challenging regulators can often come back to bite you. JPMorgan Chase proved this by publicly questioning the reforms of the Dodd-Frank Act and then privately failing to rein in some particularly problematic behavior by some of its traders. Thats what makes MetLifes decision to take its watchdogs to court so surprising.

title: Supreme Court Takes Broad View on Hostage-Takers Penalty
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday unanimously ruled that bank robbers are subject to mandatory 10-year sentences if they force others to accompany them, even for very short distances.

title: A Vintage-Inspired New Video From the Singer-Songwriter Tom Brosseau
description: I have all these cinematic ideas, but when it comes to filming its all Greek to me, says Tom Brosseau about Roll Along with Me, the first single and video from his forthcoming album, Perfect Abandon. Luckily, Brosseau found a kindred spirit and co-conspirator in the director Andrew van Baal early on in his career. The two met in San Diego in the early 2000s, and since then, van Baal has directed a number of music videos for Brosseau, as well as casting him as the lead in van Baals 2012 short film, Wonder Valley.

title: No, I Havent Given Up on Anonymous Sources
description: On Twitter this week, the journalist Peter Maass pointed out an example of a Times story that used anonymous sourcing heavily.

title: On Washington Metro, a Death Is Rare but Problems Are Almost Daily
description: WASHINGTON  An incident Monday in which one passenger was killed and scores were hurt when smoke filled a Washington Metro car during a chaotic rush hour commute has raised new concerns about Washingtons aging, troubled transit system.

title: Three Signs Pointing to Bigger Raises in 2015
description: All eyes are on wages. For workers who have faced six years of stagnant pay, Federal Reserve officials trying to decide when they can safely raise interest rates, or anyone who wants the United States economy to experience a truly robust recovery, the single biggest question about the economy in 2015 is whether pay raises will become more commonplace.

title: Israel Remembers Jewish Paris Victims
description: The Israeli president, the prime minister and the wife of one of the four Jewish victims in a Paris kosher market attack spoke at the burial ceremony for the slain men in Jerusalem.

title: MoMA to Sell a Monet in London
description: The cover of Sothebys London Impressionist and modern art sale catalog features Les Peupliers  Giverny, one of Monets depictions of poplar trees in the fields at the edge of his property in Giverny. Painted in 1887, it captures the sunset of early autumn. Sothebys is auctioning the work on Feb. 3; it is estimated to sell for $13.8 million to $18.4 million.

title: Richard Branson Enters the City Hotel Scene
description: Sir Richard Branson, the billionaire British entrepreneur, has created hundreds of enterprises, from airlines to mobile phone businesses to a cruise line, and oversees more than 50,000 employees. One of his most recent ventures, the space tourism company Virgin Galactic, had a significant setback in November: a pilot was killed in a flight test accident just months before commercial service was to begin. (We continue to be excited by the challenge of space  and make no mistake it is a huge challenge, Mr. Branson said. I am extremely proud of the team in Mojave who are driving our program forward.)

title: Restaurant Report: Caf ArtScience in Cambridge, Mass.
description: If David Edwards was ever told as a child not to play with his food, he didnt listen. The Harvard bioengineering professor and founder of the design center Le Laboratoire in Paris has invented, among other things, WikiPearl, edible, skinlike packaging for everything from ice cream to water, and Le Whaf, which turns things like cocktails and soup into inhalable vapor. Both are available at his latest venture, Caf ArtScience, which opened in October near M.I.T. alongside the first stateside version of Le Laboratoire  and aims to blend a French-American menu with palatable technology.

title: Verbatim: Exploring All Options
description: Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, encouraged his friend Mr. Graham, of South Carolina, to consider a bid for president after being asked about Mitt Romneys announcement that he may run for a third time.

title: Covering the Knicks: A Reporters Dilemma
description: Last week, basketball fans may have noticed that The Timess dedicated Knicks reporter, Scott Cacciola, was writing about something different: an undefeated womens college basketball team from Kansas playing in Missouri. On Monday, he reported on a Division III college basketball rivalry in Michigan.

title: Audra McDonald and Alan Cumming in a Reading of Kiss of the Spider Woman
description: Could a Broadway revival of the acclaimed musical Kiss of the Spider Woman be on the horizon? A multiday reading of the show, the 1993 Tony Award winner for best musical, was held last week with three big theater names playing the major roles: Audra McDonald as the title character, Alan Cumming as the gay prisoner Molina, and Steven Pasquale as the Marxist revolutionary Valentin. The Tony-winning director John Tiffany (Once) oversaw the reading, which was organized by the producer Tom Kirdahy (Its Only a Play). Mr. Kirdahy is married to the shows book writer, Terrence McNally, and is working with the Spider Woman composer, John Kander, on this springs Broadway revival of The Visit. (Spider Woman has lyrics by Fred Ebb.)

title: Lawyers for Don Siegelman, Ex-Governor of Alabama, Again Seek His Release From Prison
description: ATLANTA  For the second time in less than a month, lawyers for former Gov. Don E. Siegelman of Alabama on Tuesday took his corruption case into a federal courtroom in an attempt to speed his eventual release from prison.

description: The New York School, 1969 includes many works curated by Henry Geldzahler in his trailblazing contemporary exhibition.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  As the world focused last week on the attacks by Islamist extremists in Paris, hopes were fading for the latest effort to wind down the war in Syria, a conflict seen as driving radicalization among Muslims worldwide.

description: Pizza Hut, one of the worlds largest pizza purveyors, is adding gluten-free pizza to its lineup this month.

title: George Pataki for President?

George Pataki announced he would be the first Republican this year to test his presidential fever in New Hampshire, the first 2016 primary state.

description: NEW DELHI  The government of Goa, on Indias western coast, is setting up a program to get young gay people to lead a normal life, according to the states minister for sports and youth affairs.

title: Asking Warren to Run, and Not Taking No for an Answer
description: Its not that those who are trying to persuade Senator Elizabeth Warren to run for president arent listening to her repeated declarations that she is not, in fact, going to run for president. Their persistence is based on the hope that they can change her mind.

description: LONDON  For spies as for C.E.O.s, the rule of thumb is evidently the same: Dress for the job you want.

title: The Mets Groundbreaking Henrys Show Gets a Reprise
description: Im Henry  just Henry. Indeed, that sensibility served Henry Geldzahler well. The charismatic curator, short in stature and large in vitality, in 1969 convinced that stodgiest of institutions  the Metropolitan Museum of Art  to, for a blockbuster exhibition, swap its Rembrandts and Renoirs for Rosenquists and Rauschenbergs. Formally titled New York Painting and Sculpture: 1940-1970, the exhibition was colloquially dubbed Henrys Show, which stuck in the history books as its proper name. That show contained nearly 410 works by more than 40 artists  the very catalysts of contemporary art whose fabled exploits, fueled by creativity, community and feuds, composed the history of the New York School. And many of these artists counted Geldzahler as a close personal friend. Frank Stella famously said, The thing about Henry was that he lived with us. Other curators dont live with artists. Another thing about Geldzahler, according to David Hockney: Henry had a fantastic eye. He wasnt wrong about anything. He was always right.

title: Thank You for Supporting The Collection
description: Dear readers,

title: Bill de Blasio and the N.Y.P.D.: Everyone Calls for an Apology
description: In New York City, a former mayor, Rudy Giuliani, is demanding that the current mayor, Bill de Blasio, apologize to the New York Police Department for hurting its feelings. The head of the police union, Patrick Lynch, and former Police Commissioner, Raymond Kelly, are saying the same thing  that all the bitterness between Mr. de Blasio and the police would evaporate, and everything would be O.K., if only the mayor would say he was sorry.

title: An Artist Favored by the U.S. Embassy in Pakistan
description: Jennifer Nocons solo show You See Ocean I See Sky opens tomorrow and uses pattern to reflect human behavior  and the possibility of change.

title: Obama Is Planning New Rules on Oil and Gas Industrys Methane Emissions
description: WASHINGTON  In President Obamas latest move using executive authority to tackle climate change, White House officials on Wednesday announced plans to impose new regulations on the oil and gas industrys emissions of methane, a powerful greenhouse gas. The administrations goal is to cut methane emissions from oil and gas production by up to 45 percent by 2025 from the levels recorded in 2012.

title: A Five-Bedroom House With Views of the Julian Alps
description: The stone-and-stucco farmhouse near the Italian border is on the market for $1.01 million.

title: A Reason to Believe in the Buckeyes
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  With 28 seconds left in the national championship game, Ohio State running back Ezekiel Elliott scored his fourth and final touchdown. After celebrating in the end zone, he ran to the sideline, where he slapped hands with one of the most famous athletes in the world, LeBron James, who banged Elliotts helmet with pride as Elliott jogged off to be with his teammates.

title: In Search for Love, Pitfalls Prevail
description: Man Seeking Woman, a wispily surreal anti-romantic comedy beginning on Wednesday on FXX, has an all-star team of writing and directing talent working to keep it airborne. Lorne Michaels of Saturday Night Live is an executive producer, and other key players include Ian Maxtone-Graham (The Simpsons), Jonathan Krisel (Portlandia, Kroll Show), Robert Padnick (The Office) and Dan Mirk (Onion News Network).

title: Out There
description: Scenic tours through the Milky Way and beyond.

title: IBM Introduces z13, a Mainframe for the Smartphone Economy
description: They seem a computing odd couple: the mainframe, the old workhorse, and the smartphone, the cool-kid computer of today.

title: Winter Tales of Speed and Distance
description: Athletes at the 2014 Winter Games barrel down an icy chute at 80 miles per hour and fly more than the length of a football field off a jump, among other physical feats. In these videos, learn their tricks and techniques  and then see how they used them to take home the gold.

title: A Stalwart at the Metropolitan Museum of Art to Step Down
description: For members of the press, Harold Holzer has been as much a staple of the Metropolitan Museum of Art as the Arms and Armor wing. He seemed to try to move on before  in 2005, when he was given additional responsibility for visitor services and the Multicultural Audience Development Initiative, and in 2013, when he assumed the new title of senior vice president for public affairs.

title: Preparing for a Life Without the Male Gaze
description: If you wanted to spend some time contemplating death  your own, other peoples  Abrons Arts Center on the Lower East Side was a good place to be on Monday night. As part of the American Realness festival, two very different shows  Michelle Ellsworths cheerfully wacky Preparation for the Obsolescence of the Y Chromosome and a much darker work by Jeremy Wade with an obscenity in its title  grappled with disappearance, decline and the thin line between being here and being gone.

title: California Regulator Pushes to Suspend Ocwen Financials License in State
description: Ocwen Financial, the subprime mortgage servicing firm that has already been under intense regulatory scrutiny in New York State, is now entangled with a California regulator in a dispute that complicates the companys ability to operate in that state.

title: From the Prosaic, Evoking a Sadness Under the Surface
description: Thomas Benjamin Snapp Pryor is the producer of American Realness, a dance and performance festival that he founded in 2010. He is also the manager of several artists. His main client is Miguel Gutierrez, who has appeared at American Realness every year. At the Abrons Arts Center on Monday, the festival presented four premieres. One was by the excellent Tere OConnor. One was Mr. Gutierrezs latest work, Age & Beauty Part 2: Asian Beauty @ the Werq Meeting or The Choreographer & Her Muse or &:@&.

title: 10 Are Killed in Ukraine as Diplomacy Hits a Wall
description: MOSCOW  A shell or rocket fired at an army checkpoint in southeastern Ukraine on Tuesday gutted a passenger bus and killed 10 people in one of the deadliest attacks on civilians since a precarious cease-fire in the conflict was negotiated in early September.

title: New Charlie Hebdo Cover Creates New Questions for U.S. News Media
description: After the killings at the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo last week by Islamist extremists, other news media, including web-based outlets, chose to republish some of its cartoons that many Muslims found so offensive.

title: France Without Jews Is Not France
description: Long before Chrif Kouachi burst into the offices of Charlie Hebdo last Wednesday with his brother Sad to assassinate the journalists and cartoonists gathered at the satirical magazines weekly editorial meeting, he had a dream. Mr. Kouachi wanted, according to testimony given at a 2008 court hearing, to burn synagogues, vandalize Jewish stores in Paris and terrorize the Jews. We know that dream was shared by Amedy Coulibaly, the gunman who laid siege to a kosher supermarket in Paris on Friday and killed four of the terrified hostages  Yoav Hattab, Yohan Cohen, Philippe Braham and Franois-Michel Saada  for one reason: They were Jews.

title: Mitt Romney and the Melee
description: Theres an adage in my business that its not news when a dog bites a man, only when a man bites a dog.

title: Bolt
description: A London exhibition examines a ballet choreographed in 1931 by Fyodor Lopukhov to a score by Shostakovich, and why it was banned in the Soviet Union.

title: Revisiting a Soviet Ballet That Was Banned in 1931
description: LONDON  For most in the West, ballet history moves from the establishment of classicism in Russia in the 19th century (Swan Lake, Sleeping Beauty) to the early-20th-century innovations of Diaghilevs Ballets Russes, which shifted the center of balletic gravity to the West. But while the radical propositions of Fokine, Nijinsky and Balanchine were playing out under the Ballets Russes banner in Paris and London during the first decades of the 20th century, an entirely different current and aesthetic  almost completely unknown and unseen outside of Russia  was flourishing under Soviet rule.

title: After Moguls Come Lifes Bumps
description: PARK CITY, Utah  On a dais with eight other members of the United States national ski and snowboarding team, Hannah Kearney, owner of Olympic gold and bronze medals in freestyle moguls, was asked last week if a recent World Cup victory  the 43rd of her career  gave her reason to reconsider her retirement at seasons end.

title: Ruben Ostlunds Involuntary, Play and The Guitar Mongoloid

The Film Society of Lincoln Center is holding a retrospective of Mr. Ostlunds movies through Jan. 22. The series, titled In Case of No Emergency: The Films of Ruben Ostlund, includes the three features that preceded Force Majeure, all receiving their first runs in New York.

title: A History of Christianity, With No Strings Attached
description: The long, tumultuous history of Christianity reels by like a silly cartoon in The Cardinals, an uninspired and interminable show being presented as part of the Under the Radar festival. The concept behind the production, which comes from a theater troupe called Stans Cafe of Birmingham, England, posits that three cardinals are on an evangelical mission to broaden knowledge of the Bible  through their traveling puppet theater, according to a note on the Public Theater website. Alas, the puppets get lost in transit, so the cardinals must jump into the fray to enact famous scenes from the Old and New Testaments.

What does it take to be lonesome? Nothing at all!, band members sang, in hearty harmony over rowdy guitars, as they wound up their set at the Music Hall of Williamsburg on Monday night, a show that was webcast on Yahoo.

As Tobi, a dance instructor at Juilliard, Mr. Stewart offers a study in self-protective vanity. The character  flamboyant, forever peppering his chatter with French phrases and far too insistent that his guests eat the party mix  is at once extroverted and antisocial, a combination easy to overplay.

Specialists in the classical dance forms of India fly in from around the world to perform  barefoot, wearing anklets laden with tiny bells, elaborate costumes, ornaments and jewels.

Smoothly schematic and ferociously unsentimental, the movie has been separated into several alternating voices, but its overall trajectory mirrors the arc of the sweeping double staircase that fronts the wealthy familys mansion. Each side of the staircase leads to the same luxurious entrance and all that shimmers and gleams beyond, except that not everyone manages the climb with equal success.

title: Georgia: Fight Over King Legacy Is Closer to Trial
description: Lawyers for Bernice King, the daughter of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., squared off Tuesday against lawyers for Dr. Kings estate in an effort to resolve the disputed ownership of the slain civil rights leaders Bible and Nobel Prize. But a Fulton County Superior Court judge declined to side with either party, raising the possibility of a February trial. Ms. King contends that the items do not belong to the Estate of Martin Luther King Jr. Inc. The estates three directors are Ms. King and her two brothers, Dexter King and Martin Luther King III. The brothers voted earlier to sell the items. Ms. King objects to a sale.

title: In New Congress, Wall St. Pushes to Undermine Dodd-Frank Reform

description: DETROIT  Elon Musk, chief executive of the electric car company Tesla, urged traditional automakers to step up their efforts at electrifying automobiles, saying that with gasoline prices hovering in the $2-a-gallon range, high fuel prices can no longer be expected to drive consumers toward alternatives.

title: Islams Problem With Blasphemy

People around the world have asked (but, as in the past, have not all seriously examined) this question since last weeks horrific attacks on the French satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo and on a kosher supermarket in Paris.

title: Newspaper in Israel Scrubs Women From a Photo of Paris Unity Rally
description: JERUSALEM  Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany was right there next to the president of France on Sunday, marching through the streets of Paris for all the world to see  all the world, that is, except the readers of an ultra-Orthodox newspaper in Israel.

title: We Need Another Giant Protest
description: President Obama was criticized for failing to attend, or send a proper surrogate to, the giant antiterrorism march in Paris on Sunday. That criticism was right. But it is typical of American politics today that we focus on this and not what would have really made the world feel the jihadist threat was finally being seriously confronted. And that would not be a march that our president helps to lead, but one in which hes not involved at all. That would be a million-person march against the jihadists across the Arab-Muslim world, organized by Arabs and Muslims for Arabs and Muslims, without anyone in the West asking for it  not just because of what happened in Paris but because of the scores of Muslims recently murdered by jihadists in Pakistan, Yemen, Iraq, Libya, Nigeria and Syria.

title: Can Jeb Bush Defy the Tea Party and Win?
description: Can Jeb Bush win the Republican presidential nomination while defying the most ideologically committed wing of his party?

title: Bonnaroo Festival Lineup: Billy Joel, Mumford & Sons, Kendrick Lamar and More
description: Those deciding between the slate of summer music festivals can now make a more educated pick: Following lineup announcements from Coachella, Governors Ball and various jazz gatherings, Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival, the recovering jam band carnival known for its sprawling, tie-dyed campsites, has revealed its 2015 bill.

title: In a Safer Age, U.S. Rethinks Its Tough on Crime System
description: Bullets were flying in the cities. Crack wars trapped people in their homes. The year was 1994, and President Bill Clinton captured the grim national mood, declaring gangs and drugs have taken over our streets as he signed the most far-reaching crime bill in history.

title: Murder Plot Suspect Says Boss Threatened His Life
description: A former Army sniper accused of working as a contract killer said in court papers this week that he had been ensnared in the case by his onetime boss, who, he contends, threatened to kill him if he failed to follow orders.

description: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Tuesday sharpened his opposition to a City Council bill that would criminalize the use of chokeholds by New York City police officers, promising to veto the proposed legislation if it reached his desk.

description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.  The Justice Department on Tuesday pressed ahead with the prosecution of a former Central Intelligence Agency official, a day after it said it would not force a reporter for The New York Times to testify at the trial.

title: Residents Get a Chance to Put Their Own Stamp on a Bronx Park
description: Troy Faux, 36, wanted brighter lights and longer benches around the basketball courts. Jose Rodriguez dreamed of new and improved sprinklers to entertain his 2-year-old daughter on hot summer days. And Jahiem Mewborn-Dozier, 9, longed for a roof over the basketball courts, as well as cellphone charging stations and barbecues.

title: Let Them Eat Foie Gras
description: The lifting of the California ban against selling foie gras (the hyperfattened liver of geese or ducks, brought about by overfeeding the live animals) is pretty much a nonissue, except to point out that as a nation we have little perspective on animal welfare. To single out the tiniest fraction of meat production and label it cruel is to miss the big picture, and the big picture is this: Almost all meat production in the United States is cruel.

title: Washington Governor Seeks New Taxes as a Court Order Looms
description: OLYMPIA, Wash.  Gov. Jay Inslee, a Democrat, stepped to the rostrum in the ornate House chamber of the Capitol here on Tuesday and called for the biggest increase in new tax dollars in state history.

title: Bohemian Looks From the Resort Collections

In one of the strongest resort outings, at Miu Miu, Miuccia Pradas girls slinked down the runway in psychedelic printed dresses and pantsuits. The following season, Hedi Slimane showed a free-spirited look for Saint Laurent featuring patchwork suede jackets and dresses that are sure to be in high demand come spring. But for those who cant wait that long, these pieces from the resort collections  in stores now  are every bit as groovy.

title: Whats On TV Wednesday
description: 8:20 P.M. (Starz Cinema) HELLO I MUST BE GOING (2012) A divorced 30-something (Melanie Lynskey, above, now starring in HBOs Togetherness) finds a haven from her adult problems in the suburban Connecticut home of her critical mother (Blythe Danner) and indulgent father (John Rubinstein) in this comedy written by Sarah Koskoff and directed by Todd Louiso. She also discovers sex and romance with a 19-year-old  the stepson (Christopher Abbott) of a potential client her father is desperate to impress  who has allowed his doting mother (Julie White) to believe he is gay. Needless to say, there are complications, some farcical, some belonging more to the realm of therapeutic melodrama, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. This is ultimately a tale of affirmation, self-acceptance and second chances, and its lessons, while not unwelcome, are a bit too forced and neatly packaged to make it fully satisfying. But when Ms. Lynskey and Mr. Abbott are together, there are inklings of a wilder, riskier, less predictable movie  one you may wish the characters could escape into, even though you know they never will.

title: Thomas Graboys, Doctor Who Wrote of Parkinsons Fight, Dies at 70
description: When he was just 5 years old, Thomas Graboys declared that he intended to become a doctor. As a young physician, he visited a nephew serving in the Peace Corps in Mauritania and remained for two months, treating dozens of patients a day.

title: Walter Berns, Whose Ideas Fueled Neoconservative Movement, Dies at 95
description: Walter Berns, a distinguished constitutional scholar and government professor whose disgust with Cornell Universitys response to the armed takeover of a campus building by black students propelled him to become a leading voice of the neoconservative movement, died on Saturday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 95.

title: In Ensenada, Cheap Mexican Charms Await
description: For as long as I can remember, Ensenada has had a whiff of south-of-the-border excess and spring-break stigma. Less than two hours from San Diego, down the Baja California peninsula, its one of the easiest and safest places to experience Mexico on a budget  which makes it easy to think of this small coastal city and cruise line layover as a sort of Mexico for Beginners. But dismissing northwest Baja is a mistake. Beyond the souvenir shops selling sombreros, knockoff artesana (handicrafts) and tacky T-shirts, theres a college town, a port town and a budding culinary capital that invite exploration. While Ensenada and the surrounding area can require a bit of patience, its pleasures are worth the time it takes to find them  and all the more so because they can be had so affordably.

title: Google Translate App Gets an Upgrade
description: The idea of a universal translator  a device that can seamlessly translate between languages  has been a longtime fixture in science fiction.

title: Hong Kong Leader Says Yielding to Protesters Could Stir Chaos

title: I Owe It All to Community College
description: IN 1974, I graduated from Skyline High School in Oakland, Calif., an underachieving student with lousy SAT scores. Allowed to send my results to three colleges, I chose M.I.T. and Villanova, knowing such fine schools would never accept a student like me but hoping theyd toss some car stickers my way for taking a shot. I couldnt afford tuition for college anyway. I sent my final set of stats to Chabot, a community college in nearby Hayward, Calif., which, because it accepted everyone and was free, would be my alma mater.

title: Why a Generation of Adoptees Is Returning to South Korea
description: Laura Klunders newest tattoo runs down the inside of her left forearm and reads K85-160, a number that dates to her infancy. Klunder was 9 months old when her South Korean mother left her at a police station in Seoul. The police brought her to Holt Childrens Services, a local adoption agency, where a worker assigned Klunder the case number K85-160. It was only two weeks into 1985, but she was already the 160th child to come to the agency that month, and she would go on to be one of 8,800 children sent overseas from South Korea that year. Klunder became part of the largest adoption exodus from one country in history: Over the past six decades, at least 200,000 Korean children  roughly the population of Des Moines  have been adopted into families in more than 15 countries, with a vast majority living in the United States.

title: Finding Robert Frank, Online
description: The cover image for the U.S. edition of The Americans, Robert Franks epochal book, spoke volumes about the state of the nation in the mid-1950s. The tightly-cropped photo shows passengers in the windows of a New Orleans trolley assuming their place in the social order of the Jim Crow South  progressing from a black woman in the rear to white children and adults up front (slide 4).
