description: Lively Morgue Tumblr 462 & 463

title: Cuomo Selects Another Democrat for New Yorks Highest Court
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo selected a Democratic judge from western New York to fill the last open seat on the states highest court, continuing his effort to move the seven-judge panel to the left.

title: The Kings Theater to Reopen in Brooklyn
description: A panoramic view of the Kings, which was completed by the Loews Corporation between 1929 and 1930, and is reopening on Feb. 3 following a $95 million renovation.

title: The Paradise Theater in the Bronx
description: A panoramic view of this former Wonder Theater, which was designed by John Eberson and modeled on a Venetian doges palace.

title: The Loews Jersey in Jersey City
description: A panoramic view of the mezzanine level of the lobby of the Loews Jersey, in Journal Square, a Wonder Theater that opened in 1929 and is now run by a nonprofit group.

title: The Valencia in Jamaica, Queens
description: A panoramic view of the Valencia, opened by Loews Corporation in 1929. Designed by John Eberson, this Wonder Theater was modeled on a Spanish villa, and features a trompe-loeil of an Old World courtyard in the auditorium. This is just the lobby.

title: The United Palace Theater, 175th Street in Manhattan
description: A panoramic view of the United Palace, a former Wonder Theater now run by a religious organization that has formed partnerships with an in-house booking agency for concerts and a community programming group.

title: Across the New York Area, Restoring Wonder Theater Movie Palaces to Glory
description: On Feb. 3, concertgoers will walk into a world of Jazz Age beauty at the newly renovated Kings Theater on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn. A grand lobby of walnut-paneled walls and Corinthian columns will be lit from above by massive Art Deco chandeliers, and almost 4,000 feet of newly woven gold and scarlet carpet  reconstructed from a remnant discovered beneath an old candy counter  will stretch underfoot. The theaters grand reopening, 86 years after it was first introduced to the public, will feature a performance by Diana Ross.

title: Group Urges New York City to End Credit Checks by Employers
description: New York City employers use credit checks to screen applicants for all sorts of jobs, like dog-walking and janitorial work. A coalition of municipal labor leaders, liberal advocates and left-leaning City Council members is seeking to end that practice, saying it disproportionately harms blacks and Hispanics without accurately predicting fraud or poor job performance.

title: Missing New Jersey Man Is Found Dead in the Trunk of His Car
description: A northern New Jersey man who disappeared this week and was believed to have been kidnapped was found dead in the trunk of his car in the Bronx on Thursday, according to law enforcement officials.

title: Letter From Coalition to de Blasio and City Council Pushing Ban on Credit Checks by Employers
description: The coalition said it wanted to ensure that unjustified exemptions were not written into a bill that would end the practice.

title: Bronx Stabbing Leaves One Dead and Another Hospitalized
description: A stabbing in the lobby of a co-op building in the Bronx on Thursday left one man dead and another hospitalized, the police said.

description: WASHINGTON  How could hundreds of bags of intravenous saline solution meant for training health care workers have been given to real patients?

description: propulsive \pr-pl-siv\ adjective

title: Chinese Anticorruption Agency Investigates a Security Official
description: HONG KONG  A senior official in Chinas Ministry of State Security faces investigation by the Communist Partys central anticorruption agency, the agency announced on Friday, breaching the wall of secrecy that usually protects the powerful ministry.

title: Regime Change in Switzerland
description: Blogging will be limited for the next few days, unless I can resolve the tech problems here in Delhi. But I did want to say something about the Swiss de-pegging, beyond what I put in the column.

title: Swiss Move Prompts Fears of Sustained Market Tumult
description: The Swiss central banks surprise decision to remove the cap on its currency has incited investor fears that a spate of bank and fund losses could lead to a sustained bout of market turmoil beyond the ability of central banks to ride yet again to the rescue.

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) THE LUNCHBOX (2014) When a delivery service sends the lunch intended for her husband astray, a neglected Mumbai housewife (Nimrat Kaur) finds herself communicating through handwritten letters and home-cooked meals with a widowed office worker (Irrfan Khan) nearing retirement in this debut feature from Ritesh Batra. This is not a new conceit, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, citing Youve Got Mail and The Shop Around the Corner. But the idea of two lonely souls connecting in a vast, modern metropolis, and remaining strangers even as their intimacy grows, has a durable charm. As do Mr. Khan and Ms. Kaur, islands of melancholy calm surrounded by silliness and noise. Their performances are not exactly subtle  nothing in The Lunchbox is exactly subtle  but they are graceful and dignified in the manner of movie stars in an earlier, less aggressive age, ennobling the ordinary lives they explore. And Mr. Batra makes their story touching and credible, an urban fable of hope in the face of disappointment.

title: As Pope Francis Visits Philippines, Tensions Between Church and Government Surface
description: MANILA  Pope Francis first full day in the Philippines was filled with the pageantry befitting a country in which more than 80 percent of the people identify themselves as Roman Catholics. But the tensions that have roiled relations between the church and the countrys leaders in recent years was also on display.

title: Press Freedom in Hong Kong Under Threat, Report Says
description: HONG KONG  Press freedom in Hong Kong, long an enclave of liberties in the shadow of mainland China, is increasingly threatened, with journalists assaulted, news organizations censoring stories and advertisers shunning publications that rile the authorities, a new report says.

title: Amazons Tax Deal With Luxembourg May Break Rules, E.U. Regulator Says
description: BRUSSELS  The European Unions antitrust office on Friday released a preliminary finding that a tax deal between Amazon and the Luxembourg government appears to amount to unfair state aid that may have enabled the company to underpay its taxes for a decade or more.

title: Corrections: January 16, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I see this as a call for action to close the gap between conservation on land and in the sea.

title: Kerry Travels to Paris to Show Solidarity After Terror Attacks
description: PARIS  Secretary of State John Kerry on Friday capped off a morning full of high-level meetings and wreath-laying to commemorate Frances struggle against terrorism by welcoming James Taylor at Pariss ornate City Hall.

title: As Europe Moves Aggressively Against Terrorism, New Challenges Emerge
description: BERLIN  After a series of police raids and a deadly gun battle, arrests of terror suspects in Belgium, Germany and France late Thursday and Friday highlighted the scope and complexity of the challenge facing European intelligence agencies and security services in confronting the expanding threat from radical jihadists, many of them battle-hardened in Syria and Iraq.

title: South Korean Journalists Acquitted on Charges of Defaming Presidents Brother
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Two journalists who have been vocal critics of South Koreas president were acquitted Friday on charges of defaming her brother, in a case that rights groups saw as a test of freedom of speech here.

title: Myanmar Sweeps Up Copies of Film Mocking Kim Jong-un
description: YANGON, Myanmar  Long before Sony Pictures released The Interview, a comedy about a fictitious C.I.A. plot to kill North Koreas leader, Pyongyang had declared war against the movie. It has since been blamed for a cyberattack on Sonys computers. Now, it appears that the countrys famously touchy diplomats have taken the dispute much farther afield: to the streets of Yangon, Myanmar.

title: Gov. Cuomo on New York Citys Woes
description: In recent weeks, Gov. Andrew Cuomo has repeatedly noted his concern about the unhealthy tensions in New York City between the police and Mayor Bill de Blasio. He also sees an alluring political vacuum tempting him to step forward as an impartial healer and arbitrator. I think everybody in New York City knows that this situation is unsustainable, he said on Wednesday morning.

title: Standing Up to the N.R.A.
description: Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan rebuffed heavy lobbying by the National Rifle Association and vetoed a patently dangerous gun measure Thursday that would have compounded the risks for women caught in domestic abuse cases. The measure, quietly passed by the Republican Legislature at the behest of the gun lobby, would have allowed gun permits for abusers in domestic violence and stalking cases  even those under a court-issued restraining order  if judges neglected to issue an explicit ban.

title: Layers That Conceal and Reveal
description: Luis Mallo has a simple rule for his photos. Its all about composition, he insists. He will spend 40 minutes on a single photograph, relying on the flexible bellows of his 45 view camera to align the scene and achieve that perfect composition before he loses the right light.

title: Head of Indias Central Bank Criticizes Post-Crisis Efforts
description: MUMBAI, India  Raghuram G. Rajan, the governor of the Reserve Bank of India, has a reputation for bluntness. A former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, he has criticized central banks around the globe for focusing too much on their domestic issues instead of considering the international ramifications of their decisions.

He started his sold-out Madison Square Garden show on Thursday evening with a song that insisted, Youre my life support, and finished it with his million-selling hit Stay With Me, begging someone to do just that, if only for a one-night stand.

title: Xis Selective Punishment
description: HONG KONG  A Chinese government official I know was put under shuanggui, the secretive system of internal Communist Party investigation in which victims are detained, questioned without counsel and sometimes tortured. He was held for several months last year, and he now awaits trial. This midlevel apparatchik in Yunnan Province was responsible for city planning and construction. I dont know why they targeted him  shuanggui is so opaque. Friends think he was an able official who may have taken a few bribes. But the most probable reason for his travails with the authorities was that his political patron also got in trouble.

description: Intel ended 2014 on a high note, and appears confident that its momentum can continue. But the question is how much the company has to change to keep up the pace, Quentin Hardy reports.

title: In Portugal, a Land Finely Aged Like Wine
description: The surprising thing about touching down at Lisbon Airport is how fast, heading south in a car, you find yourself transported into deep countryside. I arrived on a mild October morning, was met there by my old friend Martin Earl, and within a few minutes was crossing the Vasco da Gama Bridge, longest in Europe, an affair of towers and cables that stretches like a single bolt of flung steel across more than 10 miles of the Tagus River estuary. Immediately thereafter we swerved off the highway and decelerated into the dreaming, older world of the Alentejo (the word literally means beyond the Tejo or Tagus).

title: Morgan Collett of Saturdays Surf NYC on Where to Eat, Drink, Shop and Stay in Milan
description: The fall/winter 2015 mens wear shows kick off in Milan tomorrow, and men of style from all continents are currently descending on the city. Among them is Morgan Collett, the co-founder ofSaturdays Surf NYC  a versatile line that appeals to Rockaway beach bums and Milanese peacocks alike. I have been hearing that more and more Italians enjoy surfing, which is fantastic, he says. Our brand has so much influence from the fashion industry and the many cultures that exist in New York that I think Italians can appreciate our collection as part of a larger lifestyle. Collett has come to town twice annually for the past several years for sales appointments, and in that time has come to rely on a few standbys for shelter, sustenance and inspiration. Here, he shares his list of local hangouts  some chilled-out, others classic, all worth a visit.

title: Official Who Led Medicare Through Insurance Shakeup Is Resigning
description: WASHINGTON  Marilyn B. Tavenner, the administrator of the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, who supervised the troubled rollout of the federal insurance marketplace, said Friday that she was resigning.

title: The Rising Costs of Youth Sports, in Money and Emotion
description: JOHN AMAECHI first picked up a basketball when he was 17, after suffering through years of playing rugby in England. He soon left for Ohio to finish high school. Six years later, he started at center for the Cleveland Cavaliers and went on to have a solid N.B.A. career.

title: Soup Well
description: This week I was all set to work on quick winter soups when I remembered that I had some terrific giant white beans in my pantry that were begging to be used in a slow-simmering minestrone. So I changed my plan and made an array of warming soups, some quicker than others but all easy. The only one that requires much time on the stove (unsupervised) is the minestrone, the heartiest of the weeks recipes and a delicious vehicle not only for the beans but for winter squash, too.

title: Lego Movie Creators and Other Snubbees Unite at Critics Choice Awards
description: LOS ANGELES  Its hard to tell whether the timing of the Critics Choice Awards is cruel or ingenious or both: for the past few years, including this one, theyve been held the same day the Oscar nominations come out.

title: Italy Denies Paying Ransom for Release of Aid Workers
description: ROME  A top Italian official denied reports on Friday that a ransom of 12 million euros, or about $14 million, had been paid to secure the freedom of two young aid workers taken hostage in Syria last summer.

title: A Bankruptcy Process That Works for Small and Midsize Companies
description: Michelle M. Harner is a professor at the University of Maryland Francis King Carey School of Law.

title: Chapter 11 for Wet Seal as Tastes Change
description: The latest victim of changing teenage tastes and lifestyles, the mall-based retailer Wet Seal, said on Friday that it had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, the end of an era for a onetime Wall Street darling.

title: A New Orfeo Steps Off the Pedestal
description: LONDON  A modern curiosity of opera is that we spend vast amounts on theaters customized with all the comforts and amenities the art form needs, only to get excited by the prospect of performances in train sheds. It is the thrill of living rough. And it explains why the operatic event of the moment in London is a new Covent Garden production of Monteverdis Orfeo that is not actually playing at Covent Garden but at the Roundhouse: a cavernous industrial building in North Londons edgy Camden Town that once held trains but now holds music, though not often music of this kind.

title: TVs New Girls Club
description: There is a moment in HBOs Doll & Em when Em, a movie star, leaves her trailer to rehearse her lines alone. Doll, Ems childhood best friend and now her assistant, stays behind. In an echo of All About Eve, Doll picks up her friends script and starts reading aloud. 'Why didnt you call me? I didnt think it was my place,' she says, intoning both parts and knowing shes overstepping. The script is terrible. Its derivative. But its a transgressive moment for Doll and a distillation of her complicated envy toward Em. The sharp parody happening in that scene  of great films, of female friendship, of Hollywoods idea of better roles for women  coexists with an air of unstudied sincerity thats in fact subversive. Its a mood typical of the show and bespeaks a broader sophistication that has finally found its way onto the small screen, over a decade into what weve so often heard is a TV renaissance.

title: Happy Meals
description: Tujunga is not one of those well-to-do Los Angeles suburbs. It does not have a quaint main street or rows of tidy houses with trim lawns or a view of the ocean. When I was growing up, there were boarded-up storefronts and chain-link fences surrounding monstrous pink apartment buildings. There were abandoned houses and empty lots overrun by weeds.

title: Try This at Home!
description: I live and work in Hollywood. Some of my friends are screenwriters, and they tend to be politically progressive. They often criticize conservatives for ignoring scientific evidence when it conflicts with their politics. But when it comes to the negative effects of violence in the media, my friends dismiss the idea and insist that it is unfair to blame artists for societal issues. When confronted with scientific studies that point to media having an impact on violent behavior, most say that this is merely a reflection of what is already there. But if there is evidence of an effect, even nominal, is it unethical to write (or produce or direct) violent films and shows? NAME WITHHELD, LOS ANGELES

title: Valery Gergiev: Anyone Can Buy a Ticket
description: The conductor talks with Andrew Meier about trying his best to keep his politics and music separate.

title: The Jet Set Life of Karl Lagerfelds Favorite Male Model  for Now
description: One Sunday last spring, Brad Kroenig and his 5-year-old son, Hudson, showed up at a private airport near Paris to meet Karl Lagerfeld, the fashion designer. Karl will be here 1, 1:30 for takeoff, announced a Frenchman in a black suit and tie. O.K., cool, Brad said. The man in the suit performed something like a bow and retreated. It was 12:45. Brad sank into an armchair by the window and surveyed the tarmac. He pointed out a large gray hawk of a plane that stood off to the side of the slighter, dovelike jets. Its the same one that Oprah has, Brad said. Its the biggest one. It flies, like, the longest journey. A lot of private planes have to stop for gas.

title: Reply All: The 1.4.15 Issue
description: THE WRECK OF THE KULLUK

title: Kerry Visits Paris After Terror Attacks
description: Secretary of State John Kerry said on Friday that he went to France to share a hug with all of Paris after the Islamist attacks last week on the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo.

title: 2014 Breaks Heat Record, Challenging Global Warming Skeptics
description: Last year was the hottest on earth since record-keeping began in 1880, scientists reported on Friday, underscoring warnings about the risks of runaway greenhouse gas emissions and undermining claims by climate change contrarians that global warming had somehow stopped.

title: 1940: Thousands Join Finnish Army
description: WITH THE INTERNATIONAL BRIGADE IN THE FINNISH ARMY  Another group of Americans and even more Swedes, Norwegians and Danes reached the training center for volunteers late last night [Jan. 15] and early today to swell the number of fighting men in the International Brigade being formed in Finland. They have been coming in here every day now for four or five weeks, at first in groups of twenty to thirty, and then by hundreds. It is beginning to look as if the greatest International Column of all time will be fighting for Finland by spring. The backbone of this International Brigade will be the Swedish corps under General Eric Linder, a powerful force trained and equipped and paid for by Swedes. It will operate under the supreme command of the Finnish General Staff. Otherwise, it will resemble a private army. They are here to fight for a small country with a population about half that of the City of New York, into which a powerful neighbor has sent its armies and air force.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 17, 1940

title: Older Job Seekers Find Ways to Avoid Age Bias
description: JAMES S. KUNEN, 66, teaches English as a second language at the Center for Immigrant Education and Training at LaGuardia Community College in Queens.

title: Women Make Up Below 20 Percent of Nonacting Oscar Nominees, Group Finds
description: As the reality that this years Oscar race is the whitest since 1998 settles in, and as the Rev. Al Sharpton calls for an emergency meeting in Hollywood to address just that, another group added its voice to the chorus of dissent that greeted this years Academy Awards nominations.

title: After 24 Years, Back in Mexico
description: Angelo Cabrera, who lived in New York for years as an undocumented immigrant, is back in San Antonio Texcala, the town where he was born.

title: Seeking Legal Immigration Status, Longtime New Yorker Cant Return to U.S.
description: Had everything gone according to plan, Angelo Cabrera would have been back in the United States by now, and this time on the right side of the law.

title: Afghan Spy Chief Defies Labels, Usefully
description: WASHINGTON  Unlike his predecessor, Afghanistans spy chief, Rahmatullah Nabil, has never been accused by human rights groups of having a torture chamber in his basement.

title: A Sleepy Ottawa Neighborhood Wakes Up
description: Until recently, downtown Ottawas ByWard Market  the name for both one of Canadas oldest farmers markets and the roughly four-block neighborhood that encompasses it  suffered from a common capital-city affliction: After hours, it turned notoriously sleepy. Lately, however, numerous chefs and entrepreneurs have reimagined and reinvigorated the area, ushering in a new era of one-of-a-kind shopping, hybrid establishments and must-try bars and restaurants.

title: Despus de 24 Aos, en Mxico
description: ngelo Cabrera, quien vivi en Nueva York durante 24 aos como inmigrante indocumentado, est de regreso en Mxico y no podr volver a Estados Unidos.

title: Antiguo Residente de Nueva York No Puede Regresar a EE.UU., Tras Intento de Legalizar Su Estatus Migratorio
description: Si todo hubiera salido segn lo planificado, ngelo Cabrera ya habra estado de regreso en Estados Unidos y, esta vez, acatando plenamente la ley.

title: Arrest in Britain in Hacking of Microsofts Xbox and Sonys PlayStation Networks
description: LONDON  An 18-year-old British man was arrested on Friday in connection with a hacking attack that temporarily shut down the computer networks for Microsofts Xbox and Sonys PlayStation 4 video game consoles on Christmas Day.

title: The Art of Off-Season Training
description: Roughly 150 players from the nine National Womens Soccer League teams currently find themselves in the off-season. Some have headed overseas on loan deals to clubs in Europe, Japan or Australia, but the vast majority stay rooted to a home base for the six months between N.W.S.L. seasons.

title: Anger at Charlie Hebdo Turns Violent in Pakistan
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Clashes between the police and protesters outside the French Consulate in Karachi on Friday left four people, including two journalists, with gunshot wounds as demonstrations erupted across Pakistan against the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo and its publication of cartoons depicting the Prophet Muhammad.

title: Court to Look Into Possible Israeli War Crimes in Palestinian Territories
description: Prosecutors at the International Criminal Court opened a preliminary examination on Friday of possible war crimes committed in the Palestinian territories, the first formal step that could lead to charges against Israelis.

title: Philippines President Criticizes Church
description: President Benigno S. Aquino III of the Philippines admonished the Catholic clergy in the presence of the Pope, saying some members were too critical, and have even criticized his hair.

title: Facebook Offers Artificial Intelligence Tech to Open Source Group
description: Facebook wants the world to see a lot more patterns and predictions.

title: NBC Names a Today Veteran to Lead the Show
description: NBC News has recruited Noah Oppenheim, a Today show veteran, to lead the morning show after a period of turmoil that included the firing of its previous chief after 10 weeks on the job.

title: In Budapest, a Hotel of a Different Note
description: Budapest, a city with a rich musical legacy, will have a hotel that honors that history.

title: Boehner Turns to Taylor Swift to Pan Obamas School Plan
description: President Obama raised the hopes of many young Americans last week when he announced a plan that would make community college tuition-free for millions of students.

title: Sleater-Kinney Returns
description: Ben Ratliff and Jon Pareles are joined by Caryn Ganz, of RollingStone.com, to discuss No Cities to Love, the new album by Sleater-Kinney.

title: Oscar Snubbees, Part 2
description: The Academy may have overlooked The Lego Movie, but Twitter users didnt  beginning with the films writer-directors, Christopher Miller and Phil Lord.

title: Slow Rise in Consumer Prices May Stymie the Fed
description: WASHINGTON  Consumer prices in the United States are rising at the slowest pace during a period of economic growth in the last half-century, a trend that could delay the Federal Reserves retreat from its stimulus campaign.

title: $17 Million Home in Art Deco Chelsea Tower
description: Another apartment at Walker Tower that was claimed by one of the developers during the early stages of the Art Deco skyscrapers conversion sold for $17,156,250 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records. The duplex aerie is now back on the market for almost double the purchase price.

title: Lemon Bars With Olive Oil
description: Melissa Clark makes lemon bars sprinkled with flaky sea salt and confectioners sugar.

title: Lemon Bars With a Touch of the Tart and the Tangy
description: My mother wasnt a baker, but she did make some mean lemon bars when I was growing up, using a recipe straight out of a Charlie Brown cookbook.

title: Aaron Rodgers Has a Strained Calf, and Everyone Has Advice
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  The fans mean well, Aaron Rodgers said. On his Tuesday radio show and again at a Wednesday news conference at Lambeau Field, Rodgers thanked those who called, emailed and texted various suggestions for speeding the healing of his strained left calf.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Leaving Before the Rains Come
description: This week, Alexandra Fuller discusses her new memoir, Leaving Before the Rains Come; John Williams has news from the publishing world; Lauren Groff talks about Miranda Julys The First Bad Man; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Leaving Before the Rains Come
description: This week, Alexandra Fuller and Lauren Groff.

title: Critics Choice Awards
description: Perhaps relieved that the suspense of Oscar nominations was over, stars let their hair down Thursday night in Los Angeles.

title: Clint Eastwood Narrates a Sequence From American Sniper
description: In this video, the director Clint Eastwood discusses a scene from his Oscar-nominated film, in which Chris Kyle (Bradley Cooper) takes a moment in a bar to unwind after returning from an Iraq tour.

title: Uber to Introduce Driver Background Checks in India
description: Uber plans to introduce background check procedures for its drivers in India, the company said Thursday evening, in a move that comes weeks after a driver was charged with rape there. The episode prompted wider scrutiny of the ride-hailing service that is now banned in some parts of the country.

title: The Trip Is Ending: Dead Will Play Final Shows in July
description: Honoring a half-century of Grateful Dead music, the bands four surviving members will reunite for three shows this summer in what is being billed as their final performance together.

title: Im Glad I Did and Scripted
description: Its never been easier to be a famous teenager, even if its never easy to be a teenager. Two new debut novels find similarly plucky, quietly ambitious 16-year-old heroines at the beginning stages of stardom. Though living on opposite sides of planet showbiz  Im Glad I Did takes place in a Mad Men-era New York, while Scripted is set on an island where inhabitants lives are broadcast 24/7  each girl comes to learn the same lesson: Where the lights are brightest, youre bound to get burned.

title: Experiencing the Chokehold Firsthand
description: The New York Police Department banned the chokehold, a tactic that contributed to the death of Eric Garner, in 1993. But as a report revealed this week, the chokehold is still the first act of physical force that officers use, even facing mere verbal confrontation. To better understand the methods that the Police Department uses to subdue suspects, Kirk Semple, a reporter, was asked to experience them firsthand.

title: Letter From the Editor: Calories, a Two-Step
description: Its fair to say that the people who run Chipotle did not love our recent feature on what 2,000 calories worth of food look like. We pointed out that a single generous meal at Chipotle, centered on a carnitas burrito, can deliver 2,000 calories, which happens to be the recommended intake for many adults over an entire day.

title: A Political Challenge for the Navajo Nation
description: The tribe has inaugurated a new body of lawmakers, but does not have a president.

title: A Navajo Inauguration, Minus a New Leader
description: FORT DEFIANCE, Ariz.  Crisp suits. A roaring band. Beaming first-term lawmakers. The inauguration held here this week for the newest government of the Navajo Nation held the trappings of a typical passage of power.

title: Protests in Pakistan Over Charlie Hebdo
description: Demonstrations took place across Pakistan, including clashes between protesters and the police in Karachi, over the Muhammad cartoon published on the cover of the French newspaper Charlie Hebdo.

title: Catch Her if You Can
description: The objets dart produced in the Paris atelier of Zanuso et Filles by a young woman who calls herself Julie and claims to come from California are so lovely, it hardly seems fair to call them fakes. The same applies to Julie from California, who is really Grace from Garland, Tenn., and a first-class fraud.

title: What to Look Out for at Mens Fashion Week in Milan
description: MILAN  Its gray and drizzly here, but the crowds are coming in anyway Friday, via their Freccia Rossas (the Italian high-speed train) from Florence, where Pitti Uomo has just wrapped up, or flying in from farther afield. The fall 2015 mens wear season is well underway, with London and now Pitti complete, and the Milanese shows starting Friday night.

title: Obama and Cameron Face the Press
description: President Obama and Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain are set to hold a joint news conference at the White House. Previewing their meeting, The Timess Michael D. Shear reported in First Draft this morning that domestic and international terrorism is at the top of their agenda today.

title: An Artists Meditation Nightclub on the Las Vegas Strip
description: Artists residencies in Las Vegas tend to involve grand theater stages and bizarre ticketed performances, but at the Cosmopolitan hotel, the New York-based multimedia artist Lia Chavez has crafted an altogether different kind of spectacle. As the first in the annual lineup for the hotels P3Studio artist-in-residence program, Chavez has set up a surprisingly cerebral take on the notion of nightclubbing.

title: Bookshelf: Snow Days
description: New picture books include Peter McCartys First Snow and Deirdre Gills Outside.

title: The Secret Wisdom of the Earth, by Christopher Scotton
description: Theres a school of thought that believes the major chords are to be found in the familiar, and the great books are those that most readily suggest the well-known, well-loved classics. The Secret Wisdom of the Earth, the first novel from Christopher Scotton, brings a handful of favorite novels to mind, suggestive of several without being deeply indebted to any single one. That accounts, at least in part, for the great enthusiasm this novel has generated on its way to publication.

title: Thrillers
description: HER  By Harriet Lane  Little, Brown, $26.

title: J. Robert Lennons See You in Paradise
description: In the first story of See You in Paradise, J. Robert Lennons funny and poignant new collection, a family discovers a magic portal in their backyard. The oval, sort of man-sized, shimmering thing not only transports them to other worlds; it also serves as the readers entree to the rest of the book, with its array of futuristic and surreal psychic landscapes. The breezy blend of realism and fantasy is characteristic: The narrator, a world-weary dad, describes the first giddy era of exploration, which soon declines into domestic dysfunction as his children hit puberty and his wife grows distant. The portal, mirroring this entropy, becomes lopsided, with a sort of hernia in the lower left corner, and the narrator is left bereft and aching, trying to find his way back to some semblance of enchantment.

title: The First Bad Man, by Miranda July
description: Cheryl Glickman has a psychosomatic lump in her throat that sometimes prevents her from swallowing. She also has a burning crush on a man named Phillip Bettelheim who wants her blessing before he consummates his love for an underage girl, and a karmic connection with a child she calls Kubelko Bondy, whose spirit continually appears to her in other peoples babies. Cheryl is the protagonist of Miranda Julys very funny debut novel, The First Bad Man, and shes such an acute observer that her life is never as pathetic to the reader as it appears to the people around her. She has developed systems for everything, including a rigid housekeeping asceticism that helps her stave off the kind of debilitating sadness that, if left unchecked, can snowball from letting dirty dishes pile up in the sink to eating off said dirty dishes, to no longer bathing, to urinating in cups because theyre closer to the bed. Her ideal is unruffled contentment. When things really flow, she says, my days become dreamlike, no edges anywhere, none of the snags and snafus that life is so famous for. After days and days alone it gets silky to the point where I cant even feel myself anymore, its as if I dont exist.

title: 1965: Swedes Report Soviet Blast
description: NEW YORK  An underground atomic explosion deep in the Soviet Union has warned the Western world that the Russians may be stepping up development of their strategic nuclear weapons.

title: What I Love | Jill Platner
description: A long-held loft has gone the distance with an artist, serving as home and workshop.

title: An Artist in Her Element, a Garret
description: When she was a 21-year-old student at the Parsons School of Design, the sculptor and jewelry designer Jill Platner fell in love with a TriBeCa restaurateur. He put up a notice that they were looking for an apartment, and one of his regulars offered them a rental in NoHo: a loftlike fourth-floor walk-up with a wood-burning fireplace, a mezzanine and a peaked ceiling supported by timber beams.

title: Letters: Retelling Joans Story
description: Retelling Joans Story

title: Tony Judts When the Facts Change
description: The arc is down, is how Jennifer Homans, the widow of Tony Judt and an eminent dance critic and historian, describes the age of cruel disappointment that followed the end of the Cold War. It was the era in which her husband was condemned to live out his last two decades before his untimely death at age 62 in 2010.

title: Bitcoin Is a Victim of Disinflation
description: Bitcoin is proving a big disappointment. The virtual currency is down 33 percent against the dollar in 2015, and 71 percent in the last year. There is almost certainly more bad news to come.

title: Jane Bahks Junas Jar, and More
description: The great novels for young readers all explore the same question: How do we respond to an unfair world? For the picture book crowd, unfairness and injustice can be tough topics for discussion, but as three new books show, even the very young understand disappointment.

title: The Darkest Part of the Forest and The Ghosts of Heaven
description: As discerning readers are well aware, some of the most interesting fiction currently being written is published under the catchall category of young adult  a term that encompasses such a diversity of work as to be nearly meaningless, but that does suggest a books concerns will focus primarily on the doings of adolescent characters (though, as we shall see, even this definition does not always hold true). The young adult fiction powerhouses Holly Black and Marcus Sedgwick are masters of the genre, with well-deserved reputations for pushing it to its limits, and both writers newest books ably demonstrate that the line between young and adult is fluid indeed.

title: Jennifer Nivens All the Bright Places
description: In the opening moments of Jennifer Nivens All the Bright Places, a 12th grader named Theodore Finch poses on the narrow sixth-story ledge of his schools bell tower, arms extended, welcoming the spectators below to his death scene. And then he notices the popular Violet Markey on the same ledge, terrified, thinking about taking a leap of her own.

title: India Film Censor Resigns, Complaining of Government Interference
description: MUMBAI  Indias chief film censor, Leela Samson, resigned this week, saying she could no longer tolerate the interference of high-ranking government officials in her work. A second member of the film certification board followed suit on Friday, also citing interference.

title: Popcast: Sleater-Kinney Returns
description: As of this writing, days before the release of its new album No Cities to Love, @Sleater_Kinney  an official band account on Twitter established in late October last year  has roughly 10,000 followers. But its fair to assume that many of those followers think Sleater-Kinney was the greatest rock band of the last 25 years.

title: Patricia Arquette and Her Terrible, Horrible, Also Very Good Day
description: Patricia Arquette, the best supporting actress nominee for Boyhood, learned of the Academy honor on a busy morning:

title: Azul, Brazilian Airline Started by JetBlue Founder, Delays I.P.O. Plans Again
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  The JetBlue founder David Neeleman has postponed plans for the third time to hold an initial public offering for the Brazilian airline company he founded, as Brazils stock market continued to be volatile.

title: A Closer Look at the Global Warming Trend, Record Hot 2014 and Whats Ahead
description: Theres plenty of news coverage, including in The Times, of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announcement that 2014 was the warmest year since careful record keeping began in 1880.

title: Where Shiny Meets Gritty
description: For renters looking for new construction in Dumbo, a Brooklyn neighborhood with scant space to build, 60 Water Street has begun leasing 232 market-rate apartments, many with stunning East River views. But for many residents, historians and preservationists, the glassy complex with a 17-story tower is an eyesore that obstructs historic views seen from the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Inside the List
description: Bullies Are From Mars: Golden Son, the second novel in Pierce Browns Red Rising trilogy, enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 6. The plot of these books  in which a charismatic hero makes his way from Marss oppressed underclass into the ruling elite, where he plans a secret insurrection  has reminded some critics of the Hunger Games series, while putting others (O.K., me) in mind of Arthur Krystals observation about pulp fiction: Skilled genre writers know that a certain level of artificiality must prevail, lest the reasons we turn to their books evaporate. But in an interview last year with the publishing trade magazine Kirkus, Brown, who is 26, suggested the series is less artificial than it seems, at least to the extent it reflects his generations distrust of the political system. Im not trying to make a statement, he said; I just think it echoes a lot of the dissatisfaction that many people feel with those who make the decisions based on their own self-interests, rather than what is in the best interests of society. Its people being selfish. In the same interview, Brown said his views of cliques and social structures had been shaped in part by his childhood experiences moving from state to state with his family. A lot of times, I faced bullies  or the big dogs at school. What I wanted Red Rising to be is not necessarily an indictment on bullies, but it reflects my experiences and attitudes that I had with bullies growing up. A lot of times, you had to beat the bullies at their own game. But the difficulty is not becoming the bully yourself.

title: Bankruptcy Code Forces Rush of Empty Stores
description: The bankruptcy filing on Friday by Wet Seal, the teen apparel retailer, and the all too obvious moves in the same direction by Radio Shack, illustrate how much Chapter 11 practice has changed since the bankruptcy code was overhauled in 2005. This is especially true for retail companies.

title: Galliano for Margiela, the Royals Get Social and Leo and Rihanna?
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: U.S. Discloses New Trove of Phone Call Records
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department revealed on Thursday the existence of yet another database of American telephone records, adding new details to the disclosures in recent years about mass government surveillance.

title: Australian Open: Players to Watch
description: The Australian Open, which begins Monday, can be a springboard to success in 2015. Here are some players who are poised for a strong showing in Melbourne.

title: U.S. and Britain Present a United Front
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Friday that the United States and Britain have pledged new cooperation to bolster cybersecurity and an intensified effort against the Islamic State as the two nations work to confront a mounting threat from violent extremists across the globe in the wake of terrorist attacks in Paris.

title: Stuff We Liked: Checking Out the Neighborhood
description: We found a wide variety of thought-provoking material on the web this week.

title: The Rehabilitation of Joe Paterno, Back at No. 1
description: Amid the child-molesting scandal at Penn State, Joe Paterno lost his job, more than 100 victories as a coach and his reputation as a kind of football Renaissance man. Even a statue of him outside the universitys stadium was removed.

title: Editors Choice
description: AMERICAS BITTER PILL: Money, Politics, Backroom Deals, and the Fight to Fix Our Broken Healthcare System,  by Steven Brill. (Random House, $28.) Brills fresh, outsider curiosity makes him a superb guide to the maze of issues here.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties include a five-bedroom house in Larchmont, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Stamford, Conn.

title: Paperback Row
description: FDR AND THE JEWS, by Richard Breitman and Allan J. Lichtman. (Belknap/Harvard University, $19.95.) What, exactly, did Franklin Roosevelt do during his presidency, from 1933 to 1945, to protect the Jews of Europe from Nazi genocide? This thorough revisiting of the record reveals a concerned leader whose efforts on behalf of Jews were significant yet whose moral role was tempered by the political realities of depression and war.

title: Republicans Lay Out Calendar for Primary Debates
description: The Republican National Committee has announced the initial schedule of presidential primary debates, beginning this August and spanning seven months.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties include a Greenwich Village loft; an Upper East Side one-bedroom and a Kensington two-bedroom.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York York region:

title: A French Town Linked to Jihad Asks Itself Why
description: LUNEL, France  When this picturesque southern French town of just 25,700 people first learned late last year that six local Muslims had been killed fighting for Islam in Syria, accounting for 10 percent of the total number of French killed there, the right-wing mayor quietly asked the head of the local mosque for help.

title: Jos Saramagos Skylight
description: From outside a cobblers airy window, a little corner of Lisbon unfurls. Voyeurism is inescapable in Jos Saramagos new novel, Skylight, which peeks in on a shabby apartment building in the 1940s and takes its epigraph from the Portuguese writer Raul Brando: In all souls, as in all houses, beyond the facade lies a hidden interior. The interior at issue in this book is all the heartbreak and tepid dreams of the buildings humble residents, who are stuck in the inquisitorial silence of the past observing us and the ironic silence of the future that awaits us.

title: Sundance London Festival Canceled
description: LONDON  Sundance London, an offshoot of the Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah, will not return in 2015, the website ScreenDaily reported Friday. The London edition has been held at the O2 Center, more usually home to large-scale pop concerts, since 2012 when Robert Redford, the chairman of the Sundance Festival, said that he hoped it would help build a picture of our country that is broadly reflective of the diversity of voices not always seen in our cultural exports.

title: From Seminary to the Cemetery, Fascination Persists Over Pets and the Afterlife
description: In December, Pope Francis got the attention of pet owners everywhere when he was quoted as saying, Paradise is open to all of Gods creatures. Alas, media outlets, including The New York Times, confused the remarks and the circumstances under which they were made. The pope had actually made a broader comment about heaven during an event in November. The quotation itself was reportedly taken from remarks made years ago by Pope Paul VI.

title: SpaceX Founder Releases Photos of Rockets Crash Landing
description: It came down with a crash and a flash.

title: Paid Leave and Americas Family Values
description: Continuing his post-midterm strategy of pushing good ideas that might actually appeal to a lot of people, President Obama on Thursday announced two family friendly proposals.

title: Eccentricities, Classroom Steps and a Balcony Scene
description: New York Theater Ballet  may be small, but its repertory is mighty. For the latest installment of the Legends & Visionaries series, Diana Byer, the artistic director, dusted off some of the companys amiable works by an array of accomplished choreographers. Leading off the program at the 92nd Street Y on Saturday was Pam Tanowitzs Short Memory, created for the company in 2013 and set to music by Lou Harrison and Henry Cowell.

title: Truman and His Degrees (All Honorary)
description: Harry Truman has been the only United States president since 1901 without a bachelors degree,

title: Insider Tips: Travel in 2015
description: As a special thanks to Insiders, Times editors and reporters are giving the gift of great recommendations for 2015. Monica Drake, Travel editor, shares the places she would like to visit in the coming year.

title: Zach Blank: Outside the Great Indoors
description: Zach Blank grew up in an indoor playground; now he gets to work there. Mr. Blank, 31, is the vice president of Paragon Sporting Goods, a quintessential store for New York athletes  especially when it comes to winter sports like skiing, snowboarding and ice skating. The six-floor family business, on East 18th Street and Broadway in Manhattan, was founded in 1908 by Mr. Blanks great-grandfather, Phil Blank, an migr from Ukraine, and his father, Bruce, is the president and chief executive. Mr. Blank is studying for an M.B.A. at New York Universitys Stern School of Business. He lives in Gramercy with his fiance, Betsy Lawson, 30, a program manager at the KIPP Foundation, the charter school enterprise, and their dogs, Tristan, a rescue pit bull mix, and Archie, a goldendoodle.

title: Co-Stars at Last!
description: Cast as an extra, the groom finds his princess making a Bollywood movie at Harvard.

title: Marion Cotillard in Voluminous Dior Couture
description: The Star: Marion Cotillard

title: Readers Respond: On Tom Hanks and Community College
description: Like the boy who looked into a magic machine and wished to be Big, the actor and director Tom Hanks evoked readers youthful hopes as they recounted how they realized their ambitions through inexpensive community colleges like the one he attended in the 1970s.

title: Obama and Cameron Pledge to Fight Terror
description: President Obama and Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain said they would work together to thwart extremism and terrorism around the world.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: A Princess for a Make-Believe Prince
description: Growing up in the United States in the 1990s, Trisha Pasricha fell in love with Indian movies from the 1950s, 60s and 70s  a period known as the Golden Age of Bollywood. The glamour, the romance, the music and dancing: She loved it all. She watched and rewound the videotape of her favorite 1972 movie, Pakeezah, so many times, it broke.

title: DAngelo to Perform at the Apollo
description: After ending 2014 with the unexpected reveal of Black Messiah, his first album in almost 15 years, DAngelo is keeping the surprises coming.

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
description: A look back at the week in politics, from the White House to Capitol Hill.

title: Prince Andrew, Back in News, Faces Curse of the Spare
description: LONDON  Its not easy being the spare, the second son trained for little except hanging around waiting for your older brother to die, or to have children who then outrank you. Being Prince Andrew, the Duke of York, is a lot like being the vice president of the United States  only for life.

title: Rand Paul Gets a Gift Not Made in America
description: Senator Rand Paul is now the proud owner of the ultimate smoking jacket: a custom-made, navy blue hemp blazer.

title: A Journey Into the Mind, Beginning at the Ear
description: The origin of sound is often concealed in a blur of fast-moving arms, fingers and bows  a thick tapestry of notes created by instruments clustered together and sometimes only partly visible to the audience. A crucial element of the Korean-American vocalist and composer Bora Yoons performance art is highlighting the tactile elements of sound production, as she does during her mesmerizing Sunken Cathedral: a soundscape blending electronic, acoustic and visual components that opened on Wednesday at La MaMa as part of the Prototype festival.

title: Supreme Court to Decide Marriage Rights for Gay Couples Nationwide
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to decide whether all 50 states must allow gay and lesbian couples to marry, positioning it to resolve one of the great civil rights questions in a generation before its current term ends in June.

title: Supreme Court to Take Up Gay Marriage
description: Supreme Court to Decide Marriage Rights for Gay Couples Nationwide

title: Career Planning for Teenage Girls
description: Mel Gibsons character got to explore one mystery of the universe in the movie What Women Want, but a far bigger enigma  as any parent who has tried to raise one knows  is what teenage girls want.

title: Was Times Disgusting to Grant Anonymity to Al Qaeda Source?
description: Updated to include a response from Michael Kortan, the F.B.I.s spokesman.

title: Obama Urges Against New Iran Sanctions
description: The president urged Congress not to order new economic sanctions against Iran while negotiations over the countrys nuclear capabilities were in progress.

title: An American Techno D.J. Beloved Overseas Comes to Brooklyn
description: Half an hour into Jeff Millss futuristic black-and-white film Man From Tomorrow there is a long, unfocused shot of people dancing in a dark space. The skin from their bodies catches the light at different angles, creating shimmering gray blurs that look like particles under a microscope or energy vibrating out in the cosmos. That part of the film referenced the idea of what happens when a D.J. has been in that scenario for many, many years, explains Mills, 51, who began D.J.ing on Detroit radio in the 1980s. After several prolific decades as a producer, label boss and artist, he has become the intellectual Jupiter in the techno solar system and certainly the only person to be both canonized in Eminem lyrics and knighted Chevalier des Arts et des Lettres by the the French ministry of culture. You develop a certain type of alternative view of the audience as a collective, as a composite, he says. In most cases, Im looking at the audience as a wave, or like when you go to the sea and youre looking at the different levels of the water.

title: Percentage of Poor Students in Public Schools Rises
description: Just over half of all students attending public schools in the United States are now eligible for free or reduced-price lunches, according to a new analysis of federal data.

title: The Week in Political Pictures
Hackers List Struggles to Keep Up With Its New-Found Fame
description: Hackers List, an online meeting place for hackers and people who want to hire them, spent a good part of Friday struggling to keep the upstart web service running.

title: PepsiCo Reaches Truce With Nelson Peltz After 2 Years of Locking Horns
description: Nearly two years of public saber-rattling between PepsiCo and the billionaire investor Nelson Peltz appeared to end on Friday, as the two announced a truce of sorts.

title: As Motown Nears Closing, the Hits and Dollars Keep Coming
description: Motown: The Musical, which ends its Broadway run on Sunday, recouped its $18 investment at the end of last year, its producers announced Friday. The show began performances at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater in March 2013. Only about 25 percent of shows on Broadway earn back their capitalization and turn a profit each year.

title: Heralding New Music and Nurturing It
description: Alfred Schnittkes String Trio, written in 1985, swerves from clamorous dissonance to almost unbearably poignant lyricism and back again. On a recent afternoon, three students at the Juilliard School were starting its slow second movement in a practice room high above 66th Street. Joel Sachs, a professor at the school, sat across the room on a slouchy yellow couch, following along with a score. After a few seconds, he stopped the music.

title: City Ballets Fab Five (2015 Edition)
description: The word ballerina simply means, in Italian, a female dancer. But in the Anglo-Saxon dance world, it means quite specifically a female practitioner of ballet  and not just any female practitioner, but one who has reached the summit of her art, who exemplifies the essential attributes of classical dance. (France and Italy still dont use the word in this sense, although the Paris Opera Ballet gives us toiles or stars.) What those attributes must be has probably changed from era to era. Today we value, indeed expect, absolute technical mastery from a top ballerina, and we want musicality, dramatic power, charm, assertiveness and radiance, too.

title: Why Some Teams Are Smarter Than Others
description: ENDLESS meetings that do little but waste everyones time. Dysfunctional committees that take two steps back for every one forward. Project teams that engage in wishful groupthinking rather than honest analysis. Everyone who is part of an organization  a company, a nonprofit, a condo board  has experienced these and other pathologies that can occur when human beings try to work together in groups.

title: In Milan for Fashion Week? Heres What to Do
description: Fashion is always central to life in Milan, and never so much as during Fashion Week, which begins on Jan. 17 with the fall/winter 2015 mens wear. But there is more to do in the city, Italys second largest, than gaze at models with chiseled cheekbones, in well-tailored suits (not to imply that activity ever becomes tiring, of course).

title: The Best Way to Get Over a Breakup
description: Writing about your feelings, a practice long embraced by teenagers and folk singers, is now attracting attention as a path to good health. And a recent study suggests that reflecting on your emotions could help you get over a breakup. But, one of its authors says, journaling can have its downsides.

title: Inspiration: Some Find It Alone, Others in Collaboration
description: Chris Potter Underground Orchestra

title: Robin Pecknold of Fleet Foxes Branches Out to the Stage
description: With a worlds worth of inspiration at a writers fingertips, real creativity often comes from constraints. Thats true at least for the musician Robin Pecknold, best known as the principal songwriter for Fleet Foxes, the pop-folk band that got a Grammy nomination and a top-five debut with its last album, Helplessness Blues, in 2012. Too much freedom can be creatively paralyzing, Pecknold says. Hes currently preparing for his musical return: the score for the off-Broadway play Wyoming, which he co-composed with Neal Morgan, who has been the drummer for Joanna Newsom and Bill Callahan. With the score, I had the ability to play with genre without worrying about appropriation, Pecknold says. There is less of the self in it, compared to writing an album.

title: Cleaning Up the Macs Printers List
description: Q. I recently got a new printer for my Mac, but I still see my previous printer (which I got rid of) listed in the options when I go to print. How do I get the old model out of the list?

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: New Life for an Old Shipyard Town
description: La Ciotat, in southeast France, once seen as a victim of globalization when shipbuilding moved elsewhere, now thrives as a repair port for yachts.

title: Storm Warnings for Popes Climate Stop in the Philippines
description: [ Pope Francis made it to Tacloban and, wearing a yellow plastic rain coat like those on the tens of thousands of people before him, delivered a simple and moving homily focused on assuaging peoples sense of loss. The transcript is here.]

title: Superyachts to the Rescue
description: LA CIOTAT, France  After scuba divers checked the supporting mounts, a massive submerged boat elevator slowly raised the 661-ton, 51-meter-long yacht M/Y Sky clear of the Mediterranean, gradually revealing its black matte hull.

title: A Game of Juxtaposition
description: Using a Nikon 35 mm film camera, Cooper Neill created double exposures at the College Football Playoff national championship game, squeezing separate aspects of the event in one frame.

title: Photos: A Game of Juxtaposition
description: Covering an event like college footballs national championship game is an exciting and challenging assignment. For the game Monday night between Ohio State and Oregon in Arlington, Tex., the wire services positioned photographers at all corners of the field and on the catwalks, and editors worked on-site and used card runners to make sure photos were promptly uploaded.

title: At Hunts Point Market, Awaiting Word on Strike as Talks Continue
description: Metal barricades stood next to the entrance to the Hunts Point Terminal Produce Market in the Bronx on Friday, ready to be lined up if the more than 1,200 warehouse workers and drivers employed at the market went on strike.

title: Hearing Set For Loretta Lynch, Attorney General Nominee
Dinner Is Also a Sport
description: The holidays and all the fraught togetherness they can bring are now in the rearview mirror. But if youre still smarting over that unkind word from a brother-in-law, or a passive-aggressive takedown from Mom or Dad, some solace may be found by attending a performance of A Beautiful Day in November on the Banks of the Greatest of the Great Lakes, a quirky comedy by Kate Benson that cleverly transforms an extended familys Thanksgiving dinner into a fiercely fought competitive sport.

title: Shaking the Rafters With the Thundering Chords of a Monumental Requiem
description: Critics of Avery Fisher Hall and its acoustics usually agree that it is too big. But on Thursday evening, during the galvanic Dies Irae (Day of Wrath) in the New York Philharmonics performance of Verdis Requiem, it suddenly felt as if the hall were too small to contain such an explosion of sound. As the massed forces of the excellent New York Choral Artists invoked the Day of Judgment, shrieking piccolos pierced through the orchestral texture, and ear-shattering offbeats on the bass drum answered thundering orchestra chords. Trumpeters had been stationed on both sides of the second balcony, and the metallic bite of their salvos seemed to cut into the listener from all directions.

title: Where Dvorak Puts Fleet Fingers to the Ultimate Test
description: When musicians describe a work as awkward to play, they are referring to the finger gymnastics necessary to render a particular passage smoothly, one that may sound simple and straightforward to the listener. That category includes Dvoraks Piano Concerto in G minor, which the British pianist Stephen Hough has described as a concerto for 10 thumbs, alluding to the composers unidiomatic writing.

title: A Deal From the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional
description: On Dec. 27, the second day of the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Manhattan, the main pair event was won by Alan Lechner and Elliot Sternlicht of New York City. They were just over one board ahead of Cynthia Colin and Jeff Hand of New York City, with Beverly Perry of New York City and Ron Smith of Las Vegas third.

title: Same-Sex Marriage Decision to Put Spotlight on Republicans
description: A Supreme Court ruling recognizing a right to same-sex marriage in all 50 states would reverberate quickly through a Republican presidential field whose leading figures have not yet embraced such change and, in a few cases, have actively fought it.

title: Love Here, Drugs There, Music and a Death
description: We need a new term to describe the sort of history on offer in Whitney, the Whitney Houston biopic that airs Saturday on Lifetime. Revisionist history doesnt quite capture it; that implies a cogently argued counternarrative, with some kind of ideological motivation. And selective history isnt quite right either; that implies a narrative arc sandpapered down to cohesion in service of one idea about a person.

title: Pictures of the Day: Bahrain and Elsewhere
description: Pictures from Bahrain, China, France and Spain.

title: After the Warmest Year on Record, West Virginia Feels the Heat
description: Fridays news that 2014 was the Earths hottest year on record could not have been timelier for West Virginia, where a dissident member of the Board of Education recently altered new teaching standards to reflect his personal doubts about climate change.

title: Branching Out, but Never Far From Its Roots
description: Pilobolus, the mix of acrobatics, dance and dreamlike theater that became famous under the name of a fungus, first germinated in a 1970s Dartmouth College dance class taught by Alison Chase. Ms. Chase joined the troupe, and though, in 1980, she helped found the offshoot Momix, she stuck with Pilobolus until an acrimonious parting in 2005. Four years later, she started another company, Alison Chase/Performance, and at the Miller Theater this weekend, this latest venture had its New York debut.

title: The Perils of Odette, Retold in Brooklyn
description: How can a production as visually beautiful and stylish as the Mariinsky Ballets Swan Lake be so unmoving? The exquisitely medieval look of this staging, which this St. Petersburg company presented on Thursday to open its two-week season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is marvelously right, and other balletic felicities abound. But four central problems remain.

title: Jan. 16, 2015  Photos of the Day
description: Photos from Bahrain, India, China and France.

title: The Supreme Court and Gay Marriage
description: For the second time in three terms, the Supreme Court has agreed to consider the constitutionality of same-sex marriage. The last time around, the justices declined to take up the broad question. This time, there is every reason for them to follow the logic of their own rulings over the past 12 years and end the debate once and for all.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Turning 40, S.N.L. Settles In
description: There is no more boring complaint than Saturday Night Live used to be funnier.

title: Bill Cunningham | Stripes of all Sizes
description: Patterns and colors, particularly of the Native American variety, were an uplifting sight during the post-holiday slump.

title: When a Revolt Goes Wrong
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  In the early scenes of the Syrian documentary Our Terrible Country, the leftist writer Yassin al-Haj Saleh explores the ruins of a rebellious Damascus suburb, his clean-shaven face, Lenin-style cap and pristine clothes marking him as a recent arrival from the mostly intact government-controlled downtown.

title: Ex-Employees Accuse Health Firm of Fraud
description: Two former executives of the health technology firm NantHealth said in a lawsuit filed this week that the company made fraudulent claims about the reliability of its system, which links patient information gathered by different medical devices and pieces of hospital equipment.

title: At the Super Bowl of Linguistics, May the Best Word Win
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  It is a solemn and important duty we have, Allan Metcalf, a grandfatherly looking man, said into a microphone. He was standing in front of a crowd of the nations top linguists, many of whom were still flooding into the already packed room. The space was tight, Mr. Metcalf apologized, but the linguists had only an hour. They had to get started.

title: Bill Cunningham | Stripes of all Sizes
description: Patterns and colors, particularly of the Native American variety, were an uplifting sight during the post-holiday slump. For example, the chevron-stripe coat on a woman crossing the street mimicked the stripes on the Louis Vuitton store. No one is predicting that these colorful coats will replace New Yorks beloved all-black look, but they lift the spirits on a cold winter day. One artist took a novel approach to dressing warm and turned a Depression-era rug into a coat.

title: Evening Hours | Cheer Amid the Cold
description: Celebrations offered much-needed warmth.

title: The Dark Side of Broken Windows Policing
description: In recent weeks, New Yorkers have been watching a family drama unfold among an angry patriarch, the mayor, Bill de Blasio; his petulant charges in the Police Department, apparently as huffy as 12-year-olds told to stop texting; and a mother, Police Commissioner William J. Bratton, who, like mothers everywhere hoping to get Daddy to understand and the children to listen, has been trying to broker peace.

title: Book Review Podcast: Leaving Before the Rains Come
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Rachel Cusk reviews Alexandra Fullers new memoir, Leaving Before the Rains Come, an account of the collapse of the authors marriage. Ms. Cusk writes:

title: The Hood by Air Show
description: The designer Shayne Oliver failed to impress in Florence.

title: A Strange Performance
description: Tilda Swinton and Olivier Saillard worked together on the unexpectedly mesmerizing Cloakroom.

title: The Price of Privilege
description: They were alike in many ways, Thomas Strong Gilbert Sr. and the son to whom he gave his name and who, prosecutors say, would eventually kill him.

title: Grading Mayor Bill de Blasio: The Readers Speak
description: Reporters who cover Mayor Bill de Blasio for The New York Times recently appraised his first year in office, identifying areas of strength and concern (Grading the Mayor).

title: Hood by Air Builds the Suspense, and Tilda Swinton Erotically Checks Coats
description: FLORENCE, Italy  Boredom, as Renata Adler once wrote, implies duration. By that standard, virtually every performance-art piece ever staged is inherently a bore. How not to think about tonights dinner, the dry cleaning, that overdue email response while spending seemingly interminable moments waiting for, oh, lets say, the Hood by Air show to commence?

title: Dsquared2: Fall 2015 Menswear
description: Milan

title: A Night Out With One of Miamis Night Life Boosters
description: MIAMI BEACH  Sauntering one evening this month amid potted palms at the Villa Azur, a chic dining spot here, a pneumatically contoured young model showed off her evening gown and foot-high feathered headdress.

title: The Value of Community Colleges
description: To the Editor:

title: Preserving the Oceans
description: To the Editor:

title: The Stress of Displacement
description: To the Editor:

title: Rich, but Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinas Building Boom
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Just Fried, but Double Fried
description: Because of Roosterspin, my most significant memory of the 2014 holiday season will be about chicken. Between our visits to the restaurant, strategically located next to the Westfield train station, all I could think about was its delicious double-fried signature dish. It didnt matter whether I was spending time with family or enjoying a getaway in Cape May, all I wanted to do was eat that chicken one more time.

title: The Thwock of Ball Against Wall
description: Zerega Indoor Paddleball Courts, in Castle Hill in the Bronx, has been a popular spot for paddle ball players since the 1970s, and is picking up younger players.

title: In the Bronx, Paddle Ball All (Thwock!) Winter Long
description: You can hear the chaotic soundtrack of Zerega even before you enter the building: the ping and thwock of rubber balls hitting cement walls, the distinctive squeak of sneakers stopping short on painted floors, and the ohhhhhhs that accompany the echo of a particularly good shot.

title: Slippery Tips on Annuities From a Life Coach
description: By Page 418 of Tony Robbinss new book Money: Master the Game, which promises on the cover that its seven steps to financial freedom will be simple, I was sort of ready to put it down.

title: Obama Orders Panel to Study Police Equipment
description: President Obama on Friday ordered the creation of a new federal working group to recommend tighter standards on providing military-style equipment to local police departments. The order was part of Mr. Obamas response to racial unrest in Ferguson, Mo., that followed the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager by a white police officer, and the heavily militarized posture police used in the days afterward to confront riots and protests over the killing. In an executive order, Mr. Obama said the group would be jointly led by the secretary of defense, the attorney general and the secretary of homeland security. It is tasked with ensuring that law enforcement agencies that acquire the equipment  including firearms and tactical vehicles  are properly trained to use it, and that they comply with civil rights requirements.

title: Caning of Saudi Blogger Is Delayed Amid Protests
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A lawyer in Saudi Arabia who founded a human rights group was sentenced to 15 years in prison. His wife, a womens advocate who won a courage award from the State Department, says she is barred from leaving the country. Her brother, a writer who ran a liberal online forum, is also in jail and was sentenced to be caned regularly in a public square over the next few months.

title: The Other Pipeline You Should Worry About
description: WHILE the ire of environmental activists remains fixed on the Keystone XL pipeline, a potentially greater threat looms in the proposed expansion of Line 61, a pipeline running the length of Wisconsin carrying tar sands crude. The pipeline is owned by Enbridge, a $40 billion Canadian company, which has been responsible for several hundred spills in the past decade, including one in 2010 near Marshall, Mich., reportedly the largest and most expensive inland oil spill in American history.

title: Shared Greatness
description: Exploding sliders. Time-stopping change-ups. Three-thousand-hit machines. We expect to embrace such superlatives with any baseball Hall of Fame induction class, and 2015 was no different.

title: Failures in Screening Rikers Jail Guards
description: New Yorks notoriously corrupt and violent Rikers Island jail complex got that way after city officials let the correction officers union run the complex as it saw fit. The result was a system in which guards could beat up inmates for minor offenses, like talking back, without fear of being held accountable.

title: Travel to Cuba Eases, but Airlines Will Miss Initial Rush
description: The Obama administration this week lifted some travel and trade restrictions on Americans traveling to Cuba, but commercial airlines will not be flocking to Havana for at least another year, experts say.

title: Forty Acres and a Mule
description: In a Jan. 15, 1865 letter from Savannah, Maj. Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman reported to his wife, Ellen, that Secretary of War Edwin M. Stanton has been here and is cured of that Negro nonsense  namely, Stantons insistence that black regiments be included in his army, an idea Sherman steadfastly opposed. But if Sherman won that particular fight, he knew he faced a much larger challenge: his treatment of blacks during his triumphant campaign through Georgia.

title: Pressed by Budget Squeeze, Gov. Sam Brownback of Kansas Pulls Back on Tax Cuts
description: TOPEKA, Kan.  Gov. Sam Brownback, who made cutting taxes and shrinking government the centerpieces of his government, proposed on Friday to close a huge projected shortfall in the state budget by increasing some sales taxes and sharply slowing his plan to gradually reduce the state income tax.

title: Jury Selection for Tsarnaev Trial in Boston Sees Emotions Come to Fore
description: BOSTON  It was the first time during jury selection for the Boston Marathon bombing trial that someone had become emotional under questioning by the judge, but it was a sharp reminder of the loss that is at the heart of the case.

title: Creating a Cozy Home for Her Children
description: From the time she was 3 years old until she turned 21, Krystle Jackson lived in 13 different foster homes. So she was distraught when her own young children, Kayla and Isaiah, landed in foster care in 2012 when her daughter was seriously hurt while Ms. Jackson was at a job-training class. She fought hard to get her children back, working with New Alternatives for Childrens foster care program to meet the necessary requirements. She attended parenting class, kept appointments with the children twice a week and participated in therapy. In early 2014, she was reunited with Kayla and Isaiah.

title: Car Market Shows Signs of Revival for Europe
description: The European auto market grew last year for the first time since before the global financial crisis began, industry data showed on Friday, as consumers replaced worn-out models and analysts said they expected a modest upward trend again this year. New passenger car registrations, a proxy for sales, rose 5.7 percent in the European Union last year, reaching about 12.6 million vehicles, the European Automobile Manufacturers Association reported from Brussels. It was the first annual expansion since 2007, when the market peaked at nearly 16 million new passenger cars. Spain led the major national markets in 2014, with government trade-in incentives helping to lift sales by more than 18 percent. Germany, Europes largest auto market, grew 2.9 percent. Still, the industry is not out of danger. The stagnant economy in most of Europe, as well as crushing unemployment in countries like Greece and Spain, will continue to weigh on the market. LMC Automotive, a market research firm, estimates that European sales will gain just 1.1 percent in 2015. Carlos Da Silva, who follows Europes car market at IHS Automotive, said in a research note that the 2014 recovery was welcome news, but that Europe was not yet a fully cured patient.

title: Couple Ending a 3-Decade Journey in Travel Book Sales
description: There is no villain in this story.

title: Senators Question Stringency of Guardrail Testing
description: WASHINGTON  As testing of a potentially dangerous guardrail system continued on Friday, two United States senators sent a harshly worded letter to the federal agency conducting the tests, saying they were inadequate and should be made more rigorous.

title: A Nurse Deploys to Fight Ebola
description: Lindsey Hallen, an emergency room nurse, prepares to travel to Sierra Leone, where she will help care for Ebola patients.

title: A Nurse Decides to Get Hands-On in the Ebola Zone
description: Lindsey Hallen is in the bug spray aisle at REI, the outdoor equipment emporium in SoHo, looking for exactly the right mosquito repellent to take to West Africas Ebola zone, when her phone rings. Three ascending tones, the personal anthem of an emergency room nurse, captured in a ringtone called Summit.

title: Ray Lumpp, Who Played for Knicks and Ran a Track Meet, Dies at 91
description: For Ray Lumpp, the biggest moment in his long and varied sports career came when he was selected for the United States Olympic basketball team that went on to win a gold medal at the 1948 London Games.

title: Students Gain Access to Files on Admission to Stanford
description: For as long as people have griped about college admissions, one of the biggest complaints has been that it is a black box  applications go in, acceptances and rejections come out, but nobody can see what happens inside.

title: Disneys Chief Made $46.5 Million in 2014
description: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Company on Friday disclosed a 35 percent increase in overall pay in 2014 for its chief executive and chairman, Robert A. Iger.

title: Pentagon Will Send Troops to Train Some Syrian Rebels
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon will send up to 1,000 soldiers and other personnel on a mission to train Syrian rebels as part of the fight against the Islamic State, Defense Department officials said Friday.

title: Squabbles Among Hartford Vote Officials Fueled Election Woes, Report Says
