title: Anna Fenninger Looks Forward to Facing Lindsey Vonn at Alpine Championships
description: BOSTON  When the defending womens overall champion is on the slopes during World Cup races, fans can expect to see the flash of a cheetah whiz by, too.

title: Whats on TV Thursday
description: 8:25 A.M. (Encore) BLUE JASMINE (2013) Cate Blanchett won an Oscar for her role as Jasmine French, a Park Avenue matron fallen on hard times after her husband, Hal (Alec Baldwin), lands in prison for bilking his clients out of millions, leaving her with little more than her pearls, white Chanel jacket, Herms bag and monogrammed Louis Vuitton luggage. Destitute, in a manner of speaking, Jasmine flies first-class to San Francisco to begin life anew with her sister, Ginger (Sally Hawkins), whose scrappy existence and brutish men (Andrew Dice Clay and Bobby Cannavale) Jasmine can barely stomach without self-medicating with vodka and Xanax. Then she meets a diplomatic type (Peter Sarsgaard) with an appreciation for her decorating talents and designer threads and starts to see light at the end of her dark tunnel. With intimations of Ruth Madoff and Blanche DuBois, this shattered woman is brilliantly brought to quivering life by Ms. Blanchett, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, in Woody Allens most sustained, satisfying and resonant film since Match Point.

title: Discrimination With a Smile
description: Under Chief Justice John Roberts Jr., the Supreme Court has developed a remarkably sanguine view of race in America. Things have changed dramatically, Mr. Roberts wrote in 2013 in striking down the heart of the Voting Rights Act.

title: Lessons of the James Risen Case
description: The Obama administration has taken two actions that seem a refreshing departure from six years of aggressively attacking investigative journalism. The Justice Department abandoned an attempt to force James Risen, a New York Times reporter, to testify about a confidential source. And it tempered internal guidelines for trying to obtain records or testimony from the news media during leak investigations.

title: Japan Faces a Deadline to Save Men Held by ISIS
description: TOKYO  Japanese officials said Thursday that they were trying every possible avenue to reach the Islamic State militants who have threatened to kill two Japanese hostages but had so far failed to make contact, with time running out on a deadline to pay for the mens lives.

title: Divers Retrieve Bodies From Fuselage of AirAsia Plane
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Indonesian Navy divers, thwarted for days by bad weather, began recovering bodies on Thursday from the sunken fuselage of the AirAsia plane that crashed into the Java Sea last month, killing all 162 people aboard.

title: Test Yourself | History, Race and the Northern States
description: Here are six paragraphs from a Jan. 10 Opinion essay, When Will the North Face Its Racism?

title: 6 Qs About the News | Unlocking Scrolls Preserved in Eruption of Vesuvius, Using X-Ray Beams
description: In Unlocking Scrolls Preserved in Eruption of Vesuvius, Using X-Ray Beams, Nicholas Wade writes about advances in research that may someday help us read ancient Greek and Roman scrolls.

title: Suzlon Group to Sell German Wind Turbine Business for $1.2 Billion
description: LONDON  Suzlon Group, the Indian wind turbine maker, said on Thursday that it had agreed to sell its German business to the private equity firm Centerbridge Partners for 1 billion euros, or about $1.2 billion.

title: Recalling Romanias Revolution
description: Joseph Rodriguez grew up in Brooklyn when it was devoid of hipsters and even the city itself had a bit of a drug habit. You can hear it in his voice: a gravelly, nonstop commentary. That much has been documented, woven into the tale of a photographer known for depicting American subcultures.

title: Do You Ever Write About Challenges You Face in Life?
description: Research suggests that personal and expressive writing can be powerful. It can improve health, alleviate depression symptoms, boost memory and even increase happiness.

title: Coffee May Cut Melanoma Risk
description: Drinking coffee is associated with a slightly reduced risk for skin cancer, a new study has found.

title: Germany Isn't Turning Backward
description: BERLIN  I am a patriot. Being German, those words dont come easily, particularly for a leftish, skeptical urbanite like myself. And particularly not now, just a few days before we commemorate the 70th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz. But yes, I love my country.

title: Living With Cancer: Coming to Terms
description: While I continue taking an experimental drug to keep my cancer at bay, I cannot claim to be in either a remission or a recurrence, and the word maintenance does not shed much light on the situation. The paucity of the language at my disposal stymies me, as does its obfuscations. I am grateful that patients , hungry for more fortifying formulations, have begun to create them.

title: Swiss Watchmakers Jolted by Currency Shock
description: At Genevas annual luxury watch fair this week, Vincent Malissen was delighting in the intricacies of a gleaming timepiece from Vacheron Constantin, one of Switzerlands most prestigious watchmakers.

title: K.K.R. to Acquire British Train Travel Booking Website
description: LONDON  Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire Thetrainline.com, a booking website for train travel in Britain.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: New York Today: Up Go the Fares
description: Good morning on this gray Thursday.

title: Talk Stays Light at Mens Runway Shows, but Hints of Pariss Sorrow Linger
description: PARIS  The show must go on is a clich as a rallying cry, but it was unusually apt this month as the fall 2015 mens runway shows bore their durable way through the appointed cities on their round: first London; then Florence, Italy; then Milan and now Paris.

title: Daily Report: Internet in Orbit, Linking Much of World Directly to Google
description: Google has never shied away from novelty or big spending to find ways to connect more people to the Internet. Over the last two years, its ideas have included fleets of little satellites, solar-powered drones that would fly around the world and balloons that float high into the stratosphere, beaming the Internet to those below, Conor Dougherty reports.

title: In Myanmars Black Zones, Illicit Chinese Commerce Is Said to Thrive
description: Over the past year, The New York Times video journalist Jonah M. Kessel has been examining heroin use along Chinas border with Myanmar in what the Burmese government calls black zones, territory contested by ethnic armies.

title: Today in Politics
description: House Republicans Retreat on Plan to Ban Late-Term Abortions

title: The Powers, and Limits, of E.C.B. Stimulus, as Viewed From Davos
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  As investors on Thursday awaited a decision by theEuropean Central Bank on whether to begin buying up loads of eurozone government bonds so-called quantitative easing policy makers and bankers in Davos warned that the move would not be enough to jump-start Europes anemic growth.

title: Ex-Lawmakers Sentence for Encouraging Revolt Is Upheld in South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Koreas Supreme Court on Thursday upheld a nine-year prison sentence for a former lawmaker who was convicted of encouraging followers to take up arms to overthrow the government in the event of war with North Korea.

title: Morning Agenda: Goldman Trumps Volcker Rule
description: Goldman Sachss recent acquisitions include apartments in Spain, a mall in Utah and a European ink company  exactly the sorts of investments that many had assumed would be prohibited by the Volcker Rule, DealBooks Nathaniel Popper reports. While its competitors have been abandoning the business of making big bets with their own money, he writes, Goldman has been quietly coming up with several new ways to put its own money to work in formats that appear to stay on the right side of Volcker.

title: Why Democrats Still Lead Republicans in Online Fund-Raising
description: If there were any reason for Republicans to pay attention to over-the-top fund-raising emails from the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee last fall, it would be this: Even in a terrible year for House Democrats, the party committee showed it could raise millions online, much of it in small amounts that are the lifeblood of large campaigns.

title: U.S. Fears Chaos as Government of Yemen Falls
description: SANA, Yemen  The American-backed government of Yemen abruptly collapsed Thursday night, leaving the country leaderless as it is convulsed by an increasingly powerful force of pro-Iran rebels and a resurgent Qaeda.

title: Royal Bank of Canada in $5.4 Billion U.S. Acquisition
description: The Royal Bank of Canada said on Thursday that it had agreed to buy the City National Corporation, a private and commercial bank based in Los Angeles, for $5.4 billion in cash and stock.

title: Britain Fines and Bans 2 Former RP Martin Executives Over Compliance Failures
description: LONDON  Two former senior executives at RP Martin have been fined and banned from the securities industry for cultural and compliance failings at the small British brokerage firm, which was fined more than $2 million last year for misconduct related to the manipulation of the global benchmark known as the London interbank offered rate, or Libor.

title: Parent and Child as Two Volcanoes Under One Roof
description: The French-Canadian writer, director and actor Xavier Dolan is only 25, but Mommy, his fifth feature film in five years, seems like the work of an even younger filmmaker. I mean this, mostly, as a compliment. Stories of adolescence  young adult novels, coming-of-age movies, teenage-targeted television series  are usually the work of adults, and therefore often temper their emotional immediacy with nostalgia, condescension or grown-up wisdom. But Mommy, the story of a troubled young man and his mother, seethes and howls with unchecked feeling. Shot in the square, narrow dimensions of a cellphone video, it is a pocket opera of grandiose self-pity, a wild and uncompromising demand for attention, a cri de coeur from the selfie generation.

title: Sheldon Silver, Assembly Speaker, Took Millions in Payoffs, U.S. Says
description: Sheldon Silver, the speaker of the New York Assembly, exploited his position as one of the most powerful politicians in the state to obtain millions of dollars in bribes and kickbacks, federal authorities said on Thursday as they announced his arrest on a sweeping series of corruption charges.

title: Louis Vuittons Fall 2015 Collection at Paris Mens Fashion Week
description: [Watch the live stream.]

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: Film Highlights Air Pollutions Broad Reach
description: Life in contemporary China as seen through the eyes of the Chinese filmmaker Jia Zhangke is often a gritty, somber affair. At times, the stark realism of Mr. Jias films has been too much for Chinas censors, as was presumably the case with his last full-length film, the 2013 drama A Touch of Sin, which never made it onto Chinese screens.

title: Obama Proposes Expansion of Program Providing Subsidies for Child Care
description: LAWRENCE, Kan.  President Obama on Thursday unveiled plans to greatly increase federal assistance to working Americans struggling to afford child care, choosing a Democratic pocket in a solidly Republican state to sharpen the contrast between the two parties economic visions.

title: Tracee Ellis Ross: That Hurt Like the Bejesus
description: The actress talks with Jenna Wortham about defining her own sense of beauty and humor.

title: In Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, Quiet, Quaintness and Room for a V.I.P.
description: As a student at Parsons the New School for Design, Miisha Jones started off in a dorm, later sharing a one-bedroom in the theater district with a roommate. When her roommate graduated, Ms. Jones was happy to leave their high-rise building on West 50th Street, where she paid $1,875 for her half of a flex, or a one-bedroom turned two-bedroom by means of a temporary wall.

title: Returning to Hyderabad, Once a Land of Princes and Palaces
description: It took 15 minutes for my car to creep forward about 20 feet, giving me ample time to admire the crumbling filigreed balconies jutting precariously overhead.

title: The Orthodox Sex Guru
description: In one of her early sessions with the patient, Bat Sheva Marcus, an Orthodox Jewish sex counselor, drew up a list. The patient, who was in her 20s, wore the uniform of her rigidly devout sect: a dark suit with a shapeless skirt reaching well below the knee, dark stockings, a plain blouse buttoned up to the neck and both a wig and a crocheted hat covering her head. She had come to Marcuss offices in Midtown Manhattan from a cloistered community in Borough Park, Brooklyn, because she had been recoiling from sex with her husband. There was pain, and, more problematic for Marcus, there was no desire. The pain, Marcus and her staff deduced right away, was a result of muscle constrictions stemming from childbirth; this could be treated effectively with dilators  and without objection from the patients rabbi. But the deeper aversion was more complex. Talking with the woman at a round table in a room decorated with still lifes of pears and berries, Marcus wrote a list of ways that the patient and her husband could make sex, for her, more appealing.

title: Instagrams Graveyard Shift
description: The photograph that Markisha McClenton posted on Instagram is a self-portrait, a close-up that is muted in dim light. She might be on her way to work. She might be coming home. Her workdays begin and end in the dark, and they are dark in between. Shes a lab technician in Jacksonville, Fla. Her specialty is blood. She has worked these dark hours since her son was 7. Freedom, she told me over the phone from her lab. Thats why she works these hours: The freedom to work at night and to raise her children during the days. To her, this is good fortune. She is smiling in this photo. But her eyes are midnight eyes, 3 a.m. eyes. Why take a photo at that hour? People forget about us, the night shift, she said. The #nightshift. Thats the hashtag she used. Its how I found her.

title: Obama and Indias Premier See Mutual Benefit in Breaking the Ice
description: NEW DELHI  Ever since Indias prime minister, Narendra Modi, visited President Obama in the fall, the word in New Delhi has been that the two men  one a former Hindu activist, the other a former law professor  had chemistry.

title: By the Fire
description: To cook in fire is a lesson I learned from a wise man who was not a cook. The man was my father, and what he cooked in his fire were some of the finest and most original things Ive ever eaten  original because they were original to me, to my earliest tastes, when my senses were new.

title: Where Cervantes Once Lived in Madrid, Eclectic Boutiques Abound
description: The Madrid neighborhood of Barrio de las Letras is famous for the Spanish authors and poets who have lived here since the 14th century, including Cervantes. But, in recent years, the manageable rents in this artsy residential enclave, a short walk from the heart of the city, have encouraged locals to open equally artsy and eclectic shops. These affordable boutiques, selling everything including clothing, furniture, home goods and even guitars, are scattered along the charming crisscrossed streets lined with three- and four-story buildings, some dating back to the 18th century.

title: Thousands at Huawei Came Forward in Push Against Fraud, Founder Says
description: HONG KONG In a rare media appearance, Ren Zhengfei, the founder of Huawei, the Chinese telecommunications equipment maker, said on Thursday that the company recently carried out a campaign aimed at cutting back fraud in the company.

title: The Black Panthers, Revisited
description: When we think of the civil rights struggles of the 1960s, certain events tend to come to mind: the March on Washington, for example, or perhaps the Freedom Rides or sit-ins. Others, however, have faded from our collective memory. One of those is the story of the Black Panther Party, the subject of this Op-Doc video. Founded in 1966 in Oakland, Calif., to combat police violence, the Black Panther Party and its story are a key part of our nations still-complicated racial narrative.

title: About Op-Docs
description: Begun by the New York Times Opinion section in 2011, Op-Docs is the worlds premiere short documentary series, comprising nearly 300 short, interactive and virtual reality documentaries. Each film is produced with wide creative latitude by both renowned and emerging independent filmmakers, and premieres across Times online platforms. The goal of each Op-Doc is to present a unique story, character, argument or point of view  and to start a conversation among our global audience.

title: In a Shift, Argentine President Says Prosecutors Death Was Not a Suicide
description: BUENOS AIRES  Confronted with a deepening scandal, the president of Argentina shifted position on Thursday, saying that the death of the lead prosecutor investigating the 1994 bombing of a Jewish center was not a suicide as she and other government officials had suggested.

title: Chaotic Retreat Follows Ukrainians Withdrawal From Donetsk Airport
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  The ruins of the once gleaming and modern Donetsk airport, site of near relentless fighting in recent days, finally fell on Thursday to pro-Russian rebel forces who then paraded captured Ukrainian soldiers through the streets of the embattled city.

title: E.C.B. Announces Stimulus Plan
description: Mario Draghi, the European Central Bank president, said Thursday that the governing council agreed to a quantitative easing program that will see it buy up to 60 billion euros worth of bonds.

title: Al Pacino and Barry Levinson on Age, Accomplishments and The Humbling
description: Simon Axler, the fictional performer played by Al Pacino in The Humbling, is living a perpetual actors nightmare. In this dark comedy adapted from the 2009 Philip Roth novel, Axler finds his memory and stamina are failing him. He fears that his opportunities are drying up and that audiences no longer recognize him. He struggles with his sanity and fails at his attempt to commit suicide.

title: Wider Chaos Threatens as Fighters Seize Branch of Libyas Central Bank
description: BAYDA, Libya  The battle for control of Libya threatened to break open its central bank on Thursday as fighters with one of the countrys two warring factions seized control of its Benghazi branch, risking an armed scramble for its gold reserves that could cripple the last functioning institution in the country.

title: Daniel Handler: By the Book
description: The author, most recently, of the novel We Are Pirates (and, as Lemony Snicket, numerous childrens books) likes to read Miss Manners. Shes an extremely useful philosopher, and I consult her frequently, in order to behave better.

title: Primavera Sound Announces Lineup for May Event in Barcelona
description: The music festival Primavera Sound has announced its lineup for its 2015 event in Barcelona, with acts by the Strokes, the Black Keys, Interpol, Belle & Sebastian and Damien Rice. The 15th edition will run from May 28 to 30.

description: Record holders show why theyre on top.

description: DAVOS, Switzerland  The World Economic Forum here is supposed to be a special place where people of differing viewpoints can learn from each other as they figure out solutions to the worlds problems.

description: BRADSHAW, Neb.  An unpainted wooden barn sits in a snow-dusted cornfield along a gravel road, one of many that dot the rural horizon here.

title: Rajiv Joseph Wins $150,000 Laurents/Hatcher Foundation Award
description: The new play The Guards at the Taj, about life-shaking events in 1648 India as the sun rises on the just-completed Taj Mahal, is the recipient of the 2015 Laurents/Hatcher Foundation Award, which provides $50,000 to the winning playwright and an additional $100,000 to defray production costs for the plays premiere. The playwright is Rajiv Joseph, a Pulitzer Prize finalist for Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo, which ran on Broadway in 2011 starring Robin Williams. And the production funds will go to Off Broadways Atlantic Theater Company, which will mount the play in May, with the award-winning actor Amy Morton directing.

title: Data on Payments From Drugmakers to Doctors Is Marred by Error
description: Youd think drug and medical device makers would know how to spell the names of their own products.

title: Juilliard Receives $5 Million to Create Career Services Center
description: It is something of a given that the best conservatories, dance academies and drama schools can teach their students the craft, and sometimes the art, they need to master their fields. But teaching them how to make a living in those fields can be another matter.

title: 1890: Violent Speeches by Anarchists
description: LONDON An International Convention of Anarchist and Revolutionary delegates was opened in London today at the International Socialist Club, Soho. Some very violent and bloodthirsty speeches were pronounced. Mr. Stone attended to represent the Chicago Anarchists. He was concerned in the riots and murders in that city, and was an intimate friend of the man Parsons, executed for throwing dynamite bombs at the police. He advised the extreme section to turn their attention to the kings of commerce, their banks, exchange bourses and other machinery for oppressing the workers. The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 23, 1890

title: Netanyahu Visit Delayed Until March
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was invited to address a joint meeting of Congress next month, but it looks as though hell be coming later than expected.

description: The board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted on Thursday to raise the base fare on subways and buses by a quarter, to $2.75, and the cost of a 30-day MetroCard by $4.50, to $116.50.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Raf Simons Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

title: Tom Brady and Bill Belichick Deny Knowledge of Deflated Footballs
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Coach Bill Belichick and quarterback Tom Brady said Thursday that they had no knowledge of how the New England Patriots came to use underinflated footballs in Sundays A.F.C. championship game against the Indianapolis Colts.

title: Learning From My Oldest Patients
description: It is with a good deal of trepidation that I start any new medication in my patients who are very old, for fear of disrupting the myriad forces of genetics and environment that have allowed them to live so long.

title: Are Those Steel Drums I Hear?
description: There is no grill on a sawed-off oil drum, no lick of breeze or view of the sea in sun-shocked blue. But behind the frosted windows of LoLos Seafood Shack, which opened in Harlem in October, the extemporaneous spirit of the lolo  the kind of open-air barbecue joint found on the beaches and roadsides of St. Martin in the West Indies  is strong.

title: Speaker Sheldon Silver Should Resign From New York Assembly
description: As astonishing as it was to see Sheldon Silver, the speaker of the New York Assembly, surrender to the F.B.I. on corruption charges Thursday morning, it is even more incredible that he can choose to go on serving in his job while he defends himself against bribery and kickback charges involving millions of dollars.

title: LoLos Seafood Shack
description: A taste of the Caribbean in Harlem

title: City Opera Board Still Prefers Lower Bid
description: The board for the bankrupt New York City Opera said Thursday that it still wanted to sell the companys name and few remaining assets to its preferred suitor, even though another bidder offered $250,000 more for them at an auction in court earlier this week.

title: Court Orders Release of Mubaraks Sons Pending Retrial
description: CAIRO  An Egyptian court has ordered the release of the imprisoned sons of Hosni Mubarak, Egypts deposed president, pending their retrial on corruption charges, according to Al-Ahram, a state newspaper.

title: Tumblr Taps Its Community to Work With Advertisers
description: Tumblr has long promoted itself as a hub for artists and creative entrepreneurs. Now, Tumblr wants to put those people to work.

title: Shedding Their Secrets
description: You wouldnt think hellbenders would be hard to find: The huge salamanders, the biggest amphibians in North America, can grow up to 30 inches long. Yet hellbenders make themselves scarce, living on the bottoms of mountain streams, lurking under massive rocks.

title: An Encouraging Day for Victoria Azarenka and for U.S. Women
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  For a former champion intent on becoming a future champion, Victoria Azarenka hardly had a welcome-back draw at this Australian Open: Sloane Stephens in the first round and Caroline Wozniacki in the second.

title: First Draft Focus: Passing the Gavel
A Classic Novel of the Italian Aristocracy Returns in a Sumptuous New Edition
description: Giuseppe Tomasi di Lampedusas internationally best-selling 1958 novel, The Leopard, is a satirically sad, lush tale of Italys lost, decadent aristocratic class. Set during Italian unification after the end of Napoleonic rule, when ancient feudal territories were merged and royal families were ruined, the novel is a meditation on revolutionary change. Luchino Viscontis 1963 film adaptation of The Leopard, which won the Palme dOr at Cannes, starred Alain Delon and Burt Lancaster and visualized in rich tones that same time period.

title: Costumes Are in the Mix at Philippine Festival
description: The Dinagyang Festival draws an estimated crowd of a million people to the streets of Iloilo City in the Philippines each year, and organizers say they hope the addition of the Philippine Festival Costume Expo will bring even more attention to the event.

title: After Inspecting Private Equity Funds, S.E.C. Examiners to Broaden Focus
description: Officials at the Securities and Exchange Commission have said they discovered numerous problems when examining private equity firms during a two-year review that ended recently.

title: Text to Text | Lord of the Flies and A Fight Club for Flies
description: Lord of the Flies has been a classroom staple for decades, perhaps because the issues of bullying and male aggression remain central concerns in the lives of adolescents, even if they arent stranded on a desert island.

title: Matching G.O.P. Presidential Candidates With Those Who Tried Before
description: Its audition time for presidential candidates in the invisible primary  the critical period before the state primaries and caucuses in which party elites help choose the eventual nominees.

title: Russian, Argentine and Mauritanian Nominees Caught Up in Real-Life Turmoil
description: The Oscar process is meant to be hermetic, with the artistic merit of a movie as the sole criteria. But Academy voters do not live in a vacuum, and real life often seeps into their perceptions of the films they are being asked to honor.

title: Soul in the Machine
description: We look back at some of the many shifting personae in Bjrks 20-year career, the subject of a major retrospective at MoMA in March.

title: Draghis Bond Buying Plan Runs Counter to Eurozone Principles
description: Mario Draghi has compromised on principles for the sake of effectiveness. Mr. Draghi, the European Central Banks president, announced on Thursday a long-expected bond buying program that will be huge from the start and last until eurozone inflation gets back on track. But the eurozones version of quantitative easing runs contrary to the principles of a currency union.

title: Former Iranian Official Gets Jail and $1 Million Fine in Corruption Case
description: TEHRAN  Signaling new efforts to halt what some officials have called out-of-control corruption, Irans judiciary announced this week that it had sentenced a former vice president to five years in jail and fined him the equivalent of $1 million after his recent conviction in a longstanding corruption case.

title: Ayatollah Khamenei Appeals to Western Youth on Islam and Prejudice
description: TEHRAN  In a rare effort to reach out to the West, Irans supreme leader released a letter to youngsters in the United States and Europe imploring them to learn about Islam from original sources and not, as he said in a later posting on Twitter, have it introduced to you by prejudices.

title: When Racism Cant Be Ignored
description: Tonya Pinkins and Dianne Wiest sank into chairs at the back of the room after a recent rehearsal of the play Rasheeda Speaking. Ms. Pinkins sipped a mug of tea; Ms. Wiest wrapped herself in a gray cardigan. The antagonism of the last scene theyd worked lingered.

title: Daughters in the Business
description: Betty Gilpin and Halley Feiffer suspect they must have crossed paths as infants, lolling in some green room or other. The actor Reed Birney has told them he remembers them as little girls. Ms. Gilpin, 28, and Ms. Feiffer, 30, grew up belonging to the same hothouse subculture: the children of theater people.

title: Wendell Ford, 90, Dies; Kentucky Senator Pushed Voting Rights
description: Wendell H. Ford, a political moderate from Kentucky who served as governor and then for four terms as a senator, rising to become the Democratic whip, or assistant leader, in the early 1990s, died on Thursday at his home in Owensboro, Ky. He was 90.

title: High Rates of Opioid Prescriptions Among Women Raise Birth Defect Fears
description: The federal health authorities reported Thursday that nearly one-third of women of reproductive age had had an opioid painkiller prescription filled every year from 2008 to 2012. Experts said the practice carried considerable risks for birth defects.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Raf Simons Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

title: Modern Love | Breaching the Seawall
description: When Laurel Fantauzzo met a young woman and her bicycle in Manila, her relationship to the city was transformed.

title: Naming a Drone Lets Readers Imaginations Take Flight
description: Drone journalism remains a hot topic, and as the prospect nears reality, the news medias excitement increases, The Timess included.

title: Charges Filed Against Sheldon Silver
description: The criminal complaint filed against the speaker of the New York State Assembly, Sheldon Silver.

title: 1940: Roosevelt Urges Better Schools
description: WASHINGTON  Educated citizens are as important as adequate defense for national security, President Roosevelt declared last night in a radio address in connection with the White House conference on children in a democracy. He stressed the necessity of poor sections of the country finding means of taxation to pay for the education of children who dont receive schooling. Certainly our future is endangered when nearly a million children of elementary school age are not in school, when thousands of school districts and even some entire states do not pay for good schools, he said.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 23, 1940

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Selma
description: Ava DuVernay narrates a sequence from Selma, featuring David Oyelowo and Carmen Ejogo.

title: Belichick Denies Knowing of Football Deflation
description: New England Patriots Coach Bill Belichick denied that he had any prior knowledge about the deflation of Patriots footballs in Sundays A.F.C. championship game against the Indianapolis Colts.

title: As Construction Booms, Edgewater Fire Provides a Sobering Moment
description: EDGEWATER, N.J.  The complex of luxury apartments burned down 15 years ago, before it was even finished, in what fire officials here described then as the worst blaze they had seen in decades.

title: Executives in Davos Express Worries Over More Disruptive Cyberattacks
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Executives from Target and Home Depot were not present at the World Economic Forum, where world leaders and corporate titans are rubbing shoulders and debating weighty issues.

title: Harry Reid, Bruised but Emphatic: Im Fully Intending to Run
description: With white gauze over his right eye and with deep purple bruising still visible along his jaw, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the minority leader, made his first on-camera appearance Thursday since suffering serious injuries three weeks ago in a fall, seeking to dispel worries about his health and repeatedly asserting that he planned to seek re-election in 2016.

title: Assemblymen Respond to Silver Arrest
description: Members of the New York State Assembly respond to the arrest of Speaker Sheldon Silver on corruption charges Thursday.

title: Amazon to Buy Israeli Chip Developer
description: Amazon.com has agreed to buy Annapurna Labs, an Israeli chip developer, a spokeswoman for the American company said on Thursday.

title: Anxiety and Division Flourish Amid Europes Struggle With Terrorism
description: In Germany, opponents of immigration march on the streets of Dresden, decrying what they term the Islamization of Europe. In France, the prime minister, Manuel Valls, speaks of a kind of ethnic apartheid within his own society, an assessment mirrored by some British Muslims who accuse their government of setting them inherently apart.

title: Silvers Case May Have Vast Impact and Alter Entrenched Way of Governance
description: His power unbending, his whims often unexplained, Sheldon Silver, in his two decades as speaker of the State Assembly, became a seemingly indestructible presence at the nucleus of the New York political world, a steady advocate for liberal causes and a master tactician in Albanys closed and entrenched way of governance.

title: White House, Citing Israeli Election, Says Obama and Netanyahu Wont Meet
description: LAWRENCE, Kan.  President Obama will not meet with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel when he travels to Washington in March to address a joint session of Congress, the White House said on Thursday, citing a policy against receiving foreign leaders close to their elections.

title: A Monks Interests Captured on Camera
description: A forgotten camera said to have been used by the Trappist monk and writer Thomas Merton will appear in public for the first time on Feb. 2 in a Merton centennial exhibition at Columbia Universitys Rare Book & Manuscript Library. Merton, who died in 1968, at 53, had taken vows at a Kentucky monastery that decreed he could own few possessions. With borrowed camera equipment, he took about 1,800 photos, creating meditative abstract compositions out of rocks, leaves, wagon wheels and barn siding.

title: Nope. No Idea. Not Me. Next.
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The monosyllabic New England Patriots coach Bill Belichick and his polysyllabic quarterback Tom Brady claimed to be united in mysterious unknowing.

title: A New Nominee for Worst Tween Sitcom on TV
description: Last weekend, my daughter watched the first episode of Nickelodeons Bella and the Bulldogs. I was ranting two minutes after I walked into the room. Days later, the thought of it still infuriates me  and fills me with disbelief. In 1976, this would have been a reasonable plot to offer; even a clever take on changing gender expectations. In 2015, its an embarrassment to middle school students of both genders, imposing stereotypes more rigid and offensive than even the Dukes of Hazzard dreamed of.

title: Objections by Women Open Rift in G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans struggled on Thursday to mend another unwelcome rift that threatens to tarnish their partys image with women and younger voters, shelving a contentious bill to outlaw most abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy.

title: Hollywood Callback for Canadian Bank
description: Royal Bank of Canada is placing an expensive bet that the second times a charm for a foray south of the border. The Canadian titan is paying $5.4 billion for Beverly Hills-based City National little more than three years after it cut a painful retreat from retail banking in the United States. This time around, RBC boss David McKay, who took the reins last August, has taken aim at a growing franchise in a coveted part of the market. But hes also paying through the nose for it.

title: Eurozone Nations Face Stronger Pressures to Lift Economies
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  As the European Central Bank deploys its most powerful economic weapon, the onus for growth now lies with the 19 individual countries in the euro currency union, a fractious and highly political group.

title: Videos Show Yemens Unfolding Crisis
description: Since Monday, videos have surfaced  both professional and amateur  showing the violence unfolding between the Yemeni Army and Houthi rebels in the capital, Sana.

title: Ohio Councilman, 30, Will Challenge Portman for Senate Seat
description: Potential presidential candidates are not the only ones circling their wagons ahead of 2016.

title: U.S. Attorney Announces Silver Charges
description: The United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, Preet Bharara, announces the charges against Sheldon Silver, the longtime Assembly speaker, who was arrested Thursday morning.

title: Technology Leaders Define Digital Fault Lines
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Trust, global consensus, government support for building infrastructure and inclusion are the main challenges of the digital future, a panel of technology leaders said here on Thursday at the World Economic Forum.

title: Putting Black Lives Matter Into Action
description: The true-crime podcast Serial was a phenomenon, in part, because it was told in the first person. The narrator, Sarah Koenig, all but whispered the story into our ears, and her brainiac sensibility was as interesting as the killing at her storys core. Her uncertainty was fetching on an existential level.

title: Mockingjay Beats Out Guardians for  2014 Box Office Crown
description: Sorry, Groot: Katniss has taken your crown.

title: The Uses and Abuses of Taboos
description: In a post last week on the debate around the Charlie Hebdo killings, I explainedwhy Im not convinced by the argument that Muslims are facing an unusual (phobic?) level of provocations toward their religion in the West, and why I think a consistent standard of self-censorship around religionthat excluded cartoon treatments of Muhammed would requirea radical change in the way that religion generally, but especially Christianity, is treated in contemporary culture. Now, as promised, I want to take up the question of other cases, particularly around racism and anti-Semitism, where our culture more explicitly self-censors, and where the argument I made immediatelyfollowing the killings about speech and violence deserves a qualification. Heres part of what I originally wrote:

title: Rubio, Cruz and Paul to Appear at Koch Donor Event
description: The annual donor event hosted by Charles and David Koch in California is among the most sought-after invitations in Republican politics  and one of the most difficult parties to crash.

title: At Milans Food-Themed Worlds Fair, U.S. Will Roll Out a Fleet
description: American food trucks will serve lobster rolls and burgers at Expo Milano 2015, a worlds fair with nearly 150 countries participating. The theme of the fair, which will run May through October just outside Milan, is food  feeding the planet (an estimated nine billion people by 2050)  which is a first for a worlds fair.

title: Obama Calls for Expanded Child Care
description: President Obama, speaking at the University of Kansas, called for an expanded child care program to lessen the financial strain on families.

title: Astronomy Night at the Intrepid Museum
description: Some childhood fantasies never go away. From time to time, the Miser pictures himself in a space shuttles cockpit or thinks about how much fun it would be to play in the underground fortress at the Louvre.

title: Dries Van Noten: Fall 2015 Menswear
description: Paris

title: Ava DuVernay Narrates a Scene From Selma
description: The Oscar-nominated film Selma shows the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.s strategy going into the civil rights march in in Selma, Ala. But it also shows Dr. King (David Oyelowo) as a family man, in intimate moments with his wife, Coretta (Carmen Ejogo). In this video, the director Ava DuVernay discusses one of the calmer moments before the storm. Ms. DuVernay points out her interest in showing this relationship to give a more rounded sense of the activist and minister.

title: The Top Five Fall/Winter 2015 Mens Wear Collections From Milan
description: Ts mens fashion editors share their favorites from the latest round of shows.

title: Meet the Diplomats Leading the U.S.-Cuba Talks
description: Historic senior-level talks between the United States and Cuba kicked off this week in Havana with two formidable diplomats at the head of each delegation: Josefina Vidal, the longtime point-person in the Cuban government on American policy, and Roberta Jacobson, the Assistant Secretary of State who oversees the Western hemisphere.

title: European Central Banks Bond-Buying Will Help U.S. Tourists and Investors
description: For American investors and tourists especially, the long-awaited move by the European Central Bank on Thursday to help stimulate growth on the Continent is welcome news. For the rest of the American economy, it will not matter so much.

title: White House Proposals on 529 College Savings Plans Would Reduce Benefits
description: President Obama is proposing a radical change to the 529 college savings plans held by millions of families, which would require those who use them to rethink their approach to college savings.

title: Paris Announces Plan to Promote Secular Values
description: PARIS  Officials in France announced new measures on Thursday aimed at reinforcing secular values at French schools, after the terrorist attacks in and around Paris exposed serious cultural rifts between children in heavily immigrant communities and others in classrooms throughout the country.

title: More Footage Released From Romney Documentary
description: A prank call from Arnold Schwarzenegger.

title: When the Art Isnt on the Walls
description: On a recent Thursday evening at the New Museum in New York, the elevator door opened onto a fifth-floor gallery with a pole-dancing class in action. Some visitors looked confused and headed for the exit, but many more crowded around the edges of the floor watching the dance collaborators Brennan Gerard and Ryan Kelly learn strenuous and hypnotic moves  the kind more often practiced by strippers or teenage subway performers.

title: Lovingly Layered With Slivers of Thrill
description: Ivan Fischer and the Budapest Festival Orchestra stick to the repertoire when they come through New York. In that sense they are like any other ensemble, understandably eager to impress in the core of our music. But Mr. Fischer has a restless, inventive mind, and his players seem game for anything. So even in the ordinary, you can count on them for something extraordinary.

title: Steyer Stands Down on California Senate Run
description: Cross another name off the list of potential Senate candidates in California.

title: On Set | Bjork
description: Bjork dances to Becoming Chaina by Dutch E Germ in a look from the spring 2015 Comme des Garons collection.

title: Claiming Academic Fraud, Ex-Athletes Sue North Carolina and N.C.A.A.
description: Two former University of North Carolina athletes filed a lawsuit against their alma mater and the N.C.A.A. on Thursday, accusing them of academic fraud and failing to fulfill their stated missions of educating athletes. The athletes, Rashanda McCants, a former womens basketball star, and Devon Ramsay, a former football player, are the named plaintiffs in the suit, filed in North Carolina state court.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Louis Vuitton Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: Danny Elfmans Music for Tim Burton Films to Open Lincoln Center Festival
description: The Lincoln Center Festival will mark its 20th anniversary this summer with return engagements by the Druid Theater Company of Ireland, the Cleveland Orchestra, the theater company Cheek by Jowl and the director Yukio Ninagawa, the festival announced Thursday.

title: In Manila, Two Seasons, No Regrets
description: The Philippines has just two seasons: raining and not raining. One September, the same month a typhoon wrecked the sea wall at Roxas Boulevard in Manila, a young woman walked into the room I was in and fell into a chair next to me. And I knew that from then on I would have just two seasons as well: before her and after her. Before I even knew her name, I thought: Come with me. Take me with you.

title: Ripples of Muscle, Evoked Through Sound
description: Let er buck is the slogan of the Pendleton Round-Up in Oregon, founded in 1910 and now one of the worlds largest rodeos. Perhaps that brought out a contrarian side in the songwriter and composer Sufjan Stevens. His latest commission from the Brooklyn Academy of Music is Round-Up, a wordless, arty documentary with its score performed live for six nights at the BAM Harvey Theater, ending on Sunday. Round-Up was filmed in slow motion  300 frames a second  and the music doesnt buck; its steady and meditative, treating the rodeo as a ritual.

title: The Case Against Sheldon Silver
description: Sheldon Silver, the former powerful speaker of the New York State Assembly, was found guilty on all counts in his corruption trial. The government said he used the power and influence of his official position to obtain for himself millions of dollars of bribes and kickbacks.

title: Race for Boxers Senate Seat Loses a High-Profile Hopeful
description: LOS ANGELES  The supposedly crowded race to succeed Senator Barbara Boxer, the California Democrat who is not seeking re-election in 2016, just became less crowded.

title: Amid Swords of Civil War, a President With a Pen
description: Abraham Lincoln probably never envisioned the Internet, but he wouldnt have been surprised by the tenor of the average Internet comment board. Among the documents that make up  Lincoln Speaks: Words That Transformed a Nation, an engrossing new exhibition at the Morgan Library & Museum, is a letter not by Lincoln but to him, from a disgruntled Louisianian who signed himself Pete Muggins.

title: A Toddlers Inside Guide to New York City
description: Diego Acosta Lpez wanted to document New York from his sons perspective: inside a stroller. Thousands of pictures (including little feet and hands) ensued.

title: Weekend Entertainments From the Archives of The New York Times
description: 78 YEARS AGO

title: Eerie Self-Portraits Inspired by an Abandoned Vintage Suitcase
description: Anja Niemi began her series after finding a bag filled with the remnants of a woman named Darlenes failed career as a beauty-sales representative.

title: Joachim Koester: Body Electric
description: In the four absorbing but conceptually overbearing video and film works in this show, the Danish artist Joachim Koester addresses a persistent anxiety of modern life: that we are all just cogs in a giant machine.

title: Shimmering Memories of a Mellow Collaborator
description: Entering the homestretch of the memorial concert Friends of Jeff Golub, which ran the better part of four hours at the B. B. King Blues Club on Wednesday night, the keyboardist Jason Miles offered an encomium, brief and to the point. Whatever he did, whether it was smooth or it was blues, there was a commitment, he said of Mr. Golub, a crisp and stylistically fluid guitarist who died on Jan. 1 at 59.

title: Wells Fargo and JPMorgan Loan Officers Accused of Taking Kickbacks
description: More than 100 former Wells Fargo loan officers accepted kickbacks  including one former employees wife who collected tens of thousands of dollars in payments  as part of a scheme to steer business to a now defunct title insurance company, a federal regulator said on Thursday.

title: Ann Toebbe: Remarried
description: At once familiar and slightly bizarre, Ann Toebbes meticulous collages belong to the stay-at-home intimist tradition that begins with douard Vuillards Parisian interiors. For several years she has cut up bits of colored paper to recreate  with help from photographs and memory  the domestic interiors of her life and of the people around her. For her solo debut at this gallery in 2013, she recreated her childhood bedroom, and rooms inhabited by relatives and neighbors she knew growing up in Cincinnati.

title: Verbatim: N.F.L. Must Punish Cheaters
description: Senator Dean Heller, Republican of Nevada, calling on the N.F.L. to take decisive actions to make sure teams play by the rules.

title: People and Language, All at Sea
description: One of the blockbusters of Western art history, Thodore Gricaults The Raft of the Medusa (1818-19), took as its impetus the true story of sailors left to die at sea, drifting on a raft off the coast of Senegal. Caroline Bergvalls Drift, an installation of prints, sound works and a digital, algorithmic collage, was inspired by a similar tale, only set in the present day. In 2011, African migrants trying to reach the island of Lampedusa in the Mediterranean were left to drift at sea despite being sighted by officials; more than 60 people died.

title: Gianna Commito
description: Gianna Commito is not alone in pursuing geometric painting on a small scale. (Tomma Abts is probably her best-known fellow traveler.) But in her second solo show at the Rachel Uffner Gallery, Ms. Commito continues to clarify her territory. She favors increasingly elaborate and compressed compositions of intersecting shards, bands and recurring stripes in medleys of softened related colors: The reds and pinks with gray and black of Drisko, for example, or the blues and greens with ocher of Chestnut, one of the shows standouts.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Louis Vuitton Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: Rosetta Finds Out Much About a Comet, Even With a Wayward Lander
description: Photographs and data from the European Space Agencys Rosetta spacecraft have provided an unprecedented close-up examination of a comet, but there is one thing that has not shown up yet: the small lander that bounded to the surface in November.

title: Citing Plunge in Oil Prices, Iraq Seeks Arms on Credit to Fight ISIS
description: LONDON  Battered by a sharp decline in oil prices, Iraq is asking Western allies to provide weapons on credit for its fight against the Islamic State until Baghdad is in a better position to pay.

title: Fair City
description: Scenes from art and antiques fairs across New York City.

title: JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs Chiefs to Get a Sweeter Pay Package
description: The two most-watched chief executives on Wall Street are receiving pay packages for 2014 that are a bit more attractive than the ones they received the year before.

title: Tips for Surviving the Sundance Film Festival, From Adam Scott of Parks and Recreation
description: Adam Scott has made a career out of playing cool, self-deprecating men in television shows like the cult sitcom Party Down and the NBC comedy series Parks and Recreation. But as the Sundance Film Festival kicks off today in Park City, Utah, the real Adam Scott  a husband, father of two and as of late, film producer  is nervous. Though hes a festival veteran, the stakes are especially high this year for the 41-year-old actor, who has two films debuting at Sundance: the romantic comedy Sleeping With Other People, in which he appears with Jason Sudekis and Alison Brie, and the in-competition comedy The Overnight, which he produced with his wife, and which he stars in alongside Taylor Schilling, Jason Schwartzman and Judith Godrche. Scott took time out from his preparations to share with T his best tips for a successful Sundance.

title: Judge Vacates Guilty Pleas of Men Charged With Insider Trading in I.B.M. Stock
description: The fallout from a federal appellate ruling in December that narrowed the definition of what constitutes insider trading continues to affect other cases.

title: Pots and Pans Included
description: Fully furnished luxury homes appeal to buyers for whom time is an issue and money is not.

title: Complaint Offers Motive for Silvers Fight Against Corruption Panel
description: Sheldon Silver, the speaker of the New York Assembly and one of the most powerful politicians in Albany, did all he could to derail and undermine an anticorruption panel established by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

title: Protest Art
description: A look at works in new shows at Smack Mellon Gallery and the Gray Art Gallery.

title: Thomas Struth: Photographs
description: Works from a new show focusing on a leading German photographer at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Music Brings Out the Killer Instinct
description: For its second program of the winter season, Hear the Dance: Russia, New York City Ballet offers four works set to the music of Rachmaninoff, Stravinsky, Tchaikovsky and Glazunov. Alas, music alone, no matter how sumptuous, doesnt make a ballet. Despite the promise of debuts by several dancers on Wednesday night, Jerome Robbinss The Cage and George Balanchines Cortge Hongrois eclipsed two other ballets with little effort.

title: An Online Garage Sale, Culled From the Homes of Jeff Koons, Richard Phillips, Miuccia Prada and More
description: Leave it to the preternaturally hip Russian museum and magazine Garage to subvert that least glamorous of Sunday-afternoon routines: poking through garage sales. This Sunday, Garage will launch a digital sale (the proceeds of which will be split between CalArts and Garage Museum of Contemporary Art Education) that collects objects culled from the homes of 13 artists and creatives. According to the magazines editorial director, Michael Polsinelli, the concept was a natural fit for the organization. It began as a simple editorial idea  we as readers always want better access to great creative contributors, and its pretty great access to know whats collecting dust in their closets, attics and garages, he says. From our side, its also a neat callback to our roots: Garage  as a museum and subsequently a magazine  began in the famed bus garage designed by constructivist architect Konstantin Melnikov in Moscow.

title: Paul Pings Romney and Bush on Utah Meeting
description: Senator Rand Paul appears to be feeling a little left out of the mix, with potential Republican presidential rivals Jeb Bush and Mitt Romney holding an informal summit in Utah on Thursday.

title: The Rain Comes, but the Rescue Takes Longer
description: A three-men-in-a-raft movie that, like the raft, bobs around aimlessly for much of its running time, Against the Sun is a groaningly tedious survival story that will at least leave you with a renewed commitment to wearing sunscreen.

title: Gift of Good Manners
description: My fianc and I were recently engaged. His mother gave us a week at her timeshare vacation home as an engagement present because she cant afford to use it herself. I think this is inappropriate. The burden is on us to make all the other purchases necessary to use the present (flights, ground transport, food). It was clearly a gift of convenience. I want my fianc to say something to her, but the gift doesnt bother him. Am I wrong?

title: A Film Star Finds His Folk Groove
description: In the 2007 satirical rock n roll biopic Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story, John C. Reilly plays a Johnny Cash-Ray Charles-Bob Dylan hybrid, hamming it up on parody songs like Theres a Change A Happening (I Can Feel It).

title: Saints Owner Says Wife Will Inherit Control of Team
description: Tom Benson, the 87-year-old owner of the New Orleans Saints and the N.B.A.s New Orleans Pelicans, said Thursday that his wife, Gayle, 67, will take control of the teams when he dies.

title: Setting New Standards
description: When Lincoln Centers American Songbook series began in 1999, it was a nostalgic program showcasing popular standards by the likes of Irving Berlin, the Gershwins and Cole Porter. While keeping one foot in the past, it has since become a progressive, increasingly multicultural program devoted to the new as much as to the old  the kind of program that can give you Richard Rodgers or rap, or even a concert sung entirely in Spanish.

title: Brothers and Rivals in Gore
description: Two nut cases, one Japanese and the other Indonesian, work out their psychoses on innocent women and despicable men in the aptly named Killers, the bludgeon-y sophomore feature from the Mo Brothers, Kimo Stamboel and Timo Tjahjanto.

title: A Rum Crew Jettisons All Reason
description: The British submarine thriller Black Sea has an insistent political subtext that distinguishes it from earlier films in the undersea action genre. As its waterlogged treasure hunters brave fire and flood to find and bring back a cache of gold ingots from a sunken Nazi U-boat in the Black Sea, they grouse endlessly about paper-pushing rich guys who dont know the meaning of real work.

title: If a Car Is Going to Self-Drive, It Might as Well Self-Park, Too
description: TECHNOLOGY may soon render another skill superfluous: parking a car.

title: Abortion Bill Bait-and-Switch
description: House Republican had planned to mark Thursdays 42nd anniversary of the Supreme Courts 1973 Roe v. Wade decision by pushing through a brazenly unconstitutional measure to prohibit almost all abortions 20 weeks after fertilization. That plan was abruptly abandoned when some female representatives objected to the bills callously narrow and politically tone-deaf rape and incest exceptions.

title: Where to Get a FICO Credit Score
description: A list of lenders that provide free copies of FICO scores, three-digit numbers generally ranging from 300 to 850.

title: Free FICO Credit Scores: Options Grow for Consumers
description: It used to be that your credit score was a well-guarded secret, available only to lenders and banks, which used it to evaluate whether you were likely to pay back a loan. If you wanted to see your score, you typically had to buy it.

title: Sparring in the Boxing Ring, in Politics and in Life
description: Boxing loves an underdog story, and the hagiographic documentary Manny has a good one in Manny Pacquiao (below). According to the movie, this Filipino fighter grew up in extreme poverty, boxed for small purses to help his family and then became a superstar  amassing world titles in eight weight classes  after coming to the United States. He is revered in the Philippines, where he sits in Congress.

title: Jockeying to Get Ahead by Cutting Corners
description: The subprime mortgage disaster is treated as a muddled morality tale of glitzy corruption in Theo Avgerinoss Americons. Mr. Avgerinoss glossy, overripe take on high-flying, unscrupulous lenders  the wolves of Main Street  deteriorates into a hot mess of montages, trailer-ready one-liners and thudding drama.

title: The People Most at Risk of Losing Insurance in the Supreme Courts Health Ruling
description: The people who could lose their health insurance as a result of a Supreme Court decision this year are predominantly white, Southern, employed and middle-aged, according to an Urban Institute analysis.

title: The Grief Spread Across the Road to Recovery
description: The modestly scaled, sad-funny indie drama Cake centers on a woman and the kind of grief thats so unbearable this movie cant even handle it. Jennifer Aniston plays Claire, who, having survived a horrific accident, now lives in near isolation in Los Angeles in a midcentury magazine layout of a house. Its clean lines, drawn by an architect and embellished by a period-design obsessive, make a vivid contrast with the scars jaggedly slashed across Claires face and body. Her wounds have healed, but her grimace and the shadows darkening it announce that shes far from whole.

title: When Hunky Neighbor Becomes Homicidal Stalker
description: He can fix garage doors, beat up bullies and analyze The Iliad, but dont be fooled: The new almost-20-year-old neighbor, Noah (Ryan Guzman), is a nightmare for an almost divorced schoolteacher, Claire Peterson (Jennifer Lopez), in The Boy Next Door. She succumbs to his flattery and his sculpted body one night, after walking out on a date, and the rest of the movie is devoted to showing how bad an idea that passionate mistake was.

title: Details in Milan
description: Bags, shoes and other accessories at the mens shows during Milan Fashion week.

title: Emporiums of the Waggish and Weird
description: THIS year, as always, the Winter Antiques Show monopolizes the glamour and the glory, with top-end wares  at top-end prices  making it the trade-fair equivalent of a big Broadway musical. But there is an Off Broadway too, smaller-scale shows that accommodate the wayward, the whimsical and the downright weird.

title: Flashbacks and Forecasts
description: When I started covering the art world for The New York Times in 1991, the market was reeling from a worldwide recession. Gone were the Japanese who had been snapping up Impressionist and post-Impressionist paintings at a frenzied pace, spending huge sums for what one dealer described as pretty pictures across a crowded room. After the Japanese disappeared, sales at the auction giants Sothebys and Christies plummeted to about half of what they had been.

title: Forgotten Creators, Memorable Works
description: Celebrated masterpieces are all well and good, but the less-well-lit nooks and crannies of art history are also needed to sustain a true art lover. Thats what a big fair like the Winter Antiques Show at the Park Avenue Armory is especially good for. With 73 purveyors of rare and remarkable objects, from ancient Egyptian sculpture to Modernist painting, it offers innumerable opportunities to encounter and learn about aspects of painting, decorative arts, furniture, jewelry or glass that might be new to even the best-informed visitors.

title: Raging Against the Dying of the Stage Lights
description: In his later fiction, Philip Roth has addressed the indignities of aging with a squirm-inducing candor. How many readers (or filmgoers) are eager to contemplate the loss of their powers until it is staring them in the face?

title: A Backstage Genius at Bennington and Juilliard
description: Making a documentary about a well-known figure from the creative side of the performing arts  an actor, a singer, a writer  is easy, and common. Making one about any of the countless people who further the arts from behind the scenes is more difficult. Miss Hill: Making Dance Matter is such a documentary, advancing the idea that Martha Hill was as important a figure in modern dance in the last century as any of the art forms better-known names.

title: Raging at Racism, From Streets to Galleries
description: On Dec. 3, a grand jury declined to indict a white New York City police officer for the chokehold death of an unarmed black Staten Island resident, Eric Garner. Anger at the verdict, particularly on the part of African-Americans, already stung by the police killing of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., was intense. Street protests flared across the country in perhaps the largest public display of resistance since the 1960s.

title: Pocket-Size Picks for Photographers
description: Think small and lightweight accessories that attach to cellphones for newlyweds who want to record honeymoon memories.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Ukraine and Elsewhere  Pictures of the Day

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: New Yorks New Rentals
description: New rental buildings around the city.

title: A Sensual Utopia Driven by Ritual and Release
description: Here are two somewhat contradictory things I can tell you about The Duke of Burgundy, which takes its name from a species of butterfly. It is, Im fairly certain, quite unlike any other Sapphic S-and-M lepidoptery-themed psychological romance you have ever seen. At the same time, though, its uniqueness rests on a passionate, you might say slavish, devotion to a particular cinematic style of the past.

title: Not Quite Sure About Happily Ever After
description: If you think the characters played by Woody Allen seem insufficiently self-deprecating, Well Never Have Paris offers an even less likely romantic lead in Quinn (Simon Helberg, from The Big Bang Theory), a New York florist with unrealized musical ambitions. Now 28, Quinn plans to propose to Devon (Melanie Lynskey), his girlfriend since high school. But when he reveals his intentions to a co-worker and friend, Kelsey (Maggie Grace, in a ditsy turn), she confesses that she is in love with him.

title: The Top Five Fall/Winter 2015 Mens Wear Collections From Milan
description: Ts mens fashion editors share their favorites from the latest round of shows.

title: Iowa Governor Issues an Ethanol Warning for 2016
description: Gov. Terry E. Branstad of Iowa is telling potential presidential candidates that if they want to win over the states voters next year, they should make clear now that they support ethanol production in a big way even as a powerful coalition of interest groups in Washington is working against it.

title: Music as a Balm for a Grieving Soul
description: Song One, Kate Barker-Froylands anemic first feature, offers a wispy meditation on the healing properties of a pretty folk song  especially when sung by a shaggy-haired troubadour with bedroom eyes and a sensitive soul.

title: Jan. 22, 2015 Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Ukraine, Yemen, Malta and Nepal.

title: Spilling a Love Potion on a Fairy Princess
description: Strange Magic, directed by the Oscar-winning sound designer Gary Rydstrom from a story by George Lucas, is set in a world of fairies, elves and goblins. The fluid digital animation tickles the eye with a sea of periwinkle, pockmarked creatures and diaphanous, detailed wings.

title: He Loves Me, He Loves Me Not  Oh, Hi, Dad
description: For a film rooted in a personal story, Salvation Army feels awfully remote. This disjointed movie is the directorial debut of the Moroccan author Abdellah Taa, who caused a stir when he came out in his country, where homosexuality is illegal. Mr. Taa adapted the screenplay from his autobiographical novel of the same name.

title: Ford Opens Lab in Silicon Valley
description: In the latest sign that the distinctions between the auto and tech industries are becoming more blurry, Ford on Thursday celebrated the opening of a new research center in Palo Alto, Calif., in the heart of Silicon Valley.

title: To Fight, Flee or Simply Join Them?
description: Some scientist discovered that all people are descended from two kinds of monkey: the chimpanzee and the bonobo, declares Brendan Lynch (Ewan McGregor), a hardened criminal and chess whiz in Julius Averys grimly silly action-adventure fantasy, Son of a Gun.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Dries Van Noten Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

description: Dozens of protesters staged a show of defiance against the authorities in downtown Cairo on Thursday, waving flares and chanting against military rule ahead of the fourth anniversary of the Egyptian revolution.

title: Li Ka-shings Hutchison Whampoa in Talks for British Mobile Firm O2
description: LONDON  Hutchison Whampoa, one of the flagship companies of the Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing, said on Friday it had agreed to enter exclusive talks to buy O2, the British cellphone carrier owned by the Spanish telecom giant Telefnica, in a deal worth roughly $15 billion.

title: Pleasure, Dealt Painfully
description: Rivers of spit and acres of shiny fetish wear glisten in the Japanese fantasy R100, a gleeful gross-out in which a meek salaryman hires an army of dominatrixes to do their cruel worst. The S-&-M gear has been selected with conspicuous care, from the pointy heels (the better to kick bad boys down the stairs) to the suitcase of instruments that look modeled on those in David Cronenbergs gynecological horror show, Dead Ringers. In that 1988 movie, the sinister tool kit was for operating on mutant women; here, its hauled out to dig deeper under the viewers skin.

title: Sales Jump at Starbucks, at Outset of a Bold Push for Growth
description: Starbucks, the company that turned legions of Americans into coffee cravers, on Thursday reported robust gains in sales and earnings during this past holiday quarter.

title: King Abdullah, a Shrewd Force Who Reshaped Saudi Arabia, Dies at 90
description: King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia, who came to the throne in old age and earned a reputation as a cautious reformer even as the Arab Spring revolts toppled heads of state and Islamic State militants threatened the Muslim establishment that he represented, died on Friday, according to a statement on state television. He was 90.

title: Comes an Aristocrat, Mustache Flaring
description: Mortdecai might as well be called The Johnny Depp Movie, because its preening star, wearing an ascot and a walrus mustache that becomes a tiresome running joke, is the whole show. And what a frantically dull spectacle this vanity project is. Mortdecai, directed by David Koepp from a screenplay by Eric Aronson, would never have been made without Mr. Depps enthusiasm for the source material, the first of the 1970s trilogy of farcical novels by the British author Kyril Bonfiglioli, in the P. G. Wodehouse tradition of sophisticated silliness.

title: In Egypt, Sowing Seeds of Gender Equality
description: CAIRO  Sara was supposed to marry young. She was supposed to get a job teaching at the school a few minutes walk from her familys apartment in Cairo so shed always be close to home, safe from sexual harassment, keeping her reputation as a virtuous, Muslim woman intact.

title: Why Adnan Syed of Serial Should Have Pleaded Guilty
description: OUR modern criminal justice system is designed to avoid jury trials. Through investigation and considered use of discretion, prosecutors are expected to charge only when there is sufficient evidence to convict. Once charged, defendants are encouraged to plead guilty in part to avoid a trial penalty  a longer sentence after a trial, often a much longer one. And 95 percent of them do just that. The Supreme Court acknowledged this reality in 2012 when it described our criminal process as a system of pleas.

title: Online Storage Provider Box Prices I.P.O. at $14 a Share
description: After nearly a year of trying, the online file storage provider Box Inc. is finally set to become a public company. But it will begin trading amid questions about its future prospects.

title: Its How You Finish
description: As the world contemplates the deflated football scandal in Boston  ballghazi  please allow me one last moment of undiluted sports delirium. I live in Seattle, where this week the sky is always blue, trees are blossoming early, all children are not only above average but get into the college of their choice, free. We are a city transfixed, rhapsodically floating, after the most are-you-kidding-me experience my hometown has ever been through.

title: Outrage: Cruelty at a U.S. Meat Lab
An Albany Powerhouse on the Edge of a Volcano
description: Al Smith, the storied governor of New York in the 1920s who laid the groundwork for the New Deal, has been credited with making a famously cynical remark as he walked through a law school library. He spotted a student, bent over books and reading.

title: Trying Youths as Adults
description: To the Editor:

title: Insiders, Outsiders, and U.S. Monetary Policy
description: I ran into Olivier Blanchard over breakfast the other day. This isnt as prosaic as it sounds, because we were both in Hong Kong. On the other hand, that in turn isnt as much of a coincidence as it might seem, because there was a big financial conference here, and the set of economists who get invited to such things isnt that extensive. More broadly, many of the people who either make monetary policy or comment on it from fairly influential perches are members of what you might call the 1970s Cambridge mafia. Olivier, Ben Bernanke, Ken Rogoff, Mario Draghi, and yours truly all overlapped at MIT in the mid-70s; Larry Summers was at Harvard at the same time, taking courses at MIT; just about everyone was Stan Fischers student.
