title: Disparate Education Plans From Obama and Cuomo
description: Since President Obama announced his proposal this month to make community college free for two years for qualifying students, arguments for and against the plan have been abundant. Some have assailed the initiative as futile, maintaining that federal Pell grants already cover the cost of community college for most poor and working-class students, and that the real obstacle comes not in tuition but in living expenses and the high price of textbooks. In actuality, tuition covered by the new subsidy would free up Pell grants to help alleviate those burdens.

title: Spare Times for Jan. 23-29
description: Note: With the snowstorm forcing cancellations across the city on Monday  including the postponement of a Tuesday night event at the Museum of Jewish Heritage to mark International Holocaust Remembrance Day  we advise that you check with venues before setting out to events scheduled for Monday or Tuesday.

title: Spare Times for Children for Jan. 23-29
description: Note: With the snowstorm forcing cancellations across the city on Monday, we advise that you check with venues before setting out to events scheduled for Monday or Tuesday.

title: The Devotion Leap
description: The online dating site OkCupid asks its clients to rate each others attractiveness on a scale of 1 to 5. When men rated the women, the median score was about 3 and the ratings followed a bell curve  a few really attractive women and an equal number of women rated as unattractive.

title: Much Too Responsible
description: The United States and Europe have a lot in common. Both are multicultural and democratic; both are immensely wealthy; both possess currencies with global reach. Both, unfortunately, experienced giant housing and credit bubbles between 2000 and 2007, and suffered painful slumps when the bubbles burst.

title: DreamWorks Animation Cuts Its Staff and Output
description: DreamWorks Animation said on Thursday that it would reduce its movie output and lay off 500 employees, or roughly 19 percent of its staff, a retrenchment that follows a string of box-office misfires and two failed merger attempts.

title: Senate Rejects Human Role in Climate Change
description: The Senate on Thursday again voted to reject two measures related to the Keystone XL pipeline that declared that humans are a cause of climate change  the second set of votes on the issue in two days.

title: Fast Track on Drug for Ebola Has Faltered
description: As Ebola raged through West Africa last summer, an experimental drug was tried for the first time on two American aid workers in Liberia who were gravely ill with the virus. Both recovered, one of them rapidly.

title: Conflict, and Smiles, as U.S. and Cuba Discuss Ties
description: HAVANA  The United States and Cuba held talks on Thursday to re-establish diplomatic ties broken during the Cold War, aiming to put the countries on a path toward normal relations after decades of hostility, acrimony and mistrust.

title: Brady Says League Has Not Contacted Him
description: I thought we won the game fair and square, Patriots quarterback Tom Brady said of Sundays A.F.C. championship game against the Indianapolis Colts. New England used underinflated balls.

title: This Weeks Movies | Jan. 23, 2015
description: The New York Times film critics review Black Sea, Cake and Mommy.

title: European Central Bank Bets Big on Curing the Economy
description: Mario Draghi has delivered  for now, at least.

title: BMW and Volkswagen Team Up to Expand Network of High-Speed Charging Stations
description: WASHINGTON  As sales of electric vehicles languish, automakers are starting to address one of the biggest obstacles to their wider acceptance: the lack of charging stations.

title: Christie Uses Executive Order to Appoint an Emergency Manager in Atlantic City
description: Moving to take greater control over Atlantic City, which is struggling financially as its casino industry shrinks, Gov. Chris Christie on Thursday appointed a corporate finance lawyer to be the citys emergency manager.

title: Searching for Answers in the 1961 Death of an Ayn Rand Follower
description: Joanne OConnor keeps a three-ring binder as thick as a cinder block to contain the story that echoes through her head. It is stuffed with her research about a young woman she never met who died more than 50 years ago. She has trouble explaining why obsession gripped her so, but she does know: I had to find out what happened.

title: In Tamir Rice Case, Many Errors by Cleveland Police, Then a Fatal One
description: CLEVELAND  It began with a swap: one boys cellphone for anothers replica of a Colt pistol.

title: A Scorsese Documentary on Bill Clinton Is Stalled
description: Martin Scorsese has tackled the mob, the Dalai Lama and the real-life Wolf of Wall Street.

title: Opening His Mothers Clothing Shop, and Then Heading to Tel Aviv for a Rampage
description: AL JIB, West Bank  After the raid by Israeli security forces, details of the young Palestinian mans life had been strewn haphazardly on the floor of one room of his familys home: a mattress, a tangle of blankets and clothes, an ashtray of cigarette butts, an energy drink can and handwritten notes about electrical circuits  the young man had just received a diploma in electrical studies  and, chillingly in hindsight, a new-looking knife with a long, smooth blade.

title: Peggy Charren, Childrens TV Crusader, Dies at 86
description: Peggy Charren, whose advocacy of higher-minded television programming for children took the issue to government agencies and the halls of Congress and led to landmark legislation, died on Thursday at her home in Dedham, Mass. She was 86.

title: Conservative Gathering in Iowa Offers Platform to Several Possible 2016 Contenders
description: DES MOINES  The largest gathering of potential Republican presidential candidates so far will descend on Iowa on Saturday to test their messages at a forum shaping up as the informal starting gun for the 2016 campaign.

title: Bush and Romney in Gentlemanly Meeting
description: WASHINGTON  Jeb Bush and Mitt Romney did not reach an agreement during a Salt Lake City lunch meeting on Thursday on how to reconcile their competing plans to run for the White House next year, advisers to both men indicated after the talk.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Jan. 23
description: Photographs from the past week from New York City and the region include images from a City Council hearing on Airbnb and a protest of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos annual address.

title: How Super Was Mario? (Wonkish)
description: Mario Draghi pulled off a political triumph on QE, coming in with a program that is bigger and more open-ended than anyone expected. The goal was to jolt expectations, to convince markets that there has been a fundamental shift toward aggressiveness. And markets certainly moved in the right direction. But how much was achieved? Inquiring minds want to know  or at least I do. So Ive done some back-of-the-envelope calculations on the question of how much Draghi managed to move inflation expectations.

title: Jean Lindenmann, Who Made Interferon His Lifes Work, Is Dead at 90
description: Dr. Jean Lindenmann, a co-discoverer of interferon, the powerful antiviral substance used to treat some cancers as well as hepatitis C and multiple sclerosis, died on Jan. 15 in hospice care in Zurich. He was 90.

title: A Year After Suing Their Landlord, Brooklyn Tenants Still Lack Heat
description: Two weeks ago, a city housing inspector visited an apartment on the fourth floor of 940 Prospect Place in Brooklyn and issued a violation to the landlord for inadequate heat. The visit was nothing new  since December 2013, residents of 940 and the adjoining building at 930 Prospect Place have made more than 100 complaints about lack of heat or hot water.

title: Knocked for Risks, League Plays Defense
description: SAN ANTONIO  On a Thursday night in December, Brian Morgan stood at the 50-yard line on a community football field as two teams from the Outlaws, a youth organization, practiced to his left and right. Both teams  one with 6- and 7-year-olds and the other with 10- and 11-year-olds  were preparing for championship games in a few days.

title: Surveys Show Bias of Potential Jurors in Boston Bombing Trial
description: BOSTON  One potential juror said she was biased against Dzhokhar Tsarnaev because he is Muslim. I already feel that hes guilty, she said.

title: Obama Not Planning to Meet With Israeli Premier
description: WASHINGTON  The White House said on Thursday that President Obama would not meet Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel when he comes here in March to speak to a joint meeting of Congress and to lobby for new sanctions on Iran that Mr. Obama opposes, the latest twist in a dispute that has marked a new low in relations between the two leaders and which now threatens the chances of a nuclear deal with Tehran.

title: Lottery Numbers
Inquiry Sought After Former Commissioner Accuses Gov. Rick Scott of Meddling
description: MIAMI  As Gov. Rick Scott faced mounting questions about the ouster of the top state law enforcement chief and allegations of improper political meddling, two influential fellow Republicans called for an inquiry on Thursday into the potentially damaging accusations.

title: Baseball Lifer Leaves Office, but Not the Game
description: He has been honored in Arizona, Los Angeles and St. Louis, with a final farewell dinner set for Saturday night in Manhattan. In the middle of it all, back home in Milwaukee, 30 floors above his hometown, Bud Selig has somehow found time to pack his office.

title: The Cat Is a Thinker; the Dogs Unwell
description: In Maggie Bofills domestic comedy Winners, co-produced by the Ensemble Studio Theater and the Radio Drama Network, the home fires have guttered. At the Mackeys suburban abode, the unemployed dad, Brian, slumps in his robe, cooking inedible meals. The overworked mom, Mabel, receives racy texts from her boss. Tommy, a teenager, loses his after-school job for smoking pot, and little Gabbys proposal for the Christmas play involves an awful lot of stage blood.

title: Political Intrigue in China, With Loyalties Uncertain
description: There is roiling tumult amid the shadows in Damon Chuas uneven but beautifully staged Film Chinois, at the Beckett Theater. In this Pan Asian Repertory production, an exercise in noir styling and political intrigue, identities can be fluid and motivations suspect.

title: Fewer Trees in a Fairy-Tale Forest
description: These are the woods that you want to get lost in, a place youll find buried treasures that you didnt even know existed. Fiasco Theaters truly enchanting production of Stephen Sondheim and James Lapines Into the Woods, which opened on Thursday night at the Laura Pels Theater, makes the best case ever for a musical that interpreters have been trying to get right since the show was first staged in the mid-1980s.

title: Measure of a Radio Band
description: Administrivial Deb Amlen Sighting Alert! Once again, the Ace Hotel and I will be gently waking up New York City with the Jan. 25 Sunday crossword, and we hope you can join us for trivia, coffee and crossword-solving fun. We invade, sorry, we start at 11 a.m. Sunday, January 25, in the beautifully appointed Ace lobby, located at 20 West 29th Street. See you there!

title: Complaint Details How Silver Earned Millions From Obscure Legal Work
description: ALBANY  When federal prosecutors subpoenaed a law firm to learn what exactly Sheldon Silver, the powerful leader of the State Assembly, had done to earn the hundreds of thousands of dollars the firm paid him each year, prosecutors received just one file.

title: Nigeria: A Bird Flu Outbreak Spreads
description: An outbreak of avian flu that began in two states has spread to seven since last week and has infected more than 140,000 birds, Nigerias agriculture minister was quoted as saying by Nigerian news media on Thursday. The minister, Akwinumi Adesina, sought to assure the public that the outbreak had not reached a crisis. There is no cause for alarm, he said, though at least one strain of the virus that causes the disease, H5N1, can infect humans. He also exhorted Nigerian consumers not to fear poultry consumption because the virus is spread only through contact between live birds and people who directly handle them, and the virus dies when cooked. So, let Nigerians feel free to eat chicken and eggs, Mr. Adesina was quoted as saying. Nigeria is Africas most populous country and leading poultry producer.

description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Winklevoss Twins Aim to Take Bitcoin Mainstream
description: Bitcoin, the virtual currency that was once the talk of the financial world, has been taking a beating over the last year with the price tumbling downward.

title: Pennsylvania Court Blocks Charges Against Attorney General
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Pennsylvania Supreme Court on Thursday temporarily blocked a county prosecutor from filing charges against the state attorney general, Kathleen G. Kane, who has been accused by a grand jury of perjury and other offenses in connection with the disclosure of an investigation to a Philadelphia newspaper.

title: Events in Westchester for Jan. 25-31, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Far From Home, a Young Man Refuses to Let One Bad Choice Determine His Fate
description: Coming to New York City was a mistake, Pedro Martinez said.

title: Third Trial in 1998 U.S. Embassy Bombings in Africa Begins
description: Fourteen years after four men were convicted in a trial stemming from the deadly 1998 bombings of two United States Embassies in East Africa, a third trial in that attack began in Manhattan on Thursday.

title: Bruised but Unbowed, Reid Plans for Future
description: WASHINGTON  With white gauze over his right eye and deep purple bruises visible along his jaw, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada on Thursday held his first on-camera news conference since suffering injuries in a fall three weeks ago, seeking to dispel worries about his health and repeatedly saying he would seek re-election in 2016.

title: Gross Incompetence Cited in Rikers Island Death
description: A New York State watchdog agency overseeing jails and prisons has found that gross incompetence by medical personnel and correction officers at Rikers Island led to the death of a mentally ill inmate who was found naked and covered in feces after being locked in a cell for six days.

title: Events in New Jersey for Jan. 25-31, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Arkansas: Governor Seeks to Continue an Alternative to Medicaid
description: Gov. Asa Hutchinson, a Republican, asked lawmakers Thursday to keep the states alternative to Medicaid expansion under the Affordable Care Act in place for two more years. In the meantime, he said, a task force will come up with recommendations for changing or replacing it. The program, known as the private option, has used federal funds to buy private insurance for more than 200,000 poor people through the HealthCare.gov marketplace instead of adding them to traditional Medicaid. The Republican-dominated Legislature has to reauthorize the program with a three-fourths vote every year, and a number of lawmakers, including some elected in November, oppose it. Mr. Hutchinson said he wanted to find a compassionate, reasonable and cost-effective way to provide health care for people currently benefiting from the private option.

title: The First Woman Let Into McSorleys Reminisces (Over an Ale, of Course)
description: The low winter sun streamed into McSorleys Old Ale House and a waiter lounged next to the saloons potbellied stove on Thursday afternoon, when an 85-year-old woman with a wooden cane and a mischievous look pushed her way through the double doors.

title: Events in Connecticut for Jan. 25-31, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: A Nomad in the N.B.A. Is a Knick ... for Now
description: Lou Amundson, a forward for the Knicks, calls himself an aspiring minimalist. The possessions that surround his life suggest he has been on a long vacation  a remarkable, itinerant trip that has lasted several years, crisscrossing the United States.

title: U.S. Judge Says Dreamers Can Keep Drivers Licenses
description: PHOENIX  A federal judge has decided to make permanent an injunction overturning Arizonas ban on issuing drivers licenses to young immigrants who were brought to the United States illegally as children and spared from deportation by President Obama in 2012.

title: Salman Ascends Throne to Become Saudi King
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The new king of Saudi Arabia, Salman bin Abdul-Aziz Al Saud, has spent more than a half-century among the top echelons of one of the worlds most powerful families and is known to serve as mediator and peacekeeper between its often competing factions.

title: A Timeline of the Tamir Rice Shooting
description: A timeline of what happened after Tamir Rice, a 12-year-old boy, was killed by a police officer in Cleveland in November 2014.

title: Gay Mecca on Fire Island Sells for $10.1 Million at Auction
description: A strip of commercial real estate along the harbor in Fire Island Pines sold for $10.1 million at auction on Thursday to developers with plans to continue the revival of a former mecca for closeted gay men.

title: Modest Victory for Israel in Quest for International Meeting on Anti-Semitism
description: UNITED NATIONS  Israel scored a win at the United Nations. Sort of.

title: The Peculiar Genius of Bjrk
description: Solo musician or master collaborator? For her new album, Bjrk has merged the two sides of her artistry to create a new experience of music  again.

title: Trial of 2 Ebola Vaccines Effectiveness Is Announced
description: Federal officials said on Thursday that the first clinical trial to test the effectiveness of Ebola vaccines was expected to begin in Liberia in two weeks.

title: Vice Uses Virtual Reality to Immerse Viewers in News
description: A young woman stands in the middle of a crowd of protesters marching up a New York City street, shouting that she is fed up with police brutality, fed up with people saying that black lives dont matter, fed up with people telling her not to be angry.

title: At Mercy of the Draw, Players Often Hope for a Lucky Break
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Caroline Wozniacki did not lose her second-round match at the Australian Open on Thursday because of any moment of bad luck. There was no stray bounce on break point, no broken string on a crucial volley, no clipped net cord that swung the momentum.

description: aboriginal \a-b-rij-nl, -ri-j-nl\ noun and adjective

title: Former Thai Leader Impeached, Reawakening Tensions
description: BANGKOK  Dormant political tensions re-emerged in Thailand on Friday when the military juntas handpicked assembly impeached the countrys former prime minister, Yingluck Shinawatra.

title: Eugenie Bouchard Advances, Twirling Only Her Racket
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Returning to the site of her breakout semifinal run last year, Eugenie Bouchard advanced to the fourth round of the Australian Open in straightforward fashion on Friday  and she did not even have to twirl.

title: Weinstein Parts Ways With Press Agent for Finding Neverland
description: The film producer Harvey Weinstein and the veteran Broadway press agent Rick Miramontez have parted ways on Mr. Weinsteins forthcoming musical Finding Neverland after sharp words were said at their weekly planning meeting on Tuesday  a rare rupture in the image-conscious world of Broadway and another bump in the road for a highly anticipated musical.

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 5:30 P.M. (FX Movie Channel) THE GIRL WITH THE DRAGON TATTOO (2011) Daniel Craig stars as a crusading Swedish journalist hired by a wealthy industrialist (Christopher Plummer) to investigate the disappearance of his niece 40 years earlier in this adaptation of the Stieg Larsson novel, directed by David Fincher. Rooney Mara, in an Oscar-nominated performance, is Lisbeth Salander, the vulnerable yet ruthlessly competent computer hacker who helps him solve the mystery. She is a marvelous pop-culture character, stranger and more complex than the average superhero and more intriguing than the usual boy wizards and vampire brides, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about Lisbeth, first played by Noomi Rapace in the 2010 Swedish adaptation. It has been her fate, unfortunately, to make her furious, uninspiring way through a series of plodding and ungainly stories. And despite the slick intensity of Mr. Finchers style, his movie is not immune to the same lumbering proceduralism, Mr. Scott said, while acknowledging that Mr. Finchers impressive skill is evident.

title: Corrections: January 23, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day
description: For many years, New Yorkers have asked the question: How could Speaker Silver, one of the most powerful men in all of New York, earn millions of dollars in outside income without deeply compromising his ability to honestly serve his constituents? Today, we provide the answer: He didnt.

title: Roger Federer, Despite Multilingual Effort, Falls to Andreas Seppi at Australian Open
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Roger Federer shouted at himself in all three languages he speaks on Friday, trying to rouse a response from whatever part of him houses his tennis greatness.

title: Georgia, Back in the Death-Penalty Spotlight
description: The modern American death penalty is beset with endless complications and contradictions, and over the years no state has embodied the full range of these as consistently as Georgia.

description: There are two main schools of thought about the sudden resignation on Thursday of President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi of Yemen and his cabinet.

title: Test Yourself | Following in Wild Footsteps
description: Here are several paragraphs from a Dec. 5 Travel article, On the Wild Movie Trail in Oregon.

title: Saudi Arabias Succession Line Is Set, but the Nations Path Remains Uncertain
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Saudi Arabias new king moved with unprecedented swiftness on Friday to appoint not only the heir to his throne but the heir to his heir as well.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Microsoft HoloLens: A Sensational Vision of the PCs Future
description: In Microsoft HoloLens: A Sensational Vision of the PCs Future, Farhad Manjoo reviews Microsofts new augmented-reality headset.

title: 25 Years Later, McEnroe Reflects on an Ejection (He Can Be Serious)
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  It was 25 years to the day since John McEnroe was defaulted from the Australian Open, and McEnroe was sitting in a makeshift ESPN office at Melbourne Park and trying to recall the look on his face when he heard the verdict on court that steamy Sunday afternoon in 1990.

title: A Toddlers View of New York City
description: A lot has been said about embracing a childs view of photography. That a childs vision is innocent. That it is nave. That above all, it is pure, unburdened by the rules of cynical grown-ups.

title: Should a College Education Be Free?
description: States offer children a free public school education until they complete 12th grade. After that, they have to pay tuition. President Obama recently announced his proposal to make community college free for many students. Is he onto something? Should students be able to get a free education after high school?

title: Sony Postpones Earnings Announcement, Blaming Hacking Attacks
description: HONG KONG  Sony said Friday that it would delay the report of its earnings for the quarter ended Dec. 31 as a result of the hacking attacks on its American film studio, Sony Pictures Entertainment.

title: In Targeting Ex-Premier, Thai Junta Takes a Risk
description: BANGKOK  After months of claiming to be an honest broker in this deeply divided country, Thailands military junta swung decisively to the side of the conservative Bangkok establishment on Friday, imposing a five-year ban from politics on a former prime minister who is detested by the elites but loved in the provinces.

title: Ask Well: The Best Time to Exercise to Lose Weight
description: Question:

title: Beleaguered, Nigerians Seek to Restore a General to Power
description: KADUNA, Nigeria  Boisterous crowds packed the streets for the retired general, while young men climbed lampposts, walls and billboards to glimpse his gaunt face. Others danced on careening motorcycles, brandishing homemade brooms, symbols of his campaign.

title: Japanese Hostages Mother Urges Islamic State to Spare Him
description: TOKYO  Making a desperate plea for her sons life, the mother of one of two Japanese hostages held by the Islamic State militant group told his kidnappers on Friday that he was not an enemy of Islam.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: New York Today: Picturing a Crime Scene
description: Good morning on this fair Friday.

title: New King in Saudi Arabia Unlikely to Alter Oil Policy
description: The new king of Saudi Arabia moved quickly on Friday to assure global energy markets that the country would maintain its strategy of pushing other top exporters to maintain a high level of oil production. But a prolonged slump in oil prices, as well as budget pressures at home, will test his resolve.

title: Daily Report: Box Prices Its Offering at $14 a Share
description: After nearly a year of trying, the online file storage provider Box is finally set to become a public company. But it will begin trading in the face of questions about its future prospects, Michael J. de la Merced reports.

title: Eurozone Economy Shows Hints of Improvement, Survey Indicates
description: FRANKFURT  The eurozone economy appears to have perked up a bit at the start of 2015, an industry survey showed on Friday, just a day after the European Central Bank unveiled a major monetary stimulus program to restore growth and keep deflation at bay.

Hong Kong Editor, Attacked Last Year, Expresses Hope for Future of News Media
description: Since the newspaper editor Kevin Lau Chun-to was attacked with a cleaver last year and left bleeding on a Hong Kong street, he has embodied fears that the citys long tradition of journalistic independence is under assault.

title: Today in Politics
description: King Abdullahs Death Brings Complex U.S. Relationship Into Focus

title: Chappatte Goes to Davos
description: Policy talk at the World Economic Forum.

title: Morning Agenda: Winklevosses Plan Bitcoin Exchange
description: WINKLEVOSSES PLAN BITCOIN EXCHANGE | The Winklevoss twins, two of the biggest boosters of Bitcoin, are trying to firm up support for the virtual currency by creating the first regulated Bitcoin exchange for American customers, Nathaniel Popper and Sydney Ember write in DealBook. The brothers have hired engineers from top hedge funds, enlisted a bank and engaged regulators with the aim of opening their exchange, which they have financed themselves, in the coming months. They are calling the exchange Gemini  Latin for twins.

title: Bradley Cooper to Take The Elephant Man to London Stage
description: LONDON  The Broadway revival of The Elephant Man, starring Bradley Cooper, will travel to London in May, the plays producers announced on Friday.

title: G.E. Profit Rises as It Puts a Stronger Focus on Its Industrial Business
description: General Electric on Friday reported modestly higher quarterly profit and revenue, as it increasingly relies more on its industrial business and less on finance.

title: Is Times Vulgarity Policy Wise? Or Full of Slop?
description: When Jonathan Martin jumped through hoops last week to avoid using a vulgarity in the lead anecdote of his story, some readers let me know they didnt like it.

title: Court Upholds Frances Move to Strip Citizenship of Man Jailed on Terror Charge
description: PARIS  Frances top court ruled on Friday that it was legal for the French government to strip a French-Moroccan man of his citizenship, reinforcing the countrys right to employ the antiterrorism tool as it tries to tighten its security after deadly terrorist attacks.

title: Davos 2015: The Power Sets Ready-to-Wear Show in the Snow
description: January means showtime, from mens wear (currently wrapping up in Paris) to couture (stay tuned next week); the red carpet (Golden Globes, Critics Choice Awards and the Screen Actors Guild Awards on Sunday), and, this week, that executive style fest otherwise known as the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. If you want to know how the power set dress in the snow, this is the catwalk you need to watch.

title: London Hedge Fund Founder Sentenced to 13 Years in Prison
description: LONDON  The founder of Weavering Capital was sentenced to 13 years in prison on Friday after he was convicted of fraud and other criminal charges this week related to the collapse of the hedge fund in 2009.

title: Yemen Calm but Confused After Presidents Resignation
description: SANA, Yemen  A full day after the president of Yemen and his entire government abruptly resigned, calm prevailed on the streets of the capital even while it remained unclear who was in charge of this country of 26 million.

title: How Economists Came to Dominate the Conversation
description: Have we reached peak economist?

title: Communist Leadership Approves Security Goals for China
description: HONG KONG  Chinas Communist Party leadership approved a blueprint on Friday setting out national security priorities and warning that the country faced daunting domestic and external dangers.

title: McDonalds Tests Custom Burgers and Other New Concepts as Sales Drop
description: In what was one of its worst financial performances in the last decade, McDonalds on Friday reported sharp declines in sales and earnings, further evidence of the impact of tough competition and changing consumer tastes on one of Americas biggest and best-known restaurant brands.

title: Correcting the Trains Grammar
description: Dear Diary:

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: The Enemy as Hapless Clown
description: To mock Adolf Hitler, Charlie Chaplin created Adenoid Hynkel, who sputtered gibberish and danced with a balloon in The Great Dictator. Woody Allen lampooned American relations with Cuba in Bananas by donning a glue-on beard and impersonating a fulminating Fidel Castro. Skewering Muammar el-Qaddafi in The Dictator, Sacha Baron Cohen wore a Love Boat cap and wandered cluelessly around Manhattan.

title: New Yorks New Rentals: Smaller Apartments, More Perks
description: Developers of large rental buildings have stuck to a formula over the past several years: Keep apartments small; go big on amenities. Now, with a surge of rentals coming to market, some developers are pushing this formula to the max, tweaking apartment sizes and piling on the perks.

title: A Small Batch From Lifes Work
description: Aleksei German, who died last February at the age of 74 while putting the finishing touches on his most ambitious film, the long-awaited Hard to Be a God, was regarded by some as Russias greatest living director  despite, or perhaps because of, the fact that he managed to complete but a handful of features in a nearly half-century career.

title: Flying Deluxe Domestic Coast-to-Coast for Around $1,000
description: Whats the next best thing to business class?

title: On the Paris Mens Fall 2015 Runways, an Appetite for Destruction
description: A documentary on Kurt Cobain, produced by his daughter Frances, is set to premiere this weekend at the 2015 Sundance Film Festival as the first fully authorized film on the late grunge legend. Coincidentally, at the mens fall/winter shows in Paris, tattered knits of the sort Cobain might have worn have surfaced on the runways. Raf Simons, whose collections always reflect on the rough-and-tumble energies of youth and music, presented a series of looks with pieces in various states of deterioration. There were floor-length vests with frayed edges, coats with ragged hems, trenches with their linings spilling out of the sleeves and the hole-ridden sweater vest seen above. Unraveling ribbed sweaters at Damir Doma were a nice contrast to the tailored suits and pleated high-waisted trousers in the collection. And Yohji Yamamoto showed a Frankenstein of a jumper  two different knits ripped and haphazardly sewn together down the front.

title: In Far-Flung Myanmar, a Land of Contradictions
description: It is strange how some of the worlds most retrograde authoritarian states end up being such inadvertent conservators of both their countrys architectural heritage and vast tracts of wild, unspoiled nature. Of course, it was not their leaders intention to distinguish themselves as environmentalists or conservationists, but by so abjectly failing to develop viable economic engines, they nonetheless had this providential effect.

title: Sharing iTunes With the Whole Family
Deciding Whether to Trust Your Senses. Or Not.
description: As much as he was a director or producer, Otto Preminger (1905-86) was an impresario. He was a master self-promoter as well, with a fondness for controversial subjects, presold properties and stunt casting  not least his own role as an on-set tyrant.

title: For Sale: Multimillion-Dollar Homes, Fully Furnished
description: When James Michael Howard, a decorator from Jacksonville, Fla., began designing and building homes in the Hamptons five years ago, he decided they would have more cachet if they were furnished.

title: Rick Owens, Valentino and Louis Vuitton: The Fluidity of Gender
description: PARIS  If anatomy is destiny, Rick Owenss show, held Thursday amid a selection of provocative paintings by the poet John Giorno and the artist Chan Aye at the Palais de Tokyo, Pariss premier contemporary art museum, is destined to be remembered for some startling glimpses of the male anatomy.

title: Whats On This Week Around the World
description: The Hague

title: BBVA Agrees to Sell Stake in China Citic Bank for $1.7 Billion
description: LONDON  The Spanish lender BBVA said on Friday that it had agreed to sell a 4.9 percent stake in China Citic Bank to the Chinese real estate developer Xinhu Zhongbao for 13.1 billion Hong Kong dollars, or about $1.7 billion.

title: Sundance 2015: Robert Redford, Minding His Own Business
description: PARK CITY, Utah  The Sundance Film Festival got underway, as always, with a press conference at the Egyptian Theater here. And the festivals founder, Robert Redford, had a lot of thoughts, as always, on the topics of storytelling and cinematic diversity  Sundances raisons dtre.

title: U.S. and India Appear Ready to Try to Hash Out Differences
description: NEW DELHI  Differences that the United States and India have been grappling with for years are expected to dominate talks between President Obama and Prime Minister Narendra Modi when they meet in New Delhi next week.

title: Feta-Brined Roast Chicken
description: Melissa Clark soaks chicken in feta brine before roasting it to season the bird and lock in moisture.

title: In Silvers Backyard, Views of the Case Against Him Are Split
description: When not in Albany, Sheldon Silver, the speaker of the New York State Assembly, has spent much of his life within a small pocket of the district that he has represented for almost four decades on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. It is an area bounded by the tenement building he grew up in, the synagogue he attends and the brown-brick co-op complex where he resides today.

title: Track Changes
description: I had just turned 20 the winter I passed as a man. I was backpacking through Europe alone. Others I knew at my study-abroad program in England had found travel companions, but I had decided to venture out by myself, armed with an unlimited train pass and a small amount of cash. My strategy was to sleep on the night trains to save money. It was both a brave and a stupid plan. (Mostly stupid.) It certainly didnt occur to me in advance that I would need to alter my appearance.

title: An Issue That Feta Can Solve
description: Brining a chicken before roasting it is an age-old technique. An overnight soak in brine seasons the bird through and through, and locks in moisture for tender flesh.

title: The Case for Legalized Gambling on Sports
description: When the N.B.A. commissioner Adam Silver announced in November that he was in favor of legalizing sports betting in the United States, he shattered decades of genteel sporting tradition. For generations, major professional sports leagues in America have done their best to pretend sports gambling does not exist. But, as Silver wrote in an opinion column in The Times, illegal gambling is already everywhere. Urging legislators to contend with the reality that information technology has made it impossible to confine sports betting to Nevada, Silver argued for taking the market, worth an estimated $400 billion a year, into the realm of the licit.

title: Coeur of E.C.B. Says Stars Are Aligned for Stimulus Measures
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  A top official with the European Central Bank on Friday defended its long-awaited economic stimulus program, saying it would be more effective than critics say because it coincides with other favorable developments, like the plunge in oil prices.

title: Whose Tomb? Greece Wonders
description: Call it CSI: Alexander. For months, the excavations at a large ancient tomb in northern Greece have gripped the country. First, a marble slab wall was unearthed. Then, through announcements and leaks from the Greek Culture Ministry meted out with the pacing of a good mystery series, headless sphinxes and other statues were found. Finally, bones! But whose?

title: Why a Supreme Court Housing Case Could Have a Broad Impact
description: Jennifer Taub is a professor at Vermont Law School. Her book Other Peoples Houses was published in May by Yale University Press.

title: Reply All: The 1.11.15 Issue
description: SEBASTIAN SEUNGS QUEST TO MAP THE HUMAN BRAIN

title: Two Cents, Too Late
description: On public transportation, a young man entered my train car and made an announcement requesting money to pay for medication he needed. Three college-age men teamed up to contribute around $20. After the man left the car, a person sitting next to the trio told them that the man was actually a scammer who had used that pitch on a regular basis for a long time. Upon hearing this, the men looked crestfallen. Did the onlooker have the right to devalue their charity? Shouldnt he have intervened while the money was being offered? Should he have stayed silent afterward? PATRICK BACHLER, CHICAGO

title: The New Orleans Variations
description: Last Thanksgiving, some friends and I gathered in the Holy Cross section of New Orleanss Lower Ninth Ward. The turkey was in the oven, the oyster dressing was prepped, the cranberry sauce was made with the juice of local satsumas and the green beans were trimmed and ready to be dropped into a pan with toasted pecans and brown butter. There was plenty of beer and wine, but not much to work with in the way of cocktail-making, and a cocktail certainly seemed in order.

title: Why Is India So Crazy for World Records?
description: The first time Nikhil Shukla adjudicated a Guinness world record, two million people turned up. Standing on a makeshift dais just before dawn in January 2012, Shukla gazed with bleary, incredulous eyes; he was 28, and he had never seen such a mammoth crowd in his life. Tolls on the national highway from the nearest city, Rajkot, had been suspended to accommodate the traffic, and Shukla had to trudge 20 minutes from his V.I.P. parking spot, squeezing through dense thickets of bodies, to approach the stage. The throng that gathered in this patch of dusty farmland in western India to watch the event came from villages and towns across the district. They had responded to a call from a Gujarati community organization that, with a vague aim of promoting public harmony, wanted people to pair off and shake hands with one another, setting a world record for the most simultaneous handshakes.

title: Sundance 2015: The Bronze Does Not Exactly Wow on Opening Night
description: PARK CITY, Utah  John Cooper, Sundances director, was trying to introduce The Bronze, this years big opening-night feature, but members of the Eccles Theater audience were not done chatting. He finally stopped to shush them. But this crowd was not in a cooperative mood  right down to the reception of the film.

title: Student Contest Winners | The 2014 Year in Rap
description: In December, we invited students to write raps about the very busy news year that was 2014, and we werent at all surprised when nearly every entry mentioned Ferguson, Eric Garner, Tamir Rice or the related protests that roiled the nation from August on. Not only did these events hit close to home for many teenagers, but the hip-hop community at large has been engaged from the very beginning.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: timing lunch, childbirth pain and Disneyland diseases. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Blurring Boundaries Between Art and Activism in Cuba
description: MEXICO CITY  Of the half-dozen pieces that form Tania Brugueras series Tatlins Whisper, the one that the Cuban government silenced may have resounded most.

title: Is Your Data Safe at Healthcare.gov?
description: If youre concerned about online privacy, youve likely read a lot aboutwhat happens to the informationyou enter into sites like Facebook or Google.But now another website isgenerating privacy worries: Healthcare.gov.

title: U.S. Attorney Criticizes Albanys Three Men in a Room Culture
description: One day after charging one of New Yorks leading lawmakers with exploiting his office to obtain millions of dollars in kickbacks and bribes, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York delivered a stinging condemnation of the culture of corruption in Albany and said the system was set up to breed misdeeds.

title: Online Storage Company Box Has Strong Debut in First Day of Trading
description: Although questions had arisen about how Boxs initial public offering would fare, public investors gave the company a warm welcome on Friday, its first day of trading.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Sundance 2015: Tweet of the Week
description: As the Baggers colleague Brooks Barnes reports, Sundances opening-night film The Bronze did not go over well with many, including David Fear of Rolling Stone.com:

title: India on a Griddle: A Savory Dosa Recipe Worth the Effort
description: Pancakes for breakfast, lunch or dinner? By all means, but make mine savory, please. To me, sweet pancakes are dessert.

title: 1940: Paderewski Vows Deliverance
description: In words as resonant as the notes of Chopins Polonaise Militaire, which he has played thousands of times for encore-demanding audiences the world over, Ignace Jan Paderewski, seventy nine year old pianist-patriot, stood before his people yesterday at the Polish National Council and pledged the deliverance of his 35,000,000 countrymen. Although Paderewski was speaking not as a musician but as a Pole in the service of his nation, and although the voice of an aged man still weak from illness could not develop those crescendos that have never failed to thrill listeners as his long delicate fingers hit the keyboard, the nobility of his ideas and the dramatic turn of his phrases made the speech a series of forensic fortissimos. In the awareness that he might not live to see again the state of which he had the honor to be the first President, Paderewski stamped this discourse as the last will and testament to Poland of one of its servants.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 24, 1940

title: Leaks and Ad-Libs: How to Cover the State of the Union Address
description: This week, reporters and editors in The Timess Washington and New York offices prepared for President Obamas State of the Union address, knowing that they would write, and rewrite, articles before, during and after the speech, all on tight deadlines.

title: 1965: Smoking Countess Convicted
description: PARIS A pipe-smoking countess, who was once an interpreter on Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhowers civilian staff, was sentenced to 18 years imprisonment for plotting to assassinate President de Gaulle. The State Security Court found Mrs. Paule de Roussoulet, 56, who adopted the title Countess of Liffiac, guilty of planning to shoot Gen. de Gaulle last Feb. 15 when he visited the cole Militaire here. Two other defendants were also convicted. A civilian Jean Bichon, 51, was given 20 years and Capt. Robert Poinard, 38, was sentenced to 15 years. Security police uncovered the plot about two weeks before it was to take place. Bichon allegedly was the ringleader of the group. Poinard and Mrs. de Roussoulet, a teacher of English at the cole Militaire, were accused of encouraging the intended killers and planning to facilitate their entry to the school. Gen. de Gaulle was to have been shot by a high- powered rifle equipped with a telescopic sight as he crossed the cole courtyard.New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 24, 1965

title: Paperback Row
description: PLATO AT THE GOOGLEPLEX: Why Philosophy Wont Go Away,  by Rebecca Newberger Goldstein. (Vintage, $16.95.) Goldstein revives the art of the dialogue, bringing the Greek philosopher to life in 21st-century America and sending him on a multicity book tour. As he probes some of the deepest questions confronting us  from sexuality and child-rearing to morality and the meaning of life  we hear authentic Platonic arguments brought nicely up to date, Anthony Gottlieb wrote here.

title: For Auschwitz Museum, a Time of Great Change
description: OSWIECIM, Poland  For what is likely to be the last time, a large number of the survivors of the Nazi concentration camps at Auschwitz will gather next week under an expansive tent, surrounded by royalty and heads of state, to commemorate the 70th anniversary of the liberation of those held there at the end of World War II.

title: Editors Choice
description: LEAVING BEFORE THE RAINS COME,  by Alexandra Fuller. (Penguin Press, $26.95.) Fuller, who described her idiosyncratic African childhood in Dont Lets Go to the Dogs Tonight, here offers an account of the collapse of her long marriage.

title: Inequality as a Religious Issue: A Conversation With the Archbishop of Canterbury
description: In the two years since the Most Rev. Justin Welby was installed as archbishop of Canterbury, he has traveled the world to talk with other church leaders, and his assessment of those visits has been, in many ways, grim.

title: Inside the List
description: Starting Over: When is a debut not a debut? When a writer changes names and genres, for one thing  as did the British author Paula Hawkins, whose debut thriller, The Girl on the Train, enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 2. To judge from the Q. and A. at her publishers website, youd never know that Hawkins, a financial journalist for 15 years, previously wrote romantic comedies under a pseudonym. That was womens fiction, I suppose, Hawkins told NPR in a recent interview. Much more lighthearted, not so much killing. . . . I did enjoy writing them, but they kept getting darker and darker. And once I started writing this book I knew this was what I was supposed to be doing. It just felt completely right for me. This sounds awful, but Im not, you know, a joyful, romantic person. Well, I can be, but Ive got a proper dark side and I enjoy indulging it. Shes not kidding: The Girl on the Train is about an alcoholic commuter, fired from her job, who spins an obsessive fantasy about a couple along her train route and who may know something about the wifes disappearance. (Comparisons to Gone Girl are not misplaced.) I had no luck unearthing Hawkinss earlier pseudonym, but I did find a financial guide she published under her own name in Britain, The Money Goddess, which invents a group of Sex and the City"-like friends as it dispenses advice about shopping for mortgages or planning for retirement. Its the Bridget Jones of finance, according to one Amazon customer, who awarded it four out of five stars.

title: Letters: David Bezmozgis Replies
description: David Bezmozgis Replies

title: A Solo Spotlight for a Powerful Voice
description: NASHVILLE  At the Soundcheck rehearsal studio complex in Nashville, 18-wheeler trucks ready to haul equipment for country stars arena tours were backed up to loading bays. Its probably a safe bet that on a recent Sunday afternoon, only Studio D held a band playing a replica of an 1858 fretless minstrel banjo and two sets of bones, the hand-held percussion instrument, clattering away in a medley of tunes at least 150 years old.

title: King Abdullah Mourned by Saudis
description: Saudi Arabias King Salman led prayers for King Abdullah in Riyadh ahead of his burial Friday afternoon.

title: Reading the Tea Leaves: More Fund-Raisers by Clinton Allies
description: When will Hillary Rodham Clinton announce her long-awaited presidential campaign? One guess can be found in a new round of fund-raisers being organized by Ready for Hillary, the super PAC founded to organize grass-roots supporters and potential donors for a Clinton campaign.

title: The View from Inside the Stroller
description: Diego Acosta Lpez wanted to see what it was like when his son, Ignacio  just shy of 2  visited New York City for the first time. Now, it wasnt exactly a smart idea to let the toddler handle his big-boy DLSR. So he figured out the next best thing: mounting a GoPro camera to the boys stroller right behind his head, set it to take a picture every 10 seconds and go zipping around town.

title: Diverse Israeli Arab Political Factions Join Forces to Keep Place in Parliament
description: JERUSALEM  Facing an increased electoral threshold that threatens to bar small parties from Parliament, Israels Arab political factions announced on Friday the formation of a single ticket for the March elections.

title: The League, a Dating App for Would-Be Power Couples
description: SAN FRANCISCO  On a Saturday night just before the end of the year, single and single-ish professionals gathered for the Guardsmen Tree Lot Party, an annual fund-raiser for underprivileged children.

title: Sundance 2015: A Lesson or Two From Sundance 2014
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Every year, dozens of directors trek to this ski outpost in the mountains outside Salt Lake City hoping that a distributor will see promise in their film and make a deal to pump it out to the world. But the dream can get dicey in a hurry. Consider Song One.

title: Clinton Opponents Hone New Barbs and Attacks as 2016 Campaign Nears
description: First, she was called the bra-burning feminist with a degree from Wellesley. Then, she was the aggressively political spouse from Arkansas who plotted behind closed doors. Today, she is the millionaire elitist who socializes in New York City and the Hamptons.

title: War Is Exploding Anew in Ukraine; Rebels Vow More
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  Unexpectedly, at the height of the Ukrainian winter, war has exploded anew on a half-dozen battered fronts across eastern Ukraine, accompanied by increasing evidence that Russian troops and Russian equipment have been pouring into the region again.

title: The Wolfpack Tells of One New York Apartment With Seven Children Locked Inside
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Its quite a tale: Seven children, all with waist-length hair, are raised on welfare in a messy four-bedroom apartment on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. And they are almost never allowed to leave the house. For years.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Jill Leovys Ghettoside
description: This week, Jill Leovy discusses Ghettoside; Patton Oswalt talks about his memoir Silver Screen Fiend; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Anita Shapira discusses Ben-Gurion: Father of Modern Israel; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Theaster Gates, Artes Mundi Recipient, to Share Prize money
description: LONDON  The Chicago-based artist Theaster Gates accepted the 40,000-pound Artes Mundi prize on Thursday night in Cardiff, Wales, offering up an expletive as he announced that he would share the winnings with the nine other nominees.

title: Expedia Buys Travelocity for $280 Million in Cash
description: Expedia agreed on Friday to buy its fellow travel booking site Travelocity for $280 million in cash, nearly two years after the two forged a marketing and technology partnership.

title: At the Fulcrum of Preventing Another Financial Crisis
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Perhaps more than any other financial figure, Mark Carney has the job of ensuring that the worlds largest banks are no longer a great danger to the economies in which they operate.

title: Consumer Protection for Mortgage Seekers
description: Citing survey results showing that almost half of borrowers fail to shop around for a mortgage lender, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau wants to empower consumers to be more discerning when selecting a home loan.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Jill Leovys Ghettoside
description: This week, Jill Leovy, Patton Oswalt and Anita Shapira.

title: A Police Chief Turned Pastor, Working to Heal the Nations Racial Rifts
description: NORTH LAKE, Wis.  In the days leading up to Christmas, the aging pastor of a small Episcopal church set amid the glacial hills here began to write a parable. It came neither from Scripture nor from yuletide tradition, but rather from the priests very different earlier life.

title: Bank of England Governor Backs E.C.B. Strategy
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Mark Carney, the governor of the Bank of England, on Friday firmly backed the European Central Banks decision to buy bonds to stimulate the stagnant European economy.

title: If I Fall, if I Die, by Michael Christie
description: The skateboard, that preferred mode of transportation for the alienated and disaffected  and also able to black out the rest of the world, as Tony Hawk put it in his 2000 autobiography, Hawk. Occupation: Skateboarder  appears midway through Michael Christies novel of a troubled childhood, If I Fall, if I Die. Its a transformative object, this skateboard, redemptive and cathartic, and it helps the 11-year-old hero, Will Cardiel, convey himself, literally and figuratively, from what has been up to then a life of privation with his single mother.

title: The Forgotten Depression, by James Grant
description: When the next big economic disaster hits, Washington will almost certainly choose to do something: cut taxes, increase spending, lower interest rates. There is another option, of course: do nothing. No fiscal or monetary stimulus. Let the fire burn the rot of excess from the system. From the ashes, goes this theory, a healthier, more balanced economy will emerge.

title: Restoring a Park Slope Wreck
description: A building at the heart of Park Slope, Brooklyn, that had fallen into disrepair in recent years is being restored and converted into spacious condominium apartments.

title: The Romance of Wine
description: I am a romantic about wine. I dont mind saying it, even though some people may consider that soft and unrealistic, lacking the sort of rigor necessary to avoid being manipulated by fairy tales and marketers.

title: The Unofficial Start of the Presidential Campaign
description: This is the period when overpaid political consultants talk about the unofficial start of the presidential campaign  a notion as meaningless as the official start. Candidates take advantage of this period to launch exploratory committees that allow them to raise money without the annoyance of disclosing donors, and to soak up news coverage.

title: Kris Van Assch: Fall 2015 Menswear
description: Paris

title: Finding a Nanny Who Fits With Your Family
description: IF youre lucky enough to have a nanny like the one Shachar Scott has, one who was with her at the hospital when her twins were born more than three years ago, does everything she wants, keeps her informed when she travels and gets along brilliantly with the family, stop reading now.

title: E.C.B.s Bazooka Is a Water Pistol for Emerging Markets
description: The European Central Bank has fired its bazooka. For emerging markets, its little more than a water pistol.

title: Marissa Mayer and the Fight to Save Yahoo!, by Nicholas Carlson
description: One day in 2012, Marissa Mayer was whirling around Yahoos office in Sunnyvale, Calif., directing a redesign of the home page and the companys uncool but still widely used email application. The next, she was the proud mother of her first child, who was nicknamed BBBB in the hospital, for Big Baby Boy Bogue (her husbands last name). This would hardly be considered extraordinary if it werent for the fact that she had recently been named the companys C.E.O. Female chief executives typically live in glass boxes where every move they make is held up for intense public scrutiny, and most get themselves there through brutal amounts of work and by avoiding anything that draws attention to the fact that theyre women. Yet right after starting her job running a troubled $30 billion technology giant, Mayer announced that she would be taking a maternity leave, albeit a stunningly short one. (She took two weeks.) The audacity of the move  accepting a top executive job knowing that she was five months pregnant and then taking so little time off  prompted an Internet outcry (The Pregnant C.E.O.: Should You Hate Marissa Mayer? Forbes asked in one representative example), in which even progressives grumbled about the privilege involved, including Mayers household staff and in-office nursery. And so it was that her upsetting of the womens-issues industrial complex became all that most people know about Mayer. Yet there is much more to the picture.

title: Doulas, Who Usher in New Life, Find Mission in Support for the Dying
description: MARY HILBURN spent the last three years watching her partner of 17 years, Jo Allison Bennett, die of brain cancer. Their families werent supportive, and many of their friends found the experience too emotionally wrenching to become very involved.

title: Nets Mirza Teletovic Is Sidelined for Season by Blood Clots
description: Mirza Teletovic of the Nets will miss the rest of the season after being diagnosed with bilateral pulmonary embolus, a formation of blood clots in the lungs.

title: Book Review Podcast: Jill Leovys Ghettoside
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Jennifer Gonnerman reviews Jill Leovys Ghettoside: A True Story of Murder in America. Ms. Gonnerman writes:

title: What I Love | Dr. Patricia Wexler
description: The dermatologist Patricia Wexler and her husband, Dr. Eugene Wexler, retreat to their Upper East Side apartment.

title: Sometimes Golden Oldies Means the Band, Not the Music
description: A 4-YEAR-OLD GIRL twirled and jumped in what is normally a parking lot to the music of Monko, telling her mother it was her favorite band.

title: 700,000 Homeowners Could Still Benefit From U.S. HARP Refinancing
description: ALTHOUGH the housing market is increasingly on the mend, hundreds of thousands of homeowners still have little or no equity in their homes and could benefit from a federal mortgage refinancing program that is scheduled to end this year.

title: Her Prescription for Home: Color
description: Dr. Patricia Wexler and her husband, Eugene, were at their house in the Hamptons on a July weekend a few years ago when the call came from the superintendent of their Upper East Side condominium: Youve got to get home immediately.

title: Childless, With Regret and Advice: Dont Wait for the Perfect Picture
description: Growing up, I rebelled against my beautiful redheaded mother, a domestic goddess. A feisty orphan from the Lower East Side, she had revered the four older siblings who took care of her. She married my father at 19, planning to start her own big family. After working as a secretary and office manager to put him through medical school in the Midwest, she became a proud stay-at-home mom. She had me at 27, then my carrot-top brothers arrived, 17 months apart (called Yiddish twins), followed by a third boy. As the oldest and only girl, I was mommys little helper, which I resented. She was always cooking, feeding, cleaning. I felt born in the wrong role, resolved to escape taking care of babies.

title: The Democratic Convention: When? July 2016. Where? T.B.D.
description: The Democrats dont have a city yet, but they now have a date for their nominating convention.

title: Privilege Is a Privilege, and a Responsibility
description: Two weeks ago, I walked into a local delicatessen to get a sandwich for lunch. The man behind the counter looked to be in his early 30s, and we struck up a conversation. I asked how he was feeling about the upcoming year, and the one that just passed. Its amazing what people will tell you if they sense you are genuinely interested.

title: Where the Dead Pause, and the Japanese Say Goodbye, by Marie Mutsuki Mockett
description: Among the many shocking things about tsunamis  along with their suddenness, violence and indiscriminate destruction of life and community  is how little there is to say about them. Man-made catastrophes, like wars or nuclear accidents, provide infinite opportunities for blame, recrimination and lessons learned. But natural disasters have no politics. One can quibble about the height of sea walls, the promptness of warnings and the quality of aid given to survivors. But such events have always occurred in countries like Japan, and always will. When the wave has receded, the dead have been counted and the slow work of recovery has begun, the pundits sheepishly quit the field and abandon it to the theologians, the spiritualists and the priests.

title: Once Upon a Time, by Marina Warner
description: In her new and vigorous book on fairy tales, Once Upon a Time, the scholar Marina Warner explains a crucial stage of story pollination. Discussing early versions of Puss in Boots and Rapunzel, written by the Italians Straparola and Basile, she notes,Its no accident that these two authors created their story cycles in great seaports, where cultures, languages and ideas  and above all travelers  met one another.

title: There Was and There Was Not, by Meline Toumani
description: In 2005, Meline Toumani, an Armenian-American, went to live in Turkey  the country that, in its former incarnation as the Ottoman Empire, killed more than one million Armenians beginning in 1915, in mass deportations most historians regard as genocide. Fellow Armenians considered her decision perverse, not least because she, like them, had imbibed stories of Turkish plunder and murder along with her mothers milk. But Toumani is an idealistic, somewhat contrary soul. Although in no doubt of Turkish culpability, she was convinced of the need for reconciliation on a basic, human level.

title: SkyMalls Parent Files for Bankruptcy Protection
description: The parent of the in-flight shopping magazine SkyMall said on Friday that it had filed for bankruptcy protection, citing in-flight Wi-Fi access as one of the factors luring shoppers away from its quirky catalog of travel products, pet toys and garden gnomes.

title: Sophia: Princess, Suffragette, Revolutionary, by Anita Anand
description: Part of a biographers job is to rescue forgotten figures, and in Sophia: Princess, Suffragette, Revolutionary Anita Anand has salvaged an extraordinary one. Sophia Duleep Singh was a Punjabi princess and Queen Victorias goddaughter, a bucktoothed docile little thing who went on to become a celebrated London fashion plate and then a steely suffragist.

title: The Match Girl and the Heiress, by Seth Koven
description: Faith-based social policies have gotten a bad name lately, but not long ago they formed the core of many admirable progressive movements. Some late Victorian Christians arguably stood between Londons poorest and the Dickensian horrors suffered by the likes of Oliver Twist.

title: When Books Went to War, by Molly Guptill Manning
description: From the Airborne Infantry of the front lines to the chair-borne Finance Corps of the rear, an American soldier observed from an English hospital in the midst of World War II, you can find the boys reading as they never have before. He was referring to the ubiquitous presence, among troops stationed abroad, of Armed Services Editions, or A.S.E.s: disposable pocket-size paperback reprints of a wide range of current and classic titles paid for by the United States government and produced by a consortium of the nations publishers. The editions, as the soldiers remark suggests, met the demand for print among American military personnel overseas while opening up possibilities for greater consumption of books in the postwar period.

title: Pigalles Night at the Opra
description: PARIS  For Pigalle, the streetwear label born and raised in the not-fully-gentrified neighborhood that inspired its name, the Beaux-Arts splendor of the Palais Garnier, traditional home of the Paris Opra, seems a world apart  although, as the fan of the label and fellow Pigalle resident Caroline de Maigret pointed out, they both are technically in the 9th Arrondissement.

title: See Baja on a Ship With a Past
description: The small-ship cruise company AdventureSmith Explorations has added a historic yacht to its inventory of ships exploring the Baja Peninsula.

title: Video Reviews of Black Sea, Cake and Mommy
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Black Sea, Cake and Mommy. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Somebodys Watching Us
description: About fifty years ago, the Pulitzer Prize-winning historian Richard Hofstadter exposed a dark recess of the American psyche with an essay in Harpers Magazine, The Paranoid Style in American Politics. Hofstadter was writing about the peculiar tendency of the political right to indulge in paranoid theories, but he was careful to stipulate that the left could just as easily be infected. American politics has often been an arena for angry minds, he wrote.

title: Casey Walkers Last Days in Shanghai
description: In the lobby of an apartment building in the Chinese factory city of Dongguan, I once saw this sign: for the peace of residents, renovation will stop on jan. 1. it will resume on jan. 2.

title: Offcomer, by Jo Baker
description: Offcomer is the Lancashire word for an outsider, a person from somewhere else who will never quite fit in. Its the perfect term for the underachieving and dispirited Claire Thomas, the central character in Jo Bakers first novel  published only last month in the United States, 12 years after it appeared in Britain and 11 years before the spectacular success of Bakers fifth novel, Longbourn, in 2013.

title: Van Gogh, by Julian Bell
description: As a fledgling artist, Vincent van Gogh hired a carpenter to build a perspective frame: a wire-grid window. He used it to draw the Dutch countryside, his eyes darting between his pencil and the views through the frame. A few years later, van Gogh suffered a spate of psychiatric crises that sent him to an asylum in Saint Rmy, France. There his bedrooms barred window doubled as a new perspective frame, albeit one with only verticals, through which he sketched the wheat field below.

title: The Season of Migration, by Nellie Hermann
description: Poor van Gogh. Impossibly tenderhearted yet forbiddingly irascible. Push-pulled by scorching genius and helpless servitude to his own morality. Before becoming a painter, he put in a disastrous stint at an evangelical school, his failure there due in part to his obstinacy. As one of his classmates put it, he did not know what submission was. But to the clarity and purity of his vision he submitted in full, to the point of madness, to the point of utter self-abnegation.

title: Get Your Freekeh On
description: Chefs are coming up with all sorts of inspiring ideas for grains, and I was lucky enough to learn about some of them at last Novembers Whole Grains: Breaking Barriers conference organized in Boston by Oldways and the Whole Grains Counsel. I moderated a panel of three local chefs: Ana Sortun of Oleana and Sarma, Jason Bond of Bondir, and Barry Maiden of Hungry Mother, as well as Liz lEtoile of Four Stars Farms, a small Massachusetts farm that is producing and milling wheat, corn, rye, barley and hops. Boston area chefs are delighted that they can now get local grains, milled only days before delivery.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Junya Watanabe Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Maison Margiela Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Junya Watanabe Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.

title: Baldfaced Hornet: A Selfless Builder That Stings
description: Winter is not generally the time of year to search for insects, but then the baldfaced hornet is not an insect most are excited to see. Winter is simply the time of year when this wasps handiwork is most safely admired.

title: New Saudi King and U.S. Face Crucial Point in the Relationship
description: WASHINGTON  Almost a decade ago, an Arab diplomat famously likened the relationship between the United States and Saudi Arabia to a Catholic marriage where you can have no divorce.

title: Ben Metcalfs Against the Country
description: A remarkable thing about the novel is that it can incorporate almost anything  essays, short stories, mock memoirs, screenplays, emails  and remain a novel. This elasticity is also a sign that unlike, say, the epic or the ode, the novel is a living, evolving form. But if its outer limits are virtually nonexistent, the minimum requirement is generally that there be a narrator telling us something. In this way, any manner of book can find a way to justify calling itself a novel. But the label should not be worn lightly, since it invites scrutiny of the highest and most exacting kind.

title: Esther Freuds Mr. Mac and Me
description: See everything. Hear everything. Say nothing, reads a poster outside the town hall in Esther Freuds evocative eighth novel, Mr. Mac and Me. Its 1914, at the dawn of World War I, and the coastal Suffolk village of Walberswick is on high alert, its citizens patrolling the beaches and casting suspicious glances at newcomers, since anyone might be a spy. Our guide through this world is Thomas Maggs, age 13 when the book begins. The son of a drunk who runs the local pub, Thomas loves to draw (mostly ships) and dreams of being a sailor, though a pronounced limp, an overprotective mother and a controlling father conspire to keep him close to home.

title: British History
description: THE GREATEST KNIGHT  The Remarkable Life of William Marshal, the Power Behind Five English Thrones  By Thomas Asbridge  Ecco/HarperCollins, $27.99.

title: Immersive History
description: David Kynastons Modernity Britain, reviewed this week by Richard Aldous, is the third volume of a planned series covering British history from 1945 to 1979.

title: Modernity Britain: 1957-1962, by David Kynaston
description: On May 25, 1962, two decades after the original medieval building had been bombed by the Germans, the new Coventry Cathedral was consecrated. Alas, the service was a fiasco. Queen Elizabeths yellow outfit clashed with the canary-hued cope worn by the bishop of Coventry. The citys lord mayor, whether overawed or overheated, fainted in a cacophony of metal regalia and had to be revived by the bishop of Birmingham. An unfortunate sidesman dropped the overflowing collection plate right in front of Her Majesty. Even the building, designed by Sir Basil Spence, failed for some to live up to the occasion: The worst setback to English church architecture for a very long time, the ultramodernist critic Reyner Banham sniffed.

title: Leaders in Davos Urge Quick Action to Alter the Effects of Climate Change
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  On the heels of data showing that last year was the hottest on earth since record keeping began, business leaders, politicians and scientists at the World Economic Forum redoubled their calls to combat climate change.

title: In Rain and Snow, Its Clear That Patriots Are a Good Bet
description: Over the past 12 seasons, the New England Patriots have played so well in wet conditions that their margin of victory in those games has exceeded the betting spread  set by a global market that tries to take all known advantages into account  80 percent of the time, according to an analysis by Covers, a sports betting information website.

title: Apollo Seeks to Raise Fund to Buy Energy Sector Debt
description: Apollo Global Management is sprinting to raise a new fund to buy the debt of troubled energy companies, as the private equity giant seeks to capitalize on the recent collapse in oil prices.

title: Verbatim: A White House Jab at Tom Brady
description: Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, poking fun at Tom Bradys performance at a news conference about the use of deflated footballs in the A.F.C. championship game.

title: Historic Charleston Makes Room for New Construction
description: Long accustomed to basing its reputation on the grandeur of its old buildings, the city now finds it almost impossible to agree on how to build any new ones.

title: In Stately Old Charleston, the New Buildings on the Block Are Struggling to Fit In
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  The elegant buildings from different eras strut across Charlestons downtown neighborhoods like notes on a major scale: the Gothic churches, the Greek Revival storefronts, the homes in vivid pastels exuding Queen Anne grace, Georgian symmetry and Italianate grandeur.

title: $100.4 Million Sale at One57
description: A duplex penthouse at the pinnacle of One57, the vitreous skyscraper with nonpareil vistas of Central Park, the Hudson and East Rivers and almost every landmark on the horizon, sold for $100,471,452.77 to a mystery buyer, shattering the record for the highest price ever paid for a single residence in New York City, and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Goldman Executive Says Falling Oil Prices Will Help Firms Business
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  The sudden plunge in oil prices has been a boon for consumers, and could be a boon for Goldman Sachs, too, according to Gary D. Cohn, the investment banks president and chief operating officer.

title: Footage Shows Damage at Donetsk Airport
description: Footage produced by Army SOS, a group linked to the Ukrainian army, apparently shot on Jan.15, shows aerial views of the damage to Donetsk airport after recent fighting.

title: Guccis New Guy, the Return of the J. C. Penney Catalog and Alexander Wangs Bean Baggage
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: Stuff We Liked: End of an Era for Baby Boomers
description: Here are a few things we found elsewhere this week that tickled us.

title: Fort Hood Could Not Have Foreseen 2014 Gun Attack, Army Says
description: HOUSTON  Officials at the Fort Hood Army base in central Texas could not have prevented a shooting rampage last year in part because the troubled soldier behind the attack gave no clear warning that he posed a threat, according to an Army report released Friday.

title: Degenerate Art to Koonss Made and Heaven and Much in Between
description: The art world has always operated on the herd instinct. But over the years it has morphed into a visible playpen of power and privilege.

title: Letter From the Editor: 2015s Big Question
description: Wages are finally starting to rise again, President Obama said, during his recitation of good economic news in this weeks State of the Union address. Many of the other trends he listed were undeniable: unemployment and the deficit down, health insurance and educational attainment up. But his statement about wages left more room for debate.

title: Doctor in the House? Not After Sunday
description: Shlomos back! was the triumphant slogan when Soul Doctor, the Broadway musical about the guitar-strumming rabbi Shlomo Carlebach, reopened Off Broadway in December. But the show, which lasted not quite three months on Broadway in 2013, wont make it to the two-month mark at the Actors Temple Theater, where its last performance is Sunday.

title: At Casting Awards, Nina Ariandas Headshots, Christine Baranskis Surprise Numbers
description: A lot of actors would surely love the opportunity to appear before a room full of powerful casting directors, and when Nina Arianda did just that, she took advantage of the situation and passed out copies of her headshot. It was a joke, of course, one well-suited to the occasion: Ms. Arianda was a presenter at the Casting Society of Americas 30th annual Artios Awards, honoring achievement by casting directors, a decidedly less widely appreciated bunch than actors and directors.

title: Polish Group Demands Ida Add Context About German Occupation
description: Pawel Pawlikowskis Oscar-nominated film Ida is under fire, accused by the Polish Anti-Defamation League of failing to acknowledge the German occupation of Poland. The league has addressed its concerns to the Polish Film Institute, which provided some of the financial backing for Ida.

title: Comme des Garons Homme Plus: Fall 2015 Menswear
description: Paris

title: Departed Tastemakers: ASAP Yams and Kim Fowley
description: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss two connectors with keen ears, who died last week.

title: In San Diego, Art Is a Laughing Matter
description: Today, the citys Museum of Contemporary Art opens Laugh-in, a show featuring artists who incorporate comedic elements into their work.

title: N.F.L. Ends Silence on Underinflated Footballs to Say It Is Investigating
description: After days of silence and no comments, the N.F.L. confirmed Fridaythat game balls used by the New England Patriots during the first half ofSundaysA.F.C. championship game against the Indianapolis Colts were underinflated, and the league said it was continuing to investigate why and how that came to be.

title: As Last Paid Editors Depart, Modern Farmers Future in Doubt
