description: Modern Farmer, the quirky 100,000-circulation quarterly and website that tried to link effete urban farmers market culture with the practicalities of actual farming, became a magazine without an editorial staff on Friday, when its remaining paid editors walked out its doors.

title: Hint for Investors in Rise in Cash for Wall St. Chiefs Pay
description: Shareholders may want to take a hint from this weeks news on compensation for Wall Street chief executives. JPMorgan Chase is paying a portion of Jamie Dimons bonus in cash for the first time since 2011. And Goldman Sachs is bolstering how much cash Lloyd Blankfein gets. Meanwhile, bank stock gains are slowing.

title: Protesters in Iran Condemn Charlie Hebdo Over Muhammad Cartoon
description: TEHRAN  Iranian protesters, encouraged by state-sanctioned Friday Prayer leaders, condemned the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo for publishing a cartoon of the Prophet Muhammad.

title: Catching up with Danielle Steel, Couture Week Icon
description: As familiar a sight at the Paris couture shows as models and gowns is Danielle Steel: author of 139 books that have sold 650 million copies; member of the Ordre des Arts et des Lettres and Chevalier of the Lgion dhonneur; Guinness world record holder for longest time spent on The New York Times best-seller list; mother of nine and all-around avatar of elegance. Though Steel, who divides her time between San Francisco and Paris, keeps busy writing several books per year, if theres one thing that will tear her away from her desk, its fashion. I grew up going to haute couture shows, and began taking my daughters when they were very little girls, she says. Couture is an extraordinary experience and a dying art; each show is a thrill. It is art in one of its finest and most magical forms. Here, on the eve of couture week (and the release of her next novel, Prodigal Son, out Feb. 24 from Random House), Steel shared the details of her fashionable life in Paris (written, of course, in an email).

title: Officials Say Ebola Cases Are Falling In West Africa
description: GENEVA  The number of people falling victim to the Ebola virus in West Africa has dropped to the lowest level in months, the World Health Organization said on Friday, but dwindling funds and a looming rainy season threaten to hamper efforts to control the disease.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Comme Des Garcons Homme Plus Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

title: Mayor de Blasio Maintains His Support for Speaker Silver
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio is not wavering in his support for Sheldon Silver.

title: Hit the High Seas
description: Designers are riding a wave of rope detailing and sailor stripes.

title: A Toddlers Inside Guide to New York City
description: Diego Acosta Lpez wanted to document New York from his sons perspective: inside a stroller. Thousands of pictures (including little feet and hands) ensued.

title: Faith Hope Consolo: At Brunch, at a Museum, Always at Work
description: Faith Hope Consolo, the chairwoman of Douglas Ellimans retail leasing and sales division, likes to leverage her name. It can be seen plastered onto dozens of vacant shop windows along Madison Avenue, and a tag line, You Need Faith, is tattooed to pink pens and nail files that she sends to clients during the holidays. Ms. Consolo, one of the citys most prolific retail brokers, has clients that include Cartier, Fendi and Yves Saint Laurent. A widow who says she is sexy and 60-something, she lives in a two-bedroom on Fifth Avenue with a wraparound terrace and views of Central Park.

title: New Saudi King Addresses the Nation
description: King Salman of Saudi Arabia addressed the nation after the death of King Abdullah yesterday. He pledged continuity and unity in the country and the Arab world.

title: Judge Rules Tommie Rae Hynie Brown Was Married to James Brown
description: In a decision likely to significantly affect the long-running dispute over James Browns estate, a judge in South Carolina has ruled that Tommie Rae Hynie Brown is the widow of the singer, known as the Godfather of Soul.

title: Compromise and Persuasion Won Grudging Support for E.C.B. Bond Buying
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  The economist Hans Werner-Sinn, guru of German inflation militants, accused the European Central Bank of illegal money printing. The Frankfurter Allgemeine newspaper said the central bank was destroying trust in the euro. And a German citizens group threatened to sue.

title: New Issue for One City Opera Bidder: A Borrowed Name
description: Whats in a name? Apparently quite a lot, when it comes to opera companies.

title: Answers to Questions About Snowplows, De-Icing Sidewalks and Parking Meters
description: Q.Why do city snowplows always push the snow to the right?

title: A Singing Duo for 50 Years, a Married Couple Are Talent Scouts, Too
description: Standing back by the bar in a Manhattan nightclub, Billy Shepard and Judi Jourdan watched the jazz singer, then the rap duo, then the show-tune crooner boning up for his upcoming gig at the Best Western in Morristown, N.J.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Maison Margiela Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

title: Playing Politics on Iran
description: Normally, the visit of a world leader to the United States would be arranged by the White House. But in a breach of sense and diplomacy, House Speaker John Boehner and Ron Dermer, Israels ambassador to Washington, have taken it upon themselves to invite Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to Congress to challenge President Obamas approach to achieving a nuclear agreement with Iran.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: In Skillman, N.J., a four-bedroom 1793 farmhouse and in Manhasset, N.Y., a six-bedroom 1996 house in a gated clubhouse community.

title: Jorge Ramos, Voice of Latino Voters on Univision, Sends Shiver Through G.O.P.
description: DORAL, Fla.  Jorge Ramos, the Univision and Fusion television anchor who is often called the Walter Cronkite of Latino America, was in his suburban Miami broadcast studio when he all but pounced on the chairman of the Republican Party, Reince Priebus, who was appearing from Washington. The Republicans immigration policy is deportations, deportations, deportations, Mr. Ramos said. Why?

title: Michigans New Strategy: Embrace the Adversity
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  The only place for John Beilein, the mens basketball coach at Michigan, to sit in the hallway of the Rutgers athletic center on Tuesday night was on a medical table with a cushion held together with duct tape. He hoisted himself up, pored over the box score from his teams victory over Rutgers and accepted pats on the back and congratulations from alumni.

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
description: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties include West Village and Upper West Side co-ops, and a condo in Brooklyn.

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
On the Market in the New York Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York York Region.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York York City:

title: Insider Tips: Nonfiction in 2015
description: A New Years gift for Times Insiders: a series of inside tips from Times editors and reporters. Sewell Chan, deputy opinion editor, shares some of his favorite nonfiction reads.

title: In San Diego, Art Is a Laughing Matter
description: If the intersection of comedy, contemporary art and San Diego sounds like a strange brew, then brace yourself: Today the Museum of Contemporary Art San Diego in La Jolla opens an exhibition called Laugh-in, gathering 20 artists whose work utilizes humor in all its modes.

title: Euphorically Embracing a Long-Missing Soloist
description: A debut and a comeback were on offer at Thursdays New York Philharmonic concert at Avery Fisher Hall. A majority of the vocal, near-capacity audience was clearly there for the comeback: After an absence of almost nine years resulting partly from a shoulder injury, the Siberian-born star violinist Maxim Vengerov was returning to this stage with one of his signature pieces, Tchaikovskys Violin Concerto. He received a heros welcome. There were bravos and smattered applause between movements and a protracted ovation at the end of the piece. Isolated whoops of the weak-kneed kind usually reserved for rock stars greeted his announcement of an encore. After the intermission, clusters of seats remained empty.

title: Tasty Cozy Cool
description: Equal parts Left Bank bistro and Harlem Renaissance speakeasy, Chez Oskar in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, has remained relevant by staying true to its original aesthetic.

title: Popcast: ASAP Yams and Kim Fowley, Departed Tastemakers
description: The future of pop doesnt only rest on great singers or musicians or signature-sound producers. It also, sometimes, rests on people who understand opportunity, the movement of taste, fashion, sound, visual style, the way the wind is blowing. Theyre not primarily artists or merchants. Theyre not necessarily back-room forces  sometimes they are very public  but their roles and strengths remain in flux.

title: Fort Greene Changes. Chez Oskar Doesnt.
description: On a frigid Brooklyn night, a deep-red facade on the corner of DeKalb Avenue and Adelphi Street in Fort Greenes historic district glows invitingly. A worn wooden door awaits under the weathered sign of Chez Oskar, and those who enter will join a convivial scene that has been in steady swing for 17 years.

title: New York Alternate-Side Parking Rules Suspended Saturday
description: To facilitate snow removal, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Saturday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Pirate Ships, the Wall Street of the High Seas
description: The best pirate series introduced in 2014 that wasnt canceled returns Saturday night, its gnarly men still gnarly, its brothel still doing a booming business, and its allegiances and morality still ever-shifting.

title: New Coach Fleshes Out Jets Staff With 9 Hires
description: Todd Bowles, the Jets new head coach, appointed two coordinators and seven assistants Friday as he continued to fill out his staff.

title: Pictures of the Day: Saudi Arabia and Elsewhere
description: Saudi Arabia and Elsewhere  Pictures of the Day

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Growing Scrutiny for an Allergy Trigger Used in Personal Care Products
description: Because she has an eczema condition, Michelle Kirn intently reads ingredient labels on baby wipes, soaps and other household items to avoid allergic reactions that she says were caused by a commonly used preservative.

title: Is the Defendant White or Not?
description: AS jury selection continues in the trial of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the defendant in the Boston Marathon bombings, so does debate about what would constitute a fair and impartial jury. Questions have been raised about the race, gender, age and religiosity of prospective jurors; about the effect of holding the trial in Boston; and about the legal requirement that the jurors be open to the possibility of sentencing the defendant to death.

title: Jan. 23, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Saudi Arabia, Yemen, Afghanistan and Greece.

title: Movie Review: Mommy
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Mommy.

title: Movie Review: Black Sea
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews Black Sea.

title: Movie Review: Cake
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Cake.

title: Finding Neverland Publicist Resigns After Dispute
description: The bare-knuckled tactics of the film producer Harvey Weinstein have slammed into the more genteel sensibilities of Broadway, where he is bringing his first musical, Finding Neverland. After the shows publicist resigned  apparently in reaction to criticism from Mr. Weinstein  the producer on Thursday night ripped into the strategy to promote the musical, then changed his tone on Friday and said he had made a rookie mistake with the criticisms.

title: Door to Emancipation; Decades of Decay
description: Eric Foner, the Pulitzer Prize-winning Columbia University historian, has mined a 19th-century manuscript brought to his attention by a graduate student (who doubled as his dog walker) to produce a consummate narrative about New Yorks ambiguous relationship with the antebellum South and the fugitive slaves who fled it.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Comme Des Garons Homme Plus Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

title: Honoring Orson Welles in Wisconsin
description: Though he streaked to fame on New York stages and Hollywood sets, the actor and director Orson Welles was born in a city far away from show business capitals Kenosha, Wis., about 40 miles south of Milwaukee.

title: A Shadow of His Old Self? For Roger Federer, Maybe Not Yet
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  In darker moments for Roger Federer, a loss like Fridays, to Andreas Seppi, could have restarted the doomsday chatter that Federer likes just about as much as a certain Spanish left-handers forehand.

title: Justices to Hear Case Over Drugs Used in Executions
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to decide a case on the constitutionality of the new combinations of drugs that some states are using to execute prisoners and that critics say cause intense suffering.

title: Ale and Muskets Frame Revolt
description: There is no shame in not knowing why Boston boasts a beer called Samuel Adams, or why its the New England Patriots, not the New England Panthers or the New England Pistols.

title: Young Performers Spreading Their Wings
description: The Mariinsky Ballets production of Swan Lake is a strange bird. There have been frosty Odettes, tawdry Odiles, uncharismatic Siegfrieds and a frequently irritating Joker. Yet the luminosity of the staging, a 1950 revision of the celebrated 1895 version choreographed by Marius Petipa and Lev Ivanov, manages to shine in its sets, lighting and costumes. To see swans  theyre not real, but they look it  glide across the lake at the start of the second scene is heart-stopping. (Even the third time around.) The swan maidens, this time real women, are bewilderingly gorgeous as they skim across the stage or frame it, poised like statues.

title: Hooked on Novocain? Call This Number
description: In its humor, Everybody Gets Cake!, the comedy troupe Parallel Exits new show at 59E59 Theaters, is a throwback. Specifically, its a throwback to 1968.

title: Women Fighting for Their Land and Opportunity
description: In a hard-to-reach corner of Myanmar, Adriane Ohanesian searched for the young female fighters of the Kachin Independence Army, which has waged a long civil war.

title: Joined for a New Year.
description: Lori Levine and Jan van Arsdale were married Jan. 1, at ABC Kitchen in New York.

title: Balanchine as Shape-Shifter, Concealing Surprises in Familiarity
description: Thursday was the 111th birthday of George Balanchine, the most revelatory, influential and protean ballet master in history. New York City Ballet, the company he founded with Lincoln Kirstein in 1948, celebrated the occasion by bringing three Balanchine ballets back to the repertory: Donizetti Variations (1960), La Valse (1951) and Chaconne (1976).

title: Meeting Each Other Halfway, and Then Some
description: When Lori Levine goes out for a night on the town, she is often in the company of famous men like George Clooney, Chris Noth or Adrien Brody. But thats her job.

title: Gorman at Morgan Stanley to Receive $4.4 Million Stock Bonus
description: Morgan Stanleys chief executive, James Gorman, is receiving a $4.4 million stock bonus for 2014 in addition to his $1.5 million salary.

title: Berluti: Fall 2015 Menswear
description: Paris

title: A Moviemaking Couple Takes on Sundance, Together and Separately
description: For a pair of Chicagoans who operate far outside the Hollywood bubble, Joe and Kris Swanberg are finding filmmaking a surprisingly fruitful family business. The low-key couple made waves last month when it was announced that Joe and Kris would each separately premiere a film at the Sundance Film Festival  an anomaly in the events 31-year history. Kris found out a few hours before I did, Joe says. I had sort of made my peace with the idea that I wasnt going to get in, so there was a part of me that was really thrilled to just go and be Kriss husband for the whole festival.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Bill Cunningham | Fashion-Forward Lads
description: Young men are pushing the style envelope with felt hats, winged sneakers and fur-collared coats.

title: Bill Cunningham | Fashion-Forward Lads
description: Young men are pushing the style envelope with felt hats, winged sneakers and fur-collared coats. These are not the fashion professionals attending the European mens shows; they are New Yorkers. A newer look: dress coats in patterns, colors or with embroidered shoulders. Many of the men who never had a chance to experience rakish hats are into them this season. Even the hairstyles are interesting, the sides of the head shaven close and topped with a comb-over or a sleek, finlike mohawk. Torn trousers have been around for decades, but they now have embroidery, stencils or a dozen miniature pockets.

title: Daily Kos Founder Considering Run For Congress
description: Representative Barbara Lee of California may not wind up as our woman in Havana  disputing reports that she was seeking the nomination to be ambassador  but when she does leave Congress, there may be a nationally known liberal waiting to run for her seat: Markos Moulitsas.

title: Evening Hours | The Weight of History
description: Honoring the past and the arts.

title: U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara Challenges Insider Trading Ruling
description: When an appeals court overturned the convictions of two hedge fund managers last month, the ruling reverberated throughout the legal world and rewrote the governments insider trading playbook.

title: Sarah Silverman Gets Serious at Sundance
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  The harrowing drama I Smile Back, making its debut on Sunday at the Sundance Film Festival, opens with a drawn-out shot of a naked, forlorn woman. She is an alcoholic suburban mom having a cocaine-fueled affair and wrestling with mental illness. At one point she gets beaten bloody in an alley.

title: Martin Shorts Night Out With Matthew Broderick
description: Martin Short has so much going on these days, he cant afford to get the sniffles.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: A Stage for Nurturing New Works
description: Established and fledgling playwrights can test out their productions in staged readings at the John Drew Theater Lab at Guild Hall in East Hampton.

title: Where New Works Go to Be Nurtured: John Drew Theater Lab in East Hampton
description: Joe Brondo started writing a play last June  a first for him  and after two weeks showed his first draft to Josh Gladstone, the artistic director of the John Drew Theater Lab at Guild Hall in East Hampton, where Mr. Brondo is assistant technical director. Mr. Gladstone had started the theater lab in February 2014 to develop and present staged readings of new plays and other one-night showcases for creative work.

title: Eddie Redmayne and Emma Stone on Acting, Fame and Protecting Their Privacy
description: Emma Stone was delighted to grant Eddie Redmayne a retroactive wish on his birthday candle, since he forgot to make one when he blew it out.

title: Libyan Peace Talks to Resume, U.N. Says
description: GENEVA  The United Nations said Friday that most of Libyas feuding factions had agreed to meet in Geneva next week to resume talks on ending a conflict that has put the country at risk of economic and social collapse.

title: Blackstone Is Said to Raise $4.5 Billion for Energy Fund
description: The Blackstone Group has finished raising $4.5 billion for a new fund dedicated to investments in the energy sector, as the private equity giant seeks to profit on the rout in oil prices, a person with knowledge of the matter said on Friday.

title: Tumblr 466  469
description: Tumblr 466  469

title: Congressional Republicans Call on F.C.C. to Release Internal Net Neutrality Document
description: Congressional Republicans took a tactical step this week in their brewing confrontation with the Federal Communications Commission over who sets the rules for the future of the Internet.

title: SkyMall Is Going Bankrupt, and Its All Your Fault
description: The first time I met Felix Salmon, the financial journalist, was on a United flight from Newark to Kansas City. Throughout the flight, he would tap my shoulder and excitedly point out increasingly ridiculous items in the SkyMall catalog.

title: Staying Put and Bearing Witness to the Holocaust
description: Rather than flee to safe havens in America or Israel, some 2,700 Jews who survived Auschwitz returned to their European town in what is now Romania.

title: From a Fount of Grief, Endless Invention
description: As Americas oldest modern dance troupe, the Martha Graham Dance Company devotes much effort to maintaining traditions. A project called Lamentation Variations was not supposed to be one of them. The opening night of the companys 2007 New York season happened to fall on Sept. 11. To commemorate the anniversary of the 9/11 attacks, the groups artistic director, Janet Eilber, decided to invite three choreographers to contribute pieces inspired by a film of Lamentation, Grahams canonical 1930 dance of grief.

title: In Westchester, a 130-Year-Old Theater Primps for Its Next Act
description: In all likelihood, few of the 80,000 people who attend events at the Tarrytown Music Hall each year noticed that the floor near the north end of the east wall had become slightly spongy underfoot. But Bjorn Olsson, executive director of the hall, had. And he knew why: Poor drainage outside had allowed water to gather, erode the wood-on-stone foundation and seep in under the hall.

title: More Than Tools: Sometimes Instruments Inspire
description: Jeremy Pelt

title: From Valiant Prince to Smoldering Rebel
description: These are not your history professors founding fathers. With their chiseled jawlines and devil-may-care gazes, Historys Sons of Liberty  John Hancock (Rafe Spall), John Adams (Henry Thomas), Paul Revere (Michael Raymond-James) and Joseph Warren (Ryan Eggold)  skew more Versace model than early American revolutionary. Then theres Sam Adams, the Harvard-educated statesman, master of propaganda and Boston Tea Party champion. In real life Adams was a stout 50-something in the 1770s; here hes played by Ben Barnes, 33, a dashing London-born actor.

title: Tracee Ellis Ross Is Big on Big Hair
description: Earlier this month, I interviewed the actress Tracee Ellis Ross about her role on Black-ish (her new hit show on ABC), her playful presence on social media and her childhood as a daughter of the legendary singer Diana Ross. You can read an excerpt from our conversation in this weeks Talk column. Throughout the hourlong phone call, however, we kept drifting back to one subject: Rosss trademark curly cloud of hair and the way Instagram and Pinterest have contributed to the expansion of mainstream beauty standards online and in Hollywood. Much of that discussion didnt make it into the print version of the interview, but it felt worth sharing  and worth adding to. Jenna Wortham

title: Mining Lifes Complications for Laughs
description: Spinning Wheel, the Blood, Sweat & Tears pop classic, introduces each of the three acts of Alan Ayckbourns Absurd Person Singular.

title: This Cold House
description: DENVER  OVER the summer, I moved into a house in rural Nebraska where, for the first time ever, I had full control of the thermostat. It was a drafty 4,000-square-foot palace of cold-to-the touch cinder-blocks that had long stood empty. As fall approached, I started to think about heating. Keeping that whole place at 70 degrees with natural gas, for just one person, seemed like a waste. I wondered: How cold could I let my house get, while remaining comfortable?

title: Ocwen Reaches Settlement With California Regulator
description: The embattled subprime mortgage servicer Ocwen Financial on Friday reached a settlement with a California regulator that will allow it to continue operating in the state.

title: I Love You. I Hate You. Its Complicated.
description: If Nol Cowards Private Lives is to be believed  and with this shiny, new, perfectly polished production at Hartford Stage, how can it not be?  sexual mores in England changed a great deal between 1924 and 1930. There is poor Lady Mary in the recent episode of Downton Abbey, an elegant young widow being preached to by her grandmother because she has spent the night in a hotel with a man to whom she is not married. Then there is the rather cavalier Amanda Chase Prynne, the heroine of Private Lives, casually informing her ex-husband, Elyot Chase, of the men she has had affairs with since their divorce five years ago.

title: Who Will Rule the Oil Market?
description: WASHINGTON  A HISTORIC change of roles is at the heart of the clamor and turmoil over the collapse of oil prices, which have plummeted by 50 percent since September. For decades, Saudi Arabia, backed by the Persian Gulf emirates, was described as the swing producer. With its immense production capacity, it could raise or lower its output to help the global market adjust to shortages or surpluses.

title: Snapchat Plans to Offer Original Media Content
description: Snapchat, the photo messaging start-up, is joining with a select group of media companies to offer users original editorial content, according to three people briefed on the matter.

title: Inventiveness With a Hot Plate
description: Even for veteran chefs working in state-of-the-art kitchens, it can be taxing to consistently whip up sophisticated, satisfying meals for a parade of discriminating patrons. So when a self-taught cook manages to pull it off using only a hot plate, a plug-in stew pot and a panini press, the results can seem like feats of culinary magic.

title: Syrian Airstrike Hits Damascus Suburb, Killing Dozens
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A Syrian government airstrike on Friday hit a market square in an insurgent-held suburb of Damascus, the capital, killing several dozen people, antigovernment activists in the area said, while five Lebanese soldiers were killed in clashes with militants who crisscross the Syrian border, in one of the worst recent cases of spillover violence.

title: Cuomo Cites School Crisis in New York; Data Suggest Otherwise
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, in his State of the State address this week, exhorted lawmakers to make significant changes to New York States education system. He painted a picture of a system in crisis: only a third of students reaching proficiency on state math and English tests, less than 40 percent of high school students prepared for college, hundreds of thousands of mostly minority students condemned to failing schools.

title: A Move to More Casual Fare
description: A meal at Ariane Kitchen & Bar begins with croissants. They are everything croissants should be: buttery and flaky; their ends just the slightest bit crisp. But they are small, and shouldnt stop you from enjoying the rest of the meal, you think, as you reach for a second one.

title: After an Anxiety-Filled Campaign, Greek Voters Consider a Turn to the Left
description: GLYFADA, Greece  Katerina Georgiou, 64, who used to own a private school, says that she will probably act out of fear when she decides who to vote for in Sundays general election.

title: V.A.s Treatment of Veterans Trauma
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge Big Hosts Online World Cup
description: Internet bridge continues to gain in popularity. The first World Cup of Online Bridge has been organized by Bridge Big (bridgebig.com). Players can enter directly or qualify through preliminary events, which run until next Saturday. The final will take place on Feb. 1.

title: Health Care and Prosperity
description: To the Editor:

title: Intimate, Casual and Classical, in a Club Setting
description: Its wonderful to be here in the Red Fish, the Swedish mezzo-soprano Anne Sofie von Otter said on Wednesday evening. And it was wonderful to have her there.

title: How to Test North Korea
description: To the Editor:

title: Pennsylvanias Governor Breaks Through a G.O.P. Tide
description: HARRISBURG, Pa.  Standing outside the Capitol here  an ornate jewel wedged in the center of this recession-beaten industrial city  the businessman and political neophyte Tom Wolf told the gathered crowd this week, Im going to be an unconventional governor.

title: Disciplining Police Officers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Gay Couple Awaits the Justices Decision
description: CHICAGO  It may have been a coincidence that the United States Supreme Court announced its intent to hear another same-sex marriage case the same week as the holiday honoring Martin Luther Kings Birthday, but it was hard not to notice the connection. The gay marriage question is one that has civil rights at its center, after all.

title: Why Tolerate Terrorist Publications?
description: WHILE most of us would agree that religious fundamentalists, foreign and domestic, sometimes do serious harm to our society, there are other kinds of fundamentalists who are also dangerous: I refer to legal fundamentalists.

title: Mobile Monitoring of Blood Glucose Is Approved
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved a set of mobile medical applications that allow people with diabetes to share information about the level of glucose in their blood with doctors in real time using an iPhone. Such apps have existed but were not in broad use, in part because they had not met regulatory requirements.Dr. K. M. Venkat Narayan, professor of medicine and epidemiology at Emory University, said that the apps would be useful for certain patients, for example those with extreme fluctuations in glucose levels, but would not fundamentally change diabetes monitoring.

title: Archaeologists Want Egyptian Officials Charged for Damage to Tutankhamens Burial Mask
description: Outraged over what appears to be serious damage to one of Egypts ancient treasures  scratches and a layer of glue on the golden burial mask of Tutankhamen  a group of Egyptian archaeologists said on Friday that they planned to file charges against officials at the state-run Egyptian Museum in Cairo.

title: Dishes So Complex the Waiters Use Crib Sheets
description: On a winters night at the four-month-old Hopscotch in Croton-on-Hudson, I asked our waiter to tell me about the quenelle-shaped oval that adorned a dish called oxtail strudel. He blushed a bit and backed up in the direction of the kitchen, saying, I just need to check my notes. That the waiters at Hopscotch  who are very quick and personable  rely on crib sheets says a lot about the complexity of the dishes with which Kenyon Hart, the chef de cuisine, is spoiling patrons.

title: U.S. Army Report of the Investigation Into 2014 Fort Hood Shooting
description: The Armys report, which has been redacted in places, says that no clear warnings existed about Specialist Ivan A. Lopezs mental state, and that no single factor prompted the episode.

title: For Obamas Visit, India Takes a Broom to Stray Monkeys and Cows
description: NEW DELHI  When an important guest is on his way over, it is common practice to sweep up ones odds and ends and hide them all in the back room. So it was in New Delhi this week.

title: Japanese Dishes, With a Side Order of Kitsch
description: To enjoy Teinei Ya (pronounced TAY-nay YA), a Japanese restaurant in Little Neck that opened last May, you have to like your food served with a rather large dollop of kitsch. Diners who can get past this  or better yet, learn to embrace it  are in for a culinary treat. On a stretch of Northern Boulevard on the Queens side of the Nassau County border in a neighborhood that is rife with cheap and interesting international food, this is a restaurant that holds its own, and then some.

title: In Brooklyn, Spotlight Recedes From Site of Fatal Ambush of 2 Officers
description: For years, the stretch of curb outside the back door of Mikes Pizza, on the corner of Myrtle and Tompkins Avenues in Brooklyn, belonged, unofficially, to a man known to neighbors as Mr. Wallace. They knew he always parked his Cadillac there to keep his walk home to the Tompkins Houses across the street short.

title: Former Party Official Says Spains Leader Knew of Slush Fund
description: MADRID  The former treasurer at the heart of a slush-fund scandal that has undermined Spains governing Popular Party accused Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy on Friday of knowing from the beginning about the partys illegal payments.

title: Jeb Bush Sounds Sympathetic Note for Immigrants
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In a sweeping speech that leaned heavily on economic policy, former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida on Friday described immigrants as the engine of economic vitality before calling for a more welcoming immigration policy that could put him at odds with some in the more conservative wing of his party.

title: For SkyMall, It All Seemed So Cool at Six Miles High
description: For years, it was something of a ritual. You had made it through airport security, survived the lengthy delays and even crammed your carry-on into an overhead bin. Then you could settle in, buckle up and reach into the seat-back pocket in front of you. There, pressed up against the motion-sickness bag or the laminated emergency instruction card, you would find the latest edition of SkyMall.

title: Gamesmanship vs. Cheating
description: Over the years, Derek Jeter developed a tic at the plate that gave him an advantage. Or was it a trick? Whenever a pitch darted inside, Jeter bent over, stuck out his backside, held back his bat, and watched as the ball went by. It was his way of signaling to the umpire that the pitch was a ball, and often he got the call.

title: Kerry, at Davos, Urges Multipronged Fight Against Violent Extremism
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Secretary of State John Kerry on Friday called for an ambitious campaign to combat the root causes of violent extremism, which he said represented one of the most grave threats to international order since the end of World War II.

title: Microsofts Holographic Vision Triggers a Flashback
description: SEATTLE  This week, Microsoft did what it usually does when it has an intriguing new technology that isnt fully baked: It released a video.

title: The Plunder of Myanmar
description: Chinas exploding appetites have unleashed a wholesale looting of Myanmars valuable natural resources. While this often involves outright theft, it also comes in the form of crony capitalism. Myanmars military elite has deals with Chinese companies that are eager to exploit the land, with little concern for the environment or people. The Kachin Independence Army, a rebel group that controls part of northeastern Myanmar, also takes a cut of some of this trade with China, especially jade hacked out of the earth by impoverished, heroin-addicted laborers.

title: Raced to Death at the Big A
description: The tragic degradation of thoroughbred racing continues at New Yorks Aqueduct Racetrack, where the fatality rate for horses  7.8 per 1,000 horses  has reached more than four times the national average as heedless owners put unproven horses at risk for lucrative purses. Twelve horses broke down in competition and had to be put to death in just 22 days in the tracks current winter meet.

title: In Spectacle of Biggest Stars, a Modest Center Stands Out
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Reporters and photographers at the N.H.L. All-Star Game media day thronged around Zemgus Girgensons, a modest second-year center for one of the leagues worst teams who obliterated a list of hockey superstars in fan voting dominated by his home country, Latvia, where he is a national hero.

title: Crusading for Israel in a Way Some Say Is Misguided
description: JERUSALEM  She is a crusading lawyer who serially sues rogue nations, terror groups and international banks to show, as she put it, there is a price to Jewish blood. She is a mother of six who, while seven months pregnant with triplets, astonished an Israeli court with a motion requesting that a hearing be moved to her home. (It was denied.).

title: The Greeks Head to the Polls, Many Saying Enough
description: ATHENS  Driving along a broad avenue lined with restaurants, the Greek man at the wheel points to the trash cans. Every night, he says, people rummage through them for scraps of food. His two well-educated daughters cannot find jobs; more than half of Greek youths have no work, and the jobs that do appear are often short-term and lacking in benefits.

title: Long Led by Silver, Assembly Democrats Face Uncertainty on a Successor
description: ALBANY  With New York Democrats still reeling on Friday from the arrest of their powerful Assembly leader, Sheldon Silver, on federal graft charges, the states political corridors were abuzz with one question: Who could take his place?

title: Dont Blame Nafta
description: On Wednesday, the day after President Obamas State of the Union address, a handful of Democratic House members, along with one senator, Bernie Sanders of Vermont, held a news conference to denounce one of the very few proposals the president put forward that actually has a chance of passage. The objects of their displeasure were the new trade agreements currently being negotiated by the administration.

title: Amid Times Squares Bright Lights, Murders in the Shadows
description: A major in the United States Marine Corps spent this week in and around Times Square on a business trip, a stranger marveling at the sights.

title: And Now: Air Republicans
description: Tough week for the House Republicans. Speaker John Boehners high point must have been not clapping when President Obama talked about job growth in the State of the Union.

title: Sounds Like a Plan
description: Administrivial Deb Amlen Sighting Alert! Once again, the Ace Hotel and I will be gently waking up New York City with the Jan. 25 Sunday crossword, and we hope you can join us for trivia, coffee and crossword-solving fun. We invade, sorry, we start at 11 a.m. Sunday, Jan. 25, in the beautifully appointed Ace lobby, located at 20 West 29th Street. See you there!

title: Argentina Points to Spy After Lawyers Eerie Death
description: BUENOS AIRES  Argentinas government asserted on Friday that an ousted spymaster was involved in the murky events around the death of the prosecutor investigating the 1994 bombing of a Jewish center, with President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchners chief of staff claiming that the prosecutor did not even write a complaint accusing her and top aides of subverting his inquiry.

title: Jackie Selebi, South Africa Police Head Convicted in Bribery Case, Dies at 64
description: Jackie Selebi, South Africas first black national police commissioner, who in 2010 was convicted of taking bribes from a drug trafficker in a trial that drew immense international attention, died on Friday in a Pretoria hospital. He was 64.

title: Washington Post Reporter, Jailed in Tehran, Is Said to Be Out of Solitary Confinement
description: Jason Rezaian, the Washington Posts Iran correspondent, who was imprisoned and placed in solitary confinement six months ago for unspecified reasons, has been moved recently and has a cellmate, his brother said Friday.

title: After a Deal, British Chocolates Wont Cross the Pond
description: Have you tried Hersheys chocolate? asked Nicky Perry, a longtime British expatriate living in New York.

title: Vince Camuto Dies at 78; Shoe Mogul Founded Nine West
description: Vince Camuto, a quiet titan of retail and founder of the footwear behemoth Nine West, whose specialty was the midpriced but stylish shoe, died on Wednesday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 78.

title: Adaptability Aids in a Drivers Evolution
description: Scott Pruetts success as a racecar driver comes down to adaptability.

title: Columbia Doctor, Player in Sheldon Silver Investigation, Is Leaving Post
description: Robert N. Taub, a doctor and government witness in the federal corruption case against the State Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, is leaving his position as the head of a Columbia University cancer center, and the center is being disbanded, a university spokesman said Friday.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 23, 2015
In Unraveling Season, the Knicks String Together Reasons for Hope
description: Milestones for the Knicks this season have been nothing but negative, but finally, 44 games in, they can attach their names to something of relatively reasonable acclaim: The Knicks, for the first time this season, have won three in a row.

title: Ralph Morse, Photographer, Dies at 97
description: Mr. Morses images peppered the glossy pages of Life and Time magazines during a 50-year career.

title: Ralph Morse, Life Photographer of Big Events, Is Dead at 97
description: Everybody can point to some lucky break that advanced his career. For Ralph Morse, it was a serendipitous visit to Jones Beach with friends the weekend after he had been hired as a darkroom assistant for a photo sales agency. His impromptu shots of a father bouncing his child in the air so captivated his boss that Mr. Morse was promoted to full-time photographer.

title: Dallas Taylor, Drummer for Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young, Dies at 66
description: Dallas Taylor, a rock n roll drummer who played behind David Crosby, Stephen Stills and Graham Nash, among other big names, and who overcame desperate addictions to drugs and alcohol to become a counselor for other addicts, died on Jan. 18 in Los Angeles. He was 66.

title: Ward Swingle, Who Made Classical Music Jazzy, Dies at 87
description: Ward Swingle, an American jazz vocalist, conductor and arranger whose Swingle Singers brought classical music into the Qiana Age with best-selling Bach that bubbled and bounced, died on Jan. 19 in Eastbourne, England. He was 87.

title: Newly Energetic, Venus Williams Battles Her Way Into the Fourth Round
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  For the first time in nearly four years, Venus Williams is back in the second week of a Grand Slam singles tournament.

title: Ernie Banks, the Eternally Hopeful Mr. Cub, Dies at 83
description: Ernie Banks, the greatest power-hitting shortstop of the 20th century and an unconquerable optimist whose sunny disposition never dimmed in 19 seasons with the perennially stumbling Chicago Cubs, died on Friday in Chicago. He was 83.

title: Baseballs Eternal Optimist
description: Ernie Banks, the greatest power-hitting shortstop of the 20th century, maintained his sunny disposition in 19 seasons with the perennially stumbling Chicago Cubs.

title: Sheldon Silvers Arrest Leaves Governor Cuomo in Difficult Spot
description: On Wednesday, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo unleashed a lengthy and aspirational oration laying out an ambitious social agenda for his second term. In 84 minutes, he devoted only about 40 seconds to the issue of cleaning up Albany.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: It was pure illusion that peace could be achieved now. None of the sides has yet achieved its goals. The only real surprise is that the fighting started in the winter instead of the spring.

title: Corrections: January 24, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Whats on TV Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (TCM) THE ESSENTIALS: RAGS TO RICHES Robert Osborne and Drew Barrymore explain why Michael Apteds Coal Miners Daughter (1980), starring Sissy Spacek in an Oscar-winning portrayal of the country legend Loretta Lynn  a role for which she did all the singing  is required viewing. A gentle touch gives this movie its distinctive sweetness, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times, adding that the film risks understating its story to make Loretta Lynns biography part of a larger fabric, and the gamble pays off.

title: 1965: Commons Honors Churchill at His Death
description: LONDON  The Mother of Parliaments paid tribute today [Jan. 25] to her most famous son.

title: 1915: An Interview With Winston Churchill
description: Winston Churchill, wartime prime minister of Britain,died 50 years ago today, on Jan. 24, 1965. Here is an interview published in the New York Herald, European Edition, in 1915, when he was the first lord of the Admiralty:

title: Obama Will End India Trip Early to Visit Saudi Arabia
description: NEW DELHI  President Obama has decided to cut short his planned three-day trip to India and visit Saudi Arabia, where he will pay his respects to the royal family after the death of King Abdullah and meet with the kings successor, White House officials said Saturday.

title: 27 Are Killed by Rockets in Ukraine
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  A barrage of rockets struck homes and a market in the Azov Sea port city of Mariupol in eastern Ukraine on Saturday, killing 27 people and wounding 97 others, the Interior Ministry said.

title: Sundance 2015: Documentaries Suddenly Made Timely
description: PARK CITY, Utah  If timing is everything, then four documentary filmmakers are about to have a very good run in this resort town.

title: In Africa, Mosquito Nets Are Putting Fish at Risk
description: Across the continent, mosquito-net fishing is an unintended consequence of a campaign to eradicate malaria.

title: Before the Bowl Was Super

Planted on the side of State Highway 114, about 30 miles west of Lubbock, beyond the oil rigs that rise from fallow cotton fields, the sign has borne the brunt of harsh winters and searing summers.

This turmoil in the Middle East will dominate conversations on the Sunday shows, when Denis McDonough, the White House chief of staff, will discuss the administrations foreign policy. He will appear on all five network shows.

title: De Blasio, Obama and a Flawed Vision of Liberalism
description: MAYOR BILL DE BLASIO recently got some good news in his standoff with the Police Department. In thefirst major poll conducted after the high-profile murder of two patrolmen, 69 percent of New Yorkers said they objected to police officers turning their backs on the mayor at their colleagues funerals, while 77 percent rejected a union bosss accusation that the mayor shared blame for the deaths. Over all, more than half of New Yorkers said that they believed that discipline had broken down among police.

title: How Auschwitz Is Misunderstood
description: AUSCHWITZ was liberated 70 years ago, on Jan. 27, 1945, and news of its existence shocked the world. With its principal killing center at one of its main camps, Auschwitz-Birkenau, becoming fully operational in 1942, it was Germanys largest and the most notorious extermination site. There the Germans slaughtered approximately 1.1 million people, a million of whom were Jews. Its mention evokes notions of evil and instant horror. Auschwitz was a death factory, an oxymoron that would have made no sense before the Holocaust, but that now is effortlessly comprehensible.

title: Prisoners of the Saudis
description: THE Western response to the death of Abdullah bin Abdul Aziz al-Saud, king of Saudi Arabia and custodian of the Two Holy Mosques, followed two paths. Along one, various officials and luminaries offered the gestures  half-mast flags, public obsequies  expected when a great statesman enters the hereafter. John Kerry described the late monarch as a man of wisdom and vision and a revered leader. Tony Blair called him a modernizer of his country and a staunch advocate of interfaith relations, who was loved by his people and will be deeply missed.

description: As recently as October, Secretary of State John Kerry argued that there will never be peace in Syria as long as President Bashar al-Assad remains the focus of power there. Even now, American officials continue to insist that any lasting political solution will require Mr. Assads exit. But the unsettling truth is that the brutal dictator is still clinging to power and the United States and its allies are going to have to live with him, at least for now.

description: PARK CITY, Utah  Jay and Mark Duplass have so many projects going that at least among some Sundance festivalgoers here, their hyper-productivity is becoming a bit of a punch line.

title: Moments in Time With Schubert
description: Schuberts music, in which a single moment can blissfully expand into a spacious, contemplative arc, offers an ideal forum to explore the concept of time. When devising the program for his two coming concerts at the 92nd Street Y, the pianist Shai Wosner was inspired by differing notions of time  comparing the multitasking, contemporary 140-character attention span with Schuberts era, when a seven-minute piece was deemed short.

title: The Meaning of Being Alone
description: In Solitudes solo, the Montreal choreographer Daniel Lveill highlights five performers  Mathieu Campeau, Esther Gaudette, Justin Gionet, Jason Martin and Emmanuel Proulx  who offer kinetic explorations, both subtle and athletic, of what it means to be alone. This grouping of spare, elegant dances, performed in silence and to Bach, also introduces a new performance series at Abrons Arts Center: Travelogues, organized by Laurie Uprichard, formerly the director of Danspace Project and the Dublin Dance Festival. During Ms. Uprichards tenure at Danspace Project, Mr. Lveills unadorned choreography was regularly on display; his 2012 production, which features Marc Parents austere lighting, is a chance to revisit Mr. Lveills unaffected choreographic voice. The series will continue in May with a shared program by Kimberly Bartosik and Dylan Crossman, as well as in October with separate engagements by the Irish company ponydance and the Los Angeles choreographer Lionel Popkin.  (Friday and Saturday at 8 p.m., Sunday at 3 p.m., Abrons Arts Center, 466 Grand Street, at Pitt Street, Lower East Side; 212-352-3101, abronsartscenter.org).

title: Run the Jewels to Join Jack White
description: Remember when Jack White used to hate hip-hop? It was 2003  more innocent, genre-segregated times!  when he gave an interview to Rolling Stone and more or less tried to bury the whole genre. Rock purists cheered; most everyone else shrugged and sighed. Hes made tentative steps toward reconciliation over the years, but maybe none as convincing as inviting the agit-noise post-backpack rap duo Run the Jewels to open for him Friday at Madison Square Garden. Granted, Run the Jewels  the partnership of Killer Mike and El-P  are a favorite of those who might malign hip-hops center. But there will be no mistaking, once theyre on stage, their bona fides. And like Mr. White, theyre brash and not terribly concerned with who they step on with their words. (Friday at 8 p.m. at Madison Square Garden; thegarden.com.)

title: A Buddy Movie, With a Crime Spree
description: Just what elements make Ridley Scotts 1991 feminist neo-western Thelma & Louise so timeless? For one thing, its unfaded relevance. But you can find out on Thursday at the Chelsea Cinemas, where the drag queen Hedda Lettuce is to introduce the film  about two modern-day outlaws (Susan Sarandon and Geena Davis) on the run after killing a would-be rapist  as part of her classics series. Certainly, there are the gorgeous desert vistas shot by the cinematographer Adrian Biddle. And the leading actresses, both at career peaks. And, as a seductive sociopath, a young Brad Pitt, arriving at stardom fully formed, like a he-Venus on the half-shell.

More often, mindful of his divorce years ago, Mr. Garren, a 64-year-old Illinoisan, remains in his pew, watching with slight embarrassment as the rest of the row moves to the front of the church.

Then he risked it all  for a soap opera from South Korea.

He was just one of more than two dozen angry young men from the grimy Molenbeek district in Brussels who, lured by the promise of adventure and reward from God, have taken up the fight for Islam.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 24, 2015
Carmelo Anthony Is Out, and the Knicks Winning Streak Is Over

title: Joe Franklin, a Talk Show Institution in New York, Dies at 88
description: Joe Franklin, who became a New York institution by presiding over one of the most compellingly low-rent television programs in history, one that even he acknowledged was an oddly long-running parade of has-beens and yet-to-bes interrupted from time to time by surprisingly famous guests, died on Saturday in a hospice in Manhattan. He was 88.

title: When Mango Mania Was Revolutionary
description: In 1968, two years after he began the Cultural Revolution, Mao Zedong wrested it from the hands of avid but unruly students and handed it over to a more worshipful working class. During the transition, he happened to receive, as an ambassadorial gift from Pakistan, a basket of fresh mangoes. And as a symbolic act of largess, he had the exotic fruit delivered to a group of workers. In doing so, he created an instant cult. Not only was the fruit not eaten, but it was also revered as an emblem of the leaders godlike love. The mangoes were preserved and became objects of worship. Wax and plastic duplicates were created and enshrined. Mango madness pervaded the culture: Images of the yellow fruit appeared in posters, on porcelain and in textile designs. Maos Golden Mangoes and the Cultural Revolution, a China Institute exhibition organized by the art historian Alfreda Murck, perfectly captures the devotional fervor of that moment. And a mere moment it was. Within a year, the fad was over. Mango memorabilia went into closets and then to flea markets, from which Ms. Murck, who lived many years in Beijing, rescued choice examples to tell this fascinating tale of consumerist infatuation. (Through April 26, 125 East 65th Street, 212-744-8181, chinainstitute.org.)

title: Whats on TV Sunday
description: 9 P.M. (History) SONS OF LIBERTY This fictionalized prequel to the American Revolution follows hunkier, more youthful versions of the founding fathers  Sam Adams (Ben Barnes), John Hancock (Rafe Spall), John Adams (Henry Thomas), Dr. Joseph Warren (Ryan Eggold) and Paul Revere (Michael Raymond-James)  as they lead the revolt against the British crown.  'Sons of Liberty is fun and engaging, a better option than a much more ambitious, highfalutin series on AMC last year, Turn, which followed a ring of spies working for Gen. George Washington and which was far too elliptical and unwelcoming, Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times about this three-night mini-series. And while it may not be history exactly, its a well-made dramatization that brings history to life.

description: ATHENS  Greece rejected the harsh economics of austerity on Sunday and sent a warning to the rest of Europe as the left-wing Syriza party won a decisive victory in national elections, positioning its tough-talking leader, Alexis Tsipras, to become the next prime minister.

title: In Bold Push Forward, Islamist Militants Attack a Major Nigerian City
description: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria  Maiduguri, the major city in Nigerias northeast, came under sustained attack from Boko Haram terrorists on Sunday, and officials here called it the groups most audacious assault on the city to date.

title: Birdman Takes Producers Guild Award
description: In something of a surprise, Birdman captured the Producers Guild equivalent of best picture on Saturday, beating out another awards-season front-runner, Boyhood.

title: President Obama in India
description: During a three-day trip to India, President Obama will discuss climate change and nuclear cooperation.

title: Rebels Tied to Blackout Across Most of Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Towns and cities across Pakistan plunged into darkness early Sunday when what officials said was an attack by militants on a transmission line short-circuited the national electricity grid, presenting a new indictment of the governments faltering efforts to solve the countrys chronic power crisis.

title: Kerry Meets With Nigerian Leaders to Encourage Peaceful Election
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  Concerned that Nigeria could face postelection turmoil, Secretary of State John Kerry on Sunday urged President Goodluck Jonathan and his principal political rival to respect the results of next months presidential vote and to discourage their supporters from carrying out violent protests.

description: President Obama met with Prime Minister Narendra Modi in an effort to maintain the partnership between the United States and India.

title: From Inside Prison, a Terrorism Suspect Shares His Diary
description: Theres a revealing moment in Mohamedou Ould Slahis gripping and depressing Guantnamo Diary when a new interrogator is assigned to question him. By this point, Mr. Slahi has been asked the same questions and given the same answers for years. But the new military interrogator, a woman he describes as quiet and polite, surprises him with a novel inquiry about what he knows of another terrorism suspects travel to Iraq in 2003.

title: A Pianist, Duly Smitten, Mines a Prolific Master
description: Jonathan Biss has become an authority on Beethoven. First there was Beethovens Shadow, an eloquent volume on his relationship with that composers music that would be slim if it were available for more than your Kindle. A volume of his ongoing recording series of the complete sonatas has emerged every year of the past few, and the fourth is out this week on his new label, JB Recordings. And his innovative online course, in association with Coursera and the Curtis Institute, is in its third season. So far, over 60,000 students have learned about everything from expositions and recapitulations to the metaphysics of slow movements.

title: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Clippers at Spurs

title: An Unblinking Look at Sexual Assaults on Campus
description: PARK CITY, Utah  The Hunting Ground, set for release in theaters and broadcast on CNN, was billed by the Sundance Film Festival as a piercing, monumental expos of rape culture on campuses. Judging by viewer reaction at the films premiere and the comments of two United States senators afterward, festival programmers might have undersold it.

title: A Valiant Cub Goes on the Hunt

title: Moving, Sometimes at a Snails Pace, to Music and Shakespeare
description: BRUSSELS  There is a lot riding on Anne Teresa De Keersmaekers new Golden Hours (As you like it), set to music by Brian Eno, which opened at the Kaaitheater here on Friday. In December, the Brussels opera house, the Thtre Royal de la Monnaie, which co-produced the work, and with which Ms. De Keersmaeker has had a 23-year association, announced it would have to remove all dance from its programming if projected budget cuts by the federal government go ahead.

title: Recalling a Film From the Liberation of the Camps
description: The HBO documentary Night Will Fall is a movie about the Holocaust, a movie about remembering the Holocaust and primarily, at least in formal terms, a movie about a movie. It may not do full justice to all these subjects in its tight 78 minutes, but its not a film youre likely to forget.

title: Two Dead in Murder-Suicide at Home Depot in Chelsea
description: An armed employee walked into a Manhattan Home Depot on Sunday and fatally shot his manager before killing himself amid scores of horrified colleagues and shoppers, the authorities said.

description: In its humor, Everybody Gets Cake!, the comedy troupe Parallel Exits new show at 59E59 Theaters, is a throwback. Specifically, its a throwback to 1968.

title: Playing at One Club, but Winning All Over
description: STaC stands for Sectional Tournaments at Clubs. The same boards are played in all competing clubs.

title: Its a Picture Thats Worth a Thousand Triumphs
description: No record was at stake Sunday afternoon. Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski had already taken care of that, eclipsing Bob Knights mark for wins by an N.C.A.A. Division I mens basketball coach, 902, in 2011 and chugging steadily onward.

title: Larry David Racks Up a Big Broadway Advance
description: Larry Davids stage debut, Fish in the Dark, has set a Broadway record for advance ticket sales for a play before performances begin, taking in $13.5 million. Its an extraordinary number driven by audience demand and a willingness to pay high ticket prices of up to $425, an amount that few plays have charged before. Plays with popular stars (Bradley Cooper in The Elephant Man, Bryan Cranston in All the Way) often have advance sales of several million dollars, while even many musicals  which tend to be bigger sellers than plays  often struggle to build an eight-figure advance. A spokesman for the plays lead producer, Scott Rudin, confirmed the figure on Sunday. It beats the previous record for a play, $13.05 million for the 2013 revival of Harold Pinters Betrayal, another Rudin production, starring the real-life couple Daniel Craig and Rachel Weisz. Mr. David (above) is widely known as the star of HBOs Curb Your Enthusiasm and co-creator and head writer of Seinfeld. He is both the author and star of Fish in the Dark, his first play, a comedy about a death in the family. Fish in the Dark, directed by Anna D. Shapiro (a Tony winner for August: Osage County), is scheduled to begin performances on Feb. 2 at the Cort Theater.

title: Fallen Journalist Finds Solace and Success in Poetry
description: Sometimes, the words come to her on the Garden State Parkway or on the Outerbridge Crossing, snippets of verse that capture a flash of light, an eruption of color, a piercing cry.

title: Evolution for Libraries in Brooklyn
description: Two proposals to sell and develop local library sites are wending through the Brooklyn Public Library pipeline, and, predictably, opponents have manned the barricades, citing the usual arguments about selling off public land to rapacious developers.

title: Distilling Japanese Sound From a Varied Catalog
description: Chinese contemporary music has attained considerable visibility and influence in the West in recent decades. Chinese-born composers, some of them scarred by the Cultural Revolution, have made major inroads in the classical music scene in the United States and elsewhere.

title: A Choreographer Who Wrote and Drew
description: Whether or not you personally knew Remy Charlip, the choreographer and childrens book author who died in 2012 at 83, hes easy to love. On Friday, as part of its Fridays at Noon series, the 92nd Street Y presented Remy Charlip: I Love You, a program of readings, performances and film screenings commemorating his whimsical life and work.

title: Verizons Mobile Supercookies Seen as Threat to Privacy
description: For the last several months, cybersecurity experts have been warning Verizon Wireless that it was putting the privacy of its customers at risk. The computer codes the company uses to tag and follow its mobile subscribers around the web, they said, could make those consumers vulnerable to covert tracking and profiling.

title: Live Arts Aims High
description: The lineup of music, dance, lectures and film screenings is set for the 2015 Live Ideas Festival, organizers said on Sunday. This multidisciplinary festival of arts and ideas was founded in 2013 by New York Live Arts, a Chelsea group. Each year has a different theme, with previous festivals focusing on the works of the neurologist Oliver Sacks and the playwright and author James Baldwin. This years edition, assembled by the visual artist and performer Laurie Anderson, is themed S K Y  Force and Wisdom in America Today. The sky  a multidimensional symbol of aspiration, vastness, change, threat and now information storage  is a fitting image for this years festival, Bill T. Jones, New York Live Arts artistic director, said in a statement. Highlights of the festival, taking place April 15-19, include a new commission by the Bessie Award-winning choreographer Beth Gill and screenings of films by Julian Schnabel. Tickets range from free to $65. Information is at newyorklivearts.org.

title: Six Urban Characters in Search of a Retreat
description: A new play about six strangers who leave the city for a silent retreat in the woods will open the 2015 season at the Manhattan nonprofit Ars Nova, organizers said on Sunday. The production, Small Mouth Sounds, by Bess Wohl (American Hero), is directed by Rachel Chavkin (Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812) and developed through Ars Novas Play Group. It opens March 10 and runs through April 11. Other season highlights include Bridget Everett (the full title is unprintable)  (April 9), a concert by the alt-cabaret performer Bridget Everett and various Ars Nova emerging artists; and the annual ANT Fest in June. Fall will bring Futurity, a new musical with book and lyrics by Csar Alvarez.

title: New Beginning
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  If you ever have the opportunity to meet Ian Livengood in person, you might note his quiet demeanor, his friendly smile, his self-deprecating sense of humor. Its not until you get to know him a lot better that the FRESH part of him starts to emerge, and when that happens, I advise you to run like heck. Or have a beer with him, which is much more fun.

title: Greek Leftists Adopt Patti Smith Anthem People Have the Power as Their Own
description: Two minutes after the polls closed in Greece on Sunday night, activists for the left-wing Syriza party celebrated projections of a decisive victory by posting a link on Twitter to People Have the Power, a song by the American poet and singer Patti Smith that has become something of an unofficial anthem for the populist movement.

title: Unease for What Microsofts HoloLens Will Mean for Our Screen-Obsessed Lives

In one sense, it was heartening. Business reporters are frequently hung up on the new and the insurgent, but seeing mature companies adapt to a changed world is equally interesting.

title: Chitresh Das, Influential Performer and Educator of Indian Dance, Dies at 70
description: Chitresh Das, a teacher and performer who widely disseminated the north Indian classical dance form kathak in the United States, died on Jan. 4 in San Rafael, Calif. He was 70.

As a veteran lawmaker on the Navajo reservation, he is also an integral part of the establishment, known for his starched shirts, polite manner and ardent anti-marijuana stance.

title: Two Japanese Hostages, as Different as Can Be, Linked by Fate in Syria

title: Worry for Solar Projects After End of Tax Credits
description: For more than a year now, an enormous solar thermal power plant has been humming along in the Arizona desert, sending out power as needed, even well after sunset. The plant, called Solana, was developed by the Spanish energy and technology company Abengoa and has succeeded in meeting an elusive solar goal  producing electricity when the sun is not shining  and displacing fossil-fuel-based power in the grid.

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 8 P.M. (TCM) DIRECTED BY LUIS BUUEL This five-film tribute to Buuel (1900-1983), known as the father of Surrealist cinema, begins with Belle de Jour (1968), starring Catherine Deneuve (above right, with Genevive Page) as a frigid young housewife able to achieve sexual satisfaction only after becoming a prostitute. Writing in The New York Times, Renata Adler called Belle de Jour a really beautiful movie, and somehow, letting the color in  this is Buuels first color film  has changed the emotional quality of his obsessions in a completely unpredictable way. In The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie (1972), an Oscar-winner for best foreign film, at 10, six upwardly mobile friends try to have dinner together  but find they cant. In addition to being extraordinarily funny and perfectly acted, Vincent Canby wrote, The Discreet Charm moves with the breathtaking speed and self-assurance that only a man of Buuels experience can achieve without resorting to awkward ellipsis. The lineup continues with Diary of a Chambermaid (1964), an adaptation of the novel by Octave Mirbeau about the foibles and hypocrisy of the landed gentry as seen through the eyes of a worldly domestic (Jeanne Moreau), at midnight; Viridiana (1962), in which a young nun (Silvia Pinal) tries to help the poor after inheriting a fortune, at 2 a.m.; and The Exterminating Angel (1962), where guests at a lavish dinner party in an elegant home in Mexico City find themselves unable to leave the parlor for several days, during which the social order begins to break down, at 3:45.

title: Romney to Larry King: Ill Decide in Two Weeks
Can Torture Ever Be Moral?
description: The recent Senate report on the Central Intelligence Agencys use of torture has been the focus of a national debate about whether torture is ever permissible.This interview, the second in a series on political topics, discusses philosophical ideas that underlie this debate. My interviewee is Jeff McMahan, Whites Professor of Moral Philosophy at the University of Oxford. He is the author of The Ethics of Killing.  Gary Gutting

title: Aer Lingus Considers New Takeover Offer From British Airways Parent
description: LONDON  Aer Lingus said on Monday that its board of directors was considering the latest revised takeover bid from the parent of British Airways and the Spanish carrier Iberia, the third time it has been approached since December.

title: In My Cats Death, a Human Comfort
description: Recently, when I told a friend about my cats death from cancer, I found myself saying, It was such a better experience than when my mom died! I realized how crazy it sounded  I hadnt meant to compare their deaths like accommodations on TripAdvisor  but it was true.

title: Mr. Maduro in His Labyrinth
description: Framed portraits of the Venezuelan leader Hugo Chvez were propped up at various stops of President Nicols Maduros recent whirlwind trip abroad, as the man at the helm of the nation with the worlds largest oil reserves begged for bailouts.

title: Maduro en su laberinto
description: Retratos enmarcados del fallecido lder venezolano Hugo Chvez se expusieron en diversos eventos que realiz el Presidente Nicols Maduro, durante su reciente gira internacional, una misin en la que el hombre al mando de la nacin con mayores reservas petroleras, recorri el mundo rogando por un rescate financiero.

title: Unsafe E-Cigarettes
description: To the Editor:

title: Tough on Crime Fadeout: What Constitutes Safety?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ending Greeces Nightmare
description: Alexis Tsipras, leader of the left-wing Syriza coalition, is about to become prime minister of Greece. He will be the first European leader elected on an explicit promise to challenge the austerity policies that have prevailed since 2010. And there will, of course, be many people warning him to abandon that promise, to behave responsibly.

title: When the Elderly Face Social Rejection
Legalized Bribery
description: LAST Thursday, Sheldon Silver, the speaker of the New York Assembly for the past 20 years, was arrested and charged with mail and wire fraud, extortion and receiving bribes. According to Preet Bharara, the federal prosecutor who brought the charges, the once seemingly untouchable Mr. Silver took millions of dollars for legal work he did not do. In exchange, he used his official power to steer business to a law firm that specialized in getting tax breaks for real estate developers, and he directed state funds to a doctor who referred cases to another law firm that paid Mr. Silver fees.

title: Contrasting Perspectives on the Price of Medicines
description: To the Editor:

title: Farming Science, Without the Conscience
description: You dont have to be a vegan to be repulsed by an account in The Times revealing the moral depths to which the federal government  working as a handmaiden to industrial agriculture  has sunk in pursuit of cheaper meat and fatter corporate profits. The article, by Michael Moss, examines the little-known U.S. Meat Animal Research Center, financed by American taxpayers, which employs the sophisticated tools and scientific expertise of modern animal management  apparently without a conscience.

title: A Promising Garbage Workaround
description: Nearly a decade ago, Mayor Michael Bloombergs administration declared a new era of solid waste stewardship, a veritable trash Enlightenment, when it adopted a plan that would handle New York Citys garbage for the next 20 years. The plan was built on the reasonable and fair idea that each borough needed to take adequate responsibility for its own trash.

title: Mark Wahlberg and the Purpose of Pardons
Vote Result in Greece Challenges More Than Austerity
description: ATHENS  Days before his emphatic victory in the Greek elections, Alexis Tsipras appeared at the final campaign rally of his left-wing Syriza party with a ponytailed Spaniard named Pablo Iglesias, whose own far-left political movement is now shaking up Spain.

title: 6 Qs About the News | The Super Bowl and the Rumors of Wrongdoing
description: In Belichick Offers Details on Footballs and Again Denies Wrongdoing, The Associated Press and Ben Shpigel write about questions surrounding the balls used by the New England Patriots in the A.F.C. championship game last Sunday.

title: Test Yourself | Virtual Reality and the News
description: Here are several paragraphs from a Jan. 23 article, Vice Uses Virtual Reality to Immerse Viewers in News.

title: Women Fighting for Their Land and Opportunity
description: Adriane Ohanesian went to Myanmars Kachin State in 2013 to photograph a lengthy civil war that had been invisible to much of the world. The country had long shunned the outside world, and the region, home to the mostly Christian Kachin people, was hard to get to.

title: Do Poor People Have It Easy?
description: Government programs designed to help people through difficult economic times, like unemployment compensation and Section 8 housing, sometimes get criticized by those who believe recipients have it easy. What do you think about that idea?

title: Scores of Philippine Police Officers Killed in Firefight With Rebels
description: MANILA  At least 43 police officers in the southern Philippines were killed during an attempt to capture one of Southeast Asias most wanted terrorism suspects, police and government officials said on Monday.

title: A Drone, Too Small for Radar to Detect, Rattles the White House
description: WASHINGTON  A White House radar system designed to detect flying objects like planes, missiles and large drones failed to pick up a small drone that crashed into a tree on the South Lawn early Monday morning, according to law enforcement officials. The crash raised questions about whether the Secret Service could bring down a similar object if it endangered President Obama.

title: White House Says Device Found on Grounds Poses No Threat
description: A Drone, Too Small for Radar to Detect, Rattles the White House

title: Salt May Not Affect Heart Risks
description: A new study suggests that dietary salt may have little or no effect on the risk for heart disease in older adults.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: New Phase of Space Travel Hopes to Set Sail on Sunlight
description: To sail on winds of sunlight has long been a dream of rocket scientists.

title: Amazon and Its Friends
description: During the 2012 campaign, Mitt Romney made an off-the-cuff comment about how corporations are people. He was mocked but perhaps was ahead of his time. A few years later, corporations are not only people but our friends.

title: New York Today: The Latest Travel and Weather Information
description: Here are the latest updates on the storm currently bearing down on the city:

title: With Parade, India Celebrates Republic Day
description: The event was a mix of modern-day military hardware, soldiers in traditional turbans and costumes riding camels, and a series of floats from myriad states.

title: Can This Treatment Help Me? Theres a Statistic for That
Spy Agency in Britain Falls Victim to a Prankster
description: LONDON  At a time when Western leaders are clamoring for greater powers to conduct covert surveillance, a prankster in Britain has turned the tables, obtaining a private cellphone number for a top intelligence chief and apparently telephoning the prime minister in his name, British officials acknowledged on Monday.
