title: Daily Report: Why Messaging Apps Are So Hot
description: Some publishers, game makers and e-commerce companies are using personal messaging apps like Instagram, WeChat and Snapchat as a new distribution and moneymaking platform, Mike Isaac and Michael J. de la Merced report.

title: Democrats Set Record in 2014, in Fund-Raising Anyway
description: Democrats raised $4.1 million in December after their bruising losses in the midterm elections. That put their 2014 total at a record $131 million and helped them shave their debt to $10 million, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee said on Monday.

title: Those Radical VSPs
description: As we head for the big Greek face-off, Francesco Saraceno makes a point Ive also made on a number of occasions: although many of the press reports describe Syriza as far-left, its actually preaching fairly conventional economics, while the supposedly responsible officials of Brussels and Berlin have been relying on radical doctrines like expansionary austerity and a growth cliff at 90 percent. The same has to a certain extent been true in the US context.

title: Morning Agenda: U.S. Challenges Insider Trading Ruling
description: Federal prosecutors are seeking to reverse, or at least narrow, a crucial insider trading ruling that overturned the convictions of two hedge fund managers last month, DealBooks Matthew Goldstein and Ben Protess report. Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, is asking the same three-judge panel that issued the ruling to revisit its decision, according to a filing on Friday. As an alternative, Mr. Bhararas filing proposes the legal equivalent of a do-over in a process known as en banc.

title: Internal Devaluation in Greece
description: One point that seems relevant to talk about Grexit (Greek exit from the euro) and all that: at this point its not clear that Greece needs a big boost to competitiveness. Internal devaluation via falling wages is incredibly costly  but Greece has been paying incredible costs, and has achieved a sharp fall in relative wages:

title: Perry Finds an Admiring Audience on the Road in Iowa
description: Five days after leaving behind the pomp of the Texas governors office, Rick Perry stood before 30 Iowans at a Pizza Ranch in Indianola, Iowa, on Sunday trying to convince them that the humble mortal just inches away was fit to occupy the Oval Office.

title: China to Force Authors to Provide Real Names When Publishing Online
description: Zhou Shuren is widely regarded as one of Chinas most influential 20th-century writers. But to most readers, he is known as Lu Xun, one of the more than 100 pen names the author used, often to evade the repercussions of provocative political views.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: Journalist Who Reported on Argentine Prosecutors Death Flees to Israel
description: JERUSALEM  Damin Pachter, the first journalist to report the suspicious death of an Argentine prosecutor, has fled to Israel, saying that he feared for his life in Argentina.

title: GrandVision Plans to Raise Up to $1.2 Billion in Amsterdam I.P.O.
description: LONDON  GrandVision, the Dutch operator of the optical retailers Vision Express in Britain and Gnrale dOptique in France, plans to raise as much as 1.1 billion euros, or about $1.2 billion, in an initial public offering on Euronext in Amsterdam next month.

title: Ocwen and Bondholders Clash Over Mortgage Services
description: The embattled subprime mortgage servicer Ocwen Financial is accusing a group of mortgage-bond investors of pushing for fast foreclosure and objecting to principal reductions on billions of dollars in mortgages.

title: Saint-Gobain Suffers Setback in Bid for Control of Swiss Chemical Maker
description: LONDON  The French conglomerate Saint-Gobain suffered a setback on Monday in its bid to take control of Sika, the Swiss specialty chemical maker.

title: Revisiting Andrea Chnier at the Royal Opera House
description: LONDON  Andrea Chnier is one of those operas that most major companies do every 20 years or so: often enough for it to count as repertory but not for anyone to remember if it was worth the effort the last time around. And as the last Covent Garden staging was in fact 30 years ago  a generation past  it was a curious, inquisitive audience that came to Tuesdays opening of a big new international production that is scheduled for Beijing and San Francisco after London.

title: Shakeups in Best Picture and Best Actor Races
description: PARK CITY, Utah  As potential nominees for next years Oscars were making the rounds at Sundance, with the requisite publicists and strategists at their sides, this years race delivered a shakeup over the weekend, courtesy of the Producers Guild and Screen Actors Guild awards.

title: New York City Is Spared the Worst Effects of Snowstorm
description: For the latest on the winter storm affecting the New York region, click here.

title: A Radio Hosts Strategy for Christie: Let Him Rant
description: Over five years and 58 hours, Eric Scott has sat across the table from Gov. Chris Christie inside the studios of WKXW-FM (101.5), hosting a call-in program that captures the many moods of New Jerseys mercurial chief executive.

title: Blizzard Questions, Including Why a European Weather Model (Usually) Excels at U.S. Forecasts
description: | Needless to say, theres plenty of day-after cogitation and finger pointing over the New York side of snowfall forecasts, which the European model did poorly at  along with many meteorologists. Read Henry Fountains news story and Eric Holthauss great Slate piece on how only the Weather Channel got snow forecasts right.

description: WASHINGTON  Kanye West took home the Visionary Award at the B.E.T. Honors on Saturday during an evening of surprise freestyles at the Warner Theater near the White House.

description: President Obama and the first lady attended Indias Republic Day Parade on Monday and watched a grand display of military hardware, marching bands, helicopters and elaborately dressed camels.

title: At Universities, a Push for Data-Driven Career Services
description: Officials at the University of California, San Diego, had sparse information on the career success of their graduates until they set up a branded page for the university on LinkedIn a couple of years ago.

title: Who Gets a Raise?
description: Is it time to ask for a raise?Neil Irwin at The Upshot writes that this could (finally) be a good year for wages, with small businesses, and a big health insurer, planning to increase pay. And The Billfold titled a recent postThe Year America Gets a Raise (though its author, Mike Dang, also cautioned that we can only watch and wait to see if wages really rise).

title: Video Review: The 2015 Nissan Murano, Dressed Up and Looking Good
description: LEAF, Juke, Quest and Cube are proof that Nissan doesnt play it safe with design. This could be because of its alliance with the French automaker Renault. If not, the French curves Nissan uses must come directly from the mother country.

description: A crossover that never fit in with the flannel shirt crowd leans farther toward the fashion scene.

title: U.S. Envoy Urges Thailand to Lift Martial Law
description: BANGKOK  The most senior United States diplomat to visit Thailand since the military seized power in May called on Monday for the lifting of martial law and delivered harsh words to the junta.

title: 1915: Attack on Egypt Imminent
description: LONDON A despatch from Cairo to the Daily News and Leader says that air scouts report that everything is ready for the advance of the Turkish army upon the Suez Canal excepting the arrangements for the transport of heavy guns, for which a system of tramways is being laid with the utmost speed on the soft desert soil. A general survey of the situation seems to point to the delivery of the blow immediately north of the Bitter Lakes, but the movements of the invading army are likely to be greatly impeded in many directions by flooded areas. The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 27, 1915

title: Streetwear, a Little Older and Wiser at OAMC
description: PARIS  On a recent afternoon, the Balenciaga showroom was buzzing with buyers from international stores pawing through blazers and eyeballing leather knapsacks. A pair at one table in the center caught the eye. One wore a shirt with the oversize graphic logo of Off-White, Virgil Ablohs line; the other, the oversize graphic logo of Palace, the London-based skate-wear brand.

title: Mubarak Sons Released From Egyptian Jail
description: CAIRO  The two adult sons of former President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt were released from jail early Monday, just one day after the fourth anniversary of the revolt that cast them down from the pinnacle of power.

description: This short documentary shows a mothers efforts to manage her daughters daily struggle with a life-threatening condition: Type I diabetes.

description: Thousands of football fans are flying into Phoenix this week for the Super Bowl on Sunday, but will locals be joining in the festivities? Are they embracing their roles as hosts, or just bracing themselves?

title: Midnight Three & Six
description: For the past eight years, the Chamberlain family in Fort Worth, Tex., has been coping with a nightmare all parents fear: In 2006, their daughter, Grace, was given a diagnosis of a life-threatening disease. Grace has Type 1 diabetes, for which there is no cure. Now 15 years old, she has endured approximately 34,000 blood tests, 5,550 shots and 1,660 medical tubing injections to keep her alive.

title: How the Smell of Rain Bubbles From the Ground
description: A familiar scent fills the air after a dry stretch is broken by a summer rain. There is even a word for this fresh, earthy smell: petrichor. The term was coined in the 1960s when scientists reported that the smell came from chemicals in the surface that the rain landed on.

title: Millions Paid by X Prize Foundation for Progress Toward Trip to Moon
description: In 2004, the X Prize Foundation celebrated the culmination of its first prize competition, awarding $10 million for successful flights of SpaceShipOne, the first privately financed reusable spacecraft to take a pilot to space, defined as 62 miles above the Earths surface.

description: Panos Kammenos, left, the leader of the Independent Greeks, announced a new coalition government on Monday after meeting with Alexis Tsipras, who swept to power on Sunday in Greece.

title: Eddie Redmayne on Ignoring the Odds
description: Newly minted SAG Award winner Eddie Redmayne (The Theory of Everything) set his sights on being an actor when he was 12 and was cast in a London production of Oliver! directed by Sam Mendes. He was Workhouse Boy No. 40. Mr. Redmayne tells the Baggers colleague Philip Galanes that his parents were supportive  to a point: My dad works in finance, so he kept giving me the stats: only one in a hundred actors makes it. Hed ask, Have you thought about producing?'

title: Christian Dior: Spring 2015 Couture
description: Paris

title: Seattle Running Back Joins List of N.F.L.s Defiant Ones
description: PHOENIX  One chooses not to speak with the news media, while the other was often accused of talking too much. But Marshawn Lynch, the embattled Seattle Seahawks running back, and Jim McMahon, the quarterback of the 1985 Chicago Bears, have a lot in common in terms of drawing the N.F.L.s ire in the time leading up to a Super Bowl.

title: New Leader in Greece Now Faces Creditors
description: ATHENS  As the new Greek prime minister turns to fulfilling his campaign pledge of renegotiating his countrys bailout loans and reducing its staggering debt burden, he may find that Greeces international creditors will be harder to persuade than the countrys voters.

title: More Differences Than Similarities Are Found in Autistic Siblings
description: Most siblings with a diagnosis of autism do not share the same genetic risk factors for the disorder and are as distinct in their behaviors as any brothers and sisters, scientists reported on Monday in a study that came as a surprise to many doctors, if not to parents.

title: Sundance 2015: Scientology Documentary Draws Crush of Festgoers
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Any doubts that anticipation was high for Oscar winner Alex Gibneys latest documentary, Going Clear, an expos about the Church of Scientology, were allayed Sunday afternoon at the packed premiere at Sundance.

title: White House Says Device Poses No Threat
description: Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, says that a small electronic device found on the White House lawn overnight is not thought to pose a threat to anyone within the building.

title: No Comment Necessary: Donald Trump, Border-Fence Builder
description: At the Freedom Summit in Iowa on Saturday, Donald Trump said that if he runs for president, and is elected president, he will build a border fence to keep out criminals, crooks and Islamic terrorists.

title: Sundance 2015: A Buying Spree Propelled by Video on Demand
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Distributors are snapping up Sundance movies with a ferocity not seen in years, a reflection of the quality of this years lineup and independent films improving economics, fueled by video on demand.

title: AT&T to Buy Nextel Mexico for $1.9 Billion
description: AT&T continued its southward expansion on Monday, agreeing to buy Nextel Mexico for nearly $1.9 billion as part of its campaign to expand its Latin American presence.

title: After a Bad Decision, Avoid the Shame and the Blame
description: About 10 years ago, my wife and I were driving around Park City during one of our annual summer trips to Utah. We knew that at some point we wanted to live there, so we were excited when we discovered a new housing development. Only a handful of lots had been sold, and the developer offered us a great discount off an already low price in an attempt to reel us in.

title: Tom Brady Cannot Stop
description: Last July, a few weeks before the New England Patriots started training camp, I got a call from Donald Yee, the agent in Los Angeles who has represented Tom Brady since he entered the N.F.L. in 2000. It had been four years since I first told Yee that I was interested in writing about Brady, even though I typically cover politics. I grew up in the Boston suburbs, rooted for the Patriots as a kid and even possessed vague memories of watching the team play at Fenway Park, one of their homes before they settled into the nowhereland of Foxborough, Mass., in 1971. My friend Josh and I once wrote a letter to the teams young quarterback, Jim Plunkett, inviting him to dinner at Joshs house. (Plunkett never responded.) Their teams were mostly bad, their owner was an embarrassment, their stadium a dump. Yet the Patriots always retained a lovable haplessness about them, with their cute minuteman logos, their A.F.L. lineage and the identity crisis that comes from being named after an entire region instead of a city or state. (The Seattle Seahawks are not the Pacific Northwest Seahawks.)

title: George Sichermans Pool Puzzles
On the Mens Fall/Winter 2015 Runways, a Collection of Vinyl
description: Black vinyl has been associated with fetishists attire, the 70s punk scene, Hype Williamss music videos of the late 90s and, more recently, installations by the artist Urs Fischer. And the slick plastic made a comeback in the fall/winter mens collections last week, giving an alluring, glossy finish to some of the looks. Calvin Kleins  Italo Zucchelli deployed the fabric  in both gray and black  in a range of familiar mens silhouettes including baggy trousers, parkas, and shrunken pilot jackets. The model wearing a structured black PVC raincoat in Raf Simonss recent collection proved that the shiny material can seem approachable when worn as part of a monochromatic look. And for his first appearance on the Paris fashion calendar, Stphane Ashpool orchestrated a theatrical presentation inside a classic opera house for his street-wear-cum-high-fashion brand Pigalle. Among the nubby knits, track suits, puffers and shearlings was the black vinyl bomber jacket seen above.

title: Learning From Animal Friendships
description: A goat frolics with a baby rhinoceros.  A pig nestles up to a house cat. A rat snake makes nice with the dwarf hamster originally intended as its lunch.

title: 1965: Fiery Suicide in Vietnam
description: SAIGON  A 17-year-old girl drenched herself with gasoline and burned herself to death today [Jan. 26] as a political protest against the government of Premier Tran Van Huong. The protest suicide  the first of its kind in South Vietnam since October, 1963  took place at Nha Trang, a coastal city 200 miles north of Saigon, during an antigovernment demonstration. The suicide occurred shortly after two terrorist bombs had exploded at an annex of the American military advisory headquarters in Saigon, injuring one Army officer but causing little damage.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 27, 1965

title: Facebook Is Said to Block Pages Critical of Muhammad to Avoid Shutdown in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  To avoid being banned throughout Turkey, Facebook has blocked Turkish users access to a number of pages containing content that the authorities had deemed insulting to the Prophet Muhammad, according to a company employee with direct knowledge of the matter and a report by the state broadcaster TRT.

title: First Draft Focus: A Wintry Mix for Washington

description: A beef chili infused with red chiles, chocolate and beer for bold flavor.

description: If you like to make chili and dont live in Texas, consider yourself lucky.

title: Animals as Friends
description: A look at some odd animal pairings.

title: The Surprise Isnt That an Extreme Party Won in Greece. Its That It Took This Long.
description: When I was last in Greece, for a reporting trip in May 2012, Syriza, a political party whose name is an acronym for coalition of the radical left, had recorded shockingly strong results in a recent election. The centrist, mainstream sources I was meeting with  such as bankers and ex-politicians  were nervous about what Syriza supporters, whom they viewed as wackos, meant for their country.

title: A Photographer Documents Ebolas Deadly Spread
description: A collection of work by the photographer Daniel Berehulak, who has been capturing lives touched by the Ebola virus across West Africa since August.

description: Barbie and other traditional toys are having a much tougher time supporting their elderly parent Mattel, a toymaker significantly weakened by stiff competition from small upstarts and by digital distractions aimed at children.

description: The critically acclaimed Broadway drama The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time has recouped its $4.75 million capitalization, its producers announced on Monday, confirming the plays status as one of the big hits of the 2014-15 theater season.

title: Unlikely Friends
description: Videos of unlikely animal friendships are popular on social media. Scientists are now considering how to define such relationships and why they are so fascinating to us.

title: Reading List for a Better Understanding of Events in Saudi Arabia
description: Neil MacFarquhar, with The Timess reporters Helene Cooper and Rod Nordland, wrote a news analysis about Saudi Arabian-American relations in the wake of King Abdullahs death.

title: Assembly Democrats Call on Sheldon Silver to Step Down as Speaker

title: Tom Petty to Share Credit for Sam Smiths Stay With Me
description: Last year, the British singer Sam Smith scored a big hit with his gospel-tinged song Stay With Me, which reached No. 2 and established Mr. Smith as a major new vocal talent.

title: Snow Day Approaches
description: Bread. Milk. Bottled water. Flashlights, batteries, etcetera, etcetera. Normal storm preparations, check. But whos prepared for the children to be home from school tomorrow and maybe for a day or two thereafter? A number of schools across the East Coast have already canceled for Tuesday, Jan. 27, 2015, in anticipation of heavy snow and hazardous travel conditions, and many are dismissing early today as well.

description: A look back at some of the houses recent feats of interior design.

title: Before the Storm
description: On Monday morning, New Yorkers prepared for a powerful blizzard that was set to sweep across the region.

title: Supreme Court Rules Against Retirees in Union Health Benefits Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday ruled that a chemical company may be able to cut the health benefits of its retired workers, unanimously reversing an appeals court ruling that said the benefits had vested for life.

title: SkyMall Stumbles as Airlines Hone Their Sales Pitches
description: WE might get a little more knee room in coach, now that the familiar SkyMall catalog is disappearing from that thick stash of printed material the airlines cram into seat-back pockets.

title: Even in Affluent Towns, Rising Tax Bills Mean Angst, and Appeals
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y.  It is hard, homeowners in this emblem of affluence agree, to feel sorry for the tax problems of people who live in 6,000-square-foot homes set on two or three manicured acres with swimming pools and tennis courts.

title: Anatomy of a Health Care Mess
description: Never sign up for a tour of the sausage factory, not if you want to keep eating sausage. In the case of health care, unfortunately, no one gets to abstain. Journalists and legislators, doctors and nurses, reformers and reformed alike, all eventually land on the conveyor belt that feeds those grinding gears.

title: Study Suggests Earlier Use of Tools by Hominids
description: Somewhere along the journey from ape to human, our ancestors developed hands that were better suited to holding tools than climbing trees. A new study suggests the transition took place as much as 3.2 million years ago  about 600,000 years earlier than previously thought.

title: The Bee Solution to Winter
description: Q. Do bees hibernate, especially where temperatures are below freezing for extended periods? Why dont they just freeze?

title: Ukrainian Forces Struggle as Fighting Flares in East
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  The shattered remains of a tank bearing a tattered Ukrainian flag sat beside the main highway to Mariupol on Monday afternoon, a remnant of what pro-Russian rebel forces said was a failed attempt by Ukrainian forces to push into rebel-held territory a few days after a shelling attack left 30 dead in that port city.

title: Paul Singers Fund, Elliott, Takes a Stake in Informatica
description: Over the past two years, Paul Singers hedge fund, Elliott Management, has successfully pushed a number of technology companies to sell themselves. Now, it appears that the $25 billion hedge fund has set its sights on a new target.

title: For First Time, Church of England Consecrates a Woman to Serve as a Bishop
description: LONDON  Centuries of tradition were overturned in the Church of England on Monday when it consecrated the first woman to serve as one of its bishops at a service in York Minister.

title: African Mosquitoes, Toxic Nets
description: The Timess East Africa bureau chief, Jeffrey Gettleman, wrote on Sunday about one of the continents biggest recent public health campaigns  and its surprising unintended consequences. He explains his personal experience with mosquito nets and provides insight, and empathy, into inadvertent trouble that results from mosquito nets intended to defend against malaria.

title: U.S. Drone Kills 3 Qaeda Operatives in Yemen, Continuing Policy on Strikes
description: WASHINGTON  A C.I.A. drone strike in Yemen, the first since the resignation of President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi, killed three suspected Qaeda fighters on Monday, American officials said, in a signal that the United States will continue its counterterrorism operations there despite the apparent takeover by Houthi fighters.

title: A Friendly but Willful Old Spirit, Pouring Tea
description: If you have to be haunted, you really couldnt ask for a nicer sort of ghost. The specter at the heart of Hugh Leonards semi-autobiographical play Da, revived by the Irish Repertory Theater, pours piping cups of tea and proffers packs of cigarettes. Most of the time he lounges in his favorite armchair, singing snatches of songs and telling jokes.

title: A New Face for Violet
description: Violet Pietrok was born with a Tessier Cleft, a rare defect that left a fissure in her skull. Surgeons at Boston Childrens Hospital, aided by 3-D prints of her skull, hope to repair the damage.

title: A Snowless Snow Day
Seeking Contrasts, Finding Similarities
description: The violinist Miranda Cuckson started to play Mario Davidovskys Synchronisms No. 9 (1988) just after 3 p.m. on Sunday at Spectrum on the Lower East Side. While the piece is a duet with electronics, it begins with a plaintive solo line, lonely yet warm, like the glow of firelight spied across a snowy plain by night.

title: Republicans Pretend to Care About Inequality
description: Every time I think the Republican Partys political spin cant get more brazen, House Speaker John Boehner and the new Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell show me that Ive just succumbed to the soft bigotry of low expectations.

title: A Literary Agent Writes His Own Novel
description: The literary agent Bill Clegg is renowned in the publishing world as a ruthless negotiator who routinely wrings fat six- and seven-figure advances out of editors for experimental debut novels from unknown authors.

title: Off the 3-D Printer, Practice Parts for the Surgeon
description: BOSTON  The surgeon held a translucent white plastic eye socket in each hand. Gently moving them away from each other, Dr. John Meara showed the distance between Violet Pietroks eyes at birth. He slid the sockets closer to demonstrate their positions 19 months later, after he had operated on her.

title: Sundance Veterans Winona Ryder and Peter Sarsgaard on College Psych Experiments, Beetlejuice 2 and the Lure of TV
description: Winona Ryder and Peter Sarsgaard seem ambivalent, if amused, by their roles as elder statespeople of the Sundance Film Festival. The actors, both 43, have become synonymous with the kind of quirky indie fare that has come to epitomize Sundance over the years: Ryder, as the breakout star of Beetlejuice and with her roles in the cult films Heathers and Edward Scissorhands in the late 80s and early 90s; and Sarsgaard with celebrated turns in the Sundance films The Dying Gaul, An Education and Garden State, among others. This week, they star alongside one another for the first time in Experimenter, the director Michael Almereydas drama about the social psychologist Stanley Milgram and his controversial experiments on obedience in the 1960s. Its a peculiar film  as Milgram, Sarsgaard routinely breaks the fourth wall by speaking directly to the camera; at several points an elephant appears from seemingly nowhere to hint at the deeper meaning behind Milgrams experiments  and yet it never crumbles under its own weight, thanks to the steady talents of Sarsgaard and Ryder, who plays Milgrams wife, Sasha. (Ryder is also a jury member at this years festival.) T sat down with the actors prior to Sundays premiere to discuss ambiguous audience reactions, the allure of television and the rising specter of a Beetlejuice sequel.

title: Former Lords Resistance Army Commander Appears at War Crimes Court
description: A captured Ugandan rebel commander made his first public appearance Monday at a hearing before the International Criminal Court, where he stands accused of crimes including murder and enslavement.

title: Grieg, Extended
description: One of the most striking features of Griegs String Quartet in G minor is the textural richness created by techniques including double stopping, in which two notes are played simultaneously. Given the works allure, it receives surprisingly infrequent airings. But listeners had a chance to admire the scores many charms during a passionate performance by the Amphion String Quartet at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday evening, in a concert presented by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center.

title: In Push for Change, Finra Is Opposed by the Wall St. Firms It Regulates
description: Wall Street has pulled out all the stops in opposing a plan by its own self-regulator to require brokers to share extensive information about their clients accounts.

title: Cuomo Tells New Yorkers to Stay Home
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Monday urged New Yorkers to stay indoors and avoid hazardous conditions during the snowstorm.

title: Dress Blues
description: From double-breasted jean jackets to starched culottes, tailored denim is the next big thing.

title: De Blasio: No Food Takeout During Storm
description: New York City banned non-emergency vehicles after 11 p.m. When asked about food delivery, Mayor Bill de Blasio said, A food delivery bicycle is not an emergency vehicle.

title: Snowed In? Heres What to Watch, Read or Listen To
description: Its too cold to go out. Your remote is working, but forget flipping though the channels: let us guide you. Your stereo is searching for something better than what youre listening to now? You need a new book? We hear you. Here are our recommendations for whats streaming on TV, what should be rocking your apartment and great reads to curl up with.

title: Christie on New Jerseys Preparations
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey spoke about the preparations he was taking ahead of the snowstorm.

title: Pluralsight, a Training Service for Tech Professionals, Buys Code School
description: Pluralsight, an online service that provides advanced training courses for technology professionals, is on a shopping spree.

title: De Blasio Declares State of Emergency
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced a state of emergency and said that only emergency vehicles would be allowed on New York City streets after 11 p.m. Monday.

title: Behind the Poster: The Visit
description: The moody poster art for the musical The Visit shows the Tony Award-winning actress Chita Rivera looking regal in a crisp white maxi-coat, with bright red lips and a sparkling necklace adding bold accents to the scene. She stands with a cane before a shadowy recess that hints at the shows dark tale about a wealthy widow who seeks revenge on a former lover. (In his review for the production at the Williamstown Theater Festival, Ben Brantley wrote that Scott Pasks set suggests a long-abandoned train station where you can buy a ticket straight to hell.) The long-gestating musical, from the songwriters John Kander and Fred Ebb (Chicago) and the playwright Terrence McNally, arrives on Broadway this spring.

title: Translating, if Not Analyzing, Gender Dynamics
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  Some choreographers build up to audience participation, or infiltration, during the course of an evening, but not the South African artist Robyn Orlin. Within the first five minutes of her expansively titled At the same time we were pointing a finger at you, we realized we were pointing three at ourselves, her fluorescent-clad dancers clamber into the audience, swatting at the seats and the people in them with rubber flip-flops.

title: Post Holdings Buying MOM Brands for $1.15 Billion
description: Post Holdings, maker of classic cereals like Grape-Nuts, Honeycomb and Post Raisin Bran, said on Monday that was spending $1.15 billion to buy MOM Brands, the family-owned maker of Malt-O-Meal.

title: A Quirky Innocence
description: An offbeat navet is informing fashion this spring, from eyelet nightshirts to textured tights.

title: Paris Couture Week: Christian Dior Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

title: Met Opera Cancels Premiere; Broadway Shows Canceled
description: The snowstorm forced the Metropolitan Opera to cancel one of the highlights of its season: Monday nights planned premiere of a new production of a double bill of Tchaikovskys Iolanta, starring Anna Netrebko, and Bartoks Bluebeards Castle.

title: 3 Men Are Charged With Serving as Secret Agents for Russia in New York
description: The three men would typically agree to meet outside, where one might tell another that he had a book, umbrella or hat to pass on. Then, at the appointed time and place, the secret handoff would occur: a bag, magazine or slip of paper changing hands.

title: The Uniquely Modern Grandeur of Diors Couture Stage Sets
description: Since Raf Simons debuted as Diors creative director in 2012, his romantic yet futuristic collections have remained a high point of couture week. And the same is true of the sets on which they have been presented. Today, at the Muse Rodin, Simons showed printed transparent vinyl coats, structured cutout gowns and graphic jumpsuits amidst an elaborate network of scaffolding with pink-carpeted stairs  as per usual, an immersive installation that deepened the clothes sense of drama. Here, a look at the structure and the houses other recent feats of set design.

title: In Selma, Trench Coats Amid Protests
description: Ruth E. Carter, the costume designer for Selma, explains how a heightened collar, colorful suits and coat pockets help transport viewers back to the violent but hopeful days of 1965.

title: In Performance | Jonny Donahoe
description: Mr. Donahoe in a scene from Every Brilliant Thing, a solo show about a man who creates a list of lifes pleasures for his suicidal mother. The play is at the Barrow Street Theater through March 29.

title: C.I.A. Officer Is Found Guilty in Leak Tied to Times Reporter
description: WASHINGTON  Jeffrey A. Sterling, a former Central Intelligence Agency officer, was convicted of espionage Monday on charges that he told a reporter for The New York Times about a secret operation to disrupt Irans nuclear program.

title: Merger of Packaging Makers Can Face Cultural Challenges
description: Delivering on the promise of a $16 billion paper merger may require some precision. Stockholders in the packaging giants Rock-Tenn and MeadWestvaco will share their combined company evenly, with a roughly balanced board.

title: Readers Respond: On Taking Dating Advice From David Brooks
description: As David Brooks picked up the topic of online dating, he must have known he was displaying the very vulnerability he cited as a prerequisite for love.

title: Mariinsky Ballet
description: Yevgeny Ivanchenko and Yekaterina Kondaurova in Jerome Robbinss In the Night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Tweaking an Illustrious Tradition to Incorporate Western Notions
description: A reader recently left a voice mail message telling me, The Russians invented ballet! No, they certainly didnt, but you can see why many people believe that they must have  especially the Mariinsky Ballet of St. Petersburg. Last weekend, the company ended a two-week season of three different programs at the Brooklyn Academy of Music; this week it moves on to the Kennedy Center in Washington with a program of late-19th- and early-20th-century choreography.

title: Wright Foundation Names Architecture Dean
description: After a period of turmoil over the fate of its architecture school, the Frank Lloyd Wright Foundation has selected Aaron Betsky as its new dean. Mr. Betsky, who last year stepped down as the director of the Cincinnati Art Museum, said he would start next month, succeeding Victor Sidy, who has led the school since 2005. The school does have to grow, not just in terms of student numbers, but also in terms of its capacity and its academic excellence, Mr. Betsky said in a telephone interview. We have to keep proving that this is the best experimental-architecture school in the world. Facing the loss of its accreditation, the foundation in October approved a possible path toward independent incorporation of its architecture school  provided fund-raising targets are met. Mr. Betsky, who has taught and written extensively about architecture, said he was undaunted, having raised more than $80 million in his eight years at the Cincinnati Art Museum. The architecture schools main campus is in Scottsdale, Ariz., with a campus for summer terms in Spring Green, Wis.

title: High Cholesterol Takes Its Toll Over Time
description: Having high cholesterol in your 30s and 40s increases your risk for heart disease, and the longer it stays elevated, the greater the risk, a new study reports.

title: Push Over, Cornish Pasty: Balti Curry Seeks a Place in British Culinary Lore
description: BIRMINGHAM, England  The year after opening a small restaurant here in 1977, Mohammed Arif spent two weeks in his native Pakistan, where he saw spicy, aromatic curries being cooked and served, sizzling, in the same dish.

title: A Mobile Umbilical Cord, Off the Table, but Still Connected
description: Im sorry, looks like youre getting a text. Gosh, I should probably have my phone out too! We were two women, meeting for the first time, seated across from each other in a cozy coffee shop. She was squeezing in our date between more-than-full-time work and two children, and I sandwiched the visit between shuttling my three kids, working from home, and a key board meeting for my start-up nonprofit. We had just 40 minutes to get to know each other and see if we could support each other in our growing careers.

title: Hold the Drug, Go Straight to the Source
description: Ground-up artemisia plants, from which the anti-malaria drug artemisinin is derived, appear to work much better than the refined drug does by itself, according to research at the University of Massachusetts.

title: Releases From Jamie Cullum and Charlie Wilson
description: JAMIE CULLUM

title: Koch Brothers Budget of $889 Million for 2016 Is on Par With Both Parties Spending
description: The political network overseen by the conservative billionaires Charles G. and David H. Koch plans to spend close to $900 million on the 2016 campaign, an unparalleled effort by coordinated outside groups to shape a presidential election that is already on track to be the most expensive in history.

title: Cleaning Up Water by Running It Through Dirt
description: Storm runoff can be toxic to aquatic life, but a new study suggests a simple and relatively inexpensive solution: Filter the water through dirt before it enters streams, rivers or the ocean.

title: Paris Couture Week: Christian Dior Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

title: Strong Sales for Hedwig on Broadway
description: Fans of the 1990s downtown musical Hedwig and the Angry Inch and its 2001 movie version turned out in strong numbers last week to see the original Hedwig, John Cameron Mitchell, play the role for the first time on Broadway in the hit production there. According to box office data released on Monday, Hedwig had one of the highest average ticket prices on Broadway last week  $115.72  and grossed $609,617 for six performances, or 93 percent of the maximum possible amount. Hedwig is the creation of Mr. Mitchell (who wrote the book) and Stephen Trask (who wrote the music and lyrics), and won the Tony Award for best musical revival in June (as well as a best actor Tony for its star at the time, Neil Patrick Harris). Mr. Mitchell is scheduled to play Hedwig on Broadway through March 14.

title: One Pioneers Attempt to Rescue Another
description: To the list of books about transformative technology companies and their visionary leaders we can now add one about Silicon Valleys wayward soul and would-be savior: Yahoos Marissa Mayer.

title: Flawed Case Contributes to Acquittals in Murder of Costa Rican Turtle Guardian
description: A Costa Rican judge today acquitted seven men of murder charges in the May, 2013, slaying of Jairo Mora, a young sea turtle conservationist, citing faults in handling of evidence and other problems with the investigation. Below you can read courtroom details as reported for the Tico Times by Lindsay Fendt, whose fine coverage of this case was cited here in 2013.

title: Deep Into That Darkness Peering
description: Exquisitely stylish and excessively bleak, the new musical Nevermore: The Imaginary Life and Mysterious Death of Edgar Allan Poe, at New World Stages, takes the sad facts of Poes life and makes them gloomier still.

title: A Versatile Pianist Grounded in Groove, His Collaborators in Tow
description: There isnt much in the modern-jazz-musician tool kit that Marc Cary hasnt mastered, but he has a particular subspecialty in the area of groove. A pianist who came up the old-school way, with mentors like Abbey Lincoln and Betty Carter, Mr. Cary has always been adept with a range of rhythmic strategies, from a deep-house pulse to a swinging churn.

title: Shaping His Genius to Transform Everyday Life
description: Plenty of lives are admirable or eventful, but only a very few are so influential that its difficult to wrap your head around just how much they meant to the world. Thomas A. Edison lived such a life, and it receives a thorough two-hour examination in Tuesdays American Experience on PBS.

title: Giambattista Valli: Spring 2015 Couture
description: Paris

title: Your Letters: End of Life Decisions and Writing Your Story
description: Advance Directives

title: Budget Forecast Sees End to Sharp Deficit Declines
description: WASHINGTON  The federal budget deficit will continue to inch downward through next year, but even with the economy on an upward trajectory, the governments red ink will begin to rise in 2017 and expand with an aging population, the Congressional Budget Office said Monday.

title: Kurd Militia Says ISIS Is Expelled From Kobani
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Kurdish militias regained full control of the northern Syrian town of Kobani on Monday, driving Islamic State militants out with the help of American-led airstrikes, Kurdish activists on the scene said.

title: Avant-Garde (Hair)Style in Schiaparellis Couture Presentation
description: T shares the best hairstyles from the runways.

title: A Snowstorm in New York
description: The city was virtually deserted overnight with drivers ordered to stay off the roads, the subways shut down and bridges and tunnels closed.

title: Greeces Agonized Cry to Europe
description: The message from Sundays elections in Greece was unambiguous: The Greeks cannot and will not continue to abide by the austerity regime that has brought their economy to its knees. It was a message the Germans and other Europeans who continue to insist that Greece pay off its mountainous debt, no matter what the damage, must hear. Persisting on their dogmatic course is not only wrong for Greece but dangerous for the entire European Union.

title: Chinas Other E-Commerce Giant Follows Its Own Path
description: BEIJING  Just about every June, on the anniversary of his companys founding, Richard Liu dons a big motorcycle helmet and red uniform, hops on a three-wheeled electric bike and makes home deliveries for his e-commerce company JD.com.

title: Hoping to Set Sail on Sunlight
description: To sail on winds of sunlight has long been a dream of rocket scientists.

title: Weekend Scrambles Top Oscar Prospects
description: LOS ANGELES  An unexpected double win for Alejandro G. Irritus Birdman, at the expense of Richard Linklaters Boyhood, jolted the Oscar race over the weekend, even as Harvey Weinstein made a bid to enhance his own contender, The Imitation Game, as a filmic standard-bearer against past injustices directed at gays.

title: Alex Sharp and Russell Janzen Win Barnes Foundation Prize
description: The Clive Barnes Foundation named Alex Sharp and Russell Janzen winners of its fifth annual awards for young actors and dancers during a ceremony at Walter Reade Theater on Monday.

title: Price Cuts for Crucial Microsoft Products Eroded Holiday-Season Profit
description: SEATTLE  Microsoft has conjured up some attention-grabbing new products lately to help it restart growth. The companys results over the holidays show how badly it needs them to work.

title: My Very Educated Readers Just Served Us Some New Planet Mnemonics
description: When Pluto was demoted from planethood, the trusty mnemonic My Very Educated Mother Just Served Us Nine Pizzas had to be retooled. But there are still those who are rooting for the dwarf planets to be considered actual planets, which would require a new mnemonic. Its not just that P - for Pluto  would be added back but also C for Ceres, E for Eris, H for Haumea and M for Makemake, creating the new order: M-V-E-M-C-J-S-U-N-P-H-M-E. We asked our readers to submit their own mnemonics. Here are some of our favorites:

title: Reid Recuperating at Home After Surgery
description: Senator Harry Reid was back at his home in Washington on Monday after having surgery for injuries sustained in an exercise accident on Jan. 1.

title: At Diors Spring 2015 Couture Presentation, a Perfect Storm of Pattern and Texture
description: The tent at the Muse Rodin for todays Dior spring 2015 haute couture show was transformed by mirrored walls and a bilevel mass of white scaffolding that felt a bit like the inside of a kaleidoscope. The effect upon entering was jarring  which also seemed to be the intention of Raf Simonss collection, a mash-up of various historical references from the 50s and 60s taken for a futuristic spin. One of the best looks was a plastic floral-print cape worn over a crystal-embellished minidress and a floral-tattoo-print bodysuit and paired with high-gloss short boots. Just like the shows venue, the look was multifaceted, but somehow harmonious all the same.

title: Rand Paul Challenges Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz on Iran
description: Politicians who oppose President Obama can bluster all they want, grab headlines and curry favor with donors yet dont have to be responsible for their (too often) irresponsible critiques and prescriptions on foreign policy. So it was refreshing to hear Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky split with some of his fellow Republicans on Iran during a presidential forum on Saturday organized by Freedom Partners.

title: A DIY Printing Studio, Two Exhibitions for Douglas Coupland and More from the Art Calendar
description: Ts list of happenings worth visiting in the week ahead.

title: Pakistan and Elsewhere  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos of the Day  Pakistan and Elsewhere

title: Jan. 26, 2015  Photos of the Day
description: Photos from Pakistan, Cambodia, Ukraine and the United States.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: In Emergencies, Companies Are Turning to Employee-Tracking Services
description: The recent terrorist attack in Paris put Norm Sheehan, a safety director for an international development company, on high alert.

title: Greek Election Reflects a Deep Divide in Europe
description: BRUSSELS  The Greek election not only strengthened opponents of austerity, it also highlighted a fundamental tension at the heart of Europes six-decade-long push to forge a closer union of democratic states: what to do when voters in different countries have different, even opposite, demands.

title: As Oil Prices Sink, BP Freezes Workers Wages
description: HOUSTON  The British oil giant BP announced on Monday that it was freezing the wages of its 80,000 workers, another sign that oil companies are being forced to cut back in the face of collapsing oil prices.

title: Sothebys Raises Its Rates for Buyers
description: Its about to get more expensive to shop at Sothebys.

title: S.&P. Cuts Russian Debt One Notch to Junk Level
description: As Russia deals with the heavy toll of Western sanctions and falling oil prices, a major credit ratings agency on Monday downgraded the countrys sovereign debt to below investment grade, the first time it has fallen to that level in more than a decade.

title: In Sedona at Super Bowl Time: A Little Escape
description: Two hours north of Glendale, Ariz., and away from the hubbub before the Super Bowl on Feb. 1 at University of Phoenix Stadium, is LAuberge de Sedona, a 9.2-acre resort that is offering an Escape the Super Bowl package.

title: Helena Morrissey, Aiming at Britains Glass Ceilings, Gets Results
description: LONDON  Suggest to Helena Morrissey that she is Britains version of Sheryl Sandberg, and she smiles politely.

title: Greece: Think Flows, Not Stocks
description: How should we think about the bargaining that may or may not now take place between the new Greek government and the troika? (No bargaining if the troika basically says no concessions.) Most discussion is framed in terms of what happens to the debt. But as both Daniel Davies and James Galbraith point out  with very different de facto value judgments, but never mind for now  at this point Greek debt, measured as a stock, is not a very meaningful number. After all, the great bulk of the debt is now officially held, the interest rate bears little relationship to market prices, and the interest payments come in part out of funds lent by the creditors. In a sense the debt is an accounting fiction; its whatever the governments trying to dictate terms to Greece decide to say it is.

title: Not Dressed to Impress, and Running Into a High School Classmate
description: IM lucky enough to have a lot of friends all around the world, which makes business travel kind of fun. Ive been flying my entire career, and now as chief executive of Maxifier, an advertising technology company, Im traveling as much as ever.

title: For Students (and Some Adults), School Cancellation in New York Comes as Welcome News
description: They are perhaps the three sweetest words to a young persons ear: School is canceled. And this week, students in New York City were able to savor the cheerful news further in advance than usual.

title: Oklahoma Asks Supreme Court to Delay Executions
description: Oklahoma officials asked the United States Supreme Court on Monday to stay the execution of three inmates on death row until the court rules on the constitutionality of the states lethal injection process. The court agreed on Friday to decide a case on the constitutionality of the new combinations of drugs that some states are using to execute prisoners, which critics say cause intense suffering.

title: His Heart and a Coachs Advice Take a World Cup Star Abroad
description: LONDON  DeAndre Yedlin had modest plans for New Years Eve 2013. He went to his mothers house in Seattle. He watched some fireworks on television. He went to sleep.

title: The Supreme Court Meets the Real World
Egyptian Is Convicted of Genital Mutilation
description: CAIRO  A court on Monday handed down what officials said was Egypts first criminal conviction for the practice of female genital mutilation, sentencing a doctor to more than two years of hard labor for committing manslaughter while performing the procedure on a 13-year-old girl.

title: Marcus Borg, Liberal Scholar on Historical Jesus, Dies at 72
description: Marcus J. Borg, a scholar who popularized a liberal intellectual approach to Christianity with his lectures and books about Jesus as a historical figure, died on Wednesday at his home in Powell Butte, Ore. He was 72.

title: With New Confidence, Rangers Reanimate Power Play
description: The Rangers oft-derided power play  a source of frustration through the regime of their former coach John Tortorella and during Alain Vigneaults first season behind the bench  is now a source of confidence as the team heads into the second half of the season.

title: Investment Riches Built on Subprime Auto Loans to Poor
description: The loans were for used Dodges, Nissans and Chevrolets, many with tens of thousands of miles on the odometer, some more than a decade old.

title: Killing of Protester Prompts Rare Criticism From Egyptian State Newspaper
description: The killing of Shaimaa al-Sabbagh, a peaceful protester whose body was riddled with shotgun pellets on Saturday in Cairo, was condemned in an unusually frank editorial published Monday on the front page of Al Ahram, the flagship state newspaper in Egypt, and signed by its chairman, Ahmed Sayed el-Naggar.

title: Islanders Kyle Okposo Is Sidelined
description: Kyle Okposo, the Islanders top-line right wing, will be sidelined for six to eight weeks with an upper-body injury. The team announced no further details on the injury.

title: S.E.C. Has Yet to Set Rule on Tricky Ratio of C.E.O.s Pay to Workers
description: Last week, we learned that Timothy D. Cook, Apples chief executive, was paid $9.2 million for 2014. Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase made $20 million. The Starbucks chief Howard Schultz took home $21.5 million. And Viacom said that its chief, Philippe Dauman, received $44.3 million.

title: Decades After Sit-In, South Carolina Seeks to Make Things Right
description: ROCK HILL, S.C.  Clarence H. Graham has been known by many titles in his hometown: Honor student. Vietnam veteran. Social worker. Father. And criminal, for an act that is now considered heroic.

title: Seahawks Dismiss Talk of Dynasty and Focus on Task at Hand
description: PHOENIX  Asked to face the news media for a second time before the New England Patriots even landed here, the Seattle Seahawks found themselves discussing the possibility of becoming a dynasty on Sunday by winning Super Bowl XLIX and becoming the ninth team to repeat as champions.

title: U.S. and India Share Sense of Unease Over China
description: NEW DELHI  When President Obama landed here for a three-day visit, he brought a long list of issues to discuss, like energy and trade. But when he and Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India sat down to talk, the first 45 minutes were dominated by just one: China.

title: Phoenix Open May End With Scramble to Super Bowl Stadium
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  One of the New England Patriots most ardent fans is in town this week. The twist is that it is a business trip for him.

title: Israel: Dissident Reservists Dismissed
description: The military on Monday terminated the service of 43 reservists from an elite intelligence unit who in September signed a letter refusing to participate in actions against Palestinians for moral reasons. The letter by veterans of the clandestine Unit 8200 claimed that its work harmed innocent people, amounted to political persecution, and made it more difficult to resolve the underlying conflict. The military said that the refusal violated its standards and morals, and questioned why the complaint was aired publicly rather than through the chain of command. The military views with great severity any attempt to elude mandatory military service especially when the act is intended to make a political statement, its statement said. A leader of the reservists group, speaking on the condition of anonymity because the military prohibits members of 8200 from being identified publicly, said the army is trying to make the issues that we were trying to raise go away by making us go away.

title: Argentine Leader Attacks Spy Agency Amid Furor Over Prosecutors Death
description: BUENOS AIRES  With her government badly shaken over the mysterious death of a prosecutor investigating the 1994 bombing of a Jewish center, President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner said in a televised speech on Monday night that she would immediately send a bill to Congress to dissolve the nations premier intelligence agency.

title: Senate Democrats Delay G.O.P. Attempt to Force Keystone Vote
description: Senate Democrats on Monday successfully delayed Republican efforts to force a vote on a bill to approve construction of the Keystone XL oil pipeline.

title: Pace of Deals Picks Up at Sundance Festival
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Distributors are snapping up Sundance movies with a fervor not seen in years, a reflection of the quality of this years lineup and the improving economics  fueled by video on demand  of independent film.

title: Budget Office Slashes Estimated Cost of Health Coverage
description: WASHINGTON  The Congressional Budget Office on Monday significantly lowered its estimate of the cost of providing health insurance coverage to millions of Americans under the Affordable Care Act.

title: Gotham Recap: A Victory for Good, With Help From a Thug
description: Season 1, Episode 13, Welcome Back, Jim Gordon

title: Instagram Photos From the Snowstorm
description: Readers share their images of the snow.

title: Nissan Plans 1,000 New Stations to Quickly Charge Electric Cars
description: WASHINGTON  Nissan said it would help open about 1,000 high-speed charging stations for electric vehicles between now and April 2016.

title: Plan to Protect Refuge Has Alaskans Offended and Fearful Over Money
description: ANCHORAGE  Bitter reaction here to the Obama administrations proposal to protect a huge portion of the Arctic goes beyond political divisions over oil and environmental policy, to questions about how Alaskans are perceived and respected in their sometimes awkward long-distance relationship with the rest of the nation, residents and political leaders say.

title: Fired Fox Employee Kills Himself Outside News Corp. Building
description: Near the entrance to the News Corporation building on Avenue of the Americas in Midtown Manhattan, a Texas man quietly passed out small protest cards to employees arriving to work through falling snow on Monday morning.

title: Saudi Succession Hints at Shift in Foreign Role
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Prince Mohammed bin Nayef, the interior minister of Saudi Arabia, arrived at a meeting of security chiefs from across the Arab world in Marrakesh, Morocco, last March to deliver a call to arms: It was time, he declared, for a concerted effort to eradicate the Muslim Brotherhood, according to two Arab officials briefed on the meeting.

title: U.S. Aid Agency Suspends Group From New Contracts
description: WASHINGTON  The United States Agency for International Development announced Monday that it had suspended one of its largest contractors, International Relief and Development, a nonprofit group based in Virginia, because of questions over oversight of its spending.

title: Times Squares Crushing Success Raises Questions About Its Future
description: The Crossroads of the World has never been more popular. And that is becoming a problem.

title: A Nigerian City, Long Under Siege, Survives an Audacious Militant Assault
description: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria  It was the kind of onslaught many feared.

title: WikiLeaks Assails Google and the U.S.
description: Lawyers acting for WikiLeaks and its fugitive editor, Julian Assange, said Monday that they were exploring possible legal action against the American government and Google over the seizure of emails and other data belonging to three of the whistle-blowing organizations journalists. A lawyer for WikiLeaks, Michael Ratner, told journalists in Geneva that the group had written on Monday to Googles chairman, Eric Schmidt, and to American officials demanding details and explanations for search and seizure warrants issued to Google by the Department of Justice in March 2012. In response to the warrants, Google turned over to law enforcement authorities all data associated with the accounts of the journalists, Mr. Ratner said. WikiLeaks said it was astonished and disturbed that Google had waited more than two and a half years to notify the journalists that the authorities had issued the warrants, denying them the opportunity to oppose them in court. A Google spokesman said that its policy was to inform people about government requests for their data except in limited cases, like when we are gagged by a court order, which sadly happens quite often.

title: Treatment of Overdose Will Cost Cities Less
description: The Clinton Foundation on Monday announced that it had negotiated a lower price for an emergency treatment that can prevent overdoses with a company that makes it. The soaring cost of the treatment has constrained its widespread use by municipalities across the country.

title: One Who Gives a Hoot
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  Oh, hey there! James Tuttle is back, and hes offering us a variety of roh sounds spelled in different ways. This will be another quick one, since were battening down the hatches here for the winter snowpocalypse.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 26, 2015
Joan Riverss Daughter Files Malpractice Suit Against Manhattan Clinic
description: The anesthesiologist was getting nervous.

title: Reid Is Home After Surgery for Injuries
description: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada was back at his home in Washington on Monday after surgery for injuries sustained in an exercise accident on Jan. 1. Mr. Reid, the Senates Democratic leader, was sitting in his living room with Mrs. Reid, cracking jokes and asking about the whip count for this evenings vote on the Keystone pipeline legislation, his office said. Doctors removed a blood clot from Mr. Reids right eye and repaired bones in his face, his office said. The surgery took three and a half hours, and Mr. Reid was under full anesthesia. Doctors say they are hopeful that he will regain sight in the eye. Mr. Reid is expected to monitor Senate business from home this week.

title: Sal Polisi, Master Woodcarver at South Street Seaport Museum, Dies at 79
description: Sal Polisi spent his life awash in mermaids.

title: Good Night, New York: Quiet Streets After a Harried Commute
description: New York City came to a quiet standstill early Tuesday as heavier bands of snow blanketed the region.

title: White House to Propose Allowing Oil Drilling Off Atlantic Coast
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Tuesday will announce a proposal to open up coastal waters from Virginia to Georgia for oil and gas drilling, according to a person briefed on the plan.

title: Edgar Froese, Adventurous Leader of Tangerine Dream, Dies at 70
description: Edgar Froese, the leader of the long-running and prolific German group Tangerine Dream  first an improvising avant-garde rock band, then an ambient electronic-music project, and finally an arena-filling machine of smooth and heroic synthesizer pulsations  died on Jan. 20 in Vienna. He was 70.

title: Government Declassifies 2007 Surveillance Court Rulings
description: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit, the government has declassified two previously Top Secret rulings from May and August 2007 by Judge Roger Vinson of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court. The disclosure filled in a missing link in the history of the evolving legality of the Bush administrations warrantless surveillance program. The government previously declassified key rulings from January 2007 and April 2007revealing an internal dispute on the court as the Bush administration struggled to put the program on a firmer legal footing. Congress legalized the program with the Protect America Act in August 2007, ending the efforts to fit it into the existing Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act.

title: Robert Kraft Defends Patriots Amid Uproar Over Deflated Footballs
description: CHANDLER, Ariz.  A visibly angry Robert K. Kraft made a surprise appearance Monday night during the New England Patriots news media availability, reading a statement defending Coach Bill Belichick, quarterback Tom Brady and the organization.

title: Word of the Day | euthanasia
description: euthanasia \y-th-na-zh(e-)\ noun

title: Top Officials Join Obama in Brief Visit to Saudi King
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  President Obama met with King Salman of Saudi Arabia on Tuesday, leading a bipartisan delegation of prominent current and former officials to shore up an important relationship and offer condolences for the death of King Abdullah.

title: Gas, Still Not as Cheap as It Used to Be
description: The decline in gasoline prices over the past four months has been sharp and surprising. But for Americans wondering why their family budgets still feel strained, part of the answer is almost as surprising:

title: Documents Show N.S.A.s Wiretap Moves Before Congresss Approval
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge ruled in 2007 that the U.S.A. Patriot Act empowered the National Security Agency to collect foreigners emails and phone calls from domestic networks without prior judicial approval, newly declassified documents show.

title: Amazon Investigated in Japan Over Child Pornography
description: HONG KONG  Amazon.coms Japan unit has said that it is cooperating with the local authorities in an investigation into whether child pornography has been sold on its website.

title: Whats on TV Tuesday
description: 7:30 P.M. (Starz Cinema) IN DARKNESS (2011) A Polish sewer worker and sometime thief (Robert Wieckiewicz) and his young sidekick (Krzysztof Skonieczny) discover a group of Jews who have taken refuge from the Nazis in the underground waterways of Lvov and decide to help them  first as a business proposition, and then out of moral obligation  in this dramatization of real-life events by the director Agnieszka Holland. The visual contrast between the worlds above and below ground is handled beautifully and evocatively, and it gives In Darkness the dreamlike quality of a fairy tale, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this Oscar nominee for best foreign-language film. It is not a bad movie, he added. It is touching, warm and dramatically satisfying. But that, given the subject matter, is exactly the problem.

title: Tomas Berdych Keeps Nerve in Lopsided Win Over Rafael Nadal
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Rafael Nadal has always seemed to enjoy the chase more than the trophy, which may be why he is always biting his trophies.

title: Maria Sharapova Romps Into Australian Open Semifinals
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  After some unflinching words from her family, Maria Sharapova has been relentless on her opponents.

description: FRONT PAGE

title: British Begin Inquiry Into Death of Ex-K.G.B. Officer
description: LONDON  Offering new details after years of official silence, a public inquiry into the death of Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. officer and vitriolic critic of the Kremlin, opened on Tuesday with a lawyer for his widow saying that the trail of evidence would lead directly to the door of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

title: The Yale Student and the Policeman

title: Is Vaping Worse Than Smoking?
description: So I suppose you heard about the latest e-cigarette study, the one that said that the vapors e-cigarette users inhale contain multiple forms of formaldehyde. It was much in the news last week, after its authors, five scientists from Portland State University, published a peer-reviewed letter outlining their findings in the prestigious New England Journal of Medicine.

title: How to Leave a Mark
description: The big debate during the 20th century was about the relationship between the market and the state. Both those institutions are now tarnished. The market is prone to devastating crashes and seems to be producing widening inequality. Government is gridlocked, sclerotic or captured by special interests. Government is an ever more rigid and ineffective tool to address market failures.

title: President Obama Protects a Valued Wilderness
description: The Arctic National Wildlife Refuge covers only a small part of Alaska. Smaller still is the coastal plain of the refuge, a narrow, 1.5 million-acre strip flanking the Beaufort Sea. The plain is an ecological and biological wonder, the hunting grounds for Alaskan natives and home to caribou, polar bears, all manner of marine life and countless bird species. It may also contain one of the biggest unexploited oil fields in America.

title: The Humane Death Penalty Charade
description: When the United States at last abandons the abhorrent practice of capital punishment, the early years of the 21st century will stand out as a peculiar period during which otherwise reasonable people hotly debated how to kill other people while inflicting the least amount of constitutionally acceptable pain.

title: Investing in Our Future at Community Colleges
description: To the Editor:

title: Save the New Ukraine
description: A NEW Ukraine was born a year ago in the pro-European protests that helped to drive President Viktor F. Yanukovych from power. And today, the spirit that inspired hundreds of thousands to gather in the Maidan, Kievs Independence Square, is stronger than ever, even as it is under direct military assault from Russian forces supporting separatists in eastern Ukraine.

title: Q. and A.: Luigi Tomba on Privatized Housing and Political Legitimacy in China
description: Luigi Tomba, 49, is the associate director of the Australian Center on China in the World at the Australian National University in Canberra. In his new book, The Government Next Door: Neighborhood Politics in Urban China, Mr. Tomba, a native of Italy who first went to China in 1988, challenges the conventional wisdom that a property-owning middle class is helping to foster civil society in China. Instead, his research leads him to conclude that the privatization of housing has strengthened the grip of the Communist Party.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Learning from Animal Friendships
description: In Learning From Animal Friendships, Erica Goode writes about how some interspecies relationships might merit scientific research.

title: Dentons to Merge With Dacheng of China to Create Worlds Largest Law Firm
description: HONG KONG  The multinational law firm Dentons announced on Tuesday that it would merge with the Dacheng Law Offices of China, creating a firm with the worlds largest number of lawyers.

title: Aer Lingus Receptive to Latest Offer From Parent of British Airways
description: LONDON  Aer Lingus said on Tuesday that its board of directors would be willing to recommend that shareholders accept the latest takeover bid from the parent of British Airways, valued at about $1.5 billion, if certain conditions were met, paving the way for potential deal.

title: Siemens Profit Down 25% on Weak Economy and Lower Oil Prices
description: FRANKFURT  Siemens, the German engineering and electronics company, said on Tuesday that profit fell 25 percent in its first quarter as sales to the energy industry slumped, a sign of falling fuel prices having repercussions beyond the main oil-producing countries.

title: As Visit Ends, Obama Presses India on Human Rights and Climate Change
description: NEW DELHI  President Obama concluded his three-day trip here Tuesday with a tough-love message to his hosts, as he vowed to be Indias best partner in taking its place in the ranks of the worlds great powers but urged it to do more to protect human rights and fight climate change.

title: I.P.O. Could Value Sunrise Communications of Switzerland at $3.7 Billion
description: LONDON  Sunrise Communications, one of the largest telecommunications companies in Switzerland, said on Tuesday that an initial public offering this year could value its recently formed holding company at up to 3.3 billion Swiss francs, or about $3.7 billion.

title: What Would You Do on a Snow Day?
description: Officials from New York City warned that the winter storm bearing down on the region this week could be one of the most powerful blizzards ever recorded. That might well mean a snow day for millions of students from New Jersey to Maine.

title: Staying Put and Bearing Witness to the Holocaust
description: While recent terror attacks and anti-Semitism have led a growing number of French Jews to flee to Israel, another European Jewish community is determined to stay put, and has been for a long time.

title: Psychotherapy as a Kind of Art
description: On the day, some decades ago, that I sent off the manuscript of what would become my sixth published book, I was suddenly possessed  there is no other word  by the desire to leave this world, and to do so by stepping in front of an oncoming bus. I walked to the edge of the sidewalk, stepped down, hesitated, let the bus go by, and decided to go home, where, if one of my children, then ages 4, 2 and 1, defied me in any way, I imagined picking that child up and throwing the child against a wall or through a window.

title: On the Greek Election
description: Left-wing party Syriza has promised to renegotiate Greeces debt.

description: It was an unprecedented step for what became, in New York City, a common storm: For the first time in its 110-year history, the subway system was shut down because of snow.

title: Gomorrah: Italys Criminally Great TV Show
description: NAPLES, Italy  Gomorrah, which recounts the exploits of the fictional Savastanos crime family, is Italys all-time most popular TV series. And it is starting to go global: Twelve of the first episodes have already been sold for broadcast in 50 countries. Gomorrah will tell world viewers a great story. But what will it tell them about Italy itself?

description: The great blizzard of 2015 did not turn out to be a blizzard in New York City. Only 7.8 inches had fallen in Central Park as of 7 a.m. and not much more after that.

description: PARIS  It was day two at Haute Couture, and Natalie Portman was beaming. She was sitting in the front row at the Dior show, on the grounds of the Muse Rodin in Paris.

title: Airlines Suspend Flights to Iraqs Baghdad Airport After Jet Is Hit by Gunfire
description: BAGHDAD  A commercial jet carrying 154 passengers was struck by gunfire as it landed at Baghdad International Airport, officials said Tuesday, adding to fears that Iraqs most important transportation hub remains vulnerable to militant attacks.

title: Thom Browne and Saint Laurent, Paired but Oh So Different
description: PARIS  Thom Browne and Hedi Slimane, two designers with almost nothing in common, were once again linked on Sunday by a scheduling coincidence that placed their shows back-to-back, the two final rounds in the mens wear fashion marathon that just concluded here.

description: Long overshadowed by its rival Alibaba, JD.com has emerged as Chinas other online goliath by carving out its own distinct identity, David Barboza reports.

title: Apologies All Around After Watch Is Presented as Gift in Taiwan
description: Guides to Chinese business etiquette often carry a reminder to never give a timepiece as a gift. The phrase giving a clock, or , sounds in Mandarin too much like paying ones last respects to the deceased, and the act of it is one of a few taboos based on Chinese pronunciation.

title: In Reprieve to Obama, Senate Democrats Agree to Wait on Iran Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON  Ten Senate Democrats who have advocated putting more sanctions on Iran gave the White House a two-month reprieve on Tuesday, saying they would wait until after the late-March deadline for completing the outlines of a deal to restrain Tehrans nuclear program before voting for a bill that President Obama has said would undermine any chance of reaching an agreement.

title: Chanel: Spring 2015 Couture

title: Morning Agenda: Subprime Auto Loans Spun Into Gold
description: Across the country, there is a booming business in lending to poor people with bad credit who need cars to get to work. But this market is as much about Wall Streets perpetual demand for high returns as it is about used cars, DealBooks Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg report. An influx of investor money is making more loans possible, but all that money may also be enabling excessive risk-taking that could have repercussions throughout the financial system.

title: Officer Shoots Man Holding Woman at Knife Point in Lower Manhattan, Police Say
description: A police officer shot a man at an apartment in Lower Manhattan early on Tuesday after the man threatened a woman with a knife, officials said.

title: Storm That Glanced at Region Hit Hard in New England
description: BOSTON  The projected epic storm that failed to deliver in New York City instead turned its full fury on eastern New England on Tuesday, unleashing howling winds that created whiteout conditions across the region and upended life on Nantucket, where virtually everyone lost power as well as all methods of modern communications.

title: Group Linked to ISIS Says Its Behind Assault on Libyan Hotel

Muammar el-Qaddafi more than three years ago.

title: Close but Not Quite
description: As a colleague said in pointing out a couple of these recent lapses in word choice, sometimes on deadline we seem to grab the first word we think of, not necessarily the best. With language as with facts, precision should be our hallmark.

title: In Performance: Jonny Donahoe of Every Brilliant Thing
description: This weeks video features a scene from Every Brilliant Thing, a solo show starring the British comic Jonny Donahoe as a son who comes up with a huge list of reasons why his depressed and suicidal mother should continue living. The show, written by Duncan Macmillan (with Mr. Donahoe) and directed by George Perrin, continues through March 29 at the Barrow Street Theater.
