title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: Indonesian Military Halts Search for Victims of AirAsia Crash
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Indonesias armed forces on Tuesday officially halted the search for passengers on the AirAsia plane that crashed into the Java Sea last month, killing all 162 people aboard.

title: The Debt Non-Spiral
description: Amid all the other economic news, the CBO has issued its latest budget projections. According to the projections, the US deficit will soon stop shrinking and begin to rise again. Cue the Very Serious People, who are deeply distressed at the failure of the promised fiscal crisis to materialize; Im sure well see editorials and op-eds in the next few days warning us that the deficit is still public enemy #1.

title: 1965 U.K. Says Farewell to Churchill
description: LONDON  Britain began its long and sad farewell to Sir Winston Churchill today. Just as Big Ben pealed 11 a.m., the great door of St. Stephen at Westminster hall swung wide.

title: Paris Takes Pains to Reassure Tourists
description: A throng of visitors huddled outside LAs du Fallafel on the Rue des Rosiers, braving the cold for a taste of the legendary restaurants takeout shawarma and chickpea fritters. Around them, people jammed onto the narrow cobbled street, dressed in bright scarves, arms loaded with shopping bags and cameras.

title: Roman Architecture, Beyond the Colosseum
description: For people who love contemporary architecture, trying to find striking new buildings in the historic center of Rome is about as easy as trying to go gluten-free there. But if you move a little farther out  or a lot  there are stunning treasures to find, from museums to stadiums to churches, not to mention animated new neighborhoods that you probably would have never explored in the first place.

title: Twitter Adds Group Messaging and Video Recording
description: Faced with slow growth in new users and usage by existing users, Twitter executives repeatedly promised improvements to make the social network more inviting.

title: The Tyranny of Greece Over Germany
description: No, I havent lost my mind. Thats the title of a classic book by Eliza Marian Butler arguing that German culture was warped by an obsession with ancient Greece, which has nothing at all to do with the current problems of macroeconomic policy. But the title came to mind when I read Simon Wren-Lewiss meditation on two different hypotheses about the disastrous 2010 turn to austerity. One hypothesis, as he says, is that it was just bad luck: Greece blew up at the end of 2009, and false analogies with Greece soon dominated policy debate; you can call this Hellenization of discourse the tyranny of Greece, not so much over Germany, as over the OECD as a whole.

title: Weekly News Quiz | Jan. 20-26, 2015

title: Totally Prepared. Still Freaking Out.
description: When my wife, Rachel, got off the phone with the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) on Jan. 19, after her usual morning check in on how Evy was doing  we visit her in the afternoons to be clear of doctors rounds, which would keep us in the hallway and not by Evys side  her voice had a mixture of amazement, pride and fear, the verbal equivalent of turning white when scared.

title: S.E.C. Faces Challenges Over the Constitutionality of Some of Its Court Proceedings

title: Marriage of Convenience
description: Of the many gay and lesbian couples fighting for the right to marry in the courts, April DeBoer and Jayne Rowse are listed first in the case that the Supreme Court will hear this spring. DeBoer and Rowse, who live in Hazel Park, Mich., want to marry so they can both be adoptive parents to the four children they are raising together. The women, both nurses, stagger their hospital shifts so they can take turns at home with the kids, ages 2 to 6, two of whom have special needs.

title: Lyft, Now in Talks for More Funding, Pushes Growth Strategy
description: Lyft, the popular ride-hailing start-up, is nowhere near as large as Uber, its top competitor. That certainly has not stopped Lyft from trying to catch up.

description: Hillary Rodham Clintons presumed 2016 presidential campaign is already drawing a lot of criticism. That may not be a surprise. But Amy Chozick, a political reporter, is finding that the attacks against Mrs. Clinton have a new angle. She describes the challenge of reporting fairly on this subtle shift and what it may mean.

The exchange added to already heightened tensions along a once-quiet frontier that has been increasingly destabilized by the Syrian civil war.

On April 18 hell present the North American premiere of the Wild Man Dance Suite in the Temple of Dendur at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: A Data-Science Lender Takes on Student Debt
description: Louis Beryl insists that financially responsible young people are the borrowers most disadvantaged by the traditional math of consumer lending. The standard scoring of creditworthiness relies largely on a persons credit history, and thats a blunt instrument. Since young people have slender credit histories, he said, they pay higher rates than they should.

Now he was headed out again  with chicken madras, chicken poori and an order of lemon rice  on a longer trip to Greenpoint.

description: A compilation of scenes from Boston; Providence, R.I.; and other areas as a winter storm barreled through the region Monday night into Tuesday.

title: White House Drone Crash Described as a U.S. Workers Drunken Lark
description: WASHINGTON  It was 42 degrees and raining lightly around 3 a.m. on Monday when an inebriated off-duty employee for a government intelligence agency decided it was a good time to fly his friends drone, a 2-foot-by-2-foot quadcopter that sells for hundreds of dollars and is popular among hobbyists.

title: Most New York Theaters and Concert Halls Will Reopen Tuesday
description: The shows are going on. With this weeks snowstorm a bust (at least in most of New York City), Broadway producers and theater owners announced that most plays and musicals would hold their regularly scheduled Tuesday evening performances. Disneys two Broadway musicals, The Lion King and Aladdin, have been canceled, a decision producers made on Monday amid grim weather forecasts and the state of emergency declared by government officials. Both shows are offering refunds for Tuesday nights shows.

title: Cuomo: Travel Ban Lifted in New York
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, in coordination with nearby states leaders, reopened roads and mass transit services in New York after a predicted destructive storm in the region failed to materialize.

title: Paris Couture Week: Chanel Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: Jordan Hostage Crisis May Hurt U.S. Ties
description: AMMAN, Jordan  In the hostage crisis unfolding in Jordan, the countrys so-far steadfast support for the American-led coalition fighting the Islamic State may yet become collateral damage.

title: Jams to Join the California Cooking Comeback
description: Headliner

title: The Storm in New York on Instagram
description: As the late-January storm approached the city, some New Yorkers rushed home and then frolicked in the snow.

title: Drones at the White House. And in Yemen.
description: On Monday a C.I.A. drone strike in Yemen killed three suspected Qaeda fighters. Then on Tuesday President Obama called for the regulation of unmanned aircraft.

title: Snowstorm Hits New England
description: High winds and whiteout conditions swept across New England.

title: 1915: Indian Receives Victoria Cross
description: LONDON  At Buckingham Palace, yesterday, King George conferred the Victoria Cross on Sepoy Khudadad Khan, the first Indian soldier to earn the coveted distinction. Khudadad Khan, or the 129th Duke of Connaughts Own Baluchis, was the sole survivor of a gallant machine-gun team, who on October 30 heroically fought to the last, every man being bayoneted at his post. Though badly wounded, Khudadad Khan managed some time afterward to rejoin his company, but never left his gun until he had rendered it useless to the enemy.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 28, 1915

title: Did New York Overreact to the 2015 Blizzard?
description: The winter storm once predicted to drop two feet or moreof snow on New York City actually left only around eightinches as of early Tuesday morning, leading some to wonder if precautions like shutting down the New York subways were misplaced. Is preparing too much for such storms better than preparing too little  or are some kinds of preparations themselves dangerous?

title: Yahoo Could Sell Its Alibaba Shares Without a Big Tax Bill
description: Tuesday could be one of the biggest moments of Marissa Mayers two-and-a-half-year career as chief executive, as Yahoo is expected to unveil its strategy to sell off its remaining stake in the Alibaba Group of China.

title: North Carolinas Food Sisterhood
description: Beyond restaurants, women run the states pre-eminent pasture-raised meats and organic produce distribution businesses and preside over its farmers markets.

title: The North Carolina Way
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  Back in the 1970s, when Nathalie Dupree and Shirley Corriher were cooking together in Atlanta, they wanted to avoid the kind of relationship in which competition slides into rancor.

title: Chris Brown Postpones Tour
description: The Chris Brown drama continues.

title: Sundance 2015: The Strange Tale of an Amputated Leg, Brought to You by Kickstarter
description: PARK CITY, Utah  At least 17 films playing at Sundance were made possible by Kickstarter, including the raw-edged James White, about a reckless man (Christopher Abbott) and his cancer-stricken mother (Cynthia Nixon).

title: Scott Walker Starts Committee; Step Toward Presidential Run
description: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin has taken a further step toward running for the Republican presidential nomination in 2016, creating a committee called Our American Revival to help him spread his message and pay for campaign-related activities around the country in advance of an official announcement.

title: Fidel Castro Shares Views on Warming of Relations
description: MEXICO CITY  Fidel Castro has ended his silence of almost six weeks over the deal to restore diplomatic relations between the United States and Cuba, writing in a letter that he supported a peaceful end to conflict but still distrusted American politics.

title: Obamas Plan: Allow Drilling in Atlantic, but Limit It in Arctic
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration moved Tuesday to open up a vast stretch of East Coast waters to oil and gas drilling, a decision that could have a profound impact on the economic and environmental future of states from Virginia to Georgia. The move also adds a new dimension to the legacy of President Obama.

title: How 2014s Huge Market Moves Are Affecting the Economy in 2015
description: Global financial markets made a series of epic moves in the second half of 2014: toward a sharply lower price of oil, much lower interest rates, and a far stronger dollar.

title: Senate Democrats, Bowing to Obama, Put Off Iran Vote
description: A group of Senate Democrats who had been pushing for legislation to impose new sanctions on Iran said Tuesday that they would hold off on a vote until late March.

title: Sheldon Silver Should Resign Already
description: Political etiquette, what there is of it, decrees that after getting arrested, a politician should step down. But New York Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver has spent the last few days trying to hang on despite the serious corruption charges leveled against him last week.

title: Trying to Lose Her Fashion Inhibitions
description: Dear Diary:

title: Paris Couture Week: Bouchra Jarrar Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

title: Sheldon Silver to Be Replaced as Speaker of New York State Assembly
description: ALBANY  Sheldon Silver, who faces federal corruption charges, is being replaced as speaker of the New York State Assembly next week, Democratic lawmakers said on Tuesday, paving the way for them to choose a new leader in an election to be held Feb. 10.

title: Shutting Down New Yorks Subways Is Very Expensive
description: Monday night, for the first time in the 110-year history of New York Citys subways, the system was shut down for a snowstorm. Tuesday morning, with eight inches of snow on the ground in Central Park as of 7 a.m., that decision is looking pretty unnecessary.

title: Houthis Blame Separatists in Yemen for Stalemate
description: SANA, Yemen  The Houthi rebel group that has seized control of Yemens capital said on Tuesday that separatist forces in the south were responsible for the impasse preventing an end to the political crisis convulsing the country.

title: Not the Same, but Playing as One
description: Seahawks Coach Pete Carroll and running back Marshawn Lynch grew up in vastly different circumstances in the Bay Area but became one of the N.F.L.s most productive pairings.

title: The Super Bowls Perfect Odd Couple
description: The ranch-style house where Pete Carroll grew up sits on a suburban cul-de-sac near San Francisco in Marin County, one of the wealthiest counties in the country. It was a gathering place for friends, with a pool table inside and football games out front. The door was always open.

title: Missing: Bare-Chested Celtic God, Last Seen in Northern Ireland
description: DUBLIN  The police in Northern Ireland, tongues firmly in cheek, have issued a missing-person appeal to the public after a statue of a Celtic god of the sea was stolen from a remote mountainside.

title: Not a Blizzard, But Still Pretty
description: Time-lapse videos of the January snowstorm in New York City.

title: Netanyahu Talk Stirs Backlash in Israeli Race
description: Michael B. Oren, who spent four years as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahus ambassador to Washington, has called on Mr. Netanyahu to cancel his speech to Congress about Iran. Amos Yadlin, a former military intelligence chief who frequently briefed the Israeli prime minister on security matters, denounced the event as irresponsible.

title: Mormon Church Wants Freedom to Discriminate
description: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints held a rare news conference in Salt Lake City today that is drawing headlines about a supposedly new, accommodating stand on gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender rights.

title: Martin Brodeur Is Set to Retire, but He Will Stay With Blues
description: Last April, goalie Martin Brodeur won his final game in a Devils jersey, and he saluted the Prudential Center crowd after it serenaded him with a Mar-ty! chant.

title: Not a Blizzard, but Still Pretty
description: Time-lapse videos of the January snowstorm in New York City.

title: An Artist Whose Signature Style Is a Lack of One
description: When Parker Ito was growing up in Seal Beach, a small city in Orange County, California, he watched David Copperfield DVDs assiduously. He dreamed of being a magician. Then, I wanted to be a professional skateboarder, the artist, 28, said from a folding chair set atop the barren rooftop of his Los Angeles studio in the El Sereno neighborhood. It was a few weeks before his new, knotty multimedia show, A Lil Taste of Cheeto in the Night, would open in a 7,800-square-foot warehouse in Downtown Los Angeles, adjacent to Chteau Shatto, the gallery co-owned by Itos girlfriend and art dealer, Liv Barrett.

title: Netanyahu Defends Speech to Congress
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel defended his coming speech before Congress about Iran after critics accused him of trying to win an election scheduled two weeks after the trip.

title: North End Grill and Blue Smoke
description: New chefs helm the kitchens at these Danny Meyers Union Square Hospitality Group restaurants.

title: Restaurant Review: Blue Smoke and North End Grill
description: If you hooked a seismograph to Danny Meyers Union Square Hospitality Group, the readout for most of the last two decades would be boringly predictable. Regular spikes would indicate the orderly arrival of restaurants, with just a few aberrant tremors here and there: the closure of Tabla and, very rarely, a change of chef.

title: Aer Lingus Deal Could Spur Airline Consolidation in Europe
description: PARIS  The European airline industry is one of the biggest in the world, on par with that of the United States. But with more than 150 carriers vying for 800 million passengers each year, Europe is also the worlds most fragmented and least profitable airline market.

title: Poetic Voice Wrapped Tight in Its Shifting Politics
description: There are two ways to rank writers, the poet John Berryman said, in terms of gift and in terms of achievement.

title: A Four-Bedroom House in a Resort Town Near Melbourne
description: Overlooking a golf club and a short walk from the beach, it is on the market for $2.025 million.

description: T shares the best hairstyles from the runways.

title: Snowstorms Forecast Was Mostly Right, Even if It Felt Wrong in New York
description: In the wake of the blizzard that wasnt, New Yorkers on Tuesday were asking how the weather forecasters could have been so wrong.

title: Armani Priv: Spring 2015 Couture
description: Paris

title: A New Zealand Festival Coming to La MaMa
description: The art of sleep, New Zealand gang culture and a man who believes he is the key to putting another Clinton in the White House are among the offerings slated for a new theater festival at LaMaMa in March.

title: Inside a Harvey Weinstein Story:  Reporters Notebook
description: On Friday, Patrick Healy, The Timess theater reporter, wrote about a dispute between the film producer Harvey Weinstein and the Finding Neverland theater publicist Rick Miramontez. He describes the delicate business of getting both sides of a hot-button story.

title: Enticing All to See the Bigger Picture
description: Play enough video games and soon youll start to wonder what it all means. Is there a point?

title: New Yorks Sanitation Commissioner Faced First Major Test
description: Kathryn Garcia stopped by Sanitation Department garages to check on her workers. She stood with Mayor Bill de Blasio to take questions about storm preparations. And she prepared herself for the snow that was threatening New York and would be the first big test of her tenure as the citys sanitation commissioner.

title: The Blizzard of 1888
description: The storm dropped nearly 50 inches of snow in March, bringing New York City to a virtual standstill.

title: Picturing Royalty
description: A look at the work of the painter Kehinde Wiley.

title: Techniques for Robbing a Grave
description: The age-old mystery has at last been solved: Benjamin Franklin was Jack the Ripper.

title: Navigating a Cold War, at Work and at Home
description: The Americans has a deep and discerning sense of irony, which is probably a prerequisite for a series about Soviet spies posing as suburban parents in Reagan-era America. Season 3 of this espionage drama begins on Wednesday on FX, and it may be the most provocative one yet.

title: House Republicans Ready to Resume Fight on Immigration
description: Immigration is heating up (yet again) on Capitol Hill.

title: Firefight Kills 4 in Kashmir
description: NEW DELHI  A colonel in Indias army, a police officer and two militants died Tuesday in a gun battle in Kashmir, the police said. Indian forces had surrounded a house where militants were thought to be visiting, in the Pulwama district of India-administered Kashmir, when the troops were attacked with grenades and Kalashnikov fire. Col. Munindra Nath Rai, a highly decorated officer and commander of the local Indian Army unit, led the operation and was killed. He had been awarded a gallantry medal the day before, Indian news media reported.

title: Convincing and Conniving, a Law Firms Specialty
description: When Suits started three and a half years ago, its premise didnt seem built for the long haul. An entire show built around the idea of a lawyer who has to pretend that he went to Harvard Law School? Something like that worked for Michael J. Fox in The Secret of My Success, but for not quite two hours.

title: Trailer: The Dam Keeper
description: A preview of the film.

title: De Blasio Defends Storm Preparations
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York stressed the importance of heeding warnings though a snowstorm affected the city much less than had been anticipated.

title: A Bolero of Blooms at Chanels Spring/Summer 2015 Couture Presentation
description: Chanels couture shows are known for their elaborate sets, and at this mornings presentation Karl Lagerfeld staged a man-made botanical garden complete with male-model gardeners who watered the set to help the flowers grow. It wasnt surprising, then, that many of the looks that followed incorporated fantastical flora. The collection opened with solid tangerine-and-green skirt suits and blossomed into an exquisite bouquet of embroidered dresses and separates. Some of the girls donned lace eye masks and others grunge-style beanies that lent themselves to the laid-back ease of this bold collection. A standout of the day was this two-piece cobalt look topped with a floral bolero and grounded by flat black leather boots.

title: Yahoo to Spin Off Its Stake in Alibaba
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Marissa Mayer, chief executive of Yahoo, said on Tuesday that the Internet company would spin off its 15.4 percent stake in Alibaba, Chinas leading e-commerce company, into a separate company.

title: Maternity Test
description: What can a pregnant photojournalist cover? Everything.

title: Romney to Be Inducted Into Washingtons Alfalfa Club
description: Mitt Romney may never become president, but he has won admission to at least one exclusive Washington fraternity: the Alfalfa Club.

title: What You Get for ... $1,850,000
description: This weeks properties include an 18th-century house in Connecticut, a 1992 house in Chicago and a midcentury modern in Tucson.

title: Smithsonian Considers Opening London Location
description: The Smithsonian Institution said on Tuesday that it was considering opening a new 40,000-square-foot exhibition space in London in 2021. The move, if it goes ahead, will be the first time in the Smithsonians 168-year history that it has opened a permanent exhibition space outside the United States.

title: In Paris, Reality Collides With Fashion
description: PARIS  What looked to be the worst snowstorm in years was heading toward the Northeast as the mens season drew to a close in Paris. Outside it was a balmy 48 degrees, but the last uncanceled flight to New York on Monday left around 10.

description: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple is famous for setting trends.

title: How Yahoos Spinoff of Its Alibaba Stake Will Work
description: Yahoo finally announced what it will do with its $39 billion stake in the Alibaba Group: spin it off to investors. As I noted earlier, its the simplest way of dealing with shareholder pressure to sell those shares in a tax-efficient manner.

title: Paris Couture Week: Armani Priv Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

title: A Fury Arrives. Hypocrisy, Too.
description: This month, Abderrahmane Sissakos Timbuktu, an official selection in Cannes last year and a current nominee for the best foreign-language film Oscar, was caught up in the aftermath of the Charlie Hebdo murders, when the mayor of a Paris suburb briefly succeeded in banning it from a local cinema. Coming amid an outpouring of public and official support for freedom of speech, this act of censorship was both dismaying and ridiculous.

description: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

title: A Multiplicity of Voices in High-Energy Movement
description: When his troupe turned 30 last year, David Parsons established GenerationNOW, a fellowship for up-and-coming choreographers. On Thursday at the Joyce Theater, Parsons Dance unveiled the first result of that admirable initiative, a world premiere by the former company member Natalie Lomonte, alongside new and old works by Mr. Parsons, Trey McIntyre and another Parsons alumnus, Robert Battle.

title: A New Level of Refugee Suffering
description: KHANKE, Iraq  I HAVE visited Iraq five times since 2007, and I have seen nothing like the suffering Im witnessing now.

title: Los Angeles Opera Season to Open With Domingo Singing Gianni Schicchi
description: Plcido Domingo, the general director of the Los Angeles Opera, plans to open the companys 30th anniversary season in September with a feat few other impresarios could attempt: He will sing the title role in Puccinis one-act opera Gianni Schicchi and then, after the intermission, move down to the orchestra pit to conduct Leoncavallos Pagliacci.

title: Obama Relents on Proposal to End 529 College Savings Plans
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, facing angry reprisals from parents and from lawmakers of both parties, will drop his proposal to effectively end the popular college savings accounts known as 529s, but will keep an expanded tuition tax credit at the center of his college access plan, White House officials said Tuesday.

title: Young, French and Desperate for a Ride Out of Town
description: Its easy for filmmakers and critics alike to confuse artiness with art. As I watched My Name Is Hmmm ..., the feature directing debut of the French fashion designer agns b. (identified here as Agns Troubl), I kept wondering why the story about Cline (Lou-Llia Demerliac), a glum 11-year-old who escapes her sexually abusive father by hiding out in the back of a truck, insists on changing style and texture every few minutes.

title: A Chance to Salvage a Masters Creation
description: Unless county legislators act quickly, a paragon of midcentury American idealism will be lost.

description: What lesson should we draw from the success of Uber?

description: Kosovo and More  Pictures of the Day

title: A Climate Hawk Separates Energy Thought Experiments from Road Maps
description: David Roberts, the progressive environmental blogger who coined the phrase climate hawk, has done the environmental community a great service with a Grist post stressing the difference between a vision of a climate-safe energy future and a strategy for making that vision a reality.

title: Jan. 27, 2015  Photos of the Day
description: Photos from Kosovo, Baghdad, Ukraine and South Korea.

title: The Blizzard That Wasnt
description: In New York City, roads and subways were nearly deserted Tuesday morning, as people woke up to a much lighter snowfall than had been predicted. Some were irritated; others just headed to the park.

title: Pakistan Criticizes Indias Inclusion in Nuclear Suppliers Group
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  In an unusually critical statement, a senior Pakistani official said that Pakistan remained opposed to Indias inclusion in the Nuclear Suppliers Group and feared that the countrys growing nuclear cooperation with the United States could harm deterrence efforts in South Asia.

title: Robbers Crash Into Wells Fargo Museum to Steal Gold Nuggets
description: Three masked robbers smashed a stolen sport utility vehicle into the entrance of Wells Fargos corporate museum in the heart of San Franciscos financial district on Tuesday, then held a security guard at gunpoint and made off with gold nuggets from a display case, the San Francisco police said.

title: Living in Corona, Queens
description: A neighborhood in north-central Queens deemed by the city as having the most heavily Latin American immigrant community in the borough.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: The Gains From the Economic Recovery Are Still Limited to the Top One Percent
description: Its the economic statistic that spawned the Occupy protest movement (We are the 99 percent), reshaped President Obamas domestic program (middle-class economics), and most recently led the eternal Republican presidential hopeful Mitt Romney to bemoan that the rich have gotten richer.

title: Report Sheds Light on Transgender Sex Workers in China
description: When Piao Piao, 26, who was born a boy in Shandong Province, arrived in Beijing in 2008 to live a life as the woman she felt she truly was, she faced innumerable problems. After she began dressing as a woman, while still using official documents that identified her as male, it was difficult for her to find a mainstream job. So she became an entertainer in bars, and supplemented her income as a sex worker.

title: Oil Prices Spectrum of Pain
description: As the price of crude oil fluctuates, why some countries are faring much better than others.

title: On South County, Alabama
description: After moving to Alabama, RaMell Ross began to make photos that redefined his view of a place where history gave way to the routines of everyday life.

title: A Conversation With Kenneth S. Aschendorf
description: Mr. Aschendorf, 52, is a founder and principal of APF Properties, a real estate investment company that specializes in Class B office buildings, mainly in Midtown Manhattan, including the Club Row Building at 28 West 44th Street and 1156 Avenue of the Americas.

title: After Steadily Falling, Price for Gas Notches an Increase
description: HOUSTON  For 123 consecutive days, the AAA motor club reported a daily drop in national gasoline prices, bringing hundreds of dollars of savings to almost every American family. But that streak has now come to an end.

title: Botswana Doctor Is Named to Lead W.H.O. in Africa
description: A defining moment in the life of Dr. Matshidiso Moeti, the World Health Organizations new regional director for Africa, came when she was 9 and her father realized that her little sisters mathematics textbook was below even the level he had studied as a poor child on a South African farm.

title: The Lasting Impacts of Football
description: BERKELEY, CALIF.  As the youngest of Chuck Merceins four children, the actress Jenny Mercein had at least two things going for her. She received constant reminders  an indoctrination, really  that the children of anyone who had played football for Vince Lombardis Green Bay Packers would never, ever quit at anything. And she was Daddys little girl.

title: Recent Commercial Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: We Dodged Icy Doom. Lets Gripe.
description: You cant be a Monday morning quarterback on something like the weather, Bill de Blasio said right after the snow.

title: At the Pump
description: Fuel stations around the world.

title: In DuPont Fight, Activist Investor Picks a Strong Target
description: Shareholder activism is in full roar as hedge funds prowl and companies retreat, but Nelson Peltzs campaign to replace four directors at DuPont may just be where corporate America finally draws the line and tries to stem the activist tide.

title: Sugary Drinks Tied to Earlier Menstruation
description: Here is another mark against sugary drinks: A new study has found that drinking them is associated with lowered age of menarche.

title: A New Chapter for America and India
description: After years of near misses and unfulfilled promises, President Obama and Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India appear to have set relations between their democracies on a deeper, perhaps even revolutionary, path.

title: Yahoo Announces Alibaba Spin-Off
description: Marissa Mayer, Yahoos chief executive, unveiled a plan to spin off Yahoos 15 percent stake in the Chinese e-commerce giant into a separate company in order to avoid a large tax bill.

title: Can Greece's Anti-Austerity Government Succeed?
Lynch to Cast Herself as Departure From Holder in Bid to Be Attorney General
description: WASHINGTON  Loretta E. Lynch on Wednesday will cast herself as an apolitical career prosecutor who is a departure from Eric H. Holder Jr. when she faces a new Republican-controlled Judiciary Committee that includes some of the administrations fiercest critics in Congress.

title: Hostos College in Bronx to Offer a Food Studies Program
description: In an unusual English class at Hostos Community College in the Bronx, students do not immerse themselves in the words of Chaucer, Fitzgerald or Garca Mrquez.

title: Life of Italian Nobility for Sale, Complete With Regulations and Taxes
description: PONTASSIEVE, Italy  Nestled on a gentle Tuscan hill near this town just east of Florence, and caressed by the morning fog, sits a medieval castle that was once home to the few prominent noble families who plotted against the Medicis rule during the Renaissance, some of whom are believed to have taken refuge here.

title: An Event as Wild as Any Game
description: The Seahawks and the Patriots participated in the Super Bowls media day, which included a man wearing a barrel and a brief appearance by Marshawn Lynch.

title: Dog Missing for Months Is Rescued Amid Snowstorm
description: As New York City shut down in anticipation of a fearful snowstorm, a resourceful if hungry gray whippet named Burt approached a pile of canned dog food that rose like a mirage in the snowy expanse of Randalls Island.

title: Health Care Enrollment Appears to Be Near Goal
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Tuesday that 9.5 million people had signed up to receive health coverage through public marketplaces in 2015, with less than a month to go before the enrollment deadline.

title: Ukraine: E.U. Sends Aid to East
description: The European Union delivered three planeloads of aid to eastern Ukraine on Tuesday, including blankets, tents, heaters and warm clothing, as part of a stepped-up effort to help the nearly one million people who have fled their homes in the war-torn region. The planes landed in Dnipropetrovsk, outside the area where pro-Russian separatists are battling the Ukrainian military. The assistance is being delivered by a coalition including Unicef, Save the Children, the World Food Program and People in Need, and is part of more than $53 million in aid pledged by European Union countries. The effort contrasted sharply with Russias unilateral dispatch of convoys to eastern Ukraine in recent months, which drew criticism from the Ukrainian government and the Red Cross over a lack of inspections and participation of international groups. We have not forgotten the population of Ukraine, said Christos Stylianides, the European commissioner for humanitarian assistance, who oversaw the planes arrival. Were in there big time, he added. It is our job to minimize the pain.

title: An Overflow of Memories From Joe Franklins Storied Career
description: Joe Franklins Memory Lane, read the sign nearly buried in an avalanche of ephemera in Room 305, off a nondescript hallway in a Times Square building.

title: Mexico Officially Declares Missing Students Dead
description: MEXICO CITY  Four months after the abduction of 43 rural college students shook the nation and set off a political crisis, Mexicos attorney general on Tuesday officially declared the students dead, saying confessions and forensic evidence supported the theory that their bodies were incinerated near a garbage dump.

title: Mormons Seek Golden Mean Between Gay Rights and Religious Beliefs
description: Mormon leaders tried to stake out a middle ground in the escalating battle between gay rights and religious freedom on Tuesday, demanding that both ideas, together, be treated as a national priority.

title: Myriad Genetics Ending Patent Dispute on Breast Cancer Risk Testing
description: Myriad Genetics has essentially given up trying to stop other companies from offering tests for increased risk of breast cancer, ending a dispute that was the subject of a landmark Supreme Court ruling that human genes cannot be patented.

title: U.S. Strengths Buoy Consumers but Hurt Corporations With Business Abroad
description: What is good for the American consumer may be less so for big American companies.

title: Georgia Executes Warren Lee Hill for Murder
description: ATLANTA  The State of Georgia executed a convicted murderer, Warren Lee Hill, on Tuesday night, ending a prolonged legal fight that led to a series of court-ordered reprieves and frequently tested the states standards for capital punishment.

title: Russian Movie Leviathan Gets Applause in Hollywood but Scorn at Home
description: MOSCOW  In many ways, the movie Leviathan is Russias greatest cinematic accomplishment in years, maybe decades. The Golden Globe winner this month for best foreign film, it provides an unrelenting, vodka-soaked portrait of small-town corruption that has been praised by critics and filmmakers throughout the world  everywhere, it seems, but Russia.

title: Egypt Condemns Western Outrage at Fatal Shooting of Protester
description: Egypts Foreign Ministry expressed dismay on Tuesday that the killing of a female activist in Cairo, which occurred as riot police used force to disperse a peaceful protest, had drawn widespread condemnation from the West.

title: Empire May Provide Fox the Big Hit It Needs
description: Foxs new hip-hop drama Empire is proving to be a platinum property for a network that desperately needed one.

title: Bill Monbouquette, 78, Dies; Pitching Ace When Red Sox Struggled
description: Bill Monbouquette, a stalwart right-handed pitcher for the Boston Red Sox during one of the leaner periods in the history of the franchise, died on Sunday in Boston. He was 78.

title: Leon Brittan, 75, Dies; Quit Thatcher Cabinet in Leak Case
description: LONDON  Leon Brittan, a British politician who rose fast and far in the Margaret Thatcher government, only to see his career crash over a leaked letter in a dispute over a helicopter company, died on Jan. 21 at his home here. He was 75.

title: On Tour, the Stories Keep Getting Weirder
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Toward the end of the state-of-his-game address, Tiger Woods delivered a line that should be appropriated posthaste by the PGA Tour as its catchphrase. Forget These Guys Are Good. Given the headlines illuminating the sport this month, the better slogan would be It Is What It Is.

title: Potential Perry Rivals #StandWithRick on Prosecution
description: Former Gov. Rick Perrys legal problems are not going away anytime soon, but potential Republican rivals  if he runs for president  are standing by his side.

title: One Question for the N.F.L.: Why Insist on a Media Day Charade?
description: PHOENIX  Marshawn Lynch is so polite that he told the dozens of reporters waiting for him on Tuesday at the Super Bowls media day that he was going to snub them before he actually went ahead and did it.

title: Indiana Will Allow Entry to Medicaid for a Price
description: WASHINGTON  After a lengthy back-and-forth, the Obama administration has agreed to let Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana, a Republican, expand Medicaid on his own terms, including some that have not been allowed before under federal rules.

title: System That Powers City Is Shut Down by Threat of Snow
description: Just after 9 a.m. on Tuesday, the No-Show Snow transit system shutdown came to an end, and the first A train rumbled out of the 207th Street terminal. By the time it reached 125th Street, there were 66 passengers in the second car, maybe 500 on the entire train. Seats were scarce.

title: In Seahawks Fierce Secondary, New Members Make the Cut
description: PHOENIX  To gain membership in the N.F.L.s most exclusive subculture, no formal application process is required. No paperwork need be sent or interview aced. As Marcus Burley learned on Aug. 30, all he had to do was show up.

description: Virtually shutting down the entire New York City metropolitan area for a blizzard that flaked out was a costly decision, but it will not have a lasting effect on the region, economists said on Tuesday.

description: In the summer of 2010, an unlikely espionage ring based in the suburbs of New York ended in an even more unlikely fashion: an exchange of Russian and American prisoners conducted on a sunny tarmac in Europe.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers
States Move to Make Citizenship Exams a Classroom Aid
description: PHOENIX  Like high school civics students around the country, the juniors and seniors in Darcy Whites government class here will have to take a final exam. But these students  and all others in Arizona  will soon face an extra hurdle: To graduate, they will have to pass the  test that is given to immigrants who want to become United States citizens, a multiple-choice exam that includes such questions as What do we call the first 10 amendments to the Constitution? and What did Susan B. Anthony do?

title: Across the Pacific By Raft

In fact, it would not be incorrect for me to say that YOU are at the center of Mr. Cees thoughts. YOUll see what I mean if YOUve finished solving.

title: Civil War Submarines
description: In the darkness of Feb. 17, 1864, off the coast of Charleston, S.C., the Union warship Housatonics crew clung to her rigging and masts that thrust up from the shallow water, awaiting rescue. Despite the fact that Housatonics attacker, the Confederate submarine Hunley, would not return from her mission and remain missing for over 150 years, her victory proved the viability of submarines as a weapon. The North and South would approach that knowledge in different ways.

title: Son of Indicted New York State Senator Is Found Guilty in Tax Case
description: The son of a New York State senator under federal indictment was convicted on Monday of three counts of filing false tax returns.

title: North Carolinas Food Sisterhood
description: Beyond restaurants, women run the states pre-eminent pasture-raised meat and organic produce distribution businesses and preside over its farmers markets.

title: Uganda: Agency Cuts Refugees Rations
description: Faced with a funding shortfall, the World Food Program, the lead United Nations relief agency for fighting hunger, halved rations on Tuesday to nearly 150,000 refugees in Uganda, a majority of them from the Democratic Republic of Congo. The cuts, announced by the agencys Uganda director, Alice Martin-Daihirou, come as the program struggles to raise $30 million to fund the Uganda operation for the next six months. Ms. Martin-Daihirou called the step a last resort to ensure we can continue providing lifesaving support to the 150,000 refugees, nearly half of all refugees receiving the agencys assistance in Uganda. Their arrival predated the December 2013 outbreak of fighting in South Sudan, which caused a flight of 138,000 South Sudanese to Uganda, who are not affected by the cuts. The agencys recurrent funding problems have forced it to cut or halt food-aid distribution. Last month, it suspended a voucher program that had helped nearly 1.7 million Syrian refugees, but resumed it after an emergency fund-raising appeal.

title: Israeli Group Says Military Attacks on Palestinian Homes Appeared to Violate Law
description: JERUSALEM  An Israeli human rights group said Israels attacks on residential buildings in Gaza during the 50-day war against Hamas last summer appeared in at least some instances to violate the provisions of international law and raised grave legal concerns in others, according to a report to be published on Wednesday.

title: Surging Islanders Overpower the Rangers at Home
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  The first-place Islanders have had the upper hand over the Rangers this season. The teams had met twice, at Madison Square Garden, and the Islanders came away with victories both times.

title: N.F.L. Investigator Seeks to Consult Columbia Physicist Over Patriots Deflated Footballs
description: A law firm hired by the N.F.L. to investigate footballs used by the New England Patriots has formally asked the Columbia University physics department for help in understanding how weather and temperature could affect the pressure in footballs, according to a summary of the communication obtained by The New York Times.

title: A$AP Rocky on His Sundance Hit, Mourning A$AP Yams and Why He Rejects Those Tupac Comparisons
description: Its been an up-and-down couple of weeks for A$AP Rocky. On Saturday, the 26-year-old rapper attended the world premiere of his new film, Dope, a hip-hop-driven comedy in which he plays a drug dealer named Dom. (Also featured are Keith Stanfield, Zo Kravitz and Rockys ex-girlfriend, the model Chanel Iman.) The movie  Rockys first  has been a Sundance hit, drawing rave reviews and becoming an early favorite to win the festivals audience award. But Rocky, n Rakim Mayers, was in little mood to celebrate. Just six days earlier, on Jan. 18, his close friend and collaborator Steven A$AP Yams Rodriguez died suddenly of still-undisclosed causes. On Sunday morning, Rocky would have to fly to New York City for the funeral.

title: Opening Ceremony Brings Vivienne Westwoods Worlds End Shop Stateside
description: Opening Ceremonys latest co-conspirator is Vivienne Westwood, who has designed for the boutique a 20-piece collection based on the timeless clothes for heroes found at her fabled Worlds End shop in London. Wed been wanting to do something with Vivienne for a while, says Humberto Leon, the stores cofounder with Carol Lim. Growing up, I remember being excited about her brands messages and its relevancy to culture  and I wanted to share this incredible story that I revere, if people dont already know about it. The resulting capsule, priced from $95 for a T-shirt to $1,500 for a bomber jacket, includes reissued garments dating back to the 70s  and transcends gender. It plays on this idea of unisex that weve been working on for many years, says Andreas Kronthaler, Westwoods design partner and creative director (and husband). We know a woman looks great in a mans shirt, but can a man look great in a womans dress? It could be the case  its about pushing boundaries and experimenting. Asked to select a standout item, Kronthaler mentions the Pirate Trouser, originally from Westwoods 1981 Pirate collection, for its muscly, active-looking, dynamic leg shape; Leon, however, declined to choose just one. Its hard to pick specifics because its about telling the whole story, he says.

title: A New Place for the Fashion Set to Eat in Paris
description: Charmed by their shape and attracted by their purported powers, the Parisian chef Jean-Franois Pige has been collecting four-leaf clover objects for many years  but the success of his new restaurant Clover is due to a lot more than just luck.

title: Whats On TV Wednesday
description: 8 P.M. (13, 49) PENGUIN POST OFFICE Every summer in the Southern Hemisphere, a British post office at Port Lockroy, above, becomes the most popular tourist attraction for cruise ships to the Antarctic Peninsula, as some 3,000 gentoo penguins take up residence alongside the other seasonal inhabitants: volunteers from the United Kingdom Antarctic Heritage Trust, who run the remote outpost. There, each November, after a bout of intensive deep-sea fishing, the gentoos find their mates, build their nests, raise their young  and pose for pictures, as long as the photographer stays 15 feet away. This Nature episode ventures to Antarctica to film the four-month ritual. In Sinkholes  Buried Alive, at 10, Nova investigates what happens when the ground opens up beneath your feet.

title: Czar Putins Next Moves
description: ZURICH  Last March, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton was quoted as saying that Russian President Vladimir Putins attack on Ukraine, supposedly in defense of Russian-speakers there, was just like what Hitler did back in the 30s  using ethnic Germans to justify his invasion of neighboring lands. At the time, I thought such a comparison was over the top. I dont think so anymore. Id endorse Mrs. Clintons comparison purely for the shock value: It draws attention to the awful things Putin is doing to Ukraine, not to mention his own country, whose credit rating was just reduced to junk status.

The Fraud of the Student-Athlete Claim
description: Two former athletes at the University of North Carolina have filed a lawsuit against their alma mater and the National Collegiate Athletic Association, accusing them of academic fraud. College athletes who sue for compensation is an old story. But, in this instance, Rashanda McCants, a former womens basketball player, and Devon Ramsay, who played football, are suing because, they say, they didnt receive a meaningful education. They are seeking class-action status, damages for some athletes and changes in academic oversight.

New findings suggest that the sources of dispute in contemporary life go far beyond ideological differences or mere polarization. title: Morning Agenda: Yahoos Alibaba Split
description: Marissa Mayer, the chief executive of Yahoo, said on Tuesday that the Internet company would spin off its 15.4 percent stake in Alibaba, Chinas leading e-commerce company, into a separate company, Vindu Goel and Michael J. de la Merced report in The New York Times. Shareholders will directly reap all the remaining profit from Yahoos investment, which cost almost nothing a decade ago but is now worth about $39.5 billion. The Alibaba stake alone now makes up nearly 85 percent of Yahoos market value. Shares of Yahoo rose about 7 percent in after-hours trading after disclosure of the plan.

title: Gateway to Freedom, by Eric Foner

title: Yasmina Rezas Happy Are the Happy
description: Like a handful of the 18 people who populate her latest novel, Happy Are the Happy, Yasmina Reza is formidably accomplished. A prolific novelist and playwright  two of her works for the stage, Art and God of Carnage, won Tony Awards for best play  as well as a screenwriter and actress, she haunts the halls of power in her native France. Happy Are the Happy is another coup, a quick and delicate book thats as funny as it is humane. Each of its short chapters, titled with the name of the character speaking, is told in the first person and concerns, for the most part, other characters in the book soon to introduce themselves if they havent already. Everyone gets a word in, and the style is feathery as gossip. Characters chime with one another in ways they never realize, a conviviality that is bittersweet. Their voices are self-aware, a little jaundiced, vulnerable, sometimes plaintive, and entirely authentic. Accomplishment, Reza suggests, is no hedge against yearning or regret. Status, wealth, celebrity, sex appeal and good health are unevenly distributed and underappreciated, until they are in decline. Life isnt sparkly, its a slog: People, practically oldsters, lurching around Paris, bearing their lives. Perhaps chasing the impractical is simply a way to stay in motion.

Colombian bakeries, Mexican taquerias and Dominican lunch counters dot commercial areas. Spanish conversations fill the streets. And sporting goods stores are more likely to display Ecuadorean national soccer jerseys than fan gear from the Jets and Giants.

The second is to blow past the checkpoint and hope the soldiers guarding it dont open fire on you.

title: A Chicago Neighborhood Follows a Latin Beat
description: Pilsen, about a dozen blocks south of downtown Chicago, got its name from 19th-century Czech settlers who long ago gave way to more recent waves of Mexican immigrants. The enclaves reputation seemed to bottom out in 2005, when the doll company American Girl introduced Marisol Luna, whose family leaves gritty Pilsen for the suburbs. But even then, a mix of Latino cafes and attractions including the National Museum of Mexican Art was drawing visitors and artists. Now new breweries, restaurants and the relocation of the popular Redmoon Theater have rooted Pilsen on Chicagos tourism map.

title: 36 Hours in Belfast, Northern Ireland
description: Avoided, underrated or just plain forgotten, Belfast is a city thats been fighting a bad reputation for half a century. A visit today, however, is an eye-opening experience in the best possible way. Belfast has been coming into its own in the last few years, developing a vibrant restaurant scene, award-winning architecture  the Royal Institute of British Architects gave the MAC, a sleek arts venue, a National Award in 2013  and a new cosmopolitanism, although fried breakfasts and a heightened awareness of sectarian conflict are still an integral part of most residents days. The friendliness of the people is whats most appealing in this small and very walkable city, from smiling servers to talkative bartenders to helpful strangers on the street. Visit Belfast to soak up good vibes, to eat well and to drink unstintingly. Its a city thats at its best when enjoyed from behind a pint glass.

title: Boeing Says Dreamliner to Yield More Cash in 15
description: Boeing, reporting a strong end to 2014, on Wednesday forecast better cash flow and said that it would deliver more commercial planes in 2015.

title: A Push for a Greater Government Role in Housing Finance
description: At a conference on housing finance last month, a collection of investors described their innovative rent-to-own products.

title: Regulators Crack Down on Marketers of Unlimited Data Plans
description: Federal regulators are cracking down on mobile service providers that advertise unlimited data plans only to reduce the speed of data transmission if customers reach a certain limit on their data use. Slowed data speeds can make it difficult for mobile device users to browse the web or watch streaming videos.

description: Before asking eurozone creditors to reduce Greeces public debt, the countrys prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, might consider making good on another pledge: a permanent mortgage moratorium.

title: Questions About Blown Blizzard Forecasts, and the Gender of Blizzard Forecasters
description: Needless to say, theres lots offinger pointingand post-blizzard cogitation under way in the wake of the raging noreaster the Weather Channel called Juno and others called the Blizzard of 2015. As you likely know, the western and most densely populated part of the National Weather Service blizzard-warning zone was largely spared.

title: Another Standardized Test, This Time of Citizenship
description: What sounds at first hearing like at the very least, a reasonable idea  requiring high school students to take the same citizenship exam as immigrants who want to become United States citizens  is arguably not that simple.

title: Below the Line: Visual Effects of Guardians of the Galaxy
description: For the sci-fi adventure Guardians of the Galaxy, the filmmakers had two major visual problems to solve: how to make rich, colorful worlds set in many interstellar locations that kept the spirit of the comics on which the film is based and how to depict two of the more unconventional characters, Groot (a tree man) and Rocket Raccoon.

title: Long Anticipated, Madison Keyss Big Moment Is Here

title: States Renew Fight to Stop Same-Sex Marriage
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  As the nation waits for the Supreme Court to decide whether same-sex marriages should be legal nationwide, another, more mundane front has opened in the wedding wars: the offices of the state and local officials who perform civil marriages and issue licenses.

title: German Anti-Immigrant Leaders Resign
description: BERLIN  The anti-immigrant group that spawned large rallies and counterprotests around Germany announced a leadership exodus on Wednesday, just a week after its founder was forced to step down when photos of him posed as Hitler circulated on social media.

title: Enthusiasm, Entirely Uncurbed
description: Larry David may be the only person on Broadway who could delight audiences by forgetting his lines. As fans of his HBO hit Curb Your Enthusiasm recall, when his character drew a blank while starring in The Producers on Broadway, he ad-libbed a hilarious stand-up routine that won the crowd over. That probably wont happen in his new comedy, Fish in the Dark, which has established itself as the blockbuster new play of the spring season even before it begins.

title: Sundance 2015: Writers Made Photogenic and Crazy Tales Made Poignant
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Writers, a Sundance program director here gently observed, do not make for the easiest documentary subjects: pecking away on a deadline is not actually dramatic, no matter what we might tell our editors.

title: New Cruises for Single Travelers
description: Its not always easy being a solo traveler, particularly when it comes to cruises. Tour companies hit you with single supplements, while singles mixers draw a wide age-range of passengers  too wide, for some.

title: In the Flesh
description: Embrace the tonal subtlety of a rose gold timepiece with a nude band against bare skin.

title: Skull Fossil Offers New Clues on Human Journey From Africa
description: Anthropologists exploring a cave in Israel have uncovered a rare 55,000-year-old skull fossil that they say has a story to tell of a reverberating transition in human evolution, at a point when and where some early humans were moving out of Africa and apparently interbreeding with Neanderthals.

description: Brooks Barnes covers show business for The Times. Last week he attended the Sundance Film Festival. For a reporter, the festival is probably less glamorous than it seems. He describes the highs and lows of covering the screenings, and how he avoided the festivals public relations hype.

title: Suspicion Is Cast on Aide in Death of Argentine Prosecutor
description: BUENOS AIRES  Argentinas government on Wednesday cast greater suspicion on an aide to Alberto Nisman, the prosecutor whose mysterious death this month has shaken the country, by describing the aide as an intelligence operative  adding to its assertions that rogue spies were involved in the events around Mr. Nismans death.

title: Whitewashing the Crazy, Fed Edition
description: How does one report on politics when a significant wing of the political spectrum is, not to put too fine a point on it, stark raving mad? I appreciate that its hard to do without attracting accusations of bias; on the other hand, theres a temptation to soft-pedal the crazy, to make it seem as if politicians were less out there than they really are.

title: Verbatim: Scott Walker on Being Boring
description: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, on shedding his image as a boring politician while he considers a run for president.

title: Moriah Evanss Social Dance 1-8: Index at Issue Project Room
description: Before each performance of Social Dance 1-8: Index, the choreographer Moriah Evans personally escorts audience members to seats of her choosing. Its the action of a hostess, though Ms. Evans isnt cordial. As a cold abstraction of a social gesture, and as an indication of Ms. Evanss close control over every part of her work, this is an apt introduction to what follows.

title: OK Go Video and Volcano Journey Make the Cut for Drone Film Festival
description: Superman flying with a GoPro, an intricately choreographed OK Go music video and a trip inside a volcano will all be part of the first New York City Drone Film Festival, organizers announced Wednesday.

title: Coverage in an Instant: In the Field With @crowleygraph
description: While he is shooting and filing images for print and the web, Stephen Crowley, a photographer for The Times, is also sharing photos on his Instagram account, @crowleygraph.

title: Federal Reserve Wont Raise Interest Rates Before June, at Earliest
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve kept its options open on Wednesday, signaling that it would not raise short-term interest rates any earlier than June, while leaving unresolved how much longer it might be willing to wait before lifting its benchmark rate from near zero, where the central bank has held it for more than six years.

title: At Silk Road Trial, Lawyers Fight to Include Evidence They Call Vital: Emoji
description: The trial of Ross W. Ulbricht, a California man charged with running an online black-market bazaar called Silk Road, had barely begun when an unusual objection was lodged.

title: Dabbling in Romantic Chemistry
description: Since playing one of the geeks on the short-lived TV series Freaks and Geeks, Martin Starr  variously bearded, bespectacled, acerbic, nerdy or all of the above  has been part of many memorable comic ensembles, from the films Knocked Up and Adventureland to HBOs current series Silicon Valley. But for his latest film, he did his most surprising thing to date for a role: clean up.

title: Workers at Londons National Gallery Plan Five-Day Strike
description: LONDON  Employees at the National Gallery here have voted in favor of a five-day strike in response to the museums decision to outsource visitor and security services to a private company. The change would affect approximately 400 of the 600 staff members. About 250 employees who are members of the Public and Commercial Services union voted in favor of the strike, which is planned for Feb. 3 to 7. Mark Serwotka, the general secretary of the union, said in a statement that the museums plan risks damaging the worldwide reputation of what is one of the U.K.s greatest cultural assets.

title: Perfectly Reasonable Question: Gender of Letter Writers
description: From time to time, I take up questions that have come to me from readers, pose them to Times editors, and publish the questions and answers without providing further commentary. Ill do a few of those over the next few days.

title: 1890: Horrible Sufferings at Sea
description: LONDON  Sufferings at sea have seldom taken a more horrible form than those undergone by the crew of the ship Arethusa of Liverpool. The Arethusa was bound from the Tyne to Valparaiso, and on September 29 her cargo of coal took fire. On October 2, the crew of twenty-three men took to two boats, and at that time they were only twenty six miles from Falkland Islands, when the weather became dirty and during the night the boats parted company. Seven days later the boat, with the captain and ten men, arrived at Port Stanley, the crew being in a pitiable condition. The barque Lady Octavia picked up the other boat.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 29, 1890

title: Lynch Appears Before Senate Committee
description: Loretta E. Lynch, President Obamas nominee for attorney general, answers questions on immigration and law enforcement from the Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: Judge Says Bankruptcy of Caesars Unit Can Proceed in Chicago

title: Colombia Calls for Release of Venezuelan Political Prisoner
description: Latin American governments typically refrain from criticizing the domestic policies of their neighbors. But Colombia broke with that unwritten rule this week by calling on Venezuela to free the political prisoner Leopoldo Lpez.

description: Janice Dean is a senior meteorologist at Fox News and the mother of two boys, Matthew, 5, and Theodore, 3. This post was written before the snowstorm that hit the East Coast earlier this week.

It was 2011, and J. Christopher Burch hovered nearby, surveying guests who had come to celebrate the opening of his new candy-colored emporium.

Its the centerpiece of Oxfams latest campaign, timed to coincide with the touching down of several of those billionaires in Davos for the World Economic Forum last week.

title: Expensive Drugs Work Better Than Cheap Ones
description: Expensive drugs work better than cheap ones  or at least some people firmly believe they do.

description: Mayra Rodrguez Valladares is managing principal at MRV Associates, a capital markets and financial regulatory consulting and training firm in New York. On Twitter, she is @MRVAssociates.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 10 P.M. (13, 49) GRANTCHESTER James Norton (Happy Valley), above, portrays Sidney Chambers, a small-town vicar with a love of jazz, whiskey and complicated women who discovers an enthusiasm for sleuthing after a concerned parishioner compels him to investigate a grisly suicide in this new Masterpiece Mystery! series, based on the mysteries by James Runcie. Grantchester will be breezy fun for fans of the form, though the more discerning will be put off by how rudimentary the actual murder mysteries are after being squeezed into 50 minutes (half the norm for this type of show), Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times about what he called cozy mysteries. And while it benefits from the presence of the veteran Robson Green (Wire in the Blood, Touching Evil) as Sidneys sidekick, Inspector Keating, Mr. Hale added, he found Mr. Norton, though amiable and good to look at, a little dim: As religiously inclined young British sleuths go  and I apologize for a reference that only my fellow British-mystery zealots will understand  hes no Hathaway. In Downton Abbey, which leads in at 9, Lady Mary (Michelle Dockery) and Lord Gillingham (Tom Cullen) check into a Liverpool hotel  the better to check out their love. The art historian Simon Bricker (Richard E. Grant) turns his attention from a Piero della Francesca painting to its owner, Lady Cora (Elizabeth McGovern). A secret from the past of the Dowager Countess (Maggie Smith) resurfaces. And the police continue to investigate the death of Lord Gillinghams valet.

title: The Camera Is On: Now Go Create
description: Justin Peck is not a lonely guy. He has a girlfriend, close colleagues, a loving family. But you wouldnt necessarily know this from watching him in Ballet 422, the documentary that chronicles his third piece of choreography for New York City Ballet from creation to performance. In the film, to be released on Feb. 6, Mr. Peck is so intensely focused, so singular of purpose, that you wonder whether he has anything left for a personal life.

title: King Charles III, a Hit in London, Is Aiming at Broadway
description: Broadway is getting Queen Elizabeth II this spring in The Audience, a play starring Helen Mirren as the monarch, and in all probability Broadway will get her son soon afterward with King Charles III, Mike Bartletts future-history play that has earned critical acclaim in London.

title: This Just In: Local Newscasters Play Themselves on TV
description: Perhaps you choked down all three seasons of The Newsroom, the fictional HBO series that wrapped up last month, and have been feeling as if you need some kind of antidote. Something to counteract all the earnestness, all the impossibly sharp newsroom dialogue about earthshaking issues. Five minutes of Breaking Greenville should do the trick.

title: A Trove of Vintage Counterculture Photographs Sees the Light of Day
description: The Family Acid, debuting at this weekends L.A. Art Book Fair, compiles decades worth of psychedelic shots.

title: Facebook Sales Beat Forecasts, but Expenses Increase Even Faster
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When Mark Zuckerberg warned investors three months ago that Facebooks expenses were going to rise sharply, he really meant it.

title: Ulyana Sergeenko, Coutures Russian Ambassador, on How to Look Relaxed and Gorgeous (Even When Youre Stressed Out)
description: If Ulyana Sergeenko is having a hectic couture season, it certainly doesnt show. However uncertain the Russian presence in fashion may be at the moment, the designer, who presented her fifth collection earlier this week, has become the face of it  and deservedly so, given her flawless grooming and porcelain complexion. (Perhaps her more low-key approach  forgoing the typical runway format, she instead hosted one-on-one appointments at Le Bristol in Paris  hasnt hurt.) Here, Sergeenko shares her secrets to maintaining a relaxed look and immaculate skin, even when under pressure.

description: A.E.G. Live, the second-largest concert company in the world, has hired Gary Gersh, a seasoned music executive, as its president of global talent, the company announced on Wednesday.

description: Steven Noble, the costume designer for The Theory of Everything, tried to echo the characters long emotional journeys in increasingly muted, heavy and oversized clothes.

description: To the Editor:

description: In preparation for the Super Bowl, a search for good bottle openers.

title: Bringing Warm Exuberance to a Series of Character Studies
description: Scarlatti, announced the French pianist Alexandre Tharaud before his second encore at Zankel Hall on Tuesday night, emphatically pronouncing the name of a composer he has championed live and on disc. He offered Scarlattis Sonata in D Minor (K. 141), decisively rendering the percussive effects and guitarlike inflections in a rendition notable for its articulation and wild exuberance.

title: Fiery Odes Dedicated to a Love Still Burning
description: A big voice and a loving heart versus a thoughtless, deceitful boyfriend. There should be no question about which deserves to prevail. But without the struggle, countless pop songs would never exist. Seinabo Sey (pronounced SAY-na-bo See) joins the fray with the sadder-but-stronger songs she brought to Le Poisson Rouge on Tuesday night.

title: Grand Royal Illusions
description: LONDON  Well never be royals, begins the chorus of the hit pop song by Lorde thats played as the curtain falls on Mike Bartletts dazzling King Charles III at Wyndhams Theater. And arent we the lucky ones?

title: Walkabout: Tourism in Tripoli Creates Optimism
description: Renewed Hope While foreign visitors have largely avoided the northern Lebanese city of Tripoli as violence has risen over the outbreak of the Syrian civil war, smaller groups of tourists have decided to explore the historic city, much to delight of local residents. (Associated Press)

title: Paris Couture Week: Viktor & Rolf Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

title: A Looker Who Lives for Laughs
description: In Funny Girl, Nick Hornby uses the story of a reluctant beauty queen from Blackpool as the hook for a rambunctious cultural history of British television comedy 50 years ago. As befits a novel about a popular sitcom, this novel packs in lots of laughs, but its also got more heft than Mr. Hornbys readers may expect. Its story begins in 1964, when the standards for everything that Britain found funny, familiar, thrilling and off limits were drastically changing. And its characters create the biggest hit on the BBC with a show thats a sign of its times.

title: Paris Couture Week: Viktor & Rolf Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

title: Pete Carroll Has a Fan Club Deep in Patriots Territory
description: MEDFIELD, Mass.  Seattle Seahawks Coach Pete Carroll, who left this town in 2000, says he cannot remember ever going back. He need not worry. His sterling reputation endures in Medfield, a community 25 minutes from Gillette Stadium in Foxborough.

title: Trailer: Amira & Sam
description: A preview of the film.

title: Consumer Product Safety Commission Warns About Danger to Children From Unsecured TVs
description: As football fans rush to buy televisions before Sundays Super Bowl game, the Consumer Product Safety Commission is warning parents to properly secure their electronics, especially big-screen TVs

title: Romney,in Speech at Mississippi State, Examines What Went Wrong in 2012
description: STARKVILLE, Miss.  Mitt Romney sounded out themes for a potential third presidential run, lamented the nature of the political process and offered a dose of barely veiled self-criticism in a visit Wednesday to this college town.

title: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
description: Lebanon and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Jan. 28, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Lebanon, Gaza City, Syria and Paris.

title: Governor Cites Massachusettss Good Luck
description: Gov. Charlie Baker said that the snow from the storm Monday and Tuesday was lighter and fluffier than expected, leading to fewer power failures.

title: A Street-Style Trick That Works IRL and More
description: Piling on outerwear to stay warm is a street-style trick that works IRL. And there are ways to pull off the stratagem without looking like a coat lady. The stylist Kusum Lynn suggests wearing a leather jacket or puffer under a classic mens wear coat, adding an oversize scarf for color. For an undone yet still chic ensemble, she likes a relaxed-fit robe coat (preferably with an exaggerated collar) worn atop a chunky cardigan. To counter the proportions of slouchy outerwear, wear tailored trousers. You can be at work with the worst hangover and feel like youre still getting cozy in bed under the covers, Ms. Lynn said.

title: An Inventive Postwar Japanese Painter Has His Moment
description: Ironically, Kazuo Shiragas feet were nearly his feet of clay. The breakout star of the Gutai Art Association, Shiraga became colloquially known as the foot painter; the Japanese postwar movements founder, Jiro Yoshihara, even dismissed Shiraga as a nobody, if he didnt paint with his feet. After his 1955 performance Challenging Mud, in which the artist wrestled a mixture of cement, gravel, clay, plaster, pebbles and twigs into a formless form, Shiraga devised an entirely new painting technique. From 1959 onward, he suspended himself from his studio ceiling and manipulated the paint exclusively with his ten toes to create a range of textures from the slinky and supple to the protruding and violent. Almost 60 years later, Shiraga, whose dynamic contributions blend painting and performance, is still a misunderstood radical who is only now receiving the sort of American institutional and gallery attention that properly contextualizes the depth and reach of his practice.

title: To Allay Fears, N.F.L. Huddles With Mothers
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla.  Rebecca Morgan squared her feet, bent her knees, raised her hands and tried to connect with her inner linebacker. Beside her, two dozen other mothers did the same as they listened to Mike Haynes, a former N.F.L. defensive lineman, teach them how to tackle safely.

title: Hobby House
description: A Texan moves back into his family home, but not before making room for his boyhood obsession.

title: Japanese Designers Provide a Wealth of Ideas in Paris
description: PARIS  To defy circumstance and live with joie de vivre! one Congolese dandy said, explaining his philosophy in a 2014 documentary about Les Sapeurs, or le Socit des Ambianceurs et des Personnes lgantes (Society of Ambiance-Makers and Elegant Persons), and incidentally describing a fundamental purpose of fashion.

title: The Book Ends, and the Story Begins
description: In American Sniper, Chris Kyle (Bradley Cooper) peers through the scope of a high-powered rifle, finger on the trigger, preparing to shoot a young boy. A Navy SEAL on his first tour of duty in Iraq, he has been tasked with protecting the lives of the Marines under his watch, and the boy is running full speed at a convoy of them, his hands wrapped around an enormous Russian-made grenade.

title: All-but-Forgotten Prisoner in Jordan Is at Center of Swap Demand by ISIS
description: AMMAN, Jordan  During the nine years that Sajida al-Rishawi, 46, has been sitting in self-imposed solitary confinement in her cell at the Juweidah Womens Prison in Jordan, refusing to mix with other prisoners, she has had hardly any visitors, other than her court-appointed lawyer.

title: Zaha Hadid Settles Libel Suit Against New York Review of Books
description: The architect Zaha Hadid has settled her case against the New York Review of Books and critic Martin Filler, and donated the settlement money to an undisclosed charity that protects and champions labor rights, dezeen magazine reported on Tuesday.

title: Sick Childs Father Seeks Vaccination Requirement in California
description: In the latest salvo in the vaccination wars that have shaken California since a measles outbreak originated at Disneyland last month, the father of a 6-year-old boy with leukemia has asked the superintendent of his Marin County school district to keep unvaccinated children out of school.

title: American Sniper Fuels a War on the Home Front
description: As American Sniper continues to spawn think pieces, internecine celebrity squabbles and diatribes from hand-wringing lefties and chest-thumping righties, its interesting to remember the naysaying about the films prospects that swirled just last month.

title: Scholars at Odds on Ukraine
description: Since the crisis in Ukraine began, the Russia scholar Stephen F. Cohen has cast himself in the role of the unbowed dissenter, whose sharp criticisms of Americas foreign policy in the region have earned him denunciations as Putins American toady, as The New Republic put it, and worse.

title: First Draft Focus: Obama Bids Farewell to Hagel
Adrian Grenier Pitches Whale Movie With Sundance Party
description: PARK CITY, Utah  While the Sundance Film Festival crowd was wondering last Saturday about which films to see and which gifting suites had the best swag, the actor Adrian Grenier had gathered about 100 friends for a candlelit dinner at a private home in Deer Valley, Utah. The occasion was not the coming Entourage movie in which he stars, but a passion project about a whale.

title: Not Just Telling a Joke, but Showing It, Too
description: The choreography of stand-up comedy is usually pretty simple: Walk onstage, grab the microphone and tell a joke. Lean forward, look one way and tell another.

title: Friendship 9 Convictions Thrown Out
description: A judge in Rock Hill, S.C., vacated the convictions of nine black men who were arrested in 1961 for sitting at a whites-only lunch counter.

title: Ice, Polar Bears and Death, but Its Not Global Warming
description: Fortitude, an ambitious 12-episode murder mystery beginning on Thursday night, takes place in two unusual locales. One is its slightly fantastical far-far-north setting, a fictional Arctic island  based on the Norwegian archipelago of Svalbard  where a small international community is outnumbered by polar bears; crime is thought to be nonexistent; and anyone near death is exiled to the mainland, because bodies cant be buried in the permafrost.

title: Amazons Got Mail
description: Amazon Web Serviceson Wednesday announced Amazon WorkMail, an email service that adds a new front to the fierce competition in the cloud. WorkMail, which works behind existing interfaces like Microsoft Outlook, is being promoted as safer and cheaper than other systems.

title: 54 Years Later, South Carolina Court Clears Friendship Nine
description: ROCK HILL, S.C.  Fifty-four years after they went to jail for an anti-segregation protest in this former mill town, the African-American men who came to be known as the Friendship Nine returned to court Wednesday dressed in their sober Sunday best, as though a judge might sentence them again.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Finding a Path to Making 4 Spades in Florida
description: Zeke Jabbour, an eight-time national champion, hosts an annual charity pro-am tournament to benefit the National Parkinson Foundation. Chaired by Joanne Weingold and Molly ONeill, this years event  with 196 players, the biggest yet  was held on Sunday at St. Andrews Country Club in Boca Raton, Fla.
