Quibbles over whether it should be called outsider, folk or self-taught are less prominent, and there has been somewhat of a shift to supporting living artists.

title: A Brush With Fame, Long Before His Life in Art
description: DEALERS tend to be fond of an artist with a story. Jerry Torre has a doozy. Several, in fact.

title: Jim Woodring: You Drive!
description: While barely if at all known in the high-art realm, Jim Woodring is a giant in the world of comics and graphic novels. Scott Eder Gallery, which specializes in comic art, here presents an assortment of recent drawings and paintings that display Mr. Woodrings extraordinary gifts as a draftsman, storyteller and creator of hilarious characters and hallucinatory situations.

title: Has the Measles Outbreak Changed Your Views on Vaccination? Describe Your Experience
description: New York Times journalists would like to hear from parents, particularly those in California and Arizona, who have chosen not to vaccinate their children against measles and other diseases.

title: A Snowstorm Passes Over, but Leaves Stravinsky Scrambling in Its Wake
description: There is an ineffable, unmistakable quality at the core of great live performances. Call it energy; call it joy. And it doesnt require the material to be happy: It is possible for a rendition of a symphony to be joyful, even if the work is weighty.

title: Sings Millennium Mart at Interstate Projects
description: The Korean market is a relatively new institution in New York, but it has precedents in older corner stores, bodegas and delis where various cultures have mingled and clashed. Sings Millennium Mart, organized by Seung-Min Lee, is billed as the corner deli of the future, rather than any particular type  although Ms. Lee was born in Korea and her family has worked in the food business in New York.

title: Sri Lanka to Free Tamils and Return Their Land
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka  The Sri Lankan government pledged Thursday to free hundreds of minority Tamil detainees and return much of the Tamil land in the north and east that the military seized and continues to hold years after the end of the countrys bitter civil war.

title: What I Love | Valerie Steele
description: The director of the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology lives with her husband, John S. Major, in a Chelsea loft.

title: Diana Thater: Science, Fiction
description: Entering this spectacular exhibition by the West Coast video artist Diana Thater, you might think youve walked onto the set of a Stanley Kubrick sci-fi movie. The whole show is flooded by an intense blue glow cast by lights beaming from the floor in all corners. In the center of the gallery is a mysterious, room-size box, which appears to hover a few inches off the floor over a band of bright yellow light. A grainy video is projected on the ceiling directly above the box. It shows large beetles  dung beetles  slowly burrowing into the earth and moving about in thicket of brown grass.

title: Bjrk Gets Personal
description: Jon Pareles tells Ben Ratliff about club-hopping with Bjrk in Iceland and listening to her new album, Vulnerica, which was released last week.

title: Pictures of the Day  Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Ukraine and More: Pictures of the Day

title: Uche Okeke: Works on Paper, 1958-1993
description: Histories of Modernism are constantly changing as scholars come to realize its global breadth and local particularities. The marketplace is slower on the uptake. Although New York has a few galleries specializing in early-to-mid-20th-century Asian work, Skoto Gallery in Chelsea remains, more than two decades after it opened, the sole full-time outlet for comparable work from Africa. And it gives us some Modernism-merging-into-contemporary basics in a thumbnail survey of works on paper by the influential West African artist Uche Okeke.

title: How, and Why, Apple Overtook Microsoft
description: When Microsoft stock was at a record high in 1999, and its market capitalization was nearly $620 billion, the notion that Apple Computer would ever be bigger  let alone twice as big  was laughable. Apple was teetering on bankruptcy. And Microsofts operating system was so dominant in personal computers, then the center of the technology universe, that the government deemed the company an unlawful monopoly.

title: Three Americans Are Killed in a Shooting at Kabul Airport
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Three American military contractors were killed in a shooting on the military side of Kabuls international airport on Thursday, military officials said.

title: A Flower Delivery That Brought More Pain Than Pleasure
description: With the best of intentions, I once did something regrettable.

title: Oscar Nominated Shorts
description: Images of films in the program.

title: Hershey to Buy Krave, a Maker of Jerky
description: Chocolate-covered jerky? Its no longer a wild idea, with Hersheys on Thursday announcing plans to buy a tiny, trendy jerky company.

title: Jan. 29, 2015   Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Ukraine, Israel, Australia and France.

title: Martin Brodeur Retires With Most Wins and a Smile
description: Martin Brodeur acknowledged on Thursday that he could have found other opportunities to continue to play goaltender in the N.H.L.

title: An Eyeful Next Door
description: The man next door cut down his bamboo trees and exposed his backyard to us (and 20 others in our building). Our young son loves reporting on the doings in the newly visible yard, especially the man in the pool. Our neighbor uses his hot tub most mornings, stark naked and in full view of our building. May I speak with him about a compromise? (p.s. He is not European. The gossip is that he is 30, and his parents bought him the house. Yes, I am judging.)

title: And to the Point
description: At Oscar time, short films are both an afterthought and a corrective. Office-pool hustlers will hope for a lucky break or an inside line (Is there a Pixar cartoon? Something with cute kids? A Holocaust theme?), while more casual observers will brace themselves for disproportionately long, achingly sincere speeches from filmmakers nobody has ever heard of. But if the shorts are inevitably upstaged by the main show, they also offer a vision of what the Academy Awards should and could be but very rarely are: eclectic, cosmopolitan, scrappy and surprising.

title: Bomb Attacks at Security Sites in Sinai Kill at Least 26
description: CAIRO  A series of simultaneous bombings targeting security facilities in the Sinai killed at least 26 people Thursday night, prompting fears that the Egyptian governments campaign of home demolitions, curfews and sweeping arrests has failed to choke off a budding insurgency there.

title: In Montreal, a Week for Poutine
description: With a food scene as diverse as Montreals, tourists often dont know where to start eating.

title: In Fashion
description: Athletic sportswear has come a long way from the track and the field. High fashion sounds a call to action with all-American lettered jerseys, motocross stripes and high-tech mesh.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Manitowoc to Split in Two After Pressure From Activists
description: The Manitowoc Company, a manufacturer in Wisconsin, plans to spit itself in two after pressure from powerful activist investors.

title: Theater Listings for Jan. 30-Feb. 5
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Greeces Feisty Finance Minister Tries a More Moderate Message
description: ATHENS  In the first days after the election victory of the leftist party Syriza in Greece, Yanis Varoufakis, the new finance minister, has lobbed some rhetorical grenades, referring to his countrys foreign-imposed austerity budgets as fiscal waterboarding and calling Greeces international bailout deals a toxic mistake.

title: The Thrum of Thrill-Seeking
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Every January at the Sundance Film Festival, a movie or two will pop, exciting a cinematic congregation that descends on this resort town praying for the next big thing and at times finding it. Last year the festival got the party started with Whiplash, one of its opening selections, and then sent attendees into raptures with Boyhood. No single title has dominated this years event, yet after a slow start that had some writing off the event before it really got going, good and great movies  from coming-of-age tales like The Diary of a Teenage Girl and Me and Earl and the Dying Girl to documentaries like Prophets Prey and Welcome to Leith  affirmed that, once again, this was the place to be.

title: Oil Cash Waning, Venezuelan Shelves Lie Bare
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Mary Noriega heard there would be chicken.

title: Comedy Listings for Jan. 30-Feb. 5
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Positive Science on ART Babies
description: A large study has found that assisted reproduction technology, or ART, has markedly improved over the past 20 years, with the outcomes of these fertility treatments now better than ever.

title: Movie Listings for Jan. 30-Feb. 5
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Pop, Rock & Cabaret Listings for Jan. 30-Feb. 5
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Jazz Listings for Jan. 30-Feb. 5
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Opera & Classical Music Listings for Jan. 30-Feb. 5
description: Reviews of classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Sundance in Slow-Mo
description: James Franco, Saoirse Ronan, Jason Schwartzman and other Sundance darlings do their thing in a slow motion video booth The Times set up on festival Main Street.

title: Dance Listings for Jan. 30-Feb. 5
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Spurning Placidity for the Fire Within
description: Other ensembles may play more consistently with technical prowess and exacting coordination than the Mariinsky Orchestra. But at its best, this ensemble, the house band of the Mariinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, Russia, brings dark, rich sound; vivid character; and emotional depth to its performances, especially in Russian repertory. The orchestra was not quite at its best for the two all-Russian programs that Valery Gergiev, its longtime music director, conducted at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday and Wednesday nights.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Jan. 30-Feb. 5
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Bernice Gordon, Prolific Crossword Constructor,  Dies at 101
description: SPECIAL POST  Bernice Gordon, who reinvented herself as an artist and a crossword-puzzle constructor after raising three children, died this morning at her home in Philadelphia. She was 101.

title: Spare Times for Children for Jan. 30-Feb. 5
description: Hello From Japan!

title: A Mothers Illness, a Daughters Duty
description: After Nancy Borowicks father died of cancer, she wasted no moments as she chronicled her mothers illness.

title: Spare Times for Jan. 30-Feb. 5
description: Museums and Sites

title: Abstracted Moves
description: Before each performance of Social Dance 1-8: Index, the choreographer Moriah Evans personally escorts audience members to seats of her choosing. Its the action of a hostess, though Ms. Evans isnt cordial. As a cold abstraction of a social gesture, and as an indication of Ms. Evanss close control over every part of her work, this is an apt introduction to what follows.

title: Joe Biden: A Plan for Central America
description: AS we were reminded last summer when thousands of unaccompanied children showed up on our southwestern border, the security and prosperity of Central America are inextricably linked with our own.

title: At Halftime, Hear Her Roar
description: More cartoon character than gridiron warrior, Katy Perry will bring some whimsy to the Super Bowl this weekend.

title: Exploring the Limits in a Mans World
description: Cline Sciammas Girlhood can be described (like so many movies these days) as a coming-of-age story, and it honors the genre, and its main character, with exemplary sensitivity and sympathy. But even as she stops at familiar stations on the road to maturity  problems at home and school, new friendships and first love  Ms. Sciamma revels in the risky, reckless exuberance of adolescence and in the sheer joy of filming it.

title: On Film, the Dance Hidden in Hands, Poetry and Parkinsons
description: Its time for a new kind of dance film, one that forces you to see the art form differently, that even makes you breathe a little differently. This seasons Dance on Camera festival, now in its 43rd year, presents several unconventional offerings that aim spotlights at the choreographic rigor of hand-clapping games and competitive cheerleading or reveal how Parkinsons patients can dance with hypnotic purity.

title: Concussions Are Down, N.F.L. Says
description: PHOENIX  The N.F.L. said that the number of concussions fell 11.8 percent this season compared to 2013 as players adjust to new, stricter rules on helmet-to-helmet tackles.

title: Embracing a Fantasy From Their Pixar Past
description: This years nominees for the Oscar for animated short film cover a variety of subjects and styles. But the film that has generated the most excitement among professional animators is The Dam Keeper, a painterly short by Daisuke Tsutsumi and Robert Kondo, former Pixar art directors who have started their own studio.

title: Katy Perry Touches Down in Football Fandom
description: PHOENIX  As the final seconds ticked off the clock on the first Saturday in October, capping a hectic but exhilarating day, a University of Mississippi student turned to his neighbor and planted a kiss on her lips. This was no ordinary seatmate, though: It was the pop superstar Katy Perry. And this was no ordinary game; Ole Miss had just upset Alabama.

title: Katy Perry Teases Her Halftime Show
description: The singer dropped hints at a news conference about her appearance at the Super Bowl on Sunday with Lenny Kravitz and an unnamed guest performer.

title: A Medieval Time on a Planet Far Away
description: The future is mired in the muddy, muddy past in Hard to Be a God, Aleksei Germans full-contact, madly outr adaptation of the 1964 science-fiction novel by Arkady and Boris Strugatsky. The films helter-skelter action takes place on another planet, but not some gleamingly advanced version of our own. On the parallel world of Arkanar, its still the Middle Ages, and the rabble spend their lives tramping through muck, surviving warring factions (or not), and apparently delighting in the total lack of sanitation.

title: Italy Opens Voting for New President. Let the Intrigue Begin.
description: ROME  Shortly before voting began in Parliament on Thursday to elect Italys new president, a flash mob gathered in the cold rain outside the Quirinale, as the presidential residence is called.

title: ConocoPhillips and Occidental Post Losses, Reflecting Oil Price Plunge
description: HOUSTON  After years of making record profits as oil prices soared, Americas oil giants are beginning to lose money.

title: Deflation Experiments Show Patriots May Have a Point After All
description: Thomas Healy does not have tickets to the Super Bowl, but he plans to fly to Phoenix with something that is even harder to come by than seats at Sundays game: the first detailed, experimental data on how atmospheric conditions might have reduced the air pressure in footballs used by the New England Patriots in their victory over the Indianapolis Colts nearly two weeks ago.

title: More Special-Needs Students Remain at Charter Schools, Report Finds
description: In the continuing battle over the growth of charter schools, critics often say that many New York charter schools push out students with special needs.

title: Offshore Wind Farm Leases Draw Few Bids From Wary Industry
description: Not too long ago, in 2013, the Obama administration began auctioning off leases for offshore wind farms up and down the Eastern Seaboard, hoping to spur a nascent industry.

title: Law Firm Founds Project to Fight Revenge Porn
description: A California law student and a Virginia man dated for about six months after meeting through an online dating service. The fallout from the breakup, however, has gone on far longer, as the former boyfriend faces federal criminal charges over posting nude selfies and a sexually explicit video of the woman on pornographic websites.

title: Take My Iraqi Niece, Please
description: Stripped of the beard, glasses and unwashed curtain of hair that transform him into Gilfoyle on HBOs Silicon Valley, the actor Martin Starr is unrecognizable in the prickly love story Amira & Sam. His blank-eyed impassivity and deadpan line delivery, though, are exactly the same; and while they work beautifully to play a testy techie on a comedy show, they make him an unpersuasive lover and an unappealing leading man.

title: Group of Senators Seeks to Lift Cuba Travel Limits
description: WASHINGTON  A bipartisan group of senators introduced legislation on Thursday to permanently lift all restrictions on American travel to Cuba, the first step in what will be a pitched congressional battle over how far the United States should go in expanding trade and tourism with the Communist island nation.

title: A Boy Praises the Principal of His Brooklyn School, and a Fund-Raising Campaign Takes Off
description: The fat yellow package was addressed to the principal, students and staff of Mott Hall Bridges Academy in Brownsville, Brooklyn. Inside were hundreds of red business cards printed with a single message: You Matter.

title: Senators Introduce Cuba Travel Bill
description: A bipartisan group of senators spoke in support of a bill that would remove a ban on Americans traveling to Cuba, in light of President Obamas restoration of diplomatic relations.

title: A Musician Who Was a Player, Too
description: Even if, like me, youre a sucker for men with tossable hair and precision eyeliner, you cant help noticing that The Devils Violinist is hysterical  and possibly historical  hooey. More bodice-ripper than biopic, this German-Austrian coproduction about the life of the Italian violinist Niccol Paganini is so magnificently misjudged that it almost defies description.

title: Spotify to Raise $500 Million; Move Could Delay an I.P.O.
description: Spotify, the popular streaming music service, has retained Goldman Sachs to raise $500 million in private investment, a move that would probably delay the possibility of an initial public stock offering in the near future.

title: With Ability to Script Success, What Could Go Wrong?
description: Project Almanac, a teenage time-travel fable, begins with its hero delivering a college admissions essay to the camera and continues to pretend that everything we see was filmed by the characters. Its the latest example of the found-footage conceit, which apparently reflects a misperception among screenwriters that the filmmakers have to be part of the story, or else the movie doesnt happen.

title: Civil Lawsuit on Revenge Porn
description: The former boyfriend of a California law student posted nude selfies and a sexually explicit video of her on pornographic websites.

title: For Special-Care Residents, New York State Policy Means Leaving Home
description: Long after lunchtime one recent afternoon, John Cosentino sat at his usual table, eating his usual snacks. On this day, he was the only resident of the Brooklyn Developmental Center in its cavernous cafeteria, drafty and lit with the bleakness of an earlier era.

title: N.B.A. Signs Deal With Chinese Internet Giant
description: The N.B.A. announced a five-year deal Thursday with the Chinese Internet giant Tencent Holdings Limited to carry games, highlights and other league content on its digital platforms. The deal is worth at least $500 million, said a person briefed on the details of the agreement who was not authorized to speak publicly about it. The deal will start on July 1.

title: Back When They Were Fab
description: Backstreet Boys: Show Em What Youre Made Of is a film that only fans who are seriously overinvested in that once formidable boy band could love.

title: Drones Spotted, but Not Halted, Raise Concerns
description: WASHINGTON  As Major League Baseballs top players took the field at the All-Star Game in Minneapolis in July, a covert radar system scanned the sky above the 40,000-seat stadium for what security experts said was an emerging threat to public safety: drones.

title: Crash Death May Be Tied to a Takata Airbag
description: Honda Motor is investigating a possible sixth death linked to Takata airbags that can rupture, the automaker and lawyers said on Thursday, as a new estimate put the number of those injured by the defective airbags as high as 64.

title: Events in New Jersey for Feb. 1-7, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Embedded With the E. T. Fighters
description: Alien Outpost, the first feature from Jabbar Raisani, should really be called Alien Out of Sight, as the few, mostly distant glimpses were allowed of the movies extraterrestrials tell us very little. What we do learn  from a flurry of opening title cards  is that these so-called Heavies invaded Earth in 2021 and were chased off a year later, inexplicably leaving thousands of their kind behind. Probably just to annoy us.

title: Jewish American Pilots Fighting for Israel
description: Produced by Nancy Spielberg (sister of Steven Spielberg), the documentary Above and Beyond recounts the story of Jewish American pilots who, beginning in 1948, secretly fought for Israel in its war of independence, when the Israeli military was nascent.

title: Los Angeles to Build Housing for Veterans
description: Even as Los Angeles became home to the countrys largest population of homeless military veterans, the Department of Veterans Affairs for years has used much of its 387-acre tract near the citys exclusive Brentwood neighborhood for other purposes, including leasing property to a car rental agency and the laundry facilities of a major hotel chain. This happened over the objections of veterans advocates who thought that the tract, which had been deeded to the government in 1888 for the purpose of housing disabled veterans, should be used to house some of Los Angeless 4,000 homeless veterans.

title: Plane Crashes Near Aruba After Pursuit by Military Jets
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  A small civilian aircraft, pursued by Venezuelan military jets, crashed Thursday into the Caribbean Sea near the island of Aruba, officials on the island said.

title: Rod McKuen, Poet and Lyricist With Vast Following, Dies at 81
description: Rod McKuen, a ubiquitous poet, lyricist and songwriter whose work met with immense commercial success if little critical esteem, died on Thursday in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 81.

title: Events on Long Island for Feb. 1-7, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Hostages of Racism
description: Feeding over-the-top language to underdeveloped characters, Deon Taylors Supremacy dramatizes racism with an unvarying intensity that quickly becomes wearing. The furnace at its center is Tully (Joe Anderson), a white supremacist newly released from prison after serving 15 years for armed robbery. With a swastika on his cheek and hate in his heart, Tully hits the road with Doreen (Dawn Olivieri), a coked-up Aryan floozy, before robbing a convenience store and shooting a police officer. All this, and weve barely cleared the opening credits.

title: Netanyahu Is Talking to Leading Democrats to Little Effect So Far
description: WASHINGTON  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has been reaching out to leading Capitol Hill Democrats to try to ease criticism over his coming address to Congress, but has made little progress.

title: Shake Shack, Born in a Park, Is Going Public With Big Dreams
description: Nearly 14 years ago, on something of a lark, the restaurateur Danny Meyer opened a Chicago-style hot dog cart in Manhattans Madison Square Park, hoping to draw crowds to the park and give summer jobs to the staff at one of his nearby high-end restaurants.

title: A Small Plane, Sputtering, Gently Merges Into a Northbound Lane on a New Jersey Highway
description: A small airplane was cruising about 3,500 feet over the northwest corner of New Jersey on Thursday afternoon when its single engine sputtered out, rendering it powerless as it descended miles from a landing strip.

title: Course Gives Tiger Woods Some Problems, but Fans Dont
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Tiger Woods took a lemon and squeezed a two-over-par 73 out of itThursday, proving there is nothing wrong with his mental game. After nearly six months away from full-field competition, Woodss golf remains a little green. If it were a piece of fruit, he would let it ripen a few months before picking it.

title: House Democrats, Facing Long Odds, Take Inspiration From the Top
description: PHILADELPHIA  President Obama sought to buck up House Democrats on retreat here, even as Republicans back in Washington proved the value of being in the majority by pushing through the Senate a bill to approve the Keystone XL pipeline.

title: This Weeks Movies | Jan. 30, 2015
description: The New York Times film critics review Black or White, Girlhood and Hard to Be a God.

title: Events in Connecticut for Feb. 1-7, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Marked for Death After Helping a Friend
description: Set in the underbelly of Las Vegas and full of dull existential timeouts, Wild Card is about second chances. For the security consultant played by Jason Statham, that would mean finally escaping the (violent) grind. For the films storied screenwriter, William Goldman, its the rare privilege of re-adapting his novel Heat after its first incarnation in 1986 with Burt Reynolds.

title: As Venezuelan Oil Prices Fall, Social Programs Suffer
description: Venezuelans have put up with shortages and long lines for years, but the economic situation has recently grown dire.

title: Demis Roussos Dies at 68; Greek Singer Was Internationally Known
description: ATHENS  Demis Roussos, an internationally famous Greek singer known for both his heartfelt pop songs and his flamboyant clothes, died here on Sunday. He was 68.

title: Mans Decades-Old Burglary Conviction Is Vacated in Brooklyn
description: As he made his way through immigration at Kennedy International Airport after returning to New York from Barbados, Michael Waithe was stopped.

title: R.K. Laxman, Cartoonist Who Amused India for Decades, Dies at 93
description: R. K. Laxman, a fixture of Indian society whose satirical comic strip featuring a character he called the Common Man appeared daily on the front page of The Times of India for more than five decades, died on Jan. 26 in the western Indian city of Pune. He was 93.

title: A Hearing on Housing in Detroit Draws a Reluctant Crowd
description: DETROIT  It is the sort of convention no city wants to host.

title: The Case of Etan Patz
description: The disappearance of Etan Patz, a 6-year-old boy, gripped New York City in 1979 and the years that followed.

title: A Fragile Circle of Love, Doomed at Every Turn
description: A Month in the Country feels like a week in the gulag  or perhaps I should say a stint in a minimum-security prison?  in the Classic Stage Companys listless staging of Ivan Turgenevs melancholy comedy of romantic misalliances and infatuations. The production, which opened on Thursday night, stars two performers riding high on television fame: Taylor Schilling, the jailed Piper Chapman of Orange Is the New Black, portrays the restless, disaffected heroine, Natalya, and Peter Dinklage, from Game of Thrones, is her ardent admirer, Rakitin.

title: Whats the Point of an Eating Utensil?
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  David Phillips is back with a 66-worder that definitely shows how younger constructors can bring us the freshest puzzles. He has some interesting points to make about this puzzle, so Ill briefly talk about some of the highlights and then skedaddle out of his way.

title: Saudi King Hands Out Pink Slips and Bonuses
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Less than a week after ascending the throne, King Salman of Saudi Arabia issued an array of royal decrees on Thursday  abolishing government bodies, changing ministers, dismissing the chief of intelligence and further consolidating his own authority.

title: What to Wear? First Ladies Are Steeped in Protocol
description: WASHINGTON  The first lady, Michelle Obama, bared her head in Saudi Arabia, but covered it at the Vatican and at an Indonesian mosque. Laura Bush wore a head scarf only briefly in Saudi Arabia and to tour the Dome of the Rock in Jerusalem. Hillary Rodham Clinton covered her head in Eritrea, the West Bank and Pakistan, but did not in Saudi Arabia.

title: Field Thins Quickly in Contest for New Assembly Speaker
description: ALBANY  The magic number is 76. And on Thursday, State Assemblyman Carl E. Heastie appeared to be tantalizingly close to, or past, that threshold and thus on the precipice of ascending to the soon-to-be-vacant speakership of the New York Assembly.

title: Race for Assembly Speaker Is a Fight Until the End
description: As fast as Assemblywoman Catherine Nolan speaks  and there are few in public life who can, like her, reel off complete, properly punctuated sentences with dependent clauses at 60 miles per hour  she could not keep up with the call-waiting beep on her phone on Thursday afternoon.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 29, 2015
Events in Westchester for Feb. 1-7, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Oscars Animated Shorts Roundup
description: The New York Times film critic A. O. Scott shares his thoughts on the Academy Award nominees for best animated short film.

title: N.Y.P.D. Plans Initiatives to Fight Terrorism and Improve Community Relations
description: The future of the New York Police Department will include patrol officers with more time to visit with community members and learn their concerns.

title: As Diva Is Cheered, Protester Climbs Onto Stage at the Met Opera
description: A protester carrying a sign criticizing the policies of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia climbed over the orchestra pit and onto the stage at the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday night as the diva Anna Netrebko took her curtain call after performing the title role in Tchaikovskys Iolanta.

title: With Sweeping Plastics Ban, New York Village Joins Environmental Vanguard
description: HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.  When New York City recently announced that it was banning plastic foam food containers, the move was hailed by environmentalists as historic.

title: Two Infants Die in New York in Unrelated Episodes
description: Two infants died on Thursday morning in separate episodes in Manhattan and Brooklyn, the authorities said.

title: Behind the Scenes, Network Production Crews Find a Friendlier Belichick
description: Bill Belichicks funereal demeanor is so rooted in the public imagination that any smile or moment of loquaciousness is like finding a great prize in a Cracker Jack box. You cherish little diversions like the one at Super Bowl media day on Tuesday when he talked about a hand-held monkey puppet.

title: The Worst 4th-Down Decisions in Super Bowl History
description: Tom Landry made the mistake in two different Super Bowls. Marv Levy, the longtime Bills coach, made it in an excruciating loss to the Giants in 1991. Mike Tomlin, Mike Martz and Lovie Smith have all done it, too. Perhaps most surprisingly, Bill Belichick has done it multiple times in his Super Bowl appearances.

title: Lundqvists Lone Mistake Is One Too Many as Rangers Fall to Canadiens
description: For much of Thursday nights Rangers-Canadiens game, two of the N.H.L.s best goaltenders showed just how good they are.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Jan. 30
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images of winter footwear and scenes from Joe Franklins office and Times Square.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 30, 2015
description: If one thing is lacking, O.K. If there are no automobile parts, well see. Food, thats problematic. But health care, thats more problematic. Where will it end?

title: Martha A. Derthick, Analyst Who Untangled Public Policy, Dies at 81
description: Martha A. Derthick, a political scientist whose trenchant analyses of typically impenetrable subjects like Social Security, federalism, deregulation and tobacco litigation were praised as masterful and definitive, died on Jan. 12 at a hospital in Charlottesville, Va. She was 81.

title: Recipes From a Chef Beloved by Artists
description: Mina Stone just wants to be able to feed everyone. Every menu is sort of structured around everybody, whether theyre vegetarian or vegan or meat eaters, being able to be satisfied by a dish, says the Brooklyn-based personal chef who, for the past nine years, has made a name for herself in the New York art scene. She prepares lunch three days a week for the artist Urs Fischer and his staff at his Red Hook studio, serves post-opening dinners for the gallerist Gavin Brown and cooks for the painter Elizabeth Peyton. Fittingly, Stone also admits to developing recipes based on color: When you look at your plate, she says, I feel like all those items should be really beautiful together.

title: Surge in Subprime Loans Linked to Cars Draws Regulatory Scrutiny
description: It is a tempting offer: Convert that beaten-up car in the driveway into hard cash with a simple loan.

title: Word of the Day | impasse
description: impasse \im-pas, im-\ noun

title: Global Warming: What Should Be Done?
description: This nationwide survey asked people for their views on whether global warming will be beneficial or detrimental, about how the president and Congress have responded to it, and what they believe government should do about it.

title: The New York Times/Stanford University Poll on Global Warming
description: An overwhelming majority of the American public, including nearly half of Republicans, support government action to curb global warming, according to the poll.

title: Suge Knight, Music Executive, Is Questioned by Police in Hit-and-Run
description: The Los Angeles County Sheriffs Department on Friday morning questioned Marion Knight, the hip-hop music executive known as Suge, who was believed to have been involved in a hit-and-run that left one pedestrian dead and another hospitalized in Compton, Calif., a day earlier.

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 9 P.M. (13); 10 P.M. (49) SHAKESPEARE UNCOVERED Actors and directors tour some of Shakespeares greatest works in this series, which begins a second season. Hugh Bonneville, who began his career at the Open Air Theater in Regents Park in London understudying Ralph Fiennes as Lysander in A Midsummer Nights Dream, goes to see the play on Midsummer Night at the Globe Theater. There he speaks with the artistic director, Dominic Dromgoole, and the actor David Walliams; looks back at performances by James Cagney and Helen Mirren and settings by the directors Peter Brook and Julie Taymor; and offers some musings of his own. At 10, Christopher Plummer takes on King Lear, a role he has played to acclaim under the direction of Jonathan Miller, by delving into the plays history, pondering how the storm scenes might have been produced at Shakespeares own theater and looking at some alternate endings. Ian McKellen and Simon Russell Beale share their insights as well.

title: China to Tally Suicides by Civil Servants
description: China will begin tabulating deaths of officials after a spate of suicides last year raised questions about the effects of the countrys continuing anticorruption campaign.

title: Corrections: January 30, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Koch Money in 2016
description: To the Editor

title: Resettling Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: Skip the Fraternity Parties
description: To the Editor:

title: Child Health and Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: Can Students Have Too Much Tech?
description: PRESIDENT OBAMAs domestic agenda, which he announced in his State of the Union address this month, has a lot to like: health care, maternity leave, affordable college. But there was one thing he got wrong. As part of his promise to educate American children for an increasingly competitive world, he vowed to protect a free and open Internet and extend its reach to every classroom and every community.

title: A Huge Victory for Homeless Veterans
description: The Veterans Affairs Department is going to provide housing for disabled homeless veterans on the vast property it owns in Los Angeles. On Wednesday, it announced an agreement with plaintiffs in a lawsuit that restores the West Los Angeles V.A. campus to serving veterans in need, by housing them there, and by ending the practice of leasing parts of the 387-acre property to outside parties in deals that do not meet the goal of serving veterans.

title: Rabbits and Rebels
description: The babies came one after the other in my family, six in eight years time, then a miscarriage, a seventh, and finally a dire medical warning: An eighth child might leave the rest without the young woman who had brought us into this world. My mother went to her general practitioner first, then the Roman Catholic bishop. The doctor said stop. The cleric said shame if you do.

title: Europes Greek Test
description: In the five years (!) that have passed since the euro crisis began, clear thinking has been in notably short supply. But that fuzziness must now end. Recent events in Greece pose a fundamental challenge for Europe: Can it get past the myths and the moralizing, and deal with reality in a way that respects the Continents core values? If not, the whole European project  the attempt to build peace and democracy through shared prosperity  will suffer a terrible, perhaps mortal blow.

title: Defining the Middle Class
description: To the Editor:

title: Being Who We Are
description: In the middle of 2013, the United States began supporting moderate rebels in Syria. We gave them just enough support to betray them.

title: No Case for Killing the Medical Device Tax
description: In seeking to dismantle the Affordable Care Act piece by piece, congressional Republicans have placed a high priority on repealing a tax on medical devices that would raise some $29 billion over the next 10 years to help ensure that health reform will not increase the deficit. Repealing the tax is a terrible idea that has been given a veneer of respectability by support from liberal Democrats in states with large concentrations of device manufacturers. They include Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, Senators Amy Klobuchar and Al Franken of Minnesota and Representative Ron Kind of Wisconsin, among others. President Obama ought to veto any bill that eliminates the tax.

title: Requiem for a Friend, and for Empathy
Washington and Havana Break the Ice
description: A couple of years after Americas attempted invasion of Cuba in 1961, the disastrous intervention known as the Bay of Pigs, an envoy President John F. Kennedy secretly dispatched to Havana posed an odd question to the Cuban leader, Fidel Castro.

title: For V.A. Hospitals (and Patients), a Major Health Victory
description: Earlier this month, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced that the United States is making modest progress in bringing down rates of hospital-acquired infections.

title: Qatar Airways Acquires 9.99% Stake in British Airways Parent
description: PARIS  Qatar Airways said on Friday that it had acquired a 9.99 percent stake in the International Airlines Group, the parent company of British Airways and Iberia of Spain, deepening an existing commercial partnership with the group and further extending the emirate's push into Europe.

title: The Lessons of the Michelle Obama Head Scarf Hoo-Ha
description: Leave the real world to enter the alternate fashion-verse (a.k.a. the couture shows) for a few days, and what happens? A faux fashion scandal! Such is the irony of this life. Still, it contains an important lesson.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Jerome Jarre: The Making of a Vine Celebrity
description: In Jerome Jarre: The Making of a Vine Celebrity, Nick Bilton writes about how a 20-something with $400 to his name became an international celebrity through social media.

title: Test Yourself | From the Campaign Trail to a Storage Locker in Queens
description: Here are several paragraphs from a Jan. 27 article, All the Presidents Memorabilia.

title: Honda Cuts Profit Forecast for Year as It Deals With Recalls
description: TOKYO  Facing mounting costs to recall cars containing potentially deadly airbag defects, the Japanese automaker Honda Motor on Friday cut its profit forecast for the year by more than $400 million.

title: A Mothers Illness, a Daughters Duty
description: Though it is nothing she would have wished for, in a relatively short time Nancy Borowick became an expert in photographing death.

title: Are You a Saver or a Spender?
description: Do you spend money easily? Do you always want new clothes, music or gadgets? Or are you more frugal and careful with your cash?

title: Fall in Eurozone Prices Inflames Fears of Deflation
description: FRANKFURT  Consumer prices in the 19-country eurozone fell in January for a second consecutive month, compared with a year earlier, according to data released Friday.

title: British Regulators Assessing Loan Insurance Compensation Efforts
description: LONDON  British regulators said on Friday that they had begun a review of the efforts that banks have taken to compensate consumers who were improperly sold a contentious insurance product costing the industry billions of dollars in claims.

title: Are Vitamin Drinks a Bad Idea?
description: Companies are increasingly adding vitamins and minerals to juices, sports drinks and bottled water, responding to a growing consumer demand for these products. Even though the amounts of added nutrients in these drinks are typically small, some nutrition scientists are concerned that through their overall diets, many people may be ingesting levels of vitamins and other nutrients that are not only unnecessary, but potentially harmful.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: U.S. to Collect Genetic Data to Hone Care
description: WASHINGTON  Saying that the possibilities are boundless, President Obama on Friday announced a major biomedical research initiative, including plans to collect genetic data on one million Americans so scientists could develop drugs and treatments tailored to the characteristics of individual patients.

title: New York Today: Snow Day Fashion
description: Greetings on this mild, sloppy, snowy Friday.

title: China Warns Against Western Values in Imported Textbooks
description: In law school at Peking University in the late 1970s, Li Keqiang, now Chinas premier, was an avid student of English and helped translate texts that gave his generation its first, exhilarating exposure to Western legal ideals after the death of Mao.

title: Daily Report: How Apple Surpassed Microsoft
description: When Microsoft stock was at a record high in 1999, and its market capitalization was nearly $620 billion, the notion that Apple Computer would ever be bigger  let alone twice as big  was laughable. Apple was teetering on bankruptcy. And Microsofts operating system was so dominant in personal computers, then the center of the technology universe, that the government deemed the company an unlawful monopoly, James B. Stewart writes in his Common Sense column.

title: As Venezuelan Oil Prices Drop, Social Programs Suffer
description: As the price of oil, the countrys main export, has plunged in recent weeks, the economic situation has grown dire.

title: South Africa Grants Parole to a Death-Squad Leader
description: South Africa has granted parole to Eugene de Kock, the convicted death-squad leader widely known as Prime Evil because of his torture of black activists during the apartheid era, after he served two decades in prison, the Justice Ministry said on Friday.

title: Q. and A. With Charles Plosser of the Fed: Raise Rates Sooner Rather Than Later
description: The Federal Reserve issued a unanimous policy statement for the first time in half a year on Wednesday, but that doesnt mean internal differences have dissipated.

title: Today in Politics
description: The Talent Primary: No One Votes, but Results May Determine Race

title: Romney Email Raises Intrigue About a 2016 Run
description: Mitt Romney appears poised to decide whether he will pursue another presidential bid.

title: Q. and A.: Roderick MacFarquhar on Xi Jinpings High-Risk Campaign to Save the Communist Party
description: Two years into Xi Jinpings tenure as Chinas president, many analysts consider him to be the most powerful leader since Deng Xiaoping, the man who oversaw Chinas opening to the world and its market-oriented policies after the chaos of the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution. Roderick MacFarquhar, a scholar of elite Communist Party politics at Harvard University, goes one step further. Mr. Xi, he says, is the most powerful Chinese leader since Chairman Mao Zedong, the Great Helmsman who declared the founding of the Peoples Republic in 1949 and was worshiped almost as a god by millions of fanatical Red Guards.

title: Jay Z Bids for a Swedish Streaming Company to Expand His Empire
description: Jay Z, the rap star and entrepreneur, has made a $56 million offer for the Swedish company Aspiro, the owner of two digital music services, in a deal that would give him a foothold in the rapidly expanding world of streaming music and put him in competition with major players like Apple and Spotify.

title: Morning Agenda: Crackdown on Car Title Loans
description: CRACKDOWN ON LOANS LINKED TO CARS | Car title loans, which allow owners to borrow money against their cars, are under fire, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Michael Corkery report in DealBook. On Friday, the Federal Trade Commission is expected to announce that it has reached a settlement with two car title lenders, First American Title Lending and Finance Select, over suspicions that they misled borrowers by failing to accurately disclose the terms and costs of the loans, according to people briefed on the action. The agreement will require the companies, both based in Georgia, to overhaul how they advertise and promote their loans, the people said.

title: Neither Rain Nor Snow Nor Lack of Transit
description: Kyle Massey is an assistant news editor. He has worked at The Times since 1999.

title: Fallen Hip-Hop Mogul Is Charged With Killing a Man He Struck With His Vehicle
description: Marion Knight, the former chief executive of Death Row Records, who is better known as Suge, was arrested in West Hollywood on Friday on suspicion of murder after the authorities said the vehicle he was driving struck two men in the parking lot of a fast-food restaurant.

title: Popcast: Bjrk Gets Personal
description: Bjrks new album Vulnicura, released two months ahead of schedule last week as an emergency response to a leak, is a record about heartbreak and estrangement, and based in real events. But the string arrangements are astringent and intense, the beats spacious or chopped-up, and her lyrics refuse to default in revenge or self-pity. Shes looking for safety, clarity, and the right way to mourn the end of one family construct and to build another. Dont remove my pain, she sings in Notget. It is my chance to heal.

title: Perfectly Reasonable Question: Why the Signed Editorials?
description: A reader, Myron Farber, who was also a longtime Times reporter, writes with a question Ive heard from others. He mentioned a recent editorial signed by Brent Staples and observed:

title: Gunman Who Killed 3 Americans Was Said to Wear Afghan Military Uniform
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The gunman who killed three American military contractors at Kabuls international airport on Thursday was wearing an Afghan military uniform, the authorities said on Friday. The Taliban hailed the attack, but it was not clear whether they were claiming direct responsibility for it.

title: Sometimes Heartbreak Takes a Hostage
description: REYKJAVIK, ICELAND  It wasnt exactly a beach day. It was a chilly, damp November morning with a drizzle that turned intermittently to rain. Bjrk called it sniffle weather; she and a video crew were at Grotta, a lighthouse on a spit of land on the coast here that she has often rented for stretches of isolated songwriting.

title: Whats On This Week Around the World
description: Brussels

title: Reader Idea | For High School Online Newspapers, The Times Offers Inspiration
description: STEAM Lab, a piece inspired by a Times video for The Gator, a school newspaper in Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: Litchi Toxin May Have Caused Mysterious Epidemic in India, Inquiry Finds
description: NEW DELHI  An intensive investigation of a mysterious annual epidemic in northern India in which thousands of young children suffer convulsions, lapse into comas and die has concluded that a toxin found in litchi fruit may be the cause.

title: African Nations Show Progress in Uniting to Beat Back Militants in Nigeria
description: African leaders are stepping up their response to Boko Haram, with Chadian soldiers chasing the militants from a northern Nigerian town and the African Union calling for a 7,500-member regional force to tackle what it called a serious threat to the continent.

title: How to Find the Best Deals on Flights
description: The popular search site Kayak.com handles more than one billion travel booking searches annually, primarily for airfare and hotels.

title: You Googled It, We Answered It
description: What are the most pressing travel questions of 2015?

title: On Slaverys Doorstep in Ghana
description: Mandred Henry was a health care sales rep from Hartford whom people often stopped on the street, saying he was a dead ringer for Morgan Freeman. Throughout his life he identified strongly with his African-American background. He was president of the local N.A.A.C.P. chapter. He remembered his mother keeping her grandmothers slavery manumission papers in her top drawer.

title: A Texas Sniff Test
description: Dear Diary:

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Growth Rate Put at 2.6% as Economy Pulls Ahead
description: Powered by healthy spending from increasingly optimistic consumers, the American economy is emerging as an island of relative strength in the face of renewed torpor and turmoil elsewhere in much of the world.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: Drones at the White House
description: A drone crashed into the White House lawn early Monday.

title: Explosion Kills Dozens at Shiite Mosque in Pakistan
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  An explosion ripped through a Shiite mosque in southern Pakistan during Friday Prayer, killing at least 55 people and wounding at least 59 in an apparent suicide bombing, the police said.

title: A Backdrop for the Color Black
description: Valerie Steele approaches fashion as if it were rocket science.

title: The Gangs All Here
description: Living down the hall from a bosom buddy is the stuff of sitcoms. Consider Lucy and Ethel in I Love Lucy, Seinfeld and Kramer in Seinfeld, or most of the characters in Friends.

title: How the Poll on Global Warming Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/Stanford University/Resources for the Future Poll on global warming is based on telephone interviews conducted Jan. 7 to 22 with 1,006 adults throughout the United States.

title: Most Republicans Say They Back Climate Action, Poll Finds
description: WASHINGTON  An overwhelming majority of the American public, including half of Republicans, support government action to curb global warming, according to a poll conducted by The New York Times, Stanford University and the nonpartisan environmental research group Resources for the Future.

title: The Los Feliz Neighborhood of Los Angeles Gets its First Boutique Hotel
description: The east side of Los Angeles has long been established as the stomping ground of the citys creative class, but a lack of appealing hotels has posed a bit of a challenge for out-of-towners looking to bed down there. That is changing, however, with the arrival of Hotel Covell, a boutique establishment from the hospitality entrepreneur Dustin Lancaster and the interior designer Sally Breer, which opens this weekend above Lancasters beloved Los Feliz hangout Bar Covell.

title: 1940: Finns Engage Russian Army
description: On the north central front  One of the great battles of the war is being fought in the Kushmov sector. The battle began before dawn yesterday [Jan. 29] in an area where there had been relative peace since December 30. The Finns engaged the 54th Red Army Division, which is the only Russian force on the entire northern front still on Finnish territory.

title: Look at This World (Not All of Its Nice)
description: With The Matrix (1999), the Wachowskis made their mark in Hollywood by building a complex and intricate science-fiction universe that operated on its own terms. Their latest film, Jupiter Ascending, due Feb. 6, is a return to that kind of world-building, an adventure film with political undertones and a distinct visual style.

title: Life in Memory and Real Time
description: Richard Linklaters Boyhood  now available in a dual Blu-ray DVD edition from Paramount  may or may not win the Academy Award for best picture in February, but its a safe bet that no movie released in 2014 received more passionate approval.

title: 1890: Duprs Paintings Are Sold
description: One of the most important picture sales of the season thus far took place yesterday [Jan. 30] afternoon at the Petit Gallery. It was the art collection of the late Jules Dupr, the father of the French landscape painting, and the predecessor of Corot and Rousseau in the natural or realistic school of modern art. The handsome galleries were crowded with artists and prominent Parisian amateurs, among whom were noticed and admired a goodly number of the fair sex.

title: In Alzheimers Cases, Financial Ruin and Abuse Are Always Lurking
description: MIDWAY through the film Still Alice, which tracks the growing grip of Alzheimers on a 50-something Columbia University professor, that professor, played by Julianne Moore, stands at a lectern to address an Alzheimers conference. She is holding a yellow highlighter and a copy of her speech.

title: Novak Djokovic Beats Stan Wawrinka to Advance to Australian Open Final
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Sequels can be irresistible. A cast with great chemistry reprising beloved roles in a similar setting is often a formula for entertainment, if not duplication of the originals success.

title: Groups Document Swath of Destruction Left by Boko Haram
description: Thousands of buildings were burned, damaged or destroyed in northern Nigerian towns.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: timing exercise, sugary drinks and keeping the weight off. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Shooting Birdman and Drawing Soccer-Style Cheers
description: With the Birdman cast taking the top prize at the Screen Actors Guild Awards on Sunday, it seemed a good time to revisit the ensembles dynamics.

title: Reply All: The 1.18.15 Issue
description: WHY A GENERATION OF ADOPTEES IS RETURNING TO SOUTH KOREA

title: Black Mirror and the Horrors and Delights of Technology
description: One of the most disturbing moments in the British TV series Black Mirror is what appears to be a passionate love scene. The episode takes place in a version of the future where most people have had small devices, called grains, surgically implanted in their heads that can record and replay their memories on demand. As the encounter progresses, it is revealed that the couple are actually having dull and mechanical sex, their eyes grayed out as they both tune into their grains to watch memories of their previous trysts, from an earlier, steamier time in their relationship.

title: His Qualifications  and Mine
description: While volunteering at a local charity, I became friends with a fellow worker. I considered recommending him for membership to a local service club. The club requires vetting, so I checked him out and discovered that he had been convicted of tax fraud, disbarred from practicing law and sentenced to three years in prison. That ended the possibility of club sponsorship. But our friendship continued. He has now asked me for letters of reference. Would it be unethical for me to write these letters, even with careful wording that my recommendation applies only to the time I have known him? NAME WITHHELD, VANCOUVER, BRITISH COLUMBIA

title: David Duchovny: I Like Fooling Around With Words
description: The actor talks to Taffy Brodesser-Akner about steamy X-Files fan fiction and his new novel, not suitable for Disney.

title: Dive Nights
description: One evening in the fall of 1993, when I was 9, my father climbed into a Dumpster. This was in a Connecticut college town  a place totally unlike Chongqing, the sooty, cacophonous Chinese city where I grew up  that was almost as strange to me as my father was. I had known him for only half a year, which was how long my mother and I had been in the United States; he moved here shortly after I was born.

title: Shake Shack More Than Doubles Its I.P.O. Price in Market Debut
description: Customers have been known to line up for close to an hour to order a burger and some crinkle-cut fries at Shake Shack. On Friday, investors showed an equal amount of enthusiasm for the companys stock.

title: The Economic Benefits of Paid Parental Leave
description: When Larisa Casillas gave birth to a boy two years ago, the Bay Area nonprofit organization where she worked gave her only four weeks of paid leave. But she took more than that, including 12 weeks paid by Californias state family leave program, one of the few of its kind in the nation.

title: Israel Takes New Step to Expand West Bank Housing
description: JERUSALEM  Israel on Friday published bids for the building of 450 new housing units in West Bank settlements, deepening Palestinian anger and eliciting blunt criticism from the United States, which called the move illegitimate, counterproductive and likely to worsen Israel's isolation.

title: Scene from Girlhood
description: The French director Cline Sciammas coming-of-age story features Marieme, a 16-year-old girl who joins a gang in the Paris suburbs.

title: Support Waning, Romney Decides Against 2016 Bid
description: WASHINGTON  On a ski lift high above the powdery slopes of Deer Valley, Utah, Mitt Romney made it clear: His quest for the White House, which had dominated nearly a decade of his life, was coming to a close.

title: The Tricky Calculus of Picking Jameis Winston
description: TAMPA, Fla.  At a downtown park here on April 26, the Sexual Violence Task Force of Tampa Bay will host a Take Back the Night rally, a candlelight vigil and silent march to raise sexual assault awareness.

title: A Clip from the Anticipated New French Film Girlhood
description: In an Oscar season in which the Best Picture frontrunner is named Boyhood, it might seem too easy to give the English-language title of Girlhood to Bande de Filles (Gang of Girls), the third feature, premiering in New York on Friday, from the ascendant French director Cline Sciamma. But in fairness, Sciammas luminously twisty coming-of-age story  that of Marieme, a 16-year-old girl with limited options growing up in the drab towers of one of the toughbanlieues that ring Paris  shares with Linklaters film both a fierce specificity to its time and place and the universal heft of a classic bildungsroman.

title: Tweet of the Week
description: Every year, the Oscar races are likened to political campaigns. Neil Patrick Harris, host of the Feb. 22 Academy Awards ceremony, takes that comparison to its logical conclusion:

title: Lining Up to Receive Aid in Ukraine, Crowd Is Devastated by a Mortar Attack
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  Seven people were killed and at least three wounded in a pair of mortar attacks on the citys west side Friday, including one that hit a crowd of people waiting in line to receive humanitarian aid as fighting raged outside of town.

title: An Internationally Renowned Sculptor Returns to His Down Home Roots
description: Patrick Dougherty created his newest piece on the grounds of the botanical garden in Chapel Hill, just down the way from his home  a log cabin he also built with his own two hands.

title: Reversing Course, Russia Cuts Interest Rate
description: Facing the economic stings of falling oil prices and Western sanctions, the Central Bank of Russia unexpectedly reversed course on Friday, lowering its crucial interest rate after a year of increases.

title: Daughter to Disney: Ill Take the Tiara, You Keep the Prince
description: Our hotel room seemed to radiate with pink glitter. The Disney World staff knew it was my daughters fifth birthday and that she loves everything princess, so they filled our room with princess galore. There was a Rapunzel balloon and a Little Mermaid coloring book and a Cinderella Barbie doll  as if Cinderella could get any skinnier. On the bed was a piece of paper announcing that the next day, my daughter Willa had an appointment at something called The Bibbidi Bobbidi Boutique. Beyond that was a giant pile of sugary confections, like a hyped-up mountain surveying the scene. I reached over and bit off the head of a chocolate Mickey.

title: Video Reviews of Black or White, Girlhood and Hard to Be a God
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Black or White, Girlhood and Hard to Be a God. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Don't Trade Away Our Health
description: A secretive group met behind closed doors in New York this week. What they decided may lead to higher drug prices for you and hundreds of millions around the world.

title: Bleak Report For Quarter From Mattel
description: The toymaker Mattel on Friday promised to take swift action to reverse years of sales declines as it released grim earnings, just days after the abrupt resignation of its chief executive.

title: Does Political Correctness Work?
description: Ive spent a few days traveling, so Ive had time to mull over what kind of intervention might be useful in the debate kicked off by Jonathan Chaits big New York Magazine essay on the alleged return of a speech-policing, debate-squelching, illiberal P.C.left. The critical response has ranged from the splutteringto the dismissive, with the latter being seemingly the sophisticated left-wing take: There is no such thing as political correctness, the term is just a tool used by privileged white men to marginalize the legitimate arguments of the less-privileged, Chaits lament is the latest iteration in a long tradition of internet-era complaints from prominent columnists confronted with tough criticism from outside their comfort zone, except now the criticism making him uncomfortable iscoming from Twitterers instead of netroots types, etc.

title: Verizon Wireless to Allow Complete Opt Out of Mobile Supercookies
description: Verizon Wireless, which has been under fire by privacy advocates since late last year, has decided to make a major revision to its mobile ad-targeting program. Users who do not want to be tracked with an identifier that Verizon uses for ad-targeting purposes will soon be able to completely opt out, the company said on Friday.

title: Aftermath of Pakistan Mosque Explosion
description: More than 40 people were killed and scores wounded after a suicide attack at a Shiite mosque in Shikarpur, Pakistan.

title: Biden Says G.O.P. Will Try to Steal Credit for Better Economy
description: PHILADELPHIA  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Friday warned Democrats that if they did not speak up and take credit for the economic recovery, Republicans would try to steal the credit for themselves.

title: Islamic Militants Surprise Kurds in Iraq, Killing a Commander in a Day of Attacks
description: BAGHDAD  Exploiting a foggy night as cover, Islamic State militants launched a surprise attack on Iraqi Kurdish positions on the outskirts of Kirkuk early Friday, killing a senior Kurdish commander and at least five of his men, security officials in the city said.

title: Reader Mailbag: Why Does Josh Barro Hate the Merely Affluent?
description: In my article Thursday on President Obamas failed plan to curtail tax preferences for college savings accounts, which benefit mostly people with higher incomes, I called out the merely affluent  people with family incomes of, say, $175,000  for pleading poverty and putting themselves off limits for tax increases.

title: Mortgage Shopping and Credit Scores
description: Borrowers need not avoid shopping around for the best mortgage deal out of fear that allowing multiple lenders to pull, or check, their credit will chip away at their score.

title: Historians Sift the Ruins for Fergusons Legacy
description: DELLWOOD, Mo.  Amid the ashes and the shards of glass, Juanita Morris found remnants of her life before Nov. 24. There was the foam mannequin head that once showcased hats, now charred from the fire. A leopard-print blouse still clung to a melted hanger. And the sewing machine she used for alterations lay buried and crumpled in the wreckage of her store, Fashions R Boutique.

title: Letter From the Editor: Whos Really Middle Class?
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: Oscar Shorts in Theaters
description: Its that time in the season when you can get ahead of your Oscar ballot competitors by seeing all the nominated shorts. Those shorts open in theaters nationwide  Friday in three feature-length compilations: animated, live-action and documentary.

title: Churchills Funeral, and the Perils of Staying Home
description: Sir Winston Churchill  who, as Franklin Roosevelts partner during World War II, was the most consequential British ally in American history  was honored and buried in England 50 years ago today, but neither the American president nor vice president was present.

title: Audio of Mitt Romneys Call to Supporters
description: Our friend Alex Leary from The Tampa Bay Times posted an audio clip of Mitt Romneys call to supporters today, embedded below:

title: Chevron to Abandon Shale Natural Gas Venture in Poland
description: LONDON  Chevron said on Friday that it would abandon efforts to find and produce natural gas from shale rock in Poland, in perhaps the biggest setback yet to fledgling efforts to start a European shale oil and gas industry that might help replace the regions dwindling fuel resources.

title: Quiz: Our Genetically Modified Diet
description: How much of what we eat is genetically modified?

title: Many G.M.O.-Free Labels, Little Clarity Over Rules
description: Few industry debates are as heated these days as the one about labeling foods that contain genetically modified ingredients.

title: $33 Million Penthouse on Central Park West
description: A fully renovated penthouse near the top of the Trump International Hotel and Tower, with picture-book park, river or cityscape views from each of its oversize windows, sold for $33,000,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Inside the List
description: Children of Divorce: Alexandra Fullers third memoir, Leaving Before the Rains Come  No. 10 on the hardcover nonfiction list  is also her third best seller, following Dont Lets Go to the Dogs Tonight (about her childhood in war-torn Rhodesia) and Cocktail Hour Under the Tree of Forgetfulness (about her indomitable mother). Fullers new book describes the collapse of her marriage, and in a recent interview with the Times reporter Penelope Green she bristled at the idea that she would have shown a draft to her ex-husband. Theres almost this expectation you need to get approval, she said. I doubt Ernest Hemingway was asked what his ex-wives thought of his writing. I think women have to stop asking for permission. She didnt say, though, whether she had shared the memoir with her children, who are 21, 17 and 9. So I asked. Theres a very fine line, she said by phone from Washington, D.C., where she was on book tour, between protecting your children, as you should, and smothering them to the point that they dont know whats going down in the world. She had offered to show relevant passages to her older two, and Sarah, the 21-year-old, took her up on it. Shes a fantastic writer in her own way, Fuller said. At the same time I was working on this book, she wrote an essay about the divorce for her student magazine. It was so poignant. My ex-husband read it and said, Thats not what happened. But of course it was totally from her perspective. Its another prism. Were reading each others stuff now not just as people who were personally involved, but as writers able to appreciate each others talent. And her 17-year-old son? Fuller laughed. He has better boundaries than anyone I know. He said, Mum, I lived it. I dont need to read it.

title: German and British Regulators Examining Deutsche Banks Controls and Reporting
description: LONDON  German and British regulators are examining Deutsche Banks systems and controls as questions have again arisen about the German lenders reporting procedures.

title: A Daughters Promise, a Mothers Story
description: Shortly before Mia Slavenska died in 2002, Maria Ramas, her daughter, made a promise: to tell her story. She had spent many years feeling, as many artists do who outlive their fame and their time of creativity, that the dance world wouldnt remember her and her contribution, Ms. Ramas said in an interview. It was really difficult for her to make peace with that.

title: As Measles Cases Spread in U.S., So Does Anxiety
description: The measles outbreak tied to Disneyland continued to spread anxiety Friday as two new cases emerged overnight in Marin County in California  along with at least one in Nebraska  while Arizona officials warned that at least 1,000 people may have been exposed to the virus through seven others in that state.

title: Anne Enright Is Irelands First Fiction Laureate
description: LONDON  The Irish Arts Council has announced that the Man Booker prize-winning novelist Anne Enright will serve as Irelands first laureate for fiction.

title: Former London Trader Sentenced to Seven Years in Investment Scheme
description: LONDON  A trader who reportedly once spent more than $300,000 on drinks on a single night out was sentenced to seven years in prison after he was convicted of fraud in an investment scheme that authorities say took in 5 million pounds, or about $7.55 million, from investors.

title: In Berlin, a New Shop That Offers Much More Than Shopping
description: Spanning the lower levels of the private club Soho House Berlin in the citys Mitte district, a new space officially opening this weekend  called, simply, the Store  offers just about everything a creative professional might want under one roof: a place to work, to play and to indulge in a bit of spending.

title: Law Creates Special Savings Accounts for Disabled People
description: People with disabilities, and their families, will soon have a tax-favored way to save money for a range of expenses.

title: Hall of Small Mammals, byThomas Pierce
description: There was that moment starting in the late 1980s when the culture was seized with so-called recovered memories. Some were clearly real, but a surprising number couldnt have been; they were too fantastic  elephants butchered in church basements, ordinary suburban parents gathered on the outskirts of town, in forests, to perform satanic rituals (though really, who wouldnt thrill at the idea of ones mother doing that while one slept?). A lot of the stories came from children, so one hesitated to call them lies. They were fictions. They were the great outrageous stories made up to express the more regular feelings of loss or disenchantment or anger.

title: Jenny Uglows In These Times
description: Most Americans probably have an indistinct idea of the warfare between Britain and France at the turn of the 19th century. So far as Britain is concerned, we are likely to recall that Admiral Nelson won a great victory in 1805 at Trafalgar, off the coast of Spain, and was mortally wounded during the battle. In words that became famous, he had signaled to his fleet, England expects that every man will do his duty. We are likelier to remember the Duke of Wellingtons triumph at Waterloo 10 years later, which ended Napoleons sensational career. A comment Wellington supposedly made afterward is also frequently quoted, that the engagement had been a damned close-run thing. And as a sidelight to the international conflict there was our own American War of 1812, during which Francis Scott Key was inspired to write his verses about the rockets red glare and bombs bursting in air.

title: A Theory of the Drone, by Grgoire Chamayou
description: For thousands of years, the outstanding characteristic of war was the violent interaction known as fighting. It was the fighters willingness and ability to cope with and overcome danger that distinguished them from assassins and often made them into heroes  alive or dead  deserving of the highest rewards society could bestow.

title: Trespassers, Beware!
description: Its always the voice, the singular sound of a place like none other, that draws you into a regional mystery. In Tom Coopers first novel, THE MARAUDERS (Crown, $26), that beguiling music comes out of the Louisiana bayous, where a raucous chorus of shrimp fishermen, marijuana growers, treasure hunters, professional crooks and common thieves fight to be heard.

title: Only One Thing Can Save Us, by Thomas Geoghegan
description: Thomas Geoghegan, a veteran labor lawyer, wants his book read by upscale liberals who worry about income inequality and the vanishing middle class but who turn up their noses at all those stolid unions still clinging to life in urban America. Properly reconstituted, Geoghegan insists, the labor movement can save us, and by us he means the country as a vibrant democracy, and a Democratic Party that has lost millions of working-class voters either to apathy or to the Republicans.

title: Letters: Among the Disrupted
description: Among the Disrupted

title: The Girl on the Train, by Paula Hawkins
description: Alfred Hitchcock may have said all there is to say about the fallibility of making assumptions about what you see through a window, but, like most important lessons, this one can bear some repeating. To the limited scope of a window frame, the former London journalist Paula Hawkins, in her debut thriller, The Girl on the Train, offers a few additional obfuscations. First, her novels protagonist, Rachel, looks out through the window of a moving train on her daily commute. Second, Rachel is your basic hot mess: depressed, unemployed, still in mourning for the death of her marriage and prone to alcoholic blackouts that coincide with critical moments in the tale of a missing woman later found dead. Rachel might as well be wearing a sign that reads Unreliable Narrator.

title: They Eat Horses, Dont They? by Piu Marie Eatwell
description: French women do get fat. Their children do throw food. And they dont look the other way when their husbands cheat.

title: The Girl From Human Street, by Roger Cohen
description: In the years around the turn of the 20th century, Roger Cohens family joined the mass exodus of Jews out of their long, mostly dismal residency in the Pale of Settlement. Like thousands of their Lithuanian landsmen, Cohens relatives headed for the sunny, still-undeveloped, resource-rich country of South Africa. In this new world they began with nothing, worked hard and achieved much. As is often true of successful immigrant families, their grandchildren could live as though the old world had never been. Cohens father became a doctor, his mother was college educated. Both were raised with the comforts that only numerous servants can provide: They never had to boil an egg, Cohen writes. Being a Jew in South Africa was not unlike being a Jew in the American South: Anti-Semitism was not absent, but it was greatly mitigated by a segregated black underclass all but legally enslaved.

title: The Sacrifice, by Joyce Carol Oates
description: Writing difference is a challenge, particularly in fiction. How do men write women and vice versa? How do writers of one race or ethnicity write about people of another race or ethnicity? More important, how do writers tackle difference without reducing their characters to caricatures or stereotypes? Some handle the challenge with aplomb. Bill Chengs Southern Cross the Dog and Louise Erdrichs The Round House come to mind. Others fail: At one point in Kathryn Stocketts The Help, a black woman compares her skin color with that of a cockroach. To write difference well demands empathy, an ability to respect the humanity of those you mean to represent.

title: Scott Blackwoods See How Small
description: On the busy corner of Rockwood and West Anderson Lanes in north Austin, Tex., stands a beige-bricked strip mall. At first glance, nothing about it is remarkable.
