The usual suspects  Jimmy Johns, a pet grooming shop  line the row of one-story facades. Near one end, Classy Nails Spa is wedged between a hair salon and a furniture showroom. In a bed of white granite rocks shaded by an oak, a bronze plaque commemorates the lives of four young women  Amy Ayers, Eliza Thomas, and Sarah and Jennifer Harbison.

title: David Adams The Man Who Couldnt Stop
description: One cold Northern England evening in November 1990, when David Adam was a first-year college student in Leeds, he enjoyed an encouraging first date with a young woman that culminated in a bit of physical intimacy ending somewhere short of intercourse. The next day when a friend asked Adam if he had sex with the woman, he lied in the traditional manner of boastful, insecure young men everywhere and said that he had, without a condom. You could have AIDS, the friend said. That wasnt true  or was, at most, exceedingly unlikely. Nevertheless, the idea lodged in Adams mind, where it set about establishing permanent residency. By the following summer, the fear that he might already have AIDS, or would someday contract it, had hijacked his brain. The snowflake of a single intrusive thought, as he puts it, had become a blizzard that blew the snow into every corner of my mind, and laid down a blanket that muffled every surface. For the next 20 years, Adam was consumed by the fear that he had contracted, or would contract, H.I.V.: He called the National AIDS Helpline so many times daily that the half-dozen staffers there came to recognize his voice; he got blood tests; he compulsively examined and re-examined every red stain he ever came across to determine whether it might be AIDS-tainted blood, and whether it might somehow have contaminated him. He knew this to be irrational  he was a science writer!  yet he couldnt resist his compulsions. He had developed obsessive-compulsive disorder, or O.C.D.

title: Reading in Transit
description: Peeking at what your fellow passengers are reading is a time-honored sport on the New York subway. The Amsterdam-based photographer Reinier Gerritsen captures his peeks for posterity in The Last Book, a collection of candid photos of subterranean readers. Gerritsen comes to New York for two weeks three times a year and spent 13 weeks shooting straphangers for the project. No e-readers were allowed. I read only printed books, Gerritsen said via email, though he owned up to having an iPad.

title: Ideas of Order, by Neil L. Rudenstine
description: Time has formed its judgment on the 154 poems that make up what we call Shakespeares sonnets. Most are known to some and some are known to all. Eight or 10 are probably here for as long as we are, two or three perhaps longer, lighting out for deep space in binary code, beyond praise or burial. Any critical word a living poet might say about them now would necessitate the wearing of a jesters motley  with first-person I as ones little stick to shake  so excuse me while I don this costume, leaf haplessly hither and thither through all 154 and cry that I would take the least of the plays over the whole blooming thing.

title: Editors Choice
description: GHETTOSIDE: A True Story of Murder in America, by Jill Leovy. (Spiegel & Grau, $28.) Focusing on South Los Angeles, Leovy examines the circumstances of the countrys disturbingly high rate of murders of African-American men.

title: Paperback Row
description: PRISCILLA: The Hidden Life of an Englishwoman in Wartime France,  by Nicholas Shakespeare. (Harper Perennial, $15.99.) Shakespeare knew that Priscilla Thompson, his glamorous but enigmatic aunt, had lived in Vichy France, and family lore even had her jailed by the Gestapo for her work in the Resistance. But long after her death in 1982, the author has pieced together a far more intriguing story: that of a femme fatale who made painful compromises to survive the Nazi occupation.

title: Yannick Nzet-Sguin Extends Philadelphia Orchestra Contract
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra extended the contract of its dynamic music director, Yannick Nzet-Sguin, through the 2021-22 season, the orchestra announced Friday.

title: Short Stories
description: SINGLE, CAREFREE, MELLOW  Stories  By Katherine Heiny  Knopf, $23.95.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties include a five-bedroom house in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and a three-bedroom condo in Weehawken, N.J.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties include co-ops in Carnegie Hill, on the Upper East Side and in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Every Year Is the Year of the Dumpling
description: Dumplings are said to bring good fortune, and eating them is a time-honored traditional way to celebrate the Chinese New Year, which falls on Feb. 19 this year. So why not rally a few friends for a little homemade dumpling feast?

title: When Consumers Give Up Their Right to Trial in Financial Disputes
description: Jeff Sovern is a professor of law at St. Johns University School of Law and co-coordinator of the Consumer Law and Policy Blog.

title: Shes the Johnny Appleseed of Pickling
description: If you find yourself wandering near Whale Creek, in an industrial stretch of Long Island City, Queens, and you come across a dilapidated 1986 International Harvester school bus emitting a faint smell of decay, no need to call the authorities.

title: Speaker Candidate Drew Ethics Panels Notice
description: ALBANY  Over $10,000 for car repairs. Hundreds of dollars in interest and finance charges on credit-card balances. Thousands of dollars in expenses for which no explanation was given.

title: Let Them Bake Baguettes
description: Ten years ago, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appeared at a new employment center in the South Bronx to announce an initiative called the Hunts Point Vision Plan, aimed at expanding economic opportunity in an area that although markedly improved from the dereliction of the 1970s, was still not a place distinguished by tasting menus and other signifiers of urban prosperity.

title: Same-Sex Interfaith Couples Face Roadblock to Marriage in Judaism
description: SOMERVILLE, Mass.  When Julia Spiegelman and Erina Donnelly, two teachers who met as undergraduates at Bryn Mawr, became engaged, they were looking forward to planning a wedding that included elements from both of their religions.

title: Mitt Romney Drops Out
description: There are a couple of remarkable aspects to Mitt Romneys announcement that he will not run for president, after all.

title: Ratings Now Cut Both Ways, So Dont Sass Your Uber Driver
description: People routinely use the Internet to review services from plumbers to hairdressers. Now the tables are turned. Companies are rating their customers, shunning those who do not make the grade.

title: An App, Happy, Offers Discounts for Drinkers
description: Happy, known on Android phones as Happy Any Hour, is a new app that allows users to drink on the cheap at participating bars in Brooklyn and downtown Manhattan. Download the app, and suddenly it is as if you have joined a club: A flash of your phone screen suddenly gets you $2 off the Smuttynose I.P.A. that you have been craving.

title: Stuff We Liked: Parking the Car in Harvard Yard (With 11 Permits)
description: What we liked elsewhere on the web this week:

title: Sheldon Silver andNew Yorks Caldron of Corruption
description: Now that Sheldon Silver has been pressured into agreeing to resign as speaker of New Yorks Assembly after his arrest on corruption charges, the governor and the lawmakers who so poorly represent the state should not kid themselves into thinking they have made real progress on cleaning up what the federal prosecutor who indicted Mr. Silver called the caldron of corruption in Albany.

title: Sundance 2015 Video: Festival in Slo-Mo
description: At the Sundance Film Festival this week in Park City, Utah, we asked actors, directors and others to step into our slow-motion booth and perform a 5-section action either from their movie or representative of it. Heres what happened.

title: Chanel vs. the Costume Institute, Amal Clooneys Gown and Naomi Campbell on the Instagirls
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: Etan Patz Trial Starts, 35 Years After Boy Disappeared on SoHo Street
description: The murder trial against a man accused of killing Etan Patz got underway on Friday, with opening statements made in a proceeding that prosecutors hope will finally lay to rest a question that for decades has tormented the Patz family and, in a sense, all of New York City: What really happened to the 6-year-old boy?

title: An Original Seahawk by Way of New England
description: There is a man in South Dakota who, on occasion, will stump people with a trivia question: Can you name the original starting quarterback of the Seattle Seahawks?

title: New Walking Tours in Japan and China
description: Country Walkers, the Vermont walking tour company, will amble east this year, with new trips in Japan and China.

title: Butterflies, Rain, Shelter
description: Draw on Times staff members expertise.

title: Remembering the Neediest: An Inside Look
description: For over 100 years, The Times has provided direct assistance to struggling New Yorkers through the Neediest Cases Fund. Michael McElroy, a copy editor on the Metro desk, led the effort to tell the stories of those whom it helped last year.

title: Harry Reid Wont Take Some Things Lying Down. Like Rest.
description: WASHINGTON  Some of the biggest decisions in Washington these days are being made not at either end of Pennsylvania Avenue, but in a well-appointed one-bedroom condominium at the Ritz-Carlton on M Street.

title: Romneys Withdrawal Is a Reflection of Bushs Strength
description: In renouncing a new run for president Friday, Mitt Romney becomes the first big casualty of the invisible primary  the behind-the-scenes competition for donors, endorsements and campaign operatives.

title: Auditioning for School of Rock
description: An open casting call for School of Rock, the new Broadway musical from Andrew Lloyd Webber, was held recently at the Winter Garden Theater.

title: Video: Vying for a Seat in School of Rock
description: Early in the morning on Jan. 24, hundreds of kids and their tired-looking parents trekked through winter slush to the Winter Garden Theater on Broadway for an open casting call for the musical School of Rock.

title: Managing Health Costs With Crowdfunding
description: SOMETIMES paying for a loved ones health care expenses literally takes a crowd.

title: Miami Tourists to New York City: Let It Snow
description: For many New Yorkers this week, as the blizzard panic lifted from the city, the pressing culinary question on Tuesday was, Now what do I do with all this Dinty Moore? One answer was just to walk away, perhaps to find a table someplace where the snow outside maintained its fleeting Currier & Ives majesties. Why not? With Tavern on the Green shuttered because of the weather, scenic duty fell to the slight remove of the restaurants of the Time Warner Center at Columbus Circle, where the trees of Central Park displayed dustings of white thingamajigs suspended perilously above their inevitable future as unloved street slush. Quiet descended on the city, cocktails and Pat LaFrieda beef products descended on the polished black tables of the Stone Rose Lounge, and stranded tourists consoled themselves for having to spend an extra night in the worlds greatest city. Poor babies.

title: Jack Leggett, Who Cultivated Writers in Iowa, Dies at 97
description: Jack Leggett, who nourished a generation of poets and novelists as director of the University of Iowa Writers Workshop, perhaps the nations pre-eminent graduate program in creative writing, died on Sunday in Napa, Calif. He was 97.

title: Kerry to Meet with Ukrainian Leaders in Kiev
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State John Kerry plans to travel to Ukraine next week and will meet with President Petro O. Poroshenko and other senior Ukrainian leaders, the State Department announced Friday.

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
description: A look back at the week in politics.

title: An Internationally Renowned Sculptor Returns to His Down-Home Roots
description: In this series, the photographer Rinne Allen documents harvests across the South, exploring the many uses of natures seasonal yield.

title: Cauliflower Parmesan
description: Melissa Clark bakes fried cauliflower smothered in tomato sauce, Parmesan and fresh mozzarella.

title: First Draft Focus: Week in Political Pictures
Conductor Dies After Collapsing on Stage
description: GENEVA  The Israeli conductor Israel Yinon collapsed during a youth concert at a Swiss university on Thursday evening and died, a member of the university staff reported.

title: Movie Review: Hard to Be a God
description: The Times critic Nicolas Rapold reviews Hard to Be a God.

title: Romney Out, Scott Walker Makes His (Anti-Washington) Case
description: Less than two hours after Mitt Romney announced that he was not going to make another run at the White House, Gov. Scott Walker, Republican of Wisconsin, made a case for why he might be the man for the job.

title: Movie Review: Black or White
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews Black or White.

title: For Manoush Zomorodi, Time for Some Conscious Unplugging
description: Manoush Zomorodi, the host and managing editor of WNYC public radios New Tech City, a podcast that explores how technology affects the way we live, hasnt been bored in seven years. She traces her condition to 2007, when the iPhone was introduced. Concerned that shes not alone, and that letting the mind wander spurs creativity, Ms. Zomorodi, 41, is spearheading Bored and Brilliant, a seven-day challenge that asks participants to minimize device use and enjoy idle time  with the help of an app. Were trying to embrace the ridiculousness of it, she said. Ms. Zomorodi lives in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, with her husband, Josh Robin, 38, a reporter for NY1, and their son, Kai, 7, and daughter, Soraya, 4.

title: Movie Review: Girlhood
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Girlhood.

title: A Stage Awash in Tears and Blood
description: A new production at the Metropolitan Opera involves weeks of concentrated work, leading to a dress rehearsal and then, usually after a couple of days off, the opening night.

title: What Were Reading Now
description: One year ago next week, President Obama signed the 2014 Farm Bill into law, a piece of legislation that will cut $8.7 billion in food stamp benefits over the next decade. (If that number sounds monstrously high, consider the fact that the Republicans plan would have cut benefits by between $20.5 billion and $39 billion.)

title: Parmigiana Dishes to Warm Weary Souls
description: Its been nearly a half-century since veal parmigiana anchored menus of the fanciest Italian restaurants in America, the kinds of places where tuxedoed waiters were as likely to burst into a Verdi aria as they were to light your cigarette.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York York Region:

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York York City:

title: Daily Mail Buys Site Targeting Millennials
description: The Daily Mail, a British tabloid that became an online behemoth with fast, salacious stories, announced on Friday that it had bought Elite Daily, a website aimed at millennials, as part of a plan to become a larger media conglomerate.

title: Brooding, Nostalgia and Wacky Humor
description: Christopher Durang saves the best speech for last in Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike, the comedic mash-up in which the playwright mixes bits of Anton Chekhov with large doses of his own brand of wacky humor. The play is running at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport through March 8.

title: The Surprising Power of Blue-State Republicans
description: There is a basic mystery at the heart of modern Republican presidential politics. The partys voters, despite electing conservatives to the House and Senate, have repeatedly chosen relatively moderate nominees, like Mitt Romney and John McCain, in the primaries.

title: Insider Tips: Wine in 2015
description: A New Years gift for Times Insiders: a series of inside tips from Times editors and reporters. Eric Asimov, chief wine critic, provides a list of bottles to drink in the new year.

title: The Theater Is His Church
description: As Billy Porter transformed Take the Moment, an obscure song from the Richard Rodgers-Stephen Sondheim musical Do I Hear a Waltz?, into a pop-gospel plea at the Appel Room on Wednesday evening, his performance created the kind of epiphany that a great voice can conjure out of thin air. The key lay not only in Mr. Porters innate vocal power but also in his commitment to shoot the moon, no matter the consequences. His go-for-broke approach recalled singers like Patti LaBelle, for whom there are no halfways and who risk drowning in emotional intensity.

title: Alison Brie on the State of the Rom-Com and the End of Mad Men
description: In the director Leslye Headlands Sleeping With Other People, which premiered at Sundance last week, Alison Brie plays Lainey, a serial cheater whose longing for a stable relationship is constantly railroaded by an obsession with her college crush (Adam Scott). She meets her match when she strikes up a friendship with Jake (Jason Sudeikis), a good-natured womanizer who just happens to have taken her virginity 12 years earlier. At the premiere, Headland described the film as When Harry Met Sally for jerks (though she used a slightly stronger word), which is to say that, like the directors previous effort, Bachelorette, it is more than a little naughty and twisted (and, it follows, a perfect starring vehicle for Brie). The 32-year-old L.A. native has been stealing scenes for the better part of a decade playing type-A characters on Mad Men and Community, and she viewed Headlands film  and its many sex scenes  as an opportunity to try out a new direction. T sat down with the actress in Park City to discuss high-school sweethearts, Sleepless in Seattle and the highly secretive world of Mad Men.

title: True Grits
description: Most life-changing food experiences involve exotic or high-end foods like truffles. But my latest life-changing food experience involved humble grits and polenta  cornmeal mush.

title: A High Court Check on Insider Trading
description: United States insider trading enforcers are making enemies in high places. Their aggressive view of the law has already irked appeals judges, and the Supreme Court may be next. Justice Antonin Scalia may get his long-sought opportunity to rein in Wall Street watchdogs.

title: Till Death Parts Them
description: Some of you have probably been worried about what has become of Rob Lowe since he left the quirky comforts of Pawnee and Parks and Recreation last year. You have good reason to be. Turns out, he married a stripper who had him brutally murdered.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Their Picture Finally Comes Into Focus
description: Four years ago, Kevin McCauley received a Christmas card sent by Kristine Mattson, a woman he dated in high school and college before each took a separate path in the late 1980s, when he went to medical school on the East Coast, and she was married in their native California.

title: A Tom Brady Sneak Is the Patriots Unstoppable Play
description: CHANDLER, Ariz.  The most automatic play in the Patriots offensive playbook over the last 14 seasons involves Tom Brady, but it is not a pass. It is having Brady tuck the ball and lower his shoulder and shimmy into a narrow gap, gaining inch after bruising inch, the quarterback with a fullbacks mentality.

title: Taxing 529 College Savings Plans: A Plan That Went Awry
description: Earlier this week, we were treated to a truly odd Washington spectacle. Just over a week after making a set of pointed policy proposals that had little chance of getting to Congress and surviving intact, President Obama made front-page news by changing his mind about one of the smaller ones.

title: At Your Service: Information Sleuth at the New York Public Library
description: The answer man adjusted his headset, settled into his office chair and faced the next callers question.

title: Exclusive | 300 Central Park West
description: A duplex penthouse perched in one of the majestic twin towers of the Eldorado is poised to enter the market for $29 million.

title: A Scientists View of Planetary Boundaries from the Ground Up  in Rural India
description: Ive been tracking various reactions to the updated assessment of planetary boundaries  nine physical or biological parameters that define a safe operating space for humanity.

title: For Entertaining Grandly
description: A duplex penthouse with four terraces perched in one of the majestic twin towers of the Eldorado, an Art Deco landmark at 300 Central Park West, is poised to enter the market for $29 million.

title: Bill Cunningham | Snow Day
description: With the schools closed, Tuesday was a day in the park for parents, children and dogs.

title: A Bull Market for Shake Shack Burgers
description: The Occupy Wall Street protesters are long gone from Lower Manhattan. But on Friday morning, fanatics of a different sort mobbed a block of Broad Street outside the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Economists Advice on Super Bowl Pick: Follow the Money
description: So, you want to be a football expert, but cant actually be bothered devoting the hours required to understand the intricacies of the game? Let me help. Like you, I know that Im never going to be the most knowledgeable football fan  Ive never played the game, and grew up watching Australian rules football instead  but equally, I dont want to be excluded from water cooler conversations.

title: Roger Goodell Acknowledges Tough Year but Says He Wont Resign
description: PHOENIX  N.F.L Commissioner Roger Goodell saidon Fridaythat he had been chastened by a season of embarrassing scandals, contentious battles and growing distrust, but that he had no intention of resigning.

title: Obama on New Medical Funding Initiative
description: The president discussed a new initiative included in his budget that would fund research into precision medicine, which tailors treatment to genetic and other factors of individual patients.

title: Republican Rivals Shower Praise on Romney Upon His Exit
description: The bickering among potential rivals for the Republican presidential nomination was becoming increasingly tense in recent weeks, but after Mitt Romney announced Friday that he would not be making a third run for the White House, there was nothing but praise.

title: The Myth of the Harmless Wrong
description: SOCIAL conservatives who bemoan the immorality of same-sex marriage typically also decry the harm it wreaks on society. The pundit Alan Keyes calls gay marriage a social weapon of mass destruction, while the North Carolina pastor Michael Barrett argues that widespread gay marriage would be equivalent to a nuclear holocaust.

title: Its 2 A.M. and You Need Tonkatsu
description: Ichibantei has carved out a very particular niche in the East Village, offering the unlikely pairing of home-style Japanese comfort food with a nonstop playlist of roots reggae. A loyal following is drawn to its heartfelt take on classic dishes that include donburi (rice bowls), tonkatsu (deep-fried pork cutlets) and kara-age (Japanese-style fried chicken), as well as $5 beers served in frosted mugs and a variety of sakes.

title: Nearing Cutoff, Victim Claims Pour Into G.M. Program
description: With a midnight Saturday deadline looming, hundreds of death and injury claims have been pouring into General Motors compensation program for victims of accidents caused by a defective ignition switch in millions of small cars.

title: Bill Cunningham | Snow Day
description: With the schools closed, Tuesday was a day in the park for parents, children and dogs. A young mother brought her 10-month-old baby , who looked like an upside-down radish in a green jacket and red hat, and put the child into a plastic bucket for a first sleigh ride. Pedestrians leapt like ballet dancers over slushy curbsides. Tourists ventured into the south end of Central Park. The fountain in Bryant Park was newly frozen, and a group of youngsters had a snow fight using cafeteria trays. A young man built a snowman, chilled wine bottles inside of it, then poured himself a glass. He said it was his birthday.

title: Line Up, Children, Single File
description: Barbara Foley never imagined her daughters would be single at ages 36, 38 and 40.

title: Argentine Leader Pleads For Unity During Inquiry
description: BUENOS AIRES  In a veiled reference to the fallout from the mysterious death of a federal prosecutor this month, President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner of Argentina blamed unspecified forces on Friday for provoking upheaval, pleading with Argentines to remain united and to not let them bring conflicts here that are causing desolation, death and strain on other countries.

title: Senate Democrats to Try to Block Funding Bill Over Immigration
description: Senator Richard J. Durbin, the chambers No. 2 Democrat, said Friday that Senate Democrats would seek to block debate on a House-passed bill to fund the Department of Homeland Security that would cancel President Obamas actions protecting millions of unauthorized immigrants from deportation.

title: Who Is Running for President?
description: Donald J. Trump officially accepted the Republican party's nomination on July 22. Hillary Clinton was officially nominated on July 26 at the Democratic Convention.

title: How to Get Through Cold-and-Flu Season Without Making Enemies
description: Good manners and cold-and-flu season share an uneasy relationship, like spell-check and Chaucer. Consider, for instance, the pale, disheveled gentleman  a guy in that sweet spot of the hipster/homeless Venn diagram  that the artist Andrew Pope said he and about 15 other straphangers stood next to on the F train a few winters ago.

title: Sundance Courts a New Celebrity Crowd
description: PARK CITY, Utah  There was a love fest going on inside the publicist Kari Feinsteins Sundance Style Lounge. Like the dozens of gifting suites that popped up along Main Street during the Sundance Film Festival last week, this one was filled with freebies: leather boots, knitted hats, portable cellphone chargers and, perhaps most outlandishly, a three-night, all-expenses-paid trip to Aruba, valued at $10,000.

title: Street Style at Couture Fashion Week
description: Fashionable looks spotted outside the shows in Paris.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Guantnamo Diary
description: Mark Danner on Guantnamo Diary and David Adam on The Man Who Couldnt Stop.

title: Evening Hours | The Magic of Snow
description: The blizzard that wasnt and two stylish celebrations.

title: Greece Signals Unwillingness to Cooperate With Auditors
description: ATHENS  The new Greek finance minister used a joint appearance with a top eurozone official on Friday to insist that Greece would no longer cooperate with auditors representing its international creditors and would not seek an extension to the countrys bailout program.

title: Schubert, Then and Now
description: The pianist Shai Wosner is probably sick of hearing that he bears a certain physical resemblance to Schubert (though his choice of eyeglasses only fosters the notion). His identification with the composer, however, clearly runs much deeper, as he showed in a superb rendition of the late Sonata in A (D. 959) at the 92nd Street Y on Wednesday evening. The performance was part of a two-concert series, The Schubert Effect, which Mr. Wosner, its curator, is sharing with the Parker Quartet.

title: At Bulgari Hotel Milan, Renowned Chefs Are Guests
description: Guest cooking stints by high-profile chefs at upscale hotels is a certifiable trend, and the Bulgari Hotel Milan has upped the ante with Epicurea, a seven-month food festival.

title: Larry Clark Explores the Subject of Misspent Youths
description: Ive had many, many vices, said Larry Clark, who has made a career of filming and photographing wayward adolescents shuffling through life in a haze of heroin, marijuana and random sex. He may well have been referring to his own errant youth. But now, if a vice remains, it is the occasional tipple.

title: Europes Young Entrepreneurs
description: MADRID  When Jordan Casey took to the stage to present his technology business, he jumped onto the platform rather than walking up the access ramp.

title: The Recital Experience, Expanded
description: Helena Rubinstein, the cosmetics magnate and subject of a current exhibition at the Jewish Museum, didnt want to just sell makeup. She wanted to give her customer what she called a salon experience.

title: Relatives Gather, and Music Ensues
description: Theres no musical generation gap in the Thompson Family Band, which started a sold-out three-night stand at City Winery on Thursday. Richard Thompson, a pioneer and grandmaster of British folk-rock, shared the stage with his children, a grandchild and some helpful in-laws.

title: Book Review Podcast: Guantnamo Diary
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Mark Danner reviews Mohamedou Ould Slahis Guantnamo Diary. Mr. Danner writes:

title: Bush Moves to Shore Up D.C. Money
description: Jeb Bush will be swinging through Washington on Feb. 17., attending two events for his super PAC, Right to Rise, as he looks to lock down big D.C. donors before the first fund-raising deadline.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Bluebeards Castle and Iolanta
description: Images from the Metropolitan Operas new productions of two short operas.

title: Grab Bag of Wit and Pathos
description: Shannon Hummel founded Cora Dance in 1997 as a dance company, but in recent years her organization has branched out in its aims and activities. Committed to increasing access to dance, she has opened a pay-what-you-can community-center studio in Red Hook, Brooklyn, and taken her choreography and workshops to parks and public housing developments. Stories, the program that opened at BAM Fisher on Thursday, is designed as a container, as she put it, for all that Cora Dance now is.

title: Details at Couture Fashion Week
description: Veiled beanies at Chanel and twisted hair crowns at Valentino.

title: Couture Tries to Find Its Place in the Real World
description: PARIS  Sometimes it seems as if the first month of the new year is one giant runway show  and thats before you even get to the official collections.

title: Work in Progress, Stormy and Insistent
description: Its tempting to want to watch Savages from a distance. As a unit, this London band works on a grand scale, making a post-punk squall thats streamlined but not skeletal. From its earliest shows, its been adept at filling a space with a sound thats imposing, urgent and mildly gloomy.

title: The Top 10 Moments from Spring/Summer 2015 Couture Week
description: From the fashion to the haute joaillerie to the off-the-runway star sightings, these were some of the seasons most memorable moments.

title: Welcoming the Dark Twist in Her Career
description: LONDON  In retrospect, Paula Hawkins realizes that sending her half-finished thriller to publishers before shed written the crucial, explosive final scenes might seem like a brazen act of overconfidence. At the time, though, she badly needed the money.

title: Uber Pledges to Improve Data Privacy Practices
description: Uber, the popular ride-hailing start-up, on Friday said it would strengthen its data privacy practices, responding to months of criticism that the company had taken a lackadaisical approach to guarding the customer information.

title: Exposures
description: Portraits of young, teenage, brides in Guatemala.

title: Christies Hosts an Online Auction With Some Fresh Names in Fine Jewelry
description: Though Christies is renowned for its antique jewelry offerings, next week the auction house is turning its eye toward new design  the type of pieces favored by the client whod rather submit bids with a click of a mouse than with a paddle. The auction house has tapped Dalia Oberlander, a former Sothebys employee and founder of the fashionable fine jewelry site Latest Revival, to curate a limited-edition, seven-piece collection to be sold exclusively online. The assortment includes Monique Pans diamond pav ring with a fossilized dinosaur bone; Deborah Paganis chandelier earrings with gray and black diamonds; and custom necklaces, earrings and rings by influential brands such as Maiyet, Pamela Love and Completedworks. Each piece also comes with a signed sketch from the designer. Its jewelry that can be passed down through generations and will remain as relevant and fresh in the future as it is now, Oberlander says.

title: Incursion Wasnt a First for a Protester
description: It was an encore performance. The pro-Ukrainian protester who was arrested after climbing onto the stage of the Metropolitan Opera following a performance said on Friday that he had done something similar at a concert at Harvard last year.

title: Survival and Death in a Faraway War
description: Vivid autochromes document how 170,000 West African soldiers took part in World War Is most decisive conflicts.

title: Houthis March Through Yemens Capital
description: Houthi rebels rallied support during a march through Sana, Yemens capital, denouncing the United States.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Ukraine and More  Pictures of the Day

title: A French Comics Festival Reflects
description: The 42nd annual Angoulme comics festival opened with metal detectors, a show devoted to Charlie Hebdo and past front pages of the newspaper all over town.

title: World Champion Uses Bidding to His Advantage in Pro-Am
description: When you have a two-suited hand, it is always tempting to enter the auction. You hope that you will find a fit with partner  even better, a double fit  and win a lot of tricks despite a relatively low combined point-count.

title: For Charlie, a Somber Comics Fest in France
description: ANGOULME, France  The 42nd annual Angoulme comics festival opened Thursday with a few firsts: Metal detectors at the entrance to every venue, and  not unrelated  a prize awarded posthumously to the five cartoonists killed by jihadist gunmen in Paris three weeks ago at the satirical weekly Charlie Hebdo.

title: Jan. 30, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Ukraine, Syria, South Korea and Britain.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Candidate Tracker: Who Is Running for President (or Not)?
Does Censorship Make Us Safer?
description: To the Editor:

title: Appearances Can Be Treasonous
description: The women are young, workplace-glamorous, nearly interchangeable. Beneath black cloche hats pulled so far down that we cant see their eyes, their red-lipsticked mouths are uniform perfection.

title: Preserving a Building
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dangerous State of Americans Savings
description: MORE than half of American households have less than one month of income available in readily accessible savings to use in case of an emergency, a new report from the Pew Charitable Trusts finds.

title: Presidents Can Be So Romantic
description: Valentines-themed getaways are all about romance; Presidents Day weekend tends to be more straightforward. But this year the holidays fall on the same weekend, and hotels around the country are offering packages that celebrate both occasions.

title: The Top 10 Moments From Spring/Summer 2015 Couture Week
description: The spring 2015 womens couture shows wrapped up yesterday in Paris. From the fashion to the haute joaillerie to the off-the-runway star sightings, these were some of the seasons most memorable happenings.

title: A School Crisis? Yes
description: To the Editor:

title: GFI Shareholders Reject CME Merger, Clearing Way for Hostile Bid
description: Shareholders of the GFI Group, a New York brokerage firm, have rejected a planned acquisition by the CME Group, clearing a path for a hostile bid by a rival firm.

title: Prosecutor Drops Toughest Charges in Chicago Stings That Used Fake Drugs
description: In a partial retreat from drug prosecutions that spurred a national debate over possible entrapment and racial profiling, the federal prosecutor in Chicago has dropped the most serious charges against 27 defendants who were caught in so-called stash-house stings.

title: U.S.-Israeli Friction Over the Netanyahu Invitation
description: To the Editor:

title: Judges and Disclosure
description: To the Editor:

title: East End Bread from East End Wheat
description: Farmers are bringing back commercial grain production, with the notion that bread has a distinctive connection to the soil.

title: On the East End of Long Island, Embracing Local Wheat
description: Wines have their Tuscan countryside; cheeses, their hillside caves in southern France. So wouldnt it make sense that bread, too, might hold a connection to the place where the wheat is grown and the dough kneaded? Thats the goal in Amagansett, where farmers and bakers work the bounty of the land, encouraged by the idea of terroir: that the soil and the elements combine to create a distinct flavor bound to place.

title: Spy vs. Nonspy in Putins Russia
description: Earlier this week, F.B.I. agents in New York arrested a 39-year-old Russian man named Evgeny Buryakov, whom federal prosecutors accused of participating in a spy ring gathering economic intelligence on the United States. There were three spies in all, according to the criminal complaint federal prosecutors filed on Monday, all agents of the Russian Foreign Intelligence Service (S.V.R.), who had been posing for several years as civilians. Buryakov worked at the New York branch of the Russian state-owned Vnesheconombank; his suspected accomplices worked as a Russian trade representative and diplomatic attach.

title: Lowcountry Cooking Travels North
description: Who says you have to grow up with grits to love them  or to cook them? Sarah Gresko, raised in New Jersey, absorbed enough traditional Lowcountry cooking while working in restaurants in Charleston, S.C., that she got the itch to sell some grits in Hopewell, at SweetGrass, her first restaurant as owner and chef.

title: Federal Construction Projects Must Plan for Flood Risks From Climate Change
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Friday continued to push his aggressive climate change agenda, signing an executive order requiring that all federally funded construction projects take into account the flood risks linked to global warming.

title: U.N. Rights Chief Says Hell Shine a Light on Countries Big and Small
description: GENEVA  IN a 20-year career at the United Nations, Prince Zeid Raad Zeid al-Hussein has had more than a few opportunities to witness the human capacity for cruelty, but nothing seared his memory quite like two scenes from the Balkan wars of the 1990s.

title: Holding Soccer Drive and Devotion to a Certain Standard
description: Its encouraging to witness first-hand how soccer is taking off in the United States. According to a recent survey, youth soccer participation rates increased roughly 300 percent from 1974 to 2014. During my current off-season, I have conducted a number of clinics for some of these youth players. Typically, a club will invite me in for a day, and I work with boys and (mostly) girls on and off the field. Ages and ability levels vary greatly, but I am always astounded and moved by the level of enthusiasm and eagerness I see in the players.

title: Chinese Agency Softens Criticism of Alibaba on Sales of Fake Goods
description: It was only two days ago that a Chinese government regulator chastised the Alibaba Group, the e-commerce giant, for failing to curb the sale of fake goods on its sites.

title: I See Very Serious Dead People
description: In the long run, of course, when were all dead.

title: Friday Night Music: Carolina Chocolate Drops, Up In The Air
description: I spent 12 days tromping around Asia, so of course I found myself listening to a lot of Americana  Civil Wars (sigh), Sarah Jarosz, and Carolina Chocolate Drops. Im not sure exactly why youd want them playing in a gondola, but never mind  still great.

title: When a Rivalry Was Young, Maria Sharapova Held Her Own
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  As strange as it might seem considering their lifetime head-to-head results, Maria Sharapova had a winning record against Serena Williams until their burgeoning rivalry shifted to Australia.

title: Oil Prices Surge 8% After Long Slide Down
description: HOUSTON  Oil prices suddenly spiked more than 8 percent on Friday, in the biggest one-day price move for the volatile commodity in nearly three years. But most energy experts said it was too soon to say whether any meaningful shift was underway.

title: Nevada: Soccer Stadium Foes Petition Drive Rejected
description: A petition drive for a referendum on using public money to help pay for construction of a soccer stadium in downtown Las Vegas did not gather enough valid signatures, Clark County officials said Friday. Opponents of the stadium subsidy submitted more than 9,800 signatures to the county Elections Department. After randomly sampling 500 signatures, elections officials said that only 6,966 were valid, less than the 8,258 they say are required to put the question on the June 2 ballot. Opponents say the state Constitution requires only 2,306 signatures, and have asked a district court judge to order the county to accept fewer signatures. A hearing is scheduled on Feb. 10.

title: Odd Photo Choice for Venezuela Promotional Effort
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Not long ago, Jim Wyss, a South America correspondent for The Miami Herald, was detained by Venezuelan authorities for 48 hours and questioned by military intelligence. This week, he briefly became a poster boy for Venezuelan national pride.

title: Trinity Guardrail Test
description: A sequence from video footage of the eighth crash test of a Trinitys ET-Plus guardrail, which shows a car colliding with a guardrail.

title: For Tourists Seeking Drugs, an Experience Thats Less Than Authentic
description: P. T. Barnum declared over 100 years ago that there is one born every minute. But where, when they grow up to become adults who visit New York, do they go to buy cocaine?

title: Pilots Union Approves Contract With Airline
description: American Airlines pilots approved a new five-year contract with the airline, clearing a big internal hurdle toward integrating operations from the merger of American Airlines and US Airways.

title: Assessment of Guardrails May Hinge on Final Crash Test
description: As a debate swirls over whether a widely used guardrail system is safe, more than 30 states have been waiting for the results of crash tests before deciding whether to continue to use the guardrails or, possibly, have them removed.

title: Venezuela: Military Says It Downed Plane Near Aruba
description: Venezuelas defense minister said Friday that Venezuelan military aircraft had shot down a small plane that crashed a day earlier in the waters near the island of Aruba. Officials in Aruba said Thursday that the plane had gone down after being pursued by Venezuelan jets, but it was not immediately known if they had fired on it. The Venezuelan defense minister, Vladimir Padrino, said that the plane had taken off from the southern state of Apure, which is a regular loading point for drug flights. Our aircraft intercepted and it did not follow orders and, well, it was disabled, he said, adding that the encounter took place over Venezuelas territorial waters. The Aruban authorities said that the craft crashed in waters belonging to the island, which lies just off Venezuelas coast. Officials in Aruba said that body parts and about 400 packages that appeared to contain drugs were found in the wreckage. A Justice Ministry official in Aruba said Friday that the plane was registered in the United States.

title: Speck of Interstellar Dust Obscures Glimpse of Big Bang
description: Scientists will have to wait a while longer to find out what kicked off the Big Bang.

title: Newcomers Buy Ad Time at the Super Bowl
description: About a month after advertising on television for the first time, the makers of the free mobile game Heroes Charge decided at the last minute that they wanted to make a much bigger splash: a commercial during televisions biggest advertising event, the Super Bowl.

title: Slipping Into Darkness in South Africa
description: The Kafkaesque existence that millions of people suffered through under South Africas apartheid laws is rendered with powerful simplicity in Sizwe Banzi Is Dead.

title: Oswalds Coffin Belongs to His Brother, Not Funeral Home, a Judge Rules
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The wood coffin that held the body of Lee Harvey Oswald belongs to his brother and not a Fort Worth funeral home that sought to sell it for more than $87,000, a Texas judge ruled Friday.

title: Bernice Gordon, Crossword Creator for The Times, Dies at 101
description: Bernice Gordon, a self-described              who over the last six decades contributed some 150 crossword puzzles to The New York Times, died on Thursday at her home in Philadelphia. She was 101.

title: Vague Job Outline Leads to Defining Role With Seahawks
description: PHOENIX  Rocky Seto is the Seattle Seahawks defensive passing game coordinator.

title: Buyers of Used Cars Are Left to Find Recalls on Their Own
description: Buying a used car in the United States can be a dangerous proposition  if the vehicle has an unadvertised safety defect.

title: Canada Seeks to Strengthen Spy Agency After Attacks
description: OTTAWA  Citing the attacks by radical Islamists that killed two Canadian soldiers in October and the more recent assaults in France, Prime Minister Stephen Harper introduced sweeping legislation on Friday that would greatly expand the role of Canadas spy service, allowing courts to remove online postings and increasing police detention powers.

title: A Strained Alliance: Obama-Netanyahu Rift Grew Over Years
description: WASHINGTON  For six years, the pattern has been the same. A dispute between American and Israeli leaders spills out into the open. Analysts declare the relationship in crisis. Then the two sides try to tamp down emotions and argue that the rupture is not as dire as it looks.

title: Japanese Comfort Food in the Wee Hours
description: In a neighborhood teeming with Japanese food offerings, Ichibantei has its own niche.

title: Vaccine Critics Turn Defensive Over Measles
description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, Calif.  Their children have been sent home from school. Their families are barred from birthday parties and neighborhood play dates. Online, people call them negligent and criminal. And as officials in 14 states grapple to contain a spreading measles outbreak that began near here at Disneyland, the parents at the heart of Americas anti-vaccine movement are being blamed for incubating an otherwise preventable public-health crisis.

title: Judge Rules for Warner Bros. in Dispute Over Gravity
description: LOS ANGELES  While viewers work through this years Oscar films, a court here is still working its way through one of last years nominees, Gravity. On Friday, Judge Margaret M. Morrow of the United States District Court for the Central District of California in Los Angeles dismissed a complaint by the author Tess Gerritsen, who had claimed that Warner Bros. breached a contract with her when it made Gravity without giving her credit or 2.5 percent of the films net profit.

title: Mitt Quits. Again. Probably.
description: Mitt Romney is out! And we hardly had time to adjust to the idea that he was in.

title: A Fading Titan, Cheered On With Pity
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Watching Tiger Woods launch wildly errant drives was hard. Watching his ground-ball chip shots was harder. But the hardest part of watching Woodss career-worst round Friday at the Phoenix Open was seeing the greatest golfer of his generation turn into the lovable last-place straggler.

title: Rematch in the Final, but Only the Names Are the Same
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Once more, it will be Novak Djokovic versus Andy Murray with the Norman Brookes Challenge Cup and the Australian Open title at stake.

title: Was Abolitionism a Failure?
description: ON Jan. 31, 1865, Congress passed the 13th Amendment, banning slavery in America. It was an achievement that abolitionists had spent decades fighting for  and one for which their movement has been lauded ever since.

title: Loyalist Forsakes Gandhis Fraying Party
description: NEW DELHI  A longtime and prominent loyalist of the Indian National Congress party publicly broke with the partys president, Sonia Gandhi, and her son, Rahul, on Friday. The loyalist accused the Gandhis of interfering with her decisions when she was environment minister, forcing her to resign without explanation, then making her a scapegoat for their governments failings.

title: A Hearty Visit to Germany
description: I must have passed Jennifers Restaurant hundreds of times over the years. Set on a remote stretch along the Croton Reservoir, the modest roadside German restaurant has been operating  with a brief interlude in the 90s (and with one other name)  since 1979.

title: Store Steps Onto New Turf To Aid 2 Officers Families
description: The Super Bowl is familiar territory for Modells Sporting Goods, the New York retail institution: Every year, racks at almost all of its locations hang heavy with N.F.L. T-shirts and jerseys, and this year is no exception  Modells stores are crowded with clothing displaying loyalty to the New England Patriots, the Seattle Seahawks or simply the game itself.

title: Near Collision in the Skies Is Recounted by Passengers
description: To her left, Kay Germano noticed a small silvery speck hurtling toward her airplane. Maybe it was a bird, she thought, lost in the clouds. She paid it no heed.

title: Higher Pay for New York Citys Managers
description: Last year, Mayor Bill de Blasio made good on a pledge to raise the pay of tens of thousands of unionized New York City employees, granting higher wages to teachers, nurses and other rank-and-file workers who had gone without contracts for years.

title: Give It a Go
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  This is the kind of crossword puzzle that has enough verbalization clues and entries that I could almost write todays entire blog post in all cap answers. Ill leave that fun to the commenters.

title: Yves Chauvin, Green Chemist and Nobel Laureate, Dies at 84
description: Yves Chauvin, who shared the 2005 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for deciphering a green chemistry reaction now used to make pharmaceuticals and plastics more efficiently while generating less hazardous waste, died on Tuesday in Tours, France. He was 84.

title: The Bahamas Tightens Immigration
description: Raids on places where Haitians live have swept up hundreds of people since a new policy took effect, requiring everyone to hold a passport.

title: Immigration Rules in Bahamas Sweep Up Haitians
description: NASSAU, Bahamas  Kenson Timothee was walking down the street when a uniformed officer asked him a question that sends Bahamians of Haitian descent like him into a panic these days: Do you have a passport?

title: Wadsworth Atheneums New Spaces for Contemporary Art
description: In 1844, the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Arts inaugural exhibition included Thomas Coles Mt. Etna From Taormina, completed the year before. Two years later, the fledgling institution purchased Frederic Edwin Churchs first painting, the brand-new Hooker and Company Journeying Through the Wilderness From Plymouth to Hartford, in 1636.

title: Service Restored, but Still No Empty Seats
description: Aude Back de Surany, center, of France, was among the C train passengers in Manhattan on Friday after uptown service on the line was restored. Early in the morning, a power failure at Chambers Street cause a brief halt in uptown service on the A, C and E lines.

title: A Call to Raise Tipped Workers Wages in New York
description: A New York State board on Friday recommended an increase in the hourly wage for tipped workers like restaurant servers, proposing a rate of $7.50 an hour before gratuities. The current wage, which has not increased since 2011, is $5.

title: Chinas Self-Destructive Tech Crackdown
description: Under the guise of improving security, the Chinese government is clamping down on technology companies and further limiting the access its citizens have to information that is not sanitized by the Communist Party. These moves will hurt the Chinese economy and create a major rift between China and the rest of the world.

title: With Oil Revenue Dropping, Mexico Announces Budget Cuts
description: MEXICO CITY  Faced with declining prices for its oil exports, Mexicos government announced $8.3 billion in budget cuts, slashing the budget of the state oil company. It also effectively canceled a bullet train project at the center of a conflict-of-interest scandal that has weakened Enrique Pea Nietos presidency.

title: Rooting Out Brutality at Rikers Island
description: New York Citys correction commissioner did the right thing this month when he fired a captain and five guards who tied up and savagely beat an inmate at the Rikers Island jail complex in the spring of 2012. But the fact that it took nearly three years to dismiss the officers reveals  again  a disciplinary process badly in need of repair. It also underscores the need for the full-scale reforms that the Justice Department is seeking in federal court.

title: New Yorks Real Scandal
description: Editors' Note:

title: Civil War Mural, Obscured for Decades, Resurfaces on a Shelf
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  A historic Civil War mural that bounced, mislabeled, from museum to museum for several decades has emerged from storage, its identity reclaimed. But because of its size, its owners are still pondering where it can be displayed.

title: Survivors of 1998 U.S. Embassy Bombings Can Testify in Trial, Judge Rules
description: In terrorism trials in Manhattan in recent years, perhaps no testimony has been as riveting as that offered by the survivors of the 1998 bombings by Al Qaeda of the United States embassies in Nairobi, Kenya, and Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, which killed 224 people and wounded thousands.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 30, 2015
New York to Pay $3.9 Million to End Suit Over Police Killing of Teenager
description: The family of a Bronx teenager who was fatally shot by a police officer who had barged into his apartment after suspecting him of taking part in a drug deal has agreed to settle a wrongful-death lawsuit against the city for $3.9 million.

title: With Eye on Harvard, Basketball Player Has 2 Careers on His Mind
description: On a family trip to Boston two years ago, the former Jets linebacker Mo Lewis and his son Chris toured the Massachusetts Institute of Technologys campus. Chris Lewis, a ninth-grader at the time, had already received basketball scholarship offers from Memphis and New Mexico. Still, he had always dreamed of becoming an engineer, and few colleges had a better engineering program than M.I.T.

title: Charlie Williams, a Met Traded for Mays, Dies at 67
description: Charlie Williams, a pitcher best known as the trade bait the Mets used to land Willie Mays in the twilight of his career, died on Tuesday in Daytona Beach, Fla. He was 67.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 31, 2015
description: I said, Id rather you miss an entire semester than you get the shot.

title: Craig Ramini, Whose Heart Led to Buffalo Mozzarella, Dies at 57
description: Craig Ramini, a 52-year-old Silicon Valley software consultant at the time, didnt know his curds from his wheys or a bison from a paesan (and maybe even whether buffaloes had wings or originated in western New York) when he confronted a midlife crisis early in 2009.

title: Edward J. Saylor, 94, Dies; Took Fight to Japan With Doolittle Raiders
description: SEATTLE  Edward J. Saylor, one of the last surviving members of the Doolittle Raiders, a band of World War II airmen who bombed Japan in early 1942, stunning the Japanese at a time when their army and navy were racking up victories across Asia, died on Wednesday at his home near here. He was 94.

title: A Mere 112 Million? The Super Bowls Audience Is Tough to Gauge
description: The Super Bowl may sometimes disappoint as a competitive game, but never as an audience grabber. Witness Seattles 43-8 drubbing of Denver last year. Despite being a blowout, it was the fourth straight Super Bowl to draw 100 million viewers, generating a record 112.8 million.

title: Stig Bergling, a Cold War Spy Known for His Escape, Dies at 77
description: Stig Bergling, one of Swedens most notorious Cold War spies, who in 1987 escaped from prison during a conjugal visit, died on Jan. 24 in Stockholm. He was 77.

title: Love, the Other Letdown
description: Blizzards  or feared blizzards, like this weeks storm  tear us from our daily lives. In that, they are like love. They also tend to be fickle, blowing in quickly and dissipating just as fast. These poems about Monday evenings storm and its relationship to romance (or the lack thereof) were found in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings.

title: Bobby Shmurda Posts $2 Million Bail
description: Bobby Shmurda, the spark-plug Brooklyn rapper, has posted $2 million bail after spending more than six weeks in jail on gun and drug charges related to allegations of a gang conspiracy, his lawyer said on Friday.

title: Whats on TV Saturday
description: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) BAD WORDS (2014) Guy Trilby (Jason Bateman, who also directed), a 40-year-old bully who has wormed his way onto the spelling-bee circuit, mows down the small-fry competition with one expletive after another until he reaches the nationals. And then he encounters Chaitanya Chopra (Rohan Chand), a socially awkward 10-year-old sorely in need of a friend. It would be something to see Mr. Bateman go authentically dark (perhaps not that dark), but its also enough just to watch him as he widens his eyes, furrows his brow and shows off his excellent timing, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Its a fluid feature-directing debut, and he pulls the ensemble together smoothly, she added. The performances are funny, appealing and, in the case of Allison Janney, as a spelling bee official, wonderful. A dowdied-down Kathryn Hahn has it tougher as Jenny, a reporter whos chasing Guy for his story and occasional sex. Its a pathetic role, largely because shes a sad piata made for the whacking simply because, it seems, the only thing worse than making kids cry is being a journalist.

title: Corrections: January 31, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Serena Williams Wins Australian Open With Coughs, Guts and Aces
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  The record still shows that Maria Sharapova is a pushover for Serena Williams: her muse, her matchup made in tennis heaven.

title: Super Bowls Are Getting More Interesting
description: Any football fans old enough to remember the 1980s are old enough to remember the idea that Super Bowls were lousy football games. Blowouts were the norm for much of the 1980s and 1990s, with scores like 38-9, 46-10, 55-10 and 52-17.

title: Shots Fired at Kabul Protest Against French Newspaper
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Gunfire erupted on Saturday at a demonstration in Kabul where several hundred people had gathered to protest the publication of cartoons depicting the Prophet Muhammad in the satirical French newspaper Charlie Hebdo, witnesses said.

title: Andrew Filev of Wrike: Check Your Ego at the Door
description: This interview with Andrew Filev, chief executive of Wrike, a provider of project management software, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Two Judges Who Get It About Banks
description: Big banks hold great sway in Washington these days, far more than troubled homeowners do. But outside the Beltway, many people remain caught in the maw of the financial giants, which is why it is heartening when some judges step into the fray.

title: A Focus on Fitness, and a Passion for the Packers
description: Hoyt Harper is senior vice president and global brand leader of Sheraton Hotels and Resorts Group in Stamford, Conn.

title: The Case of the Disappearing Diamond Ring
description: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

title: Few Smiles for These Cameras
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: G.O.P. Campaigns Scramble to Add Romney Donors
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey and former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida plunged into all-out battle this weekend for the biggest unclaimed prize in American politics and the decisive advantage that could go with it: the billion-dollar donor network once harnessed by Mitt Romney.

title: Climate Changes Bottom Line
description: It was 8 degrees in Minneapolis on a recent January day, and out on Interstate 394, snow whipped against the windshields of drivers on their morning commutes. But inside the offices of Cargill, the food conglomerate, Greg Page, the companys executive chairman, felt compelled to talk about global warming.

title: Cunard Ships Will Travel Back in Time
description: Cunard, the British cruise line, made its inaugural trans-Atlantic voyage in the summer of 1840, ferrying passengers from Liverpool, England, to Boston aboard the Britannia, the first ship the company built for its first fleet, all paddleboat steamers. This summer, in honor of its 175th anniversary, Cunard plans to recreate that original voyage, but this time on the Queen Mary 2, one of its modern ocean liners.

title: The Vaccine Lunacy
description: A FEW years back, an acerbic friend of mine who was a recent transplant to Los Angeles told me that she itched to write a satirical novel with the following narrative:

title: Papers Fuel a 7-Alarm Fire at a Warehouse in Brooklyn
description: A seven-alarm fire engulfed a warehouse crammed with official documents near the waterfront in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on Saturday morning, sending plumes of brown, acrid smoke into the air that were visible as far away as New Jersey.

title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Daniel Raymon is well known to New York Times solvers as a crossword puzzle constructor and has had four cryptic crosswords published here as well.

title: Cars With Faulty Airbags Are Recalled Second Time, but Fix May Take a Year
description: Toyota, Chrysler and Honda are recalling about 2.1 million vehicles with airbags that might suddenly deploy even when the vehicle is not in a crash after earlier recalls did not sufficiently address the problem. Federal regulators said replacement parts might not be fully available until the end of the year.

title: Fire on Williamsburg Waterfront
description: The seven-alarm fire on North 11th Street began on Saturday morning.

title: White House Seeks to Limit Health Laws Tax Troubles
description: WASHINGTON  Obama administration officials and other supporters of the Affordable Care Act say they worry that the tax-filing season will generate new anger as uninsured consumers learn that they must pay tax penalties and as many people struggle with complex forms needed to justify tax credits they received in 2014 to pay for health insurance.

title: An Expressive, Propulsive Voice
description: The Miller Theaters Composer Portraits series has long been an invaluable new-music series, offering a carefully curated anthology of works by a single author that allows audiences to immerse themselves in one compositional voice.

title: Do-It-Yourself Mining in Eastern Ukraine
description: The rebel government has lifted a ban on private coal mining, a widespread practice in the financially struggling region.

title: A Silver Lining Coated in Coal Dust in Eastern Ukraine
description: SNIZHNE, Ukraine  Outside Vladimir Morozs snug little brick home, winter and hardship grip war-stricken eastern Ukraine. Money is scarce, the store shelves are bare and an icy wind whips over the snowy steppe.

title: Losing Mobility and Gaining a Work Life
description: I always cringe a little when I hear people say that affirmative action doesnt work or isnt fair. Thats because I know I wouldnt be where I am today without it. I also know that very few people see the issue from the same perspective that I do.

title: Bad Tayloring
description: Since they arent currently able to demand a return to the gold standard  and maybe a ban on paper money?  Republicans are pushing to mandate that the Fed follow the so-called Taylor rule, which relates short-term interest rates to unemployment (and/or the output gap) and inflation. John Taylor, not surprisingly, likes this idea. But its a really terrible idea, and not just for the reasons Tony Yates describes.

title: Blue Dot for Obama Prompts Red Nebraska to Revisit Electoral College Rules
description: LINCOLN, Neb.  If this state had an official color, it would most certainly be red. Football fans here don scarlet sweatshirts each game day, red meat is a dietary staple and, for decades, Republican presidential candidates filled Nebraskas borders on the electoral map with their partys hue.

title: The Voice Mail Oracle Speaks (Silly)
description: Princeton has Microsoft speech recognition on its voice mail; Ive used Google for other purposes. The Google versions tend to be funny but decipherable; the Microsoft versions, well.

title: Carl Djerassi, 91, a Creator of the Birth Control Pill, Dies
description: Carl Djerassi, an eminent chemist who 63 years ago synthesized a hormone that changed the world by creating the key ingredient for the oral contraceptive known as the pill, died on Friday at his home in San Francisco. He was 91.

title: Bait and Switch, a Common Ploy of Patriots and Seahawks
description: The Patriots and the Seahawks share a knack for the trick play. They make it look like something that the defense recognizes, but it is something entirely different.

title: Italy Elects President, While Mulling a Change in Role
description: ROME  Italian lawmakers on Saturday elected Sergio Mattarella, a veteran politician and constitutional court judge, as the countrys president, a post that is expected to be redefined during his tenure.

title: Thousands March in Spain to Support Left-Wing Party
description: MADRID  At least 100,000 supporters of Podemos, the left-wing party that is threatening to overhaul Spains bipartisan party system, marched in downtown Madrid on Saturday in a show of force at the beginning of a busy year of elections.

title: At Age XLIX, Super Bowl Has No Sense of Place
description: PHOENIX  Most of what makes the setting of this Super Bowl different from all the rest is a climbing wall meant to evoke the Grand Canyon. In a downtown parking lot, visible from the raised set of the N.F.L. Network and near a giant light-up cutout of letters reading XLIX, the wall, made of fake rock, has an enormous video screen in the middle that plays commercials.

title: Sampling From Musics Buffet to Find New Arenas
description: With their second act as a band, the members of Fall Out Boy have pulled off what once seemed at least highly unlikely: not only outlasting their emo peers from the early aughts but also transcending them all the way to the top of the Billboard charts  and with real guitars, too, a rare sound on pop radio today. After a five-year hiatus, the band returned in 2013 with Save Rock and Roll, a typically irreverent album that made its debut at No. 1; now, its new single, Centuries, is hovering in the Top 20 and scoring sporting events on TVs and in stadiums across the country.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: Young Talent, Taking New Steps
description: Since its founding in 1959, Nederlands Dans Theater has been remarkably venturesome, assembling an impressive contemporary repertory. In 1978, it established Nederlands Dans Theater 2 (NDT2, for short) for dancers between 17 and 22 years old. More than a training ground, NDT2 has a distinct repertory, several pieces from which will be shown in its first season here in five years, including some unusual examples of collaborative choreography. Paul Lightfoot, NDT2s director, and Sol Len, its artistic adviser, teamed up for the highly emotional Subject to Change and the eccentric Shutters Shut, which unites choreographic play with wordplay as dancers interpret a poem by Gertrude Stein. Working together, the Israeli choreographers Sharon Eyal and Gai Behar created Sara, an exploration of memories and dreams.

title: Folk Works Known as Fraktur
description: The Pennsylvania Germans produced the handsome ceramics known as redware and vibrantly painted furniture. They also made lavishly embellished documents called fraktur, 200 outstanding examples of which are in Drawn With Spirit: Pennsylvania German Fraktur From the Joan and Victor Johnson Collection opening on Sunday at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

title: Promethean Fire, Smoldering Still
description: The great fires in American history are generally identified with a city or a building: Chicago in 1871, Boston in 1872, the Iroquois Theater in 1903, the Triangle shirtwaist factory in 1911. But a wildfire in August 1910 in the northern Rockies dwarfed all of those in geographic scope. An episode of American Experience on Tuesday on PBS that examines that blaze borrows one of its nicknames for its title: The Big Burn.

title: Back in Town With Tricky Tunes
description: A composer doesnt necessarily mean a songwriter, especially in jazz. Guillermo Klein, originally from Argentina, who has written brilliantly for his jazz groups in New York and Barcelona since the mid-90s, never made a distinction. He creates pieces full of tricky counterpoint and canon, but he also writes emotionally direct, harmonically complex, circular songs to be sung by himself and others, including Liliana Herrero and Luciana Souza.

title: Its Safe to Look Back
description: Its amazing what you can do with ingenuity, a microbudget, a butcher knife and a Captain Kirk mask. Take Halloween, John Carpenters 1978 classic, which unleashed the killer Michael Myers (not to mention Jamie Lee Curtis) on the world. John Carpenter: Master of Fear, a Brooklyn Academy of Music retrospective Thursday through Feb. 22, offers Halloween on Friday; other screenings include Mr. Carpenters tribute to Hong Kong cinema, Big Trouble in Little China (1986); his remake of The Thing (1982); and his Reagan-era parable They Live (1988).

title: After Many Milestones, Karrie Webb Returns to Where It All Began
description: OCALA, Fla.  Karrie Webb said she was caught by surprise last week when she arrived at the Golden Ocala Golf and Equestrian Club for the L.P.G.A.s 2015 season opener and realized she had come full circle.

title: Richard von Weizscker, 94, Dies: First President of Reunited Germany
description: Richard von Weizscker, the patrician first president of the reunited Germany and a guardian of his nations moral conscience, has died, the presidents office in Berlin announced on Saturday. He was 94.

title: Closing the Math Gap for Boys
description: ON a recent afternoon, the banter of boisterous adolescents at Edwin G. Foreman High School, in a poor, racially and ethnically mixed Chicago neighborhood, echoed off the corridor walls. But Room 214 was as silent as a meditation retreat. Inside, 16 ninth- and 10th-grade African-American and Latino boys were working, two-on-one, with a tutor. Theyre among 1,326 boys in 12 public schools in this city who are sweating over math for an hour every day.

title: Louisiana Squeezed as Oil Prices Drop
description: CUT OFF, La.  The first thing you hear is, Can you cut 10 percent? explained Jimmy Lafont, whose towboat operation is one of the countless oil-field service companies spread across south Louisiana. Cajuns normally have a habit of cutting the price quick like.

title: Armenia and Azerbaijan Clash With Increasing Ferocity Over Disputed Land
description: An armed conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan over the territory of Nagorno-Karabakh has escalated with deadly consequences in recent months.

title: Australian Open Intent on Leading the World in Pampering Players
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  For decades, professional tennis players struggled with tournament organizers to get more money and better services, and while that battle is far from over, the level of player pampering at the Australian Open suggests a historic victory.

title: The Only Baby Book Youll Ever Need
description: SOUTH PORTLAND, Me.  LIKE many parents, I have a particular book I like to give to friends when they announce theyre pregnant for the first time. It is the book I read early in my wifes pregnancy, blurting out passages about everything from birth, baby minding and child rearing to education, work and discipline. But you probably wont find it in the baby section of your local bookstore. The Anthropology of Childhood: Cherubs, Chattel, Changelings, by David F. Lancy, is an academic title  but its possibly the only book that new parents will ever need.

title: Clashes Intensify Between Armenia and Azerbaijan Over Disputed Land
description: AGDAM, Azerbaijan  Overshadowed by the fighting in Ukraine, another armed conflict in the former Soviet Union  between Armenia and Azerbaijan over the territory of Nagorno-Karabakh  has escalated with deadly ferocity in recent months, killing dozens of soldiers on each side and pushing the countries perilously close to open war.

title: Dying Shouldnt Be So Brutal
description: Travel safe! It has become a nearly reflexive wish I give to friends who are coming or going. This fall, I noticed myself holding back from saying it to Michael, a dear friend who was wrestling with incurable cancer. The journey metaphor was too poignant.

title: Michel Nischan
description: Michel Nischan is a two-time James Beard Award-winning chef who co-founded and now runs Wholesome Wave, a nonprofit sustainable food advocacy group that has forged partnerships with health care providers nationwide to prescribe and make farm-fresh produce available in low-income communities.

title: Heroes and Bystanders
description: ONE of the great heroes of the 20th century was Auschwitz prisoner No. 4859, who volunteered to be there.

title: Our Loud, Proud Left
description: FOR the last week, liberal journalists have been furiously debating whether a new political correctness has swept over the American left. The instigator of this argument was New York magazines Jonathan Chait, normally a scourge of Republicans, whose essay on what he dubbed the new P.C. critiqued left-wing activists for their zeal to play language cop, shout down arguments and shut down debate outright.

title: Forty Years of Servitude, and Counting
description: An enduring injustice was supposed to end on Jan. 1. That was the effective date for new rules by the Labor Department that would have required employers of home care aides for the elderly and disabled to pay at least the federal minimum wage and time and a half for overtime. Specifically, the new rules would have ended a federal regulation from 1974 that labeled home care aides companions, a designation that lets their employers  generally, for-profit agencies  ignore basic labor protections.

title: Questions in the Church
description: Readers share experiences of divorce, and discuss the stand against birth control.

title: Fighting Racial Isolation in Hartford
description: The fact that New York has the most segregated public schools in the nation does not bode well for the states future. It is a disaster for poor and minority children, who are disproportionately trapped in schools that will not prepare them for the new economy. And it is harming children of all races and economic levels who are in demographically homogeneous schools that do not reflect society or expose them to fresh perspectives.

title: Mitts White Horse Pulls Up Lame
description: SALT LAKE CITY  WHEN the Mitt Romney documentary premiered here at the Sundance Film Festival last year, one member of the audience was especially charmed by the candidate up on the screen.

title: Retroactively Authorizing War
description: They went largely unnoticed, four words President Obama ad-libbed during the State of the Union address last month as he asked lawmakers to provide legal cover for Americas military intervention in Iraq and Syria.

title: Flexing to Embrace a Flip Side
description: A few weeks ago, Jay Donn, a pioneer of the Brooklyn street-dance form known as flex, was stopped by police officers in a subway station. This wasnt part of the crackdown on dancing in trains: The police were concerned about the wires protruding from the bags he carried. What the officers found inside must have surprised them. This heavily tattooed dancer was transporting tutus.

title: Whitney Houstons Daughter Found Unresponsive in Tub
description: The daughter of the singer Whitney Houston was found unresponsive in a bathtub at her home outside Atlanta on Saturday morning and taken to a hospital, officials said.

title: Politics Is Personal, and Professional
description: Lisa Batiashvili, the 35-year-old Georgian violinist who is this seasons artist in residence with the New York Philharmonic and will perform Barbers Violin Concerto with that orchestra this week, is an eloquent musician. In concert and on award-winning recordings, she has captivated critics and audiences with her natural elegance, silky sound and the meticulous grace of her articulation. There is a laserlike directness to her playing that enables her to transmit concentrated emotions without a trace of affectation or theatrics: the musical equivalent to laparoscopic surgery.

title: Ukraine Fighting Continues as Talks Stall
description: ARTEMOVSK, Ukraine  Envoys representing Ukraine, Russia and a European monitoring group opened a new round of cease-fire talks on Saturday aimed at ending a two-week-old flare-up in violence in the Ukraine war.

title: What Were Watching: Sunday Shows
description: Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate in 2012, ended speculation of a third bid for the White House on Friday, but other 2016 Republican hopefuls are still gearing up for a long campaign season. Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin will appear on ABCs This Week, and Mike Huckabee, the former governor of Arkansas, will be on CNNs State of the Union.
